
       
Dealings
with
the
Firm
of
Dombey
and
Son
:
Wholesale
,
Retail
and
for
Exportation
Dombey
and
Son
 
Charles
Dickens
  
1846
-
<EOS>
-1848
  
Information
about
the
source
     
Chapter
1
.
<EOS>
Dombey
and
Son
 
DOMBEY
sat
in
the
corner
of
the
darkened
room
in
the
great
arm
-
chair
by
the
bedside
,
and
Son
lay
tucked
up
warm
in
a
little
basket
bedstead
,
carefully
disposed
on
a
low
settee
immediately
in
front
of
the
fire
and
close
to
it
,
as
if
his
constitution
were
analogous
to
that
of
a
muffin
,
and
it
was
essential
to
toast
him
brown
while
he
was
very
new
.
  
<EOS>
Dombey
was
about
eight
-
and
-
forty
years
of
age
.
<EOS>
Son
about
eight
-
and
-
forty
minutes
.
<EOS>
Dombey
was
rather
bald
,
rather
red
,
and
though
a
handsome
well
-
made
man
,
too
stern
and
pompous
in
appearance
,
to
be
prepossessing
.
<EOS>
Son
was
very
bald
,
and
very
red
,
and
though
(
of
course
)
an
undeniably
fine
infant
,
somewhat
crushed
and
spotty
in
his
general
effect
,
as
yet
.
<EOS>
On
the
brow
of
Dombey
,
Time
and
his
brother
Care
had
set
some
marks
,
as
on
a
tree
that
was
to
come
down
in
good
time
---
remorseless
twins
they
are
for
striding
through
their
human
forests
,
<EOS>
notching
as
they
go
---
while
the
countenance
of
Son
was
crossed
and
recrossed
with
a
thousand
little
creases
,
which
the
same
deceitful
Time
would
take
delight
in
smoothing
out
and
wearing
away
with
the
flat
part
of
his
scythe
,
as
a
preparation
of
the
surface
for
his
deeper
operations
.
  
<EOS>
Dombey
,
exulting
in
the
long
-
looked
-
for
event
,
jingled
and
jingled
the
heavy
gold
watch
-
chain
that
depended
from
below
his
trim
blue
coat
,
whereof
the
buttons
sparkled
phosphorescently
in
the
feeble
rays
of
the
distant
fire
.
<EOS>
Son
,
with
his
little
fists
curled
up
and
clenched
,
seemed
,
in
his
feeble
way
,
to
be
squaring
at
existence
for
having
come
upon
him
so
unexpectedly
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
house
will
once
again
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
be
not
only
in
name
but
in
fact
Dombey
and
Son
;
Dom
-
bey
and
Son
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
words
had
such
a
softening
influence
,
that
he
appended
a
term
of
endearment
to
Mrs
Dombey
's
name
(
though
not
without
some
hesitation
,
as
being
a
man
but
little
used
to
that
form
of
address
)
:
and
said
,
"
Mrs
Dombey
,
my
---
my
dear
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
transient
flush
of
faint
surprise
overspread
the
sick
lady
's
face
as
she
raised
her
eyes
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
will
be
christened
Paul
,
my
---
Mrs
Dombey
---
of
course
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
feebly
echoed
,
"
Of
course
,
"
or
rather
expressed
it
by
the
motion
of
her
lips
,
and
closed
her
eyes
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
His
father
's
name
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
and
his
grandfather
's
!
<EOS>
I
wish
his
grandfather
were
alive
this
day
!
"
<EOS>
And
again
he
said
"
Dom
-
bey
and
Son
,
"
in
exactly
the
same
tone
as
before
.
  
<EOS>
Those
three
words
conveyed
the
one
idea
of
Mr
Dombey
's
life
.
<EOS>
The
earth
was
made
for
Dombey
and
Son
to
trade
in
,
and
the
sun
and
moon
were
made
to
give
them
light
.
<EOS>
Rivers
and
seas
were
formed
to
float
their
ships
;
rainbows
gave
them
promise
of
fair
weather
;
winds
blew
for
or
against
their
enterprises
;
stars
and
planets
circled
in
their
orbits
,
to
preserve
inviolate
a
system
of
which
they
were
the
centre
.
<EOS>
Common
abbreviations
took
new
meanings
in
his
eyes
,
and
had
sole
reference
to
them
:
AD
had
no
concern
with
anno
Domini
,
but
stood
for
anno
Dombei
---
and
Son
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
risen
,
as
his
father
had
before
him
,
in
the
course
of
life
and
death
,
from
Son
to
Dombey
,
and
for
nearly
twenty
years
had
been
the
sole
representative
of
the
firm
.
<EOS>
Of
those
years
he
had
been
married
,
ten
---
married
,
as
some
said
,
to
a
lady
with
no
heart
to
give
him
;
whose
happiness
was
in
the
past
,
and
who
was
content
to
bind
her
broken
spirit
to
the
dutiful
and
meek
endurance
of
the
present
.
<EOS>
Such
idle
talk
was
little
likely
to
reach
the
ears
of
Mr
Dombey
,
whom
it
nearly
concerned
;
and
probably
no
one
in
the
world
would
have
received
it
with
such
utter
incredulity
as
he
,
if
it
had
reached
him
.
<EOS>
Dombey
and
Son
had
often
dealt
in
hides
,
but
never
in
hearts
.
<EOS>
They
left
that
fancy
ware
to
boys
and
girls
,
and
boarding
-
schools
and
books
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
would
have
reasoned
:
That
a
matrimonial
alliance
with
himself
must
,
in
the
nature
of
things
,
be
gratifying
and
honourable
to
any
woman
of
common
sense
.
<EOS>
That
the
hope
of
giving
birth
to
a
new
partner
in
such
a
house
,
could
not
fail
to
awaken
a
glorious
and
stirring
ambition
in
the
breast
of
the
least
ambitious
of
her
sex
.
<EOS>
That
Mrs
Dombey
had
entered
on
that
social
contract
of
matrimony
:
almost
necessarily
part
of
a
genteel
and
wealthy
station
,
even
without
reference
to
the
perpetuation
of
family
firms
:
with
her
eyes
fully
open
to
these
advantages
.
<EOS>
That
Mrs
Dombey
had
had
daily
practical
knowledge
of
his
position
in
society
.
<EOS>
That
Mrs
Dombey
had
always
sat
at
the
head
of
his
table
,
and
done
the
honours
of
his
house
in
a
remarkably
lady
-
like
and
becoming
manner
.
<EOS>
That
Mrs
Dombey
must
have
been
happy
.
<EOS>
That
she
could
n't
help
it
.
  
<EOS>
Or
,
at
all
events
,
with
one
drawback
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
That
he
would
have
allowed
.
<EOS>
With
only
one
;
but
that
one
certainly
involving
much
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
married
ten
years
,
and
until
this
present
day
on
which
Mr
Dombey
sat
jingling
and
jingling
his
heavy
gold
watch
-
chain
in
the
great
arm
-
chair
by
the
side
of
the
bed
,
had
had
no
issue
.
   
<EOS>
---
To
speak
of
;
none
worth
mentioning
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
a
girl
some
six
years
before
,
and
the
child
,
who
had
stolen
into
the
chamber
unobserved
,
was
now
crouching
timidly
,
in
a
corner
whence
she
could
see
her
mother
's
face
.
<EOS>
But
what
was
a
girl
to
Dombey
and
Son
!
<EOS>
In
the
capital
of
the
House
's
name
and
dignity
,
such
a
child
was
merely
a
piece
of
base
coin
that
could
n't
be
invested
---
a
bad
Boy
---
nothing
more
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
cup
of
satisfaction
was
so
full
at
this
moment
,
however
,
that
he
felt
he
could
afford
a
drop
or
two
of
its
contents
,
even
to
sprinkle
on
the
dust
in
the
by
-
path
of
his
little
daughter
.
  
<EOS>
So
he
said
,
"
Florence
,
you
may
go
and
look
at
your
pretty
brother
,
if
you
like
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
touch
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
child
glanced
keenly
at
the
blue
coat
and
stiff
white
cravat
,
which
,
with
a
pair
of
creaking
boots
and
a
very
loud
ticking
watch
,
embodied
her
idea
of
a
father
;
but
her
eyes
returned
to
her
mother
's
face
immediately
,
and
she
neither
moved
nor
answered
.
  
<EOS>
Next
moment
,
the
lady
had
opened
her
eyes
and
seen
the
child
;
and
the
child
had
run
towards
her
;
and
,
standing
on
tip
-
toe
,
the
better
to
hide
her
face
in
her
embrace
,
had
clung
about
her
with
a
desperate
affection
very
much
at
variance
with
her
years
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Lord
bless
me
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
rising
testily
.
<EOS>
"
A
very
ill
-
advised
and
feverish
proceeding
this
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
I
had
better
ask
Doctor
Peps
if
he
'll
have
the
goodness
to
step
up
stairs
again
perhaps
.
<EOS>
I
'll
go
down
.
<EOS>
I
'll
go
down
.
<EOS>
I
need
n't
beg
you
,
"
he
added
,
pausing
for
a
moment
at
the
settee
before
the
fire
,
"
to
take
particular
care
of
this
young
gentleman
,
Mrs
<EOS>
---
"
  
"
Blockitt
,
Sir
?
"
suggested
the
nurse
,
a
simpering
piece
of
faded
gentility
,
who
did
not
presume
to
state
her
name
as
a
fact
,
but
merely
offered
it
as
a
mild
suggestion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
this
young
gentleman
,
Mrs
Blockitt
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
Sir
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
remember
when
Miss
Florence
was
born
---
"
  
"
Ay
,
ay
,
ay
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
bending
over
the
basket
bedstead
,
and
slightly
bending
his
brows
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Miss
Florence
was
all
very
well
,
but
this
is
another
matter
.
<EOS>
This
young
gentleman
has
to
accomplish
a
destiny
.
<EOS>
A
destiny
,
little
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
As
he
thus
apostrophised
the
infant
he
raised
one
of
his
hands
to
his
lips
,
and
kissed
it
;
then
,
seeming
to
fear
that
the
action
involved
some
compromise
of
his
dignity
,
went
,
awkwardly
enough
,
away
.
  
<EOS>
Doctor
Parker
Peps
,
one
of
the
Court
Physicians
,
and
a
man
of
immense
reputation
for
assisting
at
the
increase
of
great
families
,
was
walking
up
and
down
the
drawing
-
room
with
his
hands
behind
him
,
to
the
unspeakable
admiration
of
the
family
Surgeon
,
who
had
regularly
puffed
the
case
for
the
last
six
weeks
,
among
all
his
patients
,
friends
,
and
acquaintances
,
as
one
to
which
he
was
in
hourly
expectation
day
and
night
of
being
summoned
,
in
conjunction
with
Doctor
Parker
Peps
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
,
"
said
Doctor
Parker
Peps
in
a
round
,
deep
,
sonorous
voice
,
muffled
for
the
occasion
,
like
the
knocker
;
"
do
you
find
that
your
dear
lady
is
at
all
roused
by
your
visit
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stimulated
as
it
were
?
"
said
the
family
practitioner
faintly
:
bowing
at
the
same
time
to
the
Doctor
,
as
much
as
to
say
,
"
Excuse
my
putting
in
a
word
,
but
this
is
a
valuable
connexion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
was
quite
discomfited
by
the
question
.
<EOS>
He
had
thought
so
little
of
the
patient
,
that
he
was
not
in
a
condition
to
answer
it
.
<EOS>
He
said
that
it
would
be
a
satisfaction
to
him
,
if
Doctor
Parker
Peps
would
walk
up
stairs
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
!
<EOS>
We
must
not
disguise
from
you
,
Sir
,
"
said
Doctor
Parker
Peps
,
"
that
there
is
a
want
of
power
in
Her
Grace
the
Duchess
<EOS>
---
I
beg
your
pardon
;
I
confound
names
;
I
should
say
,
in
your
amiable
lady
.
<EOS>
That
there
is
a
certain
degree
of
languor
,
and
a
general
absence
of
elasticity
,
which
we
would
rather
---
not
---
"
  
"
See
,
"
interposed
the
family
practitioner
with
another
inclination
of
the
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
so
,
"
said
Doctor
Parker
Peps
,
"
which
we
would
rather
not
see
.
<EOS>
It
would
appear
that
the
system
of
Lady
Cankaby
---
excuse
me
:
I
should
say
of
Mrs
Dombey
:
<EOS>
I
confuse
the
names
of
cases
---
"
  
"
So
very
numerous
,
"
murmured
the
family
practitioner
---
"
ca
n't
be
expected
I
'm
sure
---
quite
wonderful
if
otherwise
<EOS>
---
Doctor
Parker
Peps
's
West
-
End
practice
---
"
  
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
"
quite
so
.
<EOS>
It
would
appear
,
I
was
observing
,
that
the
system
of
our
patient
has
sustained
a
shock
,
from
which
it
can
only
hope
to
rally
by
a
great
and
strong
---
"
   
"
And
vigorous
,
"
murmured
the
family
practitioner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
so
,
"
assented
the
Doctor
---
"
and
vigorous
effort
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pilkins
here
,
who
from
his
position
of
medical
adviser
in
this
family
---
no
one
better
qualified
to
fill
that
position
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
murmured
the
family
practitioner
.
"
<EOS>
"
Praise
from
Sir
Hubert
Stanley
!
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
are
good
enough
,
"
returned
Doctor
Parker
Peps
,
"
to
say
so
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pilkins
who
,
from
his
position
,
is
best
acquainted
with
the
patient
's
constitution
in
its
normal
state
(
an
acquaintance
very
valuable
to
us
in
forming
our
opinions
on
these
occasions
)
,
is
of
opinion
,
with
me
,
that
Nature
must
be
called
upon
to
make
a
vigorous
effort
in
this
instance
;
and
that
if
our
interesting
friend
the
Countess
of
Dombey
---
I
beg
your
pardon
;
Mrs
Dombey
---
should
not
be
---
"
  
"
Able
,
"
said
the
family
practitioner
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
make
that
effort
successfully
,
"
said
Doctor
Parker
Peps
,
"
then
a
crisis
might
arise
,
which
we
should
both
sincerely
deplore
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
they
stood
for
a
few
seconds
looking
at
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Then
,
on
the
motion
---
made
in
dumb
show
---
of
Doctor
Parker
Peps
,
they
went
up
stairs
;
the
family
practitioner
opening
the
room
door
for
that
distinguished
professional
,
and
following
him
out
,
with
most
obsequious
politeness
.
  
<EOS>
To
record
of
Mr
Dombey
that
he
was
not
in
his
way
affected
by
this
intelligence
,
would
be
to
do
him
an
injustice
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
man
of
whom
it
could
properly
be
said
that
he
was
ever
startled
or
shocked
;
but
he
certainly
had
a
sense
within
him
,
that
if
his
wife
should
sicken
and
decay
,
he
would
be
very
sorry
,
and
that
he
would
find
a
something
gone
from
among
his
plate
and
furniture
,
and
other
household
possessions
,
which
was
well
worth
the
having
,
and
could
not
be
lost
without
sincere
regret
.
<EOS>
Though
it
would
be
a
cool
,
business
-
like
,
gentlemanly
,
self
-
possessed
regret
,
no
doubt
.
  
<EOS>
His
meditations
on
the
subject
were
soon
interrupted
,
first
by
the
rustling
of
garments
on
the
staircase
,
and
then
by
the
sudden
whisking
into
the
room
of
a
lady
rather
past
the
middle
age
than
otherwise
,
but
dressed
in
a
very
juvenile
manner
,
particularly
as
to
the
tightness
of
her
bodice
,
who
,
running
up
to
him
with
a
kind
of
screw
in
her
face
and
carriage
,
expressive
of
suppressed
emotion
,
flung
her
arms
round
his
neck
,
and
said
in
a
choking
voice
,
  
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Paul
!
<EOS>
He
's
quite
a
Dombey
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
returned
her
brother
---
for
Mr
Dombey
was
her
brother
---
"
<EOS>
I
think
he
is
like
the
family
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
agitate
yourself
,
Louisa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
foolish
of
me
,
"
said
Louisa
,
sitting
down
,
and
taking
out
her
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
"
but
he
's
---
<EOS>
he
's
such
a
perfect
Dombey
!
<EOS>
I
never
saw
anything
like
it
in
my
life
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
is
this
about
Fanny
,
herself
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
How
is
Fanny
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Paul
,
"
returned
Louisa
,
"
it
's
nothing
whatever
.
<EOS>
Take
my
word
,
it
's
nothing
whatever
.
<EOS>
There
is
exhaustion
,
certainly
,
but
nothing
like
what
I
underwent
myself
,
either
with
George
or
Frederick
.
<EOS>
An
effort
is
necessary
.
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
<EOS>
If
dear
Fanny
were
a
Dombey
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
But
I
dare
say
she
'll
make
it
;
I
have
no
doubt
she
'll
make
it
.
<EOS>
Knowing
it
to
be
required
of
her
,
as
a
duty
,
of
course
she
'll
make
it
.
<EOS>
My
dear
Paul
,
it
's
very
weak
and
silly
of
me
,
I
know
,
to
be
so
trembly
and
shaky
from
head
to
foot
;
but
I
am
so
very
queer
that
I
must
ask
you
for
a
glass
of
wine
and
a
morsel
of
that
cake
.
<EOS>
I
thought
I
should
have
fallen
out
of
the
staircase
window
as
I
came
down
from
seeing
dear
Fanny
,
and
that
tiddy
ickle
sing
.
<EOS>
"
These
last
words
originated
in
a
sudden
vivid
reminiscence
of
the
baby
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
succeeded
by
a
gentle
tap
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Chick
,
"
said
a
very
bland
female
voice
outside
,
"
how
are
you
now
,
my
dear
friend
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Paul
,
"
said
Louisa
in
a
low
voice
,
as
she
rose
from
her
seat
,
"
it
's
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
The
kindest
creature
!
<EOS>
I
never
could
have
got
here
without
her
!
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
,
my
brother
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
Paul
,
my
dear
,
my
very
particular
friend
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
lady
thus
specially
presented
,
was
a
long
lean
figure
,
wearing
such
a
faded
air
that
she
seemed
not
to
have
been
made
in
what
linen
-
drapers
call
"
fast
colours
"
originally
,
and
to
have
,
by
little
and
little
,
washed
out
.
<EOS>
But
for
this
she
might
have
been
described
as
the
very
pink
of
general
propitiation
and
politeness
.
<EOS>
From
a
long
habit
of
listening
admirably
to
everything
that
was
said
in
her
presence
,
and
looking
at
the
speakers
as
if
she
were
mentally
engaged
in
taking
off
impressions
of
their
images
upon
her
soul
,
never
to
part
with
the
same
but
with
life
,
her
head
had
quite
settled
on
one
side
.
<EOS>
Her
hands
had
contracted
a
spasmodic
habit
of
raising
themselves
of
their
own
accord
as
in
involuntary
admiration
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
were
liable
to
a
similar
affection
.
<EOS>
She
had
the
softest
voice
that
ever
was
heard
;
and
her
nose
,
stupendously
aquiline
,
had
a
little
knob
in
the
very
centre
or
key
-
stone
of
the
bridge
,
whence
it
tended
downwards
towards
her
face
,
as
in
an
invincible
determination
never
to
turn
up
at
anything
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
's
dress
,
though
perfectly
genteel
and
good
,
had
a
certain
character
of
angularity
and
scantiness
.
<EOS>
She
was
accustomed
to
wear
odd
weedy
little
flowers
in
her
bonnets
and
caps
.
<EOS>
Strange
grasses
were
sometimes
perceived
in
her
hair
;
and
it
was
observed
by
the
curious
,
of
all
her
collars
,
frills
,
tuckers
,
wristbands
,
and
other
gossamer
articles
---
indeed
of
everything
she
wore
which
had
two
ends
to
it
intended
to
unite
---
that
the
two
ends
were
never
on
good
terms
,
and
would
n't
quite
meet
without
a
struggle
.
<EOS>
She
had
furry
articles
for
winter
wear
,
as
tippets
,
boas
,
and
muffs
,
which
stood
up
on
end
in
a
rampant
manner
,
and
were
not
at
all
sleek
.
<EOS>
She
was
much
given
to
the
carrying
about
of
small
bags
with
snaps
to
them
<EOS>
,
that
went
off
like
little
pistols
when
they
were
shut
up
;
and
when
full
-
dressed
,
she
wore
round
her
neck
the
barrenest
of
lockets
,
representing
a
fishy
old
eye
,
with
no
approach
to
speculation
in
it
.
<EOS>
These
and
other
appearances
of
a
similar
nature
,
had
served
to
propagate
the
opinion
,
that
Miss
Tox
was
a
lady
of
what
is
called
a
limited
independence
,
which
she
turned
to
the
best
account
.
<EOS>
Possibly
her
mincing
gait
encouraged
the
belief
,
and
suggested
that
her
clipping
a
step
of
ordinary
compass
into
two
or
three
,
originated
in
her
habit
of
making
the
most
of
everything
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
with
a
prodigious
curtsey
,
"
that
to
have
the
honour
of
being
presented
to
Mr
Dombey
<EOS>
is
a
distinction
which
I
have
long
sought
,
but
very
little
expected
at
the
present
moment
.
<EOS>
My
dear
Mrs
Chick
---
may
I
say
Louisa
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
took
Miss
Tox
's
hand
in
hers
,
rested
the
foot
of
her
wine
-
glass
upon
it
,
repressed
a

,
and
said
in
a
low
voice
"
Bless
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Louisa
then
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
"
my
sweet
friend
<EOS>
,
how
are
you
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Better
,
"
Mrs
Chick
returned
.
<EOS>
"
Take
some
wine
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
almost
as
anxious
as
I
have
been
,
and
must
want
it
,
I
am
sure
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
of
course
officiated
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Tox
,
Paul
,
"
pursued
Mrs
Chick
,
still
retaining
her
hand
,
"
knowing
how
much
I
have
been
interested
in
the

of
the
event
of
to
-
day
,
has
been
working
at
a
little

Fanny
,

I

.
<EOS>
It

,
Paul
,

I

,

,

,
that
Miss
Tox

.
<EOS>
I
call
"
Welcome
little
Dombey
"
Poetry
,
myself
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
the
device
?
"
<EOS>
inquired

brother
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
the
device
,
"
returned
Louisa
.
  
<EOS>
"
But

me
the

to

,

,
"

Tox
in

low

,
"
that
nothing
but
<EOS>
the
---
I
have
some

in
expressing

---
the

result
would
have

<EOS>
a

:
"
<EOS>
Welcome
,

,
"

,
as
I

.
<EOS>
But
the

attendant
on
angelic

<EOS>
,
will
,
I
hope
,
excuse
what
must

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
made
a
graceful
bend
as
she
spoke
,
in
favour
of
Mr
Dombey
,
which
that
gentleman
graciously
acknowledged
.
<EOS>
Even
the
sort
of
recognition
of
Dombey
and
Son
,
conveyed
in
the
foregoing
conversation
,
was
so
palatable

,
that

,

---
though
he
affected
to
consider
her
a
weak
good

---
had
perhaps

over

than
anybody
else
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
with
a
sweet

,
"
after
this
,
I
forgive
Fanny
everything
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
declaration
in
a
Christian
spirit
,
and
Mrs
Chick
felt
that
it
did
her
good
.
<EOS>
Not
that
she
had
anything
particular
to
forgive
in
her
sister
-
in
-
law
,
nor
indeed
anything
at
all
,
except
her
having
married
her
brother
---
in
itself
a
species
of
audacity
---
and
her
having
,
in
the
course
of
events
,
given
birth
to
a
girl
instead
of
a
boy
:
which
,
as
Mrs
Chick
had
frequently
observed
,
was
not
quite
what
she
had
expected
of
her
,
and
was
not
a
pleasant
return
for
all
the
attention
and
distinction
she
had
met
with
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
being
hastily
summoned
out
of
the
room
at
this
moment
,
the
two
ladies
were
left
alone
together
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
immediately
became
spasmodic
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
knew
you
would
admire
my
brother
.
<EOS>
I
told
you
<EOS>
so
before
-
hand
,
my
dear
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
's
hands
and

expressed
how
much
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
as
to
his
property
,
my
dear
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
m
---
mense
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
his
deportment
,
my
dear
Louisa
!
"
said
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
presence
!
<EOS>
His
dignity
!
<EOS>
No
portrait
that
I
have
ever
seen
of
any

has
been
half
so
replete
with
those

.
<EOS>
Something
so
stately
,
you
know
:
<EOS>
so
uncompromising
:
so
very
wide
across
the
chest
:
so

!
<EOS>
A
pecuniary
Duke
of
York
,
my
love
,
and
nothing
short
of
it
!
"
said
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
I
should

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
Paul
!
"
exclaimed

,
as

,
"
you
look

!
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
the

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

Fanny
---
"
  
"
Now
,

Paul
,
"

"
do

.
<EOS>
If

,
Paul
,
you

rest
<EOS>
assured
that

's

.
<EOS>
And
that

,
"
she

,
taking

,

,
in

-

<EOS>
,
"
she
must

encouraged
,

,

,
urged

make
.
<EOS>
Now
,

Paul
,
come

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
who
,
besides
being
generally
influenced
by
his
sister
for
the
reason
already
mentioned
,
had
really
faith
in
her
as
an
experienced
and
bustling
matron
,
acquiesced
:
and
followed
her
,
at
once
,
to
the
sick
chamber
.
  
<EOS>
The
lady
lay
upon
her
bed
as
he
had
left
her
,
clasping
her
little
daughter
to
her
breast
.
<EOS>
The
child
clung
close
about
her
,
with
the
same
intensity
as
before
,
and
never
raised
her
head
,
or
moved
her
soft
cheek
from
her
mother
's
face
,
or
looked
on
those
who
stood
around
,
or
spoke
,
or
moved
,
or
shed
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Restless
without
the
little
girl
,
"
the
Doctor
whispered
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
We
found
it
best
to
have
her
in
again
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
such
a
solemn
stillness
round
the
bed
;
and
the
two
medical
attendants
seemed
to
look
on
the
impassive
form
with
so
much
compassion
and
so
little

,
that
Mrs
Chick
was
for
the

diverted
from
her
purpose
.
<EOS>
But
presently
summoning
courage
,
and
what
she
called
presence
of
mind
,
she
sat
down
by
the
bedside
,
and
said
in
the
low
precise

of
one
who
endeavours
to
awaken

:
  
"
<EOS>
Fanny
!
<EOS>
Fanny
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
no
sound
in
answer
but
the
loud

of
Mr
Dombey
's
watch
and
Doctor
Parker
Peps
's
watch
,
which
seemed
in
the
silence
to
be
running
a
race
.
  
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
with
assumed

,
"
<EOS>
here
's
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
come
to
see

.
<EOS>
Wo
n't

speak
to

?
<EOS>
They
want
to
lay
your
little
boy
---
the
baby
,
Fanny
,
you
know
;
you
have
hardly
seen
him
yet
,
I
think
---
in

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

<EOS>

For

"
Poor

!
"
  
<EOS>
It

characteristic

Mr
Dombey
's

,

through

child
.
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
Not

,

in
the
wife
of
an

Hind
who
has
been

"
mostly

"
all

life
,
and
yet
at
whose
door
Death
had
never
knocked
,

at
whose

four
sons
daily
sit
---
but
poor
little
fellow
!
  
<EOS>
Those
words
being
on
his
lips
,
it
occurred
to

---
and
it
is
an
instance
of

with

were
tending

one

---
that
a
great

was
being

this

's

.
<EOS>
Her
infant
was
a
boy
too
.
<EOS>
Now
,
would
it
be
possible
for
her
to
change
them
?
  
<EOS>
Though
he
was
soon
satisfied
that
he

as

---
though
possible
,
there
was
no

---
he
could
not

pursuing
it
so
far
as
to
entertain
within
himself
a
picture
of
what
his
condition

,
if

should
discover
such

when
he
was
grown
old
.
<EOS>
Whether
a
man
so

,
would
be
able

result

of

,

,
and

,
from

,

?
  
<EOS>
As

subsided
,

gradually

away
,
though

much

shadow

,
that

wasconstant
in
his
resolution
to
look
closely
after
Richards
himself
,
without
appearing
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
Being
now
in
an
easier
frame
of
mind
,
he
regarded
the
woman
's
station
as
rather
an
advantageous
circumstance
than
otherwise
,
by
placing
,
in
itself
,
a
broad
distance
between
her
and
the
child
,
and
rendering
their
separation
easy
and
natural
.
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
terms
were
ratified
and
agreed
upon
between
Mrs
Chick
and
Richards
,
with
the
assistance
of
Miss
Tox
;
and
Richards
being
with
much
ceremony
invested
with
the
Dombey
baby
,
as
if
it
were
an
Order
,
resigned
her
own
,
with
many
tears
and
kisses
,
to
Jemima
.
<EOS>
Glasses
of
wine
were
then
produced
,
to
sustain
the
drooping
spirits
of
the
family
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
take
a
glass
yourself
,
Sir
,
wo
n't
you
?
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
as
Toodle
appeared
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
,
Mum
,
"
said
Toodle
,
"
since
you
are
suppressing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
're
very
glad
to
leave
your
dear
good
wife
in
such
a
comfortable
home
,
ai
n't
you
,
Sir
?
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
nodding
and
winking
at
him
stealthily
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Mum
,
"
said
Toodle
.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
wishing
of
her
back
agin
.
"
  
Polly
cried
more
than
ever
at
this
.
<EOS>
So
Mrs
Chick
,
who
had
her
matronly
apprehensions
that
this
indulgence
in
grief
might
be
prejudicial
to
the
little
Dombey
<EOS>
(
"
acid
,
indeed
,
"
she
whispered
Miss
Tox
)
,
hastened
to
the
rescue
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
little
child
will
thrive
charmingly
with
your
sister
Jemima
,
Richards
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
;
"
and
you
have
only
to
make
an
effort
<EOS>
---
this
is
a
world
of
effort
,
you
know
,
Richards
---
to
be
very
happy

.
<EOS>
You
have
been
already
measured
for
your
mourning
,
have

,
Richards
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ye
---
es
,
Ma'am
,
"
sobbed
Polly
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
it
'll
fit
beautifully
.
<EOS>
I
know
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
"
for
the
same
young
person
has
made

many
dresses
.
<EOS>
The
very
best
materials
,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
you
'll
be
so
smart
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
"
that
your
husband
wo
n't
know
you
;
<EOS>
will
you
,
Sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
know
her
,
"
said
Toodle
,
gruffly
,
"
anyhows
and
anywheres
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Toodle
was
evidently
not
to
be
bought
over
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
to
living
,
Richards
,
you
know
,
"
pursued
Mrs
Chick
,
"
why
the
very
best
of

.
<EOS>
You
will
order
your
little

every

;
and

take

to
,
I
'm
sure
will

as

if

a
Lady
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
to
be
sure
!
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
keeping

with
great

.
"
<EOS>
And
as
to
porter
!
<EOS>
---
quite
unlimited
,
will
it
not
,
Louisa
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
"
returned
Mrs
Chick
in

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
a
little

,
you
know
,
<EOS>
my
dear
,
in
point
of
vegetables
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
pickles
,
perhaps
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
With

,
"

,
"
she
'll
consult
her

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

,

,

,
"

Tox
,
"
however
fond
<EOS>
she
is
of
her
own

child
---
<EOS>
and
I
'm
sure
<EOS>
,
Louisa
,

for

of
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
"
cried
Mrs
Chick
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Still
,
"
resumed
Miss
Tox
,
"
she
naturally
must
be
interested
in
her
young
charge
,
and
must
consider
it
a
privilege
to
see
a
little
cherub
closely
connected
with
the
superior
classes
,
gradually
unfolding
itself
from
day
to

at
one
common

.
<EOS>
Is
it
not
so
,
Louisa
?
"
  
"
Most
undoubtedly
!
"
said
Mrs
Chick
.
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
my
love
,
she
's
already
quite
contented
and

,
and
means
to
say

-
bye
to
her
sister
Jemima
and
her

,
and
her
good
honest
husband
,
with
a
light

and
a

;
do
n't
she
,
my
dear
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
!
"
cried
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
she
does
!
"
  
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
which
,
however
,
poor
Polly
embraced
them
all
round
in
great
distress
,
and
finally
ran
away
to
avoid
any
more
particular
leave
-
taking
between
herself
and
the
children
.
<EOS>
But
the
stratagem
hardly
succeeded
as
well
as
it
deserved
;
for
the
smallest
boy
but
one
divining
her
intent
,
immediately
began
swarming
up
stairs
after
her
---
if
that
word
of
doubtful
etymology
be
admissible
---
on
his
arms
and
legs
;
while
the
eldest
(
known
in
the
family
by
the
name
of
Biler
,
in
remembrance
of
the
steam
engine
)
beat
a
demoniacal
tattoo
with
his
boots
,
expressive
of
grief
;
in
which
he
was
joined
by
the
rest
of
the
family
.
  
<EOS>
A
quantity
of
oranges
and
halfpence
thrust
indiscriminately
on
each
young
Toodle
,
checked
the
first
violence
of
their
regret
,
and
the
family
were
speedily
transported
to
their
own
home
,
by
means
of
the
hackney
-
coach
kept
in
waiting
for
that
purpose
.
<EOS>
The
children
,
under
the
guardianship
of
Jemima
,
blocked
up
the
window
,
and
dropped
out
oranges
and
halfpence
all
the
way
along
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toodle
himself
preferred
to
ride
behind
among
the
spikes
,
as
being
the
mode
of
conveyance
to
which
he
was
best
accustomed
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
3
.
<EOS>
In
which
Mr
Dombey
,
as
a
Man
and
a
Father
,
is
seen
at
the
Head
of
the
Home
-
Department
 
<EOS>
THE
funeral
of
the
deceased
lady
having
been
"
performed
"
to
the
entire
satisfaction
of
the
undertaker
,
as
well
as
of
the
neighbourhood
at
large
,
which
is
generally
disposed
to
be
captious
on
such
a
point
,
and
is
prone
to
take
offence
at
any
omissions
or
short
-
comings
in
the
ceremonies
,
the
various
members
of
Mr
Dombey
's
household
subsided
into
their
several
places
in
the
domestic
system
.
<EOS>
That
small
world
,
like
the
great
one
out
of
doors
,
had
the
capacity
of
easily
forgetting
its
dead
;
and
when
the
cook
had
said
she
was
a
quiet
-
tempered
lady
,
and
the
house
-
keeper
had
said
it
was
the
common
lot
,
and
the
butler
had
said
who
'd
have
thought
it
,
and
the
housemaid
had
said
she
could
n't
hardly
believe
it
,
and
the
footman
had
said
it
seemed
exactly
like
a
dream
,
they
had
quite
worn
the
subject
out
,
and
began
to
think
their
mourning
was
wearing
rusty
too
.
  
<EOS>
On
Richards
,
who
was
established
up
stairs
in
a
state
of
honourable
captivity
,
the
dawn
of
her
new
life
seemed
to
break
cold
and
grey
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
house
was
a
large
one
,
on
the
shady
side
of
a
tall
,
dark
,
dreadfully
genteel
street
in
the
region
between
Portland
Place
and
Bryanstone
Square
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
corner
house
,
with
great
wide
areas
containing
cellars
frowned
upon
by
barred
window
,
and
leered
at
by
crooked
-
eyed
doors
leading
to
dustbins
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
house
of
dismal
state
,
with
a
circular
back
to
it
,
containing
a
whole
suit
of
drawing
-
rooms
looking
upon
a
gravelled
yard
,
where
two
gaunt
trees
,
with
blackened
trunks
and
branches
,
rattled
rather
than
rustled
,
their
leaves
were
so
smoke
-
dried
.
<EOS>
The
summer
sun
was
never
on
the
street
,
but
in
the
morning
about
breakfast
-
time
,
when
it
came
with
the
water
-
carts
and
the
old
-
clothes
men
,
and
the
people
with
geraniums
,
and
the
umbrella
-
mender
,
and
the
man
who
trilled
the
little
bell
of
the
Dutch
clock
as
he
went
along
.
<EOS>
It
was
soon
gone
again
to
return
no
more
that
day
;
and
the
bands
of
music
and
the
straggling
Punch
's
shows
going
after
it
,
left
it
a
prey
to
the
most
dismal
of
organs
,
and
white
mice
;
with
now
and
then
a
porcupine
,
to
vary
the
entertainments
;
until
the
butlers
whose
families
were
dining
out
,
began
to
stand
at
the
house
-
doors
in
the
twilight
,
and
the
lamplighter
made
his
nightly
failure
in
attempting
to
brighten
up
the
street
with
gas
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
as
blank
a
house
inside
as
outside
.
<EOS>
When
the
funeral
was
over
,
Mr
Dombey
ordered
the
furniture
to
be
covered
up
---
perhaps
to
preserve
it
for
the
son
with
whom
his
plans
were
all
associated
---
and
the
rooms
to
be
ungarnished
,
saving
such
as
he
retained
for
himself
on
the
ground
floor
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
mysterious
shapes
were
made
of
tables
and
chairs
,
heaped
together
in
the
middle
of
rooms
,
and
covered
over
with
great
winding
-
sheets
.
<EOS>
Bell
-
handles
,
window
-
blinds
,
and
looking
-
glasses
,
being
papered
up
in
journals
,
daily
and
weekly
,
obtruded
fragmentary
accounts
of
deaths
and
dreadful
murders
.
<EOS>
Every
chandelier
or
lustre
,
muffled
in
Holland
,
looked
like
a
monstrous
tear
depending
from
the
ceiling
's
eye
.
<EOS>
Odours
,
as
from
vaults
and
damp
places
,
came
out
of
the
chimneys
.
<EOS>
The
dead
and
buried
lady
was
awful
in
a
picture
-
frame
of
ghastly
bandages
.
<EOS>
Every
gust
of
wind
that
rose
,
brought
eddying
round
the
corner
from
the
neighbouring
mews
,
some
fragments
of
the
straw
that
had
been
strewn
before
the
house
when
she
was
ill
,
mildewed
remains
of
which
were
still
cleaving
to
the
neighbourhood
;
and
these
,
being
always
drawn
by
some
invisible
attraction
to
the
threshold
of
the
dirty
house
to
let
immediately
opposite
,
addressed
a
dismal
eloquence
to
Mr
Dombey
's
windows
.
  
<EOS>
The
apartments
which
Mr
Dombey
reserved
for
his
own
inhabiting
,
were
attainable
from
the
hall
,
and
consisted
of
a
sitting
-
room
;
a
library
,
which
was
in
fact
a
dressing
-
room
,
so
that
the
smell
of
hot
-
pressed
paper
,
vellum
morocco
,
and
Russia
leather
,
contended
in
it
with
the
smell
of
divers
pairs
of
boots
;
and
a
kind
of
conservatory
or
little
glass
breakfast
-
room
beyond
,
commanding
a
prospect
of
the
trees
before
mentioned
,
and
,
generally
speaking
,
of
a
few
prowling
cats
.
<EOS>
These
three
rooms
opened
upon
one
another
.
<EOS>
In
the
morning
,
when
Mr
Dombey
was
at
his
breakfast
in
one
or
other
of
the
two
first
-
mentioned
of
them
,
as
well
as
in
the
afternoon
when
he
came
home
to
dinner
,
a
bell
was
rung
for
Richards
to
repair
to
this
glass
chamber
,
and
there
walk
to
and
fro
with
her
young
charge
.
<EOS>
From
the
glimpses
she
caught
of
Mr
Dombey
at
these
times
,
sitting
in
the
dark
distance
,
looking
out
towards
the
infant
from
among
the
dark
heavy
furniture
---
the
house
had
been
inhabited
for
years
by
his
father
,
and
in
many
of
its
appointments
was
old
-
fashioned
and
grim
---
she
began
to
entertain
ideas
of
him
in
his
solitary
state
,
as
if
he
were
a
lone
prisoner
in
a
cell
,
or
a
strange
apparition
that
was
not
to
be
accosted
or
understood
.
  
<EOS>
Little
Paul
Dombey
's
foster
-
mother
had
led
this
life
herself
,
and
had
carried
little
Paul
through
it
for
some
weeks
;
and
had
returned
up
stairs
one
day
from
a
melancholy
saunter
through
the
dreary
rooms
of
state
<EOS>
(
she
never
went
out
without
Mrs
Chick
,
who
called
on
fine
mornings
,
usually
accompanied
by
Miss
Tox
,
to
take
her
and
Baby
for
an
airing
---
or
in
other
words
,
to
march
them
gravely
up
and
down
the
pavement
;
like
a
walking
funeral
)
;
when
,
as
she
was
sitting
in
her
own
room
,
the
door
was
slowly
and
quietly
opened
,
and
a
dark
-
eyed
little
girl
looked
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
Miss
Florence
<EOS>
come
home
from
her
aunt
's
,
no
doubt
,
"
thought
Richards
,
who
had
never
seen
the
child
before
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hope
<EOS>
I
see
you
well
,
<EOS>
Miss.
"
  
"
Is
that
my
brother
?
"
asked
the
child
,
pointing
to
the
Baby
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
pretty
,
"
answered
Richards
.
<EOS>
"
Come
and
kiss
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
the
child
,
instead
of
advancing
,
looked
her
earnestly
in
the
face
,
and
said
:
  
"
What
have
you
done
with
my
Mama
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
the
little
creeter
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Richards
,
"
what
a
sad
question
!
<EOS>
I
done
?
<EOS>
Nothing
,
<EOS>
Miss.
"
  
"
What
have
they
done
with
my
Mama
?
"
inquired
the
child
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
such
a
melting
thing
in
all
my
life
!
"
<EOS>
said
Richards
,
who
naturally
substituted
for
this
child
one
of
her
own
,
inquiring
for
herself
in
like
circumstances
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Come
nearer
here
,
my
dear
Miss
!
<EOS>
Do

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
Nothwithstanding

's

on
Polly
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
But

that
is

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,
all

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
which

.
  
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Polly

,

,

Miss
Nipper
,

little

beside

,

,
and
without

.
<EOS>
An
opening
happened
to
present
itself
that
very

.
  
<EOS>
She
had
been
rung
down
into
the
glass
room
as
usual
,
and
had
walked

and
about

,
with

,
when
,

and

<EOS>
,

Dombey
came
out
,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good

,
Richards
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Just

stiff

,

.
<EOS>
Such

looking

,
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
is
Master
Paul
,
Richards
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
thriving
,
Sir
,
and
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
looks
so
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
glancing
with
great
interest
at
the
tiny
face
she
uncovered
for
his
observation
,
and
yet
affecting
to
be
half
careless
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
They
give
you
everything
you
want
,
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
thank
you
,
Sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
suddenly
appended
such
an
obvious
hesitation
to
this
reply
,
however
,
that
Mr
Dombey
,
who
had
turned
away
,
stopped
,
and
turned
round
again
,
inquiringly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
nothing
is
so
good
for
making
children
lively
and
cheerful
,
Sir
,
as
seeing
other
children
playing
about
'
em
,
"
observed
Polly
,
taking
courage
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
mentioned
to
you
,
Richards
,
when
you
came
here
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
with
a
frown
,
"
that
I
wished
you
to
see
as
little
of
your
family
as
possible
.
<EOS>
You
can
continue
your
walk
if
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
,
he
disappeared
into
his
inner
room
;
and
Polly
had
the
satisfaction
of
feeling
that
he
had
thoroughly
misunderstood
her
object
,
and
that
she
had
fallen
into
disgrace
without
the
least
advancement
of
her
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
Next
night
,
she
found
him
walking
about
the
conservatory
when
she
came
down
.
<EOS>
As
she
stopped
at
the
door
,
checked
by
this
unusual
sight
,
and
uncertain
whether
to
advance
or
retreat
,
he
called
her
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
really
think
that
sort
of
society
is
good
the
child
,
"
he
said
sharply
,
as
if
there
had
been
no
interval
since
she
proposed
it
,
"
where
's
Miss
Florence
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
could
be
better
than
Miss
Florence
,
Sir
,
"
said
Polly
eagerly
,
"
but
I
understood
from
her
little
maid
that
they
were
not
to
---
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
rang
the
bell
,
and
walked
till
it
was
answered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
them
always
to
let
Miss
Florence
be
with
Richards
when
she
chooses
,
and
go
out
with
her
,
and
so
forth
.
<EOS>
Tell
them
to
let
the
children
be
together
,
when
Richards
wishes
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
iron
was
now
hot
,
and
Richards
striking
on
it
boldly
---
it
was
a
good
cause
and
she
was
bold
in
it
,
though
instinctively
afraid
of
MrDombey
---
<EOS>
requested
that
Miss
Florence
might
be
sent
down
then
and
there
,
to
make
friends
with
here
little
brother
.
  
<EOS>
She
feigned
to
be
dandling
the
child
as
the
servant
retired
on
this
errand
,
but
she
thought
that
she
saw
Mr
Dombey
's
colour
changed
;
that
the
expression
of
his
face
quite
altered
;
that
he
turned
,
hurriedly
,
as
if
to
gainsay
what
he
had
said
,
or
she
had
said
,
or
both
,
and
was
only
deterred
by
very
shame
.
  
<EOS>
And
she
was
right
.
<EOS>
The
last
time
he
had
seen
his
slighted
child
,
there
had
been
that
in
the
sad
embrace
between
her
and
her
dying
mother
,
which
was
at
once
a
revelation
and
a
reproach
to
him
.
<EOS>
Let
him
be
absorbed
as
he
would
in
the
Son
on
whom
he
built
such
high
hopes
,
he
could
not
forget
that
closing
scene
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
forget
that
he
had
had
no
part
in
it
.
<EOS>
That
,
at
the
bottom
of
its
clear
depths
of
tenderness
and
truth
,
lay
those
two
figures
clasped
in
each
other
's
arms
,
while
he
stood
on
the
bank
above
them
,
looking
down
a
mere
spectator
---
not
a
sharer
with
them
---
quite
shut
out
.
  
<EOS>
Unable
to
exclude
these
things
from
his
remembrance
,
or
to
keep
his
mind
free
from
such
imperfect
shapes
of
the
meaning
with
which
they
were
fraught
,
as
were
able
to
make
themselves
visible
to
him
through
the
mist
of
his
pride
,
his
previous
feelings
of
indifference
towards
little
Florence
changed
into
an
uneasiness
of
an
extraordinary
kind
.
<EOS>
He
almost
felt
as
if
she
watched
and
distrusted
him
.
<EOS>
As
if
she
held
the
clue
to
something
secret
in
his
breast
,
of
the
nature
of
which
he
was
hardly
informed
himself
.
<EOS>
As
if
she
had
an
innate
knowledge
of
one
jarring
and
discordant
string
within
him
,
and
her
very
breath
could
sound
it
.
  
<EOS>
His
feeling
about
the
child
had
been
negative
from
her
birth
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
conceived
an
aversion
to
her
:
it
had
not
been
worth
his
while
or
in
his
humour
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
been
a
positively
disagreeable
object
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
now
he
was
ill
at
ease
about
her
.
<EOS>
She
troubled
his
peace
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
preferred
to
put
her
idea
aside
altogether
,
if
he
had
known
how
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
---
who
shall
decide
on
such
mysteries
!
---
he
was
afraid
that
he
might
come
to
hate
her
.
  
<EOS>
When
little
Florence
timidly
presented
herself
,
Mr
Dombey
stopped
in
his
pacing
up
and
down
and
looked
towards
her
.
<EOS>
Had
he
looked
with
greater
interest
and
with
a
father
's
eye
,
he
might
have
read
in
her
keen
glance
the
impulses
and
fears
that
made
her
waver
;
the
passionate
desire
to
run
clinging
to
him
,
crying
,
as
she
hid
her
face
in
his
embrace
,
"
Oh
father
,
try
to
love
me
!
<EOS>
there
's
no
one
else
!
"
<EOS>
the
dread
of
a
repulse
;
the
fear
of
being
too
bold
,
and
of
offending
him
;
the
pitiable
need
in
which
she
stood
of
some
assurance
and
encouragement
;
and
how
her
overcharged
young
heart
was
wandering
to
find
some
natural
resting
-
place
,
for
its
sorrow
and
affection
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
saw
nothing
of
this
.
<EOS>
He
saw
her
pause
irresolutely
at
the
door
and
look
towards
him
;
and
he
saw
no
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
"
he
said
,
"
come
in
:
<EOS>
what
is
the
child
afraid
of
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
came
in
;
and
after
glancing
round
her
for
a
moment
with
an
uncertain
air
,
stood
pressing
her
small
hands
hard
together
,
close
within
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
here
,
Florence
,
"
said
her
father
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
who
I
am
?
"
  
"
Yes
,
Papa
.
"
  
"
Have
you
nothing
to
say
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
tears
that
stood
in
her
eyes
as
she
raised
them
quickly
to
his
face
,
were
frozen
by
the
expression
it
wore
.
<EOS>
She
looked
down
again
,
and
put
out
her
trembling
hand
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
took
it
loosely
in
his
own
,
and
stood
looking
down
upon
her
for
a
moment
,
as
if
he
knew
as
little
as
the
child
,
what
to
say
or
do
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
<EOS>
Be
a
good
girl
,
"
he
said
,
patting
her
on
the
head
,
and
regarding
her
as
it
were
by
stealth
with
a
disturbed
and
doubtful
look
.
<EOS>
"
Go
to
Richards
!
<EOS>
Go
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
little
daughter
hesitated
for
another
instant
as
though
she
would
have
clung
about
him
still
,
or
had
some
lingering
hope
that
he
might
raise
her
in
his
arms
and
kiss
her
.
<EOS>
She
looked
up
in
his
face
once
more
.
<EOS>
He
thought
how
like
her
expression
was
then
,
to
what
it
had
been
when
she
looked
round
at
the
Doctor
---
that
night
---
and
instinctively
dropped
her
hand
and
turned
away
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
difficult
to
perceive
that
Florence
was
at
a
great
disadvantage
in
her
father
's
presence
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
only
a
constraint
upon
the
child
's
mind
,
but
even
upon
the
natural
grace
and
freedom
of
her
actions
.
<EOS>
Still
Polly
persevered
with
all
the
better
heart
for
seeing
this
;
and
,
judging
of
Mr
Dombey
by
herself
,
had
great
confidence
in
the
mute
appeal
of
poor
little
Florence
's
mourning
dress
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
hard
indeed
,
"
thought
Polly
,
"
if
he
takes
only
to
one
little
motherless
child
,
when
he
has
another
,
and
that
a
girl
,
before
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
,
Polly
kept
her
before
his
eyes
,
as
long
as
she
could
,
and
managed
so
well
with
little
Paul
,
as
to
make
it
very
plain
that
he
was
all
the
livelier
for
his
sister
's
company
.
<EOS>
When
it
was
time
to
withdraw
up
stairs
again
,
she
would
have
sent
Florence
into
the
inner
room
to
say
good
-
night
to
her
father
,
but
the
child
was
timid
and
drew
back
:
and
when
she
urged
her
again
,
said
,
spreading
her
hands
before
her
eyes
,
as
if
to
shut
out
her
own
unworthiness
,
"
Oh
no
,
no
!
<EOS>
He
do
n't
want
me
.
<EOS>
He
do
n't
want
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
little
altercation
between
them
had
attracted
the
notice
of
Mr
Dombey
,
who
inquired
from
the
table
where
he
was
sitting
at
his
wine
,
what
the
matter
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Florence
was
afraid
of
interrupting
,
Sir
,
if
she
came
in
to
say
good
-
night
,
"
said
Richards
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
does
n't
matter
,
"
returned
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
let
her
come
and
go
without
regarding
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
child
shrunk
as
she
listened
---
and
was
gone
before
her
humble
friend
looked
round
again
.
  
<EOS>
However
,
Polly
triumphed
not
a
little
in
the
success
of
her
well
-
intentioned
scheme
,
and
in
the
address
with
which
she
had
brought
it
to
bear
:
whereof
she
made
a
full
disclosure
to
Spitfire
when
she
was
once
more
safely
intrenched
up
stairs
.
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper
received
that
proof
of
her
confidence
,
as
well
as
the
prospect
of
their
free
association
for
the
future
,
rather
coldly
,
and
was
anything
but
enthusiastic
in
her
demonstrations
of
joy
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
would
have
been
pleased
,
"
said
Polly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
Mrs
Richards
,
I
'm
very
well
pleased
,
thank
you
,
"
returned
Susan
,
who
had
suddenly
become
so
very
upright
that
she
seemed
to
have
put
an
additional
bone
in
her
stays
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
show
it
,
"
said
Polly
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
Being
only
a
permanency
<EOS>
I
could
n't
be
expected
to
show
it
like
a
temporary
,
"
said
Susan
Nipper
.
<EOS>
"
Temporaries
carries
it
all
before
'em
here
,
I
find
,
but
though
there
's
a
excellent
party
-
wall
between
this
house
and
the
next
,
I
may
n't
exactly
like
to
go
to
it
,
Mrs
Richards
,
notwithstanding
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
4
.
<EOS>
In
which
some
more
First
Appearances
are
made
on
the
Stage
of
these
Adventures
 
<EOS>
THOUGH
<EOS>
the
offices
of
Dombey
and
Son
were
within
the
liberties
of
the
City
of
London
,
and
within
hearing
of
Bow
Bells
,
when
their
clashing
voices
were
not
drowned
by
the
uproar
in
the
streets
,
yet
were
there
hints
of
adventurous
and
romantic
story
to
be
observed
in
some
of
the
adjacent
objects
.
<EOS>
Gog
and
Magog
held
their
state
within
ten
minutes
'
walk
;
the
Royal
Exchange
was
close
at
hand
;
the
Bank
of
England
,
with
its
vaults
of
gold
and
silver
"
down
among
the
dead
men
"
underground
,
was
their
magnificent
neighbour
.
<EOS>
Just
round
the
corner
stood
the
rich
East
India
House
,
teeming
with
suggestions
of
precious
stuffs
and
stones
,
tigers
,
elephants
,
howdahs
,
hookahs
,
umbrellas
,
palm
trees
,
palanquins
,
and
gorgeous
princes
of
a
brown
complexion
sitting
on
carpets
,
with
their
slippers
very
much
turned
up
at
the
toes
.
<EOS>
Anywhere
in
the
immediate
vicinity
there
might
be
seen
pictures
of
ships
speeding
away
full
sail
to
all
parts
of
the
world
;
outfitting
ware
-
houses
ready
to
pack
off
anybody
anywhere
,
fully
equipped
in
half
an
hour
;
and
little
timber
midshipmen
in
obsolete
naval
uniforms
,
eternally
employed
outside
the
shop
doors
of
nautical
instrument
-
makers
in
taking
observations
of
the
hackney
coaches
.
  
<EOS>
Sole
master
and
proprietor
of
one
of
these
effigies
---
of
that
which
might
be
called
,
familiarly
,
the
woodenest
---
of
that
which
thrust
itself
out
above
the
pavement
,
right
leg
<EOS>
foremost
,
with
a
suavity
the
least
endurable
,
and
had
the
shoe
buckles
and
flapped
waistcoat
the
least
reconcileable
to
human
reason
,
and
bore
at
its
right
eye
the
most
offensively
disproportionate
piece
of
machinery
---
sole
master
and
proprietor
of
that
midshipman
,
and
proud
of
him
too
,
an
elderly
gentleman
in
a
Welsh
wig
had
paid
house
-
rent
,
taxes
,
and
dues
,
for
more
years
than
many
a
full
-
grown
midshipman
of
flesh
and
blood
has
numbered
in
his
life
;
and
midshipmen
who
have
attained
a
pretty
green
old
age
,
have
not
been
wanting
in
the
English
navy
.
  
<EOS>
The
stock
-
in
-
trade
of
this
old
gentleman
comprised
chronometers
,
barometers
,
telescopes
,
compasses
,
charts
,
maps
,
sextants
,
quadrants
,
and
specimens
of
every
kind
of
instrument
used
in
the
working
of
a
ship
's
course
,
or
the
keeping
of
a
ship
's
reckoning
,
or
the
prosecuting
of
a
ship
's
discoveries
.
<EOS>
Objects
in
brass
and
glass
were
in
his
drawers
and
on
his
shelves
,
which
none
but
the
initiated
could
have
found
the
top
of
,
or
guessed
the
use
of
,
or
having
once
examined
,
could
have
ever
got
back
again
into
their
mahogany
nests
without
assistance
.
<EOS>
Everything
was
jammed
into
the
tightest
cases
,
fitted
into
the
narrowest
corners
,
fenced
up
behind
the
most
impertinent
cushions
,
and
screwed
into
the
acutest
angles
,
to
prevent
its
philosophical
composure
from
being
disturbed
by
the
rolling
of
the
sea
.
<EOS>
Such
extraordinary
precautions
were
taken
in
every
instance
to
save
room
,
and
keep
the
thing
compact
;
and
so
much
practical
navigation
was
fitted
,
and
cushioned
,
and
screwed
into
every
box
(
whether
the
box
was
a
mere
slab
,
as
some
were
,
or
something
between
a
cocked
hat
and
a
star
-
fish
,
as
others
were
,
and
those
quite
mild
and
modest
boxes
as
compared
with
others
)
;
that
the
shop
itself
,
partaking
of
the
general
infection
,
seemed
almost
to
become
a
snug
,
sea
-
going
,
ship
-
shape
concern
,
wanting
only
good
sea
-
room
,
in
the
event
of
an
unexpected
launch
,
to
work
its
way
securely
to
any
desert
island
in
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
Many
minor
incidents
in
the
household
life
of
the
Ships'Instrument
-
maker
who
was
proud
of
his
little
midshipman
,
assisted
and
bore
out
this
fancy
.
<EOS>
His
acquaintance
lying
chiefly
among
ship
-
chandlers
and
so
forth
<EOS>
,
he
had
always
plenty
of
the
veritable
ships
'
biscuit
on
his
table
.
<EOS>
It
was
familiar
with
dried
meats
and
tongues
,
possessing
an
extraordinary
flavour
of
rope
yarn
.
<EOS>
Pickles
were
produced
upon
it
,
in
great
wholesale
jars
,
with
"
dealer
in
all
kinds
of
Ships
'
Provisions
"
on
the
label
;
spirits
were
set
forth
in
case
bottles
with
no
throats
.
<EOS>
Old
prints
of
ships
with
alphabetical
references
to
their
various
mysteries
,
hung
in
frames
upon
the
walls
;
the
Tartar
Frigate
under
weigh
,
was
on
the
plates
;
outlandish
shells
,
seaweeds
,
and
mosses
,
decorated
the
chimney
-
piece
;
the
little
wainscotted
back
parlour
was
lighted
by
a
sky
-
light
,
like
a
cabin
.
  
<EOS>
Here
he
lived
too
,
in
skipper
-
like
state
,
all
alone
with
his
nephew
Walter
:
a
boy
of
fourteen
who
looked
quite
enough
like
a
midshipman
,
to
carry
out
the
prevailing
idea
.
<EOS>
But
there
it
ended
,
for
Solomon
Gills
himself
(
more
generally
called
old
Sol
)
was
far
from
having
a
maritime
appearance
.
<EOS>
To
say
nothing
of
his
Welsh
wig
,
which
was
as
plain
and
stubborn
<EOS>
a
Welsh
wig
as
ever
was
worn
,
and
in
which
he
looked
like
anything
but
a
Rover
,
he
was
a
slow
,
quiet
-
spoken
,
thoughtful
old
fellow
,
with
eyes
as
red
as
if
they
had
been
small
suns
looking
at
you
through
a
fog
;
and
a
newly
-
awakened
manner
,
such
as
he
might
have
acquired
by
having
stared
for
three
or
four
days
successively
through
every
optical
instrument
in
his
shop
,
and
suddenly
came
back
to
the
world
again
,
to
find
it
green
.
<EOS>
The
only
change
ever
known
in
his
outward
man
,
was
from
a
complete
suit
of
coffee
-
colour
cut
very
square
,
and
ornamented
with
glaring
buttons
,
to
the
same
suit
of
coffee
-
colour
minus
the
inexpressibles
,
which
were
then
of
a
pale
nankeen
.
<EOS>
He
wore
a
very
precise
shirt
-
frill
,
and
carried
a
pair
of
first
-
rate
spectacles
on
his
forehead
,
and
a
tremendous
chronometer
in

fob
,
rather
than
doubt
which
precious
possession
,
he
would
have
believed
in
a
conspiracy
against
it
on
the
part
of
all

clocks
and
watches
in
the
City
,
and

of

very
Sun

.
<EOS>
Such
as
he
was
,
such
he
had
been
in
the
shop
and
parlour
behind
the
little
midshipman
,
for
years
upon
years
;
going
regularly
aloft

bed
every
night
in
a
howling

remote
from
the
lodgers
,
where
,
when
gentlemen
of
England
who
lived
below
at
ease
had
little

no

of
the
state
of
the
weather
,
it
often
blew
great
guns
.
  
<EOS>
It

half

,
and
an

,
when
the
reader

Solomon
Gills
become

.
<EOS>
Solomon
Gills
is
in
the
act
of
seeing
what
time
it
is
by
the
unimpeachable

.
<EOS>
The
usual
daily
clearance
has

making
in
the
City
for
an

or

;
and
the
human

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

have
thinned
,
"
as

"
very

.
"
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
All

weather
-

in

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
No

Uncle

!
"
said
the
boy
,
"
what
are
you
about
?
<EOS>
that
's
the
wonderful
Madeira
!
<EOS>
---
there
's
only
one
more
bottle
!
"
  
<EOS>
Uncle
Sol
nodded
his
head
,
implying
that
he
knew
very
well
what
he
was
about
;
and
having
drawn
the
cork
in
solemn
silence
,
filled
two
glasses
and
set
the
bottle
and
a
third
clean
glass
on
the
table
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
drink
the
other
bottle
,
Wally
,
"
he
said
,
"
when
you
come
to
good
fortune
;
when
you
are
a
thriving
,
respected
,
happy
man
;
when
the
start
in
life
you
have
made
to
-
day
shall
have
brought
you
,
as
I
pray
Heaven
it
may
!
---
to
a
smooth
part
of
the
course
you
have
to
run
,
my
child
.
<EOS>
My
love
to
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
Some
of
the
fog
that
hung
about
old
Sol
seemed
to
have
got
into
his
throat
;
for
he
spoke
huskily
.
<EOS>
His
hand
shook
too
,
as
he
clinked
his
glass
against
his
nephew
's
.
<EOS>
But
having
once
got
the
wine
to
his
lips
,
he
tossed
it
off
like
a
man
,
and
smacked
them
afterwards
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Uncle
,
"
said
the
boy
,
affecting
to
make
light
of
it
,
while
the

stood
in

,
"
for
the
honour
you
have
done
me
,
et
cetera
,
et
cetera
.
<EOS>
I
shall
now
beg
to
propose
Mr
Solomon
Gills
with
three
times
three
and
one
cheer
more
.
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
<EOS>
and
you
'll
return
thanks
,
Uncle
,
when
we
drink
the
last
bottle
together
;
wo
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
They
clinked
their
glasses
again
;
and
Walter
,
who
was
hoarding
his
wine
,
took
a
sip
of
it
,
and
held
the
glass
up
to
his
eye
with
as
critical
an
air
as
he
could
possibly
assume
.
  
<EOS>
His
Uncle
sat
looking
at

for
some

.
<EOS>
When
their
eyes
at
last
met
,
he
began
at
once
to
pursue
the
theme
that
had
occupied
his

,
aloud
,
as

had
been

all

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Walter
,
"
he
said
,
"
in
truth
this
business
is
merely
a
habit
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
accustomed
to
the
habit
that
I
could
hardly
live
if
I
relinquished
it
:
<EOS>
but
there
's
nothing
doing
,
nothing
doing
.
<EOS>
When
that
uniform
was
worn
,
"
pointing

the
little
midshipman
,
"
then
indeed
,
fortunes
were
to
be
made
,
and
were

.
<EOS>
But
competition
,
competition
---
new
invention
,
new
invention
---
alteration
,
alteration
---
the
world
's
gone
past
me
.
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
where
I
am
myself
;
much
less
where
my
customers
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
Never
mind
'em
,
Uncle
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Since

came

at

,

---
and
that
's
ten

,
"
said

"
<EOS>
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Two
,

,

?
<EOS>
There

---
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

!
<EOS>

Mile

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
it
's

,
"
said

,
"

.
<EOS>
Two

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
They

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
<EOS>
If

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
Uncle

"

boy
,
as
if

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
said
only
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Wally
,
"
resumed
the
old
man
,
after
a

:
"
not
being
like
the
Savages
who
came
on
Robinson
Crusoe
's
Island
,
we
ca
n't
live
on
a
man
who
asks
for
change
for
a
sovereign
,
and
a
woman

inquires
the
way
to
Mile
-
End
Turnpike
.
<EOS>
As
I
said
just
now
,
the
world
has
gone
past
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
blame
it
;
but
I
no
longer
understand
it
.
<EOS>
Tradesmen
are
not
the
same
as
they
used
to
be
,
apprentices
are
not
the
same
,
business
is
not
the
same
,
business

are
not
the
same
.
<EOS>
Seven
-
eighths
of
my
stock
is
old
-
fashioned
.
<EOS>
I
am
an
old
-
fashioned
man
in
an
old
-
fashioned
shop
,
in
a
street
that
is
not
the
same
as
I
remember
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
fallen
behind
the
time
,
and
am
too
old
to
catch
it
again
.
<EOS>
Even
the
noise
it
makes
a
long
way
ahead
,
confuses
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
was
going
to
speak
,
but
his
Uncle
held
up
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,
Wally
---
therefore
it
is
that
I
am
anxious
you
should
be
early
in
the
busy

,
and
on
the
world
's
track
.
<EOS>
I
am
only
the
ghost
of
this
business
---
its
substance
vanished
long

;
and
when
I

,
its

will

laid
.
<EOS>
As

is
clearly
no
inheritance

then
,
I

best
to
use
for
your

,
almost
the
only

of
the
old

that
stands

,
thought

habit
.
<EOS>
Some

suppose

to

.
<EOS>
I
wish
for

they

.
<EOS>
But

,

,
you
in

as
Dombey
's
are

road

.
<EOS>
Be

,

like

,

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
Indeed

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
said
Solomon
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure

,
"
and

to
a
second
glass
of
the
old
Madeira
,

.
"
<EOS>
As
to
the
Sea
,
"

"
that

,

wo

:

wo

.
<EOS>
It

natural

that
you
should

,

;

it
wo
n't

,
it
wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Solomon
Gills
rubbed
his
hands
with
an

,
as

talked
of
the
sea
,
though
;
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Think

this
wine
for

,
"
said
old
Sol
,
"
which
has

to
the
East

and
back
<EOS>
,

'm

,

.
<EOS>
Think

,

,

:
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"
that

.
<EOS>
Think

:
<EOS>
what

"
  
"
<EOS>
What

,

,

,

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly

,
"
said

:
"
has
gone

,

.
<EOS>
Why
,

Sally

---
"
  
"
In

,

,

nine
!
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
Ay
,

!
"
<EOS>

,
"

!
<EOS>
Then
,

;

(

"
Rule

,
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

"
  
"

,
"

"

---
"
  
"
Private

<EOS>
Owners

"

,
"

"
when

,
four
days
'
sail

"
  
"

,
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

"
Dear
Edward
,
think

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
Leap
down

!
"
and
flung
himself

!
"
  
<EOS>
The
kindling

and
heightened

of
the
boy
,
who
had
risen
from
his

in
the
earnestness
of
what

,
seemed
to
remind
old
Sol
of
something
he
had
forgotten
,
or
that
his

mist
had
hitherto
shut

.
<EOS>
Instead

proceeding
with
any
more
anecdotes
,
as
he
had
evidently
intended
but
a

before

he
gave
a
short
dry
cough
,
and
said
,
"
Well
!
suppose
we
change
the
subject
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
truth
was
,
that
the
simple
-
minded
uncle
in
his
secret
attraction
towards
the
marvellous
and
adventurous
---
of
which
he
was
,
in
some
sort
,
a
distant
relation
,
by
his
trade
---
had
greatly
encouraged
the
same
attraction
in
the
nephew
;
and
that
everything
that
had
ever
been
put
before
the
boy
to
deter
him
from
a
life
of
adventure
,
had
had
the
usual
unaccountable
effect
of
sharpening
his
taste
for
it
.
<EOS>
This
is
invariable
.
<EOS>
It
would
seem
as
if
there
never
was
a
book
written
,
or
a
story
told
,
expressly
with
the
object
of
keeping
boys
on
shore
,
which
did
not
lure
and
charm
them
to
the
ocean
,
as
a
matter
of
course
.
  
<EOS>
But
an
addition
to
the
little
party
now
made
its
appearance
,
in
the
shape
of
a
gentleman
in
a
wide
suit
of
blue
,
with
a
hook
instead
of
a
hand
attached
to
his
right
wrist
;
very
bushy
black
eyebrows
;
and
a
thick
stick
in
his
left
hand
,
covered
all
over
(
like
his
nose
)
with
knobs
.
<EOS>
He
wore
a
loose
black
silk
handkerchief
round
his
neck
,
and
such
a
very
large
coarse
shirt
collar
,
that
it
looked
like
a
small
sail
.
<EOS>
He
was
evidently
the
person
for
whom
the
spare
wine
-
glass
was
intended
,
and
evidently
knew
it
;
for
having
taken
off
his
rough
outer
coat
,
and
hung
up
,
on
a
particular
pet
behind
the
door
,
such
a
hard
glazed
hat
as
a
sympathetic
person
's
head
might
ache
at
the
sight
of
,
and
which
left
a
red
rim
round
his
own
forehead
as
if
he
had
been
wearing
a
tight
basin
,
he
brought
a
chair
to
where
the
clean
glass
was
,
and
sat
himself
down
behind
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
usually
addressed
as
Captain
,
this
visitor
;
and
had
been
a
pilot
,
or
a
skipper
,
or
a
privateers
-
man
,
or
all
three
perhaps
;
and
was
a
very
salt
-
looking
man
indeed
.
  
<EOS>
His
face
,
remarkable
for
a
brown
solidity
,
brightened
as
he
shook
hands
with
uncle
and
nephew
;
but
he
seemed
to
be
of
a
laconic
disposition
,
and
merely
said
:
  
"
How
goes
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
well
,
"
said
Mr
Gills
,
pushing
the
bottle
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
took
it
up
,
and
having
surveyed
and
smelt
it
,
said
with
extraordinary
expression
:
  
"
<EOS>
The
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
,
"
returned
the
Instrument
-
maker
.
  
<EOS>
Upon
that
he
whistled
as
he
filled
his
glass
,
and
seemed
to
think
they
were
making
holiday
indeed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
arranging
his
hair
(
which
was
thin
)
with
his
hook
,
and
then
pointing
it
at
the
Instrument
-
maker
,
"
Look
at
him
!
<EOS>
Love
!
<EOS>
Honour
!
<EOS>
And
Obey
!
<EOS>
Overhaul
your
catechism
till
you
find
that
passage
,
and
when
found
turn
the
leaf
down
.
<EOS>
Success
,
my
boy
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
so
perfectly
satisfied
both
with
his
quotation
and
his
reference
to
it
,
that
he
could
not
help
repeating
the
words
again
in
a
low
voice
,
and
saying
he
had
forgotten
'em
these
forty
year
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
never
wanted
two
or
three
words
in
my
life
that
I
did
n't
know
where
to
lay
my
hand
upon
'em
,
Gills
,
"
he
observed
.
<EOS>
"
It
comes
of
not
wasting
language
as
some
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
reflection
perhaps
reminded
him
that
he
had
better
,
like
young
Norval
's
father
,
"
increase
his
store
.
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
he
became
silent
,
and
remained
so
,
until
old
Sol
went
out
into
the
shop
to
light
it
up
,
when
he
turned
to
Walter
,
and
said
,
without
any
introductory
remark
:
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
he
could
make
a
clock
if
he
tried
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
wonder
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
returned
the
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
it
would
go
!
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
making
a
species
of
serpent
in
the
air
with
his
hook
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lord
,
how
that
clock
would
go
!
"
  
<EOS>
For
a
moment
or
two
he
seemed
quite
lost
in
contemplating
the
pace
of
this
ideal
timepiece
,
and
sat
looking
at
the
boy
as
if
his
face
were
the
dial
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
's
chockfull
of
science
,
"
he
observed
,
waving
his
hook
towards
the
stock
-
in
-
trade
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Look'ye
here
!
<EOS>
Here
's
a
collection
of
'em
.
<EOS>
Earth
,
air
,
or
water
.
<EOS>
It
's
all
one
.
<EOS>
Only
say
where
you
'll
have
it
.
<EOS>
Up
in
a
balloon
?
<EOS>
There
you
are
.
<EOS>
Down
in
a
bell
?
<EOS>
There
you
are
.
<EOS>
D'ye
want
to
put
the
North
Star
in
a
pair
of
scales
and
weigh
it
?
<EOS>
He
'll
do
it
for
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
may
be
gathered
from
these
remarks
that
Captain
Cuttle
's
reverence
for
the
stock
of
instruments
was
profound
,
and
that
his
philosophy
knew
little
or
no
distinction
between
trading
in
it
and
inventing
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
with
a
sigh
,
"
it
's
a
fine
thing
to
understand
'em
.
<EOS>
And
yet
it
's
a
fine
thing
not
to
understand
'em
.
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
which
is
best
.
<EOS>
It
's
so
comfortable
to
sit
here
and
feel
that
you
might
be
weighed
,
measured
,
magnified
,
electrified
,
polarized
,
played
the
very
devil
with
:
and
never
know
how
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Nothing
short
of
the
wonderful
Madeira
,
combined
with
the
occasion
(
which
rendered
it
desirable
to
improve
and
expand
Walter
's
mind
)
,
could
have
ever
loosened
his
tongue
to
the
extent
of
giving
utterance
to
this
prodigious
oration
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
quite
amazed
himself
at
the
manner
in
which
it
opened
up
to
view
the
sources
of
the
taciturn
delight
,
he
had
had
in
eating
Sunday
dinners
in
that
parlour
for
ten
years
.
<EOS>
Becoming
a
sadder
and
a
wiser
man
,
he
mused
and
held
his
peace
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
cried
the
subject
of
his
admiration
,
returning
.
<EOS>
"
Before
you
have
your
glass
of
grog
,
Ned
,
we
must
finish
the
bottle
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stand
by
!
"
<EOS>
said
Ned
,
filling
his
glass
.
<EOS>
"
Give
the
boy
some
more
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
more
,
thank'e
,
uncle
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
said
Sol
,
"
a
little
more
.
<EOS>
We
'll
finish
the
bottle
,
to
the
House
,
Ned
---
Walter
's
house
.
<EOS>
Why
it
may
be
his
house
one
of

days
,
in
part
.
<EOS>
Who
knows
?
<EOS>
Sir
Richard
Whittington
married
his

's
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
"
Turn
again
Whittington
,
Lord
Mayor

London
,
and
when
you
are
old
<EOS>
you
will

,
"
"

.
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
!
<EOS>
Overhaul
<EOS>
the
book
,
my
lad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
although
Mr
Dombey
has
n't
a
daughter
,
"
Sol
began
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
he
has
,
Uncle
,
"
said
the
boy
,
reddening
and
laughing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Has
he
?
"
cried
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Indeed
I
think
he
has
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
know
he
has
,
"
said
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
Some
of
'em
were
talking
about
it
in
the
office
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
And
they
do
say
,
Uncle
and
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
lowering

,
"
that
he
's
taken

dislike

her
,
and
that
she
's
left
,
unnoticed
,
among
the
servants
,
and
that
his
mind
's
so
set
all
the
while
upon
having
his
son
in
the
House
,
that
although
he
's
only
a
baby
now
,
he
is
going
to
have
balances
struck
oftener
than
formerly
,
and
the
books
kept
closer
than
they
used
to
be
,
and
has
even
been
seen
(
when
he
thought
he
was
n't
)
walking
in
the
Docks
,
looking
at
his
ships
and
property
and
all
that
,
as
if
he
was
exulting
like
,
over
what
he
and
his
son
will
possess
together
.
<EOS>
That
's
what
they
say
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
knows
all
about
her
already
,
you
see
,
"
said
the
Instrumentmaker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
Uncle
,
"
cried

boy
,
still
reddening
and
laughing
,
boy
-
like
.
"
How
can
I
help
hearing
what

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
Son
's
a
little
in
our
way
at
present
<EOS>
,
I
'm
afraid
,
Ned
,
"
said

old

,
humouring

.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
much
,
"
said

Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nevertheless
,
we
'll
drink
him
,
"
pursued
Sol
.
"
<EOS>
So
,
here
's
to
Dombey
and
Son
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
very
well
,
Uncle
,
"
said
the
boy
,
merrily
.
<EOS>
"
Since
you
have
introduced
the
mention
of
her
,
and
have

with

,
and
have

I
know

,
I
shall
make
bold
to

.
<EOS>
So
here
's
to
Dombey
---
and
Son
---
and
Daughter
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
5
.
<EOS>
Paul
's
Progress
and
Christeninghead
<EOS>
>
 
<EOS>
LITTLE
Paul
,
suffering
no
contamination
,
from
the
blood
of
the
Toodles
,
grew
stouter
and
stronger
every
day
.
<EOS>
Every
day
,
too
,
he
was
more
and
more
ardently
cherished
by
Miss
Tox
,
whose
devotion
was
so
far
appreciated
by
Mr
Dombey
that
he
began
to
regard
her
as
a
woman
of
great
natural
good
sense
,
whose
feelings
did
her
credit
and
deserved
encouragement
.
<EOS>
He
was
so
lavish
of
this
condescension
,
that
he
not
only
bowed
to
her
,
in
a
particular
manner
,
on
several
occasions
,
but
even
entrusted
such
stately
recognitions
of
her
to
his
sister
as
"
pray
tell
your
friend
,
Louisa
,
that
she
is
very
good
,
"
or
"
mention
to
Miss
Tox
,
Louisa
,
that
I
am
obliged
to
her
;
"
specialities
which
made
a
deep
impression
on
the
lady
thus
distinguished
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
was
often
in
the
habit
of
assuring
Mrs
Chick
,
that
"
nothing
could
exceed
her
interest
in
all
connected
with
the
development
of
that
sweet
child
;
"
and
an
observer
of
Miss
Tox
's
proceedings
might
have
inferred
so
much
without
declaratory
confirmation
.
<EOS>
She
would
preside
over
the
innocent
repasts
of
the
young
heir
,
with
ineffable
satisfaction
,
almost
with
an
air
of
joint
proprietorship
with
Richards
in
the
entertainment
.
<EOS>
At
the
little
ceremonies
of
the
bath
and
toilette
,
she
assisted
with
enthusiasm
.
<EOS>
The
administration
of
infantine
doses
of
physic
awakened
all
the
active
sympathy
of
her
character
;
and
being
on
one
occasion
secreted
in
a
cupboard
(
whither
she
had
fled
in
modesty
)
,
when
Mr
Dombey
was
introduced
into
the
nursery
by
his
sister
,
to
behold
his
son
,
in
the
course
of
preparation
for
bed
,
taking
a
short
walk
uphill
over
Richards
's
gown
,
in
a
short
and
airy
linen
jacket
,
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
was
so
transported
beyond
the
ignorant
present
as
to
be
unable
to
refrain
from
crying
out
,
"
<EOS>
Is
he
not
beautiful
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey!Is
he
not
a
Cupid
,
Sir
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
almost
sinking
behind
the
closet
door
with
confusion
and
blushes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Louisa
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
one
day
,
to
his
sister
,
"
<EOS>
I
really
think
I
must
present
your
friend
with
some
little
token
,
on
the
occasion
of
Paul
's
christening
.
<EOS>
She
has
exerted
herself
so
warmly
in
the
child
's
behalf
from
the
first
,
and
seems
to
understand
her
position
so
thoroughly
(
a
very
rare
merit
in
this
world
,
I
am
sorry
to
say
)
,
that
it
would
really
be
agreeable
to
me
to
notice
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
Let
it
be
no
detraction
from
the
merits
of
Miss
Tox
,
to
hint
that
in
Mr
Dombey
's
eyes
,
as
in
some
others
that
occasionally
see
the
light
,
they
only
achieved
that
mighty
piece
of
knowledge
,
the
understanding
of
their
own
position
,
who
showed
a
fitting
reverence
for
his
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
so
much
their
merit
that
they
knew
themselves
,
as
that
they
knew
him
,
and
bowed
low
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Paul
,
"
returned
his
sister
,
"
you
do
Miss
Tox
but
justice
,
as
a
man
of
your
penetration
was
sure
,
I
knew
,
to
do
.
<EOS>
I
believe
if
there
are
three
words
in
the
English
language
for
which
she
has
a
respect
amounting
almost
to
veneration
,
those
words
are
,
Dombey
and
Son
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
I
believe
it
.
<EOS>
It
does
Miss
Tox
credit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
as
to
anything
in
the
shape
of
a
token
,
my
dear
Paul
,
"
pursued
his
sister
,
"
<EOS>
all
I
can
say
is
that
anything
you
give
Miss
Tox
will
be
hoarded
and
prized
,
I
am
sure
,
like
a
relic
.
<EOS>
But
there
is
a
way
,
my
dear
Paul
,
of
showing
your
sense
of
Miss
Tox
's
friendliness
in
a
still
more
flattering
and
acceptable
manner
,
if
you
should
be
so
inclined
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
is
that
?
"
asked
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Godfathers
,
of
course
,
"
continued
Mrs
Chick
,
"
are
important
in
point
of
connexion
and
influence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
why
they
should
be
,
to
my
son
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
coldly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
true
,
my
dear
Paul
,
"
retorted
Mrs
Chick
,
with
an
extraordinary
show
of
animation
,
to
cover
the
suddenness
of
her
conversion
;
"
and
spoken
like
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
might
have
expected
nothing
else
from
you
.
<EOS>
I
might
have
known
that
such
would
have
been
your
opinion
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
;
"
here
Mrs
Chick
flattered
again
,
as
not
quite
comfortably
feeling
her
way
;
"
perhaps
that
is
a
reason
why
you
might
have
the
less
objection
to
allowing
Miss
Tox
to
be
godmother
to
the
dear
thing
,
if
it
were
only
as
deputy
and
proxy
for
some
one
else
.
<EOS>
That
it
would
be
received
as
a
great
honour
and
distinction
,
Paul
,
I
need
not
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Louisa
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
after
a
short
pause
,
"
it
is
not
to
be
supposed
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
not
,
"
cried
Mrs
Chick
,
hastening
to
anticipate
a
refusal
,
"
I
never
thought
it
was
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
looked
at
her
impatiently
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
flurry
me
,
my
dear
Paul
,
"
said
his
sister
;
"
for
that
destroys
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
far
from
strong
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
quite
myself
,
since
poor
dear
Fanny
departed
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
glanced
at
the
pocket
-
handkerchief
which
his
sister
applied
to
her
eyes
,
and
resumed
:
  
"
It
is
not
to
be
supposed
,
I
say
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
I
say
,
"
murmured
Mrs
Chick
,
"
that
I
never
thought
it
was
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
Heaven
,
Louisa
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
Paul
,
"
she

with
tearful

,
"
I
must
really
be
allowed
to
speak
.
<EOS>
I
am
not

,
or
so

,
or

,

anything
,

you
are
.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
So

the
worse
for
me
.
<EOS>
But

were
the
last

.
<EOS>
I

utter
---
and

should

,
Paul
,
after
poor
dear
Fanny
<EOS>
---
I
should
still

I
never

was
.
<EOS>
And

,
"
added

Chick

,
as
if
she
had
withheld

until

,
"
I
never
did
think
it
was
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
walked
to
the
window
and
back
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
to
be
supposed
,
Louisa
,
"
he
said
(
Mrs
Chick
had
nailed

to

,
and

"
I
know

is

,
"
but
he
took

)
,
"
but
that
there

many
persons
who
,
supposing
that
I
recognised
any
claim
at
all
in
such

case
,
have
a
claim
upon
me
superior
to
Miss
Tox
's
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
not
.
<EOS>
I
recognise
no
such
thing
.
<EOS>
Paul
and
myself
will
be
able
,
when
the
time
comes
,
to
hold
our
own
---
the
house
,
in
other
words
,
will
be
able
to
hold
its
own
,
and
maintain
its
own
,
and
hand
down
its
own
of
itself
,
and
without
any
such
common
-
place
aids
.
<EOS>
The
kind
of
foreign
help
which
people
usually
seek
for
their
children
,
I
can
afford
to
despise
;
being
above
it
,
I
hope
.
<EOS>
So
that
Paul
's
infancy
and
childhood
pass
away
well
,
and
<EOS>
I
see
him
becoming
qualified
without
waste
of
time
for
the
career
on
which
he
is
destined
to
enter
,
I
am
satisfied
.
<EOS>
He
will
make
what

friends
he
pleases
in
after
-
life
,
when
he
is
actively
maintaining
---
and
extending
,
if
that

---
the
dignity
and

of
the
Firm
.
<EOS>
Until
then
,
I
am
enough
for
him
,
perhaps
,
and
all
in
all
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
wish
that
people
should
step
in
between

.
<EOS>
I
would
much
rather
show
my
sense
of
the
obliging
conduct
of
a
deserving
person
like
your
friend
.
<EOS>
Therefore
let
it
be
so
;
and
your
husband
and
myself
will
do
well
enough
for
the
other
sponsors
,
I
dare
say
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
these
remarks
,
delivered
with
great
majesty
and
grandeur
,
Mr
Dombey
had
truly
revealed
the
secret
feelings
of
his
breast
.
<EOS>
An
indescribable
distrust
of
anybody
stepping
in
between
himself
and
his
son
;
a
haughty
dread
of
having
any
rival
or
partner
in
the
boy
's
respect
and
deference
;
a
sharp
misgiving
,
recently
acquired
,
that
he
was
not
infallible
in
his
power
of
bending
and
binding
human
wills
;
as
sharp
a
jealousy
of
any
second
check
or
cross
;
these
were
,
at
that
time
,
the
master
keys
of
his
soul
.
<EOS>
In
all
his
life
,
he
had
never
made
a
friend
.
<EOS>
His
cold
and
distant
nature
had
neither
sought
one
nor
found
one
.
<EOS>
And
now
when
that
nature
concentrated
its
whole
force
so
strongly
on
a
partial
scheme
of
parental
interest
and
ambition
,
it
seemed
as
if
its
icy
current
,
instead
of
being
released
by
this
influence
,
and
running
clear
and

,
had
thawed
for
but
an
instant
to
admit
its
burden
,
and
then
frozen
with
it
into
one
unyielding

.
  
<EOS>
Elevated
thus
to
the
godmothership
of
little
Paul
,
<EOS>
in
virtue
of
her
insignificance
,
Miss
Tox
was
from
that
hour
chosen
and
appointed
to
office
;
and
Mr
Dombey
further
signified
his
pleasure
that
the
ceremony
,
already
long

,
should
take
place
without
further

.
<EOS>
His
sister
,
who
had
been
far
from
anticipating
so
signal
a
success
,
withdrew
as
soon
as
she
could
,
to
communicate
it
to
her
best
of
friends
;
and
Mr
Dombey
was
left
alone
in
his
library
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
anything
but
solitude
in
the
nursery
;
for
there
,
Mrs
Chick
and
Miss
Tox
were
enjoying
a
social
evening
,
so
much
to
the
disgust
of
Miss
Susan
Nipper
,
that
that
young
lady
embraced
every
opportunity
of
making
wry
faces
behind
the
door
.
<EOS>
Her
feelings
were
so
much
excited
on
the
occasion
,
that
she
found
it
indispensable
to
afford
them
this
relief
,
even
without
having
the
comfort
of
any

or

.
<EOS>
As
the
knight
-

of
old
relieved
their

by
carving
their

's
names
in

,
and

,
and
other
savage
places
where
there
was
no

of
there
ever
being
anybody
to
red
them
,
so
did
Miss
Susan
Nipper
curl
her

into
drawers
and

,
put
away
winks
of
disparagement

,
shed

into
stone

,

and

names
out

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

,

's

,
saw
little

safe

,
airy

,

;
and

.
<EOS>
The

now
lay
,
through
the
good

of
Polly
,
in
one

;
and

was
not
until

were

at
their

-
table
that
happening

the
little
beds
<EOS>
,

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

"
Her

,

!
"

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah

!
"
  
<EOS>
A

in
,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
quite

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

do

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

?

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I
never

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Far

.
<EOS>
Yet

I

her
!
"
  
<EOS>
What

it
was
to
Mrs
Chick
---
a
common
-
place
piece
of
<EOS>
folly
enough
,
compared
with
whom
her
sister
-
in
-
law
had
been

very
angel
of

and

---
to

and

to
the

of
that

:
in

of
her
conduct
to
her
in

:
and
to
thoroughly
believe
herself
,
and
take

in
and
make
herself

comfortable
on
the
strength
of
her
toleration!What
a
mighty
pleasant
virtue
toleration
should
be
when
we
are
right
,
to

so
very
pleasant
when
we
are
wrong
,
and
quite
unable
to
demonstrate
how
we
come
to
be
invested
with
the
privilege
of
exercising
it
!
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
was
yet
drying
her
eyes
and
shaking
her
head
,
when
Richards
made
bold
to
caution
her
that
Miss
Florence
was
awake
and
sitting
in
her
bed
.
<EOS>
She
had
risen
,
as
the
nurse
said
,
and
the
lashes
of
her
eyes
were
wet
with
tears
.
<EOS>
But
no
one
saw
them
glistening
save
Polly
.
<EOS>
No
one
else
leant
over
her
,
and
whispered
soothing
words
to
her
,
or
was
near

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
dear
nurse
!
<EOS>
"
said

child
,
looking

up
in

,
"
let
me
lie
by

brother
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
pet
?
"
said
Richards
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
Pray

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs

interposed
with

about

like

dear
,
but
Florence
repeated

,
with

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
not

,
"
she
said
,

.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
only
touch

,

.
<EOS>
Oh
,

,

,

by

-

,

I

's

!
"
  
<EOS>
Richards
took
her
without

word
,
and
carrying
her
to
the
little
bed
in

the
infant

,
laid

.
<EOS>
She

as

as

without
disturbing

;
and

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
little
thing
,
"
said

Tox
;
"
she
has

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
This
trivial

had
so

current
of
conversation
,
that
it
was
difficult
of

;
and
Mrs
Chick
moreover
had
been

by

of

,
that

.
<EOS>
The

friends

soon

their

,

.
<EOS>
Miss

had

,
and

work

,

.

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Though

<EOS>

<EOS>
Ugh
!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

The

---

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
Was
Mr
Dombey
pleased
to

?
<EOS>
He

no

by
the

of
a

;
but
outward

.
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr

,
"

,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
In

<EOS>

they
were
received
by
a
portentous
beadle
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
dismounting
first
to
help
the
ladies
out
,
and
standing
near
him
at
the
church
door
,
looked
like
another
beadle
.
<EOS>
A
beadle
less
gorgeous
but
more
dreadful
;
the
beadle
of
private
life
;
the
beadle
of
our
business
and
our
bosoms
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
's
hand
trembled
as
she
slipped
it
through
Mr
Dombey
's
arm
,
and
felt
herself
escorted
up
the
steps
,
preceded
by
a
cocked
hat
and
a
Babylonian
collar
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
for
a
moment
like
that
other
solemn
institution
,
"
Wilt
thou
have
this
man
,
Lucretia
?
"
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Please
to
bring
the
child
in
quick
out
of
the
air
there
,
"
whispered
the
beadle
,
holding
open
the
inner
door
of
the
church
.
  
<EOS>
Little
Paul
might
have
asked
with
Hamlet
"
into
my
grave
?
"
<EOS>
so
chill
and
earthy
was
the
place
.
<EOS>
The
tall
shrouded
pulpit
and
reading
desk
;
the
dreary
perspective
of
empty
pews
stretching
away
under
the
galleries
,
and
empty
benches
mounting
to
the
roof
and
lost
in
the
shadow
of
the
great
grim
organ
;
the
dusty
matting
and
cold
stone
slabs
;
the
grisly
free
seats
in
the
aisles
;
and
the
damp
corner
by
the
bell
-
rope
,
where
the
black
trestles
used
for
funerals
were
stowed
away
,
along
with
some
shovels
and
baskets
,
and
a
coil
or
two
of
deadly
-
looking
rope
;
the
strange
,
unusual
,
uncomfortable
smell
,
and
the
cadaverous
light
;
were
all
in
unison
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
cold
and
dismal
scene
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
wedding
just
on
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
beadle
,
"
but
it
'll
be
over
directly
,
if
you
'll
walk
into
the
westry
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Before
he
turned
again
to
lead
the
way
,
he
gave
Mr
Dombey
a
bow
and
a
half
smile
of
recognition
,
importing
that
he
(
the
beadle
)
remembered
to
have
had
