on
him
when
he
buried
his
wife
,
and
hoped
he
had
enjoyed
himself
since
.
  
<EOS>
The
very
wedding
looking
dismal
as
they
passed
in
front
of
the
altar
.
<EOS>
The
bride
was
too
old
and
the
bridegroom
too
young
,
and
a
superannuated
beau
with
one
eye
and
an
eye
-
glass
stuck
in
its
blank
companion
,
was
giving
away
the
lady
,
while
the
friends
were
shivering
.
<EOS>
In
the
vestry
the
fire
was
smoking
;
and
an
over
-
aged
and
over
-
worked
and
under
-
paid
attorney
's
clerk
,
"
making
a
search
,
"
was
running
his
forefinger
down
the
parchment
pages
of
an
immense
register
(
one
of
a
long
series
of
similar
volumes
)
gorged
with
burials
.
<EOS>
Over
the
fireplace
was
a
ground
-
plan
of
the
vaults
underneath
the
church
;
and
Mr
Chick
,
skimming
the
literary
portion
of
it
aloud
,
by
way
of
enlivening
the
company
,
read
the
reference
to
Mrs
Dombey
's
tomb
in
full
,
before
he
could
stop
himself
.
  
<EOS>
After
another
cold
interval
,
a
wheezy
little
pew
-
opener
afflicted
with
an
asthma
,
appropriate
to
the
churchyard
,
if
not
to
the
church
,
summoned
them
to
the
font
.
<EOS>
Here
they
waited
some
little
time
while
the
marriage
party
enrolled
themselves
;
and
meanwhile
the
wheezy
little
pew
-
opener
---
partly
in
consequence
of
her
infirmity
,
and
partly
that
the
marriage
party
might
not
forget
her
---
went
about
the
building
coughing
like
a
grampus
.
  
<EOS>
Presently
the
clerk
(
the
only
cheerful
-
looking
object
there
,
and
was
an
undertaker
)
came
up
with
a
jug
of
warm
water
,
and
said
something
,
as
he
poured
it
into
the
font
,
about
taking
the
chill
off
;
which
millions
of
gallons
boiling
hot
could
not
have
done
for
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
Then
the
clergyman
,
an
amiable
and
mild
-
looking
young
curate
,
but
obviously
afraid
of
the
baby
,
appeared
like
the
principal
character
in
a
ghost
-
story
,
"
a
tall
figure
all
in
white
;
"
at
sight
of
whom
Paul
rent
the
air
with
his
cries
,
and
never
left
again
till
he
was
taken
out
black
in
the
face
.
  
<EOS>
Even
when
that
event
had
happened
,
to
the
great
relief
of
everybody
,
he
was
heard
under
the
portico
,
during
the
rest
of
the
ceremony
,
now
fainter
,
now
louder
,
now
hushed
,
now
bursting
forth
again
with
an
irrepressible
sense
of
his
wrongs
.
<EOS>
This
so
distracted
the
attention
of
the
two
ladies
,
that
Mrs
Chick
was
constantly
deploying
into
the
centre
aisle
,
to
send
out
messages
by
the
pew
-
opener
,
while
Miss
Tox
kept
her
Prayer
-
book
open
at
the
Gunpowder
Plot
,
and
occasionally
read
responses
from
that
service
.
  
<EOS>
During
the
whole
of
these
proceedings
,
Mr
Dombey
remained
as
impassive
and
gentlemanly
as
ever
,
and
perhaps
assisted
in
making
it
so
cold
,
that
the
young
curate
smoked
at
the
mouth
as
he
read
.
<EOS>
The
only
time
that
he
unbent
his
visage
in
the
least
,
was
when
the
clergyman
,
in

(
very

and

)
the

,
relative
to
the
future
examination
of
the
child
by
the

,
happened

rest
his

on
Mr
Chick
;
and
then
Mr
Dombey
might
have
been
seen
to
express
by
a
majestic
look
,
that
he
would
like
to
catch
him
at
it
.
  
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
well
for
Mr
Dombey
,
if
he
had
thought
of
his
own
dignity
a
little
less
;
and
had
thought
of
the
great
origin
and
purpose
of
the
ceremony
in
which
he
took
so
formal
and
so
stiff
<EOS>
a
part
,
a
little
more
.
<EOS>
His
arrogance
contrasted
strangely
with
its
history
.
  
<EOS>
When
it
was
all
over
,
he
again
gave
his
arm
to
Miss
Tox
,
and
conducted
her
to
the
vestry
,
where
he
informed
the
clergyman
how
much
pleasure
it
would
have
given
him
to
have
solicited
the
honour
of
his
company
at
dinner
,
but
for
the
unfortunate
state
of
his
household
affairs
.
<EOS>
The
register
signed
,
and
the
fees
paid
,
and
the
pew
-
opener
(
whose
cough
was
very
bad
again
)
remembered
,
and
the

gratified
,
and
the
sexton
(
who
was
accidentally
on
the
door
-
steps
,
looking
with
great
interest
at
the
weather
)
not
forgotten
,
they
got
into
the
carriage
again
,
and
drove
home
in
the
same
bleak
fellowship
.
  
<EOS>
There
they
found
Mr
Pitt
turning
up
his
nose
at
a
cold
collation
,
set
forth
in
a
cold
pomp
of
glass
and
silver
,
and
looking
more
like
a
dead
dinner
lying
in
state
than

.
<EOS>
On

Miss
Tox
produced
a

for
her

,
and
Mr
Chick
a
knife
and
fork
and

in
a
case
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
also
produced
a
bracelet
for
Miss
Tox
;
and
,
on
the
receipt
of
this
token
,
Miss
Tox
was

affected
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
John
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
will
you
take
the
bottom
of
the
table
,
if

?
<EOS>
What
have
you
got
there
,
Mr
John
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
a
cold
fillet
of
veal
here
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Chick
,
rubbing
his
numbed
hands
hard

.
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
got
there
,
Sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
returned

,
"
is
some
cold
preparation
of
calf
's
head
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
I
see
cold
fowls
---
ham
---
patties
---
salad
---
lobster
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
will
do

?
<EOS>
Champagne
to
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
toothache
in
everything
.
<EOS>
The
wine
was
so

cold
that
it
forced

Miss
Tox
,
which
she

great

in
turning
into
a
"
Hem
!
"
<EOS>
The
veal
had
come
from

,
that

of
it
had
struck
a

as
of
cold

to
Mr
Chick
's

.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
alone
remained

.
<EOS>
He
might
have
been
hung
up
for
sale
at
a
Russian
fair
as

of

.
  
<EOS>
The
prevailing
influence
was
too
much
even
for
his
sister
.
<EOS>
She
made
no
effort
at
flattery
or
small
talk
,
and
directed
all
her

to
looking
as
warm
as
she
could
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Chick
,

,
after

,
and

;
<EOS>
"
I
shall

,

,

,

Paul
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bless

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
little
Dombey
!
<EOS>
"

Chick
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
John
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
with
severe
gravity
,
"
my
son
would
feel
and
express

obliged
to
you
,
<EOS>
I
have
no

,
if
he
could

.
<EOS>
He
will
prove
,

,

,

any

that
the

of

,
in

,
or

,

,

.

<EOS>
The

admitting

nothing

<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
Not

,

,

"
Louisa
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Onerous

of

may
<EOS>
---
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Expose

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
It
was
more
rounded

.
<EOS>
Obliging

,

<EOS>
"
Impose

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
Miss

together
lightly
,
in

;
and

,

,
"
eloquence

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
in
the

,

the

of
Richards
,
who
now
entered
curtseying
,
but
without
the
baby
;
Paul
being
asleep
after
the
fatigues
of

.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
having
delivered

to
this

,
addressed
her
in
the
following

:
Miss
Tox
previously
settling
her
head
on
one
side
,
and
making
other

for

on

.
  
<EOS>
"
During

or

,
Richards
,
which

seen

an

of
this

,

.
<EOS>
Desiring

,

how

,

"
  
"
Chick

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Richards

,

,
"

,

,

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Richards
quailed
under
the

of
the
reproof
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
far
from
being
friendly
,
"
pursued
Mr
Dombey
,
"
to
what
is
called
by

of
levelling

,
general

.
<EOS>
But
it
is
necessary
that
the
inferior
classes
should
continue
to
be
taught
to
know

position
,
and
to
conduct

properly
.
<EOS>
So
far
I
approve
of
schools
.
<EOS>
Having
the
power
of
nominating
a
child
on
the

of
an
ancient

,
called
(
from

)
<EOS>
the

;

,

;

(

,

Mrs

,
with

)

an
existing

;
and

has
this

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

of
her
son
,
I

,
"
said

Dombey
,

-

,
"
is

-

.
<EOS>
Louisa
,
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
One
hundred
and
forty
-
seven
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
dress
,
Richards
,
is
a
nice
,
warm
,
blue

tailed
coat
and
cap
,
turned
up
with

;
red

;
and

small

.
<EOS>
One
might

the
articles
one's
-
self
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
with
enthusiasm
,
"
and
be
grateful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
Richards
!
"
said
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
indeed
,
you
may
be
proud
.
<EOS>
The
Charitable
Grinders
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
am
very
much
obliged
,
Sir
,
"
returned
Richards
faintly
,
"
and
take
it
very
kind
that
you
should
remember
my
little
ones
.
<EOS>
"
At
the
same
time
a
vision
of
Biler
as
a
charitable
Grinder
,
with
his
very
small
legs
encased
in
the
serviceable
clothing
described
by
Mrs
Chick
,
swam
before
Richards
's
eyes
,
and
made
them
water
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
to
see
you
have
so
much
feeling
,
Richards
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
makes
one
almost
hope
,
it
really
does
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
who
prided
herself
on
taking
trustful
views
of
human
nature
,
"
that
there
may
yet
be
some
faint
spark
of
gratitude
and
right
feeling
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Richards
deferred
to
these
compliments
by
curtseying
and
murmuring
her
thanks
;
but
finding
it
quite
impossible
to
recover
her
spirits
from
the
disorder
into
which
they
had
been
thrown
by
the
image
of
her
son
in
his
precocious
nether
garments
,
she
gradually
approached
the
door
and
was
heartily
relieved
to
escape
by
it
.
  
<EOS>
Such
temporary
indications
of
a
partial
thaw
that
had
appeared
with
her
,
vanished
with
her
;
and
the
frost
set
in
again
,
as
cold
and
hard
as
ever
.
<EOS>
Mr
Chick
was
twice
heard
to
hum
a
tune
at
the
bottom
of
the
table
,
but
on
both
occasions
it
was
a
fragment
of
the
Dead
March
in
Saul
.
<EOS>
The
party
seemed
to
get
colder
and
colder
,
and
to
be
gradually
resolving
itself
into
a
congealed
and
solid
state
,
like
the
collation
round
which
it
was
assembled
.
<EOS>
At
length
Mrs
Chick
looked
at
Miss
Tox
,
and
Miss
Tox
returned
the
look
,
and
they
both
rose
and
said
it
was
really
time
to
go
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
receiving
this
announcement
with
perfect
equanimity
<EOS>
,
they
took
leave
of
that
gentleman
,
and
presently
departed
under
the
protection
of
Mr
Chick
;
who
,
when
they
had
turned
their
backs
upon
the
house
and
left
its
master
in
his
usual
solitary
state
,
put
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
threw
himself
back
in
the
carriage
,
and
whistled
"
With
a
hey
ho
chevy
!
<EOS>
"
all
through
;
conveying
into
his
face
as
he
did
so
,
an
expression
of
such
gloomy
and
terrible
defiance
,
that
Mrs
Chick
dared
not
protest
,
or
in
any
way
molest
him
.
  
<EOS>
Richards
,
though
she
had
little
Paul
on
her
lap
,
could
not
forget
her
own
first
-
born
.
<EOS>
She
felt
it
was
ungrateful
;
but
the
influence
of
the
day
fell
even
on
the
Charitable
Grinders
,
and
she
could
hardly
help
regarding
his
pewter
badge
,
number
one
hundred
and
forty
-
seven
,
as
,
somehow
,
a
part
of
its
formality
and
sternness
.
<EOS>
She
spoke
,
too
,
in
the
nursery
,
of
his
"
blessed
legs
,
"
and
was
again
troubled
by
his
spectre
in
uniform
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
I
would
n't
give
,
"
said
Polly
,
"
to
see
the
poor
little
dear
before
he
gets
used
to
'
em
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
I
tell
you
what
,
Mrs
Richards
,
"
retorted
Nipper
,
who
had
been
admitted
to
her
confidence
,
"
see
him
and
make
your
mind
easy
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dombey
would
n't
like
it
,
"
said
Polly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
would
n't
he
,
Mrs
Richards
!
"
retorted
Nipper
,
"
he
'd
like
it
very
much
,
I
think
,
when
he
was
asked
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
ask
him
,
I
suppose
,
at
all
?
"
said
Polly
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Mrs
Richards
,
quite
contrairy
,
"
returned
Susan
,
"
and
them
tow
inspectors
Tox
and
Chick
,
not
intending
to
be
on
duty
to
-
morrow
,
<EOS>
as
I
heard
'em
say
,
me
and
Miss
Floy
will
go
along
with
you
to
-
morrow
morning
,
and
welcome
,
<EOS>
Mrs
Richards
,
if
you
like
,
for
we
may
as
well
walk
there
,
as
up
and
down
a
street
,
and
better
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
Polly
rejected
the
idea
pretty
stoutly
at
first
;
but
by
little
and
little
she
began
to
entertain
it
,
as
she
entertained
more
and
more
distinctly
the
forbidden
pictures
of
her
children
,
and
her
own
home
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
arguing
that
there
could
be
no
great
harm
in
calling
for
a
moment
at
the
door
,
she
yielded
to
the
Nipper
proposition
.
  
<EOS>
The
matter
being
settled
thus
,
little
Paul
began
to
cry
most
piteously
,
as
if
he
had
a
foreboding
that
no
good
would
come
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
with
the
child
?
"
asked
Susan
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
cold
,
I
think
,
"
said
Polly
,
walking
with
him
to
and
fro
,
and
hushing
him
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
bleak
autumnal
afternoon
indeed
;
and
as
she
walked
,
and
hushed
,
and
,
glancing
through
the
dreary
windown
,
pressed
the
little
fellow
closer
to
her
breast
,
the
withered
leaves
came
showering
down
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
6
.
<EOS>
Paul
's
Second
Deprivation
 
<EOS>
POLLY
was
beset
by
so
many
misgivings
in
the
morning
,
that
but
for
the
incessant
promptings
of
her
black
-
eyed
companion
,
she
would
have
abandoned
all
thoughts
of
the
expedition
,
and
formally
petitioned
for
leave
to
see
number
one
hundred
and
forty
-
seven
,
under
the
awful
shadow
of
Mr
Dombey
's
roof
.
<EOS>
But
Susan
who
was
personally
disposed
in
favour
of
the
excursion
,
and
who
(
like
Tony
Lumpkin
)
,
if
she
could
bear
the
disappointments
of
other
people
with
tolerable
fortitude
,
could
not
abide
to
disappoint
herself
,
threw
so
many
ingenious
doubts
in
the
way
of
this
second
thought
,
and
stimulated
the
original
intention
with
so
many
ingenious
arguments
,
that
almost
as
soon
as
Mr
Dombey
's
stately
back
was
turned
,
and
that
gentleman
was
pursuing
his
daily
road
towards
the
City
,
his
unconscious
son
was
on
his
way
to
Staggs
's
Gardens
.
  
<EOS>
This
euphonious
locality
was
situated
in
a
suburb
,
known
by
the
inhabitants
of
Staggs
's
Gardens
by
the
name
of
Camberling
Town
;
a
designation
which
the
Strangers
'
Map
of
London
,
as
printed
(
with
a
view
to
pleasant
and
commodious
reference
)
on
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
,
condenses
,
with
some
show
of
reason
,
into
Camden
Town
.
<EOS>
Hither
the
two
nurses
bent
their
steps
,
accompanied
by
their
charges
;
<EOS>
Richards
carrying
Paul
,
of
course
,
and
Susan
leading
little
Florence
by
the
hand
,
and
giving
her
such
jerks
and
pokes
from
time
to
time
,
as
she
considered
it
wholesome
to
administer
.
  
<EOS>
The
first
shock
of
a
great
earthquake
had
,
just
at
that
period
,
rent
the
whole
neighbourhood
to
its
centre
.
<EOS>
Traces
of
its
course
were
visible
on
every
side
.
<EOS>
Houses
were
knocked
down
;
streets
broken
through
and
stopped
;
deep
pits
and
trenches
dug
in
the
ground
;
enormous
heaps
of
earth
and
clay
thrown
up
;
buildings
that
were
undermined
and
shaking
,
propped
by
great
beams
of
wood
.
<EOS>
Here
,
a
chaos
of
carts
,
overthrown
and
jumbled
together
,
lay
topsy
-
turvy
at
the
bottom
of
a
steep
unnatural
hill
;
there
,
confused
treasures
of
iron
soaked
and
rusted
in
something
that
had
accidentally
become
a
pond
.
<EOS>
Everywhere
were
bridges
that
led
nowhere
;
thoroughfares
that
were
wholly
impassable
;
Babel
towers
of
chimneys
,
wanting
half
their
height
;
temporary
wooden
houses
and
enclosures
,
in
the
most
unlikely
situations
;
carcases
of
ragged
tenements
,
and
fragments
of
unfinished
walls
and
arches
,
and
piles
of
scaffolding
,
and
wildernesses
of
bricks
,
and
giant
forms
of
cranes
,
and
tripods
straddling
above
nothing
.
<EOS>
There
were
a
hundred
thousand
shapes
and
substances
of
incompleteness
,
wildly
mingled
out
of
their
places
,
upside
down
,
burrowing
in
the
earth
,
aspiring
in
the
air
,
mouldering
in
the
water
,
and
unintelligible
as
any
dream
.
<EOS>
Hot
springs
and
fiery
eruptions
,
the
usual
attendants
upon
earthquakes
,
lent
their
contributions
of
confusion
to
the
scene
.
<EOS>
Boiling
water
hissed
and
heaved
within
dilapidated
walls
;
whence
,
also
,
the
glare
and
roar
of
flames
came
issuing
forth
;
and
mounds
of
ashes
blocked
up
rights
of
way
,
and
wholly
changed
the
law
and
custom
of
the
neighbourhood
.
  
<EOS>
In
short
,
the
yet
unfinished
and
unopened
Railroad
was
in
progress
;
and
,
from
the
very
core
of
all
this
dire
disorder
,
trailed
smoothly
away
,
upon
its
mighty
course
of
civilisation
and
improvement
.
  
<EOS>
But
as
yet
,
the
neighbourhood
was
shy
to
own
the
Railroad
.
<EOS>
One
or
two
bold
speculators
had
projected
streets
;
and
one
had
built
a
little
,
but
had
stopped
among
the
mud
and
ashes
to
consider
farther
of
it
.
<EOS>
A
bran
-
new
Tavern
,
redolent
of
fresh
mortar
and
size
,
and
fronting
nothing
at
all
,
had
taken
for
its
sign
The
Railway
Arms
;
but
that
might
be
rash
enterprise
---
and
then
it
hoped
to
sell
drink
to
the
workmen
.
<EOS>
So
,
the
Excavators
'
House
of
Call
had
sprung
up
from
a
beer
-
shop
;
and
the
old
-
established
Ham
and
Beef
Shop
had
become
the
Railway
Eating
House
,
with
a
roast
leg
of
pork
daily
,
through
interested
motives
of
a
similar
immediate
and
popular
description
.
<EOS>
Lodging
-
house
keepers
were
favourable
in
like
manner
;
and
for
the
like
reasons
were
not
to
be
trusted
.
<EOS>
The
general
belief
was
very
slow
.
<EOS>
There
were
frowzy
fields
,
and
cow
-
houses
,
and
dunghills
,
and
dustheaps
,
and
ditches
,
and
gardens
,
and
summer
-
houses
,
and
carpet
-
beating
grounds
,
at
the
very
door
of
the
Railway
.
<EOS>
Little
tumuli
of
oyster
shells
in
the
oyster
season
,
and
of
lobster
shells
in
the
lobster
season
,
and
of
broken
crockery
and
faded
cabbage
leaves
in
all
seasons
,
encroached
upon
its
high
places
.
<EOS>
Posts
,
and
rails
,
and
old
cautions
to
trespassers
,
and
backs
of
mean
houses
,
and
patches
of
wretched
vegetation
,
stared
it
out
of
countenance
.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
the
better
for
it
,
or
thought
of
being
so
.
<EOS>
If
the
miserable
waste
ground
lying
near
it
could
have
laughed
,
it
would
have
laughed
it
to
scorn
,
like
many
of
the
miserable
neighbours
.
  
<EOS>
Staggs
's
Gardens
was
uncommonly
incredulous
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
row
of
houses
,
with
little
squalid
patches
of
ground
before
them
,
fenced
off
with
old
doors
,
barrel
staves
,
scraps
of
tarpaulin
,
and
dead
bushes
;
with
bottomless
tin
kettles
and
exhausted
iron
fenders
,
thrust
into
the
gaps
.
<EOS>
Here
,
the
Staggs
's
Gardeners
trained
scarlet
beans
,
kept
fowls
and
rabbits
,
erected
rotten
summer
-
houses
(
one
was
an
old
boat
)
,
dried
clothes
,
and
smoked
pipes
.
<EOS>
Some
were
of
opinion
that
Staggs
's
Gardens
derived
its
name
from
a
deceased
capitalist
,
one
Mr
Staggs
,
who
had
built
it
for
his
delectation
.
<EOS>
Others
,
who
had
a
natural
taste
for
the
country
,
held
that
it
dated
from
those
rural
times
when
the
antlered
herd
,
under
the
familiar
denomination
of
Staggses
,
had
resorted
to
its
shady
precincts
.
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
may
,
Staggs
's
Gardens
was
regarded
by
its
population
as
a
sacred
grove
not
to
be
withered
by
railroads
;
and
so
confident
were
they
generally
of
its
long
outliving
any
such
ridiculous
inventions
,
that
the
master
chimney
-
sweeper
at
the
corner
,
who
was
understood
to
take
the
lead
in
the
local
politics
of
the
Gardens
,
had
publicly
declared
that
on
the
occasion
of
the
Railroad
opening
,
if
ever
it
did
open
,
two
of
his
boys
should
ascend
the
flues
of
his
dwelling
,
with
instructions
to
hail
the
failure
with
derisive
jeers
from
the
chimney
-
pots
.
  
<EOS>
To
this
unhallowed
spot
,
the
very
name
of
which
had
hitherto
been
carefully
concealed
from
Mr
Dombey
by
his
sister
,
was
little
Paul
now
borne
by
Fate
and
Richards
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
my
house
,
Susan
,
"
said
Polly
,
pointing
it
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
,
indeed
,
Mrs
Richards
?
"
said
Susan
,
condescendingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
there
's
my
sister
Jemima
at
the
door
,
I
do
declare
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Polly
,
"
with
my
own
sweet
precious
baby
in
her
arms
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
sight
added
such
an
extensive
pair
of
wings
to
Polly
's
impatience
,
that
she
set
off
down
the
Gardens
at
a
run
,
and
bouncing
on
Jemima
,
changed
babies
with
her
in
a
twinkling
;
to
the
utter
astonishment
of
that
young
damsel
,
on
whom
the
heir
of
the
Dombeys
seemed
to
have
fallen
from
the
clouds
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Polly
!
"
cried
Jemima
.
<EOS>
"
You
!
<EOS>
what
a
turn
you
have
given
me
!
<EOS>
who
'd
have
thought
it
!
<EOS>
come
along
in
Polly
!
<EOS>
How
well
you
do
look
to
be
sure
!
<EOS>
The
children
will
go
half
wild
to
see
you
Polly
,
that
they
will
.
"
  
<EOS>
That
they
did
,
if
one
might
judge
from
the
noise
they
made
,
and
the
way
in
which
they
dashed
at
Polly
and
dragged
her
to
a
low
chair
in
the
chimney
corner
,
where
her
own
honest
apple
face
became
immediately
the
centre
of
a
bunch
of
smaller
pippins
,
all
laying
their
rosy
cheeks
close
to
it
,
and
all
evidently
the
growth
of
the
same
tree
.
<EOS>
As
to
Polly
,
she
was
full
as
noisy
and
vehement
as
the
children
;
and
it
was
not
until
she
was
quite
out
of
breath
,
and
her
hair
was
hanging
all
about
her
flushed
face
,
and
her
new
christening
attire
was
very
much
dishevelled
,
that
any
pause
took
place
in
the
confusion
.
<EOS>
Even
then
,
the
smallest
Toodle
but
one
remained
in
her
lap
,
holding
on
tight
with
both
arms
<EOS>
round
her
neck
;
while
the
smallest
Toodle
but
two
mounted
on
the
back
of
the
chair
,
and
made
desperate
efforts
,
with
one
leg
in

air
,
to
kiss
her
round
the
corner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
!
<EOS>
there
's
a
pretty
little
lady
come
to
see
you
,
"
said
Polly
;
"
and
see

quiet

is
!
<EOS>
what
a
beautiful
little
lady
,
ai
n't
she
?
"
  
<EOS>
This
reference
to
Florence
,
who
had

standing
by
the
door
not
unobservant
of
what
passed
,
directed
the
attention
of
the
younger
branches
towards
her
;
and
had
likewise
the
happy
effect
of
leading
to
the

of
Miss
Nipper
,
who
was
not
quite
free
from
a
misgiving
that
she
had

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
do
come
in
and
sit
down
a
minute
,
Susan
,
please
,
"
said
Polly
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
my
sister
Jemima
,
this
is
.
<EOS>
Jemima
,
I
do
n't
know
what
I
should

with
myself
,
if
it
was
n't
for
Susan
Nipper
;
I
should

here
now
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
do
sit
down
,
Miss
Nipper
,
if
you

,
"
quoth
Jemima
.
   
<EOS>
Susan
took
the
extreme
corner
of
a
chair
,
with
a
stately
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
was
so
glad
to
see
anybody
in
all
my

;
now
really
I
never
was
,
Miss
Nipper
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
Susan
relaxing
,
took
a
little
more
of
the

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
untie
your

-

,
and
make

at
home
,
Miss
Nipper
,
please
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
am

's

than
you
're
used

;
but
yoy'll
make

,
I
'm

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
black
-
eyed
was
so
softened
by
this
deferential

,
that
she
caught
up
little
Miss
Toodle
who
was
running
past
,
and
took
her
to
Banbury
Cross

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
where
's
my
pretty
boy
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

?
<EOS>
I

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
He
'll
break
his
heart
,
when
he
hears
his
mother
has
been
here
.
<EOS>
He
's
at
school
,
Polly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gone
already
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
He
went
for
the
first

yesterday
,
for
fear

should

any

.
<EOS>
But
it
's
half
-
holding
,

:

---
you

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
does

look
,
Jemima
,

!
"
<EOS>
faltered

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

do

'd

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

,

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
His
legs
is
short
,
"
returned
Jemima
;
"
especially
behind
;
but
they
'll
get
longer
,
Polly
,
every

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
slow
,
prospective
kind

;
but
the

and
good

with
which

,

did

.
<EOS>
After

's

,

,

more

:
  
"
<EOS>
And

's

,
<EOS>
Jemima

?
"
<EOS>
---
for
by
that

,
Mr
Toodle
was
generally

in
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
again
!
"
said
Jemima
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
pity
!
<EOS>
Father
took
his

with

this

,
and
is
n't

till

.
<EOS>
But
he
's
always
talking
of
you
,
Polly
,
and

;
and

the
peaceablest
,

,
best
-

in
the

,
as

always

and

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
,
Jemima
,
"
cried

simple

;
delighted
by

speech
,
and

by

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
you
need
n't
thank

,
Polly
,
"
said
her

,
giving

a
sound

,
and
then
dancing
little
Paul
cheerfully
.
<EOS>
"
I
say
the
same
of
you
sometimes
,
and
think

too
.
"
  
<EOS>
In

,
it

regard
in
the
light
of
a
failure
a
visit
which

;
so

hopefully
about
family

,
and

Biler
,
and
about
all
his
brothers
and

:
while
the
black
-
eyed
,
having
performed

to
Banbury

and
back
,
took
sharp
note
of
the
furniture
,
the

,
the

,
the
castle
on
the
mantel
-

with

in

,
susceptible

by

-

;
and
the

,
each

's

in

;
regarded
by
the
Staggs
's

.
<EOS>
The
conversation
soon

general
lest
the
black
-
eyed
should
go
off
at
score
and

,
that

related
to

Mr

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Also

her

,

and

.
<EOS>
Having
relieved
her

of

,
she
partook
of
shrimps
and
porter
,
and
evinced
a
disposition
to
swear
eternal

.
  
<EOS>
Little
Florence
herself
was
not
behind
-

in

:
for
,
being

forth

young

to

-

of
the
Gardens
<EOS>
,
she
entered
with

,
heart
and

,
on

across

that
had
collected
in

.
<EOS>
She
was
still

in
that

,
when
sought
and
found
by
Susan
;
who
,
such
was

sense

,
even

,
delivered

to

(
punctuated

)
on

,
while
washing

;
and
predicted
that
she
would
bring

grey

of
her

in

,

to

.
<EOS>
After

,

pretty

above

on

,
between

,
an

was
again

---
for

had
all

,
and

little
Paul
---
and

.
  
<EOS>
But
first
the
young
Toodles
,
victims
of
a

,
were
deluded
into
repairing
in

to

's

in

,

;
and

,
Polly

;

that

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you

that

might

to

a

in

,
Susan
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
,
Polly
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
not
,
Mrs
Richards
?
"
returned
Susan
.
  
<EOS>
It
's
getting
on
towards
our
dinner
time
you
know
,
said
Polly
.
  
<EOS>
But
lunch
had
rendered
her
companion
more
than
indifferent
to
this
grave
consideration
,
so
she
allowed
no
weight
to
it
,
and
they
resolved
to
go
"
a
little
round
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,
it
happened
that
poor
Biler
's
life
had
been
,
since
yesterday
morning
,
rendered
weary
by
the
costume
of
the
Charitable
Grinders
.
<EOS>
The
youth
of
the
streets
could
not
endure
it
.
<EOS>
No
young
vagabond
could
be
brought
to
bear
its
contemplation
for
a
moment
,
without
throwing
himself
upon
the
unoffending
wearer
,
and
doing
him
a
mischief
.
<EOS>
His
social
existence
had
been
more
like
that
of
an
early
Christian
,
than
an
innocent
child
of
the
nineteenth
century
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
stoned
in
the
streets
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
overthrown
into
gutters
;
bespattered
with
mud
;
violently
flattened
against
posts
.
<EOS>
Entire
strangers
to
his
person
had
lifted
his
yellow
cap
off
his
head
and
cast
it
to
the
winds
.
<EOS>
His
legs
had
not
only
undergone
verbal
criticisms
and
revilings
,
but
had
been
handled
and
pinched
.
<EOS>
That
very
morning
,
he
had
received
a
perfectly
unsolicited
black
eye
on
his
way
to
the
Grinders
'
establishment
,
and
had
been
punished
for
it
by
the
master
:
a
superannuated
old
Grinder
of
savage
disposition
,
who
had
been
appointed
schoolmaster
because
he
did
n't
know
anything
,
and
was
n't
fit
for
anything
,
and
for
whose
cruel
cane
all
chubby
little
boys
had
a
perfect
fascination
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
it
fell
out
that
Biler
,
on
his
way
home
,
sought
unfrequented
paths
;
and
slunk
along
by
narrow
passages
and
back
streets
,
to
avoid
his
tormentors
.
<EOS>
Being
compelled
to
emerge
into
the
main
road
,
his
ill
fortune
brought
him
at
last
where
a
small
party
of
boys
,
headed
by
a
ferocious
young
butcher
,
were
lying
in
wait
for
any
means
of
pleasurable
excitement
that
might
happen
.
<EOS>
These
,
finding
a
Charitable
Grinder
in
the
midst
of
them
---
unaccountably
delivered
over
,
as
it
were
,
into
their
hands
---
set
up
a
general
yell
and
rushed
upon
him
.
  
<EOS>
But
it
so
fell
out
likewise
,
that
,
at
the
same
time
,
Polly
,
looking
hopelessly
along
the
road
before
her
,
after
a
good
hour
's
walk
,
had
said
it
was
no
use
going
any
further
,
when
suddenly
she
saw
this
sight
.
<EOS>
She
no
sooner
saw
it
than
,
uttering
a
hasty

,
and
giving
Master
Dombey
to
the
black
-
eyed
,
she
started
to
the
rescue
of
her
unhappy
little
son
.
  
<EOS>
Surprises
,
like
misfortunes
,
rarely
come
alone
.
<EOS>
The
astonished
Susan
Nipper
and
her
two
young
charges
were
rescued
by
the
bystanders
from
under
the
very
wheels
of
a
passing
carriage
before
they
knew
what
had
happened
;
and
at
that
moment
(
it
was
market
day
)
<EOS>
a
thundering
alarm
of
"
Mad
Bull
"
was
raised
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
wild
confusion
before
her
,
of
people
running
up
and
down
,
and
shouting
,
and
wheels
running
over
them
,
and
boys
fighting
,
and
mad
bulls
coming
up
,
and
the
nurse
in
the
midst
of
all
these
dangers
being
torn
to
pieces
,
Florence
screamed
and
ran
.
<EOS>
She
ran
till
she
was
exhausted
,
urging
Susan
to
do
the
same
;
and
then
,
stopping
and
wringing
her
hands
as
she
remembered
they
had
left
the
other
nurse
behind
,
found
,
with
a
sensation
of
terror
not
to
be
described
,
that
she
was
quite
alone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Susan
!
Susan
!
"
cried
Florence
,
clapping
her
hands
in
the
very
ecstasy
of
her
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
where
are
they
?
<EOS>
where
are
they
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
are
they
?
"
said
an
old
woman
,
coming
hobbling
across
as
fast
as
she
could
from
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
did
you
run
away
from
'
em
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
frightened
,
"
answered
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
know
what
I
did
.
<EOS>
I
thought
they
were
with
me
.
<EOS>
Where
are
they
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
took
her
by
the
wrist
,
and
said
,
"
I
'll
show
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
a
very
ugly
old
woman
,
with
red
rims
round
her
eyes
,
and
a
mouth
that
mumbled
and
chattered
of
itself
when
she
was
not
speaking
.
<EOS>
She
was
miserably
dressed
,
and
carried
some
skins
over
her
arm
.
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
have
followed
Florence
some
little
way
at
all
events
,
for
she
had
lost
her
breath
;
and
this
made
her
uglier
still
,
as
she
stood
trying
to
regain
it
:
working
her
shrivelled
yellow
face
and
throat
into
all
sorts
of
contortions
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
was
afraid
of
her
,
and
looked
,
hesitating
,
up
the
street
,
of
which
she
had
almost
reached
the
bottom
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
solitary
place
---
more
a
back
road
than
a
street
---
and
there
was
no
one
in
it
but
herself
and
the
old
woman
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
be
frightened
now
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
still
holding
her
tight
.
<EOS>
"
Come
along
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
do
n't
know
you
.
<EOS>
What
's
your
name
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Brown
,
"
said
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
Mrs
Brown
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Are
they
near
here
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Florence
,
beginning
to
be
led
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
Susan
an't
far
off
,
"
said
Good
Mrs
Brown
;
"
and
the
others
are
close
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
anybody
hurt
?
"
cried
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
of
it
,
"
said
Good
Mrs
Brown
.
  
<EOS>
The
child
shed
tears
of
delight
on
hearing
this
,
and
accompanied
the
old
woman
willingly
;
though
she
could
not
help
glancing
at
her
face
as
they
went
along
---
particularly
at
that
industrious
mouth
---
and
wondering
whether
Bad
Mrs
Brown
,
if
there
were
such
a
person
,
was
at
all
like
her
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
not
gone
far
,
but
had
gone
by
some
very
uncomfortable
places
,
such
as
brick
-
fields
and
tile
-
yards
,
when
the
old
woman
turned
down
a
dirty
lane
,
where
the
mud
lay
in
deep
black
ruts
in
the
middle
of
the
road
.
<EOS>
She
stopped
before
a
shabby
little
house
,
as
closely
shut
up
as
a
house
that
was
full
of
cracks
and
crevices
could
be
.
<EOS>
Opening
the
door
with
a
key
she
took
out
of
her
bonnet
,
she
pushed
the
child
before
her
into
a
back
room
,
where
there
was
a
great
heap
of
rags
of
different
colours
lying
on
the
floor
;
a
heap
of
bones
,
and
a
heap
of
sifted
dust
or
cinders
;
but
there
was
no
furniture
at
all
,
and
the
walls
and
ceiling
were
quite
black
.
  
<EOS>
The
child
became
so
terrified
that
she
was
stricken
speechless
,
and
looked
as
though
about
to
swoon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
do
n't
be
a
young
mule
,
"
said
Good
Mrs
Brown
,
reviving
her
with
a
shake
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
a
going
to
hurt
you
.
<EOS>
Sit
upon
the
rags
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
obeyed
her
,
holding
out
her
folded
hands
,
in
mute
supplication
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
a
going
to
keep
you
,
even
,
above
an
hour
,
"
said
Mrs
Brown
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
D'ye
understand
what
I
say
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
child
answered
with
great
difficulty
,
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
Good
Mrs
Brown
,
taking
her
own
seat
on
the
bones
,
"
do
n't
vex
me
.
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
,
I
tell
you
I
wo
n't
hurt
you
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
do
,
I
'll
kill
you
.
<EOS>
I
could
have
you
killed
at
any
time
---
even
if
you
was
in
your
own
bed
at
home
.
<EOS>
Now
let
's
know
who
you
are
,
and
what
you
are
,
and
all
about
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
's
threats
and
promises
;
the
dread
of
giving
her
offence
;
and
the
habit
,
unusual
to
a
child
,
but
almost
natural
to
Florence
now
,
of
being
quiet
,
and
repressing
what
she
felt
,
and
feared
,
and
hoped
;
enabled
her
to
do
this
bidding
,
and
to
tell
her
little
history
,
or
what
she
knew
of
it
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Brown
listened
attentively
,
until
she
had
finished
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
your
name
's
Dombey
,
eh
?
"
said
Mrs
Brown
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
ma'am
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
that
pretty
frock
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
said
Good
Mrs
Brown
,
"
and
that
little
bonnet
,
and
a
petticoat
or
two
,
and
anything
else
you
can
spare
.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Take
'em
off
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
obeyed
,
as
fast
as
her
trembling
hands
would
allow
;
keeping
,
all
the
while
,
a
frightened
eye
on
Mrs
Brown
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
divested
herself
of
all
the
articles
of
apparel
mentioned
by
that
lady
,
Mrs
B
examined
them
at
leisure
,
and
seemed
tolerably
well
satisfied
with
their
quality
and
value
.
  
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
running
her
eyes
over
the
child
's
slight
figure
,
"
I
do
n't
see
anything
else
---
except
the
shoes
.
<EOS>
I
must
have
the
shoes
,
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
little
Florence
took
them
off
with
equal
alacrity
,
only
too
glad
to
have
any
more
means
of
conciliation
about
her
.
<EOS>
The
old
woman
then
produced
some
wretched
substitutes
from
the
bottom
of
the
heap
of
rags
,
which
she
turned
up
for
that
purpose
;
together
with
a
girl
's
cloak
,
quite
worn
out
and
very
old
;
and
the
crushed
remains
of
a
bonnet
that
had
probably
been
picked
up
from
some
ditch
or
dunghill
.
<EOS>
In
this
dainty
raiment
,
she
instructed
Florence
to
dress
herself
;
and
as
such
preparation
seemed
a
prelude
to
her
release
,
the
child
complied
with
increased
readiness
,
if
possible
.
  
<EOS>
In
hurriedly
putting
on
the
bonnet
,
if
that
may
be
called
a
bonnet
which
was
more
like
a
pad
to
carry
loads
on
,
she
caught
it
in
her
hair
which
grew
luxuriantly
,
and
could
not
immediately
disentangle
it
.
<EOS>
Good
Mrs
Brown
whipped
out
a
large
pair
or
scissors
,
and
fell
into
an
unaccountable
state
of
excitement
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
could
n't
you
let
me
be
,
"
said
Mrs
Brown
,
"
when
I
was
contented
?
<EOS>
You
little
fool
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
I
have
done
,
"
panted
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
help
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Could
n't
help
it
!
"
cried
Mrs
Brown
.
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
expect
I
can
help
it
?
<EOS>
Why
,
Lord
!
"
said
the
old
woman
,
ruffling
her
curls
with
a
furious
pleasure
,
"
anybody
but
me
would
have
had
'em
off
first
of
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
was
so
relieved
to
find
that
it
was
only
her
hair
and
not
her
head
which
Mrs
Brown
coveted
,
that
she
offered
no
resistance
or
entreaty
,
and
merely
raised
her
mild
eyes
towards
the
face
of
that
good
soul
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
n't
once
had
a
gal
of
my
own
---
beyond
seas
now
---
that
was
proud
of
her
hair
,
"
said
Mrs
Brown
,
"
I
'd
have
had
every
lock
of
it
.
<EOS>
She
's
far
away
,
she
's
far
away
!
<EOS>
Oho
!
Oho
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Brown
's
was
not
a
melodious
cry
,
but
,
accompanied
with
a
wild
tossing
up
of
her
lean
arms
<EOS>
,
it
was
full
of
passionate
grief
,
and
thrilled
to
the
heart
of
Florence
,
whom
it
frightened
more
than
ever
.
<EOS>
It
had
its
part
,
perhaps
,
in
saving
her
curls
;
for
Mrs
Brown
,
after
hovering
about
her
with
the
scissors
for
some
moments
,
like
a
new
kind
of
butterfly
,
bade
her
<EOS>
hide
them
under
the
bonnet
and
let
no
trace
of
them
escape
to
tempt
her
.
<EOS>
Having
accomplished
this
victory
over
herself
,
Mrs
Brown
resumed
her
seat
on
the
bones
,
and
smoked
a
very
short
black
pipe
,
mowing
and
mumbling
all
the
time
,
as
if
she
were
eating
the
stem
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
pipe
was
smoked
out
,
she
gave
the
child
a
rabbitskin
to
carry
,
that
she
might
appear
the
more
like
her
ordinary
companion
,
and
told
her
that
she
was
now
going
to
lead
her
to
a
public
street
whence
she
could
inquire
her
way
to
her
friends
.
<EOS>
But
she
cautioned
her
,
with
threats
of
summary
and
deadly
vengeance
in
case
of
disobedience
,
not
to
talk
to
strangers
,
nor
to
repair
to
her
own
home
(
which
may
have
been
too
near
for
Mrs
Brown
's
convenience
)
,
but
to
her
father
's
office
in
the
City
;
also
to
wait
at
the
street
corner
where
she
would
be
left
,
until
the
clock
struck
three
.
<EOS>
These
directions
Mrs
brown
enforced
with
assurances
that
there
would
be
potent
eyes
and
ears
in
her
employment
cognizant
of
all
she
did
;
and
these
directions
Florence
promised
faithfully
and
earnestly
to
observe
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
,
Mrs
Brown
,
issuing
forth
,
conducted
her
changed
and
ragged
little
friend
through
a
labyrinth
of
narrow
streets
and
lanes
and
alleys
,
which
emerged
,
after
a
long
time
,
upon
a
stable
yard
,
with
a
gateway
at
the
end
,
whence
the
roar
of
a
great
thoroughfare
made
itself
audible
.
<EOS>
Pointing
out
this
gateway
,
and
informing
Florence
that
when
the
clocks
struck
three
she
was
to
go
to
the
left
,
Mrs
Brown
,
after
making
a
parting
grasp
at
her
hair
which
seemed
involuntary
and
quite
beyond
her
own
control
,
told
her
she
knew
what
to
do
,
and
bade
her
go
and
do
it
:
remembering
that
she
was
watched
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
lighter
heart
,
but
still
sore
afraid
,
Florence
felt
herself
released
,
and
tripped
off
to
the
corner
.
<EOS>
When
she
reached
it
,
she
looked
back
and
saw
the
head
of
Good
Mrs
Brown
peeping
out
of
the
low
wooden
passage
,
where
she
had
issued
her
parting
injunctions
;
likewise
the
first
of
Good
Mrs
Brown
shaking
towards
her
.
<EOS>
But
though
she
often
looked
back
afterwards
---
every
minute
,
at
least
,
in
her
nervous
recollection
of
the
old
woman
---
she
could
not
see
her
again
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
remained
there
,
looked
at
the
bustle
in
the
street
,
and
more
and
more
bewildered
by
it
;
and
in
the
meanwhile
the
clocks
appeared
to
have
made
up
their
minds
never
to
strike
three
any
more
.
<EOS>
At
last
the
steeples
rang
out
three
o'clock
;
there
was
one
close
by
,
so
she
could
n't
be
mistaken
;
and
<EOS>
---
after
often
looking
over
her
shoulder
,
and
often
going
a
little
way
,
and
as
often
coming
back
again
,
lest
the
all
-
powerful
spies
of
Mrs
Brown
should
take
offence
---
she
hurried
off
,
as
fast
as
she
could
in
her
slipshod
shoes
,
holding
the
rabbit
-
skin
tight
in
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
All
she
knew
of
her
father
's
offices
was
that
they
belonged
to
Dombey
and
Son
,
and
that
that
was
a
great
power
belonging
to
the
City
.
<EOS>
So
she
could
only
ask
the
way
to
Dombey
and
Son
's
in
the
City
;
and
as
she
generally
made
inquiry
of
children
---
being
afraid
to
ask
grown
people
---
she
got
very
little
satisfaction
indeed
.
<EOS>
But
by
dint
of
asking
her
way
to
the
City
after
a
while
,
and
dropping
the
rest
of
her
inquiry
for
the
present
,
she
really
did
advance
,
by
slow
degrees
,
towards
the
heart
of
that
great
region
which
is
governed
by
the
terrible
Lord
Mayor
.
  
<EOS>
Tired
of
walking
,
repulsed
and
pushed
about
,
stunned
by
the
noise
and
confusion
,
anxious
for
her
brother
and
the
nurses
,
terrified
by
what
she
had
undergone
,
and
<EOS>
the
prospect
of
encountering
her
angry
father
in
such
an
altered
state
;
perplexed
and
frightened
alike
by
what
had
passed
,
and
what
was
passing
,
and
what
was
yet
before
her
;
Florence
went
upon
her
weary
way
with
tearful
eyes
,
and
once
or
twice
could
not
help
stopping
to
ease
her
bursting
heart
by
crying
bitterly
.
<EOS>
But
few
people
noticed
her
at
those
times
,
in
the
garb
she
wore
:
or
if
they
did
,
believed
that
she
was
tutored
to
excite
compassion
,
and
passed
on
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
too
,
called
to
her
aid
all
the
firmness
and
self
-
reliance
of
a
character
that
her
sad
experience
had
prematurely
formed
and
tried
:
and
keeping
the
end
she
had
in
view
steadily
before
her
,
steadily
pursued
it
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
full
two
hours
later
in
the
afternoon
than
when
she
had
started
on
this
strange
adventure
,
when
escaping
from
the
clash
and
clangour
of
a
narrow
street
full
of
carts
and
waggons
,
she
peeped
into
a
kind
of
wharf
or
landing
-
place
upon
the
river
-
side
,
where
there
were
a
great
many
packages
,
casks
,
and
boxes
,
strewn
about
;
a
large
pair
of
wooden
scales
;
and
a
little
wooden
house
on
wheels
,
outside
of
which
,
looking
at
the
neighbouring
masts
and
boats
,
a
stout
man
stood
whistling
,
with
his
pen
behind
his
ear
,
and
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
as
if
his
day
's
work
were
nearly
done
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
then
!
"
said
this
man
,
happening
to
turn
round
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
n't
got
anything
for
you
,
little
girl
.
<EOS>
Be
off
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
is
this
the
City
?
"
asked
the
trembling
daughter
of
the
Dombeys
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
It
's
the
City
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
well
enough
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
Be
off
!
<EOS>
We
have
n't
got
anything
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
anything
,
thank
you
,
"
<EOS>
was
the
timid
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Except
to
know
the
way
to
Dombey
and
Son
's
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
who
had
been
strolling
carelessly
towards
her
,
seemed
surprised
by
this
reply
,
and
looking
attentively
in
her
face
,
rejoined
:
  
"
Why
,
what
can
you
want
with
Dombey
and
Son
's
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
know
the
way
there
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
looked
at
her
yet
more
curiously
,
and
rubbed
the
back
of
his
head
so
hard
in
his
wonderment
that
he
knocked
his
own
hat
off
.
  
<EOS>
"
Joe
!
"
he
called
to
another
man
---
a
labourer
---
as
he
picked
it
up
and
put
it
on
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Joe
it
is
!
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
's
that
young
spark
of
Dombey
's
who
's
been
watching
the
shipment
of
them
goods
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just
gone
,
by
t'other
gate
,
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
Call
him
back
a
minute
.
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
ran
up
an
archway
,
bawling
as
he
went
,
and
very
soon
returned
with
a
blithe
-
looking
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
Dombey
's
jockey
,
an't
you
?
"
said
the
first
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
in
Dombey
's
House
,
Mr
Clark
,
"
returned
the
boy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look'ye
here
,
then
,
"
said
Mr
Clark
.
  
<EOS>
Obedient
to
the
indication
of
Mr
Clark
's
hand
,
the
boy
approached
towards
Florence
,
wondering
,
as
well
he
might
,
what
he
had
to
do
with
her
.
<EOS>
But
she
,
who
had
heard
what
passed
,
and
who
,
besides
the
relief
of
so
suddenly
considering
herself
safe
at
her
journey
's
end
,
felt
reassured
beyond
all
measure
by
his
lively
youthful
face
and
manner
,
ran
eagerly
up
to
him
,
leaving
one
of
the
slipshod
shoes
upon
the
ground
and
caught
his
hand
in
both
of
hers
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
lost
,
if
you
please
!
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lost
!
"
cried
the
boy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
was
lost
this
morning
,
a
long
way
from
here
---
and
I
have
had
my
clothes
taken
away
,
since
---
<EOS>
and
I
am
not
dressed
in
my
own
now
---
and
<EOS>
my
name
is
Florence
Dombey
,
my
little
brother
's
only
sister
---
<EOS>
and
,
oh
dear
,
dear
,
take
care
of
me
,
if
you
please
!
"
<EOS>
sobbed
Florence
,
giving
full
vent
to
the
childish
feelings
she
had
so
long
suppressed
,
and
bursting
into
tears
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
her
miserable
bonnet
falling
off
,
her
hair
came
tumbling
down
about
her
face
:
moving
to
speechless

and
commiseration
,
young
Walter
,
nephew
of
Solomon
Gills
,
Ships
'
Instrument
-
maker
in
general
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Clark
stood
rapt
in
amazement
:
observing
under
his
breath
<EOS>
,
I
never
saw
such
a
start
on
this
wharf
before
.
<EOS>
Walter
picked
up
the
shoe
,
and
put
it
on
the
little
foot
as
the
Prince
in
the
story
might
have
fitted
Cinderella
's
slipper
on
.
<EOS>
He
hung
the
rabbit
-
skin
over
his
left
arm
;
gave
the
right
to
Florence
:
and
felt
,
not
to
say
like
Richard
Whittington
---
that
is
a
tame
comparison
---
<EOS>
but
like
Saint
George
of
England
,
with
the
dragon
lying
dead
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
cry
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
said
Walter
,
in
a
transport
of
enthusiasm
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
wonderful
thing
for
me
that
I
am
here
!
<EOS>
You
are
as
safe
now
as
if
you
were
guarded
by
a
whole
boat
's
crew
of
picked
men
from
a
man
-
of
-
war
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
do
n't
cry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
cry
any
more
,
"
said
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
only
crying
for
joy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Crying
for
joy
!
"
<EOS>
thought
Walter
,
"
and
I
'm
the
cause
of
it!Come
along
,
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
There
's
the
other
shoe
off
now!Take
<EOS>
mine
,
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
no
,
no
,
"
said
Florence
,
checking
him
in
the
act
of
impetuously
pulling
off
his
own
.
<EOS>
"
These
do
better
.
<EOS>
These
do
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
to
be
sure
,
"
said
Walter
,
glancing
at
her
foot
,
"
mine
are
a
mile
too
large
.
<EOS>
What
am
I
thinking
about
!
<EOS>
You
never
could
walk
in
mine
!
<EOS>
Come
along
,
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
Let
me
see
the
villain
who
will
dare
molest
you
now
.
"
  
<EOS>
So
Walter
,
looking
immensely
fierce
,
led
off
Florence
,
looking
very
happy
;
and
they
went
arm
-
in
-
arm
along
the
streets
,
perfectly
indifferent
to
any
astonishment
that
their
appearance
might
or
did
excite
by
the
way
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
growing
dark
and
foggy
,
and
beginning
to
rain
too
;
but
they
cared
nothing
for
this
:
being
both
wholly
absorbed
in
the
late
adventures
of
Florence
,
which
she
related
with
the
innocent
good
faith
and
confidence
of
her
years
,
while
Walter
listened
as
if
,
far
from
the
mud
and
grease
of
Thames
Street
,
they
were
rambling
alone
among
the
broad
leaves
and
tall
trees
of
some
desert
island
in
the
tropics
---
as
he
very
likely
fancied
,
for
the
time
,
they
were
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
we
far
to
go
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Florence
at
last
,
lifting
up
her
eyes
to
her
companion
's
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
By
-
the
-
bye
<EOS>
,
"
said
Walter
,
stopping
,
"
let
me
see
;
where
are
we
?
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
know
.
<EOS>
But
the
offices
are
shut
up
now
,
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
There
's
nobody
there
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
has
gone
home
long
ago
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
we
must
go
home
too
?
<EOS>
or
,
stay
.
<EOS>
Suppose
I
take
you
to
my
uncle
's
,
where
I
live
<EOS>
---
it
's
very
near
here
---
and
go
to
your
house
in
a
coach
to
tell
them
you
are
safe
,
and
bring
you
back
some
clothes
.
<EOS>
Wo
n't
that
be
best
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
so
,
"
answered
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
?
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
?
"
  
<EOS>
As
they
stood
deliberating
in
the
street
,
a
man
passed
them
,
who
glanced
quickly
at
Walter
as
he
went
by
,
as
if
he
recognised
him
;
but
seeming
to
correct
that
first
impression
,
he
passed
on
without
stopping
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
think
it
's
Mr
Carker
,
"
said
Walter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Carker
in
our
House
.
<EOS>
Not
Carker
our
manager
,
Miss
Dombey
---
the
other
Carker
;
the
junior
---
Halloa
!
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
Walter
Gay
?
"
said
the
other
,
stopping
and
returning
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
believe
it
,
with
such
a
strange
companion
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
stood
near
a
lamp
,
listening
with
surprise
to
Walter
's
hurried
explanation
,
he
presented
a
remarkable
contrast
to
the
two
youthful
figures
arm
-
in
-
arm
before
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
old
,
but
his
hair
was
white
;
his
body
was
bent
,
or
bowed
as
if
by
the
weight
of
some
great
trouble
:
and
there
were
deep
lines
in
his
worn
and
melancholy
face
.
<EOS>
The
fire
of
his
eyes
,
the
expression
of
his
features
,
the
very
voice
in
which
he
spoke
,
were
all
subdued
and
quenched
,
as
if
the
spirit
within
him
lay
in
ashes
.
<EOS>
He
was
respectably
,
though
very
plainly
dressed
,
in
black
;
but
his
clothes
,
moulded
to
the
general
character
of
his
figure
,
seemed
to
shrink
and
abase
themselves
upon
him
,
and
to
join
in
the
sorrowful
solicitation
which
the
whole
man
from
head
to
foot
expressed
,
to
be
left
unnoticed
,
and
alone
in
his
humility
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
his
interest
in
youth
and
hopefulness
was
not
extinguished
with
the
other
embers
of
his
soul
<EOS>
,
for
he
watched
the
boy
's
earnest
countenance
as
he
spoke
with
unusual
sympathy
,
though
with
an
inexplicable
show
of
trouble
and
compassion
,
which
escaped
into
his
looks
,
however
hard
he
strove
to
hold
it
prisoner
.
<EOS>
When
Walter
,
in
conclusion
,
put
to
him
the
question
he
had
put
to
Florence
,
he
still
stood
glancing
at
him
with
the
same
expression
,
as
if
he
had
read
some
fate
upon
his
face
,
mournfully
at
variance
with
its
present
brightness
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
advise
,
Mr
Carker
?
"
said
Walter
,
smiling
.
<EOS>
"
You
always
give
me
good
advice
,
you
know
,
when
you
do
speak
to
me
.
<EOS>
That
's
not
often
,
though
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
your
own
idea
is
the
best
,
"
he
answered
:
looking
from
Florence
to
Walter
,
and
back
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Carker
,
"
said
Walter
,
brightening
with
a
generous
thought
,
"
Come
!
<EOS>
Here
's
chance
for
you
.
<EOS>
Go
you
to
Mr
Dombey
's
and
be
the
messenger
of
good
news
.
<EOS>
It
may
do
you
some
good
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
I
'll
remain
at
home
.
<EOS>
You
shall
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
!
"
returned
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Why
not
,
Mr
Carker
?
"
said
the
boy
.
  
<EOS>
He
merely
shook
him
by
the
hand
in
answer
;
he
seemed
in
a
manner
ashamed
and
afraid
even
to
do
that
;
and
bidding
him

night
,
and
advising
him
to
make

,

away
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
said
Walter
,
looking
after
him
as
they
turned
away
also
,
"
we
'll
go
to
my
uncle
's
as
quick
as
we
can
.
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
hear
Mr
Dombey
speak
of
Mr
Carker
the
junior
,
Miss
Florence
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned
the
child
,
mildly
,
"
<EOS>
I
do
n't
often
hear
papa
speak
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
true
!
<EOS>
more
shame
for
him
,
"
thought
Walter
.
<EOS>
After
a
minute
's
pause
,
during
which
he
had
been
looking
down
upon
the
gentle
patient
little
face
moving
on
at
his
side
,
he
bestirred
himself
with
his
accustomed
boyish
animation
and
restlessness
to
change
the
subject
;
and
one
of
the
unfortunate
shoes
coming
off
again
opportunely
,
proposed
to
carry
Florence
to
his
uncle
's
in
his
arms
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
though
very
tired
,
laughingly
declined
the
proposal
,
lest
he
should
let
her
fall
;
and
as
they
were
already
near
the
wooden
midshipman
,
and
as
Walter
went
on
to
cite
various
precedents
,
from
shipwrecks
and
other
moving
accidents
,
where
younger
boys
than
he
had
triumphantly
rescued
and
carried
off
older
girls
than
Florence
,
they
were
still
in
full
conversation
about
it
when
they
arrived
at
the
instrument
-
maker
's
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Holloa
,
Uncle
Sol
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Walter
,
bursting
into
the
shop
,
and
speaking
incoherently
and
out
of
breath
,
from
that
time
forth
,
for
the
rest
of
the
evening
.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
wonderful
adventure
!
<EOS>
Here
's
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
daughter
lost
in
the
streets
,
and
robbed
of
her
clothes
by
an
old
witch
of
a
woman
---
found
by
me
---
brought
home
to
our
parlour
to
rest
---
look
here
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
Heaven
!
"
said
Uncle
Sol
,
starting
back
against
his
favourite
compass
-
case
.
<EOS>
"
It
ca
n't
be
!
<EOS>
Well
,
I
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
,
nor
anybody
else
,
"
said
Walter
,
anticipating
the
rest
.
<EOS>
"
Nobody
would
,
nobody
could
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
Here
!
<EOS>
just
help
me
lift
the
little
sofa
near
the
fire
,
will
you
,
Uncle
Sol
---
take
care
of
the
plates
---
cut
some
dinner
for
her
,
will
you
,
uncle
---
throw
those
shoes
under
the
grate
.
<EOS>
Miss
Florence
---
put
your
feet
on
the
fender
to
dry
---
<EOS>
how
damp
they
are
---
here
's
an
adventure
,
uncle
,
eh
?
---
<EOS>
God
bless
my
soul
,
how
hot
I
am
!
"
  
<EOS>
Solomon
Gills
was
quite
as
hot
,
by
sympathy
,
and
in
excessive
bewilderment
.
<EOS>
He
patted
Florence
's
head
,
pressed
her
to
eat
,
pressed
her
to
drink
,
rubbed
the
soles
of
her
feet
with
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
heated
at
the
fire
,
followed
his
locomotive
nephew
with
his
eyes
,
and
ears
,
and
had
no
clear
perception
of
anything
except
that
he
was
being
constantly
knocked
against
and
tumbled
over
by
that
excited
young
gentleman
,
as
he
darted
about
the
room
attempting
to
accomplish
twenty
things
at
once
,
and
doing
nothing
at
all
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,
wait
a
minute
,
uncle
,
"
he
continued
,
catching
up
a
candle
,
"
till
I
run
up
stairs
,
and
get
another
jacket
on
,
and
then
I
'll
be
off
.
<EOS>
I
say
,
uncle
,
is
n't
this
an
adventure
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
boy
,
"
said
Solomon
,
who
,
with
his
spectacles
on
his
forehead
and
the
great
chronometer
in
his
pocket
,
was
incessantly
oscillating
between
Florence
on
the
sofa
and
his
nephew
in
all
parts
of
the
parlour
,
<EOS>
"
it
's
the
most
extraordinary
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
,
but
do
,
uncle
,
please
---
do
,
Miss
Florence
---
dinner
,
you
know
,
uncle
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
yes
,
"
cried
Solomon
,
cutting
instantly
into
a
leg
of
mutton
,
as
if
he
were
catering
for
a
giant
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
care
of
her
,
Wally
!
<EOS>
I
understand
.
<EOS>
Pretty
dear
!
<EOS>
Famished
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
You
go
and
get
ready
.
<EOS>
Lord
bless
me
!
<EOS>
Sir
Richard
Whittington
thrice
Lord
Mayor
of
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
was
not
very
long
in
mounting
to
his
lofty
garret
and
descending
from
it
,
but
in
the
meantime
Florence
,
overcome
by
fatigue
,
had
sunk
into
a
doze
before
the
fire
.
<EOS>
The
short
interval
of
quiet
,
though
only
a
few
minutes
in
duration
,
enabled
Solomon
gills
so
far
to
collect
his
wits
as
to
make
some
little
arrangements
for
her
comfort
,
and
to
darken
the
room
,
and
to
screen
her
from
the
blaze
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
when
the
boy
returned
,
she
was
sleeping
peacefully
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
capital
!
"
<EOS>
he
whispered
,
giving
Solomon
such
a
hug
that
it
squeezed
a
new
expression
into
his
face
.
<EOS>
"
Now
I
'm
off
.
<EOS>
I
'll
just
take
a
crust
of
bread
with
me
,
for
I
'm
very
hungry
---
and
---
do
n't
wake
her
,
Uncle
Sol
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Solomon
.
<EOS>
Pretty
child
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pretty
,
indeed
!
"
cried
Walter
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
such
a
face
,
Uncle
Sol
.
<EOS>
Now
I
'm
off
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
"
said
Solomon
,
greatly
relieved
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
Uncle
Sol
,
"
cried
Walter
,
putting
his
face
in
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
again
,
"
said
Solomon
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
does
she
look
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
happy
,
"
said
Solomon
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
famous
!
<EOS>
now
I
'm
off
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
,
"
said
Solomon
to
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
Uncle
Sol
,
"
cried
Walter
,
reappearing
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
again
!
"
said
Solomon
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
met
Mr
Carker
the
junior
in
the
street
,
queerer
than
ever
.
<EOS>
He
bade
me
good
-
bye
,
but
came
behind
us
here
<EOS>
---
there
's
an
odd
thing
!
<EOS>
---
for
when
we
reached
the
shop
door
,
I
looked
round
,
and
saw
him
going
quietly
away
,
like
a
servant
who
had
seen
me
home
,
or
a
faithful
dog
.
<EOS>
How
does
she
look
now
,
uncle
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pretty
much
the
same
as
before
,
Wally
,
"
replied
Uncle
Sol
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
.
<EOS>
Now
I
am
off
!
"
  
<EOS>
And
this
time
he
really
was
:
and
Solomon
Gills
,
<EOS>
with
no
appetite
for
dinner
,
sat
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
fire
,
watching
Florence
in
her
slumber
,
building
a
great
many
airy
castles
of
the
most
fantastic
architecture
;
and
looking
,
in
the
dim
shade
,
and
in
the
close

of
all
the
instruments
,
like
a

disguised
in
a
Welsh
wig
and
a
suit
of
coffee
colour
,
who
held
the
child
in
an
enchanted
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
Walter
proceeded
towards
Mr
Dombey
's
house
at
a
pace
seldom
achieved
by
a
hack
horse
from
the
stand
;
and
yet
with
his
head
out
of
window
every
two
or
three
minutes
,
in
impatient
remonstrance
with
the
driver
.
<EOS>
Arriving
at
his
journey
's
end
,
he
leaped
out
,
and
breathlessly
announcing
his
errand
to
the
servant
,
followed
him
straight
into
the
library
,
where
there
was
a
great
confusion
of
tongues
,
and
where
Mr
Dombey
,
his
sister
,
and
Miss
Tox
,
Richards
,
and
Nipper
,
were
all
congregated
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Sir
,
"
said
Walter
,
rushing
up
to
him
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
'm
happy
to
say
it
's
all
right
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Miss
Dombey
's
found
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy
with
his
open
face
,
and
flowing
hair
,
and
sparkling
eyes
,
panting
with
pleasure
and
excitement
,
was
wonderfully
opposed
to
Mr
Dombey
,
as
he
sat
confronting
him
in
his
library

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
,
Louisa
,
that
she
would
certainly
be
found
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
looking
slightly
over
his
shoulder
at
that
lady
,
who
wept
in
company
with
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
Let
the
servants
know
that
no
further
steps
are
necessary
.
<EOS>
This
boy
who
brings
the
information
,
is
young
Gay
,
from
the
office
.
<EOS>
How
was
my
daughter
found
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
I
know
how
she
was
lost
.
<EOS>
"
Here
he
looked
majestically
at
Richards
.
"
<EOS>
But
how
was
she
found
?
<EOS>
Who
found
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
believe
I
found
Miss
dombey
,
Sir
,
"
said
Walter
modestly
;
"
at
least
I
do
n't
know
that
I
can
claim
the
merit
of
having
exactly
found
her
,
Sir
,
but
I
was
the
fortunate
instrument
of
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
What
do
you
mean
,
Sir
,
"
interrupted
Mr
Dombey
,
regarding
the
boy
's
evident
pride
and
pleasure
in
his
share
of
the
transaction
with
an
instinctive
dislike
,
"
by
not
having
exactly
found
my
daughter
,
and
by
being
a
fortunate
instrument
?
<EOS>
Be
plain
and
coherent
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
quite
out
of
Walter
's
power
to
be
coherent
;
but
he
rendered
himself
as
explanatory
as
he
could
,
in
his

state
,
and
stated
why
he
had
come
alone
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
hear
this
,
girl
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
sternly
to
the
black
-
eyed
.
<EOS>
"
Take
what
is
necessary
,
and
return
immediately
with
this
young
man
to
fetch
Miss
Florence
home
.
<EOS>
Gay
,

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
thank
you
,
Sir
,
"
said
Walter
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
kind
.
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
I
was
not
thinking
of
any
reward
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
boy
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
suddenly
and
almost

;
"
and
what
you
think

,
or
affect

,
is
of
little

.
<EOS>
You
have
done
well
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
undo

.
<EOS>
Louisa
,
please
to
give
the
lad
some
wine
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
glance
followed
Walter
Gay
with
sharp
disfavour
,
as
he
left
the
room
under
the
pilotage
of
Mrs
Chick
;
and
it
may
be
that
his
mind
's
eye
followed
him
with
no
greater
relish
,
as
he
rode
back
to
his
uncle
's
with
Miss
Susan
Nipper
.
  
<EOS>
There
they
found
that
Florence
,
much
refreshed
by
sleep
,
had
dined
,
and
greatly
improved
the
acquaintance
of
Solomon
Gills
,
with
whom
she
was
on
terms
of
perfect
confidence
and
ease
.
<EOS>
The
black
-
eyed
(
who
had
cried
so
much
that
she
might
now
be
called
the
red
-
eyed
,
and
who
was
very
silent
and
depressed
)
caught
her
in
her
arms
without
a
word
of
contradiction
or
reproach
,
and
made
a
very
hysterical
meeting
of
it
.
<EOS>
Then
converting
the
parlour
,
for
the
nonce
,
into
a
private
tiring
room
,
she
dressed
her
,
with
great
care
,
in
proper
clothes
;
and
presently
led
her
forth
,
as
like
a
Dombey
as
her
natural
disqualifications
admitted
of
her
being
made
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
said
Florence
,
running
up
to
Solomon
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
very
good
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Old
Sol
was
quite
delighted
,
and
kissed
her
like
her
grandfather
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
Walter
!
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
"
said
Walter
,
giving
both
his
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
never
forget
you
,
"
pursued
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
indeed
I
never
will
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
Walter
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In
the
innocence
of
her
grateful
heart
,
the
child
lifted
up
her
face
to
his
.
<EOS>
Walter
,
bending
down
his
own
,
raised
it
again
,
all
red
and
burning
;
and
looked
at
Uncle
Sol
,
quite
sheepishly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Walter
?
"
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
Walter
!
"
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
Walter
!
"
<EOS>
"
Shake
hands
once
more
,
Walter
!
<EOS>
"
This
was
still
Florence
's
cry
,
after
she
was
shut
up
with
her
little
maid
,
in
the
coach
.
<EOS>
And
when
the
coach
at
length
moved
off
,
Walter
on
the
door
-
step
gaily
returned
the
waving
of
her
handkerchief
,
while
the
wooden
midshipman
behind
him
seemed
,
like
himself
,
intent
upon
that
coach
alone
,
excluding
all
the
other
passing
coaches
from
his
observation
.
  
<EOS>
In
good
time
Mr
Dombey
's
mansion
was
gained
again
,
and
again
there
was
a
noise
of
tongues
in
the
library
.
<EOS>
Again
,
too
,
the
coach
was
ordered
to
wait
---
"
for
Mrs
Richards
,
"
one
of
Susan
's
fellow
-
servants
ominously
