,
as
she
passed
with
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
The
entrance
of
the
lost
child
made
a
slight
sensation
,
but
not
much
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
who
had
never
found
her
,
kissed
her
once
upon
the
forehead
,
and
cautioned
her
not
to
run
away
again
,
or
wander
anywhere
with
treacherous
attendants
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
stopped
in
her
lamentations
on
the
corruption
of
human
nature
,
even
when
beckoned
to
the
paths
of
virtue
by
a
Charitable
Grinder
;
and
received
her
with
a
welcome
something
short
of
the
reception
due
to
none
but
perfect
Dombeys
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
regulated
her
feelings
by
the
models
before
her
.
<EOS>
Richards
,
the
culprit
Richards
,
alone
poured
out
her
heart
in
broken
words
of
welcome
,
and
bowed
herself
over
the
little
wandering
head
as
if
she
really
loved
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Richards
!
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
with
a
sigh
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
have
been
much
more
satisfactory
to
those
who
wish
to
think
well
of
their
fellow
creatures
,
and
much
more
becoming
in
you
,
if
you
had
shown
some
proper
feeling
,
in
time
,
for
the
little
child
that
is
now
going
to
be
prematurely
deprived
of
its
natural
nourishment
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Cut
off
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
in
a
plaintive
whisper
,
"
from
one
common
fountain
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
was
my
ungrateful
case
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
solemnly
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
had
your
reflections
,
Richards
<EOS>
,
I
should
feel
as
if
the
Charitable
Grinders
'
dress
would
blight
my
child
,
and
the
education
choke
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
For
the
matter
of
that
---
but
Mrs
Chick
did
n't
know
it
<EOS>
---
he
had
been
pretty
well
blighted
by
the
dress
already
;
and
as
to
the
education
,
even
its
retributive
effect
might
be
produced
in
time
,
for
it
was
a
storm
of
sobs
and
blows
.
  
<EOS>
"
Louisa
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
necessary
to
prolong
these
observations
.
<EOS>
The
woman
is
discharged
and
paid
.
<EOS>
You
leave
this
house
,
Richards
,
for
taking
my
son
---
my
son
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
emphatically
repeating
these
two
words
,
"
into
haunts
and
into
society
which
are
not
to
be
thought
of
without
a
shudder
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
accident
which
befel
Miss
Florence
this
morning
,
I
regard
that
as
,
in
one
great
sense
,
a
happy
and
fortunate
circumstance
;
inasmuch
as
,
but
for
that
occurrence
,
I
never
could
have
known
---
and
from
your
own
lips
too
---
of
what
you
had
been
guilty
.
<EOS>
I
think
,
Louisa
,
the
other
nurse
,
the
young
person
,
"
here
Miss
Nipper
sobbed
aloud
,
"
being
so
much
younger
,
and
necessarily
influenced
by
Paul
's
nurse
,
may
remain
.
<EOS>
Have
the
goodness
to
direct
that
this
woman
's
coach
is
paid
to
"
---
Mr
Dombey
stopped
and
winced
---
"
to
Staggs
's
Gardens
.
"
  
<EOS>
Polly
moved
towards
the
door
,
with
Florence
holding
to
her
dress
,
and
crying
to
her
in
the
most
pathetic
manner
not
to
go
away
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
dagger
in
the
haughty
father
's
heart
,
an
arrow
in
his
brain
,
to
see
how
the
flesh
and
blood
he
could
not
disown
,
clung
to
this
obscure
stranger
,
and
he
sitting
by
.
<EOS>
Not
that
he
cared
to
whom
his
daughter
turned
,
or
from
whom
turned
away
.
<EOS>
The
swift
sharp
agony
struck
through
him
,
as
he
thought
of
what
his
son
might
do
.
  
<EOS>
His
son
cried
lustily
that
night
,
at
all
events
.
<EOS>
Sooth
to
say
,
poor
Paul
had
better
reason
for
his
tears
than
sons
of
that
age
often
have
,
for
he
had
lost
his
second
mother
---
<EOS>
his
first
,
so
far
as
he
knew
---
by
a
stroke
as
sudden
as
that
natural
affliction
which
had
darkened
the
beginning
of
his
life
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
blow
,
his
sister
too
,
who
cried
herself
to
sleep
so
mournfully
,
had
lost
as
good
and
true
a
friend
.
<EOS>
But
that
is
quite
beside
the
question
.
<EOS>
Let
us
waste
no
words
about
it
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
7
.
<EOS>
A
Bird's
-
eye
Glimpse
of
Miss
Tox
's
Dwelling
-
place
;
also
of
the
State
of
Miss
Tox
's
Affections
 
<EOS>
MISS
TOX
inhabited
a
dark
little
house
that
had
been
squeezed
,
at
some
remote
period
of
English
History
,
into
a
fashionable
neighbourhood
at
the
west
end
of
the
town
,
where
it
stood
in
the
shad
like
a
poor
relation
of
the
great
street
round
the
corner
,
coldly
looked
down
upon
by
mighty
mansions
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
exactly
in
a
court
,
and
it
was
not
exactly
in
a
yard
;
but
it
was
in
the
dullest
of
No
-
Thoroughfares
,
rendered
anxious
and
haggard
by
distant
double
knocks
.
<EOS>
The
name
of
this
retirement
,
where
grass
grew
between
the
chinks
in
the
stone
pavement
,
was
Princess
's
Place
;
and
in
Princess
's
Place
was
Princess
's
Chapel
,
with
a
tinkling
bell
,
where
sometimes
as
many
as
five
-
and
-
twenty
people
attended
service
on
a
Sunday
.
<EOS>
The
Princess
's
Arms
was
also
there
,
and
much
resorted
to
by
splendid
footmen
.
<EOS>
A
sedan
chair
was
kept
inside
the
railing
before
the
Princess
's
Arms
,
but
it
had
never
come
out
within
the
memory
of
man
;
and
on
fine
mornings
,
the
top
of
every
rail
(
there
were
eight
-
and
-
forty
,
as
Miss
Tox
had
often
counted
)
was
decorated
with
a
pewter
-
pot
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
another
private
house
besides
Miss
Tox
's
in
Princess
's
Place
:
not
to
mention
an
immense
pair
of
gates
,
with
an
immense
pair
of
lion
-
headed
knockers
on
them
,
which
were
never
opened
by
any
chance
,
and
were
supposed
to
constitute
a
disused
entrance
to
somebody
's
stables
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
there
was
a
smack
of
stabling
in
the
air
of
Princess
's
Place
;
and
Miss
Tox
's
bedroom
(
which
was
at
the
back
)
commanded
a
vista
of
Mews
,
where
hostlers
,
at
whatever
sort
of
work
engaged
,
were
continually
accompanying
themselves
with
effervescent
noises
;
and
where
the
most
domestic
and
confidential
garments
of
coachmen
and
their
wives
and
families
,
usually
hung
,
like
Macbeth
's
banners
,
on
the
outward
walls
.
  
<EOS>
At
this
other
private
house
in
Princess
's
Place
,
tenanted
by
a
retired
butler
who
had
married
a
housekeeper
,
apartments
were
let
Furnished
,
to
a
single
gentleman
:
to
wit
,
a
wooden
-
featured
,
blue
-
faced
Major
,
with
his
eyes
starting
out
of
his
head
,
in
whom
Miss
Tox
recognised
,
as
she
herself
expressed
it
,
"
something
so
truly
military
;
"
and
between
whom
and
herself
,
an
occasional
interchange
of
newspapers
and
pamphlets
,
and
such
Platonic
dalliance
,
was
effected
through
the
medium
of
a
dark
servant
of
the
Major
's
,
who
Miss
Tox
was
quite
content
to
classify
as
a
"
native
,
"
without
connecting
him
with
any
geographical
idea
whatever
.
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
there
never
was
a
smaller
entry
and
staircase
,
than
the
entry
and
staircase
of
Miss
Tox
's
house
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
taken
altogether
,
from
top
to
bottom
,
it
was
the
most
inconvenient
little
house
in
England
,
and
the
crookedest
;
but
then
,
Miss
Tox
said
,
<EOS>
what
a
situation
!
<EOS>
There
was
very
little
daylight
to
be
got
there
in
the
winter
:
<EOS>
no
sun
at
the
best
of
times
<EOS>
:
air
was
out
of
the
question
,
and
traffic
was
walled
out
.
<EOS>
Still
Miss
Tox
said
,
think
of
the
situation
!
<EOS>
So
said
the
blue
-
faced
Major
,
whose
eyes
were
starting
out
of
his
head
:
who
gloried
in
Princess
's
Place
:
and
who
delighted
to
turn
the
conversation
at
his
club
,
whenever
he
could
,
to
something
connected
with
some
of
the
great
people
in
the
great
street
round
the
corner
,
that
he
might
have
the
satisfaction
of
saying
they
were
his
neighbours
.
  
<EOS>
The
dingy
tenement
inhabited
by
Miss
Tox
was
her
own
;
having
been
devised
and
bequeathed
to
her
by
the
deceased
owner
of
the
fishy
eye
in
the
locket
,
of
whom
a
miniature
portrait
,
with
a
powdered
head
and
a
pigtail
,
balanced
the
kettleholder
on
opposite
sides
of
the
parlour
fireplace
.
<EOS>
The
greater
part
of
the
furniture
was
of
the
powdered
-
head
and
pig
-
tail
period
:
comprising
a
platewarmer
,
always
languishing
and
sprawling
its
four
attenuated
bow
legs
in
somebody
's
way
;
and
an
obsolete
harpsichord
,
illuminated
round
the
maker
's
name
with
a
painted
garland
of
sweet
peas
.
  
<EOS>
Although
Major
Bagstock
had
arrived
at
what
is
called
in
polite
literature
,
the
grand
meridian
of
life
,
and
was
proceeding
on
his
journey
down
-
hill
with
hardly
any
throat
,
and
a
very
rigid
pair
of
jaw
-
bones
,
and
long
-
flapped
elephantine
ears
,
and
his
eyes
and
complexion
in
the
state
of
artificial
excitement
already
mentioned
,
he
was
mightily
proud
of
awakening
an
interest
in
Miss
Tox
,
and
tickled
his
vanity
with
the
fiction
that
she
was
a
splendid
woman
,
who
had
her
eye
on
him
.
<EOS>
This
he
had
several
times
hinted
at
the
club
:
in
connexion
with
little
jocularities
,
of
which
old
Joe
Bagstock
,
old
Joey
Bagstock
,
old
J
Bagstock
,
old
Josh
Bagstock
,
or
so
forth
,
was
the
perpetual
theme
:
<EOS>
it
being
,
as
it
were
,
the
Major
's
stronghold
and
donjon
-
keep
of
light
humour
,
to
be
on
the
most
familiar
terms
with
his
own
name
.
  
<EOS>
"
Joey
B
,
Sir
,
"
the
Major
would
say
,
with
a
flourish
of
his
walking
-
stick
,
"
is
worth
a
dozen
of
you
.
<EOS>
If
you
had
a
few
more
of
the
Bagstock
breed
among
you
,
Sir
,
you
'd
be
none
the
worse
for
it
.
<EOS>
Old
Joe
,
Sir
,
need
n't
look
far
for
a
wife
even
now
,
if
he
was
on
the
look
-
out
;
but
he
's
hard
-
hearted
,
Sir
,
is
Joe
---
he
's
tough
,
Sir
,
tough
,
and
de
-
vilish
sly
!
"
<EOS>
After
such
a
declaration
wheezing
sounds
would
be
heard
;
and
the
Major
's
blue
would
deepen
into
purple
,
while
his
eyes
strained
and
started
convulsively
.
  
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
his
very
liberal
laudation
of
himself
,
however
,
the
Major
was
selfish
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
doubted
whether
there
ever
was
a
more
entirely
selfish
person
at
heart
;
or
at
stomach
is
perhaps
a
better
expression
,
seeing
that
he
was
more
decidedly
endowed
with
that
latter
organ
than
with
the
former
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
idea
of
being
overlooked
or
slighted
by
anybody
;
least
of
all
,
had
he
the
remotest
comprehension
of
being
over
-
looked
and
slighted
by
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
,
Miss
Tox
,
as
it
appeared
,
forgot
him
---
gradually
forgot
him
.
<EOS>
She
began
to
forget
him
soon
after
her
discovery
of
the
Toodle
family
.
<EOS>
She
continued
to
forget
him
up
to
the
time
of
the
christening
.
<EOS>
She
went
on
forgetting
him
with
compound
interest
after
that
.
<EOS>
Something
or
somebody
had
superseded
him
as
a
source
of
interest
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
morning
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
,
meeting
Miss
Tox
in
Princess
's
Place
,
some
weeks
after
the
changes
chronicled
in
the
last
chapter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
morning
,
Sir
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
;
very
coldly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Joe
Bagstock
,
Ma'am
,
"
observed
the
Major
,
with
his
usual
gallantry
,
"
has
not
had
the
happiness
of
bowing
to
you
at
your
window
,
for
a
considerable
period
.
<EOS>
Joe
has
been
hardly
used
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
His
sun
has
been
behind
a
cloud
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
inclined
her
head
;
but
very
coldly
indeed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Joe
's
luminary
has
been
out
of
town
,
Ma'am
,
perhaps
,
"
inquired
the
Major
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
?
out
of
town
?
<EOS>
oh
no
,
I
have
not
been
out
of
town
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
much
engaged
lately
.
<EOS>
My
time
is
nearly
all
devoted
to
some
very
intimate
friends
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
I
have
none
to
spare
,
even
now
.
<EOS>
Good
morning
,
Sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
Miss
Tox
,
with
her
most
fascinating
step
and
carriage
,
disappeared
from
Princess
's
Place
,
the
Major
stood
looking
after
her
with
a
bluer
face
than
ever
:
muttering
and
growling
some
not
at
all
complimentary
remarks
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
damme
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
rolling
his
lobster
eyes
round
and
round
Princess
's
Place
,
and
apostrophizing
its
fragrant
air
,
"
six
months
ago
<EOS>
,
the
woman
loved
the
ground
Joe
Bagstock
walked
on
.
<EOS>
What
's
the
meaning
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
decided
,
after
some
consideration
,
that
it
meant
man
-
traps
;
that
it
meant
plotting
and
snaring
;
that
Miss
Tox
was
digging
pitfalls
.
"
<EOS>
But
you
wo
n't
catch
Joe
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
.
<EOS>
"
He
's
tough
,
Ma'am
,
tough
,
is
JB
.
<EOS>
Tough
,
and
de
-
vilish
sly
!
"
<EOS>
over
which
reflection
he
chuckled
for
the
rest
of
the
day
.
  
<EOS>
But
still
,
when
that
day
and
many
other
days
were
gone
and
past
,
it
seemed
that
Miss
Tox
took
no
heed
whatever
of
the
Major
,
and
thought
nothing
at
all
about
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
wo
nt
,
once
upon
a
time
,
to
look
out
at
one
of
her
little
dark
windows
by
accident
,
and
blushingly
return
the
Major
's
greeting
;
but
now
,
she
never
gave
the
Major
a
chance
,
and
cared
nothing
at
all
whether
he
looked
over
the
way
or
not
.
<EOS>
Other
changes
had
come
to
pass
too
.
<EOS>
The
Major
,
standing
in
the
shade
of
his
own
apartment
,
could
make
out
that
an
air
of
greater
smartness
had
recently
come
over
Miss
Tox
's
house
;
that
a
new
cage
with
gilded
wires
had
been
provided
for
the
ancient
little
canary
bird
;
that
divers
ornaments
,
cut
out
of
coloured
card
-
boards
and
paper
,
seemed
to
decorate
the
chimney
-
piece
and
tables
;
that
a
plant
or
two
had
suddenly
sprung
up
in
the
windows
;
that
Miss
Tox
occasionally
practised
on
the
harpsichord
,
whose
garland
of
sweet
peas
was
always
displayed
ostentatiously
,
crowned
with
the
Copenhagen
and
Bird
Waltzes
in
a
Music
Book
of
Miss
Tox
's
own
copying
.
  
<EOS>
Over
and
above
all
this
,
Miss
Tox
had
long
been
dressed
with
uncommon
care
and
elegance
in
slight
mourning
.
<EOS>
But
this
helped
the
Major
out
of
his
difficulty
;
and
he
determined
within
himself
that
she
had
come
into
a
small
legacy
,
and
grown
proud
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
on
the
very
next
day
after
he
had
eased
his
mind
by
arriving
at
this
decision
,
that
the
Major
,
sitting
at
his
breakfast
,
saw
an
apparition
so
tremendous
and
wonderful
in
Miss
Tox
's
little
drawing
-
room
,
that
he
remained
for
some
time
rooted
to
his
chair
;
then
,
rushing
into
the
next
room
,
returned
with
a
double
-
barrelled
opera
-
glass
,
through
which
he
surveyed
it
intently
for
some
minutes
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
Baby
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
shutting
up
the
glass
again
,
"
for
fifty
thousand
pounds
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
could
n't
forget
it
.
<EOS>
He
could
do
nothing
but
whistle
,
and
stare
to
that
extent
,
that
his
eyes
compared
with
what
they
now
became
,
had
been
in
former
times
quite
cavernous
and
sunken
.
<EOS>
Day
after
day
,
two
,
three
,
four
times
a
week
,
this
Baby
reappeared
.
<EOS>
The
Major
continued
to
stare
and
whistle
.
<EOS>
To
all
other
intents
and
purposes
he
was
alone
in
Princess
's
Place
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
has
ceased
to
mind
what
he
did
.
<EOS>
He
might
have
been
black
as
well
as
blue
,
and
it
would
have
been
of
no
consequence
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
The
perseverance
with
which
she
walked
out
of
Princess
's
Place
to
fetch
this
baby
and
its
nurse
,
and
walked
back
with
them
,
and
walked
home
with
them
again
,
and
continually
mounted
guard
over
them
;
and
the
perseverance
with
which
she
nursed
it
herself
,
and
fed
it
,
and
played
with
it
,
and
froze
its
young
blood
with
airs
upon
the
harpsichord
;
was
extraordinary
.
<EOS>
At
about
this
same
period
,
too
,
she
was
seized
with
a
passion
for
looking
at
a
certain
bracelet
;
also
with
a
passion
for
looking
at
the
moon
,
of
which
she
would
take
long
observations
from
her
chamber
window
.
<EOS>
But
whatever
she
looked
at
;
sun
,
moon
,
stars
,
or
bracelet
;
she
looked
no
more
at
the
Major
.
<EOS>
And
the
Major
whistled
,
and
stared
,
and
wondered
,
and
dodged
about
his
room
,
and
could
make
nothing
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
quite
win
my
brother
Paul
's
heart
,
and
that
's
the
truth
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
one
day
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
turned
pale
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
grows
more
like
Paul
every
day
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
returned
no
other
reply
than
by
taking
the
little
Paul
in
her
arms
,
and
making
his
cockade
perfectly
flat
and
limp
with
her
caresses
.
  
<EOS>
"
His
mother
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
"
whose
acquaintance
I
was
to
have
made
through
you
,
<EOS>
does
he
at
all
resemble
her
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
at
all
,
"
returned
Louisa
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
was
---
she
was
pretty
,
I
believe
?
"
<EOS>
faltered
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
poor
dear
Fanny
was
interesting
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
after
some
judicial
consideration
.
"
<EOS>
Certainly
interesting
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
that
air
of
commanding
superiority
which
one
would
somehow
expect
,
almost
as
a
matter
of
course
,
to
find
in
my
brother
's
wife
;
nor
had
she
that
strength
and
vigour
of
mind
which
such
a
man
requires
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
heaved
a
deep
sigh
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
she
was
pleasing
:
"
said
Mrs
Chick
:
"
<EOS>
extremely
so
.
<EOS>
And
she
meant
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
oh
,
dear
,
how
well
poor
Fanny
meant
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
Angel
!
"
cried
Miss
Tox
to
little
Paul
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
picture
of
you
own
Papa
!
"
  
<EOS>
If
the
Major
could
have
known
how
many
hopes
and
ventures
,
what
a
multitude
of
plans
and
speculations
,
rested
on
that
baby
head
;
and
could
have
seen
them
hovering
,
in
all
their
heterogeneous
confusion
and
disorder
,
round
the
puckered
cap
of
the
unconscious
little
Paul
;
he
might
have
stared
indeed
.
<EOS>
Then
would
he
have
recognised
,
among
the
crowd
,
some
few
ambitious
motes
and
beams
belonging
to
Miss
Tox
;
then
would
he
perhaps
have
understood
the
nature
of
that
lady
's
faltering
investment
in
the
Dombey
Firm
.
  
<EOS>
If
the
child
himself
could
have
awakened
in
the
night
,
and
seen
,
gathered
about
his
cradle
-
curtains
,
faint
reflections
of
the
dreams
that
other
people
had
of
him
,
they
might
have
scared
him
,
with
good
reason
.
<EOS>
But
he
slumbered
on
,
alike
unconscious
of
the
kind
intentions
of
Miss
Tox
,
the
wonder
of
the
Major
,
the
early
sorrows
of
his
sister
,
and
the
stern
visions
of
his
father
;
and
innocent
that
any
spot
of
earth
contained
a
Dombey
or
a
Son
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
8
.
<EOS>
Paul
's
further
Progress
,
Growth
,
and
Character
 
BENEATH
the
watching
and
attentive
eyes
of
Time
---
so
far
another
Major
<EOS>
---
Paul
's
slumbers
gradually
changed
.
<EOS>
More
and
more
light
broke
in
upon
them
;
distincter
and
distincter
dreams
disturbed
them
;
an
accumulating
crowd
of
objects
and
impressions
swarmed
about
his
rest
;
and
so
he
passed
from
babyhood
to
childhood
,
and
became
a
talking
,
walking
,
wondering
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
downfall
and
banishment
of
Richards
,
the
nursery
may
be
said
to
have
been
put
into
commission
:
as
a
Public
Department
is
sometimes
,
when
no
individual
Atlas
can
be
found
to
support
it
.
<EOS>
The
Commissioners
were
,
of
course
,
Mrs
Chick
and
Miss
Tox
:
who
devoted
themselves
to
their
duties
with
such
astonishing
ardour
that
Major
Bagstock
had
every
day
some
new
reminder
of
his
being
forsaken
,
while
Mr
Chick
,
bereft
of
domestic
supervision
,
cast
himself
upon
the
gay
world
,
dined
at
clubs
and
coffee
-
houses
,
smelt
of
smoke
on
three
different
occasions
,
went
to
the
play
by
himself
,
and
in
short
,
loosened
(
as
Mrs
Chick
once
told
him
)
every
social
bond
,
and
moral
obligation
.
  
<EOS>
Yet
,
in
spite
of
his
early
promise
,
all
this
vigilance
and
care
could
not
make
little
Paul
a
thriving
boy
.
<EOS>
Naturally
delicate
,
perhaps
,
he
pined
and
wasted
after
the
dismissal
of
his
nurse
,
and
,
for
a
long
time
,
seemed
but
to
wait
his
opportunity
of
gliding
through
their
hands
,
and
seeking
his
lost
mother
.
<EOS>
This
dangerous
ground
in
his
steeple
-
chase
towards
manhood
passed
,
he
still
found
it
very
rough
riding
,
and
was
grievously
beset
by
all
the
obstacles
in
his
course
.
<EOS>
Every
tooth
was
a
break
-
neck
fence
,
and
every
pimple
in
the
measles
a
stone
wall
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
down
in
every
fit
of
the
hooping
-
cough
,
and
rolled
upon
and
crushed
by
a
whole
field
of
small
diseases
,
that
came
trooping
on
each
other
's
heels
to
prevent
his
getting
up
again
.
<EOS>
Some
bird
of
prey
got
into
his
throat
instead
of
the
thrush
;
and
the
very
chickens
turning
ferocious
---
if
they
have
anything
to
do
with
that
infant
malady
to
which
they
lend
their
name
---
worried
him
like
tiger
-
cats
.
  
<EOS>
The
chill
of
Paul
's
christening
had
struck
home
,
perhaps
to
some
sensitive
part
of
his
nature
,
which
could
not
recover
itself
in
the
cold
shade
of
his
father
;
but
he
was
an
unfortunate
child
from
that
day
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Wickam
often
said
she
never
see
a
dear
so
put
upon
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Wickam
was
a
waiter
's
wife
---
which
would
seem
equivalent
to
being
any
other
man
's
widow
---
whose
application
for
an
engagement
in
Mr
Dombey
's
service
had
been
favourably
considered
,
on
account
of
the
apparent
impossibility
of
her
having
any
followers
,
or
any
one
to
follow
;
and
who
,
from
within
a
day
or
two
of
Paul
's
sharp
weaning
,
had
been
engaged
as
his
nurse
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Wickam
was
a
meek
woman
,
of
a
fair
complexion
,
with
her
eyebrows
always
elevated
,
and
her
head
always
drooping
;
who
was
always
ready
to
pity
herself
,
or
to
be
pitied
,
or
to
pity
anybody
else
;
and
who
had
a
surprising
natural
gift
of
viewing
all
subjects
in
an
utterly
forlorn
and
pitiable
light
,
and
bringing
dreadful
precedents
to
bear
upon
them
,
and
deriving
the
greatest
consolation
from
the
exercise
of
that
talent
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
hardly
necessary
to
observe
,
that
no
touch
of
this
quality
ever
reached
the
magnificent
knowledge
of
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
remarkable
,
indeed
,
if
any
had
;
when
no
one
in
the
house
---
not
even
Mrs
Chick
or
Miss
Tox
---
dared
ever
whisper
to
him
that
there
had
,
on
any
one
occasion
,
been
the
least
reason
for
uneasiness
in
reference
to
little
Paul
.
<EOS>
He
had
settled
,
within
himself
,
that
the
child
must
necessarily
pass
through
a
certain
routine
of
minor
maladies
,
and
that
the
sooner
he
did
so
the
better
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
have
bought
him
off
,
or
provided
a
substitute
,
as
in
the
case
of
an
unlucky
drawing
for
the
militia
,
he
would
have
been
glad
to
do
so
on
liberal
terms
.
<EOS>
But
as
this
was
not
feasible
,
he
merely
wondered
,
in
his
haughty
manner
,
now
<EOS>
and
then
,
what
Nature
meant
by
it
;
and
comforted
himself
with
the
reflection
that
there
was
another
milestone
passed
upon
the
road
,
and
that
the
great
end
of
the
journey
lay
so
much
the
nearer
.
<EOS>
For
the
feeling
uppermost
in
his
mind
,
now
and
constantly
intensifying
,
and
increasing
in
it
as
Paul
grew
older
,
was
impatience
.
<EOS>
Impatience
for
the
time
to
come
,
when
his
visions
of
their
united
consequence
and
grandeur
would
be
triumphantly
realized
.
  
<EOS>
Some
Philosophers
tell
us
that
selfishness
is
at
the
root
of
our
best
loves
and
affections
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
young
child
was
,
from
the
beginning
,
so
distinctly
important
to
him
as
a
part
of
his
own
greatness
,
or
(
which
is
the
same
thing
)
of
the
greatness
of
Dombey
and
Son
,
that
there
is
no
doubt
his
parental
affection
might
have
been
easily
traced
,
like
many
a
goodly
super
-
structure
of
fair
fame
,
to
a
very
low
foundation
.
<EOS>
But
he
loved
his
son
with
all
the
love
he
had
.
<EOS>
If
there
were
a
warm
place
in
his
frosty
heart
,
his
son
occupied
it
;
if
its
very
hard
surface
could
receive
the
impression
of
any
image
,
the
image
of
that
son
was
there
;
though
not
so
much
as
an
infant
,
or
as
a
boy
,
but
as
a
grown
man
---
the
"
Son
"
of
the
Firm
.
<EOS>
Therefore
he
was
impatient
to
advance
into
the
future
,
and
to
hurry
over
the
intervening
passages
of
his
history
.
<EOS>
Therefore
he
had
little
or
no
anxiety
about
them
,
in
spite
of
his
love
;
feeling
as
if
the
boy
had
a
charmed
life
,
and
must
become
the
man
with
whom
he
held
such
constant
communication
in
his
thoughts
,
and
for
whom
he
planned
and
projected
,
as
for
an
existing
reality
,
every
day
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
Paul
grew
to
be
nearly
five
years
old
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
pretty
little
fellow
;
though
there
was
something
wan
and
wistful
in
his
small
face
,
that
gave
occasion
to
many
significant
shakes
of
Mrs
Wickam
's
head
,
and
many
long
-
drawn
inspirations
of
Mrs
Wickam
's
breath
.
<EOS>
His
temper
gave
abundant
promise
of
being
imperious
in
after
-
life
;
and
he
had
as
hopeful
an
apprehension
of
his
own
importance
,
and
the
rightful
subservience
of
all
other
things
and
persons
to
it
,
as
heart
could
desire
.
<EOS>
He
was
childish
and
sportive
enough
at
times
,
and
not
of
a
sullen
disposition
;
but
he
had
a
strange
,
old
-
fashioned
,
thoughtful
way
,
at
other
times
,
of
sitting
brooding
in
his
miniature
armchair
,
when
he
looked
(
and
talked
)
like
one
of
those
terrible
little
Beings
in
the
Fairy
tales
,
who
,
at
a
hundred
and
fifty
or
two
hundred
years
of
age
,
fantastically
represent
the
children
for
whom
they
have
been
substituted
.
<EOS>
He
would
frequently
be
stricken
with
this
precocious
mood
upstairs
in
the
nursery
;
and
would
sometimes
lapse
into
it
suddenly
,
exclaiming
that
he
was
tired
:
even
while
playing
with
Florence
,
or
driving
Miss
Tox
in
single
harness
.
<EOS>
But
at
no
time
did
he
fall
into
it
so
surely
,
as
when
,
his
little
chair
being
carried
down
into
his
father
's
room
,
he
sat
there
with
him
after
dinner
,
by
the
fire
.
<EOS>
They
were
the
strangest
pair
at
such
a
time
that
ever
firelight
shone
upon
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
so
erect
and
solemn
,
gazing
at
the
blaze
;
his
little
image
,
with
an
old
,
old
face
,
peering
into
the
red
perspective
with
the
fixed
and
rapt
attention
of
a
sage
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
entertaining
complicated
worldly
schemes
and
plans
;
the
little
image
entertaining
Heaven
knows
what
wild
fancies
,
half
-
formed
thoughts
,
and
wandering
speculations
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
stiff
with
starch
and
arrogance
;
the
little
image
by
inheritance
,
and
in
unconscious
imitation
.
<EOS>
The
two
so
very
much
alike
,
and
yet
so
monstrously
contrasted
.
  
<EOS>
On
one
of
these
occasions
,
when
they
had
both
been
perfectly
quiet
for
a
long
time
,
and
Mr
Dombey
only
knew
that
the
child
was
awake
by
occasionally
glancing
at
his
eye
,
where
the
bright
fire
was
sparkling
like
a
jewel
,
little
Paul
broke
silence
thus
:
  
"
Papa
!
<EOS>
what
's
money
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
abrupt
question
had
such
immediate
reference
to
the
subject
of
Mr
Dombey
's
thoughts
,
that
Mr
Dombey
was
quite
disconcerted
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
money
,
Paul
?
"
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
Money
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
child
,
laying
his
hands
upon
the
elbows
of
his
little
chair
,
and
turning
the
old
face
up
towards
Mr
Dombey
's
;
"
what
is
money
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
was
in
a
difficulty
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
liked
to
give
him
some
explanation
involving
the
terms
circulating
-
medium
,
currency
,
depreciation
of
currency
,
paper
,
bullion
,
rates
of
exchange
,
value
of
precious
metals
in
the
market
,
and
so
forth
;
but
looking
down
at
the
little
chair
,
and
seeing
what
a
long
way
down
it
was
,
he
answered
:
"
Gold
,
and
silver
,
and
copper
.
<EOS>
Guineas
,
shillings
,
half
-
pence
.
<EOS>
You
know
what
they
are
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
I
know
what
they
are
,
"
said
Paul
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
that
,
Papa
.
<EOS>
I
mean
what
's
money
after
all
?
"
  
<EOS>
Heaven
and
Earth
<EOS>
,
how
old
his
face
was
as
he
turned
it
up
again
towards
his
father
's
!
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
money
after
all
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
backing
his
chair
a
little
,
that
he
might
the
better
gaze
in
sheer
amazement
at
the
presumptuous
atom
that
propounded
such
an
inquiry
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
Papa
,
what
can
it
do
?
"
returned
Paul
,
folding
his
arms
(
they
were
hardly
long
enough
to
fold
)
,
and
looking
at
the
fire
,
and
up
at
him
,
and
at
the
fire
,
and
up
at
him
again
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
drew
his
chair
back
to
its
former
place
,
and
patted
him
on
the
head
.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
know
better
by
-
and
-
by
,
my
man
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Money
,
Paul
,
can
do
anything
.
"
<EOS>
He
took
hold
of
the
little
hand
,
and
beat
it
softly
against
one
of
his
own
,
as
he
said
so
.
  
<EOS>
But
Paul
got
his
hand
free
as
soon
as
he
could
;
and
rubbing
it
gently
to
and
fro
on
the
elbow
of
his
chair
,
as
if
his
wit
were
in
the
palm
,
and
he
were

---
and
looking
at
the
fire
again
,
as
though
the
fire
had
been
his
adviser
and

---
<EOS>
repeated
,
after
a
short
pause
:
   
<EOS>
"
Anything
,
Papa
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Anything
---
almost
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Anything
means
everything
,
do
n't
it
,
Papa
?
"
asked
his
son
:
not
observing
,
or
possibly

,
the
qualification
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
includes
it
:
<EOS>
yes
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
did
n't
money
save
me
my
Mama
?
"
returned
the
child
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
n't
cruel
,
is

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Cruel
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
settling
his

,
and
seeming
to
resent

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
A
good

ca

cruel
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
it
's
a
good

,
and
can
do
anything
,
"
said
the
little
fellow
,
thoughtfully
,
as

back

the
fire
,
"
I
wonder
why
it
did
n't
save
me
my
Mama
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
did
n't
ask
the
question
of
his
father
this

.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
had
seen
,
with
a
child

,
that
it
had
already
made
his
father
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
But
he
repeated
the

,
as
if
it
were
quite
an
old
one
to
him
,
and
had
troubled
him
very

;
and
sat
with

,
still

and
looking
for

in

fire
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
having
recovered
from
his
surprise
,
not
to
say
his
alarm
(
for
it
was
the
very
first

on
which

child
had
ever
broached
the
subject
of
his
mother
to
him
,
though

had

him

,
in

,
evening

)
,
expounded
to
him
how
that
money
,
though
a
very
potent
spirit
,
never
to
be
disparaged
on
any

whatever
,
could
not
keep
people
alive
whose
time
was
come
to
die
;
and
how
that
we
must
all
die
,
unfortunately
,
even
in
the
City
,
though
we
were
never
so
rich
.
<EOS>
But
how
that
money
caused
us
to
be
honoured
,
feared
,
respected
,
courted
,
and

,
and
made

in

;
and
how
that
it
could
,
very

,
even
keep
off

,
for

.
<EOS>
How
,
for

,
it
had
secured
to

Mr

,
by

,
Paul
,
had
often

;
likewise
of

great

Parker

,
whom

.
<EOS>
And
how
it
could
do
all
,
that
could

.
<EOS>
This
,
with
more
to
the

,
Mr

instilled

son
,
who
listened

,
and
seemed

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
ca

strong

,

,
Papa
;

?
"
asked
Paul
,
after

;
rubbing

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
are
strong

quite
well
,
"
returned

.
<EOS>
"
Are

?
"
  
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
the
age
of
the

was

,
with

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
Eh

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Florence

,

,
"

;
"

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
"

"

ache

so
(
Wickam

)
,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
<EOS>

,
"

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

"

;

,

.
<EOS>
At

curi
-
ous
things
!
"
  
<EOS>
And

,

,
and
thinking

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr

was

,

,

,
that

,

,

.
<EOS>
Once

,

for

.
<EOS>
But

sought
the
fire
again
as

;

,
addressed
towards

,

,
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

Florence
to

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Wo

come

poor

Wickam
,
Master
Paul
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
that

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
wo
n't
,
"

,

,
like

.
  
<EOS>
Invoking

upon

,
Mrs
Wickam

,
and
presently

appeared
in

.
<EOS>
The
child
immediately
started

with
sudden

and

,
and
raised

his
father
in

,

,

,

,

,
was

.
  
<EOS>
After

room
together
,
he
thought

;
and
remembering
that
Paul
had
said

sister
sung
to
him
,

had

,

.
<EOS>
She
was

,

,

him
in

;

,

.
<EOS>
So

went
,

up
;
she

all

,

Paul
sometimes

.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
looked
after

until

---
not

---

;

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick

were

;

<EOS>
"
For

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
This

Mrs
Pipchin
was

,

.
<EOS>
Forty

been

;

,

,

,

,

itself

,

.
<EOS>
She

"

"

;
and

was
,

---

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
The

of
this

-

;

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
At

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Mrs

's
niece
,

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
,
whose

,

-

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
As

,

,

(
otherwise

)

;

.

,

;

,

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
For
tea
there
was

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Though
Mrs
Pipchin
got

,

,

,

for
she
was
as
fierce
as
ever
,
and
the
hard
grey
eye
knew
no
softening
.
  
<EOS>
After
tea
,
Berry
brought
out
a
little
work
-
box
,
with
the
Royal
Pavilion
on
the
lid
,
and
fell
to
working
busily
;
while
Mrs
Pipchin
,
having
put
on
her
spectacles
and
opened
a
great
volume
bound
in
green
baize
,
began
to
nod
.
<EOS>
And
whenever
Mrs
Pipchin
caught
herself
falling
forward
into
the
fire
,
and
woke
up
,
she
filliped
Master
Bitherstone
on
the
nose
for
nodding
too
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
it
was
the
children
's
bedtime
,
and
after
prayers
they
went
to
bed
.
<EOS>
As
little
Miss
Pankey
was
afraid
of
sleeping
alone
in
the
dark
,
Mrs
Pipchin
always
made
a
point
of
driving
her
up
stairs
herself
,
like
a
sheep
;
and
it
was
cheerful
to
hear
Miss
Pankey
moaning
long
afterwards
,
in
the
least
eligible
chamber
,
and
Mrs
Pipchin
now
and
then
going
in
to
shake
her
.
<EOS>
At
about
halfpast
nine
o'clock
the
odour
of
a
warm
sweet
-
bread
(
Mrs
Pipchin
's
constitution
would
n't
go
to
sleep
without
sweet
-
bread
)
<EOS>
diversified
the
prevailing
fragrance
of
the
house
,
which
Mrs
Wickam
said
was
"
a
smell
of
building
;
"
and
slumber
fell
upon
the
Castle
shortly
after
.
  
<EOS>
The
breakfast
next
morning
was
like
the
tea
over
night
,
except
that
Mrs
Pipchin
took
her
roll
instead
of
toast
,
and
seemed
a
little
more
irate
when
it
was
over
.
<EOS>
Master
Bitherstone
read
aloud
to
the
rest
a
pedigree
from
Genesis
(
judi
-
ciously
selected
by
Mrs
Pipchin
)
,
getting
over
the
names
with
the
ease
and
clearness
of
a
person
tumbling
up

.
<EOS>
That
done
,
Miss
Pankey
was
borne
away
to
be
shampoo'd
;
and
Master
Bitherstone
to
have
something
else
done
to
him
with
salt
water
,
from
which
he
always
returned
very
blue
and
dejected
.
<EOS>
Paul
and
Florence
went
out
in
the
meantime
on
the
beach
with
Wickam
---
who
was
constantly
in
tears
---
and
at
about
noon
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
presided
over
some
Early
Readings
.
<EOS>
It
being
a
part
of
Mrs
Pipchin
's
system
not
to
encourage
a
child
's
mind
to
develop
and
expand
itself
like
a
young
flower
,
but
to
open
it
by
force
like
an
oyster
,
the
moral
of
these
lessons
was
usually
of
a
violent
and
stunning
character
:
the
hero
---
a
naughty
boy
---
seldom
,
in
the
mildest
catastrophe
,
being
finished
off
by
anything
less
than
a
lion
,
or
a
bear
.
  
<EOS>
Such
was
life
at
Mrs
Pipchin
's
.
<EOS>
On
Saturday
Mr
Dombey
came
down
;
and
Florence
and
Paul
would
go
to
his
Hotel
,
and
have
tea
.
<EOS>
They
passed
the
whole
of
Sunday
with
him
,
and
generally
rode
out
before
dinner
;
and
on
these

Mr
Dombey
seemed
to
grow
,
like
Falstaff
's
assailants
,
and
instead
of
being
one
man
in

,
to
become
a
dozen
.
<EOS>
Sunday
evening
was
the
most
melancholy
evening
in
the
week
;
for
Mrs
Pipchin
always
made
a
point
of
being
particularly
cross
on
Sunday
nights
.
<EOS>
Miss
Pankey
was
generally
brought
back
from
an
aunt
's
at
Rottingdean
,
in
deep
distress
;
and
Master
Bitherstone
,
whose
relatives
were
all
in
India
,
and
who
was
required
to
sit
,
between

,

with

,

,
suffered
so

in
his
young

that
he
once
asked
Florence
,
on
a

night
,
if
she
could
give
him
any
idea
of
the
way
back
to
Bengal
.
  
<EOS>
But
it
was
generally
said
that
Mrs
Pipchin
was
a
woman
of
system
with
children
;
and
no
doubt
she
was
.
<EOS>
Certainly
the
wild
ones
went
home
tame
enough
,
after
sojourning
for
a
few
months
beneath
her
hospitable
roof
.
<EOS>
It
was
generally
said
,
too
,
that
it
was
highly
creditable
of
Mrs
Pipchin
to
have
devoted

to
this
way

life
,
and
to

such

of
her

,
and

stand
against
her

,
when
Mr
Pipchin
broke
his
heart
in
the
Peruvian
mines
.
  
<EOS>
At
this
exemplary
old
lady
,
Paul
would
sit
staring
in
his
little
arm
-
chair
by
the
fire
,
for
any
length

.
<EOS>
He
never
seemed
to
know
what
weariness
was
,
when
he
was
looking
fixedly
at
Mrs
Pipchin
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
fond
of
her
;
he
was

;
but
in
those
old
,
old

of

,
she
seemed
to
have
a
grotesque

for

.
<EOS>
There
he
would
sit
,
looking
at

,
and
warming

hands
,
and
looking
at
her
,
until
he
sometimes
quite
confounded
Mrs
Pipchin
,
Ogress
as

was
.
<EOS>
Once
she
asked
him
,
when

,
what

thinking

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
,
"
said

,
without

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
are

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
That

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"
Not

?
"

<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

"
to

,
Wickam

<EOS>
"
  
"
Wickam
,
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

?
<EOS>
Nobody
can
go

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
Sir
?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

should

to

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
As

had
not

in

,
and

on

,

.
<EOS>
But

sat
turning
it
over

,
with

of
fixing
Mrs
Pipchin
presently
,
that

hardy

deemed

prudent

.
  
<EOS>
From
that

,
Mrs
Pipchin
appeared
to
have
something
of

odd

,
as

.
<EOS>
She
would
make

fire
,

;
and

Mrs
Pipchin
and

fender
,
with

of

little

the

,

,
and

hard

,
until

Pipchin
was
sometimes
fain

shut

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
had
an
old
black
cat
,
who
generally
lay
coiled
upon
the
centre
foot
of
the
fender
,
purring

,
and
winking
at
the
fire
until
the
contracted

of
his

were
like
two
notes
of
admiration
.
<EOS>
The
good
old
lady
might
have
been
---
not
to
record

disrespectfully
---
a
witch
,
and
Paul
and
the
cat
her
two
familiars
,
as
they
all
sat
by

.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
quite
in
keeping
with
the
appearance
of
the
party
if

had
all
sprung
up
the

in
a
high

,
and
never

.
  
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
never
came
to
pass
.
<EOS>
The
cat
,
and
Paul
,
and
Mrs
Pipchin
,
were
constantly
to
be
found
in
their
usual

after

;
and
Paul
,
eschewing
the

of
Master
Bitherstone
,
went
on
studying
Mrs
Pipchin
,
and
the
cat
,
and
the
fire
,
night

,
as
if

were
a
book
of

,
in
three

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Wickam
put
her
own
construction
on
Paul
's
eccentricities
:
and
being
confirmed
in
her
low
spirits
by
a
perplexed
view
of
chimneys
from
the
room
where
she
was
accustomed
to
sit
,
and
by
the
noise
of
the
wind
,
and
by
the
general
dulness
(
gashliness
was
Mrs
Wickam
's
strong
expression
)
of
her
present
life
,
deduced
the
most
dismal
reflections
from
the
foregoing

.
<EOS>
It
was
a
part
of
Mrs
Pipchin
's
policy
to
prevent
her
own
"
young
hussy
"
---
that
was
Mrs

's

for
female

---

with
Mrs
Wickam
:
to
which
end
she
devoted
much

to

behind

,
and

out
on
that
devoted

,

's

.
<EOS>
But
Berry
was
free
to
hold
what

she
could
in
that
quarter
consistently
with
the
discharge
of
the

;
and
to
Berry

Wickam
unburdened

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
pretty

he
is
when

!
"
<EOS>
said

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

's

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
Oh
,

.
<EOS>
No

was

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
Berry

.

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

R"How
!

.
<EOS>
I

,

.

<EOS>
Miss

?
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

Miss

"

,

<EOS>
Master

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
"

's

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Miss
,
she
is
alive
,
"
returned
Mrs
Wickam
with
an
air
of
triumph
,
for
it
was
evident
Miss
Berry
expected
the
reverse
;
"
and
is
married
to
a
silverchaser
.
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
Miss
,
SHE
is
alive
,
"
said
Mrs
Wickam
,
laying
strong
stress
on
her
nominative
case
.
  
<EOS>
It
being
clear
that
somebody
was
dead
,
Mrs
Pipchin
's
niece
inquired
who
it
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
n't
wish
to
make
you
uneasy
,
"
returned
Mrs
Wickam
,
pursuing
her
supper
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
ask
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
the
surest
way
of
being
asked
again
.
<EOS>
Miss
Berry
repeated
her
question
,
therefore
;
and
after
some
resistance
,
and
reluctance
,
Mrs
Wickam
laid
down
her
knife
,
and
again
glancing
round
the
room
and
at
Paul
in
bed
,
replied
:
  
"
<EOS>
She
took
fancies
to
people
;
whimsical
fancies
,
some
of
them
;
others
,
affections
that
one
might
expect
to
see
---
only
stronger
than
common
.
<EOS>
They
all
died
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
so
very
unexpected
and
awful
to
Mrs
Pipchin
's
niece
,
that
she
sat
upright
on
the
hard

of
the
bedstead
,
breathing
short
,
and
surveying
her
informant
with

of
undisguised

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Wickam
shook
her
left
fore
-
finger
stealthily
towards
the
bed
where
Florence
lay
;
then
turned
it
upside
down
,
and
made
several
emphatic
points
at
the
floor
;
immediately
below
which
was
the
parlour
in
which
Mrs
Pipchin
habitually
consumed
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Remember
my
words
,
Miss
Berry
,
"
said
Mrs
Wickam
,
"
and
be
thankful
that
Master
Paul
is
not
too
fond
of
you
.
<EOS>
I
am
,
that
he
's
not
too
fond
of
me
<EOS>
,
I
assure
you
;
though
there
is
n't
much
to
live
for
---
you
'll
excuse
my
being
so
free
---
in
this
jail
of
a
house
!
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Berry
's
emotion
might
have
led
to
her
patting
Paul
too
hard
on
the
back
,
or
might

produced
a
cessation
of
that
soothing

,
but
he
turned
in
his
bed
just
now
,
and
,
presently
awaking
,
sat
up
in
it
with
his
hair
hot
and
wet
from
the
effects
of
some
childish
dream
,
and
asked
for
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
out
of
her
own
bed
at
the
first
sound
of
his
voice
;
and
bending
over
his

immediately
,
sang
him
to
sleep
again
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Wickam
shaking
her
head
,
and
letting
fall
several
tears
,
pointed
out
the
little
group
to
Berry
,
and
turned
her
eyes
up
to
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
Miss
!
"
said
Wickam
,
softly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
Your
aunt
is
an
old
lady
,
Miss
Berry
,
and
it
's
what
you
must
have
looked
for
,
often
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
consolatory

,
Mrs
Wickam
accompanied
with
a
look
of
heartfelt
anguish
;
and
being
left
alone
with
the
two
children
again
,
and
becoming
conscious
that
the
wind
was
blowing
mournfully
<EOS>
,
she
indulged
in
melancholy
---
that
cheapest
and
most
accessible
of
luxuries
---
until
she
was
overpowered
by
slumber
.
  
<EOS>
Although
the
niece
of
Mrs
Pipchin
did
not
expect
to
find
that
exemplary
dragon
prostrate
on
the
hearth
-
rug
when
she
went
down
stairs
,
she
was
relieved
to
find
her
unusually
fractious
and
severe
,
and
with
every
present
appearance
of
intending
to
live
a
long
time
to
be

comfort
to
all
who
knew
her
.
<EOS>
Nor
had
she
any
symptoms
of
declining
,
in
the
course
of
the
ensuing
week
,
when
the
constitutional
viands
still
continued
to
disappear
in
regular

,
notwithstanding
that
Paul
studied
her
as
attentively
as
ever
,
and
occupied
his
usual
seat
between
the
black
skirts
and
the
fender
,
with
unwavering
constancy
.
  
<EOS>
But
as
Paul
himself
was
no
stronger
at
the
expiration
of
that
time
than
he
had
been
on
his
first
arrival
,
though
he
looked
much
healthier
in
the
face
,
a
little
carriage
was
got
for
him
,
in
which
he
could
lie
at
his
ease
,
with
an
alphabet
and
other
elementary
works
of
reference
,
and
be
wheeled
down
to
the
sea
-
side
.
<EOS>
Consistent
in
his
odd
tastes
,
the
child
set
aside
a
ruddy
-
faced
lad
who
was
proposed
as
the
drawer
of
this
carriage
,
and
selected
,
instead
,
his
grandfather
---
a
weazen
,
old
,
crab
-
faced
man
,
in
a
suit
of
battered
oilskin
,
who
had
got
tough
and
stringy
from
long
pickling
in
salt
water
,
and
who
smelt
like
a
weedy
sea
-
beach
when
the
tide
is
out
.
  
<EOS>
With
this
notable
attendant
to
pull
him
along
,
and
Florence
always
walking
by
his
side
,
and
the
despondent
Wickam
bringing
up
the
rear
,
he
went
down
to
the
margin
of
the
ocean
every
day
;
and
there
he
would
sit
or
lie
in
his
carriage
for
hours
together
:
never
so
distressed
as
by
the
company
of
children
---
Florence
alone
excepted
,
always
.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
away
,
if
you
please
,
"
he
would
say
to
any
child
who
came
to
bear
him
company
.
"
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
but
I
do
n't
want
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Some
small
voice
,
near
his
ear
,
would
ask
him
how
he
was
,
perhaps
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
well
<EOS>
,
I
thank
you
,
"
he
would
answer
.
"
<EOS>
But
you
had
better
go
and
play
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
he
would
turn
his
head
,
and
watch
the
child
away
,
and
say
to
Florence
,
"
We
do
n't
want
any
others
,
do
we
?
<EOS>
Kiss
me
,
Floy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
even
a
dislike
,
at
such
times
,
to
the
company
of
Wickam
,
and
was
well
pleased
when
she
strolled
away
,
as
she
generally
did
,
to
pick
up
shells
and
acquaintances
.
<EOS>
His
favourite
spot
was
quite
a
lonely
one
,
far
away
from
most
loungers
;
and
with
Florence
sitting
by
his
side
at
work
,
or
reading
to
him
,
or
talking
to
him
,
and
the
wind
blowing
on
his
face
,
and
the
water
coming
up
among
the
wheels
of
his
bed
,
he
wanted
nothing
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
Floy
,
"
he
said
one
day
,
"
where
's
India
,
where
that
boy
's
friends
live
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
a
long
,
long

off
,
"
said
Florence
,
raising
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
Weeks
off
?
"
asked
Paul
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
dear
.
<EOS>
Many
weeks
'
journey
,
night
and
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
were
in
India
,
Floy
,
"
said
Paul
,
after

,
"
I
should
---
what

that
Mama
did
?
<EOS>
I
forget
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Loved
me
!
"
<EOS>
answered
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
I
love
you
now
,
Floy
?
<EOS>
What
is

?
<EOS>
---
Died
.
<EOS>
If
you
were
in
India
,
I
should
die
,
Floy
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
hurriedly
put
her

aside
,
and
laid
her

,
caressing

.
<EOS>
And
so
would
she
,
she
said
,
if
he
were

.
<EOS>
He
would

better
soon
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
am
a
great
deal
better
now
!
"
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

that
.
<EOS>
I
mean
that
I
should
die
of
being
so

so

,
Floy
!
"
  
<EOS>
Another
time
,
in
the
same
place
,
he
fell
asleep
,
and
slept
quietly
for
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
Awaking
suddenly
,
he
listened
,
started
up
,
and
sat
listening
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
asked
him
what
he
thought
he
heard
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
what
it
says
,
"
he
answered
,
looking
steadily
in
her
face
.
"
<EOS>
The
sea
,
Floy
<EOS>
,
what
is
it
that
it
keeps
on
saying
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
told
him
that
it
was
only
the
noise
of
the
rolling
waves
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
know
that
they
are
always
saying
something
.
<EOS>
Always
the
same
thing
.
<EOS>
What
place
is
over
there
?
"
<EOS>
He
rose
up
,
looking
eagerly
at
the
horizon
.
  
<EOS>
She
told
him
that
there
was
another
country
opposite
,
but
he
said
he
did
n't
mean
that
:
he
meant
farther
away
---
farther
away
!
  
<EOS>
Very
often
afterwards
,
in
the
midst
of
their
talk
,
he
would
break
off
,
to
try
to
understand
what
it
was
that
the
waves
were
always
saying
;
and
would
rise
up
in
his
couch
to
look
towards
that
invisible
region
,
far
away
.
    
Chapter
9
.
<EOS>
In
which
the
Wooden
Midshipman
gets
into
Trouble
 
THAT
spice
of
romance
and
love
of
the
marvellous
,
of
which
there
was
a
pretty
strong
infusion
in
the
nature
of
young
Walter
Gay
,
and
which
the
guardianship
of
his
uncle
,
old
Solomon
Gills
,
had
not
very
much
weakened
by
the
waters
of
stern
practical
experience
,
was
the
occasion
of
his
attaching
an
uncommon
and
delightful
interest
to
the
adventure
of
Florence
with
good
Mrs
Brown
.
<EOS>
He
pampered
and
cherished
it
in
his
memory
,
especially
that
part
of
it
with
which
he
had
been
associated
:
until
it
became
the
spoiled
child
of
his
fancy
,
and
took
its
own
way
,
and
did
what
it
liked
with
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
recollection
of
those
incidents
,
and
his
own
share
in
them
,
may
have
been
made
the
more
captivating
,
perhaps
,
by
the
weekly
dreamings
of
old
Sol
and
Captain
Cuttle
on
Sundays
.
<EOS>
Hardly
a
Sunday
passed
,
without
mysterious
references
being
made
by
one
or
other
of
those
worthy
chums
to
Richard
Whittington
;
and
the
latter
gentleman
had
even
gone
so
far
as
to
purchase
a
ballad
of
considerable
antiquity
,
that
had
long
fluttered
among
many
others
,
chiefly
expressive
of
maritime
sentiments
,
on
a
dead
wall
in
the
Commercial
Roads
:
which
poetical
performances
set
forth
the
courtship
and
nuptials
of
a
promising
young
coal
-
whipper
with
a
certain
"
lovely
Peg
,
"
the
accomplished
daughter
of
the
master
and
part
-
owner
of
a
Newcastle
collier
.
<EOS>
In
this
stirring
legend
,
Captain
Cuttle
descried
a
profound
metaphysical
bearing
on
the
case
of
Walter
and
Florence
;
and
it
excited
him
so
much
,
that
on
very
festive
occasions
,
as
birthdays
and
few
other
non
-
Dominical
holidays
,
he
would
roar
through
the
whole
song
in
the
little
back
parlour
;
making
an
amazing
shake
on
the
word
Pe
-
e
-
eg
,
with
which
every
verse
concluded
,
in
compliment
to
the
heroine
of
the
piece
.
  
<EOS>
But
a
frank
,
free
-
spirited
,
open
-
hearted
boy
,
is
not
much
given
to
analysing
the
nature
of
his
own
feelings
,
however
strong
their
hold
upon
him
:
and
<EOS>
Walter
would
have
found
it
difficult
to
decide
this
point
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
great
affection
for
the
wharf
where
he
had
encountered
Florence
,
and
for
the
streets
(
albeit
not
enchanting
in
themselves
)
by
which
they
had
come
home
.
<EOS>
The
shoes
that
had
so
often
tumbled
off
by
way
,
he
preserved
in
his
own
room
;
and
,
sitting
in
the
little
back
parlour
of
an
evening
,
he
had
drawn
a
whole
gallery
of
fancy
portraits
of
good
Mrs
Brown
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
he
became
a
little
smarter
in
his
dress
after
that
memorable
occasion
;
and
he
certainly
liked
in
his
leisure
time
to
walk
towards
that
quarter
of
the
town
where
Mr
Dombey
's
house
was
situated
,
on
the
vague
chance
of
passing
little
Florence
in
the
street
.
<EOS>
But
the
sentiment
of
all
this
was
as
boyish
and
innocent
as
could
be
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
very
pretty
,
and
it
is
pleasant
to
admire
a
pretty
face
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
defenceless
and
weak
,
and
it
was
a
proud
thought
that
he
had
been
able
to
render
her
any
protection
and
assistantce
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
the
most
grateful
little
creature
in
the
world
,
and
it
was
delightful
to
see
her
bright
gratitude
beaming
in
her
face
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
neglected
and
coldly
looked
upon
,
and
his
breast
was
full
of
youthful
interest
for
the
slighted
child
in
her
dull
,
stately
home
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
it
came
about
that
,
perhaps
some
half
-
a
-
dozen
times
in
the
course
of
the
year
,
Walter
pulled
off
his
hat
to
Florence
in
the
street
,
and
Florence
would
stop
to
shake
hands
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Wickam
(
who
,
with
a
characteristic
alteration
of
his
name
,
invariably
spoke
of
him
as
"
Young
Graves
'
)
was
so
well
used
to
this
,
knowing
the
story
of
their
acquaintance
,
that
she
took
no
heed
of
it
at
all
.
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper
,
on
the
other
hand
,
rather
looked
out
for
these
occasions
:
<EOS>
her
sensitive
young
heart
being
secretly
propitiated
by
Walter
's
good
looks
,
and
inclining
to
the
belief
that
its
sentiments
were
responded
to
.
  
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
Walter
,
so
far
from
forgetting
or
losing
sight
of
his
acquaintance
with
Florence
,
only
remembered
it
better
and
better
.
<EOS>
As
to
its
adventurous
beginning
,
and
all
those
little
circumstances
which
gave
it
a
distinctive
character
and
relish
,
he
took
them
into
account
,
more
as
a
pleasant
story
very
agreeable
to
his
imagination
,
and
not
to
be
dismissed
from
it
,
than
as
a
part
of
any
matter
of
fact
with
which
he
was
concerned
.
<EOS>
They
set
off
Florence
very
much
,
to
his
fancy
;
but
not
himself
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
thought
(
and
then
he
walked
very
fast
)
<EOS>
what
a
grand
thing
it
would
have
been
for
him
to
have
been
going
to
sea
on
the
day
after
that
first
meeting
,
and
to
have
gone
,
and
to
have
done
wonders
there
,
and
to
have
stopped
away
a
long
time
,
and
to
have
come
back
an
Admiral
of
all
the
colours
of
the
dolphin
,
or
at
least
a
Post
-
Captain
with

of
insupportable

,
and
have
married
Florence
(
then
a
beautiful
young
woman
)
in

of
Mr
Dombey
's
teeth
,

,
and
watch

,
and
borne

away
to
the
blue

of
somewhere
or
other
,
triumphantly
.
<EOS>
But
these
flights
of
fancy
seldom

of

,

;

Richard

and

,
Walter

that
he

true
position
at
Dombey

's
much

.
  
<EOS>
So
it
was
that
he

he

,
in

;

saw
through

were
word

.
<EOS>
Such

,

than
of

,

"
Uncle

'

<EOS>

<EOS>
Solomon

laughingly

to

anything

;
and

,

all

and

in

,

to

of

and
Son
with

than
he
usually
carried

.
  
<EOS>
There
lived
in
those
days
,
round
the
corner
---
in
Bishopsgate
Street
<EOS>
Without
---
one
Brogley
,
sworn
broker
and
appraiser
,
who
kept
a
shop
where
every
description
of
second
-
hand
furniture
was
exhibited
in
the
most
uncomfortable
aspect
,
and
under
circumstances
and
in
combinations
the
most
completely
foreign
to
its
purpose
.
<EOS>
Dozens
of
chairs
hooked
on
to
washing
-
stands
,
which
with
difficulty
poised
themselves
on
the
shoulders
of
sideboards
,
which
in
their
turn
stood
upon
the
wrong
side
of
dining
-
tables
,
gymnastic
with
their
legs
upward
on
the
tops
of
other
dining
-
tables
,
were
among
its
most
reasonable
arrangements
.
<EOS>
A
banquet
array
of
dish
-
covers
,
wine
-

,
and
decanters
was
generally
to
be
seen
,
spread
forth
upon
the
bosom
of
a
four
-
post
bedstead
,
for
the
entertainment
of
such
genial
company
as
half
-
a
-
dozen
pokers
,
and
a
hall
lamp
.
<EOS>
A
set
of
window
curtains
with
no
windows
belonging
to
them
,
would
be
seen
gracefully
draping
a
barricade
of
chests
of
drawers
,
loaded
with
little
jars
from
chemists
'
shops
;
while
a
homeless
hearthrug
severed
from
its
natural
companion
the
fireside
,
braved
the
shrewd
east
wind
in
its
adversity
,
and
trembled
in
melancholy
accord
with
the
shrill
complainings
of
a
cabinet
piano
,
wasting
away
,
a
string
a
day
,
and
faintly
resounding
to
the
noises
of
the
street
in
its
jangling
and
distracted
brain
.
<EOS>
Of
motionless
clocks
that
never
stirred
a
finger
,
and
seemed
as
incapable
of
being
successfully
wound
up
,
as
the
pecuniary
affairs
of
their
former
owners
,
there
was
always
great
choice
in
Mr
Brogley
's
shop
;
and
various
looking
-
glasses
,
accidentally
placed
at
compound
interest
of
reflection
and
refraction
,
presented
to
the
eye
an
eternal
perspective
of
bankruptcy
and
ruin
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Brogley
himself
was
a
moist
-
eyed
,
pink
-
complexioned
,
crisp
-
haired
man
,
of
a
bulky
figure
and
an
easy
temper
---
for
that
class
of
Caius
Marius
who
sits
upon
the
ruins
of
other
people
's
Carthages
,
can
keep
up
his
spirits
well
enough
.
<EOS>
He
had
looked
in
at
Solomon
's
shop
sometimes
to
ask

question
about
articles
in
Solomon
's
way
of
business
;
and
Walter
knew
him
sufficiently
to
give
him
good
day
when
they
met
in
the
street
,
but
as

was

broker
's

with
Solomon

also
,

was
not

,

,

with

,
and
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Uncle
Sol
!
"
said

.
<EOS>
The
old
man
was

,
with

over

,
for

,
instead

.
<EOS>
"
How

?
"
  
<EOS>
Solomon

,
and

towards
the
broker
as
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is

anything
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
the
matter
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

.
"
  
<EOS>
Walter

<EOS>
"
The

,
"
said

,
"

bond

---
three

,

:
<EOS>
and
I
'm

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
possession
!
"
cried

,
looking
round
at

shop
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said

Brogley
,
in

,

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
an
execution
.
<EOS>
That
's
what
it
is
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
it
put
you
out
of
the
way
.
<EOS>
I
come
myself
,
because
of
keeping
it
quiet
and
sociable
.
<EOS>
You
know
me
.
<EOS>
It
's
quite
private
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Uncle
Sol
!
"
faltered
Walter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wally
,
my
boy
,
"
returned
his
uncle
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
first
time
.
<EOS>
Such
a
calamity
never
happened
to
me
before
.
<EOS>
I
'm
an
old
man
to
begin
.
"
<EOS>
Pushing
up
his
spectacles
again
(
for
they
were
useless
any
longer
to
conceal
his
emotion
)
,
he
covered
his
face
with
his
hand
,
and
sobbed
aloud
,
and
his
tears
fell
down
upon
his
coffee
-
coloured
waistcoat
.
  
<EOS>
"
Uncle
Sol
!
<EOS>
Pray
!
<EOS>
oh
do
n't
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Walter
,
who
really
felt
a
thrill
of
terror
in
seeing
the
old
man
weep
.
<EOS>
"
For
God
's
sake
do
n't
do
that
.
<EOS>
Mr
Brogley
,
what
shall
I
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
recommend
you
looking
up
a
friend
or
so
,
"
said
Mr
Brogley
,
"
and
talking
it
over
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Walter
,
catching
at
anything
.
"
<EOS>
Certainly
!
<EOS>
Thankee
.
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
's
the
man
,
Uncle
.
<EOS>
Wait
till
I
run
to
Captain
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
Keep
your
eye
upon
my
Uncle
,
will
you
,
Mr
Brogley
,
and
make
him
as
comfortable
as
you
can
while
I
am
gone
?
<EOS>
Do
n't
despair
,
Uncle
Sol
.
<EOS>
Try
and
keep
a
good
heart
,
there
's
a
dear
fellow
!
"
  
<EOS>
Saying
this
with
great
fervour
,
and
disregarding
the
old
man
's
broken
remonstrances
,
Walter
dashed
out
of
the
shop
again
as
hard
as
he
could
go
;
and
having
hurried
round
to
the
office
to
excuse
himself
on
the
plea
of
his
uncle
's
sudden
illness
,
set
off
,
full
speed
,
for
Captain
Cuttle
's
residence
.
  
<EOS>
Everything
seemed
altered
as
he
ran
along
the
streets
.
<EOS>
There
were
the
usual
entanglement
and
noise
of
carts
,
drays
,
omni
-
buses
,
waggons
,
and
foot
passengers
,
but
the
misfortune
that
had
fallen
on
the
wooden
midshipman
made
it
strange
and
new
.
<EOS>
Houses
and
shopswere
different
from
what
they
used
to
be
,
and
bore
Mr
Brogley
's
warrant
on
their
fronts
in
large
character
.
<EOS>
The
broker
seemed
to
have
got
hold
of
the
very
churches
;
for
their
spires
rose
into
the
sky
with
an
unwonted
air
.
<EOS>
Even
the
sky
itself
was
changed
,
and
had
an
execution
in
it
plainly
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
lived
on
the
brink
of
a
little
canal
near
the
India
Docks
,
where
there
was
a
swivel
bridge
which
opened
now
and
then
to
let
some
wandering
monster
of
a
ship
come
roaming
up
the
street
like
a
stranded
leviathan
.
<EOS>
The
gradual
change
from
land
to
water
,
on
the
approach
to
Captain
Cuttle
's
lodgings
,
was
curious
.
<EOS>
It
began
with
the
erection
of
flag
-
staffs
,
as
appurtenances
to
public
-
houses
;
then
came
slop
-
sellers
'
shops
,
with
Guernsey
shirts
,
sou'wester
hats
,
and
canvas
pantaloons
,
at
once
the
tightest
and
the
loosest
of
their
order
,
hanging
up
outside
.
<EOS>
These
were
succeeded
by
anchor
and
chain
-
cable
forges
,
where
sledge
-
hammers
were
dinging
upon
iron
all
day
long
.
<EOS>
Then
came
rows
of
houses
,
with
little
vanesurmounted
masts
uprearing
themselves
from
among
the
scarlet
beans
.
<EOS>
Then
ditches
.
<EOS>
Then
pollard
willows
.
<EOS>
Then
more
ditches
.
<EOS>
Then
unaccountable
patches
of
dirty
water
,
hardly
to
be
descried
,
for
the
ships
that
covered
them
.
<EOS>
Then
,
the
air
was
perfumed
with
chips
;
and
all
other
trades
were
swallowed
up
in
mast
,
oar
,
and
block
-
making
,
and
boat
-
building
.
<EOS>
Then
,
the
ground
grew
marshy
and
unsettled
.
<EOS>
Then
,
there
was
nothing
to
be
smelt
but
rum
and
sugar
.
<EOS>
Then
,
Captain
Cuttle
's
lodgings
---
at
once
a
first
floor
and
a
top
story
,
in
Brig
Place
---
were
close
before
you
.
  
<EOS>
The
captain
was
one
of
those
timber
-
looking
men
,
suits
of
oak
as
well
as
hearts
,
whom
it
is
almost
impossible
for
the
liveliest
imagination
to
separate
from
any
part
of
their
dress
,
however
insignificant
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
when
Walter
knocked
at
the
door
,
and
the
Captain
instantly
poked
his
head
out
of
one
of
his
little
front
windows
,
and
hailed
him
,
with
the
hard
glazed
hat
already
on
it
,
and
the
shirt
-
collar
like
a
sail
,
and
the
wide
suite
of
blue
,
all
standing
as
usual
,
Walter
was
as
fully
persuaded
that
he
was
always
in
that
state
,
as
if
the
Captain
had
been
a
bird
and
those
had
been
his
feathers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
,
my
lad
!
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Stand
by
and
knock
again
.
<EOS>
Hard
!
<EOS>
It
's
washing
day
.
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
,
in
his
impatience
,
gave
a
prodigious
thump
with
the
knocker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hard
it
is
!
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
and
immediately
drew
in
his
head
,
as
if
he
expected
a
squall
.
  
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
mistaken
:
for
a
widow
lady
,
with
her
sleeves
rolled
up
to
her
shoulders
,
and
her
arms
frothy
with
soap
-
suds
and
smoking
with
hot
water
,
replied
to
the
summons
with
startling
rapidity
.
<EOS>
Before
she
looked
at
Walter
she
looked
at
the
knocker
,
and
then
,
measuring
him
with
her
eyes
from
head
to
foot
,
said
she
wondered
he
had
left
any
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
's
at
home
,
I
know
,
"
said
Walter
with
a
conciliatory
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
?
<EOS>
"
replied
the
widow
lady
.
"
<EOS>
In
-
deed
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
just
been
speaking
to
me
,
"
said
Walter
,
in
breathless
explanation
.
  
<EOS>
"
Has
he
?
<EOS>
"
replied
the
widow
lady
.
"
<EOS>
Then
p'raps
you
'll
give
him
Mrs
MacStinger
's
respects
,
and
say
that
the
next
time
he
lowers
himself
and
his
lodgings
by
talking
out
of
winder
she
'll
thank
him
to
come
down
and
open
the
door
too
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
MacStinger
spoke
loud
,
and
listened
for
any
observations
that
might
be
offered
from
the
first
floor
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
mention
it
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
if
you
'll
have
the
goodness
to
let
me
in
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
For
he
was
repelled
by
a
wooden
fortification
extending
across
the
doorway
,
and
put
there
to
prevent
the
little
Mac
Stingers
in
their
moments
of
recreation
from
tumbling
down
the
steps
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
boy
that
can
knock
my
door
down
,
"
said
Mrs
MacStinger
,
contemptuously
,
"
can
get
over
that
,
I
should
hope
!
"
<EOS>
But
Walter
,
taking
this
as
a
permission
to
enter
,
and
getting
over
it
,
Mrs
MacStinger
immediately
demanded
whether
an
Englishwoman
's
house
was
her
castle
or
not
;
and
whether
she
was
to
be
broke
in
upon
by
"
raff
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
these
subjects
her
thirst
for
information
was
still
very
importunate
,
when
Walter
,
having
made
his
way
up
the
little
staircase
through
an
artificial
fog
occasioned
by
the
washing
,
which
covered
the
banisters
with
a
clammy
perspiration
,
entered
Captain
Cuttle
's
room
,
and
found
that
gentleman
in
ambush
behind
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
owed
her
a
penny
,
Wal'r
,
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
in
a
low
voice
,
and
with
visible
marks
of
trepidation
on
his
countenance
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Done
her
a
world
of
good
turns
,
and
the
children
too
.
<EOS>
Vixen
at
times
,
though
.
<EOS>
Whew
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
go
away
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
said
Walter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dursn't
do
it
,
Wal'r
,
"
returned
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
She
'd
find
me
out
,
wherever
I
went
.
<EOS>
Sit
down
.
<EOS>
How
's
Gills
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
dining
(
in
his
hat
)
off
cold
loin
of
mutton
,
porter
,
and
some
smoking
hot
potatoes
,
which
he
had
cooked
himself
,
and
took
out
of
a
little
saucepan
before
the
fire
as
he
wanted
them
.
<EOS>
He
unscrewed
his
hook
at
dinnertime
,
and
screwed
a
knife
into
its
wooden
socket
instead
,
with
which
he
had
already
begun
to
peel
one
of
these
potatoes
for
Walter
.
<EOS>
His
rooms
were
very
small
,
and
strongly
impregnated
with
tobacco
-
smoke
,
but
snug
enough
:
everything
being
stowed
away
,
as
if
there
were
an
earthquake
regularly
every
half
-
hour
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
's
Gills
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
Walter
,
who
had
by
this
time
recovered
his
breath
,
and
lost
his
spirits
---
or
such
temporary
spirits
as
his
rapid
journey
had
given
him
---
looked
at
his
questioner
for
a
moment
,
said
"
Oh
,
Captain
Cuttle
!
"
and
burst
into
tears
.
  
<EOS>
No
words
can
describe
the
Captain
's
consternation
at
this
sight
.
<EOS>
Mrs
MacStinger
faded
into
nothing
before
it
.
<EOS>
He
dropped
the
potato
and
the
fork
---
and
would
have
dropped
the
knife
too
if
he
could
---
and
sat
gazing
at
the
boy
,
as
if
he
expected
to
hear
next
moment
that
a
gulf
had
opened
in
the
City
,
which
had
swallowed
up
his
old
friend
,
coffee
-
coloured
suit
,
buttons
,
chronometer
,
spectacles
and
all
.
  
<EOS>
But
when
Walter
told
him
what
was
really
the
matter
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
after
a
moment
's
reflection
,
started
up
into
full
activity
.
<EOS>
He
emptied
out
of
a
little
tin
canister
on
the
top
shelf
of
the
cupboard
,
his
whole
stock
of
ready
money
(
amounting
to
thirteen
pounds
and
half
-
a
-
crown
)
,
which
he
transferred
to
one
of
the
pockets
of
his
square
blue
coat
;
further
enriched
that
repository
with
the
contents
of
his
plate
chest
,
consisting
of
two
withered
atomies
of
tea
-
spoons
,
and
an
obsolete
pair
of
knock
-
knee'd
sugar
-
tongs
;
pulled
up
his
immense
doublecased
silver
watch
from
the
depths
in
which
it
reposed
,
to
assure
himself
that
that
valuable
was
sound
and
whole
;
re
-
attached
the
hook
to
his
right
wrist
;
and
seizing
the
stick
covered
over
with
knobs
,
bade
Walter
come
along
.
  
<EOS>
Remembering
,
however
,
in
the
midst
of
his
virtuous
excitement
,
that
Mrs
MacStinger
might
be
lying
in
wait
below
,
Captain
Cuttle
hesitated
at
last
,
not
without
glancing
at
the
window
,
as
if
he
had
some
thoughts
of
escaping
by
that
unusual
means
of
egress
,
rather
than
encounter
his
terrible
enemy
.
<EOS>
He
decided
,
however
,
in
favour
of
stratagem
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
with
a
timid
wink
,
"
go
afore
,
my
lad
.
<EOS>
Sing
out
,
"
good
-
bye
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
when
you
're
in
the
passage
,
and
shut
the
door
.
<EOS>
Then
wait
at
the
corner
of
the
street
'
till
you
see
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
These
directions
were
not
issued
without
a
previous
knowledge
of
the
enemy
's
tactics
,
for
when
Walter
got
down
stairs
,
Mrs
MacStinger
glided
out
of
the
little
back
kitchen
,
like
an
avenging
spirit
.
<EOS>
But
not
gliding
out
upon
the
Captain
,
as
she
had
expected
,
she
merely
made
a
further
allusion
to
the
knocker
,
and
glided
in
again
.
  
<EOS>
Some
five
minutes
elapsed
before
Captain
Cuttle
could
summon
courage
to
attempt
his
escape
;
for
Walter
waited
so
long
at
the
street
corner
,
looking
back
at
the
house
,
before
there
were
any
symptoms
of
the
hard
glazed
hat
.
<EOS>
At
length
the
Captain
burst
out
of
the
door
with
the
suddenness
of
an
explosion
,
and
coming
towards
him
at
a
great
pace
,
and
never
once
looking
over
his
shoulder
,
pretended
,
as
soon
as
they
were
well
out
of
the
street
,
to
whistle
a
tune
.
  
<EOS>
"
Uncle
much
hove
down
,
Wal'r
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
Captain
,
as
they
were
walking
along
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
so
.
<EOS>
If
you
had
seen
him
this
morning
,
you
would
never
have
forgotten
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Walk
fast
,
Wal'r
,
my
lad
,
"
returned
the
Captain
,
mending
his
pace
;
"
and
walk
the
same
all
the
days
of
your
life
.
<EOS>
Over
-
haul
the
catechism
for
that
advice
,
and
keep
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
too
busy
with
his
own
thoughts
of
Solomon
Gills
,
mingled
perhaps
with
some
reflections
on
his
late
escape
from
Mrs
MacStinger
,
to
offer
any
further
quotations
on
the
way
for
Walter
's
moral
improvement
.
<EOS>
They
interchanged
no
other
word
until
they
arrived
at
old
Sol
's
door
,
where
the
unfortunate
wooden
midshipman
,
with
his
instrument
at
his
eye
,
seemed
to
be
surveying
the
whole
horizon
in
search
of
some
friend
to
help
him
out
of
his
difficulty
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gills
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Captain
,
hurrying
into
the
back
parlour
,
and
taking
him
by
the
hand
quite
tenderly
.
<EOS>
"
Lay
your
head
well
to
the
wind
,
and
we
'll
fight
through
it
.
<EOS>
All
you
've
got
to
do
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
with
the
solemnity
of
a
man
who
was
delivering
himself
of
one
of
the
most
precious
practical
tenets
ever
discovered
by
human
wisdom
,
"
is
to
lay
your
head
well
to
the
wind
,
and
we
'll
fight
through
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Old
Sol
returned
the
pressure
of
his
hand
,
and
thanked
him
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
then
,
with
a
gravity
suitable
to
the
nature
of
the
occasion
,
put
down
upon
the
table
the
two
tea
-
spoons
and
the
sugar
-
tongs
,
the
silver
watch
,
and
the
ready
money
;
and
asked
Mr
Brogley
,
the
broker
,
what
the
damage
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
<EOS>
What
do
you
make
of
it
?
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Lord
help
you
!
"
<EOS>
returned
the
broker
;
"
you
do
n't
suppose
that
property
's
of
any
use
,
do
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
inquired
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
<EOS>
The
amount
's
three
hundred
and
seventy
,
odd
,
"
replied
the
broker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
returned
the
Captain
,
though
he
was
evidently
dismayed
by
the
figures
:
"
all
's
fish
that
comes
to
your
net
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Mr
Brogley
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
sprats
an't
whales
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
philosophy
of
this
observation
seemed
to
strike
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
He
ruminated
for
a
minute
;
eyeing
the
broker
,
meanwhile
,
as
a
deep
genius
;
and
then
called
the
instrument
-
maker
aside
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gills
,
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
what
's
the
bearings
of
this
business
?
<EOS>
Who
's
the
creditor
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Hush
!
"
returned
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
Come
away
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
speak
before
Wally
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
matter
of
security
for
Wally
's
father
---
an
old
bond
.
<EOS>
I
've
paid
a
good
deal
of
it
,
Ned
,
but
the
times
are
so
bad
with
me
that
I
ca
n't
do
more
just
now
.
<EOS>
I
've
foreseen
it
,
but
I
could
n't
help
it
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
before
Wally
,
for
all
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
've
got
some
money
,
have
n't
you
?
"
whispered
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
---
oh
yes
---
I
've
got
some
,
"
returned
old
Sol
,
first
putting
his
hands
into
his
empty
pockets
,
and
then
squeezing
his
Welsh
wig
between
them
,
as
if
he
thought
he
might
wring
some
gold
out
of
it
;
"
but
I
---
the
little
I
have
got
,
is
n't
convertible
,
Ned
;
it
ca
n't
be
got
at
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
trying
to
do
something
with
it
for
Wally
,
and
I
'm
old
fashioned
,
and
behind
the
time
.
<EOS>
It
's
here
and
there
,
and
---
and
,
in
short
,
it
's
as
good
as
nowhere
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
looking
in
bewilderment
about
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
so
much
the
air
of
a
half
-
witted
person
who
had
been
hiding
his
money
in
a
variety
of
places
,
and
had
forgotten
where
,
that
the
Captain
followed
his
eyes
,
not
without
a
faint
hope
that
he
might
remember
some
few
hundred
pounds
concealed
up
the
chimney
,
or
down
in
the
cellar
.
<EOS>
But
Solomon
Gills
knew
better
than
that
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
behind
the
time
altogether
,
my
dear
Ned
,
"
said
Sol
,
in
resigned
despair
,
"
a
long
way
.
<EOS>
It
's
no
use
my
lagging
on
so
far
behind
it
.
<EOS>
The
stock
had
better
be
sold
---
it
's
worth
more
than
this
debt
---
and
I
had
better
go
and
die
somewhere
,
on
the
balance
.
<EOS>
I
have
n't
any
energy
left
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
understand
things
.
<EOS>
This
had
better
be
the
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
Let'em
sell
the
stock
and
take
him
down
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
pointing
feebly
to
the
wooden
midshipman
,
"
and
let
us
both
be
broken
up
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
d'ye
mean
to
do
with
Wal'r
?
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
There
,
there
!
<EOS>
Sit
ye
down
,
Gills
,
sit
ye
down
,
and
let
me
think
o
'
this
.
<EOS>
If
I
warn't
a
man
on
a
small
annuity
,
that
was
large
enough
till
to
-
day
,
I
had
n't
need
to
think
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
you
only
lay
your
head
well
to
the
wind
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
again
administering
that
unanswerable
piece
of
consolation
,
"
and
you
're
all
right
!
"
  
<EOS>
Old
Sol
thanked
him
from
his
heart
,
and
went
and
laid
it
against
the
back
parlour
fire
-
place
instead
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
walked
up
and
down
the
shop
for
some
time
,
cogitating
profoundly
,
and
bringing
his
bushy
black
eyebrows
to
bear
so
heavily
on
his
nose
,
like
clouds
setting
on
a
mountain
,
that
Walter
was
afraid
to
offer
any
interruption
to
the
current
of
his
reflections
.
<EOS>
Mr
Brogley
,
who
was
averse
to
being
any
constraint
upon
the
party
,
and
who
had
an
ingenious
cast
of
mind
,
went
,
softly
whistling
,
among
,
the
stock
;
rattling
weather
-
glasses
,
shaking
compasses
as
if
they
were
physic
,
catching
up
keys
with
loadstones
,
looking
through
telescopes
,
endeavouring
to
make
himself
acquainted
with
the
use
of
the
globes
setting
parallel
rulers
astride
on
to
his
nose
,
and
amusing
himself
with
other
philosophical
transactions
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
?
"
said
the
Captain
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
got
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have
you
,
Captain
Cuttle
?
"
cried
Walter
,
with
great
animation
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
this
way
,
my
lad
,
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Stock
's
one
security
.
<EOS>
I
'm
another
.
<EOS>
Your
governor
's
the
man
to
advance
the
money
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dombey
!
"
<EOS>
faltered
Walter
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
nodded
gravely
.
"
<EOS>
Look
at
him
,
"
he
said
,
"
Look
at
Gills
.
<EOS>
If
they
was
to
sell
of
these
things
now
,
he
'd
die
of
it
.
<EOS>
You
know
,
he
would
.
<EOS>
We
must
n't
leave
a
stone
unturned
---
and
there
's
a
stone
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
stone
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
!
<EOS>
faltered
Walter
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
run
round
to
the
office
,
first
of
all
,
and
see
if
he
's
there
,
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
clapping
him
on
the
back
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quick
!
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
felt
he
must
not
dispute
the
command
---
a
glance
at
his
uncle
would
have
determined
him
if
he
had
felt
otherwise
---
and
disappeared
to
execute
it
.
<EOS>
He
soon
returned
,
out
of
breath
,
to
say
that
Mr
Dombey
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
It
was
Saturday
,
and
he
had
gone
to
Brighton
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
what
,
Wal'r
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
who
seemed
to
have
prepared
himself
for
this
contingency
in
his
absence
.
<EOS>
"
We
'll
go
to
Brighton
.
<EOS>
I
'll
back
you
,
my
boy
.
<EOS>
I
'll
back
you
,
Wal'r
.
<EOS>
We
'll
go
to
Brighton
by
the
afternoon
's
coach
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
If
the
application
must
be
made
to
Mr
Dombey
at
all
,
which
was
awful
to
think
of
,
Walter
felt
that
he
would
rather
prefer
it
alone
and
unassisted
,
than
backed
by
the
personal
influence
of
Captain
Cuttle
,
to
which
he
hardly
thought
Mr
Dombey
would
attach
much
weight
.
<EOS>
But
as
the
Captain
appeared
to
be
of
quite
another
opinion
,
and
was
bent
upon
it
,
and
as
his
friendship
was
too
zealous
and
serious
to
be
trifled
with
by
one
so
much
younger
than
himself
,
he
forbore
to
hint
the
least
objection
.
<EOS>
Cuttle
,
therefore
,
taking
a
hurried
leave
of
Solomon
Gills
,
and
returning
the
ready
money
,
the
tea
-
spoons
,
the
sugar
-
tongs
,
and
the
silver
watch
,
to
his
pocket
---
with
a
view
,
as
Walter
thought
,
with
horror
,
to
making
a
gorgeous
impression
on
Mr
Dombey
---
bore
him
off
to
the
coach
-
office
,
without
a
minute
's
delay
,
and
repeatedly
assured
him
,
on
the
road
,
that
he
would
stick
by
him
to
the
last
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
10
.
<EOS>
Containing
the
Sequel
of
the
Midshipman
's
Disaster
 
<EOS>
MAJOR
BAGSTOCK
,
after
long
and
frequent
observation
of
Paul
,
across
Princess
's
Place
,
through
his
double
-
barrelled
opera
-
glass
;
and
after
receiving
many
minute
reports
,
daily
,
weekly
,
and
monthly
,
on
that
subject
,
from
the
native
who
kept
himself
in
constant
communication
with
Miss
Tox
's
maid
for
that
purpose
;
came
to
the
conclusion
that
Dombey
,
Sir
,
was
a
man
to
be
known
,
and
that
JB
was
the
boy
to
make
his
acquaintance
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
,
however
,
maintaining
her
reserved
behaviour
,
and
frigidly
declining
to
understand
the
Major
whenever
he
called
(
which
he
often
did
)
on
any
little
fishing
excursion
connected
with
this
project
,
the
Major
,
in
spite
of
his
constitutional
toughness
and
slyness
,
was
fain
to
leave
the
accomplishment
of
his
desire
in
some
measure
to
chance
,
"
which
,
"
as
he
was
used
to
observe
with
chuckles
at
his
club
,
"
has
been
fifty
to
one
in
favour
of
Joey
B
,
Sir
,
ever
since
his
elder
brother
died
of
Yellow
Jack
in
the
West
Indies
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
some
time
coming
to
his
aid
in
the
present
instance
,
but
it
befriended
him
at
last
.
<EOS>
When
the
dark
servant
,
with
full
particulars
,
reported
Miss
Tox
absent
on
Brighton
service
,
the
Major
was
suddenly
touched
with
affectionate
reminiscences
of
his
friend
Bill
Bitherstone
of
Bengal
,
who
had
written
to
ask
him
,
if
he
ever
went
that
way
,
to
bestow
a
call
upon
his
only
son
.
<EOS>
But
when
the
same
dark
servant
reported
Paul
at
Mrs
Pipchin
's
,
and
the
Major
,
referring
to
the
letter
favoured
by
Master
Bitherstone
on
his
arrival
in
England
---
to
which
he
had
never
had
the
least
idea
of
paying
any
attention
---
saw
the
opening
that
presented
itself
,
he
was
made
so
rabid
by
the
gout
,
with
which
he
happened
to
be
then
laid
up
,
that
he
threw
a
footstool
at
the
dark
servant
in
return
for
his
intelligence
,
and
swore
he
would
be
the
death
of
the
rascal
before
he
had
done
with
him
:
which
the
dark
servant
was
more
than
half
disposed
to
believe
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
the
Major
being
released
from
his
fit
,
went
one
Saturday
growling
down
to
Brighton
,
with
the
native
behind
him
;
apostrophizing
Miss
Tox
all
the
way
,
and
gloating
over
the
prospect
of
carrying
by
storm
the
distinguished
friend
to
whom
she
attached
so
much
mystery
,
and
for
whom
she
had
deserted
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
,
Ma'am
,
would
you
!
"
said
the
Major
,
straining
with
vindictiveness
,
and
swelling
every
already
swollen
vein
in
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
Would
you
give
Joey
B
the
go
-
by
,
Ma'am
?
<EOS>
Not
yet
,
ma'am
,
not
yet
!
<EOS>
Damme
,
not
yet
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Joe
is
awake
,
Ma'am
.
<EOS>
Bagstock
is
alive
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
JB
knows
a
move
or
two
,
Ma'am
.
<EOS>
Josh
has
his
weather
-
eye
open
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
You
'll
find
him
tough
,
Ma'am
.
<EOS>
Tough
,
Sir
,
tough
is
Joseph
.
<EOS>
Tough
,
and
de
-
vilish
sly
!
"
  
<EOS>
And
very
tough
indeed
Master
Bitherstone
found
him
,
when
he
took
that
young
gentleman
out
for
a
walk
.
<EOS>
But
the
Major
,
with
his
complexion
like
a
Stilton
cheese
,
and
his
eyes
like
a
prawn
's
,
went
roving
about
,
perfectly
indifferent
to
Master
Bitherstone
's
amusement
,
and
dragging
Master
Bitherstone
along
,
while
he
looked
about
him
high
and
low
,
for
Mr
Dombey
and
his
children
.
  
<EOS>
In
good
time
the
Major
,
previously
instructed
by
Mrs
Pipchin
,
spied
out
Paul
and
Florence
,
and
bore
down
upon
them
;
there
being
a
stately
gentleman
(
Mr
Dombey
,
doubtless
)
in
their
company
.
<EOS>
Charging
with
Master
Bitherstone
into
the
very
heart
of
the
little
squadron
,
it
fell
out
,
of
course
,
that
Master
Bitherstone
spoke
to
his
fellow
-
sufferers
.
<EOS>
Upon
that
the
Major
stopped
to
notice
and
admire
them
;
remembered
with
amazement
that
he
had
seen
and
spoken
to
them
at
his
friend
Miss
Tox
's
in
Princess
's
Place
;
opined
that
Paul
was
a
devilish
fine
fellow
,
and
his
own
little
friend
;
inquired
if
he
remembered
Joey
B
the
Major
;
and
finally
,
with
a
sudden
recollection
of
the
conventionalities
of
life
,
turned
and
apologised
to
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
my
little
friend
here
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
makes
a
boy
of
me
again
.
<EOS>
An
old
soldier
,
Sir
---
Major
Bagstock
,
at
your
service
---
is
not
ashamed
to
confess
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
the
Major
lifted
his
hat
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Damme
,
Sir
,
"
cried
the
Major
with
sudden
warmth
,
"
I
envy
you
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
recollected
himself
,
and
added
,
"
Excuse
my
freedom
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
begged
he
would
n't
mention
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
An
old
campaigner
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
a
smoke
-
dried
,
sun
-
burnt
,
usedup
,
invalided
old
dog
of
a
Major
,
Sir
,
was
not
afraid
of
being

for
his
whim
by
a
man
like
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
I
have
the
honour
of

Mr
Dombey
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
the
present
unworthy

of
that
name
,
Major
,
"
returned
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
By
G
---
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
it
's
great
name
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
name
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
firmly
,
as

to

,

to

,
"
that
is

.
<EOS>
It
is
a
name
,
Sir
,
that
a
man
is

.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
adulatory
in
Joseph
Bagstock
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
His
Royal
Highness
the
Duke
of
York
observed
on
more
than

,
"
there
is
no
adulation

Joey
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
plain
old
soldier
is
Joe
.
<EOS>
He
is
tough
to
a
fault
<EOS>
is
Joseph
:
<EOS>
"
but
it
's
a

name
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
By

Lord
,
it
's
a

!
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

good

to
rate

higher
than
it
deserves
,
perhaps
,
Major
,
"
returned

Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
"
said

Major
.
<EOS>
"
My
little
friend
here
,
Sir
,
will
certify

Joseph
Bagstock
that

is
a
thorough

going
,
down

,
plain

,
old

,

,

.
<EOS>
That
boy
,

,
"
said

in

,
"
will
live
in

.
<EOS>
That
boy
,
Sir
,
is
not

common

.
<EOS>
Take

,
Mr
Dombey
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

seemed

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here

a
boy
here
,
Sir
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Son
of
Bitherstone
of

.
<EOS>
Bill

formerly

.
<EOS>
That

,

,

.
<EOS>
Wherever

,

,

nothing
<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
Am

's

?
<EOS>
By

.
<EOS>
He
's

,

.
"
  
<EOS>

,

"
Really
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
fool
.
<EOS>
Joe
Bagstock
never
minces

.
<EOS>
The
son
of
my
old
friend
Bill
Bitherstone
,
of

,
is
a

,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
Here

Major
laughed
till

.
<EOS>
"
My
little

is

,

,

?
"
said

when

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
think

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

's

,
Sir
,
"
said

Major
,
"
you
are
right
.
<EOS>
None

tough
fellows
could
live
through
it
,
Sir
,
at

.
<EOS>
We
put

,

.
<EOS>
We
roasted

new

at

,
and
hung'em

a
three

,

.
<EOS>
Joseph
Bagstock
,

,
was

of

by

,
for
thirteen

by

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
might

,
in

this

.
<EOS>
It

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

made

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
We

iron
,
Sir
,
and
it
forged

.
<EOS>
Are

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Major
,
"
returned

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
Joey
B
,

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
made
a
very
gracious
reply
;
and
Major
Bagstock
,
having
patted
Paul
on
the
head
,
and
said
of
Florence
that
her
eyes
would
play
the
Devil
with
the
youngsters
before
long
---
"
and
the
oldsters
too
,

,
if
you
come
to

,
"
added
the
Major
,
chuckling
very
