---
stirred
up
Master
Bitherstone
with
his
walking
-
stick
,
and
departed
with
that
young
gentleman
,
at
a
kind
of
half
-
trot
;
rolling
his
head
and
coughing
with
great
dignity
,
as
he
staggered
away
,
with
his
legs
very
wide
asunder
.
  
<EOS>
In
fulfilment
of
his
promise
,
the
Major
afterwards
called
on
Mr
Dombey
;
and
Mr
Dombey
,
having
referred
to
the
army
list
,
afterwards
called
on
the
Major
.
<EOS>
Then
the
Major
called
at
Mr
Dombey
's
house
in
town
;
and
came
down
again
,
in
the
same
coach
as
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
Mr
Dombey
and
the
Major
got
on
uncommonly
well
together
,
and
uncommonly
fast
:
and
Mr
Dombey
observed
of
the
Major
,
to
his
sister
,
that
besides
being
quite
a
military
man
he
was
really
something
more
,
as
he
had
a
very
admirable
idea
of
the
importance
of
things
unconnected
with
his
own
profession
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
Mr
Dombey
,
bringing
down
Miss
Tox
and
Mrs
Chick
to
see
the
children
,
and
finding
the
Major
again
at
Brighton
,
invited
him
to
dinner
at
the
Bedford
,
and
complimented
Miss
Tox
highly
,
beforehand
,
on
her
neighbour
and
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
palpitation
of
the
heart
which
these
allusions
occasioned
her
,
they
were
anything
but
disagreeable
to
Miss
Tox
,
as
they
enabled
her
to
be
extremely
interesting
,
and
to
manifest
an
occasional
incoherence
and
distraction
which
she
was
not
at
all
unwilling
to
display
.
<EOS>
The
Major
gave
her
abundant
opportunities
of
exhibiting
this
emotion
:
being
profuse
in
his
complaints
,
at
dinner
,
of
her
desertion
of
him
and
Princess
's
Place
:
and
as
he
appeared
to
derive
great
enjoyment
from
making
them
,
they
all
got
on
very
well
.
  
<EOS>
None
the
worse
on
account
of
the
Major
taking
charge
of
the
whole
conversation
,
and
showing
as
great
an
appetite
in
that
respect
as
in
regard
of
the
various
dainties
on
the
table
,
among
which
he
may
be
almost
said
to
have
wallowed
:
greatly
to
the
aggravation
of
his
inflammatory
tendencies
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
habitual
silence
and
reserve
yielding
readily
to
this
usurpation
<EOS>
,
the
Major
felt
that
he
was
coming
out
and
shining
:
<EOS>
and
in
the
flow
of
spirits
thus
engendered
,
rang
such
an
infinite
number
of
new
changes
on
his
own
name
that
he
quite
astonished
himself
.
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
they
were
all
very
well
pleased
.
<EOS>
The
Major
was
considered
to
possess
an
inexhaustible
fund
of
conversation
;
and
when
he
took
a
late

,
after
a
long

,
Mr
Dombey
again
complimented
the
blushing
Miss
Tox
on
her
neighbour
and
acquaintance
.
  
<EOS>
But
all
the
way
home
to
his
own

,
the
Major
incessantly
said
to
himself
,
and
of

,
"
<EOS>
Sly
,
Sir
---
sly
,
Sir
---
de
-
vil
-
ish
sly
!
"
<EOS>
And
when
he
got
there
,
sat
down
in
a
chair
,
and
fell
into
a
silent
fit
of
laughter
,
with
which
he
was
sometimes
seized
,
and
which
was
always
particularly
awful
.
<EOS>
It
held
him
so
long
on
this
occasion
that
the
dark
servant
,
who
stood
watching
him
at
a
distance
,
but
dared
not
for
his
life
approach
,
twice
or

gave
him
over
for
lost
.
<EOS>
His
whole
form
,
but
especially
his
face
and
head
,
dilated
beyond
all
former
experience
;
and
presented
to
the
dark
man
's
view
,
nothing
but
a
heavy
mass
of
indigo
.
<EOS>
At
length
he
burst
into
a
violent
paroxysm
of
coughing
,
and
when
that
was
a
little
better
burst
into
such
ejaculations
as
the
following
:
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
,
Ma'am
,
would
you
?
<EOS>
Mrs
Dombey
,
eh
,
Ma'am
?
<EOS>
I
think
not
,
Ma'am
.
<EOS>
Not
while
Joe
B
can
put
a
spoke
in
your

,
Ma'am
.
<EOS>
JB
's
even
with
you
now
,
Ma'am
.
<EOS>
He
is
n't
altogether

out
,
yet
,
Sir
,
is
n't
Bagstock
.
<EOS>
She
's
deep
,
Sir
,
deep
,
but
Josh
is
deeper
.
<EOS>
Wide
awake
is
old
Joe
---
broad

,
and
staring
,
Sir
!
<EOS>
"
There
was
no
doubt
of
this
last

being
true
,
and
to
a
very
fearful

;
as
it
continued
to
be
during
the
greater

of
that
night
,
which
the
Major
chiefly
passed
in
similar
exclamations
,
diversified
with
fits
of

and
choking
that
startled

whole
house
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
on
the
day
after
this
occasion
(
being
Sunday
)
<EOS>
when
,
as
Mr
Dombey
,
Mrs
Chick
,
and
Miss
Tox
were
sitting
at

,
still
eulogising
the
Major
,
Florence
came
running
in
:
her
face
suffused
with
a
bright

,
and
her

sparkling

:
and
cried
,
  
"
Papa
!
<EOS>
papa
!
<EOS>
Here
's
Walter
!
<EOS>
and
he
wo
n't
come
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
cried
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
What
does
she
mean
?
<EOS>
What
is
this
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Walter
,
Papa
!
"
said
Florence
timidly
;
sensible
of
having
approached
the
presence
with
too
much

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
found
me
when
I
was
lost
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Does
she
mean
young
Gay
,
Louisa
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Dombey
,
knitting
his
brows
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Really
,
this
child
's
manners
have
become
very
boisterous
.
<EOS>
She
can
not
mean
young
Gay
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
See
what
it
is
,
will
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
hurried
into
the
passage
,
and
returned
with
the
information
that
it
was
young
Gay
,
accompanied
by
a
very
strange
-
looking
person
;
and
that
young
Gay
said
he
would
not
take
the
liberty
of
coming
in
,
hearing
Mr
Dombey
was
at
breakfast
,
but
would
wait
until
Mr
Dombey
should
signify
that
he
might
approach
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
the
boy
to
come
in
now
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
Gay
,
what
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
Who
sent
you
down
here
?
<EOS>
Was
there
nobody
else
to
come
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Sir
,
"
returned
Walter
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
been
sent
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
so
bold
as
to
come
on
my
own
account
,
which
I
hope
you
'll
pardon
when
I
mention
the
cause
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
Mr
Dombey
without
attending
to
what
he
said
,
was
looking
impatiently
on
either
side
of
him
(
as
if
he
were
a
pillar
in
his
way
)
at
some
object
behind
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
Who
is
that
?
<EOS>
I
think
you
have
made
some
mistake
in
the
door
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
'm
very
sorry
to
intrude
with
any
one
,
Sir
,
"
cried
Walter
,
hastily
:
"
but
this
is
---
this
is
Captain
Cuttle
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Wal'r
,
my
lad
,
"
observed
the
Captain
in
a
deep
voice
:
"
stand
by
!
"
  
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
the
Captain
,
coming
a
little
further
in
,
brought
out
his
wide
suit
of
blue
,
his
conspicuous
shirt
-
collar
,
and
his
knobby
nose
in
full
relief
,
and
stood
bowing
to
Mr
Dombey
,
and
waving
his
hook
politely
to
the
ladies
,
with
the
hard
glazed
hat
in
his
one
hand
,
and
a
red
equator
round
his
head
which
it
had
newly
imprinted
there
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
regarded
this
phenomenon
with
amazement
and
indignation
,
and
seemed
by
his
looks
to
appeal
to
Mrs
Chick
and
Miss
Tox
against
it
.
<EOS>
Little
Paul
,
who
had
come
in
after
Florence
,
backed
towards
Miss
Tox
as
the
Captain
waved
his
hook
,
and
stood
on
the
defensive
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Gay
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
got
to
say
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
Again
the
Captain
observed
,
as
a
general
opening
of
the
conversation
that
could
not
fail
to
propitiate
all
parties
,
"
Wal'r
,
stand
by
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
,
Sir
,
"
began
Walter
,
trembling
,
and
looking
down
at
the
ground
,
"
that
I
take
a
very
great
liberty
in
coming
---
indeed
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
I
do
.
<EOS>
I
should
hardly
have
had
the
courage
to
ask
to
see
you
,
Sir
,
even
after
coming
down
,
I
am
afraid
,
if
I
had
not
overtaken
Miss
Dombey
,
and
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
following
his
eyes
as
he
glanced
at
the
attentive
Florence
,
and
frowning
unconsciously
as
she
encouraged
him
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
if
you
please
.
"
  
"
Aye
,
aye
,
"
observed
the
Captain
,
considering
it
incumbent
on
him
,
as
a
point
of
good
breeding
,
to
support
Mr
Dombey
.
"
<EOS>
Well
said
!
<EOS>
Go
on
,
Wal'r
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
ought
to
have
been
withered
by
the
look
which
Mr
Dombey
bestowed
upon
him
in
acknowledgment
of
his
patronage
.
<EOS>
But
quite
innocent
of
this
,
he
closed
one
eye
in
reply
,
and
gave
Mr
Dombey
to
understand
by
certain
significant
motions
of
his
hook
,
that
Walter
was
a
little
bashful
at
first
,
and
might
be
expected
to
come
out
shortly
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
entirely
a
private
and
personal
matter
,
that
has
brought
me
here
,
Sir
,
"
continued
Walter
,
faltering
,
"
and
Captain
Cuttle
---
"
  
"
Here
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
the
Captain
,
as
an
assurance
that
he
was
at
hand
,
and
might
be
relied
upon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
a
very
old
friend
of
my
poor
uncle
's
,
and
a
most
excellent
man
,
Sir
,
"
pursued
Walter
,
raising
his
eyes
with
a
look
of
entreaty
in
the
Captain
's
behalf
,
"
<EOS>
was
so
good
as
to
offer
to
come
with
me
,
which
I
could
hardly
refuse
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
no
,
no
,
"
observed
the
Captain
complacently
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
not
.
<EOS>
No
call
for
refusing
.
<EOS>
Go
on
,
Wal'r
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
therefore
,
Sir
,
"
said
Walter
,
venturing
to
meet
Mr
Dombey
's
eye
,
and
proceeding
with
better
courage
in
the
very
desperation
of
the
case
,
now
that
there
was
no
avoiding
it
,
"
therefore
I
have
come
,
with
him
,
Sir
,
to
say
that
my
poor
old
uncle
is
in
very
great
affliction
and
distress
.
<EOS>
That
,
through
the
gradual
loss
of
his
business
,
and
not
being
able
to
make
a
payment
,
the
apprehension
of
which
has
weighed
very
heavily
upon
his
mind
,
months
and
months
,
as
indeed
<EOS>
I
know
,
Sir
,
he
has
an
execution
in
his
house
,
and
is
in
danger
of
losing
all
he
has
,
and
breaking
his
heart
.
<EOS>
And
that
if
you
would
,
in
your
kindness
,
and
in
your
old
knowledge
of
him
as
a
respectable
man
,
do
anything
to
help
him
out
of
his
difficulty
,
Sir
,
we
never
could
thank
you
enough
for
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
's
eyes
filled
with
tears
as
he
spoke
;
and
so
did
those
of
Florence
.
<EOS>
Her
father
saw
them
glistening
,
though
he
appeared
to
look
at
Walter
only
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
very
large
sum
,
Sir
,
"
said
Walter
.
<EOS>
"
More
than
three
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
My
uncle
is
quite
beaten
down
by
his
misfortune
,
it
lies
so
heavy
on
him
;
and
is
quite
unable
to
do
anything
for
his
own
relief
.
<EOS>
He
does
n't
even
know
yet
,
that
I
have
come
to
speak
to
you
.
<EOS>
You
would
wish
me
to
say
,
Sir
,
"
added
Walter
,
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
,
"
exactly
what
it
is
I
want
.
<EOS>
I
really
do
n't
know
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
There
is
my
uncle
's
stock
,
on
which
I
believe
I
may
say
,
confidently
,
there
are
no
other
demands
,
and
there
is
Captain
Cuttle
,
who
would
wish
to
be
security
too
.
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
I
hardly
like
to
mention
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
such
earnings
as
mine
;
but
if
you
would
allow
them
---
accumulate
---
payment
---
advance
---
uncle
---
frugal
,
honourable
,
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Walter
trailed
off
,
through
these
broken
sentences
,
into
silence
:
and
stood
,
with
downcast
head
,
before
his
employer
.
  
<EOS>
Considering
this
a
favourable
moment
for
the
display
of
the
valuables
,
Captain
Cuttle
advanced
to
the
table
;
and
clearing
a
space
among
the
breakfast
-
cups
at
Mr
Dombey
's
elbow
,
produced
the
silver
watch
,
the
ready
money
,
the
teaspoons
,
and
the
sugar
-
tongs
;
and
piling
them
up
into
a
heap
that
they
might
look
as
precious
as
possible
,
delivered
himself
of
these
words
:
  
"
<EOS>
Half
a
loaf
's
better
than
no
bread
,
and
the
same
remark
holds
good
with
crumbs
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
few
.
<EOS>
Annuity
of
one
hundred
pound
prannum
also
ready
to
be
made
over
.
<EOS>
If
there
is
a
man
chock
full
of
science
in
the
world
,
it
's
old
Sol
Gills
.
<EOS>
If
there
is
a
lad
of
promise
---
one
flowing
,
"
added
the
Captain
,
in
one
of
his
happy
quotations
,
"
with
milk
and
honey
<EOS>
---
it
's
his
nevy
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
then
withdrew
to
his
former
place
,
where
he
stood
arranging
his
scattered
locks
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
had
given
the
finishing
touch
to
a
difficult
performance
.
  
<EOS>
When
Walter
ceased
to
speak
,
Mr
Dombey
's
eyes
were
attracted
to
little
Paul
,
who
,
seeing
his
sister
hanging
down
her
head
and
silently
weeping
in
her
commiseration
for
the
distress
she
had
heard
described
,
went
over
to
her
,
and
tried
to
comfort
her
:
looking
at
Walter
and
his
father
as
he
did
so
,
with
a
very
expressive
face
.
<EOS>
After
the
momentary
distraction
of
Captain
Cuttle
's
address
,
which
he
regarded
with
lofty
indifference
,
Mr
Dombey
again
turned
his
eyes
upon
his
son
,
and
sat
steadily
regarding
the
child
,
for
some
moments
,
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
was
this
debt
contracted
for
?
"
asked
Mr
Dombey
,
at
length
.
<EOS>
"
Who
is
the
creditor
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
the
Captain
,
putting
his
hand
on
Walter
's
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
<EOS>
It
came
of
helping
a
man
that
's
dead
now
,
and
that
's
cost
my
friend
<EOS>
Gills
many
a
hundred
pound
already
.
<EOS>
More
particulars
in
private
,
if
agreeable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
People
who
have
enough
to
do
to
hold
their
own
way
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
unobservant
of
the
Captain
's
mysterious
signs
behind
Walter
,
and
still
looking
at
his
son
,
"
had
better
be
content
with
their
own
obligations
and
difficulties
,
and
not
increase
them
by
engaging
for
other
men
.
<EOS>
It
is
an
act
of
dishonesty
and
presumption
,
too
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
sternly
;
"
great
presumption
;
for
the
wealthy
could
do
no
more
.
<EOS>
Paul
,
come
here
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
child
obeyed
:
and
Mr
Dombey
took
him
on
his
knee
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
money
now
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
Look
at
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
Paul
,
whose
eyes
had
wandered
to
his
sister
,
and
to
Walter
,
looked
his
father
in
the
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
money
now
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
;
"
as
much
money
as
young
Gay
has
talked
about
;
what
would
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Give
it
to
his
old
uncle
,
"
returned
Paul
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lend
it
to
his
old
uncle
,
eh
?
"
retorted
Mr
Dombey
.
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
When
you
are
old
enough
,
you
know
,
you
will
share
my
money
,
and
we
shall
use
it
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Dombey
and
Son
,
"
interrupted
Paul
,
who
had
been
tutored
early
in
the
phrase
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dombey
and
Son
,
"
repeated
his
father
.
"
<EOS>
Would
you
like
to
begin
to
be
Dombey
and
Son
,
now
,
and
lend
this
money
to
young
Gay
's
uncle
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
if
you
please
,
Papa
!
"
said
Paul
:
"
and
so
would
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Girls
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
have
nothing
to
do
with
Dombey
and
Son
.
<EOS>
Would
you
like
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Papa
,
yes
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
shall
do
it
,
"
returned
his
father
.
"
<EOS>
And
you
see
,
Paul
,
"
he
added
,
dropping
his
voice
,
"
how
powerful
money
is
,
and
how
anxious
people
are
to
get
it
.
<EOS>
Young
Gay
comes
all
this
way
to
beg
for
money
,
and
you
,
who
are
so
grand
and
great
,
having
got
it
,
are
going
to
let
him
have
it
,
as
a
great
favour
and
obligation
.
"
  
<EOS>
Paul
turned
up
the
old
face
for
a
moment
,
in
which
there
was
a
sharp
understanding
of
the
reference
conveyed
in
these
words
:
but
it
was
a
young
and
childish
face
immediately
afterwards
,
when
he
slipped
down
from
his
father
's
knee
,
and
ran
to
tell
Florence
not
to
cry
any
more
,
for
he
was
going
to
let
young
Gay
have
the
money
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
then
turned
to
a
side
-
table
,
and
wrote
a
note
and
sealed
it
.
<EOS>
During
the
interval
,
Paul
and
Florence
whispered
to
Walter
,
and
Captain
Cuttle
beamed
on
the
three
,
with
such
aspiring
and
ineffably
presumptuous
thoughts
as
Mr
Dombey
never
could
have
believed
in
.
<EOS>
The
note
being
finished
,
Mr
Dombey
turned
round
to
his
former
place
,
and
held
it
out
to
Walter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Give
that
,
"
he
said
,
"
the
first
thing
to
-
morrow
morning
,
to
Mr
Carker
.
<EOS>
He
will
immediately
take
care
that
one
of
my
people
releases
your
uncle
from
his
present
position
,
by
paying
the
amount
at
issue
;
and
that
such
arrangements
are
made
for
its
repayment
as
may
be
consistent
with
your
uncle
's
circumstances
.
<EOS>
You
will
consider
that
this
is
done
for
you
by
Master
Paul
.
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
,
in
the
emotion
of
holding
in
his
hand
the
means
of
releasing
his
good
uncle
from
his
trouble
,
would
have
endeavoured
to
express
something
of
his
gratitude
and
joy
.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Dombey
stopped
him
short
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
consider
that
it
is
done
,
"
he
repeated
,
"
by
Master
Paul
.
<EOS>
I
have
explained
that
to
him
,
and
he
understands
it
.
<EOS>
I
wish
no
more
to
be
said
.
<EOS>
"
  
As
he
motioned
towards
the
door
,
Walter
could
only
bow
his
head
and
retire
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
,
seeing
that
the
Captain
appeared
about
to
do
the
same
,
interposed
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Sir
,
"
she
said
,
addressing
Mr
Dombey
,
at
whose
munificence
both
she
and
Mrs
Chick
were
shedding
tears
copiously
;
"
I
think
you
have
overlooked
something
.
<EOS>
Pardon
me
,
Mr
Dombey
<EOS>
,
I
think
,
in
the
nobility
of
your
character
,
and
its
exalted
scope
,
you
have
omitted
a
matter
of
detail
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
Miss
Tox
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
gentleman
with
theInstrument
,
"
pursued
Miss
Tox
,
glancing
at
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
has
left
upon
the
table
,
at
your
elbow
"
  
"
Good
Heaven
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
sweeping
the
Captain
's
property
from
him
,
as
if
it
were
so
much
crumb
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
Take
these
things
away
.
<EOS>
I
am
obliged
to
you
,
Miss
Tox
;
it
is
like
your
usual
discretion
.
<EOS>
Have
the
goodness
to
take
these
things
away
,
Sir
!
"
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
felt
he
had
no
alternative
but
to
comply
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
so
much
struck
by
the
magnanimity
of
Mr
Dombey
,
in
refusing
treasures
lying
heaped
up
to
his
hand
,
that
when
he
had
deposited
the
teaspoons
and
sugar
-
tongs
in
one
pocket
,
and
the
ready
money
in
another
,
and
had
lowered
the
great
watch
down
slowly
into
its
proper
vault
,
he
could
not
refrain
from
seizing
that
gentleman
's
right
hand
in
his
own
solitary
left
,
and
while
he
held
it
open
with
his
powerful
fingers
,
bringing
the
hook
down
upon
its
palm
in
a
transport
of
admiration
.
<EOS>
At
this
touch
of
warm
feeling
and
cold
iron
,
Mr
Dombey
shivered
all
over
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
then
kissed
his
hook
to
the
ladies
several
times
,
with
great
elegance
and
gallantry
;
and
having
taken
a
particular
leave
of
Paul
and
Florence
,
accompanied
Walter
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
running
after
them
in
the
earnestness
of
her
heart
,
to
send
some
message
to
old
Sol
,
when
Mr
Dombey
,
called
her
back
,
and
bade
her
stay
where
she
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
never
be
a
Dombey
,
my
dear
child
!
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
with
pathetic
reproachfulness
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Aunt
,
"
said
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
angry
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
thankful
to
Papa
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
would
have
run
and
thrown
her
arms
about
his
neck
if
she
had
dared
;
but
as
she
did
not
dare
,
she
glanced
with
thankful
eyes
towards
him
,
as
he
sat
musing
;
sometimes
bestowing
an
uneasy
glance
on
her
,
but
,
for
the
most
part
,
watching
Paul
,
who
walked
about
the
room
with
the
new
-
blown
dignity
of
having
let
young
Gay
have
the
money
.
  
<EOS>
And
young
Gay
---
Walter
---
<EOS>
what
of
him
?
  
<EOS>
He
was
overjoyed
to
purge
the
old
man
's
hearth
from
bailiffs
and
brokers
,
and
to
hurry
back
to
his
uncle
with
the
good
tidings
.
<EOS>
He
was
overjoyed
to
have
it
all
arranged
and
settled
next
day
before
noon
;
and
to
sit
down
at
evening
in
the
little
back
parlour
with
old
Sol
and
Captain
Cuttle
;
and
to
see
the
instrument
-
maker
already
reviving
,
and
hopeful
for
the
future
,
and
feeling
that
the
wooden
midshipman
was
his
own
again
.
<EOS>
But
without
the
least
impeachment
of
his
gratitude
to
Mr
Dombey
,
it
must
be
confessed
that
Walter
was
humbled
and
cast
down
.
<EOS>
It
is
when
our
budding
hopes
are
nipped
beyond
recovery
by
some
rough
wind
,
that
we
are
the
most
disposed
to
picture
to
ourselves
<EOS>
what
flowers
they
might
have
borne
,
if
they
had
flourished
;
and
now
,
when
Walter
found
himself
cut
off
from
that
great
Dombey
height
,
by
the
depth
of
a
new
and
terrible
tumble
,
and
felt
that
all
his
old
wild
fancies
had
been
scattered
to
the
winds
in
the
fall
,
he
began
to
suspect
that
they
might
have
led
him
on
to
harmless
visions
of
aspiring
to
Florence
in
the
remote
distance
of
time
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
viewed
the
subject
in
quite
a
different
light
.
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
entertain
a
belief
that
the
interview
at
which
he
had
assisted
was
so
very
satisfactory
and
encouraging
,
as
to
be
only
a
step

two

from
a
regular
betrothal
of
Florence
to
Walter
;
and
that
the
late
transaction
had
immensely
forwarded
,
if
not
thoroughly
established
,
the
Whittingtonian
hopes
.
<EOS>
Stimulated
by
this
conviction
,
and
by
the
improvement
in
the
spirits
of
his
old
friend
,
and
by
his
own
consequent

,
he
even
attempted
,
in
favouring

with
the
ballad
of
"
Lovely
Peg
"
for
the
third

in
one

,
to
make

substitution
of
the
name
"
Florence
;
"
but
finding
this
difficult
,
on
account
of
the
word
Peg
invariably
rhyming
to
leg
(
in
which
personal
beauty
the
original
was
described
as
having
excelled
all

)
,
he
hit
upon

happy

of
changing

to
Fle
---
<EOS>
e
---
eg
;
which
he
accordingly
did
,
with
an
archness
almost
supernatural
,
and
a
voice
quite
vociferous
,
notwithstanding
that
the
time
was
close
at
hand
when
he
must
seek
the
abode
of
the
dreadful
Mrs
MacStinger
.
    
Chapter
11
.
<EOS>
Paul
's
Introduction
to
a
New
Scene
 
<EOS>
MRS
PIPCHIN
'S
constitution
was
made
of
such
hard
metal
,
in
spite
of
its
liability
to
the
fleshly
weaknesses
of
standing
in
need
of
repose
after
chops
,
and
of
requiring
to
be
coaxed
to
sleep
by
the
soporific
agency
of
sweet
-
breads
,
that
it
utterly
set
at
naught
the
predictions
of
Mrs
Wickam
,
and
showed
no
symptoms
of
decline
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
as
Paul
's
rapt
interest
inthe
old
lady
continued
unabated
,
Mrs
Wickam
would
not
budge
an
inch
from
the
position
she
had
taken
up
.
<EOS>
Fortifying
and
entrenching
herself
on
the
strong
ground
of
her
uncle
's
Betsey
Jane
,
she
advised
Miss
Berry
,
as
a
friend
,
to
prepare
herself
for
the
worst
;
and
forewarned
her
that
her
aunt
might
,
at
any
time
,
be
expected
to
go
off
suddenly
,
like
a
powder
-
mill
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Berry
took
it
all
in
good
part
,
and
drudged
and
slaved
away
as
usual
;
perfectly
convinced
that
Mrs
Pipchin
was
one
of
the
most
meritorious
persons
in
the
world
,
and
making
every
day
innumerable
sacrifices
of
herself
upon
the
altar
of
that
noble
old
woman
.
<EOS>
But
all
these
immolations
of
Berry
were
somehow
carried
to
the
credit
of
Mrs
Pipchin
by
Mrs
Pipchin
's
friends
and
admirers
;
and
were
made
to
harmonise
with
,
and
carry
out
,
that
melancholy
fact
of
the
deceased
Mr
Pipchin
having
broken
his
heart
in
the
Peruvian
mines
.
  
<EOS>
For
example
,
there
was
an
honest
grocer
and
general
dealer
in
the
retail
line
of
business
,
between
whom
and
Mrs
Pipchin
there
was
a
small
memorandum
book
,
with
a
greasy
red
cover
,
perpetually
in
question
,
and
concerning
which
divers
secret
councils
and
conferences
were
continually
being
held
between
the
parties
to
the
register
,
on
the
mat
in
the
passage
,
and
with
closed
doors
in
the
parlour
.
<EOS>
Nor
were
there
wanting
dark
hints
from
Master
Bitherstone
(
whose
temper
had
been
made
re
-
vengeful
by
the
solar
heats
of
India
acting
on
his
blood
)
,
of
balances
unsettled
,
and
of
a
failure
,
on
one
occasion
with
his
memory
,
in
the
supply
of
moist
sugar
at
tea
-
time
.
<EOS>
This
grocer
being
a
bachelor
,
and
not
a
man
who
looked
upon
the
surface
for
beauty
,
had
once
made
honourable
offers
for
the
hand
of
Berry
,
which
Mrs
Pipchin
had
,
with
contumely
and
scorn
,
rejected
.
<EOS>
Everybody
said
how
laudable
this
was
in
Mrs
Pipchin
,
relict
of
a
man
who
had
died
of
the
Peruvian
mines
;
and
what
a
staunch
,
high
,
independent
spirit
the
old
lady
had
.
<EOS>
But
nobody
said
anything
about
poor
Berry
,
who
cried
for
six
weeks
(
being
soundly
rated
by
her
good
aunt
all
the
time
)
,
and
lapsed
into
a
state
of
hopeless
spinsterhood
.
   
<EOS>
"
Berry
's
very
fond
of
you
<EOS>
,
ai
n't
she
?
"
<EOS>
Paul
once
asked
Mrs
Pipchin
when
they
were

by
the
fire
with
the
cat
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
asked
Paul
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
!
"
returned
the
disconcerted

.
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
ask
such
things
,
Sir
!
<EOS>
why

fond

your

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
she
's
very
good
,
"
said
Paul
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
nobody
like
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
retorted
Mrs
Pipchin
,

,
"
and
there
's
nobody
like
me
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
there
really
though
?
"
asked
Paul
,
leaning
forward
in

chair
,
and
looking
at

very

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
old
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
that
,
"
observed
Paul
,
rubbing
his
hands
thoughtfully
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
very
good
thing
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
did
n't
dare
to
ask
him
why
,
lest
she
should
receive
some
perfectly
annihilating
answer
.
<EOS>
But
as
a
compensation
to
her
wounded
feelings
,
she
harassed
Master
Bitherstone
to
that
extent
until
bed
-
time
,
that
he
began
that
very
night
to
make
arrangements
for
an
overland
return
to
India
,
by
Secreting
from
his
supper
a
quarter
of
a
round
of
bread
and

fragment
of
moist
Dutch
cheese
,
as
the
beginning
of
a
stock
of
provision
to
support
him
on
the
voyage
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
had
kept
watch
and
ward
over
little
Paul
and
his
sister
for
nearly
twelve
months
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
home
twice
,
but
only
for
a
few
days
;
and
had
been
constant
in
their
weekly
visits
to
Mr
Dombey
at
the
hotel
.
<EOS>
By
little
and
little
Paul
had
grown
stronger
,
and
had
become
able
to
dispense
with
his
carriage
;
though
he
still
looked
thin
and
delicate
;
and
still
remained
the
same
old
,
quiet
,
dreamy
child
that
he
had
been
when
first
consigned
to
Mrs
Pipchin
's
care
.
<EOS>
One
Saturday
afternoon
,
at
dusk
,
great
consternation
was
occasioned
in
the
castle
by
the
unlooked
-
for
announcement
of
Mr
Dombey
as
a
visitor
to
Mrs
Pipchin
.
<EOS>
The
population
of
the
parlour
was
immediately
swept
up
stairs
as
on
the
wings
of
a
whirlwind
,
and
after
much
slamming
of
bedroom
doors
,
and

overhead
,
and
some
knocking
about
of
Master
Bitherstone
by
Mrs
Pipchin
,
as
a
relief
to
the
perturbation
of
her

,
the
black
bombazeen
garments
of
the
worthy
old

darkened

audience
-

where
Mr
Dombey
was
contemplating
the
vacant
arm
-
chair
of
his
son
and
heir
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
How
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
I
am
pretty
well
,
considering
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
always
used
that
form
of
words
.
<EOS>
It
meant
,
considering
her
virtues
,
sacrifices
,
and
so
forth
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
expect
,
Sir
,
to
be
very
well
,
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
,
taking
a
chair
and
fetching
her
breath
;
"
but
such
health
as
I
have
<EOS>
,
I
am
grateful
for
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
inclined
his
head
with
the
satisfied
air
of
a
patron
,
who
felt
that
this
was
the
sort
of
thing
for
which
he
paid
so
much
a
quarter
.
<EOS>
After
a
moment
's
silence
he
went
on
to
say
:
  
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
,
I
have
taken
the
liberty
of
calling
,
to
consult
you
in
reference

.
<EOS>
I

;
but
have

,

re

.
<EOS>
You

,
Mrs

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Brighton
has
proved
very

,
Sir
,
"
returned
Mrs
Pipchin
.
"
<EOS>
Very
beneficial
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
purpose
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
his
remaining
at
Brighton
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
rubbed
her
hands
,
and
bent
her
grey

on
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
"

Mr
Dombey
,

,
"
but

now

,

.
<EOS>
In

,
Mrs
Pipchin
,
that

.
<EOS>
My
son
is
getting

,
Mrs
Pipchin
.
<EOS>
Really

is
getting
on
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
melancholy
in

Mr
Dombey
said
this
.
<EOS>
It
showed
how
long
Paul
's
childish

had
been
to

,
and
how
his
hopes
were
set
upon
a
later

.
<EOS>
Pity
may
appear
a
strange

and
so
cold
,
and
yet

worthy
subject

.
  
<EOS>
"
Six
years
old
!
"

Dombey
,

---
perhaps
to

that
rather

and

,
as

,

.
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
six
will
be
changed

,

.
"
  
"
Ten

,
"

,

,

dreary

,
"
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

Dombey
;
"

,
Mrs
Pipchin
,

is

,

,
I

,
that

he

---

,
"

,

what

was

the
frosty
eye
<EOS>
,
"
his

a

.
<EOS>
Now
,

,

,

ought

before

;
far

.
<EOS>
There

ready

mount

.
<EOS>
There

nothing

.
<EOS>
His
way
in
life
was
clear

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
It

,

Pipchin
.
"
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
I
can
say
nothing
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
quite
sure
,
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"

Dombey
,
approvingly
,
"
that

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

---

---
<EOS>
talked

,

,

,

,
"
said

Pipchin
,

hooked
nose
.
<EOS>
"
It
never
was
thought
of
in
my
time
,
and
it
has
no
business
to
be
thought
of
now
.
<EOS>
My
opinion
is
"
keep'em
at
it
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
My
good
madam
,
"
returned
Mr
Dombey
,
"
you
have
not
acquired
your
reputation
undeservedly
;
and
I
beg
you
to
believe
,
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
,
that
I
am
more
than
satisfied
with
your
excellent
system
of
management
,
and
shall
have
the
greatest
pleasure
in
commending
it
whenever
my
poor
commendation
"
---
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
loftiness
when
he
affected
to
disparage
his
own
importance
,
passed
all
bounds
---
"
can
be
of
any
service
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
thinking
of
Doctor
Blimber
's
,
Mrs
Pipchin
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
neighbour
,
Sir
?
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
the
Doctor
's
is
an
excellent
establishment
.
<EOS>
I
've
heard
that
it
's
very
strictly
conducted
,
and
there
is
nothing
but
learning
going
on
from
morning
to
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
it
's
very
expensive
,
"
added
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
it
's
very
expensive
,
Sir
,
"
returned
Mrs
Pipchin
,
catching
at
the
fact
,
as
if
in
omitting
that
,
she
had
omitted
one
of
its
leading
merits
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
some
communication
with
the
Doctor
,
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
hitching
his
chair
anxiously
a
little
nearer
to
the
fire
,
"
and
he
does
not
consider
Paul
at
all
too
young
for
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
He
mentioned
several
instances
of
boys
in
Greek
at
about
the
same
age
.
<EOS>
If
I
have
any
little
uneasiness
in
my
own
mind
,
Mrs
Pipchin
,
on
the
subject
of
this
change
,
it
is
not
on
that
head
.
<EOS>
My
son
not
having
known
a
mother
has
gradually
concentrated
much
---
too
much
---
of
his
childish
affection
on
his
sister
.
<EOS>
Whether
their
separation
---
"
Mr
Dombey
said
no
more
,
but
sat
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hoity
-
toity
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Pipchin
,
shaking
out
her
black
bombazeen
skirts
,
and
plucking
up
all
the
ogress
within
her
.
<EOS>
"
If
she
do
n't
like
it
,
Mr
Dombey
,
she
must
be
taught
to
lump
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
good
lady
apologised
immediately
afterwards
for
using
so
common
a
figure
of
speech
,
but
said
(
and
truly
)
<EOS>
that
that
was
the
way
she
reasoned
with
'em
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
waited
until
Mrs
Pipchin
had
done
bridling
and
shaking
her
head
,
and
frowning
down
a
legion
of
Bitherstones
and
Pankeys
;
and
then
said
quietly
,
but
correctively
,
"
He
,
my
good
madam
,
he
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
's
system
would
have
applied
very
much
the
same
mode
of
cure
to
any
uneasiness
on
the
part
of
Paul
,
too
;
but
as
the
hard
grey
eye
was
sharp
enough
to
see
that
the
recipe
,
however
Mr
Dombey
might
admit
its
efficacy
in
the

of
the
daughter
,
was
not
a
sovereign

for
the
son
,
she
argued
the
point
;
and
contended
that
change
,
and
new

,
and
the
different
form
of
life
he
would
lead
at
Doctor
Blimber
's
,
and
the

he
would
have

master
,
would
very
soon

sufficient

.
<EOS>
As
this
chimed
in
with
Mr
Dombey
's
own
hope
and
belief
,
it
gave
that
gentleman
a
still
higher
opinion
of
Mrs
Pipchin
's
understanding
:
and
as
Mrs
Pipchin
,
at
the
same
time
,
bewailed
the
loss
of
her
dear
little
friend
(
which
was
not
an

shock
to
her
,
as
she
had
long
expected

,
and
had
not
looked
,
in

,
for
his
remaining
with
her
longer
than
three
months
)
,
he
formed
an
equally
good
opinion
of
Mrs
Pipchin
's
disinterestedness
.
<EOS>
It
was
plain
that
he
had
given
the
subject
anxious
consideration
,
for
he
had
formed
a
plan
,
which
he
announced
to
the
ogress
,
of
sending
Paul
to
the
Doctor
's
as
a
weekly
boarder
for
the
first
half
year
,
during
which
time
Florence
would
remain
at
the
castle
,
that
she
might
receive
her
brother
there
,
on
Saturdays
.
<EOS>
This
would
wean
him
by
degrees
,
Mr
Dombey
said
;
probably
with
a
recollection
of
his
not
having
been
weaned
by
degrees
on
a
former
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
finished
the
interview
by
expressing
his
hope
that
Mrs
Pipchin
would
still
remain
in
office
as
general
superintendent
and
overseer
of
his
son
,
pending
his
studies
at
Brighton
;
and
having
kissed
Paul
,
and
shaken
hands
with
Florence
,
and
beheld
Master
Bitherstone
in
his
collar
of
state
,
and
made
Miss
Pankey
cry
by
patting
her
on
the
head
(
in
which
region
she
was
uncommonly
tender
,
on
account
of
a
habit
Mrs
Pipchin
had
of
sounding
it
with
her
knuckles
,
like
a
cask
)
,
he
withdrew
to
his
hotel
and
dinner
:
resolved
that
Paul
,
now
that
he
was
getting
so
old
and
well
,
should
begin
a
vigorous
course
of
education
forthwith
,
to
qualify
him
for
the
position
in
which
he
was
to
shine
;
and
that
Doctor
Blimber
should
take
him
in
hand
immediately
.
  
<EOS>
Whenever
a
young
gentleman
was
taken
in
hand
by
Doctor
Blimber
,
he
might
consider
himself
sure
of
a
pretty
tight
squeeze
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
only
undertook
the
charge
of
ten
young
gentlemen
,
but
he
had
,
always
ready
,
a
supply
of
learning
for
a
hundred
,
on
the
lowest
estimate
;
and
it
was
at
once
the
business
and
delight
of
his
life
to
gorge
the
unhappy
ten
with
it
.
  
<EOS>
In
fact
,
Doctor
Blimber
's
establishment
was
a
great
hot
-
house
,
in
which
there
was
a
forcing
apparatus
incessantly
at
work
.
<EOS>
All
the
boys
blew
before
their
time
.
<EOS>
Mental
green
-
peas
were
produced
at
Christmas
,
and
intellectual
asparagus
all
the
year
round
.
<EOS>
Mathematical
gooseberries
(
very
sour
ones
too
)
were
common
at
untimely
seasons
,
and
from
mere
sprouts
of
bushes
,
under
Doctor
Blimber
's
cultivation
.
<EOS>
Every
description
of
Greek
and
Latin
vegetable
was
got
off
the
driest
twigs
of
boys
,
under
the
frostiest
circumstances
.
<EOS>
Nature
was
of
no
consequence
at
all
.
<EOS>
No
matter
what
a
young
gentleman
was
intended
to
bear
,
Doctor
Blimber
made
him
bear
to
pattern
,
somehow
or
other
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
all
very
pleasant
and
ingenious
,
but
the
system
of
forcing
was
attended
with
its
usual
disadvantages
.
<EOS>
There
was
not
the
right
taste
about
the
premature
productions
,
and
they
did
n't
keep
well
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
one
young
gentleman
,
with
a
swollen
nose
and
an
excessively
large
head
(
the
oldest
of
the
ten
who
had
"
gone
through
"
everything
)
,
suddenly
left
off
blowing
one
day
,
and
remained
in
the
establishment
a
mere
stalk
.
<EOS>
And
people
did
say
that
the
Doctor
had
rather
overdone
it
with
young
Toots
,
and
that
when
he
began
to
have
whiskers
he
left
off
having
brains
.
  
<EOS>
There
young
Toots
was
,
at
any
rate
;
possessed
of
the
gruffest
of
voices
and
the
shrillest
of
minds
;
sticking
ornamental
pins
into
his
shirt
,
and
keeping
a
ring
in
his
waistcoat
pocket
to
put
on
his
little
finger
by
stealth
,
when
the
pupils
went
out
walking
;
constantly
falling
in
love
by
sight
with
nurserymaids
,
who
had
no
idea
of
his
existence
;
and
looking
at
the
gas
-
lighted
world
over
the
little
iron
bars
in
the
left
-
hand
corner
window
of
the
front
three
pairs
of
stairs
,
after
bed
-
time
,
like
a
greatly
overgrown
cherub
who
had
sat
up
aloft
much
too
long
.
  
<EOS>
The
Doctor
was
a
portly
gentleman
in
a
suit
of
black
,
with
strings
at
his
knees
,
and
stockings
below
them
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
bald
head
,
highly
polished
;
a
deep
voice
;
and
a
chin
so
very
double
,
that
it
was
a
wonder
how
he
ever
managed
to
shave
into
the
creases
.
<EOS>
He
had
likewise
a
pair
of
little
eyes
that
were
always
half
shut
up
,
and
a
mouth
that
was
always
half
expanded
into
a
grin
,
as
if
he
had
,
that
moment
,
posed
a
boy
,
and
were
waiting
to
convict
him
from
his
own
lips
.
<EOS>
Insomuch
,
that
when
the
Doctor
put
his
right
hand
into
the
breast
of
his
coat
,
and
with
his
other
hand
behind
him
,
and
a
scarcely
perceptible
wag
of
his
head
,
made
the
commonest
observation
to
a
nervous
stranger
,
it
was
like
a
sentiment
from
the
sphynx
,
and
settled
his
business
.
  
<EOS>
The
Doctor
's
was
a
mighty
fine
house
,
fronting
the
sea
.
<EOS>
Not
a
joyful
style
of
house
within
,
but
quite
the
contrary
.
<EOS>
Sad
-
coloured
curtains
,
whose
proportions
were
spare
and
lean
,
hid
themselves
despondently
behind
the
windows
.
<EOS>
The
tables
and
chairs
were
put
away
in
rows
,
like
figures
in
a
sum
:
<EOS>
fires
were
so
rarely
lighted
in
the
rooms
of
ceremony
,
that
they
felt
like
wells
,
and
a
visitor
represented
the
bucket
;
the
dining
-
room
seemed
the
last
place
in
the
world
where
any
eating
or
drinking
was
likely
to
occur
;
there
was
no
sound
through
all
the
house
but
the
ticking
of
a
great
clock
in
the
hall
,
which
made
itself
audible
in
the
very
garrets
:
and
sometimes
a
dull
crying
of
young
gentlemen
at
their
lessons
,
like
the
murmurings
of
an
assemblage
of
melancholy
pigeons
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Blimber
,
too
,
although
a
slim
and
graceful
maid
,
did
no
soft
violence
to
the
gravity
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
light
nonsense
about
Miss
Blimber
.
<EOS>
She
kept
her
hair
short
and
crisp
,
and
wore
spectacles
.
<EOS>
She
was
dry
and
sandy
with
working
in
the
graves
of
deceased
languages
.
<EOS>
None
of
your
live
languages
for
Miss
Blimber
.
<EOS>
They
must
be
dead
<EOS>
---
stone
dead
---
and
then
Miss
Blimber
dug
them
up
like
a
Ghoul
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Blimber
,
her
mama
,
was
not
learned
herself
,
but
she
pretended
to
be
,
and
that
did
quite
as
well
.
<EOS>
She
said
at
evening
parties
,
that
if
she
could
have
known
Cicero
,
she
thought
she
could
have
died
contented
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
steady
joy
of
her
life
to
see
the
Doctor
's
young
gentlemen
go
out
walking
,
unlike
all
other
young
gentlemen
,
in
the
largest
possible
shirt
-
collars
,
and
the
stiffest
possible
cravats
.
<EOS>
It
was
so
classical
,
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
As
to
Mr
Feeder
,
BA
,
Doctor
Blimber
's
assistant
,
he
was
a
kind
of
human
barrel
-
organ
,
with
a
little
list
of
tunes
at
which
he
was
continually
working
,
over
and
over
again
,
without
any
variation
.
<EOS>
He
might
have
been
fitted
up
with
a
change
of
barrels
,
perhaps
,
in
early
life
,
if
his
destiny
had
been
favourable
;
but
it
had
not
been
;
and
he
had
only
one
,
with
which
,
in
a
monotonous
round
,
it
was
his
occupation
to
bewilder
the
young
ideas
of
Doctor
Blimber
's
young
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
The
young
gentlemen
were
prematurely
full
of
carking
anxieties
.
<EOS>
They
knew
no
rest
from
the
pursuit
of
stony
-
hearted
verbs
,
savage
noun
-
substantives
,
inflexible
syntactic
passages
,
and
ghosts
of
exercises
that
appeared
to
them
in
their
dreams
.
<EOS>
Under
the
forcing
system
,
a
young
gentleman
usually
took
leave
of
his
spirits
in
three
weeks
.
<EOS>
He
had
all
the
cares
of
the
world
on
his
head
in
three
months
.
<EOS>
He
conceived
bitter
sentiments
against
his
parents
or
guardians
in
four
;
he
was
an
old
misanthrope
,
in
five
;
envied
Curtius
that
blessed
refuge
in
the
earth
,
in
six
;
and
at
the
end
of
the
first
twelvemonth
had
arrived
at
the
conclusion
,
from
which
he
never
afterwards
departed
,
that
all
the
fancies
of
the
poets
,
and
lessons
of
the
sages
,
were
a
mere
collection
of
words
and
grammar
,
and
had
no
other
meaning
in
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
went
on
blow
,
blow
,
blowing
,
in
the
Doctor
's
hot
-
house
,
all
the
time
;
and
the
Doctor
's
glory
and
reputation
were
great
,
when
he
took
his
wintry
growth
home
to
his
relations
and
friends
.
  
<EOS>
Upon
the
Doctor
's
door
-
steps
one
day
,
Paul
stood
with
a
fluttering
heart
,
and
with
his
small
right
hand
in
his
father
's
.
<EOS>
His
other
hand
was
locked
in
that
of
Florence
.
<EOS>
How
tight
the
tiny
pressure
of
that
one
;
and
how
loose
and
cold
the
other
!
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pinchin
hovered
behind
the
victim
,
with
her
sable
plumage
and
her
hooked
beak
,
like
a
bird
of
ill
-
omen
.
<EOS>
She
was
out
of
breath
---
for
Mr
Dombey
,
full
of
great
thoughts
,
had
walked
fast
---
and
she
croaked
hoarsely
as
she
waited
for
the
opening
of
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Paul
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
exultingly
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
way
indeed
to
be
Dombey
and
Son
,
and
have
money
.
<EOS>
You
are
almost
a
man
already
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Almost
,
"
returned
the
child
.
  
<EOS>
Even
his
childish
agitation
could
not
master
the
sly
and
quaint
yet
touching
look
,
with
which
he
accompanied
the
reply
.
  
<EOS>
It
brought
a
vague
expression
of
dissatisfaction
into
Mr
Dombey
's
face
;
but
the
door
being
opened
,
it
was
quickly
gone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Blimber
is
at
home
,
I
believe
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
said
yes
;
and
as
they
passed
in
,
looked
at
Paul
as
if
he
were
a
little
mouse
,
and
the
house
were
a
trap
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
weak
-
eyed
young
man
,
with
the
first
faint
streaks
or
early
dawn
of
a
grin
on
his
countenance
.
<EOS>
It
was
mere
imbecility
;
but
Mrs
Pipchin
took
it
into
her
head
that
it
was
impudence
,
and
made
a
snap
at
him
directly
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
laugh
behind
the
gentleman
's
back
?
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
.
"
<EOS>
And
what
do
you
take
me
for
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
a
laughing
at
nobody
,
and
I
'm
sure
I
do
n't
take
you
for
nothing
,
Ma'am
,
"
returned
the
young
man
,
in
consternation
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
pack
of
idle
dogs
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
only
fit
to
be
turnspits
.
<EOS>
Go
and
tell
your
master
that
Mr
Dombey
's
here
,
or
it
'll
be
worse
for
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
weak
-
eyed
young
man
went
,
very
meekly
,
to
discharge
himself
of
this
commission
;
and
soon
came
back
to
invite
them
to
the
Doctor
's
study
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
laughing
again
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
,
when
it
came
to
her
turn
,
bringing
up
the
rear
,
to
pass
him
in
the
hall
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
,
returned
the
young
man
,
grievously
oppressed
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
see
such
a
thing
as
this
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
,
Mrs
Pipchin
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
looking
round
.
"
<EOS>
Softly
!
<EOS>
Pray
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
,
in
her
deference
,
merely
muttered
at
the
young
man
as
she
passed
on
,
and
said
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
he
was
a
precious
fellow
"
---
leaving
the
young
man
,
who
was
all
meekness
and
incapacity
,
affected
even
to
tears
by
the
incident
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Pipchin
had
a
way
of
falling
foul
of
all
meek
people
;
and
her
friends
said
who
could
wonder
at
it
,
after
the
Peruvian
mines
!
  
<EOS>
The
Doctor
was
sitting
in
his
portentous
study
,
with
a
globe
at
each
knee
,
books
all
round
him
,
Homer
over
the
door
,
and
Minerva
on
the
mantel
-
shelf
.
"
<EOS>
And
how
do
you
do
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
he
said
to
Mr
Dombey
;
"
and
how
is
my
little
friend
?
"
<EOS>
Grave
as
an
organ
was
the
Doctor
's
speech
;
and
when
he
ceased
,
the
great
clock
in
the
hall
seemed
(
to
Paul
at
least
)
to
take
him
up
,
and
to
go
on
saying
,
"
how
,
is
,
my
,
lit
,
tle
,
friend
?
<EOS>
how
,
is
,
my
,
lit
,
tle
,
friend
?
"
<EOS>
over
and
over
and
over
again
.
  
<EOS>
The
little
friend
being
something
too
small
to
be
seen
at
all
from
where
the
Doctor
sat
,
over
the
books
on
his
table
,
the
Doctor
made
several
futile
attempts
to
get
a
view
of
him
round
the
legs
;
which
Mr
Dombey
perceiving
,
relieved
the
Doctor
from
his
embarrassment
by
taking
Paul
up
in
his
arms
,
and
sitting
him
on
another
little
table
,
over
against
the
Doctor
,
in
the
middle
of
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
said
the
Doctor
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
with
his
hand
in
his
breast
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
I
see
my
little
friend
.
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
,
my
little
friend
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
clock
in
the
hall
would
n't
subscribe
to
this
alteration
in
the
form
of
words
,
but
continued
to
repeat
"
how
,
is
,
my
,
lit
,
tle
,
friend
?
<EOS>
how
,
is
,
my
,
lit
,
tle
,
friend
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
I
thank
you
,
Sir
,
"
returned
Paul
,
answering
the
clock
quite
as
much
as
the
Doctor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
said
Doctor
Blimber
.
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
make
a
man
of
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
,
Paul
?
"
added
Mr
Dombey
;
<EOS>
Paul
being
silent
.
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
make
a
man
of
him
?
"
repeated
the
Doctor
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
rather
be
a
child
,
"
replied
Paul
.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
said
the
Doctor
.
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
child
sat
on
the
table
looking
at
him
,
with
a
curious
expression
of
suppressed
emotion
in
his
face
,
and
beating
one
hand
proudly
on
his
knee
as
if
he
had
the
rising
tears
beneath
it
,
and
crushed
them
.
<EOS>
But
his
other
hand
strayed
a
little
way
the
while
,
a
little
farther
---
farther
from
him
yet
---
until
it
lighted
on
the
neck
of
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
why
,
"
it
seemed
to
say
,
and
then
the
steady
look
was
broken
up
and
gone
;
the
working
lip
was
loosened
;
and
the
tears
came
streaming
forth
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
said
his
father
,
in
a
querulous
manner
,
"
I
am
really
very
sorry
to
see
this
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
away
from
him
,
do
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
quoth
the
matron
.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
blandly

his
head
,
to
keep
Mrs
Pipchin
back
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ne
-
ver
mind
<EOS>
;
we
shall
substitute
new
cares
and
new
impressions
,
Mr
Dombey
,
very
shortly
.
<EOS>
You
would
still
wish
my
little
friend
to
acquire
"
  
"
Everything
,
if
you
please
,
Doctor
,
"
returned
Mr
Dombey
,
firmly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
who
,
with
his
half
-

,
and
his
usual

,
seemed
to

Paul
with
the
sort

interest
that
might
attach
to
some
choice

animal
he

going
to
stuff
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
exactly
.
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
We
shall
impart
a
great
variety

information
to
our
little

,
and
bring
him
quickly
forward
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
Quite
a
virgin
soil
,
I
believe
you
said
,
Mr
Dombey
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Except
some

at

,
and

this

,
"
replied
Mr
Dombey
,
introducing
Mrs

,
who
instantly

to

,
and
snorted

beforehand
,
in

should
disparage

;
"
except
so
far
,
Paul
has
,
as
yet
,
applied
himself
to
no
studies
at
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
Doctor
Blimber
inclined
his
head
,
in
gentle
tolerance
of
such
insignificant
poaching
as
Mrs
Pipchin
's
,
and
said
he
was
glad
to
hear

.
<EOS>
It
was
much
more
satisfactory
,
he
observed
,
rubbing
his
hands
,
to
begin
at
the
foundation
.
<EOS>
And
again
he
leered
at
Paul
,
as
if
he
would
have
liked
to
tackle
him
with
the
Greek
alphabet
on

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
circumstance
,

,
Doctor
Blimber
,
"
pursued
Mr
Dombey
,
glancing
at
his
little
son
,
"
and
the
interview
I
have

holding
with

,
renders

,
and
consequently
,
and
further

on

valuable

,
so

,
that
---
"
   
"
Now
,
Miss
Dombey
!
"
said
the
acid

.
  
<EOS>
"
Permit

,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
"
one

.
<EOS>
Allow
me
to
present
Mrs
Blimber
and

,
who
will

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Blimber
,
"
for

,
who
had

in

,

,

,
that
fair
Sexton
in

,
"
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
My
daughter
Cornelia
,
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,

love
,
"
pursued

,

,
"
is
so
confiding

to
---
do
you
see
our
little
friend
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Blimber
,
in
an

,
of

Mr
Dombey
was
the

,
apparently

not
,
for
she
was
backing
against
the
little
friend
,
and
very
much
endangering
his
position
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
But
,
on
this
hint
,
she
turned
to
admire
his
classical
and
intellectual
lineaments
,
and
turning
again
to
Mr
Dombey
,
said
,
with
a
sigh
,
that
she
envied
his
dear
son
.
  
<EOS>
"
Like
a
bee
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Blimber
,
with
uplifted
eyes
,
"
about
to
plunge
into
a
garden
of
the
choicest
flowers
,
and
sip
the
sweets
for
the
first
time
.
<EOS>
Virgil
,
Horace
,
Ovid
,
Terence
,
Plautus
,
Cicero
.
<EOS>
What
a
world
of
honey
have
we
here
.
<EOS>
It
may
appear
remarkable
,
Mr
Dombey
,
in
one
who
is
a
wife
---
the
wife
of
such
a
husband
---
"
  
"
Hush
,
hush
,
"
said
Doctor
Blimber
.
<EOS>
"
Fie
for
shame
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dombey
will
forgive
the
partiality
of
a
wife
,
"
said
Mrs
Blimber
,
with
an
engaging
