at
his
own
door
.
<EOS>
He
knowed
Toodle
,
he
said
,
well
.
<EOS>
Belonged
to
the
Railroad
,
did
n't
he
?
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
yes
!
"
cried
Susan
Nipper
from
the
coach
window
.
  
<EOS>
Where
did
he
live
now
?
<EOS>
hastily
inquired
Walter
.
  
<EOS>
He
lived
in
the
Company
's
own
Buildings
,
second
turning
to
the
right
,
down
the
yard
,
cross
over
,
and
take
the
second
on
the
right
again
.
<EOS>
It
was
number
eleven
;
they
could
n't
mistake
it
;
but
if
they
did
,
they
had
only
to
ask
for
Toodle
,
Engine
Fireman
,
and
any
one
would
show
them
which
was
his
house
.
<EOS>
At
this
unexpected
stroke
of
success
,
Susan
Nipper
dismounted
from
the
coach
with
all
speed
,
took
Walter
's
arm
,
and
set
off
at
a
breathless
pace
on
foot
;
leaving
the
coach
there
to
await
their
return
.
  
<EOS>
"
Has
the
little
boy
been
long
ill
,
Susan
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Walter
,
as
they
hurried
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ailing
for
a
deal
of
time
,
but
no
one
knew
how
much
,
"
said
Susan
;
adding
,
with
excessive
sharpness
,
"
Oh
,
them
Blimbers
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Blimbers
?
"
echoed
Walter
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
forgive
myself
at
such
a
time
as
this
,
Mr
Walter
,
"
said
Susan
,
"
and
when
there
's
so
much
serious
distress
to
think
about
,
if
I
rested
hard
on
any
one
,
especially
on
them
that
little
darling
<EOS>
Paul
speaks
well
of
,
but
I
may
wish
that
the
family
was
set
to
work
in
a
stony
soil
to
make
new
roads
,
and
that
Miss
Blimber
went
in
front
,
and
had
the
pickaxe
!
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper
then
took
breath
,
and
went
on
faster
than
before
,
as
if
this
extraordinary
aspiration
had
relieved
her
.
<EOS>
Walter
,
who
had
by
this
time
no
breath
of
his
own
to
spare
,
hurried
along
without
asking
any
more
questions
;
and
they
soon
,
in
their
impatience
,
burst
in
at
a
little
door
and
came
into
a
clean
parlour
full
of
children
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Mrs
Richards
?
"
exclaimed
Susan
Nipper
,
looking
round
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
Mrs
Richards
,
Mrs
Richards
,
come
along
with
me
,
my
dear
creetur
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
if
it
an't
Susan
!
"
cried
Polly
,
rising
with
her
honest
face
and
motherly
figure
from
among
the
group
,
in
great
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mrs
Richards
,
it
's
me
,
"
said
Susan
,
"
and
I
wish
it
was
n't
,
though
I
may
not
seem
to
flatter
when
I
say
so
,
but
little
Master
Paul
is
very
ill
,
and
told
his
Pa
to
-
day
that
he
would
like
to
see
the
face
of
his
old
nurse
,
and
him
and
Miss
Floy
hope
you
'll
come
along
with
me
---
and
Mr
Walter
,
Mrs
Richards
---
<EOS>
forgetting
what
is
past
,
and
do
a
kindness
to
the
sweet
dear
that
is
withering
away
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mrs
Richards
,
withering
away
!
"
<EOS>
Susan
Nipper
crying
,
Polly
shed
tears
to
see
her
,
and
to
hear
what
she
had
said
;
and
all
the
children
gathered
round
(
including
numbers
of
new
babies
)
;
and
Mr
Toodle
,
who
had
just
come
home
from
Birmingham
,
and
was
eating
his
dinner
out
of
a
basin
,
laid
down
his
knife
and
fork
,
and
put
on
his
wife
's
bonnet
and
shawl
for
her
,
which
were
hanging
up
behind
the
door
;
then
tapped
her
on
the
back
;
and
said
,
with
more
fatherly
feeling
than
eloquence
,
"
Polly!cut
away
!
"
  
<EOS>
So
they
got
back
to
the
coach
,
long
before
the
coachman
expected
them
;
and
Walter
,
putting
Susan
and
Mrs
Richards
inside
,
took
his
seat
on
the
box
himself
that
there
might
be
no
more
mistakes
,
and
deposited
them
safely
in
the
hall
of
Mr
Dombey
's
house
---
where
,
by
the
bye
,
he
saw
a
mighty
nosegay
lying
,
which
reminded
him
of
the
one
Captain
Cuttle
had
purchased
in
his
company
that
morning
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
lingered
to
know
more
of
the
young
invalid
,
or
waited
any
length
of
time
to
see
if
he
could
render
the
least
service
;
but
,
painfully
sensible
that
such
conduct
would
be
looked
upon
by
Mr
Dombey
as
presumptuous
and
forward
,
he
returned
slowly
,
sadly
,
anxiously
,
away
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
gone
five
minutes
'
walk
from
the
door
,
when
a
man
came
running
after
him
,
and
begged
him
to
return
.
<EOS>
Walter
retraced
his
steps
as
quickly
as
he
could
,
and
entered
the
gloomy
house
with
a
sorrowful
foreboding
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
16
.
<EOS>
What
the
Waves
were
always
saying
 
PAUL
had
never
risen
from
his
little
bed
.
<EOS>
He
lay
there
,
listening
to
the
noises
in
the
street
,
quite
tranquilly
;
not
caring
much
how
the
time
went
,
but
watching
it
and
watching
everything
about
him
with
observing
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
sunbeams
struck
into
his
room
through
the
rustling
blinds
,
and
quivered
on
the
opposite
wall
like
golden
water
,
he
knew
that
evening
was
coming
on
,
and
that
the
sky
was
red
and
beautiful
.
<EOS>
As
the
reflection
died
away
,
and
a
gloom
went
creeping
up
the
wall
,
he
watched
it
deepen
,
deepen
,
deepen
,
into
night
.
<EOS>
Then
he
thought
how
the
long
streets
were
dotted
with
lamps
,
and
how
the
peaceful
stars
were
shining
overhead
.
<EOS>
His
fancy
had
a
strange
tendency
to
wander
to
the
river
,
which
he
knew
was
flowing
through
the
great
city
;
and
now
he
thought
how
black
it
was
,
and
how
deep
it
would
look
,
reflecting
the
hosts
of
stars
---
and
more
than
all
,
how
steadily
it
rolled
away
to
meet
the
sea
.
  
<EOS>
As
it
grew
later
in
the
night
,
and
footsteps
in
the
street
became
so
rare
that
he
could
hear
them
coming
,
count
them
as
they
passed
,
and
lose
them
in
the
hollow
distance
,
he
would
lie
and
watch
the
many
-
coloured
ring
about
the
candle
,
and
wait
patiently
for
day
.
<EOS>
His
only
trouble
was
,
the
swift
and
rapid
river
.
<EOS>
He
felt
forced
,
sometimes
,
to
try
to
stop
it
---
to
stem
it
with
his
childish
hands
---
or
choke
its
way
with
sand
---
and
when
he
saw
it
coming
on
,
resistless
,
he
cried
out
!
<EOS>
But
a
word
from
Florence
,
who
was
always
at
his
side
,
restored
him
to
himself
;
and
leaning
his
poor
head
upon
her
breast
,
he
told
Floy
of
his
dream
,
and
smiled
.
  
<EOS>
When
day
began
to
dawn
again
,
he
watched
for
the
sun
;
and
when
its
cheerful
light
began
to
sparkle
in
the
room
,
he
pictured
to
himself
---
pictured
!
<EOS>
he
saw
---
the
high
church
towers
rising
up
into
the
morning
sky
,
the
town
reviving
,
waking
,
starting
into
life
once
more
,
the
river
glistening
as
it
rolled
(
but
rolling
fast
as
ever
)
,
and
the
country
bright
with
dew
.
<EOS>
Familiar
sounds
and
cries
came
by
degrees
into
the
street
below
;
the
servants
in
the
house
were
roused
and
busy
;
faces
looked
in
at
the
door
,
and
voices
asked
his
attendants
softly
how
he
was
.
<EOS>
Paul
always
answered
for
himself
,
"
I
am
better
.
<EOS>
I
am
a
great
deal
better
,
thank
you
!
<EOS>
Tell
Papa
so
!
"
  
<EOS>
By
little
and
little
,
he
got
tired
of
the
bustle
of
the
day
,
the
noise
of
carriages
and
carts
,
and
people
passing
and
repassing
;
and
would
fall
asleep
,
or
be
troubled
with
a
restless
and
uneasy
sense
again
---
the
child
could
hardly
tell
whether
this
were
in
his
sleeping
or
his
waking
moments
---
of
that
rushing
river
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
will
it
never
stop
,
Floy
?
"
he
would
sometimes
ask
her
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
bearing
me
away
,
I
think
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
Floy
could
always
soothe
and
reassure
him
;
and
it
was
his
daily
delight
to
make
her
lay
her
head
down
on
his
pillow
,
and
take
some
rest
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
always
watching
me
,
Floy
.
<EOS>
Let
me
watch
you
,
now
!
<EOS>
"
They
would
prop
him
up
with
cushions
in
a
corner
of
his
bed
,
and
there
he
would
recline
the
while
she
lay
beside
him
:
bending
forward
oftentimes
to
kiss
her
,
and
whispering
to
those
who
were
near
that
she
was
tired
,
and
how
she
had
sat
up
so
many
night
beside
him
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
,
the
flush
of
the
day
,
in
its
heat
and
light
,
would
gradually
decline
;
and
again
the
golden
water
would
be
dancing
on
the
wall
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
visited
by
as
many
as
three
grave
doctors
---
they
used
to
assemble
downstairs
,
and
come
up
together
---
and
the
room
was
so
quiet
,
and
Paul
was
so
observant
of
them
(
though
he
never
asked
of
anybody
what
they
said
)
,
that
he
even
knew
the
difference
in
the
sound
of
their
watches
.
<EOS>
But
his
interest
centred
in
Sir
Parker
Peps
,
who
always
took
his
seat
on
the
side
of
the
bed
.
<EOS>
For
Paul
had
heard
them
say
long
ago
,
that
that
gentleman
had
been
with
his
mama
when
she
clasped
Florence
in
her
arms
,
and
died
.
<EOS>
And
he
could
not
forget
it
,
now
.
<EOS>
He
liked
him
for
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
afraid
.
  
<EOS>
The
people
round
him
changed
as
unaccountably
as
on
that
first
night
at
Doctor
Blimber
's
---
except
Florence
;
Florence
never
changed
---
and
what
had
been
Sir
Parker
Peps
,
was
now
his
father
,
sitting
with
his
head
upon
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Old
Mrs
Pipchin
dozing
in
an
easy
chair
,
often
changed
to
Miss
Tox
,
or
his
aunt
;
and
Paul
was
quite
content
to
shut
his
eyes
again
,
and
see
what
happened
next
without
emotion
.
<EOS>
But
this
figure
with
its
head
upon
its
hand
returned
so
often
,
and
remained
so
long
,
and
sat
so
still
and
solemn
,
never
speaking
,
never
being
spoken
to
,
and
rarely
lifting
up
its
face
,
that
Paul
began
to
wonder
languidly
,
if
it
were
real
;
and
in
the
night
-
time
saw
it
sitting
there
,
with
fear
.
  
<EOS>
"
Floy
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
,
dearest
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
<EOS>
at
the
bottom
of
the
bed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
nothing
there
,
except
Papa
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
figure
lifted
up
its
head
,
and
rose
,
and
coming
to
the
beside
,
said
:
"
My
own
boy
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
know
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Paul
looked
it
in
the
face
,
and
thought
,
was
this
his
father
?
<EOS>
But
the
face
so
altered
to
his
thinking
,
thrilled
while
he
gazed
,
as
if
it
were
in
pain
;
and
before
he
could
reach
out
both
his
hands
to
take
it
between
them
,
and
draw
it
towards
him
,
the
figure
turned
away
quickly
from
the
little
bed
,
and
went
out
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
Paul
looked
at
Florence
with
a
fluttering
heart
,
but
he
knew
what
she
was
going
to
say
,
and
stopped
her
with
his
face
against
her
lips
.
<EOS>
The
next
time
he
observed
the
figure
sitting
at
the
bottom
of
the
bed
,
he
called
to
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
so
sorry
for
me
,
dear
Papa
!
<EOS>
Indeed
I
am
quite
happy
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
father
coming
and
bending
down
to
him
---
which
he
did
quickly
,
and
without
first
pausing
by
the
bedside
---
Paul
held
him
round
the
neck
,
and
repeated
those
words
to
him
several
times
,
and
very
earnestly
;
and
Paul
never
saw
him
in
his
room
again
at
any
time
,
whether
it
were
day
or
night
,
but
he
called
out
,
"
Do
n't
be
so
sorry
for
me
!
<EOS>
Indeed
I
am
quite
happy
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
was
the
beginning
of
his
always
saying
in
the
morning
that
he
was
a
great
deal
better
,
and
that
they
were
to
tell
his
father
so
.
  
<EOS>
How
many
times
the
golden
water
danced
upon
the
wall
;
how
many
nights
the
dark
,
dark
river
rolled
towards
the
sea
in
spite
of
him
;
Paul
never
counted
,
never
sought
to
know
.
<EOS>
If
their
kindness
,
or
his
sense
of
it
,
could
have
increased
,
they
were
more
kind
,
and
he
more
grateful
every
day
;
but
whether
they
were
many
days
or
few
,
appeared
of
little
moment
now
,
to
the
gentle
boy
.
   
<EOS>
One
night
he
had
been
thinking
of
his
mother
,
and
her
picture
in
the
drawing
-
room
down
stairs
,
and
thought
she
must
have
loved
sweet
Florence
better
than
his
father
did
,
to
have
held
her
in
her
arms
when
she
felt
that
she
was
dying
---
for
even
he
,
her
brother
,
who
had
such
dear
love
for
her
,
could
have
no
greater
wish
than
that
.
<EOS>
The
train
of
thought
suggested
to
him
to
inquire
if
he
had
ever
seen
his
mother
;
for
he
could
not
remember
whether
they
had
told
him
,
yes
or
no
,
the
river
running
very
fast
,
and
confusing
his
mind
.
  
<EOS>
"
Floy
,
did
I
ever
see
mama
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
darling
,
why
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Did
I
ever
see
any
kind
face
,
like
mama
's
,
looking
at
me
when
I
was
a
baby
,
Floy
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
asked
,
incredulously
,
as
if
he
had
some
vision
of
a
face
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
dear
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whose
,
Floy
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
old
nurse
's
.
<EOS>
Often
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
where
is
my
old
nurse
?
"
said
Paul
.
<EOS>
"
Is
she
dead
too
?
<EOS>
Floy
,
are
we
all
dead
,
except
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
hurry
in
the
room
,
for
an
instant
---
longer
,
perhaps
;
but
it
seemed
no
more
---
then
all
was
still
again
;
and
Florence
,
with
her
face
quite
colourless
,
but
smiling
,
held
his
head
upon
her
arm
.
<EOS>
Her
arm
trembled
very
much
.
  
<EOS>
"
Show
me
that
old
nurse
,
Floy
,
if
you
please
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
not
here
,
darling
.
<EOS>
She
shall
come
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Floy
!
"
  
<EOS>
Paul
closed
his
eyes
with
those
words
,
and
fell
asleep
.
<EOS>
When
he
awoke
,
the
sun
was
high
,
and
the
broad
day
was
clear
and
warm
.
<EOS>
He
lay
a
little
,
looking
at
the
windows
,
which
were
open
,
and
the
curtains
rustling
in
the
air
,
and
waving
to
and
fro
:
then
he
said
,
"
Floy
,
is
it
to
-
morrow
?
<EOS>
Is
she
come
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Some
one
seemed
to
go
in
quest
of
her
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
Susan
.
<EOS>
Paul
thought
he
heard
her
telling
him
when
he
had
closed
his
eyes
again
,
that
she
would
soon
be
back
;
but
he
did
not
open
them
to
see
.
<EOS>
She
kept
her
word
---
perhaps
she
had
never
been
away
---
but
the
next
thing
that
happened
was
a
noise
of
footsteps
on
the
stairs
,
and
then
Paul
woke
---
woke
mind
and
body
---
and
sat
upright
in
his
bed
.
<EOS>
He
saw
them
now
about
him
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
grey
mist
before
them
,
as
there
had
been
sometimes
in
the
night
.
<EOS>
He
knew
them
every
one
,
and
called
them
by
their
names
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
who
is
this
?
<EOS>
Is
this
my
old
nurse
?
"
said
the
child
,
regarding
with
a
radiant
smile
,
a
figure
coming
in
.
  
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
.
<EOS>
No
other
stranger
would
have
shed
those
tears
at
sight
of
him
,
and
called
him
her
dear
boy
,
her
pretty
boy
,
her
own
poor
blighted
child
.
<EOS>
No
other
woman
would
have
stooped
down
by
his
bed
,
and
taken
up
his
wasted
hand
,
and
put
it
to
her
lips
and
breast
,
as
one
who
had
some
right
to
fondle
it
.
<EOS>
No
other
woman
would
have
so
forgotten
everybody
there
but
him
and
Floy
,
and
been
so
full
of
tenderness
and
pity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Floy
!
<EOS>
this
is
a
kind
good
face
!
"
said
Paul
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
see
again
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
go
away
,
old
nurse
!
<EOS>
Stay
here
.
"
  
<EOS>
His
senses
were
all
quickened
,
and
he
heard
a
name
he
knew
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
was
that
,
who
said
"
Walter
"
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
looking
round
.
<EOS>
"
Some
one
said
Walter
.
<EOS>
Is
he
here
?
<EOS>
I
should
like
to
see
him
very
much
.
"
  
<EOS>
Nobody
replied
directly
;
but
his
father
soon
said
to
Susan
,
"
Call
him
back
,
then
:
let
him
come
up
!
"
<EOS>
After
a
short
pause
of
expectation
,
during
which
he
looked
with
smiling
interest
and
wonder
,
on
his
nurse
,
and
saw
that
she
had
not
forgotten
Floy
,
Walter
was
brought
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
His
open
face
and
manner
,
and
his
cheerful
eyes
,
had
always
made
him
a
favourite
with
Paul
;
and
when
Paul
saw
him
,
he
stretched
out
his
hand
,
and
said
"
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
my
child
!
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
,
hurrying
to
his
bed
's
head
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
good
-
bye
?
"
  
<EOS>
For
an
instant
,
Paul
looked
at
her
with
the
wistful
face
with
which
he
had
so
often
gazed
upon
her
in
his
corner
by
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
yes
,
"
he
said
placidly
,
"
<EOS>
good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
Walter
dear
,
good
-
bye
!
"
<EOS>
---
turning
his
head
to
where
he
stood
,
and
putting
out
his
hand
again
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Papa
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
felt
his
father
's
breath
upon
his
check
,
before
the
words
had
parted
from
his
lips
.
  
<EOS>
"
Remember
Walter
,
dear
papa
,
"
he
whispered
,
looking
in
his
face
.
"
<EOS>
Remember
Walter
.
<EOS>
I
was
fond
of
Walter
!
"
<EOS>
The
feeble
hand
waved
in
the
air
,
as
if
it
cried
"
good
-
bye!'to
Walter
once
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
lay
me
down
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
,
Floy
,
come
close
to
me
,
and
let
me
see
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
Sister
and
brother
wound
their
arms
around
each
other
,
and
the
golden
light
came
streaming
in
,
and
fell
upon
them
,
locked
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
fast
the
river
runs
,
between
its
green
banks
and
the
rushes
,
Floy
!
<EOS>
But
it
's
very
near
the
sea
.
<EOS>
I
hear
the
waves!They
always
said
so
!
"
  
<EOS>
Presently
he
told
her
that
the
motion
of
the
boat
upon
the
stream
was
lulling
him
to
rest
.
<EOS>
How
green
the
banks
were
now
,
how
bright
the
flowers
growing
on
them
,
and
how
tall
the
rushes
!
<EOS>
Now
the
boat
was
out
at
sea
,
but
gliding
smoothly
on
.
<EOS>
And
now
there
was
a
shore
before
him
.
<EOS>
Who
stood
on
the
bank
!
---
   
<EOS>
He
put
his
hands
together
,
as
he
had
been
used
to
do
at
his
prayers
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
remove
his
arms
to
do
it
;
but
they
saw
him
fold
them
<EOS>
so
,
behind
her
neck
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mama
is
like
you
,
Floy
.
<EOS>
I
know
her
by
the
face
!
<EOS>
But
tell
them
that
the
print
upon
the
stairs
at
school
is
not
divine
enough
.
<EOS>
The
light
about
the
head
is
shining
on
me
as
I
go
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
golden
ripple
on
the
wall
came
back
again
,
and
nothing
else
stirred
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
The
old
,
old
fashion
!
<EOS>
The
fashion
that
came
in
with
our
first
garments
,
and
will
last
unchanged
until
our
race
has
run
its
course
,
and
the
wide
firmament
is
rolled
up
like
a
scroll
.
<EOS>
The
old
,
old
fashion
---
Death
!
  
<EOS>
Oh
thank
God
,
all
who
see
it
,
for
that
older
fashion
yet
,
of
Immortality
!
<EOS>
And
look
upon
us
,
angels
of
young
children
,
with
regards
not
quite
estranged
,
when
the
swift
river
bears
us
to
the
ocean
!
   
<EOS>
Chapter
17
.
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
does
a
little
Business
for
the
Young
People
 
CAPTAIN
CUTTLE
,
in
the
exercise
of
that
surprising
talent
for
deep
-
laid
and
unfathomable
scheming
,
with
which
(
as
is
not
unusual
in
men
of
transparent
simplicity
)
<EOS>
he
sincerely
believed
himself
to
be
endowed
by
nature
,
had
gone
to
Mr
Dombey
's
house
on
the
eventful
Sunday
,
winking
all
the
way
as
a
vent
for
his
superfluous
sagacity
,
and
had
presented
himself
in
the
full
lustre
of
the
ankle
-
jacks
before
the
eyes
of
Towlinson
.
<EOS>
Hearing
from
that
individual
,
to
his
great
concern
,
of
the
impending
calamity
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
in
his
delicacy
,
sheered
off
again
confounded
;
merely
handing
in
the
nosegay
as
a
small
mark
of
his
solicitude
,
and
leaving
his
respectful
compliments
for
the
family
in
general
,
which
he
accompanied
with
an
expression
of
his
hope
that
they
would
lay
their
heads
well
to
the
wind
under
existing
circumstances
,
and
a
friendly
intimation
that
he
would
"
look
up
again
'
to
-
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
compliments
were
never
heard
of
any
more
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
nosegay
,
after
lying
in
the
hall
all
night
,
was
swept
into
the
dust
-
bin
next
morning
;
and
the
Captain
's
sly
arrangement
,
involved
in
one
catastrophe
with
greater
hopes
and
loftier
designs
,
was
crushed
to
pieces
.
<EOS>
So
when
an
avalanche
bears
down
a
mountain
-
forest
,
twigs
and
bushes
suffer
with
the
trees
,
and
all
perish
together
.
  
<EOS>
When
Walter
returned
home
on
the
Sunday
evening
from
his
long
walk
,
and
its
memorable
close
,
he
was
too
much
occupied
at
first
by
the
tidings
he
had
to
give
them
,
and
by
the
emotions
naturally
awakened
in
his
breast
by
the
scene
through
which
he
had
passed
,
to
observe
either
that
his
uncle
was
evidently
unacquainted
with
the
intelligence
the
Captain
had
undertaken
to
impart
,
or
that
the
Captain
made
signals
with
his
hook
,
warning
him
to
avoid
the
subject
.
<EOS>
Not
that
the
Captain
's
signals
were
calculated
to
have
proved
very
comprehensible
,
however
attentively
observed
;
for
,
like
those
Chinese
sages
who
are
said
in
their
conferences
to
write
certain
learned
words
in
the
air
that
are
wholly
impossible
of
pronunciation
,
the
Captain
made
such
waves
and
flourishes
as
nobody
without
a
previous
knowledge
of
his
mystery
,
would
have
been
at
all
likely
to
understand
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
however
,
becoming
cognisant
of
what
had
happened
,
relinquished
these
attempts
,
as
he
perceived
the
slender
chance
that
now
existed
of
his
being
able
to
obtain
a
little
easy
chat
with
Mr
Dombey
before
the
period
of
Walter
's
departure
.
<EOS>
But
in
admitting
to
himself
,
with
a
disappointed
and
crestfallen
countenance
,
that
Sol
Gills
must
be
told
,
and
that
Walter
must
go
---
taking
the
case
for
the
present
as
he
found
it
,
and
not
having
it
enlightened
or
improved
beforehand
by
the
knowing
management
of
a
friend
---
the
Captain
still
felt
an
unabated
confidence
that
he
,
Ned
Cuttle
,
was
the
man
for
Mr
Dombey
;
and
that
,
to
set
Walter
's
fortunes
quite
square
,
nothing
was
wanted
but
that
they
two
should
come
together
.
<EOS>
For
the
Captain
never
could
forget
how
well
he
and
Mr
Dombey
had
got
on
at
Brighton
;
with
what
nicety
each
of
them
had
put
in
a
word
when
it
was
wanted
;
how
exactly
they
had
taken
one
another
's
measure
;
nor
how
Ned
Cuttle
had
pointed
out
that
resource
in
the
first
extremity
,
and
had
brought
the
interview
to
the
desired
termination
.
<EOS>
On
all
these
grounds
the
Captain
soothed
himself
with
thinking
that
though
Ned
Cuttle
was
forced
by
the
pressure
of
events
to
"
stand
by
"
almost
useless
for
the
present
,
Ned
would
fetch
up
with
a
wet
sail
in
good
time
,
and
carry
all
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
Under
the
influence
of
this
good
-
natured
delusion
,
Captain
Cuttle
even
went
to
far
as
to
revolve
in
his
own
bosom
,
while
he
sat
looking
at
Walter
and
listening
with
a
tear
on
his
shirt
-
collar
to
what
he
related
,
whether
it
might
not
be
at
once
genteel
and
politic
to
give
Mr
Dombey
a
verbal
invitation
,
whenever
they
should
meet
,
to
come
and
cut
his
mutton
in
Brig
Place
on
some
day
of
his
own
naming
,
and
enter
on
the
question
of
his
young
friend
's
prospects
over
a
social
glass
.
<EOS>
But
the
uncertain
temper
of
Mrs
MacStinger
,
and
the
possibility
of
her
setting
up
her
rest
in
the
passage
during
such
an
entertainment
,
and
there
delivering
some
homily
of
an
uncomplimentary
nature
,
operated
as
a
check
on
the
Captain
's
hospitable
thoughts
,
and
rendered
him
timid
of
giving
them
encouragement
.
  
<EOS>
One
fact
was
quite
clear
to
the
Captain
,
as
Walter
,
sitting
thoughtfully
over
his
untasted
dinner
,
dwelt
on
all
that
had
happened
;
namely
,
that
however
Walter
's
modesty
might
stand
in
the
way
of
his
perceiving
it
himself
,
he
was
as
one
might
say
,
a
member
of
Mrs
Dombey
's
family
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
,
in
his
own
person
,
connected
with
the
incident
he
so
pathetically
described
;
he
had
been
by
name
remembered
and
commended
in
close
association
with
it
;
and
his
fortunes
must
have
a
particular
interest
in
his
employer
's
eyes
.
<EOS>
If
the
Captain
had
any
lurking
doubt
whatever
of
his
own
conclusions
,
he
had
not
the
least
doubt
that
they
were
good
conclusions
for
the
peace
of
mind
of
the
Instrument
-
maker
.
<EOS>
Therefore
he
availed
himself
of
so
favourable
a
movement
for
breaking
the
West
Indian
Intelligence
to
his
old
friend
,
as
a
piece
of
extraordinary
preferment
;
declaring
that
for
his
part
he
would
freely
give
a
hundred
thousand
pounds
(
if
he
had
it
)
for
Walter
's
gain
in
the
long
-
run
,
and
that
he
had
no
doubt
such
an
investment
would
yield
a
handsome
premium
.
  
<EOS>
Solomon
Gills
was
at
first
stunned
by
the
communication
,
which
fell
upon
the
little
back
-
parlour
like
a
thunderbolt
,
and
tore
up
the
hearth
savagely
.
<EOS>
But
the
Captain
flashed
such
golden
prospects
before
his
dim
sight
:
hinted
so
mysteriously
at
Whittingtonian
consequences
;
laid
such
emphasis
on
what
Walter
had
just
now
told
them
:
and
appealed
to
it
so
confidently
as
a
corroboration
of
his
predictions
,
and
a
great
advance
towards
the
realisation
of
the
romantic
legend
of
Lovely
Peg
:
that
he
bewildered
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
Walter
,
for
his
part
,
feigned
to
be
so
full
of
hope
and
ardour
,
and
so
sure
of
coming
home
again
soon
,
and
backed
up
the
Captain
with
such
expressive
shakings
of
his
head
and
rubbings
of
his
hands
,
that
Solomon
,
looking
first
at
him
and
then
at
Captain
Cuttle
,
began
to
think
he
ought
to
be
transported
with
joy
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
'm
behind
the
time
<EOS>
,
you
understand
,
"
he
observed
in

,
passing

hand
nervously
down

whole

buttons
on

,
and
then
up
again
,
as

were
beads
and
he
were
telling
them
twice
over
:
"
and
I
would
rather
have
my
dear
boy
here
.
<EOS>
It
's
an
old
-
fashioned
notion
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
He
was
always
fond
of
the
sea
.
<EOS>
He
's
"
---
and
he
looked
wistfully
at
Walter
<EOS>
---
"
he
's
glad
to
go
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Uncle
Sol
!
"
<EOS>
cried

,
quickly
,
"
if
you
say
that
,
I
wo
n't
go
.
<EOS>
No
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
I
wo

.
<EOS>
If

uncle
thinks
I
could

,

Islands

the
West
Indies
<EOS>
,
that
's
enough
.
<EOS>
I
'm
a
fixture
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Wal'r
,
my
lad
,
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Steady
!
<EOS>
Sol
Gills
,
take
an

of
your
nevy
.
"
  
<EOS>
Following
with
his

the
majestic
action
of
the
Captain
's

,
the
old
man
looked
at

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
certain
craft
,
"
said

Captain
,
with

,
"
a
-

.
<EOS>
What
name
is
wrote
upon
that

?
<EOS>
Is

The
Gay
?
<EOS>
or
,
"
said

Captain
,

as

,
observe

,
"

The
Gills
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ned
,
"
said

old
man
,
drawing

to

,
and

through

,
"
I
know
.
<EOS>
I
know
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
know
that
Wally
considers
me
more
than

always
.
<EOS>
That
's
in
my
mind
.
<EOS>
When

is

go
,
I
mean

is
.
<EOS>
Eh
?
<EOS>
look
you
,
Ned
,
and
you

,
Wally
,
my
dear
,
this
is
new

;
and
I
'm

my
being
behind

,
and
poor
,
is
at
the

.
<EOS>
Is

really
good

for
him
,
do

,

?
"
said
the
old

,

from

.
"
<EOS>
Really

?
<EOS>
Is

?
<EOS>
I

that
advances
Wally
,
but
I
wo

Wally

,

anything
from
me
.
<EOS>
You
,
Ned
Cuttle
!
"

,

,
to

;
"

?
<EOS>

,

Cuttle
.
<EOS>
Is

behind
?
<EOS>
Ought

to

?
<EOS>
How

know
it
first
,
and
why
?
<EOS>
"
  
As

was
a
contest
of
affection
and
self
-

,
Walter
struck
in
with
infinite
effect
,
to
the
Captain
's
relief
;
and
between
them
they
tolerably
reconciled
old
Sol
Gills
,
by
continued
talking
,
to
the
project
;
or
rather
so
confused
him
,
that
nothing
,
not
even

pain
of

,
was

to

.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
much

to
balance

;
for
on
the
very

,
Walter
received
from
Mr

the
Manager
,

for

and

,
together

that
the
Son
and
Heir
would
said
in
a

,
or

or
two

.
<EOS>
In
the

of

:
which
Walter
purposely
enhanced
as
much
as

:
the
old
man
lost
what
little
self
-

he
ever
had
;
and
so
the
time
of
departure
drew
on
rapidly
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
who
did
not
fail
to
make
himself
acquainted
with
all
that
passed
,
through
inquiries
of
Walter
from
day
to
day
,
found
the
time
still
tending
on
towards
his
going
away
,
without
any
occasion
offering
itself
,
or
seeming
likely
to
offer
itself
,
for
a
better
understanding
of
his
position
.
<EOS>
It
was
after
much
consideration
of
this

,
and
much

over
such
an
unfortunate
combination
of
circumstances
,
that
a
bright
idea
occurred
to
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
Suppose
he
made
a
call
on
Mr
Carker
,
and
tried
to
find
out
from
him
how
the
land
really
lay
!
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
liked
this
idea
very
much
.
<EOS>
It
came
upon
him
in
a
moment
of
inspiration
,
as
he
was
smoking
an
early

in
Brig

after

;
and
it
was
worthy
of
the
tobacco
.
<EOS>
It
would
quiet
his
conscience
,
which
was
an
honest
one
,
and
was
made
a
little
uneasy
by
what
Walter
had
confided
to
him
,
and
what
Sol
Gills
had
said
;
and
it
would
be
a
deep
,
shrewd
act
of
friendship
.
<EOS>
He
would
sound
Mr
Carker
carefully
,
and
say
much
or
little
,
just
as
he
read
that
gentleman
's
character
,
and
discovered
that
they
got
on
well
together
or
the
reverse
.
  
<EOS>
Accordingly
without
the
fear
of
Walter
before
his
eyes
(
who
he
knew
was
at
home
packing
)
,
Captain
Cuttle
again
assumed
his
ankle
-

and
mourning

,
and
issued
forth
on
this
second
expedition
.
<EOS>
He
purchased
no
propitiatory
nosegay
on
the
present
occasion
,
as
he
was
going
to
a
place
of
business
;
but
he
put
a
small
sunflower
in
his
button
-
hole
to
give
himself
an
agreeable
relish
of
the
country
;
and
with
this
,
and
the
knobby
stick
,
and
the
glazed
hat
,
bore
down
upon
the
offices
of
Dombey
and
Son
.
  
<EOS>
After
taking
a
glass
of
warm
rum
-
and
-
water
at
a
tavern
close
by
,
to
collect

thoughts
,
the
Captain
made
a
rush
down
the
court
,
lest
its
good
effects
should
evaporate
,
and
appeared
suddenly
to
Mr
Perch
.
  
<EOS>
"
Matey
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
in
persuasive

.
<EOS>
"
One
of
your
Governors
is
named
Carker
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Perch
admitted
it
;
but
gave
him
to
understand
,
as
in
official
duty
bound
,
that
all
his
Governors
were
engaged
,
and
never
expected
to
be
disengaged
any

.
  
<EOS>
"
Look'ee
here
,
mate
,
"
said
the
Captain
in
his
ear
;
"
my
name
's
Cap'en
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
would
have
hooked
Perch
gently
to
him
,
but
Mr
Perch
eluded
the
attempt
;
not
so
much
in

,
as
in

to
Mrs

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Saying

,

's

,

,

(

,
for

)
,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

's

was

,

a

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Cap'en
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
"

,

,

;

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Perch
,

,

,
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

,

"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

liked

with

;

.
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
began

Captain
,

,

"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Walter
Gay
?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
Gay
it

,
"

,
"
right
!
"
<EOS>
The
Captain
's

Mr

's

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm

's
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
"

,
"

---
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
"

,

than

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
resumed

Captain
,
"
I

of
his

.
<EOS>
I
waited
upon
him
down

Sussex

,

,
when
---
in

,

wanted
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Captain
nodded

in

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

,
I

?
"
  
"
I

,
"

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To

!
"

.
"
<EOS>
Right
again
!
<EOS>
you
had
.
<EOS>
Now

've
took

of
coming

---
"
  
"
Wo
n't
you

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
"
returned

Captain
,

.
<EOS>
"
A

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Wo
n't

take

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

,
"
said

Manager
,
standing
,

from
the

of

,

-

,
and

Captain

.
<EOS>
"
You
have
taken
the
liberty
,
you
were

say
---
though

's

---
"
  
"
Thank'ee

,

,
"
returned

Captain
:
"
of

,

.
<EOS>
Sol
Gills
,
his
uncle
,
is
a
man

science
,
and
in
science
he
may
be
considered
a

;
but
he
ai
n't
what
I
should
altogether

a
able
seaman
---
not
a
man

practice
.
<EOS>
Wal'r
is
as
trim

lad
as

;
but
he
's

little
down

,
and

.
<EOS>
Now
what
I

,
"
said

,

,

"

,

,

,
'

wore

,

,

.
<EOS>
---
Is

right

,
and

out'ard

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

Cuttle
?
"
returned
Carker
,
gathering

skirts
and
settling

position
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
practical
man
;
what
do
you
think
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
acuteness
and
significance
of
the
Captain
's
eye
as
he
cocked
it
in
reply
,
no
words
short
of
those
unutterable
Chinese
words
before
referred
to
could
describe
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
Captain
,
unspeakably
encouraged
,
"
what
do
you
say
?
<EOS>
Am
I
right
or
wrong
?
"
  
<EOS>
So
much
had
the
Captain
expressed
in
his
eye
,
emboldened
and
incited
by
Mr
Carker
's
smiling
urbanity
,
that
he
felt
himself
in
as
fair
a
condition
to
put
the
question
,
as
if

expressed

with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Right
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
"
I
have
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Out'ard
bound
with
fair
weather
,
then
,
I
say
,
"
cried
Captain
Cuttle
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
smiled
assent
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wind
right
astarn
,
and
plenty
of
it
,
"
pursued
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
smiled
assent
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
!
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
greatly
relieved
and
pleased
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
know'd
<EOS>
how
she
headed
,
well
enough
;
I
told
Wal'r
so
.
<EOS>
Thank'ee
,
thank'ee
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Gay
has
brilliant

,
"
observed
Mr
Carker
,
stretching

mouth
wider
yet
:
"
all

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All

world
and
his

,

the

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
At

word
"
wife
"
(
which

uttered
without
design
)
,

Captain
stopped
,

,
and

,
gave

a

,
and
looked

at
his
always

friend
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'd
bet
a
gill
of
old
Jamaica
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
eyeing

attentively
,
"
that
I
know
what
you
're

at
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
took
his
cue
,
and
smiled
the
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
goes
no
farther
?
"
said
the
Captain
,
making
a
poke
at
the
door
with
the

to
assure

that
it
was
shut
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
an
inch
,
"
said

Carker
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
thinking
of
a
capital
F
perhaps
?
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
did
n't

.
  
<EOS>
"
Anything
about
a
L
,
"
said

Captain
,
"
or
a
O
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
still

.
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
right
again
?
"
inquired
the
Captain
in
a

,
with
the
scarlet
circle
on

swelling
in

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
,
in
reply
,
still
smiling
,
and
now
nodding
assent
,
Captain
Cuttle
rose
and
squeezed
him
by
the
hand
,
assuring
him
,
warmly
,
that
they
were
on
the
same
tack
,
and
that
as
for
him
(
Cuttle
)
he
had
laid
his
course
that
way
all
along
.
"
<EOS>
He
know'd
<EOS>
her
first
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
with
all
the

and
gravity
that
the
subject
demanded
,
"
in
an
uncommon

---
you
remember
his
finding
her
in
the
street
when
she
was
a'most
<EOS>
a
babby
<EOS>
---
he
has
liked
her
ever
since
,
and
she
him
,
as
much
as
two
such
youngsters

.
<EOS>
We
've
always
said
,
Sol
Gills
and

,
that
they
was
cut
out
for
each

.
"
  
<EOS>
A

,

,

,

-
head
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's

general
in
-

that

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Wind

sets

,

.
<EOS>

present

"
other

!
"

.

.

"

"

.
<EOS>

!
steady
!
<EOS>

:

.
<EOS>
Ai

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

.
"
<EOS>
Nevy

<EOS>

Gills!Wal'r
!
<EOS>
Wal'r
,

<EOS>

"
who

's

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

's

with

,
on

,

and
eyed

when

of

and

;
his
great
blue

heaving
with
the

of
such
a

,
and
his
nose
in
a
state
of
violent
inflammation
from

same
cause
.
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
right
?
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
said

,

,
for

,

odd

,
as

,
"
your

Walter
Gay
are

.
<EOS>
I

that

speak

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Honour
!
"
interposed

Captain
.
<EOS>
"
Not
a
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
him
or

?
"

Manager
.
  
<EOS>
Captain

frowned

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

---

,

"

,
"
with

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee

,

,
"
said

Captain
,
listening

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

in

,
that
's

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

,
"
why

.
<EOS>
There

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

,
"
Time
enough
.
"
<EOS>
Not

,
but

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

---

's

's

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
To

,
"

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

Wal'r
's
going

,

,
in

's

,
and

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

I
know

,
"

,
"
there
's
no

,
and
<EOS>
my

's
at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
still
blandly
assenting
in
the
same

,
Captain
Cuttle
was
strongly
confirmed
in
his
opinion
that
he
was
one
of

,
and
that
even

Dombey
might
improve

.
<EOS>
With
great

,
therefore
,
the
Captain
once
again
extended
his
enormous
hand
(
not
unlike
an
old
block
in
colour
)
,
and
gave
him
a
grip
that
left
upon
his
smoother
flesh
a
proof
impression
of
the
chinks
and
crevices
with
which
the
Captain
's
palm
was
liberally

.
  
<EOS>
"
Farewell
!
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
I
an't
a
man
of
many
words
,
but
I
take
it
very
kind
of
you
to
be
so
friendly
,
and
above
-
board
.
<EOS>
You
'll

if
I
've

at
all
intruding
,

?
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"
returned

.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
.
<EOS>
My
berth
an't
very
roomy
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
turning

again
,
"
<EOS>
but
it
's

snug
;
and
if
you
was

near
Brig
Place
,

,

---

?
<EOS>
---
and
would

,
without

was
said
by
the
person
at
the
door
,
I
should
be
proud
to
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
hospitable
invitation
,
the
Captain
said
"
Good
day
!
"
and
walked
out
and
shut
the
door
;
leaving
Mr
Carker
still
reclining
against
the
chimney
-
piece
.
<EOS>
In
whose
sly
look
and
watchful
manner
;
in
whose
false
mouth
,
stretched
but
not
laughing
;
in
whose
spotless
cravat
and
very
whiskers
;
even
in
whose
silent
passing
of
his
soft
hand
over
his
white
linen
and
his
smooth
face
;
there
was
something
desperately
cat
-
like
.
  
<EOS>
The
unconscious
Captain
walked
out
in
a
state
of
self
-
glorification
that
imparted
quite
a
new
cut
to
the
broad
blue
suit
.
<EOS>
"
Stand
by
,
Ned
!
"
said
the
Captain
to
himself
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
done
a
little
business
for
the
youngsters
to
-
day
,
my
lad
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
his
exultation
,
and
in
his
familiarity
,
present
and
prospective
,
with
the
House
,
the
Captain
,
when
he
reached
the
outer
office
,
could
not
refrain
from
rallying
Mr
Perch
a
little
,
and
asking
him
whether
he
thought
everybody
was
still
engaged
.
<EOS>
But
not
to
be
bitter
on
a
man
who
had
done
his
duty
,
the
Captain
whispered
in
his
ear
,
that
if
he
felt
disposed
for
a
glass
of
rum
-
and
-
water
,
and
would
follow
,
he
would
be
happy
to
bestow
the
same
upon
him
.
  
<EOS>
Before
leaving
the
premises
,
the
Captain
,
somewhat
to
the
astonishment
of
the
clerks
,
looked
round
from
a
central
point
of
view
,
and
took
a
general
survey
of
the
office
as
part
and
parcel
of
a
project
in
which
his
young
friend
was
nearly
interested
.
<EOS>
The
strong
-
room
excited
his
especial
admiration
;
but
,
that
he
might
not
appear
too
particular
,
he
limited
himself
to
an
approving
glance
,
and
,
with
a
graceful
recognition
of
the
clerks
as
a
body
,
that
was
full
of
politeness
and
patronage
,
passed
out
into
the
court
.
<EOS>
Being
promptly
joined
by
Mr
Perch
,
he
conveyed
that
gentleman
to
the
tavern
,
and
fulfilled
his
pledge
---
hastily
,
for
Perch
's
time
was
precious
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
give
you
for
a
toast
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
"
Wal'r
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
submitted
Mr
Perch
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
!
"
repeated
the
Captain
,
in
a
voice
of
thunder
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Perch
,
who
seemed
to
remember
having
heard
in
infancy
that
there
was
once
a
poet
of
that
name
,
made
no
objection
;
but
he
was
much
astonished
at
the
Captain
's
coming
into
the
City
to
propose
to
poet
;
indeed
,
if
he
had
proposed
to
put
a
poet
's
statue
up
---
say
Shakespeare
's
for
example
---
in
a
civic
thoroughfare
,
he
could
hardly
have
done
a
greater
outrage
to
Mr
Perch
's
experience
.
<EOS>
On
the
whole
,
he
was
such
a
mysterious
and
incomprehensible
character
,
that
Mr
Perch
decided
not
to
mention
him
to
Mrs
Perch
at
all
,
in
case
of
giving
rise
to
any
disagreeable
consequences
.
  
<EOS>
Mysterious
and
incomprehensible
,
the
Captain
,
with
that
lively
sense
upon
him
of
having
done
a
little
business
for
the
youngsters
,
remained
all
day
,
even
to
his
most
intimate
friends
;
and
but
that
Walter
attributed
his
winks
and
grins
,
and
other
such
pantomimic
reliefs
of
himself
,
to
his
satisfaction
in
the
success
of
their
innocent
deception
upon
old
Sol
Gills
,
he
would
assuredly
have
betrayed
himself
before
night
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
however
,
he
kept
his
own
secret
;
and
went
home
late
from
the
Instrument
-
maker
's
house
,
wearing
the
glazed
hat
so
much
on
one
side
,
and
carrying
such
a
beaming
expression
in
his
eyes
,
that
Mrs
MacStinger
(
who
might
have
been
brought
up
at
Doctor
Blimber
's
,
she
was
such
a
Roman
matron
)
fortified
herself
,
at
the
first
glimpse
of
him
,
behind
the
open
street
door
,
and
refused
to
come
out
to
the
contemplation
of
her
blessed
infants
,
until
he
was
securely
lodged
in
his
own
room
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
18
.
<EOS>
Father
and
Daughter
 
THERE
is
a
hush
through
Mr
Dombey
's
house
.
<EOS>
Servants
gliding
up
and
downstairs
rustle
,
but
make
no
sound
of
footsteps
.
<EOS>
They
talk
together
constantly
,
and
sit
long
at
meals
,
making
much
of
their
meat
and
drink
,
and
enjoying
themselves
after
a
grim
unholy
fashion
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Wickam
,
with
her
eyes
suffused
with
tears
,
relates
melancholy
anecdotes
;
and
tells
them
how
she
always
said
at
Mrs
Pipchin
's
that
it
would
be
so
,
and
takes
more
table
-
ale
tan
usual
,
and
is
very
sorry
but
sociable
.
<EOS>
Cook
's
state
of
mind
is
similar
.
<EOS>
She
promises
a
little
fry
for
supper
,
and
struggles
about
equally
against
her
feelings
and
the
onions
.
<EOS>
Towlinson
begins
to
think
there
's
a
fate
in
it
,
and
wants
to
know
if
anybody
can
tell
him
of
any
good
that
ever
came
of
living
in
a
corner
house
.
<EOS>
It
seems
to
all
of
them
as
having
happened
a
long
time
ago
;
though
yet
the
child
lies
,
calm
and
beautiful
,
upon
his
little
bed
.
  
<EOS>
After
dark
there
come
some
visitors
---
noiseless
visitors
,
with
shoes
of
felt
---
who
have
been
there
before
;
and
with
them
comes
that
bed
of
rest
which
is
so
strange
a
one
for
infant
sleepers
.
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
the
bereaved
father
has
not
been
seen
even
by
this
attendant
;
for
he
sits
in
an
inner
corner
of
his
own
dark
room
when
any
one
is
there
,
and
never
seems
to
move
at
other
times
,
except
to
pace
it
to
and
fro
.
<EOS>
But
in
the
morning
it
is
whispered
among
the
household
that
he
was
heard
to
go
up
stairs
in
the
dead
night
,
and
that
he
stayed
there
---
in
the
room
---
until
the
sun
was
shining
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
offices
in
the
City
,
the
ground
-
glass
windows
are
made
more
dim
by
shutters
;
and
while
the
lighted
lamps
upon
the
desks
are
half
extinguished
by
the
day
that
wanders
in
,
the
day
is
half
extinguished
by
the
lamps
,
and
an
unusual
gloom
prevails
.
<EOS>
There
is
not
much
business
done
.
<EOS>
The
clerks
are
indisposed
to
work
;
and
they
make
assignations
to
eat
chops
in
the
afternoon
,
and
go
up
the
river
.
<EOS>
Perch
,
the
messenger
,
stays
long
upon
his
errands
;
and
finds
himself
in
bars
of
public
-
houses
,
invited
thither
by
friends
,
and
holding
forth
on
the
uncertainty
of
human
affairs
.
<EOS>
He
goes
home
to
Ball
's
Pond
earlier
in
the
evening
than
usual
,
and
treats
Mrs
Perch
to
a
veal
cutlet
and
scotch
ale
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
treats
no
one
;
neither
is
he
treated
;
but
alone
in
his
own
room
he
shows
his
teeth
all
day
;
and
it
would
seem
that
there
is
something
gone
from
Mr
Carker
's
path
---
some
obstacle
reremoved
---
which
clears
his
way
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
Now
the
rosy
children
living
opposite
to
Mr
Dombey
's
house
,
peep
from
their
nursery
windows
down
into
the
street
;
for
there
are
four
black
horses
at
his
door
,
with
feathers
on
their
heads
;
and
feathers
tremble
on
the
carriage
that
they
draw
;
and
these
,
and
an
array
of
men
with
scarves
and
staves
,
attract
a
crowd
.
<EOS>
The
juggler
who
was
going
to
twirl
the
basin
,
puts
his
loose
coat
on
again
over
his
fine
dress
;
and
his
trudging
wife
,
one
-
sided
with
her
heavy
baby
in
her
arms
,
loiters
to
see
the
company
come
out
.
<EOS>
But
closer
to
her
dingy
breast
she
presses
her
baby
,
when
the
burden
that
is
so
easily
carried
is
borne
forth
;
and
the
youngest
of
the
rosy
children
at
the
high
window
opposite
,
needs
no
restraining
hand
to
check
her
in
her
glee
,
when
,
pointing
with
her
dimpled
finger
,
she
looks
into
her
nurse
's
face
,
and
asks
"
What
's
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
And
now
,
among
the
knot
of
servants
dressed
in
mourning
,
and
the
weeping
women
,
Mr
Dombey
passes
through
the
hall
to
the
other
carriage
that
is
waiting
to
receive
him
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
"
brought
down
,
"
these
observes
think
,
by
sorrow
and
distress
of
mind
.
<EOS>
His
walk
is
as
erect
,
his
bearing
is
as
stiff
as
ever
it
has
been
.
<EOS>
He
hides
his
face
behind
no
handkerchief
,
and
looks
before
him
.
<EOS>
But
that
his
face
is
something
sunk
and
rigid
,
and
is
pale
,
it
bears
the
same
expression
as
of
old
.
<EOS>
He
takes
his
place
within
the
carriage
,
and
three
other
gentlemen
follow
.
<EOS>
Then
the
grand
funeral
moves
slowly
down
the
street
.
<EOS>
The
feathers
are
yet
nodding
in
the
distance
,
when
the
juggler
has
the
basin
spinning
on
a
cane
,
and
has
the
same
crowd
to
admire
it
.
<EOS>
But
the
juggler
's
wife
is
less
alert
than
usual
with
the
money
-
box
,
for
a
child
's
burial
<EOS>
has
set
her
thinking
that
perhaps
the
baby
underneath
her
shabby
shawl
may
not
grow

to

man
,

,
and
salmon

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
feathers
wind
their
gloomy
way
along
the
streets
,
and
come
within
the
sound
of
a
church
bell
.
<EOS>
In
this

church
,
the
pretty
boy
received
all
that
will

---
a

.
<EOS>
All

,

,

.
<EOS>
It
is
well
.
<EOS>
Their

where
Florence
in
her

---
oh
lonely
,
lonely

!
---
may
pass

.
  
<EOS>
The

over
,
and
the
clergyman
withdrawn
<EOS>
,

?
  
<EOS>
Some

,

"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

.
<EOS>

I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

There

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

;
"

;

"

Well
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
I

's
a

'
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
statuary

,

,

,
"
beloved

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"
son

"

"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
Of

.
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
<EOS>
When

,
who

,

,

first

---
shaded

.
<EOS>
Nor
do

see
it

.
<EOS>
He
alights
first
,
and
passes
immediately
into
his
own
room
.
<EOS>
The
other

(
who
are
only
Mr
Chick
,

)

,

.
<EOS>
And
what
the
face
is
,
in

:
or

are
:
what

is
,
what

:

.
  
<EOS>
The
chief

that
they
know
below

,
in
the

,
is
that
"
it
seems
like
Sunday
.
<EOS>
"
They
can
hardly
persuade
themselves
but
that
there
is
something
unbecoming
,
if

,
in
the

of
the
people
out

doors
,
who
pursue

ordinary

,
and

.
<EOS>
It
is
quite
a
novelty
to
have
the
blinds
up
,
and
the

open
:
and
they
make
themselves
dismally
comfortable
over
bottles
of
wine
,
which
are
freely
broached
as
on
a
festival
.
<EOS>
They
are
much
inclines
to
moralise
.
<EOS>
Mr
Towlinson
proposes
with
a

,
"
Amendment
to
us
all
"
for
which
,
as
Cook
says
with
another

,
"
There
's
room
enough
,
God
knows
.
<EOS>
"
In
the
evening
,
Mrs
Chick
and
Miss
Tox
take
to

again
.
<EOS>
In
the
evening
also
,
Mr
Towlinson
goes
out
to
take

air
,

by
the
housemaid
,
who
has
not

.
<EOS>
They
are
very
tender
to
each
other
at
dusky
street
-

,
and
Towlinson
has
visions
of
leading
an
altered
and
blameless
existence
as
a
serious
greengrocer
in
Oxford
Market
.
  
<EOS>
There
is
sounder
sleep
and
deeper

in
Mr
Dombey
's
house
to
-
night
,
than
there

been

many

.
<EOS>
The
morning
sun
awakens
the
old
household
,
settled
down
once
more
in
their

ways
.
<EOS>
The
rosy
children
opposite
run
past
with
hoops
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
splendid
wedding
in
the
church
.
<EOS>
The
juggler
's
wife
is
active
with
the
money
-
box
in
another
quarter
of
the
town
.
<EOS>
The
mason
sings
and

as
he
chips
out
P
-
A
-
U
-
L
in
the

before

.
  
<EOS>
And
can
it
be
that
in
a
world
so
full
and
busy
<EOS>
,
the
loss
of
one
weak
creature
makes
a
void
in
any
heart
,
so
wide
and
deep
that
nothing
but
the
width
and

of
vast
eternity
can
fill

!
<EOS>
Florence
,
in
her

,
might

,
"
Oh
my
brother
,
<EOS>
oh
my
dearly

!
<EOS>
Only

!
<EOS>
Could

less

shed

light

early

,
or
give
birth

the

is

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
child
,
"

Chick
,

,

---
"
  
<EOS>
"
Which

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
---

<EOS>
Goodness

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Misplaced

!
<EOS>
I

"

"

.
"
<EOS>
"
"
Very

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

,
<EOS>
my

"

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
Dear

!
<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

me
about
him!Is
he
quite
heartbroken
?
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
was
of
a
tender
nature
,
and
there
was
something
in
this
appeal
that
moved
her
very
much
.
<EOS>
Whether
she
saw
it
in
a
succession
,
on
the

of
the
neglected

,
to
the

so

---
or

that
sought

about
the
heart
that
had

,
and
that
could

such

,

the
earnest

spirit
which
,

long

,
and

,
and

---
<EOS>
whatever

,

.
<EOS>
For

forgot

of
Mrs
Chick
,
and
,
patting

hastily

,

suffered
the

to

,
without

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs

herself

had
so
long

so

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
But

her

---
which

,

one

thing
<EOS>
---

"
Florence
,

dear

,

is

;

is

.
<EOS>
I
believe

have

.
<EOS>
Still
,

,

and
that

I

Paul
!
"

---

"
Paul
!
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"
My

"

<EOS>

.

"

.

<EOS>
"

"

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs

approved

,

<EOS>
But
Miss
Tox
,
on

,
went
upstairs

;
and
tried

to

,
in

from
Susan
Nipper
.
<EOS>
For
Miss

,
in
her

,
disparaged

as

;
yet
her

seemed

---
there
was
little

to

.
  
<EOS>
And
was

no
one
nearer
and
dearer
than
Susan
,
to
uphold
the
striving

in

?
<EOS>
Was
there
no
other
neck
to
clasp
;
<EOS>
no
other
face
to
turn
to
?
<EOS>
no
one
else
to
say
a
soothing

to
such
deep

?
<EOS>
Was
Florence
so
alone
in
the
bleak
world
that
nothing
else
remained
to
her
?
<EOS>
Nothing
.
<EOS>
Stricken
motherless
and
brotherless
at
once
---
for
in

of
little
Paul
,
that
first
and

---
this

she

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
who
can

much
she
needed

at
first
!
  
<EOS>
At
first
,
when
the
house
subsided
into
its

,
and
they

all

,
except

,
and
her
father

up
in
his

,
Florence
could

,

,

,
and
know

:
nothing
but
the

of

.
<EOS>
This
commonly
ensued
upon
the
recognition
of
some
spot

very

associated
with
him
;
and
it
made
the
miserable
house
,
at
first
,
a

of
agony
.
  
<EOS>
But
it
is
not
in
the
nature
of
pure
love
to
burn
so

and
unkindly
long
.
<EOS>
The

that
in
its

has
the

of
earth
,
may
prey

the
breast
that
gives

;
but
the

is
as
gentle

,
as
when

on

the

,
and
showed

his
brother
,

and

.
<EOS>
The
image
conjured
up
,
there
soon
returned
the
placid

,

,
the
loving

,
the
quiet

and

;
and
Florence
,
though

,
wept
more

,
and
courted
the

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
very
long
before
the
golden
water
,
dancing

,
in
the
old

,
at
the
old

,
had
her
calm

fixed

as

.
<EOS>
It

before
that
room
again
knew
her
,
often
;
sitting

,

.
<EOS>
When

,

,

prayGOD
<EOS>
---

---
to
let

love

and
remember

.
  
<EOS>
It

,
in

the

so
wide

,
her

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

,
and
when

,

:

.
<EOS>
But

was

,
often
---
very

,
in

;
and
broken

still

keys
,
when

was

.
  
<EOS>
Thus
she
gained
heart
to
look
upon
the

with

had

busy
by
his
side

the
sea

;
and
thus

she
took

again
---
with

for

,
as

sentient

;
and
,

's

,
in

,
wore

.
  
<EOS>
Why
did
the
dark
eyes
turn
so
often
from
this
work
to
where
the
rosy
children
lived
?
<EOS>
They
were
not
immediately
suggestive
of
her
loss
;
for
they
were
all
girls
:
four
little
sisters
.
<EOS>
But
they
were
motherless
like
her
---
and
had
a
father
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
easy
to
know
when
he
had
gone
out
and
was
expected
home
,
for
the
elder
child
was
always
dressed
and
waiting
for
him
at
the
drawing
-
room
window
,
or
in
the
balcony
;
and
when
he
appeared
,
her
expectant
face
lighted
up
with
joy
,
while
the
others
at
the
high
window
,
and
always
on
the
watch
too
,
clapped
their
hands
,
and
drummed
them
on
the
sill
,
and
called
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
elder
child
would
come
down
to
the
hall
,
and
put
her
hand
in
his
,
and
lead
him
up
the
stairs
;
and
Florence
would
see
her
afterwards
sitting
by
his
side
,
or
on
his

,
or
hanging
coaxingly
about
his
neck
and
talking
to

:
and
though
they
were
always
gay
together
,
he
would
often
watch
her
face
as
if
he
thought
her
like
her
mother
that
was
dead
.
<EOS>
Florence
would
sometimes
look
no
more
at
this
,
and
bursting
into
tears
would
hide
behind
the
curtain
as
if
she
were
frightened
,
or
would
hurry
from
the
window
.
<EOS>
Yet
she
could
not
help
returning
;
and
her
work
would
soon
fall
unheeded
from
her
hands
again
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
house
that
had
been
empty
,
years
ago
,
It
had
remained
so
for
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
and
while
she
had
been
away
from
home
,
this
family
had
taken
it
;
and
it
was
repaired
and
newly

;
and
there
were
birds
and
flowers
about
it
;
and
it
looked
very
different
from
its
old
self
.
<EOS>
But
she
never
thought
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
The
children
and
their
father
were
all
in
all
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
had
dined
,
she
could
see
them
,
through
the
open
windows
,
go
down
with
their
governess
or
nurse
,
and
cluster
round
the
table
;
and
in
the
still
summer
weather
,
the
sound
of
their
childish
voices
and
clear
laughter
would
come
ringing
across
the
street
,
into
the
drooping
air
of
the
room
in
which
she
sat
.
<EOS>
Then
they
would
climb
and
clamber
up
stairs
with
him
,
and
romp
about
him
on
the
sofa
,
or
group
themselves
at
his
knee
,
a
very
nosegay
of
little
faces
,
while
he
seemed
to
tell
them
some
story
.
<EOS>
Or
they
would
come
running
out
into
the
balcony
;
and
then
Florence
would
hide
herself
quickly
,
lest
it
should
check
them
in
their
joy
,
to
see
her
in
her
black
dress
,
sitting
there
alone
.
  
<EOS>
The
elder
child
remained
with
her
father
when
the
rest
had
gone
away
,
and
made
his
tea
for
him
---
<EOS>
happy
little
housekeeper
<EOS>
she
was
then
!
<EOS>
---
and
sat
conversing
with
him
,
sometimes
at
the
window
,
sometimes
in
the
room
,
until
the
candles
came
.
<EOS>
He
made
her
his
companion
,
though
she
was
some
years
younger
than
Florence
;
and
she
could
be
as
staid
and
pleasantly
demure
,
with
her
little
book
or
work
-
box
,
as
a
woman
.
<EOS>
When
they
had
candles
,
Florence
from
her
own
dark
room
was
not
afraid
to
look
again
.
<EOS>
But
when
the
time
came
for
the
child
to
say
"
Good
night
,
papa
,
"
and
go
to
bed
,
Florence
would
sob
and
tremble
as
she
raised
her
face
to
him
,
and
could
look
no
more
.
  
<EOS>
Though
still
she
would
turn
,
again
and
again
,
before
going
to
bed
herself
,
from
the
simple
air
that
had
lulled
him
to
rest
so
often
,
long
ago
,
and
from
the
other
low
soft
broken
strain
of
music
,
back
to
that
house
.
<EOS>
But
that
she
ever
thought
of
it
,
or
watched
it
,
was
a
secret
which
she
kept
within
her
own
young
breast
.
  
<EOS>
And
did
that
breast
of
Florence
---
<EOS>
Florence
,
so
ingenuous
and
true
---
so
worthy
of
the
love
that
he
had
borne
her
,
and
had
whispered
in
his
last
faint
words
---
whose
guileless
heart
was
mirrored
in
the
beauty
of
her
face
,
and
breathed
in
every
accent
of
her
gentle
voice
---
did
that
young
breast
hold
any
other
secret
?
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
One
more
.
  
<EOS>
When
no
one
in
the
house
was
stirring
,
and
the
lights
were
all
extinguished
,
she
would
softly
leave
her
own
room
,
and
with
noiseless
feet
descend
the
staircase
,
and
approach
her
father
's
door
.
<EOS>
Against
it
,
scarcely
breathing
,
she
would
rest
her
face
and
head
,
and
press
her
lips
,
in
the
yearning
of
her
love
.
<EOS>
She
crouched
upon
the
cold
stone
floor
outside
it
,
every
night
,
to
listen
even
for
his
breath
;
and
in
her
one
absorbing
wish
to
be
allowed
to
show
him
some
affection
,
to
be
a
consolation
to
him
,
to
win
him
over
to
the
endurance
of
some
tenderness
from
her
,
his
solitary
child
,
she
would
have
knelt
down
at
his
feet
,
if
she
had
dared
,
in
humble
supplication
.
  
<EOS>
No
one
knew
it
.
<EOS>
No
one
thought
of
it
.
<EOS>
The
door
was
ever
closed
,
and
he
shut
up
within
.
<EOS>
He
went
out
once
or
twice
,
and
it
was
said
in
the
house
that
he
was
very
soon
going
on
his
country
journey
;
but
he
lived
in
those
rooms
,
and
lived
alone
,
and
never
saw
her
,
or
inquired
for
her
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
did
not
even
know
that
she
was
in
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
One
day
,
about
a
week
after
the
funeral
,
Florence
was
sitting
at
her
work
,
when
Susan
appeared
,
with
a
face
half
laughing
and
half
crying
to
announce
a
visitor
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
visitor
!
<EOS>
To
me
,
Susan
!
"
said
Florence
,
looking
up
in
astonishment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
it
is
a
wonder
,
ai
n't
it
now
,
Miss
Floy
?
"
said
Susan
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
wish
you
had
a
many
visitors
<EOS>
,
I
do
,
indeed
,
for
you
'd
be
all
the
better
for
it
,
and
it
's
my
opinion
that
the
sooner
you
and
me
goes
even
to
them
<EOS>
old
Skettleses
,
Miss
,
the
better
for
both
<EOS>
,
I
may
not
wish
to
live
in
crowds
,
Miss
Floy
,
but
still
I
'm
not
a
oyster
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
To
do
Miss
Nipper
justice
,
she
spoke
more
for
her
young
mistress
than
herself
;
and
her
face
showed
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
visitor
,
Susan
,
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
Susan
,
with
an
hysterical
explosion
that
was
as
much
a
laugh
as
a
sob
,
and
as
much
a
sob
as
a
laugh
,
answered
,
  
"
Mr
Toots
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
smile
that
appeared
on
Florence
's
face
passed
from
it
in
a
moment
,
and
her
eyes
filled
with
tears
.
<EOS>
But
at
any
rate
it
was
a
smile
,
and
that
gave
great
satisfaction
to
Miss
Nipper
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
own
feelings
exactly
,
Miss
Floy
,
"
said
Susan
,
putting
her
apron
to
her
eyes
,
and
shaking
her
head
.
<EOS>
"
Immediately
I
see
that
Innocent
in
the
Hall
,
Miss
Floy
<EOS>
,
I
burst
out
laughing
first
,
and
then
I
choked
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
Nipper
involuntarily
proceeded
to
do
the
like
again
on
the
spot
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Mr
Toots
,
who
had
come
up
stairs
after
her
,
all
unconscious
of
the
effect
he
produced
,
announced
himself
with
his
knuckles
on
the
door
,
and
walked
in
very
briskly
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
d'ye
do
,
Miss
Dombey
?
"
said
Mr
Toots
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
very
well
,
I
thank
you
;
how
are
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
---
than
whom
there
were
few
better
fellows
in
the
world
,
though
there
may
have
been
one
or
two
brighter
spirits
---
had
laboriously
invented
this
long
burst
of
discourse
with
the
view
of
relieving
the
feelings
both
of
Florence
and
himself
.
<EOS>
But
finding
that
he
had
run
through
his
property
,
as
it
were
,
in
an
injudicious
manner
,
by
squandering
the
whole
before
taking
a
chair
,
or
before
Florence
had
uttered
a
word
,
or
before
he
had
well
got
in
at
the
door
,
he
deemed
it
advisable
to
begin
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
d'ye
do
,
Miss
Dombey
?
"
said
Mr
Toots
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
very
well
,
I
thank
you
;
how
are
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
gave
him
her
hand
,
and
said
she
was
very
well
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
very
well
indeed
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
taking
a
chair
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
indeed
,
I
am
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
remember
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
after
reflecting
a
little
,
"
that
I
was
ever
better
,
thank
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
kind
of
you
to
come
,
"
said
Florence
,
taking
up
her
work
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
to
see
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
responded
with
a
chuckle
.
<EOS>
Thinking
that
might
be
too
lively
,
he
corrected
it
with
a
sigh
.
<EOS>
Thinking
that
might
be
too
melancholy
,
he
corrected
it
with
a
chuckle
.
<EOS>
Not
thoroughly
pleasing
himself
with
either
mode
of
reply
,
he
breathed
hard
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
very
kind
to
my
dear
brother
,
"
said
Florence
,
obeying
her
own
natural
impulse
to
relieve
him
by
saying
so
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
often
talked
to
me
about
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
of
no
consequence
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Warm
,
ai
n't
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
beautiful
weather
,
"
replied
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
agrees
with
me
!
"
said
Mr
Toots
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
I
ever
was
so
well
as
I
find
myself
at
present
,
I
'm
obliged
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
stating
this
curious
and
unexpected
fact
,
Mr
Toots
fell
into
a
deep
well
of
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
left
Dr
Blimber
's
,
I
think
?
"
said
Florence
,
trying
to
help
him
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
hope
so
,
"
returned
Mr
Toots
.
<EOS>
And
tumbled
in
again
.
  
<EOS>
He
remained
at
the
bottom
,
apparently
drowned
,
for
at
least
ten
minutes
.
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
that
period
,
he
suddenly
floated
,
and
said
,
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Good
morning
,
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Florence
,
rising
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
though
.
<EOS>
No
,
not
just
at
present
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
sitting
down
again
,
most
unexpectedly
.
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
---
I
say
,
Miss
Dombey
!
"
  
"
Do
n't
be
afraid
to
speak
to
me
,
"
said
Florence
,
with
a
quiet
smile
,
"
I
should
be
very
glad
if
you
would
talk
about
my
brother
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
,
though
?
"
retorted
Mr
Toots
,
with
sympathy
in
every
fibre
of
his
otherwise
expressionless
face
.
"
Poor
Dombey
!
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
I
never
thought
that
Burgess
and
Co.
---
fashionable
tailors
(
but
very
dear
)
,
that
we
used
to
talk
about
---
would
make
this
suit
of
clothes
for
such
a
purpose
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
was
dressed
in
mourning
.
"
<EOS>
Poor
Dombey
!
<EOS>
I
say
!
<EOS>
Miss
Dombey
!
"
<EOS>
blubbered
Toots
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
friend
he
took
to
very
much
at
last
.
<EOS>
I
thought
you
'd
like
to
have
him
,
perhaps
,
as
a
sort
of
