.
<EOS>
You
remember
his
remembering
Diogenes
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
!
<EOS>
oh
yes
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
Dombey
!
<EOS>
So
do
I
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
,
seeing
Florence
in
tears
,
had
great
difficulty
in
getting
beyond
this
point
,
and
had
nearly
tumbled
into
the
well
again
.
<EOS>
But
a
chuckle
saved
him
on
the
brink
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
he
proceeded
,
"
Miss
Dombey
!
<EOS>
I
could
have
had
him
stolen
for
ten
shillings
,
if
they
had
n't
given
him
up
:
<EOS>
and
I
would
:
<EOS>
but
they
were
glad
to
get
rid
of
him
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
If
you
'd
like
to
have
him
,
he
's
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
I
brought
him
on
purpose
for
you
.
<EOS>
He
ai
n't
a
lady
's
dog
,
you
know
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
but
you
wo
n't
mind
that
,
will
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In
fact
Diogenes
was
at
that
moment
,
as
they
presently
ascertained
from
looking
down
into
the
street
,
staring
through
the
window
of
a
hackney
cabriolet
,
into
which
,
for
conveyance
to
that
spot
,
he
had
been
ensnared
,
on
a
false
pretence
of
rats
among
the
straw
.
<EOS>
Sooth
to
say
,
he
was
as
unlike
a
lady
's
dog
as
might
be
;
and
in
his
gruff
anxiety
to
get
out
,
presented
an
appearance
sufficiently
unpromising
,
as
he
gave
short
yelps
out
of
one
side
of
his
mouth
,
and
overbalancing
himself
by
the
intensity
of
every
one
of
those
efforts
,
tumbled
down
into
the
straw
,
and
then
sprung
panting
up
again
,
putting
out
his
tongue
,
as
if
he
had
come
express
to
a
Dispensary
to
be
examined
for
his
health
.
  
<EOS>
But
though
Diogenes
was
as
ridiculous
a
dog
as
one
would
meet
with
on
a
summer
's
day
;
a
blundering
,
ill
-
favoured
,
clumsy
,
bullet
-
headed
dog
,
continually
acting
on
a
wrong
idea
that
there
was
an
enemy
in
the
neighbourhood
,
whom
it
was
meritorious
to
bark
at
;
<EOS>
and
though
he
was
far
from
good
-
tempered
,
and
certainly
was
not
clever
,
and
had
hair
all
over
his
eyes
,
and
a
comic
nose
,
and
an
inconsistent
tail
,
and
a
gruff
voice
;
he
was
dearer
to
Florence
,
in
virtue
of
that
parting
remembrance
of
him
,
and
that
request
that
he
might
be
taken
care
of
,
than
the
most
valuable
and
beautiful
of
his
kind
.
<EOS>
So
dear
,
indeed
,
was
this
same
ugly
Diogenes
,
and
so
welcome
to
her
,
that
she
took
the
jewelled
hand
of
Mr
Toots
and
kissed
it
in
her
gratitude
.
<EOS>
And
when
Diogenes
,
released
,
came
tearing
up
the
stairs
and
bouncing
into
the
room
(
such
a
business
as
there
was
first
,
to
get
him
out
of
the
cabriolet
!
)
,
dived
under
all
the
furniture
,
and
wound
a
long
iron
chain
,
that
dangled
from
his
neck
,
round
legs
of
chairs
and
tables
,
and
then
tugged
at
it
until
his
eyes
became
unnaturally
visible
,
in
consequence
of
their
nearly
starting
out
of
his
head
;
and
when
he
growled
at
Mr
Toots
,
who
affected
familiarity
;
and
went
pell
-
mell
at
Towlinson
,
morally
convinced
that
he
was
the
enemy
whom
he
had
barked
at
round
the
corner
all
his
life
and
had
never
seen
yet
;
Florence
was
as
pleased
with
him
as
if
he
had
been
a
miracle
of
discretion
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
was
so
overjoyed
by
the
success
of
his
present
,
and
was
so
delighted
to
see
Florence
bending
down
over
Diogenes
,
smoothing
his
coarse
back
with
her
little
delicate
hand
---
<EOS>
Diogenes
graciously
allowing
it
from
the
first
moment
of
their
acquaintance
---
that
he
felt
it
difficult
to
take
leave
,
and
would
,
no
doubt
,
have
been
a
much
longer
time
in
making
up
his
mind
to
do
so
,
if
he
had
not
been
assisted
by
Diogenes
himself
,
who
suddenly
took
it
into
his
head
to
bay
Mr
Toots
,
and
to
make
short
runs
at
him
with
his
mouth
open
.
<EOS>
Not
exactly
seeing
his
way
to
the
end
of
these
demonstrations
,
and
sensible
that
they
placed
the
pantaloons
constructed
by
the
art
of
Burgess
and
Co.
in
jeopardy
,
Mr
Toots
,
with
chuckles
,
lapsed
out
at
the
door
:
by
which
,
after
looking
in
again
two
or
three
times
,
without
any
object
at
all
,
and
being
on
each
occasion
greeted
with
a
fresh
run
from
Diogenes
,
he
finally
took
himself
off
and
got
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
then
,
Di
!
<EOS>
Dear
Di
!
<EOS>
Make
friends
with
your
new
mistress
.
<EOS>
Let
us
love
each
other
,
Di
!
"
said
Florence
fondling
his
shaggy
head
.
<EOS>
And
Di
,
the
rough
and
gruff
,
as
if
his
hairy
hide
were
pervious
to
the
tear
that
dropped
upon
it
,
and
his
dog
's
heart
melted
as
it
fell
,
put
his
nose
up
to
her
face
,
and
swore
fidelity
.
  
<EOS>
Diogenes
<EOS>
the
man
did
not
speak
plainer
to
Alexander
the
Great
than
Diogenes
<EOS>
the
dog
spoke
to
Florence
.
<EOS>
He
subscribed
to
the
offer
of
his
little
mistress
cheerfully
,
and
devoted
himself
to
her
service
.
<EOS>
A
banquet
was
immediately
provided
for
him
in
a
corner
;
and
when
he
had
eaten
and
drunk
his
fill
,
he
went
to
the
window
where
Florence
was
sitting
,
looking
on
,
rose
up
on
his
hind
legs
,
with
his
awkward
fore
paws
on
her
shoulders
,
licked
her
face
and
hands
,
nestled
his
great
head
against
her
heart
,
and
wagged
his
tail
till
he
was
tired
.
<EOS>
Finally
,
Diogenes
coiled
himself
up
at
her
feet
and
went
to
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
Although
Miss
Nipper
was
nervous
in
regard
of
dogs
,
and
felt
it
necessary
to
come
into
the
room
with
her
skirts
carefully
collected
about
her
,
as
if
she
were
crossing
a
brook
on
stepping
-
stones
;
also
to
utter
little
screams
and
stand
up
on
chairs
when
Diogenes
stretched
himself
:
she
was
in
her
own
manner
affected
by
the
kindness
of
Mr
Toots
,
and
could
not
see
Florence
so
alive
to
the
attachment
and
society
of
this
rude
friend
of
little
Paul
's
,
without
some
mental
comments
thereupon
that
brought
the
water
to
her
eyes
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
as
a
part
of
her
reflections
,
may
have
been
,
in
the
association
of
ideas
,
connected
with
the
dog
;
but
,
at
any
rate
,
after
observing
Diogenes
and
his
mistress
all
the
evening
,
and
after
exerting
herself
with
much
good
-
will
to
provide
Diogenes
a
bed
in
an
ante
-
chamber
outside
his
mistress
's
door
,
she
said
hurriedly
to
Florence
,
before
leaving
her
for
the
night
:
  
"
Your
Pa
's
a
going
off
,
Miss
Floy
,
to
-
morrow
morning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
morning
,
Susan
?
"
  
"
Yes
,
Miss
;
that
's
the
orders
.
<EOS>
Early
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
"
asked
Florence
,
without
looking
at
her
,
"
where
Papa
is
going
,
Susan
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
exactly
,
Miss.
<EOS>
He
's
going
to
meet
that
precious
Major
first
,
and
I
must
say
if
I
was
acquainted
with
any
Major
myself
(
which
Heavens
forbid
)
,
it
should
n't
be
a
blue
one
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
Susan
!
"
urged
Florence
gently
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Miss
Floy
,
"
returned
Miss
Nipper
,
who
was
full
of
burning
indignation
,
and
minded
her
stops
even
less
than
usual
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
help
it
,
blue
he
is
,
and
while
I
was
a
Christian
,
although
humble
,
I
would
have
natural
-
coloured
friends
,
or
none
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
appeared
from
what
she
added
and
had
gleaned
downstairs
,
that
Mrs
Chick
had
proposed
the
Major
for
Mr
Dombey
's
companion
,
and
that
Mr
Dombey
,
after
some
hesitation
,
had
invited
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Talk
of
him
being
a
change
,
indeed
!
"
observed
Miss
Nipper
to
herself
with
boundless
contempt
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
's
a
change
give
me
a
constancy
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Good
night
,
Susan
,
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
my
darling
dear
Miss
Floy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Her
tone
of
commiseration
smote
the
chord
so
often
roughly
touched
,
but
never
listened
to
while
she
or
any
one
looked
on
.
<EOS>
Florence
left
alone
,
laid
her
head
upon
her
hand
,
and
pressing
the
other
over
her
swelling
heart
,
held
free
communication
with
her
sorrows
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
wet
night
;
and
the
melancholy
rain
fell
pattering
and
dropping
with
a
wearied
sound
.
<EOS>
A
sluggish
wind
was
blowing
,
and
went
moaning
round
the
house
,
as
if
it
were
in
pain
or
grief
.
<EOS>
A
shrill
noise
quivered
through
the
trees
.
<EOS>
While
she
sat
weeping
,
it
grew
late
,
and
dreary
midnight
tolled
out
from
the
steeples
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
was
little
more
than
a
child
in
years
---
not
yet
fourteen
---
and
the
loneliness
and
gloom
of
such
an
hour
in
the
great
house
where
Death
had
lately
made
its
own
tremendous
devastation
,
might
have
set
an
older
fancy
brooding
on
vague
terrors
.
<EOS>
But
her
innocent
imagination
was
too
full
of
one
theme
to
admit
them
.
<EOS>
Nothing
wandered
in
her
thoughts
but
love
---
a
wandering
love
,
indeed
,
and
cast
away
---
but
turning
always
to
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
in
the
dropping
of
the
rain
,
the
moaning
of
the
wind
,
the
shuddering
of
the
trees
,
the
striking
of
the
solemn
clocks
,
that
shook
this
one
thought
,
or
diminished
its
interest
.
<EOS>
Her
recollections
of
the
dear
dead
boy
---
and
they
were
never
absent
---
were
itself
;
the
same
thing
.
<EOS>
And
oh
,
to
be
shut
out
:
to
be
so
lost
:
never
to
have
looked
into
her
father
's
face
or
touched
him
since
that
hour
!
  
<EOS>
She
could
not
go
to
bed
,
poor
child
,
and
never
had
gone
yet
,
since
then
,
without
making
her
nightly
pilgrimage
to
his
door
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
a
strange
sad
sight
,
to
see
her
now
,
stealing
lightly
down
the
stairs
through
the
thick
gloom
,
and
stopping
at
it
with
a
beating
heart
,
and
blinded
eyes
,
and
hair
that
fell
down
loosely
and
unthought
of
;
and
touching
it
outside
with
her
wet
cheek
.
<EOS>
But
the
night
covered
it
,
and
no
one
knew
.
  
<EOS>
The
moment
that
she
touched
the
door
on
this
night
,
Florence
found
that
it
was
open
.
<EOS>
For
the
first
time
it
stood
open
,
though
by
but
a
hair's
-
breadth
:
and
there
was
a
light
within
.
<EOS>
The
first
impulse
of
the
timid
child
---
and
she
yielded
to
it
---
was
to
retire
swiftly
.
<EOS>
Her
next
,
to
go
back
,
and
to
enter
;
and
this
second
impulse
held
her
in
irresolution
on
the
stair
-
case
.
  
<EOS>
In
its
standing
open
,
even
by
so
much
as
that
chink
,
there
seemed
to
be
hope
.
<EOS>
There
was
encouragement
in
seeing
a
ray
of
light
from
within
,
stealing
through
the
dark
stern
door
-
way
,
and
falling
in
a
thread
upon
the
marble
floor
.
<EOS>
She
turned
back
,
hardly
knowing
what
she
did
,
but
urged
on
by
the
love
within
her
,
and
the
trial
they
had
undergone
together
,
but
not
shared
:
and
with
her
hands
a
little
raised
and
trembling
,
glided
in
.
  
<EOS>
Her
father
sat
at
his
old
table
in
the
middle
room
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
arranging
some
papers
,
and
destroying
others
,
and
the
latter
lay
in
fragile
ruins
before
him
.
<EOS>
The
rain
dripped
heavily
upon
the
glass
panes
in
the
outer
room
,
where
he
had
so
often
watched
poor
Paul
,
a
baby
;
and
the
low
complainings
of
the
wind
were
heard
without
.
  
<EOS>
But
not
by
him
.
<EOS>
He
sat
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
table
,
so
immersed
in
thought
,
that
a
far
heavier
tread
than
the
light
foot
of
his
child
could
make
,
might
have
failed
to
rouse
him
.
<EOS>
His
face
was
turned
towards
her
.
<EOS>
By
the
waning
lamp
,
and
at
the
haggard
hour
,
it
looked
worn
and
dejected
;
and
in
the
utter
loneliness
surrounding
him
,
there
was
an
appeal
to
Florence
that
struck
home
.
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
!
<EOS>
Papa
!
<EOS>
speak
to
me
,
dear
Papa
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
started
at
her
voice
,
and
leaped
up
from
his
seat
.
<EOS>
She
was
close
before
him
,
with
extended
arms
,
but
he
fell
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
come
here
?
<EOS>
What
has
frightened
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
If
anything
had
frightened
her
,
it
was
the
face
he
turned
upon
her
.
<EOS>
The
glowing
love
within
the
breast
of
his
young
daughter
froze
before
it
,
and
she
stood
and
looked
at
him
as
if
stricken
into
stone
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
not
one
touch
of
tenderness
or
pity
in
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
not
one
gleam
of
interest
,
parental
recognition
,
or
relenting
in
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
change
in
it
,
but
not
of
that
kind
.
<EOS>
The
old
indifference
and
cold
constraint
had
given
place
to
something
:
what
,
she
never
thought
and
did
not
dare
to
think
,
and
yet
she
felt
it
in
its
force
,
and
knew
it
well
without
a
name
:
that
as
it
looked
upon
her
,
seemed
to
cast
a
shadow
on
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
Did
he
see
before
him
the
successful
rival
of
his
son
,
in
health
and
life
?
<EOS>
Did
he
look
upon
his
own
successful
rival
of
his
son
,
in
that
son
's
affection
?
<EOS>
Did
a
mad
jealousy
and
withered
pride
,
poison
sweet
remembrances
that
should
have
endeared
and
made
her
precious
to
him
?
<EOS>
Could
it
be
possible
that
it
was
gall
to
him
to
look
upon
her
in
her
beauty
and
her
promise
:
thinking
of
his
infant
boy
!
  
<EOS>
Florence
had
no
such
thoughts
.
<EOS>
But
love
is
quick
to
know
when
it
is
spurned
and
hopeless
:
and
hope
died
out
of
hers
,
as
she
stood
looking
in
her
father
's
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ask
you
,
Florence
,
are
you
frightened
?
<EOS>
Is
there
anything
the
matter
,
that
you
come
here
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
came
,
Papa
---
"
  
"
Against
my
wishes
.
<EOS>
Why
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
saw
he
knew
why
:
it
was
written
broadly
on
his
face
:
and
dropped
her
head
upon
her
hands
with
one
prolonged
low
cry
.
  
<EOS>
Let
him
remember
it
in
that
room
,
years
to
come
.
<EOS>
It
has
faded
from
the
air
,
before
he
breaks
the
silence
.
<EOS>
It
may
pass
as
quickly
from
his
brain
,
as
he
believes
,
but
it
is
there
.
<EOS>
Let
him
remember
it
in
that
room
,
years
to
come
!
  
<EOS>
He
took
her
by
the
arm
.
<EOS>
His
hand
was
cold
,
and
loose
,
and
scarcely
closed
upon
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
tired
,
I
dare
say
,
"
he
said
,
taking
up
the
light
,
and
leading
her
towards
the
door
,
"
and
want
rest
.
<EOS>
We
all
want
rest
.
<EOS>
Go
,
Florence
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
dreaming
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
dream
she
had
had
,
was
over
then
,
God
help
her
!
<EOS>
and
she
felt
that
it
could
never
more
come
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
remain
here
to
light
you
up
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
whole
house
is
yours
above
there
,
"
said
her
father
,
slowly
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
its
mistress
now
.
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Still
covering
her
face
,
she
sobbed
,
and
answered
"
Good
night
,
dear
papa
,
"
and
silently
ascended
.
<EOS>
Once
she
looked
back
as
if
she
would
have
returned
to
him
,
but
for
fear
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
momentary
thought
,
too
hopeless
to
encourage
;
and
her
father
stood
there
with
the
light
---
hard
,
unresponsive
,
motionless
---
until
the
fluttering
dress
of
his
fair
child
was
lost
in
the
darkness
.
  
<EOS>
Let
him
remember
it
in
that
room
,
years
to
come
.
<EOS>
The
rain
that
falls
upon
the
roof
:
the
wind
that
mourns
outside
the
door
:
may
have
foreknowledge
in
their
melancholy
sound
.
<EOS>
Let
him
remember
it
in
that
room
,
years
to
come
!
  
<EOS>
The
last
time
he
had
watched
her
,
from
the
same
place
,
winding
up
those
stairs
,
she
had
had
her
brother
in
her
arms
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
move
his
heart
towards
her
now
,
it
steeled
it
:
but
he
went
into
his
room
,
and
locked
his
door
,
and
sat
down
in
his
chair
,
and
cried
for
his
lost
boy
.
  
<EOS>
Diogenes
was
broad
awake
upon
his
post
,
and
waiting
for
his
little
mistress
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Di
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
dear
Di
!
<EOS>
Love
me
for
his
sake
!
"
  
<EOS>
Diogenes
already
loved
her
for
her
own
,
and
did
n't
care
how
much
he
showed
it
.
<EOS>
So
he
made
himself
vastly
ridiculous
by
performing
a
variety
of
uncouth
bounces
in
the
ante
-
chamber
,
and
concluded
,
when
poor
Florence
was
at
last
asleep
,
and
dreaming
of
the
rosy
children
opposite
,
by
scratching
open
her
bedroom
door
:
rolling
up
his
bed
into
a
pillow
:
lying
down
on
the
boards
,
at
the
full
length
of
his
tether
,
with
his
head
towards
her
:
and
looking
lazily
at
her
,
upside
down
,
out
of
the
tops
of
his
eyes
,
until
from
winking
and
winking
he
fell
asleep
himself
,
and
dreamed
,
with
gruff
barks
,
of
his
enemy
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
19
.
<EOS>
Walter
goes
away
 
THE
Wooden
Midshipman
at
the
Instrument
-
maker
's
door
,
like
the
hard
-
hearted
little
midshipman
he
was
,
remained
supremely
indifferent
to
Walter
's
going
away
,
even
when
the
very
last
day
of
his
sojourn
in
the
back
parlour
was
on
the
decline
.
<EOS>
With
his
quadrant
at
his
round
black
knob
of
an
eye
,
and
his
figure
in
its
old
attitude
of
indomitable
alacrity
,
the
midshipman
displayed
his
elfin
small
-
clothes
to
the
best
advantage
,
and
,
absorbed
in
scientific
pursuits
,
had
no
sympathy
with
worldly
concerns
.
<EOS>
He
was
so
far
the
creature
of
circumstances
,
that
a
dry
day
covered
him
with
dust
,
and
a
misty
day
peppered
him
with
little
bits
of
soot
,
and
a
wet
day
brightened
up
his
tarnished
uniform
for
the
moment
,
and
a
very
hot
day
blistered
him
;
but
otherwise
he
was
a
callous
,
obdurate
,
conceited
midshipman
,
intent
on
his
own
discoveries
,
and
caring
as
little
for
what
went
on
about
him
,
terrestrially
,
as
Archimedes
at
the
taking
of
Syracuse
.
  
<EOS>
Such
a
midshipman
he
seemed
to
be
,
at
least
,
in
the
then
position
of
domestic
affairs
.
<EOS>
Walter
eyed
him
kindly
many
a
time
in
passing
in
and
out
;
and
poor
old
Sol
,
when
Walter
was
not
there
,
would
come
and
lean
against
the
doorpost
,
resting
his
weary
wig
as
near
the
shoe
-
buckles
of
the
guardian
genius
of
his
trade
and
shop
as
he
could
.
<EOS>
But
no
fierce
idol
with
a
mouth
from
ear
to
ear
,
and
a
murderous
visage
made
of
parrot
's
feathers
,
was
ever
more
indifferent
to
the
appeals
of
its
savage
votaries
,
than
was
the
midshipman
to
these
marks
of
attachment
.
  
<EOS>
Walter
's
heart
felt
heavy
as
he
looked
round
his
old
bedroom
,
up
among
the
parapets
and
chimney
-
pots
,
and
thought
that
one
more
night
already
darkening
would
close
his
acquaintance
with
it
,
perhaps
for
ever
.
<EOS>
Dismantled
of
his
little
stock
of
books
and
pictures
,
it
looked
coldly
and
reproachfully
on
him
for
his
desertion
,
and
had
already
a
foreshadowing
upon
it
of
its
coming
strangeness
.
<EOS>
"
A
few
hours
more
,
"
thought
Walter
,
"
and
no
dream
I
ever
had
here
when
I
was
a
schoolboy
will
be
so
little
mine
as
this
old
room
.
<EOS>
The
dream
may
come
back
in
my
sleep
,
and
I
may
return
waking
to
this
place
,
it
may
be
:
but
the
dream
at
least
will
serve
no
other
master
,
and
the
room
may
have
a
score
,
and
every
one
of
them
may
change
,
neglect
,
misuse
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
his
uncle
was
not
to
be
left
alone
in
the
little
back
parlour
,
where
he
was
then
sitting
by
himself
;
for
Captain
Cuttle
,
considerate
in
his
roughness
,
stayed
away
against
his
will
,
purposely
that
they
should
have
some
talk
together
unobserved
:
<EOS>
so
Walter
,
newly
returned
home
from
his
last
day
's
bustle
,
descended
briskly
,
to
bear
him
company
.
  
<EOS>
"
Uncle
,
"
he
said
gaily
,
laying
his
hand
upon
the
old
man
's
shoulder
,
"
what
shall
I
send
you
home
from
Barbados
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Hope
,
my
dear
Wally
.
<EOS>
Hope
that
we
shall
meet
again
,
on
this
side
of
the
grave
.
<EOS>
Send
me
as
much
of
that
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
will
,
Uncle
<EOS>
:
I
have
enough
and
to
spare
,
and
I
'll
not
be
chary
of
it
!
<EOS>
And
as
to
lively
turtles
,
and
limes
for
Captain
Cuttle
's
punch
,
and
preserves
for
you
on
Sundays
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
,
why
I
'll
send
you
ship
-
loads
,
Uncle
:
when
I
'm
rich
enough
.
"
  
<EOS>
Old
Sol
wiped
his
spectacles
,
and
faintly
smiled
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
Uncle
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Walter
,
merrily
,
and
clapping
him
half
a
dozen
times
more
upon
the
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
You
cheer
up
me
!
<EOS>
I
'll
cheer
up
you
!
<EOS>
We
'll
be
as
gay
as
larks
to
-
morrow
morning
,
Uncle
,
and
we
'll
fly
as
high
!
<EOS>
As
to
my
anticipations
,
they
are
singing
out
of
sight
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wally
,
my
dear
boy
,
"
returned
the
old
man
,
I
'll
do
my
best
,
I
'll
do
my
best
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
your
best
,
Uncle
,
"
said
Walter
,
with
his
pleasant
laugh
,
"
is
the
best
best
that
I
know
.
<EOS>
You
'll
not
forget
what
you
're
to
send
me
,
Uncle
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Wally
,
no
,
"
replied
the
old
man
;
"
everything
I
hear
about
Miss
Dombey
,
now
that
she
is
left
alone
,
poor
lamb
,
I
'll
write
.
<EOS>
I
fear
it
wo
n't
be
much
though
,
Wally
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
Uncle
,
"
said
Walter
,
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
,
"
I
have
just
been
up
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
ay
?
<EOS>
"
murmured
the
old
man
,
raising
his
eyebrows
,
and
his
spectacles
with
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
to
see
her
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
though
I
could
have
seen
her
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
if
I
had
asked
,
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
being
out
of
town
:
but
to
say
a
parting
word
to
Susan
.
<EOS>
I
thought
I
might
venture
to
do
that
,
you
know
,
under
the
circumstances
,
and
remembering
when
I
saw
Miss
Dombey
last
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
boy
,
yes
,
"
replied
his
Uncle
,
rousing
himself
from
a
temporary
abstraction
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
saw
her
,
"
pursued
Walter
,
"
<EOS>
Susan
,
I
mean
:
and
I
told
her
I
was
off
and
away
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
And
I
said
,
Uncle
,
that
you
had
always
had
an
interest
in
Miss
Dombey
since
that
night
when
she
was
here
,
and
always
wished
her
well
and
happy
,
and
always
would
be
proud
and
glad
to
serve
her
in
the
least
<EOS>
:
I
thought
I
might
say
that
,
you
know
,
under
the
circumstances
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
boy
,
yes
,
"
replied
his
Uncle
,
in
the
tone
as
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
added
,
"
pursued
Walter
,
"
that
if
she
---
Susan
,
I
mean
---
could
ever
let
you
know
,
either
through
herself
,
or
Mrs
Richards
,
or
anybody
else
who
might
be
coming
this
way
,
that
Miss
Dombey
was
well
and
happy
,
you
would
take
it
very
kindly
,
and
would
write
so
much
to
me
,
and
I
should
take
it
very
kindly
too
.
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
,
Uncle
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
I
scarcely
slept
all
last
night
through
thinking
of
doing
this
;
and
could
not
make
up
my
kind
when
I
was
out
,
whether
to
do
it
or
not
;
and
yet
I
am
sure
it
is
the
true
feeling
of
my
heart
,
and
I
should
have
been
quite
miserable
afterwards
if
I
had
not
relieved
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
honest
voice
and
manner
corroborated
what
he
said
,
and
quite
established
its
ingenuousness
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
,
if
you
ever
see
her
,
Uncle
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
I
mean
Miss
Dombey
now
---
and
perhaps
you
may
,
who
knows
!
<EOS>
---
tell
her
how
much
I
felt
for
her
;
how
much
I
used
to
think
of
her
when
I
was
here
;
how
I
spoke
of
her
,
with
the
tears
in
my
eyes
,
uncle
,
on
this
last
night
before
I
went
away
.
<EOS>
Tell
her
that
I
said
I
never
could
forget
her
gentle
manner
,
or
her
beautiful
face
,
or
her
sweet
kind
disposition
that
was
better
than
all
.
<EOS>
And
as
I
did
n't
take
them
from
a
woman
's
feet
,
or
a
young
lady
's
:
only
a
little
innocent
child
's
,
"
said
Walter
:
<EOS>
"
tell
her
,
if
you
do
n't
mind
,
Uncle
,
that
I
kept
those
shoes
---
she
'll
remember
how
often
they
fell
off
,
that
night
---
and
took
them
away
with
me
as
a
remembrance
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
at
that
very
moment
going
out
at
the
door
in
one
of
Walter
's
trunks
.
<EOS>
A
porter
carrying
off
his
baggage
on
a
truck
for
shipment
at
the
docks
on
board
the
Son
and
Heir
,
had
got
possession
of
them
;
and
wheeled
them
away
under
the
very
eye
of
the
insensible
Midshipman
before
their
owner
had
well
finished
speaking
.
  
<EOS>
But
that
ancient
mariner
might
have
been
excused
his
insensibility
to
the
treasure
as
it
rolled
away
.
<EOS>
For
,
under
his
eye
at
the
same
moment
,
accurately
within
his
range
of
observation
,
coming
full
into
the
sphere
of
his
startled
and
intensely
wide
-
awake
look
-
out
,
were
Florence
and
Susan
Nipper
:
Florence
looking
up
into
his
face
half
timidly
,
and
receiving
the
whole
shock
of
his
wooden
ogling
!
  
<EOS>
More
than
this
,
they
passed
into
the
shop
,
and
passed
in
at
the
parlour
door
before
they
were
observed
by
anybody
but
the
Midshipman
.
<EOS>
And
Walter
,
having
his
back
to
the
door
,
would
have
known
nothing
of
their
apparition
even
then
,
but
for
seeing
his
uncle
spring
out
of
his
own
chair
,
and
nearly
tumble
over
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Uncle
!
"
exclaimed
Walter
.
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
  
<EOS>
Old
Solomon
replied
,
"
Miss
Dombey
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Walter
,
looking
round
and
starting
up
in
his
turn
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
!
"
  
Why
,
it
was
so
possible
and
so
actual
,
that
,
while
the
words
were
on
his
lips
,
Florence
hurried
past
him
;
took
Uncle
Sol
's
snuff
-
coloured
lappels
,
one
in
each
hand
;
kissed
him
on
the
cheek
;
and
turning
,
gave
her
hand
to
Walter
with
a
simple
truth
and
earnestness
that
was
her
own
,
and
no
one
else
's
in
the
world
!
  
<EOS>
"
Going
away
,
Walter
!
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
he
replied
,
but
not
so
hopefully
as
he
endeavoured
:
"
I
have
a
voyage
before
me
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
your
Uncle
,
"
said
Florence
,
looking
back
at
Solomon
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
sorry
you
are
going
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
see
he
is
!
<EOS>
Dear
Walter
,
I
am
very
sorry
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Goodness
knows
,
"
exclaimed
Miss
Nipper
,
"
there
's
a
many
we
could
spare
instead
,
if
numbers
is
a
object
,
Mrs
Pipchin
as
a
overseer
would
come
cheap
at
her
weight
in
gold
,
and
if
a
knowledge
of
black
slavery
should
be
required
,
them
Blimbers
is
the
very
people
for
the
sitiwation
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
Miss
Nipper
untied
her
bonnet
strings
,
and
after
looking
vacantly
for
some
moments
into
a
little
black
teapot
that
was
set
forth
with
the
usual
homely
service
on
the
table
,
shook
her
head
and
a
tin
canister
,
and
began
unasked
to
make
the
tea
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Florence
had
turned
again
to
the
Instrument
-
maker
,
who
was
as
full
of
admiration
as
surprise
.
"
<EOS>
So
grown
!
"
said
old
Sol
.
"
<EOS>
So
improved
!
<EOS>
And
yet
not
altered!Just
the
same
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ye
---
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
returned
old
Sol
,
rubbing
his
hands
slowly
,
and
considering
the
matter
half
aloud
,
as
something
pensive
in
the
bright
eyes
looking
at
him
arrested
his
attention
.
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
that
expression
was
in
the
younger
face
,
too
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
remember
me
,
"
said
Florence
with
a
smile
,
"
and
what
a
little
creature
I
was
then
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
young
lady
,
"
returned
the
Instrument
-
maker
,
"
<EOS>
how
could

forget
you
,
often

!
<EOS>
At

"
  
"
Was

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
Walter
!
<EOS>
Oh

,
Walter
!
<EOS>
I

and
hardly

;
"
and

her
little

so

.
  
<EOS>
Yet

,

old

.
<EOS>
The

fair

---
for

!
<EOS>
it

---
it
,
were

of
their

.
<EOS>
They

the

he

<EOS>
"

---

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Let

!
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

,

,
"

,

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

old

!
<EOS>
Just

!
<EOS>
How

I

!
"
  
<EOS>
Old
Sol
looked
first

,

at
his

,
and

,
and
rubbed

,
and

"
Ah
!
time
,
time
,
time
!
"
  
<EOS>
There

:

Susan
Nipper
skilfully

and

,
and
awaited

the

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

to
tell
Walter
's
Uncle
,
"
said

,

's
as

"
something

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
May

I

?
"
  
<EOS>
The
Instrument
-

,

,

,

bonnet

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,
"

;

when

and

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
The
sweet
face
looking
into

,
the

,
<EOS>
the

,

made

more
winning
by
a

's
respect

,

:
  
"
<EOS>
Wally
!
say

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Walter
,
"
returned

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

"
  
<EOS>
The

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss

"

?
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
Nipper
began

,

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
but
,

,
"

,
"

,
and

,
if
you

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Like

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
could

speak

.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
,

,
I
could

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,

,

.
<EOS>
For
,
Walter
,
"
added

,

,
"
he
liked
you
very
much
,
and
said

that

,
and
said
"
Remember
Walter
!
"
<EOS>
and

,

,

,

,

!
<EOS>
This

,

,
but

,
because
my

is
full
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
in
its

sweet

,
she
held

hands
to

.
<EOS>
Walter
taking

,
stooped

and
touched
the
tearful

that
neither

turned
away
,
nor
reddened

,
but

.
<EOS>
In

,

's

.
<EOS>
It
seemed

that

,

:

,

,

,
in

,

;

,

;
and
hold

upon
it
any

that
was

in

own

.
  
<EOS>
Susan
Nipper
,
who
had
bitten
both
her
bonnet
strings
at
once
,
and
imparted
a
great

private

to
the
skylight
,
during
this
transaction
,
now
changed
the
subject
by
inquiring
who
took

and
who
took

;
and
being

on

points
,
poured
out

.
<EOS>
They
all
four
gathered
socially
about
the
little

,
and
took
tea
under
that
young
lady
's
active

;
and
the

of
Florence
in
the
back
parlour
,
brightened
the
Tartar
frigate
on
the
wall
.
  
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
ago
Walter
,
for
his
life
,
would
have
hardly
called
her
by
her
name
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
do
so
now
when
she
entreated

.
<EOS>
He
could
think
of
her
being
there
,
without
a

that

.
<EOS>
He

,
how
full

,
what
a
home
<EOS>
some
happy
man

.
<EOS>
He

,

;
and
with
a

,
if
not

deserve

---
he
still

far

---
never
to

.
  
<EOS>
Some
fairy

must
surely

of
Susan
Nipper
when
she

tea
,
engendering

reigned
in

back

during
its

.
<EOS>
Some
counter
-

must
surely
have
hovered
round
the
hands
of
Uncle
Sol
's
chronometer
,
and
moved
them
faster
than
the
Tartar
frigate
ever
went
before
the
wind
.
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
may
,
the
visitors
had
a
coach
in

at
a
quiet
corner
not
far

;
and
the
chronometer
,
on
being
incidentally

to
,
gave
such
a
positive
opinion
that
it
had
been
waiting
a
long

,
that

,

.
<EOS>
If
Uncle
Sol
had

,

never

have

that
the
chronometer
was
too

,
by

.
  
<EOS>
Florence
at

recapitulated
to
the
old

all
that

said

,
and
bound

.
<EOS>
Uncle
Sol
attended

lovingly
to
the
legs
of
the
Wooden
Midshipman
,
and
there
resigned

to
Walter
,
who
was
ready

Susan
Nipper
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Walter
,
"
said

by

,
"
I

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
signified

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
The

?
"

<EOS>
"

.
"
  
Walter

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

,
"

,

"
<EOS>
Why

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

,
Walter
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
"
said
Walter
,
understanding

.
<EOS>
"
There

.
<EOS>
Between

a

,

.
<EOS>
If

,
I

,

do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Had
Florence
any
misgiving
of
which
she
was
hardly

:
any
misgiving
that
had
sprung
into

indistinct

since
that
recent

when

down

's

:
that

,

early

,

<EOS>
Had
Walter
<EOS>
any

,

that
it

?
<EOS>
Neither

.
<EOS>
Neither

,

.
<EOS>
Susan
,

,

sharply
;
and
certainly
Miss
Nipper
's

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
may

,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
may

,
"
said

,
"
an

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
,
"

,

,
"

---

---

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There

a

words
about
her
father
,
that
Walter
understood

.
  
<EOS>
The

being
close

,
he

left

without

,
for
now

felt
what
parting
;
but

his

when

,
and
then

found

a
little
packet
in
her
own
.
  
<EOS>
"
Walter
,
"
she
said
,
looking
full

with
her

,
"
like
you
,
I
hope
for
better
things
.
<EOS>
I
will
pray
for
them
,
and
believe
that
they
will
arrive
.
<EOS>
I
made
this
little
gift
for
Paul
.
<EOS>
Pray
take
it
with
my
love
,
and
do
not
look
at
it
until
you
are
gone
away
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
God
bless
you
,
Walter!never
forget
me
.
<EOS>
You
are
my
brother
,
dear
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
glad
that
Susan
Nipper
came
between
them
,
or
he
might
have
left
her
with
a
sorrowful
remembrance
of
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
glad
too
that
she
did
not
look
out
of
the
coach
again
,
but
waved
the
little
hand
to
him
instead
,
as
long
as
he
could
see
it
.
  
<EOS>
In
spite
of
her
request
,
he
could
not
help
opening
the
packet
that
night
when
he
went
to
bed
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
purse
:
and
there
was
money
in
it
.
  
<EOS>
Bright
rose
the
sun
next
morning
,
from
his
absence
in
strange
countries
,
and
up
rose
Walter
with
it
to
receive
the
Captain
,
who
was
already
at
the
door
:
having
turned
out
earlier
than
was
necessary
,
in
order
to
get
under
weigh
while
Mrs
MacStinger
was
yet
slumbering
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
pretended
to
be
in
tip
-
top
spirits
,
and
brought
a
very
smoky
tongue
in
one
of
the
pockets
of
the
broad
blue
coat
for
breakfast
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
,
Wal'r
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
When
they
took
their
seats
at
table
,
"
if
your
uncle
's
the
man
I
think
him
,
he
'll
bring
out
the
last
bottle
of
the
Madeira
on
the
present
occasion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
Ned
,
"
returned
the
old
man
.
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
That
shall
be
opened
when
Walter
comes
home
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Well
said
!
"
cried
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
Hear
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
it
lies
,
"
said
Sol
Gills
,
"
down
in
the
little
cellar
,
covered
with
dirt
and
cobwebs
.
<EOS>
There
may
be
dirt
and
cobwebs
over
you
and
me
perhaps
,
Ned
,
before
it
sees
the
light
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hear
him
!
"
cried
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
morality
!
<EOS>
Wal'r
<EOS>
my
lad
.
<EOS>
Train
up
a
fig
-
tree
in
the
way
it
should
go
,
and
when
you
are
old
sit
under
the
shade
on
it
.
<EOS>
Overhaul
<EOS>
the
---
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
the
Captain
on
second
thoughts
,
"
<EOS>
I
an't
quite
certain
<EOS>
where
that
's
to
be
found
,
but
when
found
,
make
a
note
of
.
<EOS>
Sol
Gills
,
heave
ahead
again
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
there
,
or
somewhere
,
it
shall
lie
,
Ned
,
until
Wally
comes
back
to
claim
it
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
I
meant
to
say
.
"
  
"
And
well
said
too
,
"
returned
the
Captain
;
"
and
if
we
three
do
n't
crack
that
bottle
in
company
,
I
'll
give
you
two
leave
to
drink
my
allowance
!
"
  
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
Captain
's
excessive
joviality
,
he
made
but
a
poor
hand
at
the
smoky
tongue
,
though
he
tried
very
hard
,
when
anybody
looked
at
him
,
to
appear
as
if
he
were
eating
with
a
vast
appetite
.
<EOS>
He
was
terribly
afraid
,
likewise
,
of
being
left
alone
with
either
uncle
or
nephew
;
appearing
to
consider
that
his
only
chance
of
safety
as
to
keeping
up
appearances
,
was
in
there
being
always
three
together
.
<EOS>
This
terror
on
the
part
of
the
Captain
,
reduced
him
to
such
ingenious
evasions
as
running
to
the
door
,
when
Solomon
went
to
put
his
coat
on
,
under
pretence
of
having
seen
an
extraordinary
hackney
-
coach
pass
:
and
darting
out
into
the
road
when
Walter
went
up
stairs
to
take
leave
of
the
lodgers
,
on
a
feint
of
smelling
fire
in
a
neighbouring
chimney
.
<EOS>
These
artifices
Captain
Cuttle
deemed
inscrutable
by
any
uninspired
observer
.
  
<EOS>
Walter
was
coming
down
from
his
parting
expedition
up
stairs
,
and
was
crossing
the
shop
to
go
back
to
the
little
parlour
,
when
he
saw
a
faded
face
he
knew
,
looking
in
at
the
door
,
and
darted
towards
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Carker
!
"
cried
Walter
,
pressing
the
hand
of
John
Carker
the
Junior
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
come
in
!
<EOS>
This
is
kind
of
you
,
to
be
here
so
early
to
say
good
-
bye
to
me
.
<EOS>
You
knew
how
glad
it
would
make
me
to
shake
hands
with
you
,
once
,
before
going
away
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
how
glad
I
am
to
have
this
opportunity
.
<EOS>
Pray
come
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
likely
that
we
may
ever
meet
again
,
Walter
,
"
returned
the
other
,
gently
resisting
his
invitation
,
"
and
I
am
glad
of
this
opportunity
too
.
<EOS>
I
may
venture
to
speak
to
you
,
and
to
take
you
by
the
hand
,
on
the
eve
of
separation
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
have
to
resist
your
frank
approaches
,
Walter
any
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
melancholy
in
his
smile
as
he
said
it
,
that
showed
he
had
found
some
company
and
friendship
for
his
thoughts
even
in
that
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Mr
Carker
!
"
returned
Walter
,
"
Why
did
your
resist
them
?
<EOS>
You
could
have
done
me
nothing
but
good
,
I
am
very
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
If
there
were
any
good
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
could
do
on
this
earth
,
I
would
do
it
,
Walter
,
for
you
.
<EOS>
The
sight
of
you
from
day
to
day
,
has
been
at
once
happiness
and
remorse
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
the
pleasure
has
outweighed
the
pain
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
,
now
,
by
knowing
what
I
lose
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
in
,
Mr
Carker
,
and
make
acquaintance
with
my
good
old
uncle
,
"
urged
Walter
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
often
talked
to
him
about
you
,
and
he
will
be
glad
to
tell
you
all
he
hears
from
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
,
"
said
Walter
,
noticing
his
hesitation
,
and
speaking
with
embarrassment
himself
:
"
<EOS>
I
have
not
told
him
anything
about
our
last
conversation
,
Mr
Carker
;
not
even
him
,
believe
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
grey
Junior
pressed
his
hand
,
and
tears
rose
in
his
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
ever
make
acquaintance
with
him
,
Walter
,
"
he
returned
,
"
it
will
be
that
I
may
hear
tidings
of
you
.
<EOS>
Rely
on
my
not
wronging
your
forbearance
and
consideration
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
to
wrong
it
,
not
to
tell
him
all
the
truth
,
before
I
sought
a
word
of
confidence
from
him
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
no
friend
or
acquaintance
except
you
:
and
even
for
your
sake
,
am
little
likely
to
make
any
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
you
had
suffered
me
to
be
your
friend
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
always
wished
it
,
Mr
Carker
,
as
you
know
;
but
never
half
so
much
as
now
,
when
we
are
going
to
part
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
enough
,
"
replied
the
other
,
"
that
you
have
been
the
friend
of
my
own
breast
,
and
that
when
I
have
avoided
you
most
,
my
heart
inclined
the
most
towards
you
,
and
was
fullest
of
you
.
<EOS>
Walter
,
good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
Mr
Carker
.
<EOS>
Heaven
be
with
you
,
Sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Walter
,
with
emotion
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
,
"
said
the
other
,
retaining
his
hand
while
he
spoke
;
"
if
when
you
come
back
,
you
miss
me
from
my
old
corner
,
and
should
hear
from
any
one
where
I
am
lying
,
come
and
look
upon
my
grave
.
<EOS>
Think
that
I
might
have
been
as
honest
and
as
happy
as
you
!
<EOS>
And
let
me
think
,
when
I
know
my
time
is
coming
on
,
that
some
one
like
my
former
self
may
stand
there
,
for
a
moment
,
and
remember
me
with
pity
and
forgiveness!Walter
,
good
-
bye
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
figure
crept
like
a
shadow
down
the
bright
,
sun
-
lighted
street
,
so
cheerful
yet
<EOS>
so
solemn
in
the
early
summer
morning
;
and
slowly
passed
away
.
  
<EOS>
The
relentless
chronometer
at
last
announced
that
Walter
must
turn
his
back
upon
the
Wooden
Midshipman
:
<EOS>
and
away
they
went
,
himself
,
his
uncle
,
and
the
Captain
,
in
a
hackney
-
coach
to
a
wharf
,
where
they
were
to
take
steam
-
boat
for
some
Reach
down
the
river
,
the
name
of
which
,
as
the
Captain
gave
it
out
,
was
a
hopeless
mystery
to
the
ears
of
landsmen
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
this
Reach
(
whither
the
ship
had
repaired
by
last
night
's
tide
)
,
they
were
boarded
by
various
excited
watermen
,
and
among
others
by
a
dirty
Cyclops
of
the
Captain
's
acquaintance
,
who
,
with
his
one
eye
,
had
made
the
Captain
out
some
mile
and
a
half
off
,
and
had
been
exchanging
unintelligible
roars
with
him
ever
since
.
<EOS>
Becoming
the
lawful
prize
of
this
personage
,
who
was
frightfully
hoarse
and
constitutionally
in
want
of
shaving
,
they
were
all
three
put
aboard
the
Son
and
Heir
.
<EOS>
And
the
Son
and
Heir
was
in
a
pretty
state
of
confusion
,
with
sails
lying
all
bedraggled
on
the
wet
decks
,
loose
ropes
tripping
people
up
,
men
in
red
shirts
running
barefoot
to
and
fro
,
casks
blockading
every
foot
of
space
,
and
,
in
the
thickest
of
the
fray
,
a
black
cook
in
a
black
caboose
up
to
his
eyes
in
vegetables
and
blinded
with
smoke
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
immediately
drew
Walter
into
a
corner
,
and
with
a
great
effort
,
that
made
his
face
very
red
,
pulled
up
the
silver
watch
,
which
was
so
big
,
and
so
tight
in
his
pocket
,
that
it
came
out
like
a
bung
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
said
the
Captain
,
handing
it
over
,
and
shaking
him
heartily
by
the
hand
,
"
a
parting
gift
,
my
lad
.
<EOS>
Put
it
back
half
an
hour
every
morning
,
and
about
another
quarter
towards
the
afternoon
,
and
it
's
a
watch
that
'll
do
you
credit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Cuttle
!
<EOS>
I
could
n't
think
of
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Walter
,
detaining
him
,
for
he
was
running
away
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pray
take
it
back
.
<EOS>
I
have
one
already
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Wal'r
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
suddenly
diving
into
one
of
his
pockets
and
bringing
up
the
two
teaspoons
and
the
sugar
-
tongs
,
with
which
he
had
armed
himself
to
meet
such
an
objection
,
"
take
this
here
trifle
of
plate
,
instead
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
no
,
I
could
n't
indeed
!
"
cried
Walter
,
"
a
thousand
thanks
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
throw
them
away
,
Captain
Cuttle
!
"
<EOS>
for
the
Captain
was
about
to
jerk
them
overboard
.
<EOS>
"
They
'll
be
of
much
more
use
to
you
than
me
.
<EOS>
Give
me
your
stick
.
<EOS>
I
have
often
thought
I
should
like
to
have
it
.
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
Captain
Cuttle
!
<EOS>
Take
care
of
my
uncle
!
<EOS>
Uncle
Sol
,
God
bless
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
over
the
side
in
the
confusion
,
before
Walter
caught
another
glimpse
of
either
;
and
when
he
ran
up
to
the
stern
,
and
looked
after
them
,
he
saw
his
uncle
hanging
down
his
head
in
the
boat
,
and
Captain
Cuttle
rapping
him
on
the
back
with
the
great
silver
watch
<EOS>
(
it
must
have
been
very
painful
)
,
and
gesticulating
hopefully
with
the
teaspoons
and
sugartongs
.
<EOS>
Catching
sight
of
Walter
,
Captain
Cuttle
dropped
the
property
into
the
bottom
of
the
boat
with
perfect
unconcern
,
being
evidently
oblivious
of
its
existence
,
and
pulling
off
the
glazed
hat
hailed
him
lustily
.
<EOS>
The
glazed
hat
made
quite
a
show
in
the
sun
with
its
glistening
,
and
the
Captain
continued
to
wave
it
until
he
could
be
seen
no
longer
.
<EOS>
Then
the
confusion
on
board
,
which
had
been
rapidly
increasing
,
reached
its
height
;
two
or
three
other
boats
went
away
with
a
cheer
;
the
sails
shone
bright
and
full
above
,
as
Walter
watched
them
spread
their
surface
to
the
favourable
breeze
;
the
water
flew
in
sparkles
from
the
prow
;
and
off
upon
her
voyage
went
the
Son
and
Heir
,
as
hopefully
and
trippingly
as
many
another
son
and
heir
,
gone
down
,
had
started
on
his
way
before
her
.
  
<EOS>
Day
after
day
,
old
Sol
and
Captain
Cuttle
kept
her
reckoning
in
the
little
back
parlour
and
worked
out
her
course
,
with
the
chart
spread
before
them
on
the
round
table
.
<EOS>
At
night
,
when
old
Sol
climbed
upstairs
,
so
lonely
,
to
the
attic
where
it
sometimes
blew
great
guns
,
he
looked
up
at
the
stars
and
listened
to
the
wind
,
and
kept
a
longer
watch
than
would
have
fallen
to
his
lot
on
board
the
ship
.
<EOS>
The
last
bottle
of
the
old
Madeira
,
which
had
had
its
cruising
days
,
and
known
its
dangers
of
the
deep
,
lay
silently
beneath
its
dust
and
cobwebs
,
in
the
meanwhile
,
undisturbed
.
    
Chapter
20
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
goes
upon
a
Journey
 
<EOS>
"
MR
DOMBEY
,
Sir
,
"
said
Major
Bagstock
,
"
<EOS>
Joey
B
is
not
in
general
a
man
of
sentiment
,
for
Joseph
is
tough
.
<EOS>
But
Joe
has
his
feelings
,
Sir
,
and
when
they
are
awakened
---
Damme
,
Mr
Dombey
,
"
cried
the
Major
with
sudden
ferocity
,
"
this
is
weakness
,
and
I
wo
n't
submit
to
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Major
Bagstock
delivered
himself
of
these
expressions
on
receiving
Mr
Dombey
as
his
guest
at
the
head
of
his
own
staircase
in
Princess
's
Place
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
has
come
to
breakfast
with
the
Major
,
previous
to
their
setting
forth
on
their
trip
;
and
the
ill
-
starred
Native
had
already
undergone
a
world
of
misery
arising
out
of
the
muffins
,
while
,
in
connexion
with
the
general
question
of
boiled
eggs
,
life
was
a
burden
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
for
an
old
soldier
of
the
Bagstock
breed
,
"
observed
the
Major
,
relapsing
into
a
mild
state
,
"
to
deliver
himself
up
,
a
prey
to
his
own
emotions
;
but
---
damme
,
Sir
,
"
cried
the
Major
,
in
another
spasm
of
ferocity
,
"
I
condole
with
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
's
purple
visage
deepened
in
its
hue
,
and
the
Major
's
lobster
eyes
stood
out
in
bolder
relief
,
as
he
shook
Mr
Dombey
by
the
hand
,
imparting
to
that
peaceful
action
as
defiant
a
character
as
if
it
had
been
the
prelude
to
his
immediately
boxing
Mr
Dombey
for
a
thousand
pounds
a
side
and
the
championship
of
England
.
<EOS>
With
a
rotatory
motion
of
his
head
,
and
a
wheeze
very
like
the
cough
of
a
horse
,
the
Major
then
conducted
his
visitor
to
the
sitting
-
room
,
and
there
welcomed
him
(
having
now
composed
his
feelings
)
with
the
freedom
and
frankness
of
a
travelling
companion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dombey
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
I
'm
glad
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
I
'm
proud
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
There
are
not
many
men
in
Europe
to
whom
J
Bagstock
would
say
that
---
for
Josh
is
blunt
.
<EOS>
Sir
:
it
's
his
nature
---
but
Joey
B
is
proud
to
see
you
,
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Major
,
"
returned
Mr
Dombey
,
"
you
are
very
obliging
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
Devil
a
bit
!
<EOS>
That
's
not
my
character
.
<EOS>
If
that
had
been
Joe
's
character
.
<EOS>
Joe
might
have
been
,
by
this
time
,
Lieutenant
-
General
Sir
Joseph
Bagstock
,
KCB
,
and
might
have
received
you
in
very
different
quarters
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
old
Joe
<EOS>
yet
,
I
find
.
<EOS>
But
this
occasion
,
being
special
,
is
a
source
of
pride
to
me
.
<EOS>
By
the
Lord
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
resolutely
,
"
it
's
an
honour
to
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
in
his
estimation
of
himself
and
his
money
,
felt
that
this
was
very
true
,
and
therefore
did
not
dispute
the
point
.
<EOS>
But
the
instinctive
recognition
of
such
a
truth
by
the
Major
,
and
his
plain
avowal
of
it
,
were
very
agreeable
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
confirmation
to
Mr
Dombey
,
if
he
has
required
any
,
of
his
not
being
mistaken
in
the
Major
.
<EOS>
It
was
an
assurance
to
him
that
his
power
extended
beyond
his
own
immediate
sphere
;
and
that
the
Major
,
as
an
officer
and
a
gentleman
,
had
a
no
less
becoming
sense
of
it
,
than
the
beadle
of
the
Royal
Exchange
.
  
<EOS>
And
if
it
were
ever
consolatory
to
know
this
,
or
the
like
of
this
,
it
was
consolatory
then
,
when
the
impotence
of
his
will
,
the
instability
of
his
hopes
,
the
feebleness
of
wealth
,
had
been
so
direfully
impressed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
What
could
it
do
,
his
boy
had
asked
him
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
thinking
of
the
baby
question
,
he
could
hardly
forbear
inquiring
,
himself
,
what
could
it
do
indeed
:
what
had
it
done
?
  
<EOS>
But
these
were
lonely
thoughts
,
bred
late
at
night
in
the
sullen
despondency
and
gloom
of
his
retirement
,
and
pride
easily
found
its
reassurance
in
many
testimonies
to
the
truth
,
as
unimpeachable
and
precious
as
the
Major
's
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
in
his
friendlessness
,
inclined
to
the
Major
.
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
said
that
he
warmed
towards
him
,
but
he
thawed
a
little
.
<EOS>
The
Major
had
had
some
part
---
and
not
too
much
---
in
the
days
by
the
seaside
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
of
the
world
,
and
knew
some
great
people
.
<EOS>
He
talked
much
,
and
told
stories
;
and
Mr
Dombey
was
disposed
to
regard
him
as
a
choice
spirit
who
shone
in
society
,
and
who
had
not
that
poisonous
ingredient
of
poverty
with
which
choice
spirits
in
general
are
too
much
adulterated
.
<EOS>
His
station
was
undeniable
.
<EOS>
Altogether
the
Major
was
a
creditable
companion
,
well
accustomed
to
a
life
of
leisure
,
and
to
such
places
as
that
they
were
about
to
visit
,
and
having
an
air
of
gentlemanly
ease
about
him
that
mixed
well
enough
with
his
own
City
character
,
and
did
not
compete
with
it
at
all
.
<EOS>
If
Mr
Dombey
had
any
lingering
idea
that
the
Major
,
as
a
man
accustomed
,
in
the
way
of
his
calling
,
to
make
light
of
the
ruthless
had
<EOS>
that
hand
lately
crushed
his
hopes
,
might
unconsciously
impart
some
useful
philosophy
to
him
,
and
scare
away
his
weak
regrets
,
he
hid
it
from
himself
,
and
left
it
lying
at
the
bottom
of
his
pride
,
unexamined
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
my
scoundrel
?
"
said
the
Major
,
looking
wrathfully
round
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
The
Native
,
who
had
no
particular
name
,
but
answered
to
any
vituperative
epithet
,
presented
himself
instantly
at
the
door
and
ventured
to
come
no
nearer
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
villain
!
"
said
the
choleric
Major
,
"
where
's
the
breakfast
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
dark
servant
disappeared
in
search
of
it
,
and
was
quickly
heard
reascending
the
stairs
in
such
a
tremulous
state
,
that
the
plates
and
dishes
on
the
tray
he
carried
,
trembling
sympathetically
as
he
came
,
rattled
again
,
all
the
way
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dombey
,
"
said
the
Major
,
glancing
at
the
Native
as
he
arranged
the
table
,
and
encouraging
him
with
an
awful
shake
of
his
fist
when
he
upset
a
spoon
,
"
here
is
a
devilled
grill
,
a
savoury
pie
,
a
dish
of
kidneys
,
and
so
forth
.
<EOS>
Pray
sit
down
.
<EOS>
Old
Joe
can
give
you
nothing
but
camp
fare
,
you
see
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
excellent
fare
,
Major
,
"
replied
his
guest
;
and
not
in
mere
politeness
either
;
for
the
Major
always
took
the
best
possible
care
of
himself
,
and
indeed
ate
rather
more
of
rich
meats
than
was
good
for
him
,
insomuch
that
his
Imperial
complexion
was
mainly
referred
by
the
faculty
to
that
circumstance
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
looking
over
the
way
,
Sir
,
"
observed
the
Major
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
our
friend
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
Miss
Tox
,
"
retorted
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charming
woman
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
with
a
fat
laugh
rising
in
his
short

,
and
nearly
suffocating
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Tox
is
a
very
good
sort
of
person
,
I
believe
,
"
replied
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
The
haughty
coldness
of
the
reply
seemed
to
afford
Major
Bagstock
infinite
delight
.
<EOS>
He
swelled
and
swelled
,
exceedingly
:
and
even
laid
down
his
knife
and
fork
for
a
moment
,
to
rub
his
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Old
Joe
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
was
a
bit
of
a
favourite
in
that
quarter
once
.
<EOS>
But
Joe
has
had
his
day
.
<EOS>
J
Bagstock
is
extinguished
---
outrivalled
---
floored
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
I
tell
you
what
,
Dombey
.
"
<EOS>
The
Major
paused
in
his

,
and
looked
mysteriously
indignant
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
de
-
vilish
ambitious
woman
,
Sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
said
"
Indeed
?
"
<EOS>
with

:
mingled
perhaps

some

as
to
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
having
the

to
harbour

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
woman
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
is
,
in
her

,
a
Lucifer
.
<EOS>
Joey
B
has
had
his
day
,
Sir
,
but
he
keeps

.
<EOS>
He
sees
,
does
Joe
.
<EOS>
His
Royal
Highness
the
late
Duke
of
York
observed
of
Joey
,
at
a

,
that
he
saw
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
accompanied
this
with
such

look
,
and
,
between

,
drinking
,
hot
tea
,
devilled

,

,
and
meaning
,
was
altogether
so
swollen
and
inflamed
about

head
,
that
even

Dombey
showed
some

for
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
ridiculous
old

,
Sir
,
"
pursued

Major
,
"
aspires
.
<EOS>
She
aspires
sky

high
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Matrimonially
,
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

,
"
said
Mr

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

,
Dombey
,
"
returned
the
Major
in

warning

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
not
,
Major
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
The
Major
gave
no
answer
but
the
horse
's
cough
,
and
went
on
eating
vigorously
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
taken
an
interest
in
your
household
,
"
said
the
Major
,
stopping
short
again
,
"
and
has
been
a
frequent
visitor
at
your
house
for
some
time
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Mr
Dombey
with
great
stateliness
,
"
Miss
Tox
was
originally
received
there
,
at
the
time
of
Mrs
Dombey
's
death
,
as
a
friend
of
my
sister
's
;
and
being
a
well
-
behaved
person
,
and
showing
a
liking
for
the
poor
infant
<EOS>
,
she
was
permitted
---
I
may
say
encouraged
---
to
repeat
her
visits
with
my
sister
,
and
gradually
to
occupy
a
kind
of
footing
of
familiarity
in
the
family
.
<EOS>
I
have
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
in
the
tone
of
a
man
who
was
making
a
great
and
valuable
concession
,
"
I
have
a
respect
for
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
She
has
been
so
obliging
as
to
render
many
little
services
in
my
house
:
trifling
and
insignificant
services
perhaps
,
Major
,
but
not
to

disparaged
on
that
account
:
<EOS>
and
I
hope
I
have
had
the
good

to
be
enabled
to
acknowledge
them
by
such

and
notice
as
it

to

.
<EOS>
I
hold
myself
indebted
to
Miss
Tox
,
Major
,
"
added
Mr
Dombey
,
with
a
slight

of

hand
,
"
for
the
pleasure
of
your

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Dombey
,
"
said
the
Major
,
warmly
:
"
<EOS>
no
!
<EOS>
No
,
Sir
!
<EOS>
Joseph
Bagstock
can
never
permit
that
assertion
to
pass

.
<EOS>
Your
knowledge
of
old
Joe
,
Sir
,
such
as
he
is
,
and
old
Joe
's
knowledge
of
you
,
Sir
,
had
its
origin
in
a
noble
fellow
,
Sir
---
in
a
great

,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Dombey
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Major
,
with
a
struggle
which
it
was
not
very
difficult
to
parade
,
his
whole
life
being
a
struggle
against
all
kinds
of
apoplectic
symptoms
,
"
we
knew
each
other
through
your
boy
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
seemed
touched
,
as
it
is
not
improbable
the
Major
designed
he
should
be
,
by
this
allusion
.
<EOS>
He
looked
down
and
sighed
:
and
<EOS>
the
Major
,
rousing
himself
fiercely
,
again
said
,
in
reference
to
the
state
of
mind
into
which
he
felt
himself
in
danger
of
falling
,
that
this
was
weakness
,
and
nothing
should
induce
him
to
submit
to
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Our
friend
has
a
remote
connexion
with
that
event
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
and
all
the
credit
that
belongs
to
her
,
JB
is
willing
to
give
her
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
which
,
Ma'am
,
"
he
added
,
raising
his
eyes
from
his
plate
,
and
casting

across
Princess
's
Place
,
to
where
Miss
Tox
was
at
that
moment
visible
at
her
window
watering
her
flowers
,
"
you
're
a
scheming
jade
,
Ma'am
,
and
your
ambition
is
a
piece
of
monstrous
impudence
.
<EOS>
If
it
only
made
yourself
ridiculous
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
,
rolling
his
head
at
the
unconscious
Miss
Tox
,
while
his
starting
eyes
appeared
to
make
a
leap
towards
her
,
"
you
might
do
that
to
your
heart
's
content
,
Ma'am
,
without
any
objection
<EOS>
,
I
assure
you
,
on
the
part
of
Bagstock
.
<EOS>
"
Here
the
Major
laughed
frightfully
up
in
the
tips
of
his
ears
and
in
the
veins
of
his
head
.
"
<EOS>
But
when
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
you
compromise
other
people
,
and
generous
,
unsuspicious
people
too
,
as
a
repayment
for
their
condescension
,
you
stir
the
blood
of
old
Joe
in
his
body
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Major
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
reddening
,
"
<EOS>
I
hope
you
do
not
hint
at
anything
so
absurd
on
the
part
of
Miss
Tox
as
---
"
  
"
Dombey
,
"
returned
the
Major
,
"
<EOS>
I
hint
at
nothing
.
<EOS>
But
Joey
B
has
lived
in
the
world
,
Sir
:
lived
in
the
world
with
his
eyes
open
,
Sir
,
and
his
ears
cocked
:
and
Joe
tells
you
,
Dombey
,
that
there
's
a
de
-
vilish
artful
and
ambitious
woman
over
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
involuntarily
glanced
over
the
way
;
and
an
angry
glance
he
sent
in
that
direction
,
too
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
on
such
a
subject
that
shall
pass
the
lips
of
Joseph
Bagstock
,
"
said
the
Major
firmly
.
<EOS>
"
Joe
is
not
a
talebearer
,
but
there
are
times
when
he
must
speak
,
when
he
will
speak
!
<EOS>
---
confound
your
arts
,
Ma'am
,
"
cried
the
Major
,
again
apostrophising
his
fair
neighbour
,
with
great
ire
,
---
"
when
the
provocation
is
too
strong
to
admit
of
his
remaining
silent
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
emotion
of
this
outbreak
threw
the
Major
into
a
paroxysm
of
horse
's
coughs
,
which
held
him
for
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
On
recovering
he
added
:
  
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
Dombey
,
as
you
have
invited
Joe
---
old
Joe
,
who
has
no
other
merit
,
Sir
,
but
that
he
is
tough
and
hearty
---
to
be
your
guest
and
guide
at
Leamington
,
command
him
in
any

you
please
,
and
he
is
wholly

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
wagging
his
double
chin
with
a

,
"
what
it
is
you
people
see
in
Joe
to
make

hold
him
in
such
great
request
,
all
of
you
;
but
this
I

,
Sir
,
that
if

was

pretty

,

,
you
'd
kill
him
among
you
with

so

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
in

,

received
over
those
other

members
of
society
who
were

for
the

of
Major
Bagstock
.
<EOS>
But
the
Major
cut
him
short
by
giving
him
to
understand
that
he
followed
his
own
inclinations
,
and
that
they
had
risen
up
in

said

,
"
JB
,
Dombey
is
the
man
for

to

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
being
by
this
time
in
a
state
of
repletion
,
with
essence
of
savoury
pie
oozing
out
at
the
corners
of
his
eyes
,
and
devilled
grill
and
kidneys
tightening
his
cravat
:
and
the
time
moreover
approaching
for
the
departure
of
the
railway
train
to
Birmingham
,
by
which
they
were
to
leave
town
:
the
Native
got
him
into
his
great
-
coat
with
immense
difficulty
,
and
buttoned
him
up
until
his
face
looked
staring
and
gasping
,
over
the
top
of
that
garment
,
as
if
he
were
in
a
barrel
.
<EOS>
The
Native
then
handed
him
separately
,
and
with
a
decent
interval
between
each
supply
,
his
wash
-
leather
gloves
,
his
thick
stick
,
and
his
hat
;
which
latter
article
the
Major
wore
with
a
rakish
air
on
one
side
of
his
head
,
by
way
of
toning
down
his
remarkable
visage
.
<EOS>
The
Native
had
previously
packed
,
in
all
possible
and
impossible
parts
of
Mr
Dombey
's
chariot
,
which
was
in
waiting
,
an
unusual
quantity
of
carpet
-
bags
and
small
portmanteaus
,
no
less
apoplectic
in
appearance
than
the
Major
himself
:
and
having
filled
his
own
pockets
with
Seltzer
water
,
East
India
sherry
,

,
shawls
,
telescopes
,
maps
,
and

,
any
or
all
of
which
light
baggage
the
Major
might
require
at
any
instant
of
the
journey
,
he
announced
that
everything
was
ready
.
<EOS>
To
complete
the
equipment
of
this
unfortunate
foreigner
(
currently
believed
to
be
a
prince
in
his
own
country
)
,
when
he
took
his
seat
in
the
rumble
by
the
side
of
Mr
Towlinson
,
a
pile
of
the
Major
's
cloaks
and
great
-
coats
was
hurled
upon
him
by
the
landlord
,
who
aimed
at
him
from
the

with
those
great
missiles
like
a
Titan
,
and
so
covered
him
up
,
that
he
proceeded
,
in
a
living
tomb
,
to
the
railroad
station
.
  
<EOS>
But
before
the
carriage
moved
away
,
and
while
the
Native
was
in
the
act
of
sepulture
,
Miss
Tox
appearing
at
her
window
,
waved
a
lily
-
white
handkerchief
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
received
this
parting
salutation
very
coldly
---
very
coldly
even
for
him
---
and
honouring
her
with
the
slightest
possible
inclination
of
his
head
,
leaned
back
in
the
carriage
with
a
very
discontented
look
.
<EOS>
His
marked
behaviour
seemed
to
afford
the
Major
(
who
was
all
politeness
in
his
recognition
of
Miss
Tox
)
unbounded
satisfaction
;
and
he
sat
for
a
long
time
afterwards
,
leering
,
and
choking
,
like
an
over
-
fed
Mephistopheles
.
  
<EOS>
During
the
bustle
of
preparation
at
the
railway
,
Mr
Dombey
and
the
major
walked
up
and
down
the
platform
side
by
side
;
the
former
taciturn
and

,
and
the
latter
entertaining
him
,
or
entertaining
himself
,
with
a
variety
of
anecdotes
and
reminiscences
,
in
most
of
which
<EOS>
Joe
Bagstock
was
the
principal
performer
.
<EOS>
Neither
of
the
two
observed
that
in
the
course
of
these
walks
,
they
attracted
the
attention
of
a
working
man
who
was
standing
near
the
engine
,
and
who
touched
his
hat
every

they
passed
;
for
Mr
Dombey
habitually
looked
over
the
vulgar
herd
,
not
at
them
;
and
the
Major
was
looking
,
at
the
time
,
into
the
core
of
one
of
his

.
<EOS>
At
length
,
however
,
this
man
stepped
before
them
as

round
,
and
pulling
his

off
,
and
keeping

off
,
ducked
his
head
to
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
pardon
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
man
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
hope
you
're
a
doin'
pretty
well
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
a

abundantly

with

,
and

in

,

.
<EOS>
He

-

,

,

;

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall

'

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Beg

,

.
<EOS>
I

a
coming
round
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
'

,

,
"

,

,
"

,

---
"

.

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

,

,
"

,
"
<EOS>
I
ca

does
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

was
stopped

:
and

:
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
"

,

;
"
we
're
a

,

;

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Mr

,

,

<EOS>
"
No

,
up'ard

,

.
<EOS>
And

long

<EOS>
,
"

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
,

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Beg

,
Sir
,
"

,

:
"

except

---

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

,

,

,
"
pursued

,

.
"
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
God

,

,

!
<EOS>
You

"

"

I

.
<EOS>
Polly

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
A

's

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
The

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take

,

,
Sir
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Damme
,
Sir
,

never
does
!
<EOS>
I
always
fails
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
simple
father
was
beginning
to
submit
that
he
hoped
his
son
,
the
quondam
Grinder
,
huffed
and
cuffed
,
and
flogged
and
badged
,
and
taught
,
as
parrots
are
,
by
a
brute
jobbed
into
his
place
of
schoolmaster
with
as
much
fitness
for
it
as
a
hound
,
might
not
have
been
educated
on
quite
a
right
plan
in
some
undiscovered
respect
,
when
Mr
Dombey
angrily
repeating
"
The
usual
return
!
"
led
the
Major
away
.
<EOS>
And
the
Major
being
heavy
to
hoist
into
Mr
Dombey
's
carriage
elevated
in
midair
,
and
having
to
stop
and
swear
that
he
would
flay
the
Native
alive
,
and
break
very
bone
in
his
skin
,
and
visit
other
physical
torments
upon
him
,
every
time
he
could
n't
get
his
foot
on
the
step
,
and
fell
back
on
that
dark
exile
,
had
barely
time
before
they
started
to
repeat
hoarsely
that
it
would
never
do
:
that
it
always
failed
:
and
that
if
he
were
to
educate
"
his
own
vagabond
,
"
he
would
certainly
be
hanged
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
assented
bitterly
;
but
there
was
something
more
in
his
bitterness
,
and
in
his
moody
way
of
falling
back
in
the
carriage
,
and
looking
with
knitted
brows
at
the
changing
objects
without
,
that
the
failure
of
that
noble
educational
system
administered
by
the
Grinders
'
Company
.
<EOS>
He
had
seen
upon
the
man
's
rough
cap
a
piece
of
new
crape
,
and
he
had
assured
himself
,
from
his
manner
and
his
answers
,
that
he
wore
it
for
his
son
.
  
<EOS>
So
!
<EOS>
from
high
to
low
,
at
home
or
abroad
,
from
Florence
in
his
great
house
to
the
coarse
churl
who
was
feeding
the
fire
then
smoking
before
them
,
every
one
set
up
some
claim
or
other
to
a
share
in
his
dead
boy
,
and
was
a
bidder
against
him!Could
he
ever
forget
how
that
woman
had
wept
over
his
pillow
,
and
called
him
her
own
child
!
<EOS>
or
how
he
,
waking
from
his
sleep
,
had
asked
for
her
,
and
had
raised
himself
in
his
bed
and
brightened
when
she
came
in
!
  
<EOS>
To
think
of
this
presumptuous
raker
among
coals
and
ashes
going
on
before
there
,
with
his
sign
of
mourning
!
<EOS>
To
think
that
he
dared
to
enter
,
even
by
a
common
show
like
that
,
into
the
trial
and
disappointment
of
a
proud
gentleman
's
secret
heart
!
<EOS>
To
think
that
this
lost
child
,
who
was
to
have
divided
with
him
his
riches
,
and
his
projects
,
and
his
power
,
and
allied
with
whom
he
was
to
have
shut
out
all
the
world
as
with
a
double
door
of
gold
,
should
have
let
in
such
a
herd
to
insult
him
with
their
knowledge
of
his
defeated
hopes
,
and
their
boasts
of
claiming
community
of
feeling
with
himself
,
so
far
removed
:
if
not
of
having
crept
into
the
place
wherein
he
would
have
lorded
it
,
alone
!
  
<EOS>
He
found
no
pleasure
or
of
relief
in
the
journey
.
<EOS>
Tortured
by
these
thoughts
he
carried
monotony
with
him
,
through
the
rushing
landscape
,
and
hurried
headlong
,
not
through
a
rich
and
varied
country
,
but
a
wilderness
of
blighted
plans
and
gnawing
jealousies
.
<EOS>
The
very
speed
at
which
the
train
was
whirled
along
mocked
the
swift
course
of
the
young
life
that
had
been
borne
away
so
steadily
and
so
inexorably
to
its
foredoomed
end
.
<EOS>
The
power
that
forced
itself
upon
its
iron
way
---
its
own
---
defiant
of
all
paths
and
roads
,
piercing
through
the
heart
of
every
obstacle
,
and
dragging
living
creatures
of
all
classes
,
ages
,
and
degrees
behind
it
,
was
a
type
of
the
triumphant
monster
,
Death
.
  
<EOS>
Away
,
with
a
shriek
,
and
a
roar
,
and
a
rattle
,
from
the
town
,
burrowing
among
the
dwellings
of
men
and
making
the
streets
hum
,
flashing
out
into
the
meadows
for
a
moment
,
mining
in
through
the
damp
earth
,
booming
on
in
darkness
and
heavy
air
,
bursting
out
again
into
the
sunny
day
so
bright
and
wide
;
away
,
with
a
shriek
,
and
a
roar
,
and
a
rattle
,
through
the
fields
,
through
the
woods
,
through
the
corn
,
through
the
hay
,
through
the
chalk
,
through
the
mould
,
through
the
clay
,
through
the
rock
,
among
objects
close
at

and
almost
in
the
grasp
,
ever
flying
from
the
traveller
,
and
a
deceitful
distance
ever
moving
slowly
within
him
:
like
as
in
the
track
of
the
remorseless
monster
,
Death
!
  
<EOS>
Through
the
hallow
,
on
the
height
,
by
the
heath
,
by
the
orchard
,
by
the
park
,
by
the
garden
,
over
the
canal
,
across
the
river
,
where
the
sheep
are
feeding
,
where
the
mill
is
going
,
where
the
barge
is
floating
,
where
the
dead
are
lying
,
where
the
factory
is
smoking
,
where
the
stream
is
running
,
where
the
village
clusters
,
where
the
great
cathedral
rises
,
where
the
bleak
moor
lies
,
and
the
wild
breeze
smooths
or
ruffles
it
at
its
inconstant
will
;
away
,
with
a
shriek
,
and
a
roar
,
and
a
rattle
,
and
no
trace
to
leave
behind
but
dust
and
vapour
:
like
as
in
the
track
of
the
remorseless
monster
,
Death
!
  
<EOS>
Breasting
the
wind
and
light
,
the
shower
and
sunshine
,
away
,
and
still
away
,
it
rolls
and
roars
,
fierce
and
rapid
,
smooth
and
certain
,
and
great
works
and
massive
bridges
,
crossing
up
above
,
fall
like
a
beam
of
shadow
an
inch
broad
,
upon
the
eye
,
and
then
are
lost
.
<EOS>
Away
,
and
still
away
,
onward
and
onward
ever
<EOS>
:
glimpses
of
cottage
-
homes
,
of
houses
,
mansions
,
rich
estates
,
of
husbandry
and
handicraft
,
of
people
,
of
old
roads
and
paths
that
look
deserted
,
small
,
and
insignificant
as
they
are
left
behind
:
and
so
they
do
,
and
what
else
is
there
<EOS>
but
such
glimpses
,
in
the
track
of
the
indomitable
monster
,
Death
!
  
<EOS>
Away
,
with
a
shriek
,
and
a
roar
,
and
a
rattle
,
plunging
down
into
the
earth
again
,
and
working
on
in
such

storm
of
energy
and

,
that
amidst
the
darkness
and

the
motion
seems
reversed
,
and
to
tend
furiously
backward
,
until
a
ray

light
upon
the
wet
wall
shows
its
surface
flying
past
like

fierce

.
<EOS>
Away
once
more
into
the
day
,
and
through
the
day
,
with
a
shrill
yell
of
exultation
,
roaring
,
rattling
,
tearing
on
,
spurning
everything
with
its
dark
breath
,
sometimes
pausing
for
a
minute
where
a
crowd
of
faces
are
,
that
in
a
minute
more
are
not
;
sometimes
lapping
water
greedily
,
and
before
the
spout
at
which
it
drinks
has

to
drip
upon
the
ground
,
shrieking
,
roaring
,
rattling
through
the
purple
distance
!
  
<EOS>
Louder
and
louder
<EOS>
yet
,
it
shrieks
and
cries
as
it
comes
tearing
on
resistless
to
the
goal
:
and
now
its
way
,
still
like
the
way
of
Death
,
is
strewn
with
ashes
thickly
.
<EOS>
Everything
around
is
blackened
.
<EOS>
There
are
dark
pools
of
water
,
muddy
lanes
,
and
miserable
habitations
far
below
.
<EOS>
There
are
jagged
walls
and
falling
houses
close
at
hand
,
and
through
the
battered
roofs
and
broken
windows
,
wretched
rooms
are
seen
,
where
want
and
fever
hide
themselves
in
many
wretched
shapes
,
while
smoke
and
crowded
gables
,
and
distorted

,
and
deformity
of
brick
and
mortar
penning
up
deformity
of
mind
and
body
,
choke
the
murky
distance
.
<EOS>
As
Mr
Dombey
looks
out
of
his
carriage
window
,
it
is
never
in
his
thoughts
that
the
monster
who
has
brought

there
has
let
the
light
of
day
in
on
these
things
:
not
made
or
caused
them
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
journey
's
fitting
end
,
and
might
have
been
the
end
of
everything
;
it
was
so
ruinous
and
dreary
.
  
<EOS>
So
,
pursuing
the
one
course
of
thought
,
he
had
the
one
relentless
monster
still
before
him
.
<EOS>
All
things
looked
black
,
and
cold
,
and
deadly
upon
him
,
and
he
on
them
.
<EOS>
He
found
a
likeness
to
his
misfortune
everywhere
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
remorseless
triumph
going
on
about
him
,
and
it
galled
and
stung
him
in
his
pride
and
jealousy
,
<EOS>
whatever
form
it
took
:
<EOS>
though
most
of
all
when
it
divided
with
him
the
love
and
memory
of
his
lost
boy
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
face
<EOS>
---
he
had
looked
upon
it
,
on
the
previous
night
,
and
it
on
him
with
eyes
that
read
his
soul
,
though
they
were
dim
with
tears
,
and
hidden
soon
behind
two
quivering
hands
---
that
often
had
attended
him
in
fancy
,
on
this
ride
.
<EOS>
He
had
seen
it
,
with
the
expression
of
last
night
,
timidly
pleading
to
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
reproachful
,
but
there
was
something
of
doubt
,
almost

in
it
,
which
,
as
he
once
more
saw
that
fade
away
into
a
desolate

of
his
dislike
,
was
like
reproach
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
trouble
to
him
to
think
of
this
face
of
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
Because
he
felt
any
new
compunction
towards
it
?
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Because
the
feeling
it
awakened
in
him
---
of
which
he
had
had
some
old
foreshadowing
in
older
times
---
was
full
-
formed
now
,
and
spoke
out
plainly
,
moving
him
too
much
,
and
threatening
to
grow
too
strong
for
his
composure
.
<EOS>
Because
the
face
was
abroad
,
in
the
expression
of
defeat
and
persecution
that
seemed
to

like
the
air
.
<EOS>
Because
it
barbed
the
arrow
of
that
cruel
and
remorseless
enemy
on
which
his
thoughts
so
ran
,
and
put
into
its

a
double

.
<EOS>
Because
he
knew
full
well
,
in

,
as

,
tinging
the

of
transition
before

with

morbid

of

,
and

,

,

,
that

.
<EOS>
One
child
was
gone
,
and
one
child
left
.
<EOS>
Why
was
the
object
of
his
hope
removed
instead
of
her
?
  
<EOS>
The
sweet
,
calm
,
gentle
presence
in
his
fancy
,
moved
him
to
no
reflection
but
that
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
unwelcome
to
him
from
the
first
;
she
was
an
aggravation
of
his

now
.
<EOS>
If
his
son
had
been
his
only
child
,
and
the
same
blow
had
fallen
on
him
,
it
would
have
been
heavy

bear
;
but
infinitely
lighter
than
now
,
when

might
have
fallen
on
her
(
whom
he
could

lost
,
or
he
believed
it
,
without

)
,
and
had
not
.
<EOS>
Her
loving
and
innocent
face
rising
before
him
,
and
had
no

or
winning

.
<EOS>
He
rejected
the
angel
,
and
took
up
with
the
tormenting

in

.
<EOS>
Her

,
goodness
,
youth
,
devotion
,
love
,
were
as
so
many
atoms
in
the
ashes
upon
which

.
<EOS>
He
saw
her
image
in
the
blight
and
blackness
all

,
not

but

.
<EOS>
More
than
once
upon
this
journey
,
and
how
again
as

at
this
journey
's
end
,
tracing

,
the

into
his
mind
,
<EOS>
what
was

could

between

?
  
<EOS>
The
Major
,
who
had
been
blowing
and

all

,

,
and
whose

,

by

<EOS>
"
Dombey
,
"
said

Major
,

,
"
do

.
<EOS>
It
's

.
<EOS>
Old
Joe
,
Sir
,
would

,

.
<EOS>
You

great
<EOS>
a

,

,

.
<EOS>
In
your
position
,
Sir
,
you
're
far

that

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
even
in
his
friendly

,
thus
consulting
the

and

of
Mr
Dombey
,
and

a

of

,
Mr

felt

to
defer

;

Major

,

along
the

;
and
the
Major
,

both

a

his

than
the

they
had
just

,
came
out
for

.
  
<EOS>
In
this
flow
of
spirits
and
conversation
,
only
interrupted
by
his
usual
plethoric
symptoms
,
and
by

of

,
and
from

by
some

upon
the
Native
,
who
wore
a
pair

ear
-
rings
in
his
dark
-
brown
ears
,
and
on

his
European

sat
with

of

---
being
,

own

,
and
without
any
reference
to
the
tailor
's
art
,
long
where
they
ought
to
be
short
,
short
where
they
ought

long
,
tight

,
and
loose
where
they
ought
to
be
tight
---
and
to

he

a
new

,

the
Major
attacked

,
by

into

like

,

---
in
this
flow
of
spirits
and
conversation
,
the
Major
continued
all
day
:
so
that
when
evening
came
on
,
and
found
them
trotting
through
the
green
and
leafy
road
near
Leamington
,
the
Major
's
voice
,
what
with
talking
and
eating
and
chuckling
and
choking
,
appeared
to
be
in
the
box
under
the
rumble
,
or

some

hay
-
stack
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
the
Major
improve
it
at
the
Royal
Hotel
,
where
rooms
and
dinner
had
been
ordered
,
and
where
he
so
oppressed
his
organs
of
speech
by
eating
and
drinking
,
that
when
he
retired
to
bed
he
had
no
voice
at
all
,
except

cough
with
,
and
could
only
make
himself
intelligible
to
the
dark
servant
by
gasping

.
  
<EOS>
He
not
only
rose
next
morning
,
however
,
like
a
giant
refreshed
,
but
conducted
himself
,
at
breakfast
,
like
a
giant
refreshing
.
<EOS>
At
this
meal
they
arranged
their
daily
habits
.
<EOS>
The
Major
was
to
take
the
responsibility
or
ordering
everything
to
eat
and
drink
;
and
they
were
to
have
a
late
breakfast
together
every
morning
,
and
a
late
dinner
together
every
day
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
would
prefer
remaining
in
his
own
room
,
or
walking
in
the
country
by
himself
,
on
that

of

Leamington
;
but
next
morning
he
would
be
happy
to

the
Major
to
the
Pump
-
room
,
and
about
the
town
.
<EOS>
So
they
parted
until
dinner
-
time
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
retired
to
nurse
his
wholesome
thoughts
in
his
own
way
.
<EOS>
The
Major
,
attended
by
the
Native
carrying
a
camp
-
stool
,
a
great
-
coast
,
and
an
umbrella
,
swaggered
up
and
down
through
all
the
public
places
:
looking
into
subscription
books
to
find
out
who
was
there
,
looking
up
old
ladies
by
whom
he
was
much
admired
,
reporting
JB
tougher
than
ever
,
and
puffing
his
rich
friend
Dombey
wherever
he
went
.
<EOS>
There
never
was
a
man
who
stood
by
a
friend
more
staunchly
than
the
Major
,
when
in
puffing
him
,
he
puffed
himself
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
surprising
how
much
new
conversation
the
Major
had
to
let
off
at
dinner
-
time
,
and
what
occasion
he
gave
Mr
Dombey
to
admire
his
social
qualities
.
<EOS>
At
breakfast
next
morning
,
he
knew
the
contents
of
the
latest
newspapers
received
;
and
mentioned
several
subjects
in
connexion
with
them
,
on
which
his
opinion
had
recently
been
sought
by
persons
of
such
power
and
might
,
that
they
were
only
to
be
obscurely
hinted
at
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
who
had
been
so
long
shut
up
within
himself
,
and
who
had
rarely
,
at
any
time
,
overstepped
the
enchanted
circle
within
which
the
operations
of
Dombey
and
Son
were
conducted
,
began
to
think
this
an
improvement
on
his
solitary
life
;
and
in
place
of
excusing
himself
for
another
day
,
as
he
had
thought
of
doing
when
alone
,
walked
out
with
the
Major
arm
-
in
-
arm
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
21
.
<EOS>
New
Faces
 
<EOS>
THE
Major
,
more
blue
-
faced
and
staring
---
more
over
-
ripe
,
as
it
were
,
than
ever
---
and
giving
vent
,
every
now
and
then
,
to
one
of
the
horse
's
coughs
,
not
so
much
of
necessity
as
in
a
spontaneous
explosion
of
importance
,
walked
arm
-
in
-
arm
with
Mr
Dombey
up
the
sunny
side
of
the
way
,
with
his
cheeks
swelling
over
his
tight
stock
,
his
legs
majestically
wide
apart
,
and
his
great
head
wagging
from
side
to
side
,
as
if
he
were
remonstrating
within
himself
for
being
such
a
captivating
object
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
walked
many
yards
,
before
the
Major
encountered
somebody
else
he
knew
,
nor
many
yards
farther
before
the
Major
encountered
somebody
else
he
knew
,
but
he
merely
shook
his
fingers
at
them
as
he
passed
,
and
led
Mr
Dombey
on
:
pointing
out
the
localities
as
they
went
,
and
enlivening
the
walk
with
any
current
scandal
suggested
by
them
.
  
<EOS>
In
this
manner
the
Major
and
Mr
Dombey
were
walking
arm
-
in
-
arm
,
much
to
their
own
satisfaction
,
when
they
beheld
advancing
towards
them
,
a
wheeled
chair
,
in
which
a
lady
was
seated
,
indolently
steering
her
carriage
by
a
kind
of
rudder
in
front
,
while
it
was
propelled
by
some
unseen
power
in
the
rear
.
<EOS>
Although
the
lady
was
not
young
,
she
was
very
blooming
in
the
face
---
quite
rosy
---
and
her
dress
and
attitude
were
perfectly
juvenile
.
<EOS>
Walking
by
the
side
of
the
chair
,
and
carrying
her
gossamer
parasol
with
a
proud
and
weary
air
,
as
if
so
great
an
effort
must
be
soon
abandoned
and
the
parasol
dropped
,
sauntered
a
much
younger
lady
,
very
handsome
,
<EOS>
very
haughty
,
very
wilful
,
who
tossed
her
head
and
drooped
her
eyelids
,
as
though
,
if
there
were
anything
in
all
the
world
worth
looking
into
,
save
a
mirror
,
it
certainly
was
not
the
earth
or
sky
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
the
devil
have
we
here
,
Sir
!
"
cried
the
Major
,
stopping
as
this
little
cavalcade
drew
near
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
Edith
!
<EOS>
"
drawled
the
lady
in
the
chair
,
"
Major
Bagstock
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
Major
no
sooner
heard
the
voice
,
than
he
relinquished
Mr
Dombey
's
arm
,
darted
forward
,
took
the
hand
of
the
lady
in
the
chair
and
pressed
it
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
With
no
less
gallantry
,
the
Major
folded
both
his
gloves
upon
his
heart
,
and
bowed
low
to
the
other
lady
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
the
chair
having

,
the
motive
power
became
visible
in
the
shape
of
a
flushed
page
pushing
behind
,
who
seemed
to
have
in
part

and
in
part
out
-
pushed
his
strength
,
for
when

stood
upright
<EOS>
he
was
tall
,
and

,
and
thin
,
and
his

appeared
the
more
forlorn
from
his
having
injured
the
shape
of
his
hat
,
by
butting

carriage

his
head
to
urge

,
as
is

.
  
<EOS>
"
Joe
Bagstock
,
"
said

Major
to

,
"
is
a
proud

man
for

rest

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
false

!
<EOS>
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
Where
do

come

?
<EOS>
I
ca

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
Mrs
Skewton
.
<EOS>
"
The

.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
Mrs
Granger
.
<EOS>
"

's

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

seemed

,
for

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs

,
Dombey
,
"

"
makes
havoc

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

signified

did

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

!
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

a

,

"

,

,

false

,
"
in

what's
-
its
-

---
"
  
"
Eden
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
Mama
,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

Edith
,
"
said

,
"
I
can
not

.
<EOS>
I
never
can
remember
those

names
---
without
having
your
whole
Soul
and
Being
inspired
by
the

Nature
;
by
the

,
"

,

that
was
faint

with

,
"
of
her
artless
breath
,
you
creature
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
discrepancy
between
Mrs
Skewton
's
fresh
enthusiasm
of
words
,
and
forlornly
faded
manner
,
was
hardly
less
observable
than
that
between
her
age
,
which
was
about
seventy
,
and
her
dress
,
which
would
have
been
youthful
for
twenty
-
seven
.
<EOS>
Her
attitude
in
the
wheeled
chair
(
which
she
never
varied
)
was
one
in
which
she
had
been
taken
in
a
barouche
,
some
fifty
years
before
,
by
a
then
fashionable
artist
who
had
appended
to
his
published
sketch
the
name
of
Cleopatra
:
in
consequence
of
a
discovery
made
by
the
critics
of
the
time
,
that
it
bore
an
exact
resemblance
to
that
Princess
as
she
reclined
on
board
her
galley
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
was
a
beauty
then
,
and
bucks
threw
wine
-
glasses
over
their
heads
by
dozens
in
her
honor
.
<EOS>
The
beauty
and
the
barouche
had
both
passed
away
,
but
she
still
preserved
the
attitude
,
and
for
this
reason
expressly
,
maintained
the
wheeled
chair
and
the
butting
page
:
there
being
nothing
whatever
,
except
the
attitude
,
to
prevent
her
from
walking
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dombey
is
devoted
to
Nature
,
I
trust
?
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
settling
her
diamond
brooch
.
<EOS>
And
by
the
way
,
she
chiefly
lived
upon
the
reputation
of
some
diamonds
,
and
her
family
connexions
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
friend
Dombey
,
Ma'am
,
"
returned
the
Major
,
"
may
be
devoted
to
her
in

,
but
a
man
who
is
paramount

the
greatest

in
the
universe
---
"
  
"
No
one
can
be
a
stranger
,
"
said
Mrs

,
"
to
Mr
Dombey
's
immense
influence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
Mr
Dombey
acknowledged
the

with
a

,
the

glancing
at

,
met

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
reside
here
,

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

have

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Mama

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Edith

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
They
libel

.
<EOS>
There

,

"

,

,
"
for

I

,

I

.
<EOS>
People

.
<EOS>
But

my
what

<EOS>
his

---
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,
Mr
Dombey
,
Nature

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Cows

.
<EOS>
What
I

,

,

---
and

.
"
  
<EOS>
This

,

who

,

Nature
was

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,
"

,

,
"
is
heart
.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"

.

.

"
Where

?
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>

,

"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
again

to
his
blue

the

were
disposed

of
the

,
after

Cleopatra

:
and

.
<EOS>
The

with

;
the

with
the
very

of
her

that
common

allowed
.
  
<EOS>
The
last
glimpse
of
the
wrinkled

of
the
mother
,
with
that

on

which
the

infinitely
more

,
and
of

,

,

turned

.
<EOS>
The
Page
,
nearly
as
much

as
his
own

,
was

chair
,
uphill
,
like

slow

ram
;
<EOS>
the
top
of

's

was
fluttering

to
the
inch
as
before
;

,

by

,

,

,

of

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
as

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
Joe
Bagstock
were

,

"

<EOS>
"

-

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
Withers

<EOS>

<EOS>
Whether
