"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
is
.
<EOS>
Everybody
says
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
cousin
Feenix
raves
about
it
,
Edith
,
"
interposed
her
mother
from
her
couch
.
  
<EOS>
The
daughter
slightly
turned
her
graceful
head
,
and
raising
her
eyebrows
by
a
hair's
-
breadth
,
as
if
her
cousin
Feenix
were
of
all
the
mortal
world
the
least
to
be
regarded
,
turned
her
eyes
again
towards
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
for
the
credit
of
my
good
taste
,
that
I
am
tired
of
the
neighbourhood
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
almost
reason
to
be
,
Madam
,
"
he
replied
,
glancing
at
a
variety
of
landscape
drawings
,
of
which
he
had
already
recognised
several
as
representing
neighbouring
points
of
view
,
and
which
were
strewn
abundantly
about
the
room
,
"
if
these
beautiful
productions
are
from
your
hand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
gave
him
no
reply
,
but
sat
in
a
disdainful
beauty
,
quite
amazing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
they
that
interest
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
Are
they
yours
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
play
,
I
already
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
sing
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
answered
all
these
questions
with
a
strange
reluctance
;
and
with
that
remarkable
air
of
opposition
to
herself
,
already
noticed
as
belonging
to
her
beauty
.
<EOS>
Yet
she
was
not
embarrassed
,
but
wholly
self
-
possessed
.
<EOS>
Neither
did
she
seem
to
wish
to
avoid
the
conversation
,
for
she
addressed
her
face
,
and
---
so
far
as
she
could
---
her
manner
also
,
to
him
;
and
continued
to
do
so
,
when
he
was
silent
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
many
resources
against
weariness
at
least
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whatever
their
efficiency
may
be
,
"
she
returned
,
"
you
know
them
all
now
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
hope
to
prove
them
all
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
with
solemn
gallantry
,
laying
down
a
drawing
he
had
held
,
and
motioning
towards
the
harp
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
certainly
!
<EOS>
If
you
desire
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
rose
as
she
spoke
,
and
crossing
by
her
mother
's
couch
,
and
directing
a
stately
look
towards
her
,
which
was
instantaneous
in
its
duration
,
but
inclusive
(
if
any
one
had
seen
it
)
of
a
multitude
of
expressions
,
among
which
that
of
the
twilight
smile
,
without
the
smile
itself
,
overshadowed
all
the
rest
,
went
out
of
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
The
major
,
who
was
quite
forgiven
by
this
time
,
had
wheeled
a
little
table
up
to
Cleopatra
,
and
was
sitting
down
to
play
picquet
with
her
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
not
knowing
the
game
,
sat
down
to
watch
them
for
his
edification
until
Edith
should
return
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
going
to
have
some
music
,
Mr
Dombey
,
I
hope
?
"
said
Cleopatra
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Granger
has
been
kind
enough
to
promise
so
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
That
's
very
nice
.
<EOS>
Do
you
propose
,
Major
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
.
<EOS>
"
Could
n't
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
barbarous
being
,
"
replied
the
lady
,
"
and
my
hand
's
destroyed
.
<EOS>
You
are
fond
of
music
,
Mr
Dombey
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Eminently
so
,
"
was
Mr
Dombey
's
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
It
's
very
nice
,
"
said
Cleopatra
,
looking
at
her
cards
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
much
heart
in
it
---
undeveloped
recollections
of
a
previous
state
of
existence
---
and
all
that
---
which
is
so
truly
charming
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
"
simpered
Cleopatra
,
reversing
the
knave
of
clubs
,
who
had
come
into
her
game
with
his
heels
uppermost
,
"
that
if
anything
could
tempt
me
to
put
a
period
to
my
life
,
it
would
be
curiosity
to
find
out
what
it
's
all
about
,
and
what
it
means
;
there
are
so
many
provoking
mysteries
,
really
,
that
are
hidden
from
us
.
<EOS>
Major
,
you
to
play
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
played
;
and
Mr
Dombey
,
looking
on
for
his
instruction
,
would
soon
have
been
in
a
state
of
dire
confusion
,
but
that
he
gave
no
attention
to
the
game
whatever
,
and
sat
wondering
instead
when
Edith
would
come
back
.
  
<EOS>
She
came
at
last
,
and
sat
down
to
her
harp
,
and
Mr
Dombey
rose
and
stood
beside
her
,
listening
.
<EOS>
He
had
little
taste
for
music
,
and
no
knowledge
of
the
strain
she
played
,
but
he
saw
her
bending
over
it
,
and
perhaps
he
heard
among
the
sounding
strings
some
distant
music
of
his
own
,
that
tamed
the
monster
of
the
iron
road
,
and
made
it
less
inexorable
.
  
<EOS>
Cleopatra
had
a
sharp
eye
,
verily
,
at
picquet
.
<EOS>
It
glistened
like
a
bird
's
,
and
did
not
fix
itself
upon
the
game
,
but
pierced
the
room
from
end
to
end
,
and
gleamed
on
harp
,
performer
,
listener
,
everything
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
haughty
beauty
had
concluded
,
she
arose
,
and
receiving
Mr
Dombey
's
thanks
and
compliments
in
exactly
the
same
manner
as
before
,
went
with
scarcely
any
pause
to
the
piano
,
and
began
there
.
  
<EOS>
Edith
Granger
,
any
song
but
that
!
<EOS>
Edith
Granger
,
you
are
very
handsome
,
and
your
touch
upon
the
keys
is
brilliant
,
and
your
voice
is
deep
and
rich
;
but
not
the
air
that
his
neglected
daughter
sang
to
his
dead
son
!
  
<EOS>
Alas
,
he
knows
it
not
;
and
if
he
did
,
what
air
of
hers
would
stir
him
,
rigid
man
!
<EOS>
Sleep
lonely
Florence
,
sleep
!
<EOS>
Peace
in
thy
dreams
,
although
the
night
has
turned
dark
,
and
the
clouds
are
gathering
,
and
threaten
to
discharge
themselves
in
hail
!
   
<EOS>
Chapter
22
.
<EOS>
A
Trifle
of
Management
by
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
 
<EOS>
MR
CARKER
<EOS>
the
Manager
sat
at
his
desk
,
smooth
and
soft
as
usual
,
reading
those
letters
which
were
reserved
for
him
to
open
,
backing
them
occasionally
with
such
memoranda
and
references
as
their
business
purport
required
,
and
parcelling
them
out
into
little
heaps
for
distribution
through
the
several
departments
of
the
House
.
<EOS>
The
post
had
come
in
heavy
that
morning
,
and
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
had
a
good
deal
to
do
.
  
<EOS>
The
general
action
of
a
man
so
engaged
---
pausing
to
look
over
a
bundle
of
papers
in
his
hand
,
dealing
them
round
in
various
portions
,
taking
up
another
bundle
and
examining
its
contents
with
knitted
brows
and
pursed
-
out
lips
---
dealing
,
and
sorting
,
and
pondering
by
turns
---
would
easily
suggest
some
whimsical
resemblance
to
a
player
at
cards
.
<EOS>
The
face
of
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
was
in
good
keeping
with
such
a
fancy
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
face
of
a
man
who
studied
his
play
,
warily
:
who
made
himself
master
of
all
the
strong
and
weak
points
of
the
game
:
who
registered
the
cards
in
his
mind
as
they
fell
about
him
,
knew
exactly
what
was
on
them
,
what
they
missed
,
and
what
they
made
:
who
was
crafty
to
find
out
what
the
other
players
held
,
and
who
never
betrayed
his
own
hand
.
  
<EOS>
The
letters
were
in
various
languages
,
but
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
read
them
all
.
<EOS>
If
there
had
been
anything
in
the
offices
of
Dombey
and
Son
that
he
could
not
read
,
there
would
have
been
a
card
wanting
in
the
pack
.
<EOS>
He
read
almost
at
a
glance
,
and
made
combinations
of
one
letter
with
another
and
one
business
with
another
as
he
went
on
,
adding
new
matter
to
the
heaps
---
much
as
a
man
would
know
the
cards
at
sight
,
and
work
out
their
combinations
in
his
mind
after
they
were
turned
.
<EOS>
Something
too
deep
for
a
partner
,
and
much
too
deep
for
an
adversary
,
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
sat
in
the
rays
of
the
sun
that
came
down
slanting
on
him
through
the
skylight
,
playing
his
game
alone
.
  
<EOS>
And
although
it
is
not
among
the
instincts
wild
or
domestic
of
the
cat
tribe
to
play
at
cards
,
feline
from
sole
to
crown
was
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
,
as
he
basked
in
the
strip
of
summer
-
light
and
warmth
that
shone
upon
his
table
and
the
ground
as
if
they
were
a
crooked
dial
-
plate
,
and
himself
the
only
figure
on
it
.
<EOS>
With
hair
and
whiskers
deficient
in
colour
at
all
times
,
but
feebler
than
common
in
the
rich
sunshine
,
and
more
like
the
coat
of
a
sandy
tortoise
-
shell
cat
;
with
long
nails
,
nicely
pared
and
sharpened
;
with
a
natural
antipathy
to
any
speck
of
dirt
,
which
made
him
pause
sometimes
and
watch
the
falling
motes
of
dust
,
and
rub
them
off
his
smooth
white
hand
or
glossy
linen
:
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
,
sly
of
manner
,
sharp
of
tooth
,
soft
of
foot
,
watchful
of
eye
,
oily
of
tongue
,
cruel
of
heart
,
nice
of
habit
,
sat
with
a
dainty
steadfastness
and
patience
at
his
work
,
as
if
he
were
waiting
at
a
mouse
's
hole
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
the
letter
were
disposed
of
,
excepting
one
which
he
reserved
for
a
particular
audience
.
<EOS>
Having
locked
the
more
confidential
correspondence
in
a
drawer
,
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
rang
his
bell
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
youanswer
it
?
<EOS>
"
was
his
reception
of
his
brother
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
messenger
is
out
,
and
I
am
the
next
,
"
was
the
submissive
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
next
?
"
<EOS>
muttered
the
Manager
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
Creditable
to
me
!
<EOS>
There
!
"
  
<EOS>
Pointing
to
the
heaps
of
opened
letters
,
he
turned
disdainfully
away
,
in
his
elbow
-
chair
,
and
broke
the
seal
of
that
one
which
he
held
in
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
trouble
you
,
James
,
"
said
the
brother
,
gathering
them
up
,
"
but
"
  
"
Oh
!
you
have
something
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
knew
that
.
<EOS>
Well
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
did
not
raise
his
eyes
or
turn
them
on
his
brother
,
but
kept
them
on
his
letter
,
though
without
opening
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
he
repeated
sharply
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
uneasy
about
Harriet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Harriet
who
?
<EOS>
what
Harriet
?
<EOS>
I
know
nobody
of
that
name
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
not
well
,
and
has
changed
very
much
of
late
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
changed
very
much
,
a
great
many
years
ago
,
"
replied
the
Manager
;
"
and
that
is
all
I
have
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
if
you
would
hear
me
---
"
  
"
Why
should
I
hear
you
,
Brother
John
?
"
returned
the
Manager
,
laying
a
sarcastic
emphasis
on
those
two
words
,
and
throwing
up
his
head
,
but
not
lifting
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
Harriet
Carker
made
her
choice
many
years
ago
between
her
two
brothers
.
<EOS>
She
may
repent
it
,
but
she
must
abide
by
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
mistake
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
say
she
does
repent
it
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
black
ingratitude
in
me
to
hint
at
such
a
thing
,
"
returned
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
Though
believe
me
,
James
,
I
am
as
sorry
for
her
sacrifice
as
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
I
?
"
exclaimed
the
Manager
.
<EOS>
"
As
I
?
"
  
"
As
sorry
for
her
choice
---
for
what
you
call
her
choice
---
as
you
are
angry
at
it
,
"
said
the
Junior
.
  
<EOS>
"
Angry
?
"
repeated
the
other
,
with
a
wide
show
of
his
teeth
.
  
<EOS>
"
Displeased
.
<EOS>
Whatever
word
you
like
best
.
<EOS>
You
know
my
meaning
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
offence
in
my
intention
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
offence
in
everything
you
do
,
"
replied
his
brother
,
glancing
at
him
with
a
sudden
scowl
,
which
in
a
moment
gave
place
to
a
wider
smile
than
the
last
.
<EOS>
"
Carry
those
papers
away
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
I
am
busy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
politeness
was
so
much
more
cutting
than
his
wrath
,
that
the
Junior
went
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
But
stopping
at
it
,
and
looking
round
,
he
said
:
  
"
When
Harriet
tried
in
vain
to
plead
for
me
with
you
,
on
your
first
just
indignation
,
and
my
first
disgrace
;
and
when
she
left
you
,
James
,
to
follow
my
broken
fortunes
,
and
devote
herself
,
in
her
mistaken
affection
,
to
a
ruined
brother
,
because
without
her
he
had
no
one
,
and
was
lost
;
she
was
young
and
pretty
.
<EOS>
I
think
if
you
could
see
her
now
---
if
you
would
go
and
see
her
---
she
would
move
your
admiration
and
compassion
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Manager
inclined
his
head
,
and
showed
his
teeth
,
as
who
should
say
,
in
answer
to
some
careless
small
-
talk
,
"
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
Is
that
the
case
?
"
but
said
never
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
thought
in
those
days
:
you
and
I
both
:
that
she
would
marry
young
,
and
lead
a
happy
and
light
-
hearted
life
,
"
pursued
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
if
you
knew
how
cheerfully
she
cast
those
hopes
away
;
how
cheerfully
she
has
gone
forward
on
the
path
she
took
,
and
never
once
looked
back
;
you
never
could
say
again
that
her
name
was
strange
in
your
ears
.
<EOS>
Never
!
"
  
<EOS>
Again
the
Manager
inclined
his
head
,
and
showed
his
teeth
,
and
seemed
to
say
,
"
Remarkable
indeed
!
<EOS>
You
quite
surprise
me
!
"
<EOS>
And
again
he
uttered
never
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
go
on
?
"
said
John
Carker
,
mildly
.
  
<EOS>
"
On
your
way
?
"
replied
his
smiling
brother
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
have
the
goodness
.
"
  
<EOS>
John
Carker
,
with
a
sigh
,
was
passing
slowly
out
at
the
door
,
when
his
brother
's
voice
detained
him
for
a
moment
on
the
threshold
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
she
has
gone
,
and
goes
,
her
own
way
cheerfully
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
,
throwing
the
still
unfolded
letter
on
his
desk
,
and
putting
his
hands
firmly
in
his
pockets
,
"
you
may
tell
her
that
I
go
as
cheerfully
on
mine
.
<EOS>
If
she
has
never
once
looked
back
,
you
may
tell
her
that
I
have
,
sometimes
,
to
recall
her
taking
part
with
you
,
and
that
my
resolution
is
no
easier
to
wear
away
;
"
he
smiled
very
sweetly
here
;
"
than
marble
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
her
nothing
of
you
.
<EOS>
We
never
speak
about
you
.
<EOS>
Once
a
year
,
on
your
birthday
,
Harriet
says
always
,
"
Let
us
remember
James
by
name
,
and
wish
him
happy
,
"
but
we
say
no

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
it
then
,
if
you
please
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
to
yourself
.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
repeat
it
too
often
,
as
a
lesson
to
you
to
avoid
the
subject
in
speaking
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
know
no
Harriet
Carker
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
such
person
.
<EOS>
Youmay
have
a
sister
;
make
much
of
her
.
<EOS>
I
have
none
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
took
up
the
letter
again
,
and
waved
it
with
a
smile
of
mock
courtesy
towards
the
door
.
<EOS>
Unfolding
it
as
his
brother
withdrew
,
and
looking
darkly
after
him
as
he
left
the
room
,
he
once
more
turned
round
in
his
elbow
-
chair
,
and
applied
himself
to
a
diligent
perusal
of
its
contents
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
writing
of
his
great
chief
,
Mr
Dombey
,
and
dated
from
Leamington
.
<EOS>
Though
he
was
a
quick
reader
of
all
other
letters
,
Mr
Carker
read
this
slowly
;
weighing
the
words
as
he
went
,
and
bringing
every
tooth
in
his
head
to
bear
upon
them
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
read
it
through
once
,
he
turned
it
over
again
,
and
picked
out
these
passages
.
<EOS>
"
I
find
myself
benefited
by
the
change
,
and
am
not
yet
inclined
to
name
any
time
for
my
return
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
wish
,
Carker
,
you
would
arrange
to
come
down
once
and
see
me
here
,
and
let
me
know
how
things
are
going
on
,
in
person
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
omitted
to
speak
to
you
about
young
Gay
.
<EOS>
If
not
gone
per
Son
and
Heir
,
or
if
Son
and
Heir
still
lying
in
the
Docks
,
appoint
some
other
young
man
and
keep
him
in
the
City
for
the
present
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
decided
.
"
<EOS>
"
Now
that
's
unfortunate
!
"
said
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
,
expanding

mouth
,
as
if
it
were
made
of
India
-

:
"
for
he
is
far
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Still
that
passage
,
which
was
in
a
postscript
,
attracted
his
attention
and
his
teeth
,
once
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
he
said
,
"
my
good
friend
Captain
Cuttle
mentioned
something
about
being

along
in
the
wake
of
that
day
.
<EOS>
What
a
pity
he
's
so
far
away
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
refolded
the
letter
,
and
was
sitting
trifling
with

,
standing
it
long
-
wise
and
broad
-

,
and

over

over
on
all

---
doing
pretty

the
same
thing
,
perhaps
,
by

---
when
Mr
Perch
the

knocked

,
and
coming

,

,
laid
some

on

.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
please
to
be
engaged
,
Sir
?
"
asked
Mr
Perch
,
rubbing

,

,
like

who

hold

in

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
wants

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Perch
,
in

"
really

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr
Gills
the

's

,

,

<EOS>

,
Sir

;
several

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Perch
coughed

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Anybody
else
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
,
"

,
"
I

;

"

"

,

of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

"

,

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,

,
"

,

<EOS>

"

,
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,

,
"

,
"

,

<EOS>
as

,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
grinned

like

,
but
in

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Whether
,
"

,

<EOS>

,
"

,
"
<EOS>
I

,
myself
,
by

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
Begging

,

,
"

Perch
,

,
"
he
's

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
I

Mr
Gills
directly
.
<EOS>
Ask

to

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Perch
bowed
;
and
shutting
the
door
,
as
precisely
and
carefully
as
if
he
were
not
coming
back
for
a
week
,
went
on
his
quest
among
the
sparrows
in
the
court
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
gone
,
Mr
Carker
assumed
his
favourite
attitude
before
the
fire
-
place
,
and
stood
looking
at
the
door
;
presenting
,
with
his
under
lip
tucked
into
the
smile
that
showed
his
whole
row
of
upper
teeth
,
a
singularly
crouching
appearance
.
  
<EOS>
The
messenger
was
not
long
in
returning
,
followed
by
a
pair
of
heavy
boots
that
came
bumping
along
the
passage
like
boxes
.
<EOS>
With
the
unceremonious
words
"
Come
along
with
you
!
"
<EOS>
---
a
very
unusual
form
of
introduction
from
his
lips
---
Mr
Perch
then
ushered
into
the
presence
a
strong
-
built
lad
of
fifteen
,
with
a
round
red
face
,
a
round
sleek
head
,
round
black
eyes
,
round
limbs
,
and
round
body
,
who
,
to
carry
out
the
general
rotundity
of
his
appearance
,
had
a
round
hat
in
his
hand
,
without
a
particle
of
brim
to
it
.
  
<EOS>
Obedient
to
a
nod
from
Mr
Carker
,
Perch
had
no
sooner
confronted
the
visitor
with
that
gentleman
than
he
withdrew
.
<EOS>
The
moment
they
were
face
to
face
alone
,
Mr
Carker
,
without
a
word
of
preparation
,
took
him
by
the
throat
,
and
shook
him
until
his
head
seemed
loose
upon
his
shoulders
.
  
<EOS>
The
boy
,
who
in
the
midst
of
his
astonishment
could
not
help
staring
wildly
at
the
gentleman
with
so
many
white
teeth
who
was
choking
him
,
and
at
the
office
walls
,
as
though
determined
,
if
he
were
choked
,
that
his
last
look
should
be
at
the
mysteries
for
his
intrusion
into
which
he
was
paying
such
a
severe
penalty
,
at
last
contrived
to
utter
---
   
"
Come
,
Sir
!
<EOS>
You
let
me
alone
,
will
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
you
alone
!
"
said
Mr
Carker
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
I
have
got
you
,
have
I
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
There
was
no
doubt
of
that
,
and
tightly
too
.
<EOS>
"
You
dog
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
through
his
set
jaws
,
"
I
'll
strangle
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
Biler
whimpered
,
would
he
though
?
<EOS>
oh
no
<EOS>
he
would
n't
---
<EOS>
and
what
was
he
doing
of
---
and
why
did
n't
he
strangle
somebody
of
his
own
size
and
not
him
:
but
Biler
was
quelled
by
the
extraordinary
nature
of
his
reception
,
and
,
as
his
head
became
stationary
,
and
he
looked
the
gentleman
in
the
face
,
or
rather

the
teeth
,
and
saw
him
snarling
at
him
<EOS>
,
he
so
far
forgot
his
manhood
as
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
done
nothing
to
you
,
Sir
,
"
said
Biler
,
otherwise
Rob
,
otherwise
Grinder
,
and
always
Toodle
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
young
scoundrel
!
"
replied
Mr
Carker
,
slowly
releasing
him
,
and
moving

a

into
his

.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
daring
to
come
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
mean
no
harm
,
Sir
,
"
whimpered
Rob
,
putting
one
hand
to
his
throat
,
and
the
knuckles
of

other
to
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
never
come
again
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
I
only
wanted
work
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Work
,
young
Cain
that
you
are
!
"
repeated
Mr
Carker
,
eyeing
him
narrowly
.
<EOS>
"
An't
you
the
idlest
vagabond
in
London
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
impeachment
,
while
it
much
affected
Mr
Toodle
Junior
,
attached
to
his
character
so
justly
,
that
he
could
not
say
a
word
in
denial
.
<EOS>
He
stood
looking
at
the
gentleman
,
therefore
,
with
a

,
self
-

,
and

air
.
<EOS>
As

his
looking
at
him
,
it
may

observed
that
he
was
fascinated
by
Mr
Carker
,
and
never
took
his
round

off
him
for
an
instant
.
  
<EOS>
"
An't
you
a
thief
?
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
with
his
hands
behind
him
in
his
pockets
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
"
pleaded
Rob
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
!
"
said
Mr
Carker
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
an't
indeed
,
Sir
,
"
whimpered
Rob
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
did
such
a
thing
as
thieve
,
Sir
,
if
you
'll
believe
me
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
've
been
going
wrong
,
Sir
,
ever
since
I
took
to
bird
-
catching
and
walking
-
matching
.
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
a
cove
might
think
,
"
said
Mr
Toodle
Junior
,
with
a
burst
of
penitence
,
"
that
singing
birds
was
innocent
company
,
but
nobody
knows
what
harm
is
in
them
little
creeturs
and
what
they
brings
you
down
to
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
seemed
to
have
brought
him
down
to
a
velveteen
jacket
and
trousers
very
much
the
worse
for
wear
,
a
particularly
small
red
waistcoat
like
a
gorget
,
an
interval
of
blue
check
,
and
the
hat
before
mentioned
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
an't
been
home
twenty
times
since
them
birds
got
their
will
of
me
,
"
said
Rob
,
"
and
that
's
ten
months
.
<EOS>
How
can
I
go
home
when
everybody
's
miserable
to
see
me
!
<EOS>
I
wonder
,
"
said
Biler
,
blubbering
outright
,
and
smearing
his
eyes
with
his
coat
-
cuff
,
"
that
I
have
n't
been
and
drownded
myself
over
and
over
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
All
of
which
,
including
his
expression
of
surprise
at
not
having
achieved
this
last
scarce
performance
,
the
boy
said
,
just
as
if
the
teeth
of
Mr
Carker
drew
it
out
of
him
,
and
he
had
no
power
of
concealing
anything
with
that
battery
of
attraction
in
full
play
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
nice
young
gentleman
!
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
shaking
his
head
at
him
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
hemp
-
seed
sown
for
you
,
my
fine
fellow
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
,
Sir
,
"
returned
the
wretched
Biler
,
blubbering
again
,
and
again
having
recourse
to
his
coat
-
cuff
:
"
I
should
n't
care
,
sometimes
,
if
it
was
growed
too
.
<EOS>
My
misfortunes
all
began
in
wagging
,
Sir
;
but
what
could
I
do
,
exceptin
'
wag
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Excepting
what
?
"
said
Mr
Carker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wag
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Wagging
from
school
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
pretending
to
go
there
,
and
not
going
?
"
said
Mr
Carker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Sir
,
that
's
wagging
,
Sir
,
"
returned
the
quondam
Grinder
,
much
affected
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
chivied
through
the
streets
,
Sir
,
when
I
went
there
,
and
pounded
when
I
got
there
.
<EOS>
So
I
wagged
and
hid
myself
,
and
that
began
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
mean
to
tell
me
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
taking
him
by
the
throat
again
,
holding
him
out
at
arm's
-
length
,
and
surveying
him
in
silence
for
some
moments
,
"
that
you
want
a
place
,
do
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
thankful
to
be
tried
,
Sir
,
"
returned
Toodle
Junior
,
faintly
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
pushed
him
backward
into
a
corner
---
the
boy
submitting
quietly
,
hardly
venturing
to
breathe
,
and
never
once
removing
his
eyes
from
his
face
---
and
rang
the
bell
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
Mr
Gills
to
come
here
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Perch
was
too
deferential
to
express
surprise
or
recognition
of
the
figure
in
the
corner
:
and
Uncle
Sol
appeared
immediately
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Gills
!
<EOS>
"
said
Carker
,
with
a
smile
,
"
sit
down
.
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
You
continue
to
enjoy
your
health
,
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Sir
,
"
returned
Uncle
Sol
,
taking
out
his
pocket
-
book
,
and
handing
over
some
notes
as
he
spoke
.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
ails
me
in
body
but
old
age
.
<EOS>
Twenty
-
five
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
as
punctual
and
exact
,
Mr
Gills
,
"
replied
the
smiling
Manager
,
taking
a
paper
from
one
of
his
many

,
and
making
an
endorsement
on
it
,
while
Uncle
Sol
looked
over
him
,
"
as
one
of
your
own
chronometers
.
<EOS>
Quite
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
Son
and
Heir
has
not
been
spoken
,
I
find
by
the
list
,
Sir
,
"
said
Uncle
Sol
,
with
a
slight
addition
to
the
usual
tremor
in
his
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
Son
and
Heir
has
not
been
spoken
,
"
returned
Carker
.
<EOS>
"
There
seems
to
have
been
tempestuous
weather
,
Mr
Gills
,
and
she
has
probably
been
driven
out
of
her
course
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
safe
,
I
trust
in
Heaven
!
"
said
old
Sol
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
safe
,
I
trust
in
Heaven
!
"
<EOS>
assented
Mr
Carker
in
that
voiceless
manner
of
his
:
which
made
the
observant
young
Toodle
tremble
again
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Gills
,
"
he
added
aloud
,
throwing
himself
back
in
his
chair
,
"
you
must
miss
your
nephew
very
much
?
"
  
<EOS>
Uncle
Sol
,
standing
by
him
,
shook
his
head
and
heaved
a
deep
sigh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Gills
,
"
said
Carker
,
with
his
soft
hand
playing
round
his
mouth
,
and
looking
up
into
the
Instrument
-
maker
's
face
,
"
it
would
be
company
to
you
to
have
a
young
fellow
in
your
shop
just
now
,
and
it
would
be
obliging
me
if
you
would
give
one
house
-
room
for
the
present
.
<EOS>
No
,
to
be
sure
,
"
he
added
quickly
,
in
anticipation
of
what
the
old
man
was
going
to
say
,
"
there
's
not
much
business
doing
there
,
I
know
;
but
you
can
make
him
clean
the
place
out
,
polish
up
the
instruments
;
drudge
,
Mr
Gills
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
lad
!
"
  
<EOS>
Sol
Gills
pulled
down
his
spectacles
from
his
forehead
to
his
eyes
,
and
looked
at
Toodle
Junior
standing
upright
in
the
corner
:
<EOS>
his
head
presenting
the
appearance
(
which
it
always
did
)
of
having
been
newly
drawn
out
of
a
bucket
of
cold
water
;
his
small
waistcoat
rising
and
falling
quickly
in
the
play
of
this
emotions
;
and
his
eyes
intently
fixed
on
Mr
Carker
,
without
the
least
reference
to
his
proposed
master
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
give
him
house
-
room
,
Mr
Gills
?
"
said
the
Manager
.
  
<EOS>
Old
Sol
,
without
being
quite
enthusiastic
on
the
subject
,
replied
that
he
was
glad
of
any
opportunity
,
however
slight
,
to
oblige
Mr
Carker
,
whose
wish
on
such
a
point
was
a
command
:
and
that
the
Wooden
Midshipman
would
consider
himself
happy
to
receive
in
his
berth
any
visitor
of
Mr
Carker
's
selecting
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
bared
himself
to
the
tops
and
bottoms
of
his
gums
:
making
the
watchful
Toodle
Junior
tremble
more
and
more
:
and
acknowledged
the
Instrument
-
maker
's
politeness
in
his
most
affable
manner
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
dispose
of
him
so
,
then
,
Mr
Gills
,
"
he
answered
,
rising
,
and
shaking
the
old
man
by
the
hand
,
"
until
I
make
up
my
mind
what
to
do
with
him
,
and
what
he
deserves
.
<EOS>
As
I
consider
myself
responsible
for
him
,
Mr
Gills
,
<EOS>
"
here
he
smiled
a
wide
smile
at
Rob
,
who
shock
before
it
:
"
I
shall
be
glad
if
you
'll
look
sharply
after
him
,
and
report
his
behaviour
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
'll
ask
a
question
or
two
of
his
parents
as
I
ride
home
this
afternoon
---
respectable
people
---
to
confirm
some

in
his
own
account
of
himself
;
and
that
done
,
<EOS>
Mr
Gills
,
I
'll
send
him
round
to
you
to
-
morrow
morning
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
smile
at
parting
was
so
full
of
teeth
,
that
it
confused
old
Sol
,
and
made
him
vaguely
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
He
went
home
,
thinking
of
raging
seas
,
foundering
ships
,
drowning
men
,
an
ancient
bottle
of
Madeira
never
brought
to
light
,
and
other
dismal
matter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
boy
!
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
putting
his
hand
on
young
Toodle
's
shoulder
,
and
bringing
him
out
into
the
middle
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
Rob
said
,
"
Yes
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
understand
,
"
pursued
his
patron
,
"
that
if
you
ever
deceive
or
play
tricks
with
me
,
you
had
better
have
drowned
yourself
,
indeed
,
once
for
all
,
before
you
came
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
in
any
branch
of
mental
acquisition
that
Rob
seemed
to
understand
better
than
that
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
lied
to
me
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
"
in
anything
,
never
come
in
my
way
again
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
you
may
let
me
find
you
waiting
for
me
somewhere
near
your
mother
's
house
this
afternoon
.
<EOS>
I
shall
leave
this
at
five
o'clock
,
and
ride
there
on
horseback
.
<EOS>
Now
,
give
me
the
address
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Rob
repeated
it
slowly
,
as
Mr
Carker
wrote
it
down
.
<EOS>
Rob
even
spelt
it
over
a
second
time
,
letter
by
letter
,
as
if
he
thought
that
the
omission
of
a
dot
or
scratch
would
lead
to
his
destruction
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
then
handed
him
out
of
the
room
;
and
Rob
,
keeping
his
round
eyes
fixed
upon
his
patron
to
the
last
,
vanished
for
the
time
being
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
did
a
great
deal
of
business
in
the
course
of
the
day
,
and
bestowed
his
teeth
upon
a
great
many
people
.
<EOS>
In
the
office
,
in
the
court
,
in
the
street
,
and
on
'
Change
,
they
glistened
and
bristled
to
a
terrible
extent
.
<EOS>
Five
o'clock
arriving
,
and
with
it
Mr
Carker
's
bay
horse
,
they
got
on
horseback
,
and
went
gleaming
up
Cheapside
.
  
<EOS>
As
no
one
can
easily
ride
fast
,
even
if
inclined
to
do
so
,
through
the
press
and
throng
of
the
City
at
that
hour
,
and
as
Mr
Carker
was
not
inclined
,
he
went
leisurely
along
,
picking
his
way
among
the
carts
and
carriages
,
avoiding
whenever
he
could
<EOS>
the
wetter
and
more
dirty
places
in
the
over
-
watered
road
,
and
taking
infinite
pains
to
keep
himself
and
his
steed
clean
.
<EOS>
Glancing
at
the
passers
-
by
while
he
was
thus
ambling
on
his
way
,
he
suddenly
encountered
the
round
eyes
of
the
sleek
-
headed
Rob
intently
fixed
upon
his
face
as
if
they
had
never
been
taken
off
,
while
the
boy
himself
,
with
a
pocket
-
handkerchief
twisted
up
like
a
speckled
eel
and
girded
round
his
waist
,
made
a
very
conspicuous
demonstration
of
being
prepared
to
attend
upon
him
,
at
whatever
pace
he
might
think
proper
to
go
.
  
<EOS>
This
attention
,
however
flattering
,
being
one
of
an
unusual
kind
,
and
attracting
some
notice
from
the
other
passengers
,
Mr
Carker
took
advantage
of
a
clearer
thoroughfare
and
a
cleaner
road
,
and
broke
into
a
trot
.
<EOS>
Rob
immediately
did
the
same
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
presently
tried
a
canter
;
Rob
was
still
in
attendance
.
<EOS>
Then
a
short
gallop
;
it
was
all
one
to
the
boy
.
<EOS>
Whenever
Mr
Carker
turned
his
eyes
to
that
side
of
the
road
,
he
still
saw
Toodle
Junior
holding
his
course
,
apparently
without
distress
,
and
working
himself
along
by
the
elbows
after
the
most
approved
manner
of
professional
gentlemen
who
get
over
the
ground
for
wagers
.
  
<EOS>
Ridiculous
as
this
attendance
was
,
it
was
a
sign
of
an
influence
established
over
the
boy
,
and
therefore
Mr
Carker
,
affecting
not
to
notice
it
,
rode
away
into
the
neighbourhood
of
Mr
Toodle
's
house
.
<EOS>
On
his
slackening
his
pace
here
,
Rob
appeared
before
him
to
point
out
the
turnings
;
and
when
he
called
to
a
man
at
a
neighbouring
gateway
to
hold
his
horse
,
pending
his
visit
to
the
Buildings
that
had
succeeded
Staggs
's
Gardens
,
Rob
dutifully
held
the
stirrup
,
while
the
Manager
dismounted
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
taking
him
by
the
shoulder
,
"
come
along
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
prodigal
son
was
evidently
nervous
of
visiting
the
parental
abode
;
but
Mr
Carker
pushing
him
on
before
,
he
had
nothing
for
it
but
to
open
the
right
door
,
and
suffer
himself
to
be
walked
into
the
midst
of
his
brothers
and
sisters
,
mustered
in
overwhelming
force
round
the
family
tea
-
table
.
<EOS>
At
sight
of
the
prodigal
in
the
grasp
of
a
stranger
,
these
tender
relations
united
in
a
general
howl
,
which
smote
upon
the
prodigal
's
breast
so
sharply
when
he
saw
his
mother
stand
up
among
them
,
pale
and
trembling
,
with
the
baby
in
her
arms
,
that
he
lent
his
own
voice
to
the
chorus
.
  
<EOS>
Nothing
doubting
now
that
the
stranger
,
if
not
Mr
Ketch
in
person
,
was
one
of
that
company
,
the
whole
of
the
young
family
wailed
the
louder
,
while
its
more
infantine
members
,
unable
to
control
the
transports
of
emotion
appertaining
to
their
time
of
life
,
threw
themselves
on
their
backs
like
young
birds
when
terrified
by
a
hawk
,
and
kicked
violently
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
poor
Polly
making
herself
audible
,
said
,
with
quivering
lips
,
"
Oh
Rob
,
my
poor
boy
,
what
have
you
done
at
last
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
mother
,
"
cried
Rob
,
in
a
piteous
voice
,
"
ask
the
gentleman
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
alarmed
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
"
I
want
to
do
him
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
announcement
,
Polly
,
who
had
not
cried
yet
,
began
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
The
elder
Toodles
,
who
appeared
to
have
been
meditating
a
rescue
,
unclenched
their
fists
.
<EOS>
The
younger
Toodles
clustered
round
their
mother
's
gown
,
and
peeped
from
under
their
own
chubby
arms
at
their
desperado
brother
and
his
unknown
friend
.
<EOS>
Everybody
blessed
the
gentleman
with
the
beautiful
teeth
,
who
wanted
to
do
good
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
fellow
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
to
Polly
,
giving
him
a
gentle
shake
,
"
is
your
son
,
eh
,
Ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Sir
,
"
sobbed
Polly
,
with
a

;
"
yes
,
Sir
,
"
  
"
A
bad
son
<EOS>
,
I
am
afraid
?
"
said
Mr
Carker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
a
bad
son
to
me
,
Sir
,
"
returned

.
  
<EOS>
"
To
whom
then
?
"
said
Mr
Carker
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
a
little
wild
,
Sir
,
"
returned
Polly
,
checking
the
baby
,
who
was
making

with

and

to
launch
himself
on
Biler
,
through
the
ambient

,
"
and
has
gone
with
wrong
companions
:
but
I
hope
he
has
seen
the
misery
of
that
,
Sir
,
and
will
do
well
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
looked
at
Polly
,
and
the
clean
room
,
and
the
clean
children
,
and
the
simple
Toodle
face
,
combined
of
father
and
mother
,
that
was
reflected
and
repeated
everywhere
about
him
---
and
seemed
to
have
achieved
the
real
purpose
of
his
visit
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
husband
,
I
take
it
,
is
not
at
home
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Polly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
down
the
line
at
present
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
prodigal
Rob
seemed
very
much
relieved
to
hear
it
:
though
still
in
the
absorption
of
all
his
faculties
in
his
patron
,
he
hardly
took
his

from
Mr
Carker
's
face
,
unless
for

at
a
time
to

mother
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
"
I
'll
tell
you
how
I
have
stumbled
on
this
boy
of
yours
,
and
who
I
am
,
and
what
I
am
going
to
do
for
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
Mr
Carker
did
,
in
his
own
way
;
saying
that
he
at
first
intended
to
have
accumulated
nameless
terrors
on
his
presumptuous
head
,
for
coming
to
the
whereabout
of
Dombey
and
Son
.
<EOS>
That
he
had
relented
,
in
consideration
of
his
youth
,
his
professed
contribution
,
and
his
friends
.
<EOS>
That
he
was
afraid
he
took
a
rash
step
in
doing
anything
for
the
boy
,
and
one
that
might
expose
him
to
the
censure
of
the
prudent
;
but
that
he
did
it
of
himself
and
for
himself
,
and
risked
the
consequences
single
-
handed
;
and
that
his
mother
's
past
connection
with
Mr
Dombey
's
family
had
nothing
to
do
with
it
,
and
that
Mr
Dombey
had
nothing
to
do
with
it
,
but
that
he
,
Mr
Carker
,
was
the
be
-
all
and
the
end
-
all
of
this
business
.
<EOS>
Taking
great
credit
to
himself
for
his
goodness
,
and
receiving
no
less
from
all
the
family
then
present
,
Mr
Carker
signified
,
indirectly
but
still
pretty

,
that
Rob
's
implicit

,
attachment
,
and
devotion
,
were
for
evermore
his
due
,
and
the
least
homage
he
could
receive
.
<EOS>
And
with
this
great
truth
Rob
himself
was
so
impressed
,
that
standing
gazing
on
his
patron
with
tears
rolling
down
his
cheeks
,
he
nodded
his
shiny
head
until
it
seemed
almost
as
loose
as
it
had
done
under
the
same
patron
's
hands
that

.
  
<EOS>
Polly
,
who
had
passed
Heaven
knows
how
many
sleepless
nights
on
account
of
this
her
dissipated
firstborn
,
and
had
not
seen
him
for
weeks
and
weeks
,
could
have
almost
kneeled
to
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
,
as
to
a
Good
Spirit
---
in
spite

his

.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Carker
rising
to
depart
,
she
only
thanked
him
with
her
mother
's

and

;
thanks
so
rich
when
paid
out
of
the
Heart
's
mint
,
especially
for
any
service
Mr
Carker
had
rendered
,
that
he
might
have
given
back
a
large
amount
of
change
,
and
yet
been
overpaid
.
  
<EOS>
As
that
gentleman
made
his
way
among
the
crowding
children
to
the
door
,
Rob
retreated
on
his
mother
,
and
took

and
the
baby
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
try
hard
,
dear
mother
,
now
.
<EOS>
Upon
my
soul
I
will
!
"
said
Rob
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
do
,
my
dear
boy
!
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
will
,
for
our

and

!
"
cried
Polly
,

.
"
<EOS>
But
you
're
coming
back
to
speak

,
when
you

seen
the
gentleman
away
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
mother
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rob
hesitated
,
and
looked

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Father
---
when
's

coming

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

two

-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
come
back
,
mother
dear
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Rob
.
<EOS>
And
passing
through

shrill

brothers
and

,

Carker

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
who
had

.
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
bad
father
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
!
"
returned

,

.
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
a
better
nor
a

father
going
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
do

want

him

?
<EOS>
"
inquired

.
  
<EOS>
"
There

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
could

I

---

I

'd

---
but
a

---

good
,
Sir
;
at

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
's

expanded
,
but
he

until

was
mounted
on

horse
,

,

,

boy
,

said
:
  
"
You
'll

to

to
-

,

that

;
that

who

;
where

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
Sir
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have

that

,
and
in

,
you

,
boy
<EOS>
,

?
<EOS>
Well
,
"
he

,

,

round

:
"
I

.
<EOS>
I
want

,

---
for

---
and

.
<EOS>
Do

?
"
   
<EOS>
Rob
nodded
his
steadfast
face
,
and
said
"
Yes
,
Sir
,
"
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to

that
he
has

who

,
and
that

---
<EOS>
for
he

,

;
but

,

.
<EOS>
There

may

.
<EOS>
I

to

about
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
care
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
boy
.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,
"
returned

,

closer

boy
's
,
and
pat

:
"
take
care
<EOS>
you
talk
about
affairs
of
mine
to
nobody
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
nobody
in
the
world
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Rob
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Neither
there
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
pointing
to

place
they
had
just

,
"
nor
anywhere
else
.
<EOS>
I
'll
try
how
true

can

.
<EOS>
I
'll
prove
you
!
"
<EOS>
Making
this
,
by
his
display
of

and

,
as
much
a
threat

,
he
turned
from
Rob
's
eyes
,
which
were
nailed
upon
him
as
if
he
had
won
the
boy
by
a
charm
,
body
and

,

.
<EOS>
But
again
becoming
conscious
,
after
trotting
a
short
distance
,
that
his
devoted
henchman
,
girt
as
before
,
was
yielding
him
the
same
attendance
,
to
the
great
amusement
of
sundry

,
he
reined
up
,
and
ordered
him
off
.
<EOS>
To
insure
his
obedience
,
he
turned
in
the
saddle
and
watched
him
as
he
retired
.
<EOS>
It
was
curious
to
see
that
even
then
Rob
could
not
keep
his
eyes
wholly
averted
from
his
patron
's
face
,
but
,
constantly
turning
and
turning
again
to
look
after
him
,
involved
himself
in
a
tempest
of
buffetings
and
jostlings
from
the
other
passengers
in
the
street
:
of
which
,
in
the
pursuit
of
the
one
paramount
idea
,
he
was
perfectly
heedless
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
rode
on
at
a
foot
-
pace
,
with
the
easy
air
of
one
who
had
performed
all
the
business
of
the
day
in
a
satisfactory
manner
,
and
got
it
comfortably
off
his
mind
.
<EOS>
Complacent
and
affable
as
man
could
be
,
Mr
Carker
picked
his
way
along
the
streets
and
hummed
a
soft
tune
as
he
went
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
purr
,
he
was
so
glad
.
  
<EOS>
And
in
some
sort
,
Mr
Carker
,
in
his
fancy
,
basked
upon
a
hearth
too
.
<EOS>
Coiled
up
snugly
at
certain
feet
,
he
was
ready
for
a
spring
,
or
for
a
tear
,
or
for
a
scratch
,
or
for
a
velvet
touch
,
as
the
humour
took
him
and
occasion
served
.
<EOS>
Was
there
any
bird
in
a
cage
,
that
came
in
for
a
share
of
his
regards
?
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
young
lady
!
<EOS>
"
thought
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
,
through
his
song
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ay
!
<EOS>
when
I
saw
her
last
,
she
was
a
little
child
.
<EOS>
With
dark
eyes
and
hair
,
I
recollect
,
and
a
good
face
;
a
very
good
face
!
<EOS>
I
dare
say
she
's
pretty
.
"
  
<EOS>
More
affable
and
pleasant
yet
,
and
humming
his
song
until
his
many
teeth
vibrated
to
it
,
Mr
Carker
picked
his
way
along
,
and
turned
at
last
into
the
shady
street
where
Mr
Dombey
's
house
stood
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
so
busy
,
winding
webs
round
good
faces
,
and
obscuring
them
with
meshes
,
that
he
hardly
thought
of
being
at
this
point
of
his
ride
,
until
,
glancing
down
the
cold
perspective
of
tall
houses
,
he
reined
in
his
horse
quickly
within
a
few
yards
of
the
door
.
<EOS>
But
to
explain
why
Mr
Carker
reined
in
his
horse
quickly
,
and
what
he
looked
at
in
no
small
surprise
,
a
few
digressive
words
are
necessary
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
,
emancipated
from
the
Blimber
thraldom
and
coming
into
the
possession
of
a
certain
portion
of
his
worldly
wealth
,
"
<EOS>
which
,
"
as
he
had
been
wo
nt
,
during
his
last
half
-
year
's
probation
,
to
communicate
to
Mr
Feeder
every
evening
as
a
new
discovery
,
"
the
executors
could
n't
keep
him
out
of
,
"
had
applied
himself
,
with
great
diligence
,
to
the
science
of
Life
.
<EOS>
Fired
with
a
noble
emulation
to
pursue
a
brilliant
and
distinguished
career
,
Mr
Toots
had
furnished
a
choice
set
of
apartments
;
had
established
among
them
a
sporting
bower
,
embellished
with
the
portraits
of
winning
horses
,
in
which
he
took
no
particle
of
interest
;
and
a
divan
,
which
made
him
poorly
.
<EOS>
In
this
delicious
abode
,
Mr
Toots
devoted
himself
to
the
cultivation
of
those
gentle
arts
which
refine
and
humanise
existence
,
his
chief
instructor
in
which
was
an
interesting
character
called
the
Game
Chicken
,
who
was
always
to
be
heard
of
at
the
bar
of
the
Black
Badger
,
wore
a
shaggy
white
great
-
coat
in
the
warmest
weather
,
and
knocked
Mr
Toots
about
the
head
three
times
a
week
,
for
the
small
consideration
of
ten
and
six
per
visit
.
   
<EOS>
The
Game
Chicken
,
who
was
quite
the
Apollo
of
Mr
Toots
's
Pantheon
,
had
introduced
to
him
a
marker
who
taught
billiards
,
a
Life
Guard
who
taught
fencing
,
a
job
-
master
who
taught
riding
,
a
Cornish
gentleman
who
was
up
to
anything
in
the
athletic
line
,
and
two
or
three
other
friends
connected
no
less
intimately
with
the
fine
arts
.
<EOS>
Under
whose
auspices
Mr
Toots
could
hardly
fail
to
improve
apace
,
and
under
whose
tuition
he
went
to
work
.
  
<EOS>
But
however
it
came
about
<EOS>
,
it
came
to
pass
,
even
while
these
gentlemen
had
the
gloss
of
novelty
upon
them
,
that
Mr
Toots
felt
,
he
did
n't
know
how
,
unsettled
and
uneasy
.
<EOS>
There
were
husks
in
his
corn
,
that
even
Game
Chickens
could
n't
peck
up
;
gloomy
giants
in
his
leisure
,
that
even
Game
Chickens
could
n't
knock
down
.
<EOS>
Nothing
seemed
to
do
Mr
Toots
so
much
good
as
incessantly
leaving
cards
at
Mr
Dombey
's
door
.
<EOS>
No
tax
-
gatherer
in
the
British
dominions
---
that
wide
-
spread
territory
on
which
the
sun
never
sets
,
and
where
the
tax
-
gatherer
never
goes
to
bed
---
was
more
regular
and
persevering
in
his
calls
than
Mr
Toots
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
never
went
up
stairs
;
and
always
performed
the
same
ceremonies
,
richly
dressed
for
the
purpose
,
at
the
hall
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Good
morning
!
<EOS>
"
would
be
Mr
Toots
's
first
remark
to
the
servant
.
"
<EOS>
For
Mr
Dombey
,
"
would
be
Mr
Toots
's
next
remark
,
as
he
handed
in
a
card
.
"
<EOS>
For
Miss
Dombey
,
"
would
be
his
next
,
as
he
handed
in
another
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
would
then
turn
round
as
if
to
go
away
;
but
the
man
knew
him
by
this
time
,
and
knew
he
would
n't
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
Mr
Toots
would
say
,
as
if
a
thought
had
suddenly
descended
on
him
.
"
<EOS>
Is
the
young
woman
at
home
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
would
rather
think
she
was
,
but
would
n't
quite
know
.
<EOS>
Then
he
would
ring
a
bell
that
rang
upstairs
,
and
would
look
up
the
staircase
,
and
would
say
,
yes
,
she
was
at
home
,
and
was
coming
down
.
<EOS>
Then
Miss
Nipper
would
appear
,
and
the
man
would
retire
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
How
de
do
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
would
say
,
with
a
chuckle
and
a
blush
.
  
<EOS>
Susan
would
thank
him
,
and
say
she
was
very
well
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
's
Diogenes
going
on
?
"
would
be
Mr
Toot
's
second
interrogation
.
  
<EOS>
Very
well
indeed
.
<EOS>
Miss
Florence
was
fonder
and
fonder
of
him
every
day
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
was
sure
to
hail
this
with
a
burst
of
chuckles
,
like
the
opening
of
a
bottle
of
some
effervescent
beverage
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Florence
is
quite
well
,
Sir
,
"
Susan
would
add
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
of
no
consequence
,
thank'ee
,
"
was
the
invariable
reply
of
Mr
Toots
;
and
when
he
had
said
so
,
he
always
went
away
very
fast
.
  
<EOS>
Now
it
is
certain
that
Mr
Toots
had
a
filmy
something
in
his
mind
,
which
led
him
to
conclude
that
if
he
could
aspire
successfully
in
the
fulness
of
time
,
to
the
hand
of
Florence
,
he
would
be
fortunate
and
blest
.
<EOS>
It
is
certain
that
Mr
Toots
,
by
some
remote
and
roundabout
road
,
had
got
to
that
point
,
and
that
there
he
made
a
stand
.
<EOS>
His
heart
was
wounded
;
he
was
touched
;
he
was
in
love
.
<EOS>
He
had
made
a
desperate
attempt
,
one
night
,
and
had
sat
up
all
night
for
the
purpose
,
to
write
an
acrostic
on
Florence
,
which
affected
him
to
tears
in
the
conception
.
<EOS>
But
he
never
proceeded
in
the
execution
further
than
the
words
"
<EOS>
For
when
I
gaze
,
"
---
the
flow
of
imagination
in
which
he
had
previously
written
down
the
initial
letters
of
the
other
seven
lines
,
deserting
him
at
that
point
.
  
<EOS>
Beyond
devising
that
very
artful
and
politic
measure
of
leaving
a
card
for
Mr
Dombey
daily
,
the
brain
of
Mr
Toots
had
not
worked
much
in
reference
to
the
subject
that
held
his
feelings
prisoner
.
<EOS>
But
deep
consideration
at
length
assured
Mr
Toots
that
an
important
step
to
gain
,
was
,
the
conciliation
of
Miss
Susan
Nipper
,
preparatory
to
giving
her
some
inkling
of
his
state
of
mind
.
  
<EOS>
A
little
light
and
playful
gallantry
towards
this
lady
seemed
the
means
to
employ
in
that
early
chapter
of
the
history
,
for
winning
her
to
his
interests
.
<EOS>
Not
being
able
quite
to
make
up
his
mind
about
it
,
he
consulted
the
Chicken
---
without
taking
that
gentleman
into
his
confidence
;
merely
informing
him
that
a
friend
in
Yorkshire
had
written
to
him
(
Mr
Toots
)
for
his
opinion
on
such
a
question
.
<EOS>
The
Chicken
replying
that
his
opinion
always
was
,
"
Go
in
and
win
,
"
and
further
,
"
When
your
man
's
before
you
and
your
work
cut
out
,
go
in
and
do
it
,
"
Mr
Toots
considered
this
a
figurative
way
of
supporting
his
own
view
of
the
case
,
and
heroically
resolved
to
kiss
Miss
Nipper
next
day
.
  
<EOS>
Upon
the
next
day
,
therefore
,
Mr
Toots
,
putting
into
requisition
some
of
the
greatest
marvels
that
Burgess
and
Co.
had
ever
turned
out
,
went
off
to
Mr
Dombey
's
upon
this
design
.
<EOS>
But
his
heart
failed
him
so
much
as
he
approached
the
scene
of
action
,
that
,
although
he
arrived
on
the
ground
at
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
,
it
was
six
before
he
knocked
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
Everything
happened
as
usual
,
down
to
the
point
where
Susan
said
her
young
mistress
was
well
,
and
Mr
Toots
said
it
was
of
no
consequence
.
<EOS>
To
her
amazement
,
Mr
Toots
,
instead
of
going
off
like
a
rocket
,
after
that
observation
,
lingered
and
chuckled
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
'd
like
to
walk
up
stairs
,
Sir
!
"
said
Susan
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
think
I
will
come
in
!
"
said
Mr
Toots
.
  
<EOS>
But
instead
of
walking
up
stairs
,
the
bold
Toots
made
an
awkward
plunge
at
Susan
when
the
door
was
shut
,
and
embracing
that
fair
creature
,
kissed
her
on
the
cheek
.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
along
with
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Susan
,
"
or
I
'll
tear
your
eyes
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just
another
!
"
said
Mr
Toots
.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
along
with
you
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Susan
,
giving
him
a
push
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Innocents
like
you
,
too
!
<EOS>
Who
'll
begin
next
?
<EOS>
Go
along
,
Sir
!
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
was
not
in
any
serious
strait
,
for
she
could
hardly
speak
for
laughing
;
but
Diogenes
,
on
the
staircase
,
hearing
a
rustling
against
the
wall
,
and
a
shuffling
of
feet
,
and
seeing
through
the
banisters
that
there
was
some
contention
going
on
,
and
foreign
invasion
in
the
house
,
formed
a
different
opinion
,
dashed
down
to
the
rescue
,
and
in
the
twinkling
of
an
eye
had
Mr
Toots
by
the
leg
.
  
<EOS>
Susan
screamed
,
laughed
,
opened
the
street
-
door
,
and
ran
down
stairs
;
the
bold
Toots
tumbled
staggering
out
into
the
street
,
with
Diogenes
holding
on
to
one
leg
of
his
pantaloons
,
as
if
Burgess
and
Co.
were
his
cooks
,
and
had
provided
that
dainty
morsel
for
his
holiday
entertainment
;
Diogenes
shaken
off
,
rolled
over
and
over
in
the
dust
,
got
up
again
,
whirled
round
the
giddy
Toots
and
snapped
at
him
:
and
all
this
turmoil
,
Mr
Carker
,
reining
up
his
horse
and
sitting
a
little
at
a
distance
,
saw
to
his
amazement
,
<EOS>
issue
from
the
stately
house
of
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
remained
watching
the
discomfited
Toots
,
when
Diogenes
was
called
in
,
and
the
door
shut
:
and
while
that
gentleman
,
taking
refuge
in
a
doorway
near
at
hand
,
bound
up
the
torn
leg
of
his
pantaloons
with
a
costly
silk
handkerchief
that
had
formed
part
of
his
expensive
outfit
for
the
adventure
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
riding
up
,
with
his
most
propitiatory
smile
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
not
hurt
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
thank
you
,
"
replied
Mr
Toots
,
raising
his
flushed
face
,
"
it
's
of
no
consequence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
would
have
signified
,
if
he
could
,
that
he
liked
it
very
much
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
the
dog
's
teeth
have
entered
the
leg
,
Sir
---
"
began
Carker
,
with
a
display
of
his
own
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
you
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
it
's
all
quite
right
.
<EOS>
It
's
very
comfortable
,
thank
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
the
pleasure
of
knowing
Mr
Dombey
,
"
observed
Carker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
though
?
"
rejoined
the
blushing
Toots
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
allow
me
,
perhaps
,
to
apologise
,
in
his
absence
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
taking
off
his
hat
,
"
for
such
a
misadventure
,
and
to
wonder
how
it
can
possibly
have
happened
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
is
so
much
gratified
by
this
politeness
,
and
the
lucky
chance
of
making
friends
with
a
friend
of
Mr
Dombey
,
that
he
pulls
out
his
card
-
case
,
which
he
never
loses
an
opportunity
of
using
,
and
hands
his
name
and
address
to
Mr
Carker
:
who
responds
to
that
courtesy
by
giving
him
his
own
,
and
with
that
they
part
.
  
<EOS>
As
Mr
Carker
picks
his
way
so
softly
past
the
house
,
glancing
up
at
the
windows
,
and
trying
to
make
out
the
pensive
face
behind
the
curtain
looking
at
the
children
opposite
,
the
rough
head
of
Diogenes
came
clambering
up
close
by
it
,
and
the
dog
,
regardless
of
all
soothing
,
barks
and
growls
,
and
makes
at
him
from
that
height
,
as
if
he
would
spring
down
and
tear
him
limb
from
limb
.
  
<EOS>
Well
spoken
,
Di
,
so
near
your
Mistress
!
<EOS>
Another
,
and
another
with
your
head
up
,
your
eyes
flashing
,
and
your
vexed
mouth
worrying
itself
,
for
want
of
him
!
<EOS>
Another
,
as
he
picks
his
way
along
!
<EOS>
You
have
a
good
scent
,
Di
,
---
cats
,
boy
,
cats
!
   
<EOS>
Chapter
23
.
<EOS>
Florence
solitary
,
and
the
Midshipman
mysterious
 
FLORENCE
lived
alone
in
the
great
dreary
house
,
and
day
succeeded
day
,
and
still
she
lived
alone
;
and
the
blank
walls
looked
down
upon
her
with
a
vacant
stare
,
as
if
they
had
a
Gorgon
-
like
mind
to
stare
her
youth
and
beauty
into
stone
.
  
<EOS>
No
magic
dwelling
-
place
in
magic
story
,
shut
up
in
the
heart
of
a
thick
wood
,
was
ever
more
solitary
and
deserted
to
the
fancy
,
than
was
her
father
's
mansion
in
its
grim
reality
,
as
it
stood
lowering
on
the
street
:
always
by
night
,
when
lights
were
shining
from
neighbouring
windows
,
a
blot
upon
its
scanty
brightness
;
always
by
day
,
a
frown
upon
its
never
-
smiling
face
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
not
two
dragon
sentries
keeping
ward
before
the
gate
of
this
abode
,
as
in
magic
legend
are
usually
found
on
duty
over
the
wronged
innocence
imprisoned
;
but
besides
a
glowering
visage
,
with
its
thin
lips
parted
wickedly
,
that
surveyed
all
comers
from
above
the
archway
of
the
door
,
there
was
a
monstrous
fantasy
of
rusty
iron
,
curling
and
twisting
like
a
petrifaction
of
an
arbour
over
the
threshold
,
budding
in
spikes
and
corkscrew
points
,
and
bearing
,
one
on
either
side
,
two
ominous
extinguishers
,
<EOS>
that
seemed
to
say
,
"
Who
enter
here
,
leave
light
behind
!
<EOS>
"
There
were
no
talismanic
characters
engraven
on
the
portal
,
but
the
house
was
now
so
neglected
in
appearance
,
that
boys
chalked
the
railings
and
the
pavement
---
particularly
round
the
corner
where
the
side
wall
was
---
and
drew
ghosts
on
the
stable
door
;
and
being
sometimes
driven
off
by
Mr
Towlinson
,
made
portraits
of
him
,
in
return
,
with
his
ears
growing
out
horizontally
from
under
his
hat
.
<EOS>
Noise
ceased
to
be
,
within
the
shadow
of
the
roof
.
<EOS>
The
brass
band
that
came
into
the
street
once
a
week
,
in
the
morning
,
never
brayed
a
note
in
at
those
windows
;
but
all
such
company
,
down
to
a
poor
little
piping
organ
of
weak
intellect
,
with
an
imbecile
party
of
automaton
dancers
,
waltzing
in
and
out
at
folding
-
doors
,
fell
off
from
it
with
one
accord
,
and
shunned
it
as
a
hopeless
place
.
  
<EOS>
The
spell
upon
it
was
more
wasting
than
the
spell
that
used
to
set
enchanted
houses
sleeping
once
upon
a
time
but
left
their
waking
freshness
unimpaired
.
  
<EOS>
The
passive
desolation
of
disuse
was
everywhere
silently
manifest
about
it
.
<EOS>
Within
doors
,
curtains
,
drooping
heavily
,
lost
their
old
folds
and
shapes
,
and
hung
like
cumbrous
palls
.
<EOS>
Hecatombs
of
furniture
,
still
piled
and
covered
up
,
shrunk
like
imprisoned
and
forgotten
men
,
and
changed
insensibly
.
<EOS>
Mirrors
were
dim
as
with
the
breath
of
years
.
<EOS>
Patterns
of
carpets
faded
and
became
perplexed
and
faint
,
like
the
memory
of
those
years
'
trifling
incidents
.
<EOS>
Boards
,
starting
at
unwonted
footsteps
,
creaked
and
shook
.
<EOS>
Keys
rusted
in
the
locks
of
doors
.
<EOS>
Damp
started
on
the
walls
,
and
as
the
stains
came
out
,
the
pictures
seemed
to
go
in
and
secrete
themselves
.
<EOS>
Mildew
and
mould
began
to
lurk
in
closets
.
<EOS>
Fungus
trees
grew
in
corners
of
the
cellars
.
<EOS>
Dust
accumulated
,
nobody
knew
whence
nor
how
;
spiders
,
moths
,
and
grubs
were
heard
of
every
day
.
<EOS>
An
exploratory
blackbeetle
now
and
then
was
found
immovable
upon
the
stairs
,
or
in
an
upper
room
,
as
wondering
how
he
got
there
.
<EOS>
Rats
began
to
squeak
and
scuffle
in
the
night
time
,
through
dark
galleries
they
mined
behind
the
panelling
.
  
<EOS>
The
dreary
magnificence
of
the
state
rooms
,
seen
imperfectly
by
the
doubtful
light
admitted
through
closed
shutters
,
would
have
answered
well
enough
for
an
enchanted
abode
.
<EOS>
Such
as
the
tarnished
paws
of
gilded
lions
,
stealthily
put
out
from
beneath
their
wrappers
;
the
marble
lineaments
of
busts
on
pedestals
,
fearfully
revealing
themselves
through
veils
;
the
clocks
that
never
told
the
time
,
or
,
if
wound
up
by
any
chance
,
told
it
wrong
,
and
struck
unearthly
numbers
,
which
are
not
upon
the
dial
;
the
accidental
tinklings
among
the
pendant
lustres
,
more
startling
than
alarm
-
bells
;
the
softened
sounds
and
laggard
air
that
made
their
way
among
these
objects
,
and
a
phantom
crowd
of
others
,
shrouded
and
hooded
,
and
made
spectral
of
shade
.
<EOS>
But
,
besides
,
there
was
the
great
staircase
,
where
the
lord
of
the
place
so
rarely
set
his
foot
,
and
by
which
his
little
child
had
gone
up
to
Heaven
.
<EOS>
There
were
other
staircases
and
passages
where
no
one
went
for
weeks
together
;
there
were
two
closed
rooms
associated
with
dead
members
of
the
family
,
and
with
whispered
recollections
of
them
;
and
to
all
the
house
but
Florence
,
there
was
a
gentle
figure
moving
through
the
solitude
and
gloom
,
that
gave
to
every
lifeless
thing
a
touch
of
present
human
interest
and
wonder
.
  
<EOS>
For
Florence
lived
alone
in
the
deserted
house
,
and
day
succeeded
day
,
and
still
she
lived
alone
,
and
the
cold
walls
looked
down
upon
her
with
a
vacant
stare
,
as
if
they
had
a
Gorgon
-
like
mind
to
stare
her
youth
and
beauty
into
stone
.
  
<EOS>
The
grass
began
to
grow
upon
the
roof
,
and
in
the
crevices
of
the
basement
paving
.
<EOS>
A
scaly
crumbling
vegetation
sprouted
round
the
window
-
sills
.
<EOS>
Fragments
of
mortar
lost
their
hold
upon
the
insides
of
the
unused
chimneys
,
and
came
dropping
down
.
<EOS>
The
two
trees
with
the
smoky
trunks
were
blighted
high
up
,
and
the
withered
branches
domineered
above
the
leaves
.
<EOS>
Through
the
whole
building
white
had
turned
yellow
,
yellow
nearly
black
;
and
since
the
time
when
the
poor
lady
died
,
it
had
slowly
become
a
dark
gap
in
the
long
monotonous
street
.
  
<EOS>
But
Florence
bloomed
there
,
like
the
king
's
fair
daughter
in
the
story
.
<EOS>
Her
books
,
her
music
,
and
her
daily
teachers
,
were
<EOS>
her
only
real
companions
,
Susan
Nipper
and
Diogenes
excepted
:
of
whom
the
former
,
in
her
attendance
on
the
studies
of
her
young
mistress
,
began
to
grow
quite
learned
herself
,
while
the
latter
,
softened
possibly
by
the
same
influences
,
would
lay
his
head
upon
the
window
-
ledge
,
and
placidly
open
and
shut
his
eyes
upon
the
street
,
all
through
a
summer
morning
;
sometimes
pricking
up
his
head
to
look
with
great
significance
after
some
noisy
dog
in
a
cart
,
who
was
barking
his
way
along
,
and
sometimes
,
with
an
exasperated
and
unaccountable
recollection
of
his
supposed
enemy
in
the
neighbourhood
,
rushing
to
the
door
,
whence
,
after
a
deafening
disturbance
,
he
would
come
jogging
back
with
a
ridiculous
complacency
that
belonged
to
him
,
and
lay
his
jaw
upon
the
window
-
ledge
again
,
with
the
air
of
a
dog
who
had
done
a
public
service
.
  
<EOS>
So
Florence
lived
in
her
wilderness
of
a
home
,
within
the
circle
of
her
innocent
pursuits
and
thoughts
,
and
nothing
harmed
her
.
<EOS>
She
could
go
down
to
her
father
's
rooms
now
,
and
think
of
him
,
and
suffer
her
loving
heart
humbly
to
approach
him
,
without
fear
of
repulse
.
<EOS>
She
could
look
upon
the
objects
that
had
surrounded
him
in
his
sorrow
,
and
could
nestle
near
his
chair
,
and
not
dread
the
glance
that
she
so
well
remembered
.
<EOS>
She
could
render
him
such
little
tokens
of
her
duty
and
service
,
as
putting
everything
in
order
for
him
with
her
own
hands
,
binding
little
nosegays
for
his
table
,
changing
them
as
one
by
one
they
withered
,
and
he
did
not
come
back
,
preparing
something
for
him
every
day
,
and
leaving
some
timid
mark
of
her
presence
near
his
usual
seat
.
<EOS>
To
-
day
,
it
was
a
little
painted
stand
for
his
watch
;
to
-
morrow
<EOS>
she
would
be
afraid
to
leave
it
,
and
would
substitute
some
other
trifle
of
her
making
not
so
likely
to
attract
his
eye
.
<EOS>
Waking
in
the
night
,
perhaps
,
she
would
tremble
at
the
thought
of
his
coming
home
and
angrily
rejecting
it
,
and
would
hurry
down
with
slippered
feet
and
quickly
beating
heart
,
and
bring
it
away
.
<EOS>
At
another
time
,
she
would
only
lay
her
face
upon
his
desk
,
and
leave
a
kiss
there
,
and
a
tear
.
  
<EOS>
Still
no
one
knew
of
this
.
<EOS>
Unless
the
household
found
it
out
when
she
was
not
there
---
and
they
all
held
Mr
Dombey
's
rooms
in
awe
---
it
was
as
deep
a
secret
in
her
breast
as
what
had
gone
before
it
.
<EOS>
Florence
stole
into
those
rooms
at
twilight
,
early
in
the
morning
,
and
at
times
when
meals
were
served
downstairs
.
<EOS>
And
although
they
were
in
every
nook
the
better
and
the
brighter
for
her
care
,
she
entered
and
passed
out
as
quietly
as
any
sunbeam
,
excepting
that
she
left
her
light
behind
.
  
<EOS>
Shadowy
company
attended
Florence
up
and
down
the
echoing
house
,
and
sat
with
her
in
the
dismantled
rooms
.
<EOS>
As
if
her
life
were
an
enchanted
vision
,
there
arose
out
of
her
solitude
ministering
thoughts
,
that
made
it
fanciful
and
unreal
.
<EOS>
She
imagined
so
often
what
her
life
would
have
been
if
her
father
could
have
loved
her
<EOS>
and
she
had
been
a
favourite
child
,
<EOS>
that
sometimes
,
for
the
moment
,
she
almost
believed
it
was
so
,
and
,
borne
on
by
the
current
of
that
pensive
fiction
,
seemed
to
remember
how
they
had
watched
her
brother
in
his
grave
together
;
how
they
had
freely
shared
his
heart
between
them
;
how
they
were
united
in
the
dear
remembrance
of
him
;
how
they
often
spoke
about
him
yet
;
and
her
kind
father
,
looking
at
her
gently
,
told
her
of
their
common
hope
and
trust
in
God
.
<EOS>
At
other
times
she
pictured
to
herself
her
mother
yet
alive
.
<EOS>
And
oh
the
happiness
of
falling
on
her
neck
,
and
clinging
to
her
with
the
love
and
confidence
of
all
her
soul
!
<EOS>
And
oh
the
desolation
of
the
solitary
house
again
,
with
evening
coming
on
,
and
no
one
there
!
  
<EOS>
But
there
was
one
thought
,
scarcely
shaped
out
to
herself
,
yet
fervent
and
strong
within
her
,
that
upheld
Florence
when
she
strove
,
and
filled
her
true
young
heart
,
so
sorely
tried
,
with
constancy
of
purpose
.
<EOS>
Into
her
mind
,
as
into
all
others
contending
with
the
great
affliction
of
our
mortal
nature
,
there
had
stolen
solemn
wonderings
and
hopes
,
arising
in
the
dim
world
beyond
the
present
life
,
and
murmuring
,
like
faint
music
,
of
recognition
in
the
far
-
off
land
between
her
brother
and
her
mother
:
of
some
present
consciousness
in
both
of
her
:
<EOS>
some
love
and
commiseration
for
her
:
and
some
knowledge
of
her
as
she
went
her
way
upon
the
earth
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
soothing
consolation
to
Florence
to
give
shelter
to
these
thoughts
,
until
one
day
<EOS>
---
it
was
soon
after
she
had
last
seen
her
father
in
his
own
room
,
late
at
night
---
the
fancy
came
upon
her
,
that
,
in
weeping
for
his
alienated
heart
,
she
might
stir
the
spirits
of
the
dead
against
him
.
<EOS>
Wild
,
weak
,
childish
,
as
it
may
have
been
to
think
so
,
and
to
tremble
at
the
half
-
formed
thought
,
it
was
the
impulse
of
her
loving
nature
;
and
from
that
hour
Florence
strove
against
the
cruel
wound
in
her
breast
,
and
tried
to
think
of
him
whose
hand
had
made
it
only
with
hope
.
  
<EOS>
Her
father
did
not
know
---
she
held
to
it
from
that
time
---
how
much
she
loved
him
.
<EOS>
She
was
very
young
,
and
had
no
mother
,
and
had
never
learned
,
by
some
fault
or
misfortune
,
how
to
express
to
him
that
she
loved
him
.
<EOS>
She
would
be
patient
,
and
would
try
to
gain
that
art
in
time
,
and
win
him
to
a
better
knowledge
of
his
only
child
.
  
<EOS>
This
became
the
purpose
of
her
life
.
<EOS>
The
morning
sun
shone
down
upon
the
faded
house
,
and
found
the
resolution
bright
and
fresh
within
the
bosom
of
its
solitary
mistress
.
<EOS>
Through
all
the
duties
of
the
day
,
it
animated
her
;
for
Florence
hoped
that
the
more
she
knew
,
and
the
more
accomplished
she
became
,
the
more
glad
he
would
be
when
he
came
to
know
and
like
her
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
she
wondered
,
with
a
swelling
heart
and
rising
tear
,
whether
she
was
proficient
enough
in
anything
to
surprise
him
when
they
should
become
companions
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
she
tried
to
think
if
there
were
any
kind
of
knowledge
that
would
bespeak
his
interest
more
readily
than
another
.
<EOS>
Always
:
at
her
books
,
her
music
,
and
her
work
:
in
her
morning
walks
,
and
in
her
nightly
prayers
:
she
had
her
engrossing
aim
in
view
.
<EOS>
Strange
study
for
a
child
,
to
learn
the
road
to
a
hard
parent
's
heart
!
  
<EOS>
There
were
many
careless
loungers
through
the
street
,
as
the
summer
evening
deepened
into
night
,
who
glanced
across
the
road
at
the
sombre
house
,
and
saw
the
youthful
figure
at
the
window
,
such
a
contrast
to
it
,
looking
upward
at
the
stars
as
they
began
to
shine
,
who
would
have
slept
the
worse
if
they
had
known
on
what
design
she
mused
so
steadfastly
.
<EOS>
The
reputation
of
the
mansion
as
a
haunted
house
,
would
not
have
been
the
gayer
with
some
humble
dwellers
elsewhere
,
who
were
struck
by
its
external
gloom
in
passing
and
repassing
on
their
daily
avocations
,
and
so
named
it
,
if
they
could
have
read
its
story
in
the
darkening
face
.
<EOS>
But
Florence
held
her
sacred
purpose
,
unsuspected
and
unaided
:
and
studied
only
how
to
bring
her
father
to
the
understanding
that
she
loved
him
,
and
made
no
appeal
against
him
in
any
wandering
thought
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
Florence
lived
alone
in
the
deserted
house
,
and
day
succeeded
day
,
and
still
she
lived
alone
,
and
the
monotonous
walls
looked
down
upon
her
with
a
stare
,
as
if
they
had
a
Gorgon
-
like
intent
to
stare
her
youth
and
beauty
into
stone
.
  
<EOS>
Susan
Nipper
stood
opposite
to
her
young
mistress
one
morning
,
as
she
folded
and
sealed
a
note
she
had
been
writing
:
and
showed
in
her
looks
an
approving
knowledge
of
its
contents
.
  
<EOS>
"
Better
late
than
never
,
dear
Miss
Floy
,
"
said
Susan
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
do
say
,
that
even
a
visit
to
them
old
Skettleses
will
be
a
God
-
send
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
good
of
Sir
Barnet
and
Lady
Skettles
,
Susan
,
"
returned
Florence
,
with
a
mild
correction
of
that
young
lady
's
familiar
mention
of
the
family
in
question
,
"
to
repeat
their
invitation
so
kindly
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper
,
who
was
perhaps
the
most
thoroughgoing
partisan
on
the
face
of
the
earth
,
and
who
carried
her
partisanship
into
all
matters
great
or
small
,
and
perpetually
waged
war
with
it
against
society
,
screwed
up
her
lips
and
shook
her
head
,
as
a
protest
against
any
recognition
of
disinterestedness
in
the
Skettleses
,
and
a
plea
in
bar
that
they
would
have
valuable
consideration
for
their
kindness
,
in
the
company
of
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
know
what
they
're
about
,
if
ever
people
did
,
"
murmured
Miss
Nipper
,
drawing
in
her
breath
,
"
oh
!
trust
them
Skettleses
for
that
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
very
anxious
to
go
to
Fulham
,
Susan
,
I
confess
,
"
said
Florence
thoughtfully
:
"
<EOS>
but
it
will
be
right
to
go
.
<EOS>
I
think
it
will
be
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Much
better
,
"
interposed
Susan
,
with
another
emphatic
shake
of
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
though
I
would
prefer
to
have
gone
when
there
was
no
one
there
,
instead
of
in
this
vacation
time
,
when
it
seems
there
are
some
young
people
staying
in
the
house
<EOS>
,
I
have
thankfully
said
yes
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
For
which
I
say
,
<EOS>
Miss
Floy
,
Oh
be
joyful
!
"
returned
Susan
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
h
---
h
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
last

,
with
which
Miss
Nipper
frequently
wound

sentence
,
at
about
that
epoch

time
,
was
supposed
below
the
level

the
hall
to
have
a
general
reference
to
Mr
Dombey
,
and
to
be
expressive
of
a
yearning
in
Miss
Nipper
to
favour
that
gentleman
with
a

.
<EOS>
But
she
never
explained

;
and

,

,
the

of
mystery
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

is
before

of
Walter
,
Susan
!
"
<EOS>
observed

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Long

,
Miss
Floy
!
"

.
"
<EOS>
And
Perch
said
,
when

came
just

to
see
for

---
but
what

!
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
Much
he
knows
about

!
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
raised

,
and
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
n't
,
"
said
Susan
Nipper
,
evidently

some

,
and

,

's

,
"

,
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
Give

!
<EOS>
What
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
Miss

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

to

,

the

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
For

,

.
<EOS>
The

on

were

,
and

,

,

,

were

,
perhaps
,
and

upon

.
<EOS>
When
Florence
came
into
the
City
,
and
passed

together
,
she
dreaded
to

speaking
of
the
ship
,
and
saying
it
was
lost
.
<EOS>
Pictures
and
prints
of
vessels
fighting
with

rolling

filled

with

.
<EOS>
The

and

,
though
moving
gently
,
moved
too
fast
for
her
apprehensions
,
and
made

was
a

blowing
at
that

.
  
<EOS>
Susan
Nipper
may
or
may
not
have
been
affected
similarly
,
but
having
her

much
engaged
in
struggles
with
boys
,
whenever

any
press
of
people
---
for
,
between
that
grade
of

kind
and
herself
,
there

some

animosity
that
invariably
broke
out
,
whenever
they
came
together
<EOS>
---
it
would
seem
that
she

.
  
<EOS>
Arriving
in

of

Wooden

on

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

with

that

whistled
,
with

,
to
some

at

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Richards
's
eldest
,
Miss
!
"
said

,
"
and

's

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As

,

:
<EOS>
so

,

<EOS>
That

,

,

,
"
Strays
!
<EOS>
Whoo
-
oop!Strays
!
"

,

"
Strays
!
<EOS>
Whoo
-
oop
!
<EOS>
Strays
!
"

,

"

<EOS>

"
<EOS>
Yes

<EOS>

"

"

,

,

"

,

<EOS>
"
To

,

"

;
"
no

,
<EOS>
Miss.
Because

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

Cuttle

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
Rob

in
the
affirmative
,
and
turning
to
a

on

,
read

address

.
  
<EOS>
Florence
again
turned
to
her
maid
and
took
counsel
with
her
in

,
while
Rob
the
round
-
eyed
,
mindful
of
his
patron
's
secret
charge
,
looked
on
and

.
<EOS>
Florence
proposed
that
they
should
go
to
Captain
Cuttle
's
house
;
hear

his
own

,
what
he
thought
of

any

of
the
Son
and

;
and
bring

,
if
they
could
,
to

Uncle
Sol
.
<EOS>
Susan
at
first
objected
slightly
,
on
the
score
of
distance
;
but
a
hackney
-
coach
being
mentioned
by
her
mistress
,
withdrew
that
opposition
,
and
gave
in
her

.
<EOS>
There
were
some
minutes
of
discussion
between
them
before
they
came
to
this
conclusion
,
during
which
the
staring
Rob
paid
close
attention
to
both
speakers
,
and
inclined
his
ear
to
each
by
turns
,
as
if
he
were
appointed

of
the

.
  
<EOS>
In
fine
,
Rob
was
despatched
for
a
coach
,
the
visitors
keeping
shop
meanwhile
;
and
when
he
brought
it
,
they
got
into
it
,
leaving
word
for
Uncle
Sol
that
they
would
be
sure
to
call
again
,
on
their

.
<EOS>
Rob
having
stared
after
the
coach
until
it
was
as
invisible
as
the
pigeons
had
now
become
,
sat
down
behind
the
desk
with
a
most

;
and
in
order
that
he
might
forget
nothing
of
what
had
transpired
,
made
notes
of
it
on
various

of
paper
,
with
a
vast
expenditure
of
ink
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
danger
of
these
documents
betraying
anything
,
if
accidentally
lost
;
for
long
before
a
word
was
dry
,
it
became
as
profound
a
mystery
to
Rob
,
as
if
he
had
had
no
part
whatever
in
its
production
.
  
<EOS>
While
he
was
yet
busy
with
these
labours
,
the
hackney
-
coach
,
after
encountering
unheard
-
of
difficulties
from
swivel
-

,
soft
roads
,
impassable

,
caravans
of
casks
,

of
scarlet
-
beans
and
little
wash
-
houses
,
and
many
such
obstacles
abounding
in
that
country
,
stopped
at
the
corner
of
Brig
Place
.
<EOS>
Alighting
here
,
Florence
and
Susan
Nipper
walked
down
the
street
,
and
sought
out
the
abode
of
Captain
Cuttle
.
  
<EOS>
It
happened
by
evil
chance
to
be
one
of
Mrs
MacStinger
's
great
cleaning
days
.
<EOS>
On
these
occasions
,
Mrs
MacStinger
was
knocked
up
by
the
policeman
at
a
quarter
before
three
in
the
morning
,
and
rarely
succumbed
before
twelve
o'clock
next
night
.
<EOS>
The
chief
object
of
this
institution
appeared
to
be
,
that
Mrs
MacStinger
should
move
all
the
furniture
into
the
back
garden
at
early
dawn
,
walk
about
the
house
in
pattens
all
day
,
and
move
the
furniture
back
again
after
dark
.
<EOS>
These
ceremonies
greatly
fluttered
those
doves
the
young
MacStingers
,
who
were
not
only
unable
at
such
times
to
find
any
resting
-
place
for
the
soles
of
their
feet
,
but
generally
came
in
for
a
good
deal
of
pecking
from
the
maternal
bird
during
the
progress
of
the
solemnities
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
moment
when
Florence
and
Susan
Nipper
presented
themselves
at
Mrs
MacStinger
's
door
,
that
worthy
but
redoubtable
female
was
in
the
act
of
conveying
Alexander
MacStinger
,
aged
two
years
and
three
months
,
along
the
passage
for
forcible
deposition
in
a
sitting
posture
on
the
street
pavement
;
Alexander
being
black
in
the
face
with
holding
his
breath
after
punishment
,
and
a
cool
paving
-
stone
being
usually
found
to
act
as
a
powerful
restorative
in
such
cases
.
  
<EOS>
The
feelings
of
Mrs
MacStinger
,
as
a
woman
and
a
mother
,
were
outraged
by
the
look
of
pity
for
Alexander
which
she
observed
on
Florence
's
face
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
Mrs
MacStinger
asserting
those
finest
emotions
of
our
nature
,
in
preference
to
weakly
gratifying
her
curiosity
,
shook
and
buffeted
Alexander
both
before
and
during
the
application
of
the
paving
-
stone
,
and
took
no
further
notice
of
the
strangers
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Florence
,
when
the
child
had
found
his
breath
again
,
and
was
using
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
this
Captain
Cuttle
's
house
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mrs
MacStinger
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
Number
Nine
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Florence
,
hesitating
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
said
it
was
n't
Number
Nine
?
"
said
Mrs
MacStinger
.
  
<EOS>
Susan
Nipper
instantly
struck
in
,
and
begged
to
inquire
what
Mrs
MacStinger
meant
by
that
,
and
if
she
knew
whom
she
was
talking
to
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
MacStinger
in
retort
,
looked
at
her
all
over
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
with
Captain
Cuttle
,
I
should
wish
to
know
?
"
said
Mrs
MacStinger
.
  
<EOS>
"
Should
you
?
<EOS>
Then
I
'm
sorry
that
you
wo
n't
be
satisfied
,
"
returned
Miss
Nipper
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
Susan
!
<EOS>
If
you
please
!
"
said
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
can
have
the
goodness
to
tell
us
where
Captain
Cuttle
lives
,
ma'am
,
as
he
do
n't
live
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
says
he
do
n't
live
here
?
"
retorted
the
implacable
MacStinger
.
<EOS>
"
I
said
it
was
n't
Cap'en
Cuttle
's
house
---
<EOS>
and
it
ai
n't
his
house
---
and
forbid
it
,
that
it
ever
should
be
his
house
---
for
Cap'en
Cuttle
do
n't
know
how
to
keep
a
house
---
and
do
n't
deserve
to
have
a
house
<EOS>
---
it
's
my
house
---
and
when
I
let
the
upper
floor
to
Cap'en
Cuttle
,
oh
I
do
a
thankless
thing
,
and
cast
pearls
before
swine
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
MacStinger
pitched
her
voice
for
the
upper
windows
in
offering
these
remarks
,
and
cracked
off
each
clause
sharply
by
itself
as
if
from
a
rifle
possessing
an
infinity
of
barrels
.
<EOS>
After
the
last
shot
,
the
Captain
's
voice
was
heard
to
say
,
in
feeble
remonstrance
from
his
own
room
,
"
Steady
below
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Since
you
want
Cap'en
Cuttle
,
there
he
is
!
"
said
Mrs
MacStinger
,
with
an
angry
motion
of
her
hand
.
<EOS>
On
Florence
making
bold
to
enter
,
without
any
more
parley
,
and
on
Susan
following
,
Mrs
MacStinger
recommenced
her
pedestrian
exercise
in
pattens
,
and
Alexander
MacStinger
(
still
on
the
paving
-
stone
)
,
who
had
stopped
in
his
crying
to
attend
to
the
conversation
,
began
to
wail
again
,
entertaining
himself
during
that
dismal
performance
,
which
was
quite
mechanical
,
with
a
general
survey
of
the
prospect
,
terminating
in
the
hackney
-
coach
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
in
his
own
apartment
was
sitting
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
and
his
legs
drawn
up
under
his
chair
,
on
a
very
small
desolate
island
,
lying
about
midway
in
an
ocean
of
soap
and
water
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
windows
had
been
cleaned
,
the
walls
had
been
cleaned
,
the
stove
had
been
cleaned
,
and
everything
,
the
stove
excepted
,
was
wet
,
and
shining
with
soft
soap
and
sand
:
the
smell
of
which
dry
-
saltery
impregnated
the
air
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
the
dreary
scene
,
the
Captain
,
cast
away
upon
his
island
,
looked
round
on
the
waste
of
waters
with
a
rueful
countenance
,
and
seemed
waiting
for
some
friendly
bark
to
come
that
way
,
and
take
him
off
.
   
<EOS>
But
when
the
Captain
,
directing
his
forlorn
visage
towards
the
door
,
saw
Florence
appear
with
her
maid
,
no
words
can
describe
his
astonishment
.
<EOS>
Mrs
MacStinger
's
eloquence
having
rendered
all
other
sounds
but
imperfectly
distinguishable
,
he
had
looked
for
no
rarer
visitor
than
the
potboy
or
the
milkman
;
wherefore
,
when
Florence
appeared
,
and
coming
to
the
confines
of
the
island
,
put
her
hand
in
his
,
the
Captain
stood
up
,
aghast
,
as
if
he
supposed
her
,
for
the
moment
,
to
be
some
young
member
of
the
Flying
Dutchman
's
family
.
  
<EOS>
Instantly
recovering
his
self
-
possession
,
however
,
the
Captain
's
first
care
was
to
place
her
on
dry
land
,
which
he
happily
accomplished
,
with
one
motion
of
his
arm
.
<EOS>
Issuing
forth
,
then
,
upon
the
main
,
Captain
Cuttle
took
Miss
Nipper
round
the
waist
,
and
bore
her
to
the
island
also
.
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
then
,
with
great
respect
and
admiration
,
raised
the
hand
of
Florence
to
his
lips
,
and
standing
off
a
little
(
for
the
island
was
not
large
enough
for
three
)
,
beamed
on
her
from
the
soap
and
water
like
a
new
description
of
Triton
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
amazed
to
see
us
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Florence
,
with
a
smile
.
  
<EOS>
The
inexpressibly
gratified
Captain
kissed
his
hook
in
reply
,
and
growled
,
as
if
a
choice
and
delicate
compliment
were
included
in
the
words
,
"
Stand
by
!
<EOS>
Stand
by
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
could

rest
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
without
coming
to

what
you
think
about
dear
Walter
---
who

---

,

not
go
and
console
his

every

,

of

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
At

Cuttle
,
as

,

,
on
which

hard

hat

not
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Have

's

?
"
<EOS>

,

the

No

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
,

.
  
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"

,

"

"

<EOS>

,
"

"

,

,

,

,

,
"

---

as'll

.
<EOS>
Ah

"

,

,
"

again
a

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Will

?
<EOS>
We

a

here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Again

Captain
clapped
his

to
his

,
on
which
the
hard
glazed
hat
was
not
,
and
looked

.
<EOS>
But
at
this
instant
a
most
remarkable

occurred
.
<EOS>
The
door
opening
,
without
any
note
of
preparation
,
and
apparently
of
itself
,
the
hard
glazed
hat
in
question
skimmed
into
the
room
like
a
bird
,
and
alighted
heavily
at
the
Captain
's
feet
.
<EOS>
The
door
then
shut
as
violently
as
it
had
opened
,
and
nothing
ensued
in
explanation
of
the
prodigy
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
picked
up
his
hat
,
and
having
turned
it
over
with
a
look
of
interest
and
welcome
,
began
to
polish
it
on
his
sleeve
.
<EOS>
While
doing
so
,
the
Captain
eyed
his
visitors
intently
,
and
said
in
a
low
voice
:
  
"
<EOS>
You
see
I
should
have
bore
down
on
Sol
Gills
yesterday
,
and
this
morning
,
but
she
<EOS>
---
she
took
it
away
and
kep
it
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
long
and

of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
did
,
for
goodness
sake
?
"
asked
Susan
Nipper
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
lady
of
the
house
,
my
dear
,
"
returned
the
Captain
,
in
a
gruff
whisper
,
and
making
signals
of
secrecy
.
<EOS>
"
We
had
some
words
about
the
swabbing
of
these
here
planks
,
and
she
---
in
short
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
eyeing
the
door
,
and
relieving
himself
with
a
long

,
"
she
stopped
my
liberty
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
I
wish
she
had
me
to
deal
with
!
"
said
Susan
,
reddening
with
the
energy
of
the
wish
.
<EOS>
"
I
'd
stop
her
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
,
do
you
think
,
my
dear
?
"
rejoined

Captain
,
shaking
his
head
doubtfully
,
but
regarding

desperate

of
the
fair
aspirant
with
obvious

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
It
's
difficult
navigation
.
<EOS>
She
's
very
hard
to
carry
on
with
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
You
never
can
tell
how
she
'll
head
,
