.
<EOS>
She
's
full
one
minute
,
and
round
upon
you
next
.
<EOS>
And
when
she
is
a
tartar
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
with
the
perspiration
breaking
out
upon
his
forehead
---
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
but
a
whistle
emphatic
enough
for
the
conclusion
of
the
sentence
,
so
the
Captain
whistled
tremulously
.
<EOS>
After
which
he
again
shook
his
head
,
and
recurring
to
his
admiration
of
Miss
Nipper
's
devoted
bravery
,
timidly
repeated
,
"
Would
you
,
do
you
think
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
only
replied
with
a
bridling
smile
,
but
that
was
so
very
full
of
defiance
,
that
there
is
no
knowing
how
long
Captain
Cuttle
might
have
stood
entranced
in
its
contemplation
,
if
Florence
in
her
anxiety
had
not
again
proposed
their
immediately
resorting
to
the
oracular
Bunsby
.
<EOS>
Thus
reminded
of
his
duty
,
Captain
Cuttle
put
on
the
glazed
hat
firmly
,
took
up
another
knobby
stick
,
with
which
he
had
supplied
the
place
of
that
one
given
to
Walter
,
and
offering
his
arm
to
Florence
,
prepared
to
cut
his
way
through
the
enemy
.
  
<EOS>
It
turned
out
,
however
,
that
Mrs
MacStinger
had
already
changed
her
course
,
and
that
she
headed
,
as
the
Captain
had
remarked
she
often
did
,
in
quite
a
new
direction
.
<EOS>
For
when
they
got
downstairs
,
they
found
that
exemplary
woman
beating
the
mats
on
the
doorsteps
,
with
Alexander
,
still
upon
the
paving
-
stone
,
dimly
looming
through
a
fog
of
dust
;
and
so
absorbed
was
Mrs
MacStinger
in
her
household
occupation
,
that
when
Captain
Cuttle
and
his
visitors
passed
,
she
beat
the
harder
,
and
neither
by
word
nor
gesture
showed
any
consciousness
of
their
vicinity
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
so
well
pleased
with
this
easy
escape
---
although
the
effect
of
the
door
-
mats
on
him
was
like
a
copious
administration
of
snuff
,
and
made
him
sneeze
until
the
tears
ran
down
his
face
---
that
he
could
hardly
believe
his
good
fortune
;
but
more
than
once
,
between
the
door
and
the
hackney
-
coach
,
looked
over
his
shoulder
,
with
an
obvious
apprehension
of
Mrs
MacStinger
's
giving
chase
yet
.
  
<EOS>
However
,
they
got
to
the
corner
of
Brig
Place
without
any
molestation
from
that
terrible
fire
-
ship
;
and
the
Captain
mounting
the
coach
-
box
---
for
his
gallantry
would
not
allow
him
to
ride
inside
with
the
ladies
,
though
besought
to
do
so
<EOS>
---
piloted
the
driver
on
his
course
for
Captain
Bunsby
's
vessel
,
which
was
called
the
Cautious
Clara
,
and
was
lying
hard
by
Ratcliffe
.
  
<EOS>
Arrived
at
the
wharf
off
which
this
great
commander
's
ship
was
jammed
in
among
some
five
hundred
companions
,
whose
tangled
rigging
looked
like
monstrous
cobwebs
half
swept
down
,
Captain
Cuttle
appeared
at
the
coach
-
window
,
and
invited
Florence
and
Miss
Nipper
to
accompany
him
on
board
;
observing
that
Bunsby
was
to
the
last
degree
soft
-
hearted
in
respect
of
ladies
,
and
that
nothing
would
so
much
tend
to
bring
his
expansive
intellect
into
a
state
of
harmony
as
their
presentation
to
the
Cautious
Clara
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
readily
consented
;
and
the
Captain
,
taking
her
little
hand
in
his
prodigious
palm
,
led
her
,
with
a
mixed
expression
of
patronage
,
paternity
,
pride
,
and
ceremony
,
that
was
pleasant
to
see
,
over
several
very
dirty
decks
,
until
,
coming
to
the
Clara
,
they
found
that
cautious
craft
(
which
lay
outside
the
tier
)
with
her
gangway
removed
,
and
half
-
a
-
dozen
feet
of
river
interposed
between
herself
and
her
nearest
neighbour
.
<EOS>
It
appeared
,
from
Captain
Cuttle
's
explanation
,
that
the
great
Bunsby
,
like
himself
,
was
cruelly
treated
by
his
landlady
,
and
that
when
her
usage
of
him
for
the
time
being
was
so
hard
that
he
could
bear
it
no
longer
,
he
set
this
gulf
between
them
as
a
last
resource
.
  
<EOS>
"
Clara
a
-
hoy
!
"
cried
the
Captain
,
putting
a
hand
to
each
side
of
his
mouth
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
-
hoy
!
"
cried
a
boy
,
like
the
Captain
's
echo
,
tumbling
up
from
below
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bunsby
aboard
?
"
cried
the
Captain
,
hailing
the
boy
in
a
stentorian
voice
,
as
if
he
were
half
-
a
-
mile
off
instead
of
two
yards
.
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
!
"
cried
the
boy
,
in
the
same
tone
.
  
<EOS>
The
boy
then
shoved
out
a
plank
to
Captain
Cuttle
,
who
adjusted
it
carefully
,
and
led
Florence
across
:
returning
presently
for
Miss
Nipper
.
<EOS>
So
they
stood
upon
the
deck
of
the
Cautious
Clara
,
in
whose
standing
rigging
,
divers
fluttering
articles
of
dress
were
curing
,
in
company
with
a
few
tongues
and
some
mackerel
.
  
<EOS>
Immediately
there
appeared
,
coming
slowly
up
above
the
bulk
-
head
of
the
cabin
,
another
bulk
-
head
---
human
,
and
very
large
---
with
one
stationary
eye
in
the
mahogany
face
,
and
one
revolving
one
,
on
the
principle
of
some
lighthouses
.
<EOS>
This
head
was
decorated
with
shaggy
hair
,
like
oakum
,
which
had
no
governing
inclination
towards
the
north
,
east
,
west
,
or
south
,
but
inclined
to
all
four
quarters
of
the
compass
,
and
to
every
point
upon
it
.
<EOS>
The
head
was
followed
by
a
perfect
desert
of
chin
,
and
by
a
shirt
-
collar
and
neckerchief
,
and
by
a
dreadnought
pilot
-
coat
,
and
by
a
pair
of
dreadnought
pilot
-
trousers
,
whereof
the
waistband
was
so
very
broad
and
high
,
that
it
became
a
succedaneum
for
a
waistcoat
:
being
ornamented
near
the
wearer
's
breast
-
bone
with
some
massive
wooden
buttons
,
like
backgammon
men
.
<EOS>
As
the
lower
portions
of
these
pantaloons
became
revealed
,
Bunsby
stood
confessed
;
his
hands
in
their
pockets
,
which
were
of
vast
size
;
and
his
gaze
directed
,
not
to
Captain
Cuttle
or
the
ladies
,
but
the
mast
-
head
.
  
<EOS>
The
profound
appearance
of
this
philosopher
,
who
was
bulky
and
strong
,
and
on
whose
extremely
red
face
an
expression
of
taciturnity
sat
enthroned
,
not
inconsistent
with
his
character
,
in
which
that
quality
was
proudly
conspicuous
,
almost
daunted
Captain
Cuttle
,
though
on
familiar
terms
with
him
.
<EOS>
Whispering
to
Florence
that
Bunsby
had
never
in
his
life
expressed
surprise
,
and
was
considered
not
to
know
what
it
meant
,
the
Captain
watched
him
as
he
eyed
his
mast
-
head
,
and
afterwards
swept
the
horizon
;
and
when
the
revolving
eye
seemed
to
be
coming
round
in
his
direction
,
said
:
  
"
Bunsby
,
my
lad
<EOS>
,
how
fares
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
A
deep
,
gruff
,
husky
utterance
,
which
seemed
to
have
no
connexion
with
Bunsby
,
and
certainly
had
not
the
least
effect
upon
his
face
,
replied
,
"
Aye
,
aye
,
shipmet
<EOS>
,
how
goes
it
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
Bunsby
's
right
hand
and
arm
,
emerging
from
a
pocket
,
shook
the
Captain
's
,
and
went
back
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bunsby
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
striking
home
at
once
,
"
here
you
are
;
a
man
of
mind
,
and
a
man
as
can
give
as
opinion
.
<EOS>
Here
's
a
young
lady
as
wants
to
take
that
opinion
,
in
regard
of
my
friend
Wal'r
;
likewise
my
t'other
friend
,
Sol
Gills
,
which
is
a
character
for
you
to
come
within
hail
of
,
<EOS>
being
a
man
of
science
,
which
is
the
mother
of
inwention
,
and
knows
no
law
.
<EOS>
Bunsby
,
will
you
wear
,
to
oblige
me
,
and
come
along
with
us
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
great
commander
,
who
seemed
by
the
expression
of
his
visage
to
be
always
on
the
look
-
out
for
something
in
the
extremest
distance
,
and
to
have
no
ocular
knowledge
of
anything
within
ten
miles
,
made
no
reply
whatever
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
man
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
addressing
himself
to
his
fair
auditors
,
and
indicating
the
commander
with

,
"
that
has
fell
down
more
than
any
man
alive
;
that
has
had
more

happen
to

own
self
than
the
Seamen
's
Hospital
to
all
hands
;
that
took
as
many
spars
and
bars
and

about
the
outside

when
he

young
,
as
you
'd
want

for
on
Chatham
-
yard
to

yacht
with
;
and
yet
that
got
his
opinions
in
that
way
<EOS>
,
it
's
my
belief
,
for
there
an't
<EOS>
nothing
like
'em
afloat
or
ashore
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
stolid
commander
appeared
,
by
a
very
slight
vibration
in
his
elbows
,
to
express
some
satisfaction
in
this
encomium
;
but
if
his

had
been
as
distant
as

was
,
it
could
hardly
have
enlightened
the
beholders
less
in
reference
to
anything
that
was
passing
in
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
Shipmet
,
"
said
Bunsby
,
all
of
a

,
and
stooping
down
to
look

some

,
"
what
'll
the
ladies
drink
?
"
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
whose
delicacy
was
shocked
by
such
an
inquiry
in
connection
with
Florence
,
drew
the
sage
aside
,
and
seeming
to
explain
in
his
ear
,
accompanied
him
below
;
where
,
that
he
might
not
take
offence
,
the
Captain
drank
a
dram
himself
,
which
Florence
and
Susan
,
glancing
down
the
open
skylight
,
saw
the
sage
,
with
difficulty
finding
room
for
himself
between
his
berth
and
a
very
little
brass
fireplace
,
serve
out
for
self
and
friend
.
<EOS>
They
soon
reappeared
on
deck
,
and
Captain
Cuttle
,
triumphing
in
the
success
of
his
enterprise
,
conducted
Florence
back
to
the
coach
,
while
Bunsby
followed
,
escorting
Miss
Nipper
,
whom
he
hugged
upon
the
way
(
much
to
that
young
lady
's
indignation
)
with
his
pilot
-
coated
arm
,
like
a
blue
bear
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
put
his
oracle
inside
,
and
gloried
so
much
in
having
secured
him
,
and
having
got
that
mind
into
a
hackney
-
coach
,
that
he
could
not
refrain
from
often
peeping
in
at
Florence
through
the
little
window
behind
the
driver
,
and
testifying
his
delight
in
smiles
,
and
also
in
taps
upon
his
forehead
,
to
hint
to
her
that
the
brain
of
Bunsby
was
hard
at
it
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
Bunsby
,
still
hugging
Miss
Nipper
(
for
his
friend
,
the
Captain
,
had
not
exaggerated
the
softness
of
his
heart
)
,
uniformly
preserved
his
gravity
of
deportment
,
and
showed
no
other
consciousness
of
her
or
anything
.
  
<EOS>
Uncle
Sol
,
who
had
come
home
,
received
them
at
the
door
,
and
ushered
them
immediately
into
the
little
back
parlour
:
strangely
altered
by
the
absence
of
Walter
.
<EOS>
On
the
table
,
and
about
the
room
,
were
the
charts
and
maps
on
which
the
heavy
-
hearted
Instrument
-
maker
had
again
and
again
tracked
the
missing
vessel
across
the
sea
,
and
on
which
,
with
a
pair
of
compasses
that
he
still
had
in
his
hand
,
he
had
been
measuring
,
a
minute
before
,
how
far
she
must
have
driven
,
to
have
driven
here
or
there
:
and
trying
to
demonstrate
that
a
long
time
must
elapse
before
hope
was
exhausted
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whether
she
can
have
run
,
"
said
Uncle
Sol
,
looking
wistfully
over
the
chart
;
"
but
no
,
that
's
almost
impossible
.
<EOS>
Or
whether
she
can
have
been
forced
by
stress
of
weather
,
---
but
that
's
not
reasonably
likely
.
<EOS>
Or
whether
there
is
any
hope
she
so
far
changed
her
course
as
---
but
even
I
can
hardly
hope
that
!
"
<EOS>
With
such
broken
suggestions
,
poor
old
Uncle
Sol
roamed
over
the
great
sheet
before
him
,
and
could
not
find
a
speck
of
hopeful
probability
in
it
large
enough
to
set
one
small
point
of
the
compasses
upon
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
saw
immediately
---
it
would
have
been
difficult
to
help
seeing
---
that
there
was
a
singular
indescribable
change
in
the
old
man
,
and
that
while
his
manner
was
far
more
restless
and
unsettled
than
usual
,
there
was
yet
a
curious
,
contradictory
decision
in
it
,
that
perplexed
her
very
much
.
<EOS>
She
fancied
once
that
he
spoke
wildly
,
and
at
random
;
for
on
her
saying
she
regretted
not
to
have
seen
him
when
she
had
been
there
before
that
morning
,
he
at
first
replied
that
he
had
been
to
see
her
,
and
directly
afterwards
seemed
to
wish
to
recall
that
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
to
see
me
?
"
said
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
-
day
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
young
lady
,
"
returned
Uncle
Sol
,
looking
at
her
and
away
from
her
in
a
confused
manner
.
<EOS>
"
I
wished
to
see
you
with
my
own
eyes
,
and
to
hear
you
with
my
own
ears
,
once
more
before
---
"
There
he
stopped
.
  
<EOS>
"
Before
when
?
<EOS>
Before
what
?
"
said
Florence
,
putting
her
hand
upon
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
say
"
before
?
"
<EOS>
"
replied
old
Sol
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
did
,
I
must
have
meant
before
we
should
have
news
of
my
dear
boy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
well
,
"
said
Florence
,
tenderly
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
so
very
anxious
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
are
not
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
well
,
"
returned
the
old
man
,
shutting
up
his
right
hand
,
and
holding
it
out
to
show
her
:
"
as
well
and
firm
as
any
man
at
my
time
of
life
can
hope
to
be
.
<EOS>
See
!
<EOS>
It
's
steady
.
<EOS>
Is
its
master
not
as
capable
of
resolution
and
fortitude
as
many
a
younger
man
?
<EOS>
I
think
so
.
<EOS>
We
shall
see
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
that
in
his
manner
more
than
in
his

,
though
they
remained
with
her
too
,
which
impressed

so
much
,
that
she
would
have
confided

uneasiness
to
Captain
Cuttle
at
that

,
if

Captain
had
not
seized
that
moment
for
expounding
the
state
of
circumstances
on
which
the
opinion
of
the
sagacious
Bunsby
was
requested
,
and
entreating
that
profound
authority
to
deliver
the
same
.
  
<EOS>
Bunsby
,
whose
eye
continued
to
be
addressed
to
somewhere
about
the
half
-
way
house
between
London
and
Gravesend
,
two
or
three
times
put
out
his
rough
right
arm
,
as
seeking
to
wind
it
for
inspiration
round
the
fair
form
of
Miss
Nipper
;
but
that
young
female
having
withdrawn
herself
,
in
displeasure
,
to
the
opposite
side
of
the
table
,
the
soft
heart
of
the
Commander
of
the
Cautious
Clara
met
with
no
response
to
its
impulses
.
<EOS>
After
sundry
failures
in
this
wise
,
the
Commander
,
addressing
himself
to
nobody
,
thus
spake
;
or
rather
the
voice
within
him
said
of
its
own
accord
,
and
quite
independent
of
himself
,
as
if
he
were
possessed
by
a
gruff
spirit
:
  
"
My
name
's
Jack
Bunsby
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
christened
John
,
"
cried
the
delighted
Captain
Cuttle
.
"
<EOS>
Hear
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
I
says
,
"
pursued
the
voice
,
after
some
deliberation
,
"
I
stands
to
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
with
Florence
on
his
arm
,
nodded
at
the
auditory
,
and
seemed
to
say
,
"
Now
he
's
coming
out
.
<EOS>
This
is
what
I
meant
when
I
brought
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whereby
,
"
proceeded
the
voice
,
"
why
not
?
<EOS>
If
so
,
what
odds
?
<EOS>
Can
any
man
say
otherwise
?
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Awast
then
!
"
  
When
it
had
pursued
its
train
of
argument
to
this
point
,
the
voice
stopped
,
and
rested
.
<EOS>
It
then
proceeded
very
slowly
,
thus
:
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
believe
that
this
here
Son
and
Heir
's
gone
down
,
my
lads
?
<EOS>
Mayhap
.
<EOS>
Do
I
say
so
?
<EOS>
Which
?
<EOS>
If
a
skipper
stands
out
by
Sen
"
George
's
Channel
,
making
for
the
Downs
,
what
's
right
ahead
of
him
?
<EOS>
The
Goodwins
.
<EOS>
He
is
n't
forced
to
run
upon
the
Goodwins
,
but
he
may
.
<EOS>
The
bearings
of
this
observation
lays
in
the
application
on
it
.
<EOS>
That
an't
no
part
of
my
duty
.
<EOS>
Awast
then
,
keep
a
bright
look
-
out
for'ard
,
and
good
luck
to
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
voice
here
went
out
of
the
back
parlour
and
into
the
street
,
taking
the
Commander
of
the
Cautious
Clara
with
it
,
and
accompanying
him
on
board
again
with
all
convenient
expedition
,
where
he
immediately
turned
in
,
and
refreshed
his
mind
with
a
nap
.
  
<EOS>
The
students
of
the
sage
's
precepts
,
left
to
their
own
application
of
his
wisdom
upon
a
principle
which
was
the
main
leg
of
the
Bunsby
tripod
,
as
it
is
perchance
of
some
other
oracular
stools
---
looked
upon
one
another
in
a
little
uncertainty
;
while
Rob
the
Grinder
,
who
had
taken
the
innocent
freedom
of
peering
in
,
and
listening
,
through
the
skylight
in
the
roof
,
came
softly
down
from
the
leads
,
in
a
state
of
very
dense
confusion
.
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
however
,
whose
admiration
of
Bunsby
was
,
if
possible
,
enhanced
by
the
splendid
manner
in
which
he
had
justified
his
reputation
and
come
through
this
solemn
reference
,
proceeded
to
explain
that
Bunsby
meant
nothing
but
confidence
;
that
Bunsby
had
no
misgivings
;
and
that
such
an
opinion
as
that
man
had
given
,
coming
from
such
a
mind
as
his
,
was
Hope
's
own
anchor
,
with
good
roads
to
cast
it
in
.
<EOS>
Florence
endeavoured
to
believe
that
the
Captain
was
right
;
but
the
Nipper
,
with
her
arms
tight
folded
,
shook
her
head
in
resolute
denial
,
and
had
no
more
trust
in
Bunsby
than
in
Mr
Perch
himself
.
  
<EOS>
The
philosopher
seemed
to
have
left
Uncle
Sol
pretty
much
where
he
had
found
him
,
for
he
still
went
roaming
about
the
watery
world
,
compasses
in
hand
,
and
discovering
no
rest
for
them
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
pursuance
of
a
whisper
in
his
ear
from
Florence
,
while
the
old
man
was
absorbed
in
this
pursuit
,
that
Captain
Cuttle
laid
his
heavy
hand
upon
his
shoulder
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
cheer
,
Sol
Gills
?
"
cried
the
Captain
,
heartily
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
so
-
so
,
Ned
,
"
returned
the
Instrument
-
maker
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
remembering
,
all
this
afternoon
,
that
on
the
very
day
when
my
boy
entered
Dombey
's
house
and
came
home
late
to
dinner
,
sitting
just
there
where
you
stand
,
we
talked
of
storm
and
shipwreck
,
and
I
could
hardly
turn
him
from
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
meeting
the
eyes
of
Florence
,
which
were
fixed
with
earnest
scrutiny
upon
his
face
,
the
old
man
stopped
and
smiled
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stand
by
,
old
friend
!
"
cried
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
Look
alive
!
<EOS>
I
tell
you
what
,
Sol
Gills
;
arter
I
've
convoyed
Heart's
-
delight
safe
home
,
"
here
the
Captain
kissed
his
hook
to
Florence
,
"
I
'll
come
back
and
take
you
in
tow
for
the
rest
of
this
blessed
day
.
<EOS>
You
'll
come
and
eat
your
dinner
along
with
me
,
Sol
,
somewheres
or
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
to
-
day
,
Ned
!
"
said
the
old
man
quickly
,
and
appearing
to
be
unaccountably
startled
by
the
proposition
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
I
could
n't
do
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
returned
the
Captain
,
gazing
at
him
in
astonishment
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
have
so
much
to
do
.
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
I
mean
to
think
of
,
and
arrange
.
<EOS>
I
could
n't
do
it
,
Ned
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
must
go
out
again
,
and
be
alone
,
and
turn
my
mind
to
many
things
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
looked
at
the
Instrument
-
maker
,
and
looked
at
Florence
,
and
again
at
the
Instrument
-
maker
.
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
,
then
,
"
he
suggested
,
at
last
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
Think
of
me
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Say
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
come
here
early
,
mind
,
Sol
Gills
,
"
stipulated
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
.
<EOS>
The
first
thing
to
-
morrow
morning
,
"
said
old
Sol
;
"
and
now
good
-
bye
,
Ned
Cuttle
,
and
God
bless
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
Squeezing
both
the
Captain
's
hands
,
with
uncommon
fervour
,
as
he
said
it
,
the
old
man
turned
to
Florence
,
folded
hers
in
his
own
,
and
put
them
to
his
lips
;
then
hurried
her
out
to
the
coach
with
very
singular
precipitation
.
<EOS>
Altogether
,
he
made
such
an
effect
on
Captain
Cuttle
that
the
Captain
lingered
behind
,
and
instructed
Rob
to
be
particularly
gentle
and
attentive
to
his
master
until
the
morning
:
which
injunction
he
strengthened
with
the
payment
of
one
shilling
down
,
and
the
promise
of
another
sixpence
before
noon
next
day
.
<EOS>
This
kind
office
performed
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
who
considered
himself
the
natural
and
lawful
body
-
guard
of
Florence
,
mounted
the
box
with
a
mighty
sense
of
his
trust
,
and
escorted
her
home
.
<EOS>
At
parting
,
he
assured
her
that
he
would
stand
by
Sol
Gills
,
close
and
true
;
and
once
again
inquired
of
Susan
Nipper
,
unable
to
forget
her
gallant
words
in
reference
to
Mrs
MacStinger
,
"
Would
you
,
do
you
think
,
<EOS>
my
dear
,
though
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
the
desolate
house
had
closed
upon
the
two
,
the
Captain
's
thoughts
reverted
to
the
old
Instrument
-
maker
,
and
he
felt
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
instead
of
going
home
,
he
walked
up
and
down
the
street
several
times
,
and
,
eking
out
his
leisure
until
evening
,
dined
late
at
a
certain
angular
little
tavern
in
the
City
,
with
a
public
parlour
like
a
wedge
,
to
which
glazed
hats
much
resorted
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
principal
intention
was
to
pass
Sol
Gills
's
after
dark
,
and
look
in
through
the
window
:
which
he
did
.
<EOS>
The
parlour
door
stood
open
,
and
he
could
see
his
old
friend
writing
busily
and
steadily
at
the
table
within
,
while
the
little
Midshipman
,
already
sheltered
from
the
night
dews
,
watched
him
from
the
counter
;
under
which
Rob
the
Grinder
made
his
own
bed
,
preparatory
to
shutting
the
shop
.
<EOS>
Reassured
by
the
tranquillity
that
reigned
within
the
precincts
of
the
wooden
mariner
,
the
Captain
headed
for
Brig
Place
,
resolving
to
weigh
anchor
betimes
in
the
morning
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
24
.
<EOS>
The
Study
of
a
Loving
Heart
 
SIR
BARNET
and
Lady
Skettles
,
very
good
people
,
resided
in
a
pretty
villa
at
Fulham
,
on
the
banks
of
the
Thames
;
which
was
one
of
the
most
desirable
residences
in
the
world
when
a
rowing
-
match
happened
to
be
going
past
,
but
had
its
little
inconveniences
at
other
times
,
among
which
may
be
enumerated
the
occasional
appearance
of
the
river
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
the
contemporaneous
disappearance
of
the
lawn
and
shrubbery
.
  
<EOS>
Sir
Barnett
Skettles
expressed
his
personal
consequence
chiefly
through
an
antique
gold
snuff
-
box
,
and
a
ponderous
silk
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
which
he
had
an
imposing
manner
of
drawing
out
of
his
pocket
like
a
banner
,
and
using
with
both
hands
at
once
.
<EOS>
Sir
Barnet
's
object
in
life
was
constantly
to
extend
the
range
of
his
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
Like
a
heavy
body
dropped
into
water
---
not
to
disparage
so
worthy
a
gentleman
by
the
comparison
<EOS>
---
it
was
in
the
nature
of
things
that
Sir
Barnet
must
spread
an
ever
-
widening
circle
about
him
,
until
there
was
no
room
left
.
<EOS>
Or
,
like
a
sound
in
air
,
the
vibration
of
which
,
according
to
the
speculation
of
an
ingenious
modern
philosopher
,
may
go
on
travelling
for
ever
through
the
interminable
fields
of
space
,
nothing
but
coming
to
the
end
of
his
moral
tether
could
stop
Sir
Barnet
Skettles
in
his
voyage
of
discovery
through
the
social
system
.
  
<EOS>
Sir
Barnet
was
proud
of
making
people
acquainted
with
people
.
<EOS>
He
liked
the
thing
for
its
own
sake
,
and
it
advanced
his
favourite
object
too
.
<EOS>
For
example
,
if
Sir
Barnet
had
the
good
fortune
to
get
hold
of
a
raw
recruit
,
or
a
country
gentleman
,
and
ensnared
him
to
his
hospitable
villa
,
Sir
Barnet
would
say
to
him
,
on
the
morning
after
his
arrival
,
"
Now
,
my
dear
Sir
,
is
there
anybody
you
would
like
to
know
?
<EOS>
Who
is
there
you
would
wish
to
meet
?
<EOS>
Do
you
take
any
interest
in
writing
people
,
or
in
painting
or
sculpturing
people
,
or
in
acting
people
,
or
in
anything
of
that
sort
?
"
<EOS>
Possibly
the
patient
answered
yes
,
and
mentioned
somebody
,
of
whom
Sir
Barnet
had
no
more
personal
knowledge
than
of
Ptolemy
the
Great
.
<EOS>
Sir
Barnet
replied
,
that
nothing
on
earth
was
easier
,
as
he
knew
him
very
well
:
immediately
called
on
the
aforesaid
somebody
,
left
his
card
,
wrote
a
short
note
,
---
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Sir
---
penalty
of
your
eminent
position
---
friend
at
my
house
naturally
desirous
---
Lady
Skettles
and
myself
participate
---
trust
that
genius
being
superior
to
ceremonies
,
you
will
do
us
the
distinguished
favour
of
giving
us
the
pleasure
,
"
&
c.
,
&
c.
---
and
so
killed
a
brace
of
birds
with
one
stone
,
dead
as
door
-
nails
.
  
<EOS>
With
the
snuff
-
box
and
banner
in
full
force
,
Sir
Barnet
Skettles
propounded
his
usual
inquiry
to
Florence
on
the
first
morning
of
her
visit
.
<EOS>
When
Florence
thanked
him
,
and
said
there
was
no
one
in
particular
whom
she
desired
to
see
<EOS>
,
it
was
natural
she
should
think
with
a
pang
,
of
poor
lost
Walter
.
<EOS>
When
Sir
Barnet
Skettles
,
urging
his
kind
offer
,
said
,
"
My
dear
Miss
Dombey
,
are
you
sure
you
can
remember
no
one
whom
your
good
papa
---
to
whom
I
beg
you
to
present
the
best
compliments
of
myself
and
Lady
Skettles
when
you
write
---
might
wish
you
to
know
?
<EOS>
"
it
was
natural
,
perhaps
,
that
her
poor
head
should
droop
a
little
,
and
that
her
voice
should
tremble
as
it
softly
answered
in
the
negative
.
  
<EOS>
Skettles
Junior
,
much
stiffened
as
to
his
cravat
,
and
sobered
down
as
to
his
spirits
,
was
at
home
for
the
holidays
,
and
appeared
to
feel
himself
aggrieved
by
the
solicitude
of
his
excellent
mother
that
he
should
be
attentive
to
Florence
.
<EOS>
Another
and
a
deeper
injury
under
which
the
soul
of
young
Barnet
chafed
,
was
the
company
of
Dr
and
Mrs
Blimber
,
who
had
been
invited
on
a
visit
to
the
paternal
roof
-
tree
,
and
of
whom
the
young
gentleman
often
said
he
would
have
preferred
their
passing
the
vacation
at
Jericho
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
there
anybody
you
can
suggest
now
,
Doctor
Blimber
?
"
said
Sir
Barnet
Skettles
,
turning
to
that
gentleman
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
kind
,
Sir
Barnet
,
"
returned
Doctor
Blimber
.
<EOS>
"
Really
I
am
not
aware
that
there
is
,
in
particular
.
<EOS>
I
like
to
know
my
fellow
-
men
in
general
,
Sir
Barnet
.
<EOS>
What
does
Terence
say
?
<EOS>
Any
one
who
is
the
parent
of
a
son
is
interesting
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Has
Mrs
Blimber
any
wish
to
see
any
remarkable
person
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Sir
Barnet
,
courteously
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Blimber
replied
,
with
a
sweet
smile
and
a
shake
of
her
sky
-
blue
cap
,
that
if
Sir
Barnet
could
have
made
her
known
to
Cicero
,
she
would
have
troubled
him
;
but
such
an
introduction
not
being
feasible
,
and
she
already
enjoying
the
friendship
of
himself
and
his
amiable
lady
,
and
possessing
with
the
Doctor
her
husband
their
joint
confidence
in
regard
to
their
dear
son
---
here
young
Barnet
was
observed
to
curl
his
nose
---
she
asked
no
more
.
  
<EOS>
Sir
Barnet
was
fain
,
under
these
circumstances
,
to
content
himself
for
the
time
with
the
company
assembled
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
glad
of
that
;
for
she
had
a
study
to
pursue
among
them
,
and
it
lay
too
near
her
heart
,
and
was
too
precious
and
momentous
,
to
yield
to
any
other
interest
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
some
children
staying
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Children
who
were
as
frank
and
happy
with
fathers
and
with
mothers
as
those
rosy
faces
opposite
home
.
<EOS>
Children
who
had
no
restraint
upon
their
love
,
and
freely
showed
it
.
<EOS>
Florence
sought
to
learn
their
secret
;
sought
to
find
out
what
it
was
she
had
missed
;
what
simple
art
they
knew
,
and
she
knew
not
;
how
she
could
be
taught
by
them
to
show
her
father
that
she
loved
him
,
and
to
win
his
love
again
.
  
<EOS>
Many
a
day
did
Florence
thoughtfully
observe
these
children
.
<EOS>
On
many
a
bright
morning
did
she
leave
her
bed
when
the
glorious
sun
rose
,
and
walking
up
and
down
upon
the
river
's
bank
,
before
any
one
in
the
house
was
stirring
,
look
up
at
the
windows
of
their
rooms
,
and
think
of
them
,
asleep
,
so
gently
tended
and
affectionately
thought
of
.
<EOS>
Florence
would
feel
more
lonely
then
,
than
in
the
great
house
all
alone
;
and
would
think
sometimes
that
she
was
better
there
than
here
,
and
that
there
was
greater
peace
in
hiding
herself
than
in
mingling
with
others
of
her
age
,
and
finding
how
unlike
them
all
she
was
.
<EOS>
But
attentive
to
her
study
,
though
it
touched
her
to
the
quick
at
every
little
leaf
she
turned
in
the
hard
book
,
Florence
remained
among
them
,
and
tried
with
patient
hope
,
to
gain
the
knowledge
that
she
wearied
for
.
  
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
how
to
gain
it
!
<EOS>
how
to
know
the
charm
in
its
beginning!There
were
daughters
here
,
who
rose
up
in
the
morning
,
and
lay
down
to
rest
at
night
,
possessed
of
fathers
'
hearts
already
.
<EOS>
They
had
no
repulse
to
overcome
,
no
coldness
to
dread
,
no
frown
to
smooth
away
.
<EOS>
As
the
morning
advanced
,
and
the
windows
opened
one
by
one
,
and
the
dew
began
to
dry
upon
the
flowers
and
grass
,
and
youthful
feet
began
to
move
upon
the
lawn
,
Florence
,
glancing
round
at
the
bright
faces
,
thought
what
was
there
she
could
learn
from
these
children
?
<EOS>
It
was
too
late
to
learn
from
them
;
each
could
approach
her
father
fearlessly
,
and
put
up
her
lips
to
meet
the
ready
kiss
,
and
wind
her
arm
about
the
neck
that
bent
down
to
caress
her
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
begin
by
being
so
bold
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
could
it
be
that
there
was
less
and
less
hope
as
she
studied
more
and
more
!
  
<EOS>
She
remembered
well
,
that
even
the
old
woman
who
had
robbed
her
when
a
little
child
---
whose
image
and
whose
house
,
and
all
she
had
said
and
done
,
were
stamped
upon
her
recollection
,
with
the
enduring
sharpness
of
a
fearful
impression
made
at
that
early
period
of
life
---
had
spoken
fondly
of
her
daughter
,
and
how
terribly
even
she
had
cried
out
in
the
pain
of
hopeless
separation
from
her
child
.
<EOS>
But
her
own
mother
,
she
would
think
again
,
when
she
recalled
this
,
had
loved
her
well
.
<EOS>
Then
,
sometimes
,
when
her
thoughts
reverted
swiftly
to
the
void
between
herself
and
her
father
,
Florence
would
tremble
,
and
the
tears
would
start
upon
her
face
,
as
she
pictured
to
herself
her
mother
living
on
,
and
coming
also
to
dislike
her
,
because
of
her
wanting
the
unknown
grace
that
should
conciliate
that
father
naturally
,
and
had
never
done
so
from
her
cradle
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
this
imagination
did
wrong
to
her
mother
's
memory
,
and
had
no
truth
in
it
,
or
base
to
rest
upon
;
and
yet
she
tried
so
hard
to
justify
him
,
and
to
find
the
whole
blame
in
herself
,
that
she
could
not
resist
its
passing
,
like
a
wild
cloud
,
through
the
distance
of
her
mind
.
   
<EOS>
There
came
among
the
other
visitors
,
soon
after
Florence
,
one
beautiful
girl
,
three
or
four
years
younger
than
she
,
who
was
an
orphan
child
,
and
who
was
accompanied
by
her
aunt
,
a
grey
-
haired
lady
,
who
spoke
much
to
Florence
,
and
who
greatly
liked
(
but
that
they
all
did
)
to
hear
her
sing
of
an
evening
,
and
would
always
sit
near
her
at
that
time
,
with
motherly
interest
.
<EOS>
They
had
only
been
two
days
in
the
house
,
when
Florence
,
being
in
an
arbour
in
the
garden
one
warm
morning
,
musingly
observant
of
a
youthful
group
upon
the
turf
,
through
some
intervening
boughs
,
and
wreathing
flowers
for
the
head
of
one
little
creature
among
them
who
was
the
pet
and
plaything
of
the
rest
,
heard
this
same
lady
and
her
niece
,
in
placing
up
and
down
a
sheltered
nook
close
by
,
speak
of
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Florence
an
orphan
like
me
,
aunt
?
"
said
the
child
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
love
.
<EOS>
She
has
no
mother
,
but
her
father
is
living
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
she
in
mourning
for
her
poor
mama
,
now
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
child
quickly
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
for
her
only
brother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Has
she
no
other
brother
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
sister
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
,
very
sorry
!
"
said
the
little
girl
.
  
<EOS>
As
they
stopped
soon
afterwards
to
watch
some
boats
,
and
had
been
silent
in
the
meantime
,
Florence
,
who
had
risen
when
she
heard
her
name
,
and
had
gathered
up
her
flowers
to
go
and
meet
them
,
that
they
might
know
of
her
being
within
hearing
,
resumed
her
seat
and
work
,
expecting
to
hear
no
more
;
but
the
conversation
recommenced
next
moment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
is
a
favourite
with
every
one
here
,
and
deserves
to
be
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
the
child
,
earnestly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
is
her
papa
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
aunt
replied
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
,
that
she
did
not
know
.
<EOS>
Her
tone
of
voice
arrested
Florence
,
who
had
started
from
her
seat
again
;
and
held
her
fastened
to
the
spot
,
with
her
work
hastily
caught
up
to
her
bosom
,
and
her
two
hands
saving
it
from
being
scattered
on
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
in
England
,
I
hope
,
aunt
?
"
said
the
child
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
so
.
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
know
he
is
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Has
he
ever
been
here
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
not
.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Is
he
coming
here
to
see
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
lame
,
or
blind
,
or
ill
,
aunt
?
"
asked
the
child
.
  
<EOS>
The
flowers
that
Florence
held
to
her
breast
began
to
fall
when
she
heard
those
words
,
so
wonderingly
spoken
.
<EOS>
She
held
them
closer
;
and
her
face
hung
down
upon
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Kate
,
"
said
the
lady
,
after
another
moment
of
silence
,
"
I
will
tell
you
the
whole
truth
about
Florence
as
I
have
heard
it
,
and
believe
it
to
be
.
<EOS>
Tell
no
one
else
,
my
dear
,
because
it
may
be
little
known
here
,
and
your
doing
so
would
give
her
pain
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
will
!
"
exclaimed
the
child
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
never
will
,
"
returned
the
lady
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
trust
you
as
myself
.
<EOS>
I
fear
then
,
Kate
,
that
Florence
's
father
cares
little
for
her
,
very
seldom
sees
her
,
never
was
kind
to
her
in
her
life
,
and
now
quite
shuns
her
and
avoids
her
.
<EOS>
She
would
love
him
dearly
if
he
would
suffer
her
,
but
he
will
not
---
though
for
no
fault
of
hers
;
and
she
is
greatly
to
be
loved
and
pitied
by
all
gentle
hearts
.
"
  
<EOS>
More
of
the
flowers
that
Florence
held
,
fell
scattering
on
the
ground
;
those
that
remained
were
wet
,
but
not
with
dew
;
and
her
face
dropped
upon
her
laden
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
Florence
!
<EOS>
Dear
,
good
Florence
!
"
cried
the
child
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
why
I
have
told
you
this
,
Kate
?
"
said
the
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
I
may
be
very
kind
to
her
,
and
take
great
care
to
try
to
please
her
.
<EOS>
Is
that
the
reason
,
aunt
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Partly
,
"
said
the
lady
,
"
but
not
all
.
<EOS>
Though
we
see
her
so
cheerful
;
with
a
pleasant
smile
for
every
one
;
ready
to
oblige
us
all
,
and
bearing
her
part
in
every
amusement
here
:
she
can
hardly
be
quite
happy
,
do
you
think
she
can
,
Kate
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
not
,
"
said
the
little
girl
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
can
understand
,
"
pursued
the
lady
,
"
why
her
observation
of
children
who
have
parents
who
are
fond
of
them
,
and
proud
of
them
---
like
many
here
,
just
now
---
should
make
her
sorrowful
in
secret
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
dear
aunt
<EOS>
,
"
said
the
child
,
"
I
understand
that
very
well
.
<EOS>
Poor
Florence
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
More
flowers
strayed
upon
the
ground
,
and
those
she
yet
held
to
her
breast
trembled
as
if
a
wintry
wind
were
rustling
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
Kate
,
"
said
the
lady
,
whose
voice
was
serious
,
but
very
calm
and
sweet
,
and
had
so
impressed
Florence
from
the
first
moment
of
her
hearing
it
,
"
of
all
the
youthful
people
here
,
you
are
her
natural
and
harmless
friend
<EOS>
;
you
have
not
the
innocent
means
,
that
happier
children
have
---
"
  
"
There
are
none
happier
,
aunt
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
child
,
who
seemed
to
cling
about
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
<EOS>
As
other
children
have
,
dear
Kate
,
of
reminding
her
of
her
misfortune
.
<EOS>
Therefore
I
would
have
you
,
when
you
try
to
be
her
little
friend
,
try
all
the
more
for
that
,
and
feel
that
the
bereavement
you
sustained
---
thank
Heaven
!
<EOS>
before
you
knew
its
weight
---
gives
you
claim
and
hold
upon
poor
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not
without
a
parent
's
love
,
aunt
,
and
I
never
have
been
,
"
said
the
child
,
"
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
However
that
may
be
,
my
dear
,
"
returned
the
lady
,
"
your
misfortune
is
a
lighter
one
than
Florence
's
;
for
not
an
orphan
in
the
wide
world
can
be
so
deserted
as
the
child
who
is
an
outcast
from
a
living
parent
's
love
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
flowers
were
scattered
on
the
ground
like
dust
;
the
empty
hands
were
spread
upon
the
face
;
and
orphaned
Florence
,
shrinking
down
upon
the
ground
,
wept
long
and
bitterly
.
  
<EOS>
But
true
of
heart
and
resolute
in
her
good
purpose
,
Florence
held
to
it
as
her
dying
mother
held
by
her
upon
the
day
that
gave
Paul
life
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
know
how
much
she
loved
him
.
<EOS>
However
long
the
time
in
coming
,
and
however
slow
the
interval
,
she
must
try
to
bring
that
knowledge
to
her
father
's
heart
one
day
or
other
.
<EOS>
Meantime
she
must
be
careful
in
no
thoughtless
word
,
or
look
,
or
burst
of
feeling
awakened
by
any
chance
circumstance
,
to
complain
against
him
,
or
to
give
occasion
for
these
whispers
to
his
prejudice
.
  
<EOS>
Even
in
the
response
she
made
the
orphan
child
,
to
whom
she
was
attracted
strongly
,
and
whom
she
had
such
occasion
to
remember
,
Florence
was
mindful
of
him
.
<EOS>
If
she
singled
her
out
too
plainly
(
Florence
thought
)
from
among
the
rest
,
she
would
confirm
---
in
one
mind
certainly
:
perhaps
in
more
---
the
belief
that
he
was
cruel
and
unnatural
.
<EOS>
Her
own
delight
was
no
set
-
off
to
this
.
<EOS>
What
she
had
overheard
was
a
reason
,
not
for
soothing
herself
,
but
for
saving
him
;
and
Florence
did
it
,
in
pursuance
of
the
study
of
her
heart
.
  
<EOS>
She
did
so
always
.
<EOS>
If
a
book
were
read
aloud
,
and
there
were
anything
in
the
story
that
pointed
at
an
unkind
father
,
she
was
in
pain
for
their
application
of
it
to
him
;
not
for
herself
.
<EOS>
So
with
any
trifle
of
an
interlude
that
was
acted
,
or
picture
that
was
shown
,
or
game
that
was
played
,
among
them
.
<EOS>
The
occasions
for
such
tenderness
towards
him
were
so
many
,
that
her
mind
misgave
her
often
,
it
would
indeed
be
better
to
go
back
to
the
old
house
,
and
live
again
within
the
shadow
of
its
dull
walls
,
undisturbed
.
<EOS>
How
few
who
saw
sweet
Florence
,
in
her
spring
of
womanhood
,
the
modest
little
queen
of
those
small
revels
,
imagined
what
a
load
of
sacred
care
lay
heavy
in
her
breast
!
<EOS>
How
few
of
those
who
stiffened
in
her
father
's
freezing
atmosphere
,
suspected
what
a
heap
of
fiery
coals
was
piled
upon
his
head
!
  
<EOS>
Florence
pursued
her
study
patiently
,
and
,
failing
to
acquire
the
secret
of
the
nameless
grace
she
sought
,
among
the
youthful
company
who
were
assembled
in
the
house
,
often
walked
out
alone
,
in
the
early
morning
,
among
the
children
of
the
poor
.
<EOS>
But
still
she
found
them
all
too
far
advanced
to
learn
from
.
<EOS>
They
had
won
their
household
places
long
ago
,
and
did
not
stand
without
,
as
she
did
,
with
a
bar
across
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
one
man
whom
she
several
times
observed
at
work
very
early
,
and
often
with
a
girl
of
about
her
own
age
seated
near
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
very
poor
man
,
who
seemed
to
have
no
regular
employment
,
but
now
went
roaming
about
the
banks
of
the
river
when
the
tide
was
low
,
looking
out
for
bits
and
scraps
in
the
mud
;
and
now
worked
at
the
unpromising
little
patch
of
garden
-
ground
before
his
cottage
;
and
now
tinkered
up
a
miserable
old
boat
that
belonged
to
him
;
or
did
some
job
of
that
kind
for
a
neighbour
,
as
chance
occurred
.
<EOS>
Whatever
the
man
's
labour
,
the
girl
was
never
employed
;
but
sat
,
when
she
was
with
him
,
in
a
listless
,
moping
state
,
and
idle
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
had
often
wished
to
speak
to
this
man
;
yet
she
had
never
taken
courage
to
do
so
,
as
he
made
no
movement
towards
her
.
<EOS>
But
one
morning
when
she
happened
to
come
upon
him
suddenly
,
from
a
by
-
path
among
some
pollard
willows
which
terminated
in
the
little
shelving
piece
of
stony
ground
that
lay
between
his
dwelling
and
the
water
,
where
he
was
bending
over
a
fire
he
had
made
to
caulk
the
old
boat
which
was
lying
bottom
upwards
,
close
by
<EOS>
,
he
raised
his
head
at
the
sound
of
her
footstep
,
and
gave
her
Good
morning
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
morning
,
"
said
Florence
,
approaching
nearer
,
"
you
are
at
work
early
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'd
be
glad
to
be
often
at
work
earlier
,
Miss
,
if
I
had
work
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
so
hard
to
get
?
"
asked
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
find
it
so
,
"
replied
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
glanced
to
where
the
girl
was
sitting
,
drawn
together
,
with
her
elbows
on
her
knees
,
and
her
chin
on
her
hands
,
and
said
:
  
"
Is
that
your
daughter
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
raised
his
head
quickly
,
and
looking
towards
the
girl
with
a
brightened
face
,
nodded
to
her
,
and
said
"
Yes
.
"
<EOS>
Florence
looked
towards
her
too
,
and
gave
her
a
kind
salutation
;
the
girl
muttered
something
in
return
,
ungraciously
and
sullenly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
she
in
want
of
employment
also
?
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
Miss
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
work
for
both
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
there
only
you
two
,
then
?
"
inquired
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
us
two
,
"
said
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her
mother
has
been
dead
these
ten
year
.
<EOS>
Martha
!
<EOS>
"
(
he
lifted
up
his
head
again
,
and
whistled
to
her
)
"
wo
n't
you
say
a
word
to
the
pretty
young
lady
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
girl
made
an
impatient
gesture
with
her
cowering
shoulders
,
and
turned
her
head
another
way
.
<EOS>
Ugly
,
misshapen
,
peevish
,
ill
-
conditioned
,
ragged
,
dirty
---
but
beloved
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes!Florence
had
seen
her
father
's
look
towards
her
,
and
she
knew
whose
look
it
had
no
likeness
to
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
she
's
worse
this
morning
,
my
poor
girl
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
man
,
suspending
his
work
,
and
contemplating
his
ill
-
favoured
child
,
with
a
compassion
that
was
the
more
tender
for
being
rough
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
ill
,
then
!
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
drew
a
deep
sigh
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
my
Martha
's
had
five
short
days
'
good
health
,
"
he
answered
,
looking
at
her
still
,
"
in
as
many
long
years
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
<EOS>
and
more
than
that
,
John
,
"
said
a
neighbour
,
who
had
come
down
to
help
him
with
the
boat
.
  
<EOS>
"
More
than
that
,
you
say
,
do
you
?
"
<EOS>
cried
the
other
,
pushing
back
his
battered
hat
,
and
drawing
his
hand
across
his
forehead
.
"
<EOS>
Very
like
.
<EOS>
It
seems
long
,
long
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
the
more
the
time
,
"
pursued
the
neighbour
,
"
the
more
you
've
favoured
and
humoured
her
,
John
,
till
she
's
got
to
be
a
burden
to
herself
,
and
everybody
else
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
to
me
,
"
said
her
father
,
falling
to
his
work
again
.
<EOS>
"
Not
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
could
feel
---
who
better
?
<EOS>
---
how
truly
he
spoke
.
<EOS>
She
drew
a
little
closer
to
him
,
and
would
have
been
glad
to
touch
his
rugged
hand
,
and
thank
him
for
his
goodness
to
the
miserable
object
that
he
looked
upon
with
eyes
so
different
from
any
other
man
's
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
would
favour
my
poor
girl
---
to
call
it
favouring
---
if
I
did
n't
?
"
said
the
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
,
"
cried
the
neighbour
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
reason
,
John
.
<EOS>
But
you!You
rob
yourself
to
give
to
her
.
<EOS>
You
bind
yourself
hand
and
foot
on
her
account
.
<EOS>
You
make
your
life
miserable
along
of
her
.
<EOS>
And
what
does
she
care
!
<EOS>
You
do
n't
believe
she
knows
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
father
lifted
up
his
head
again
,
and
whistled
to
her
.
<EOS>
Martha
made
the
same
impatient
gesture
with
her
crouching
shoulders
,
in
reply
;
and
he
was
glad
and
happy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
for
that
,
Miss
,
"
said
the
neighbour
,
with
a
smile
,
in
which
there
was
more
of
secret
sympathy
than
he
expressed
;
"
only
to
get
that
,
he
never
lets
her
out
of
his
sight
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Because
the
day'll
come
,
and
has
been
coming
a
long
while
,
"
observed
the
other
,
bending
low
over
his
work
,
"
when
to
get
half
as
much
from
that
unfort'nate
child
of
mine
---
to
get
the
trembling
of
a
finger
,
or
the
waving
of
a
hair
---
would
be
to
raise
the
dead
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
softly
put
some
money
near
his
hand
on
the
old
boat
,
and
left
him
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
Florence
began
to
think
,
<EOS>
if
she
were
to
fall
ill
,
if
she
were
to
fade
like
her
dear
brother
,
would
he
then
know
that
she
had
loved
him
;
would
she
then
grow
dear
to
him
;
would
he
come
to
her
bedside
,
when
she
was
weak
and
dim
of
sight
,
and
take
her
into
his
embrace
,
and
cancel
all
the
past
?
<EOS>
Would
he
so
forgive
her
,
in
that
changed
condition
,
for
not
having
been
able
to
lay
open
her
childish
heart
to
him
,
as
to
make
it
easy
to
relate
with
what
emotions
she
had
gone
out
of
his
room
that
night
;
what
she
had
meant
to
say
if
she
had
had
the
courage
;
and
how
she
had
endeavoured
,
afterwards
,
to
learn
the
way
she
never
knew
in
infancy
?
  
<EOS>
Yes
,
she
thought
if
she
were
dying
,
he
would
relent
.
<EOS>
She
thought
,
that
if
she
lay
,
serene
and
not
unwilling
to
depart
,
upon
the
bed
that
was
curtained
round
with
recollections
of
their
darling
boy
,
he
would
be
touched
home
,
and
would
say
,
"
Dear
Florence
,
live
for
me
,
and
we
will
love
each
other
as
we
might
have
done
,
and
be
as
happy
as
we
might
have
been
these
many
years
!
"
<EOS>
She
thought
that
if
she
heard
such
words
from
him
,
and
had
her
arms
clasped
round
him
,
she
could
answer
with
a
smile
,
"
It
is
too
late
for
anything
but
this
;
I
never
could
be
happier
,
dear
father
!
"
<EOS>
and
so
leave
him
,
with
a
blessing
on
her
lips
.
  
<EOS>
The
golden
water
she
remembered
on
the
wall
,
appeared
to
Florence
,
in
the
light
of
such
reflections
,
only
as
a
current
flowing
on
to
rest
,
and
to
a
region
where
the
dear
ones
,
gone
before
,
were
waiting
,
hand
in
hand
;
and
often
when
she
looked
upon
the
darker
river
rippling
at
her
feet
,
she
thought
with
awful
wonder
,
but
not
terror
,
of
that
river
which
her
brother
had
so
often
said
was
bearing
him
away
.
  
<EOS>
The
father
and
his
sick
daughter
were
yet
fresh
in
Florence
's
mind
,
and
,
indeed
,
that
incident
was
not
a
week
old
,
when
Sir
Barnet
and
his
lady
going
out
walking
in
the
lanes
one
afternoon
,
proposed
to
her
to
bear
them
company
.
<EOS>
Florence
readily
consenting
,
Lady
Skettles
ordered
out
young
Barnet
as
a
matter
of
course
.
<EOS>
For
nothing
delighted
Lady
Skettles
so
much
,
as
beholding
her
eldest
son
with
Florence
on
his
arm
.
  
<EOS>
Barnet
,
to
say
the
truth
,
appeared
to
entertain
an
opposite
sentiment
on
the
subject
,
and
on
such
occasions
frequently
expressed
himself
audibly
,
though
indefinitely
,
in
reference
to
"
a
parcel
of
girls
.
<EOS>
"
As
it
was
not
easy
to
ruffle
her
sweet
temper
,
however
,
Florence
generally
reconciled
the
young
gentleman
to
his
fate
after
a
few
minutes
,
and
they
strolled
on
amicably
:
Lady
Skettles
and
Sir
Barnet
<EOS>
following
,
in
a
state
of
perfect
complacency
and
high
gratification
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
the
order
of
procedure
on
the
afternoon
in
question
:
and
Florence
had
almost
succeeded
in
overruling
the
present
objections
of
Skettles
Junior
to
his
destiny
,
when
a
gentleman
on
horseback
came
riding
by
,
looked
at
them
earnestly
as
he
passed
,
drew
in
his
rein
,
wheeled
round
,
an
came
riding
back
again
,
hat
in
hand
.
  
<EOS>
The
gentleman
had
looked
particularly
at
Florence
;
and
when
the
little
party
stopped
,
on
his
riding
back
,
he
bowed
to
her
,
before
saluting
Sir
Barnet
and
his
lady
.
<EOS>
Florence
had
no
remembrance
of
having
ever
seen
him
,
but
she
started
involuntarily
when
he
came
near
her
,
and
drew
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
horse
is
perfectly
quiet
,
I
assure
you
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
,
but
something
in
the
gentleman
himself
---
Florence
could
not
have
said
what
---
that
made
her
recoil
as
if
she
had
been
stung
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
the
honour
to
address
Miss
Dombey
,
I
believe
?
"
said
the
gentleman
,
with
a
most
persuasive
smile
.
<EOS>
On
Florence
inclining
her
head
,
he
added
,
"
My
name
is
Carker
.
<EOS>
I
can
hardly
hope
to
be
remembered
by
Miss
Dombey
,
except
by
name
.
<EOS>
Carker
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
,
sensible
of
a
strange
inclination
to
shiver
,
though
the
day
was
hot
,
presented
him
to
her
host
and
hostess
;
by
whom
he
was
very
graciously
received
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
pardon
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
"
a
thousand
times
!
<EOS>
But
I
am
going
down
to
-
morrow
morning
to
Mr
Dombey
,
at
Leamington
,
and
if
Miss
Dombey
can
intrust
me
with
any
commission
,
need
<EOS>
I
say
how
very
happy
I
shall
be
?
"
  
<EOS>
Sir
Barnet
immediately
divining
that
Florence
would
desire
to
write
a
letter
to
her
father
,
proposed
to
return
,
and
besought
Mr
Carker
to
come
home
and
dine
in
his
riding
gear
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
had
the
misfortune
to
be
engaged
to
dinner
,
but
if
Miss
Dombey
wished
to
write
,
nothing
would
delight
him
more
than
to
accompany
them
back
,
and
to
be
her
faithful
slave
in
waiting
as
long
as
she
pleased
.
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
with
his
widest
smile
,
and
bent
down
close
to
her
to
pat
his
horse
's
neck
,
Florence
meeting
his
eyes
,
saw
,
rather
than
heard
him
say
,
"
There
is
no
news
of
the
ship
!
"
  
<EOS>
Confused
,
frightened
,
shrinking
from
him
,
and
not
even
sure
that
he
had
said
those
words
<EOS>
,
for
he
seemed
to
have
shown
them
to
her
in
some
extraordinary
manner
through
his
smile
,
instead
of
uttering
them
,
Florence
faintly
said
that
she
was
obliged
to
him
,
but
she
would
not
write
;
she
had
nothing
to
say
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
to
send
,
Miss
Dombey
?
"
said
the
man
of
teeth
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
but
my
---
but
my
dear
love
---
if
you
please
.
"
  
<EOS>
Disturbed
as
Florence
was
,
she
raised
her
eyes
to
his
face
with
an
imploring
and
expressive
look
,
that
plainly
besought
him
,
if
he
knew
---
which
he
as
plainly
did
---
that
any
message
between
her
and
her
father
was
an
uncommon
charge
,
but
that
one
most
of
all
,
to
spare
her
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
smiled
and
bowed
low
,
and
being
charged
by
Sir
Barnet
with
the
best
compliments
of
himself
and
Lady
Skettles
,
took
his
leave
and
rode
away
:
leaving
a
favourable
impression
on
that
worthy
couple
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
seized
with
such
a
shudder
as
he
went
,
that
Sir
Barnet
,
adopting
the
popular
superstition
,
supposed
somebody
was
passing
over
her
grave
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
,
turning
a
corner
,
on
the
instant
,
looked
back
,
and
bowed
,
and
disappeared
,
as
if
he
rode
off
to
the
churchyard
straight
,
to
do
it
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
25
.
<EOS>
Strange
News
of
Uncle
Sol
 
CAPTAIN
CUTTLE
,
though
no
sluggard
,
did
not
turn
out
so
early
on
the
morning
after
he
had
seen
Sol
Gills
,
through
the
shop
-
window
,
writing
in
the
parlour
,
with
the
Midshipman
upon
the
counter
,
and
Rob
the
Grinder
making
up
his
bed
below
it
,
but
that
the
clocks
struck
six
as
he
raised
himself
on
his
elbow
,
and
took
a
survey
of
his
little
chamber
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
eyes
must
have
done
severe
duty
,
if
he
usually
opened
them
as
wide
on
awaking
as
he
did
that
morning
;
and
were
but
roughly
rewarded
for
their
vigilance
,
if
he
generally
rubbed
them
half
as
hard
.
<EOS>
But
the
occasion
was
no
common
one
,
for
Rob
the
Grinder
had
certainly
never
stood
in
the
doorway
of
Captain
Cuttle
's
bedroom
before
,
and
in
it
he
stood
then
,
panting
at
the
Captain
,
with
a
flushed
and
touzled
air
of
bed
about
him
,
that
greatly
heightened
both
his
colour
and
expression
.
  
<EOS>
"
Holloa
!
"
roared
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
  
<EOS>
Before
Rob
could
stammer
a
word
in
answer
,
Captain
Cuttle
turned
out
,
all
in
a
heap
,
and
covered
the
boy
's
mouth
with
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Steady
,
my
lad
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
"
do
n't
ye
speak
a
word
to
me
as
yet
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
looking
at
his
visitor
in
great
consternation
,
gently
shouldered
him
into
the
next
room
,
after
laying
this
injunction
upon
him
;
and
disappearing
for
a
few
moments
<EOS>
,
forthwith
returned
in
the
blue
suit
.
<EOS>
Holding
up
his
hand
in
token
of
the
injunction
not
yet
being
taken
off
,
Captain
Cuttle
walked
up
to
the
cupboard
,
and
poured
himself
out
a
dram
;
a
counterpart
of
which
he
handed
to
the
messenger
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
then
stood
himself
up
in
a
corner
,
against
the
wall
,
as
if
to
forestall
the
possibility
of
being
knocked
backwards
by
the
communication
that
was
to
be
made
to
him
;
and
having
swallowed
his
liquor
,
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
messenger
,
and
his
face
as
pale
as
his
face
could
be
,
requested
him
to
"
heave
ahead
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
mean
,
tell
you
,
Captain
?
"
asked
Rob
,
who
had
been
greatly
impressed
by
these
precautions
.
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
said
Rob
,
"
I
ai
n't
got
much
to
tell
.
<EOS>
But
look
here
!
"
  
<EOS>
Rob
produced
a
bundle
of
keys
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
surveyed
them
,
remained
in
his
corner
,
and
surveyed
the
messenger
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
look
here
!
"
<EOS>
pursued
Rob
.
  
<EOS>
The
boy
produced
a
sealed
packet
,
which
Captain
Cuttle
stared
at
as
he
had
stared

.
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
woke
this

,
Captain
,
"

,
"
which
was
about
a
quarter

five
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gone
!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Flowed
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
The

's

,

,

:

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
"
For
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
sir
,
"

,
"
is

,

.
<EOS>
Upon

,

,

.
<EOS>
I
wish
I

!
<EOS>
Here
's

sitiwation

lad

's
just

,
"

,

;
"
his

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
These

,

,

.
<EOS>
Taking

"
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
Enclosed

!
"
<EOS>
The

"
and
Testament
.
<EOS>
---
Where
's

?
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
see

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Do

,

.
<EOS>
I

Testament
.
"
  
<EOS>
Captain

,

;

---
   
"
Which
do
n't

,

decisive
intelligence
of

,

Ned
,

,
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

;
then
,
as

re
-
establishment

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

;

.
<EOS>
So
no

,

,

,
Solomon
Gills
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Captain
took

,

,
written
below
:
"
<EOS>
"
The
boy
Rob
,
well
recommended
,
as
I

,
from
Dombey
's

.
<EOS>
If

should
come

,
take
care
,
Ned
,
of
the
little
Midshipman
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
To
convey
to
posterity
any
idea
of
the

which
the
Captain
,
after
turning
this
letter
over
and
over
,

a

,
sat

,

held

-

on
the
subject
in

,
would

,

,

own

,

,

.
<EOS>
At

Captain
was
too

;

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
In

,

having

,

,

to
decide
,
generally
,

:

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

!
<EOS>
what

?
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
And

,

<EOS>
"

"
I

.

,

,

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Considering

youth
as

,

,

,

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
However
,

,

the
Instrument
-
maker
's
house
without

.
<EOS>
As

were
not

,

Captain
's
first

was
to
have
the
shop

;
and
when
the
daylight
was
freely

,
he
proceeded
,
with
its
aid
,
to
further
investigation
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
first
care
was
to
establish
himself
in
a
chair
in
the
shop
,
as
President
of

solemn

that
was
sitting
within

;
and
to
require
Rob
to
lie
down
in

under

counter
,
show
exactly
where
he

keys
and
packet
when

<EOS>
,
how

when

,

off

Brig
Place
---

latter

from
being
carried
farther
than

---
and
so
on
to
the
end
of
the
chapter
.
<EOS>
When
all

had
been
done
several

,

Captain

and
seemed
to
think

matter
had
a

.
  
<EOS>
Next
,

Captain
,

body
,
instituted

over

;

,
thrusting

behind
doors
,
bringing
his

into
violent

with

,

with

.
<EOS>
Mounting

old
man
's

,

that

not

,
but

,
as

the

yet

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
think
,
Captain
,
"
said
Rob
,

,
"
that

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
so
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,
and
wore

he

,
beyond

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,
"

Captain
---
"
not

---
about

?
<EOS>
Hey
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

,
"

,
"
that

gone

snore
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

Captain
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

,

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

I
'm

,
and
a
light

;

Gills
has

near
daybreak
,
though
ever
so
much
on
tip
-
toe
,
I
'm
pretty
sure
I
should
have
heard
him
shut
the
door
at
all
events
.
"
  
<EOS>
On
mature
consideration
of
this
evidence
,
Captain
Cuttle
began
to
think
that
the
Instrument
-
maker
must
have
vanished
of
his
own
accord
;
to
which
logical
conclusion
he
was
assisted
by
the
letter
addressed
to
himself
,
which
,
as
being
unquestionably
in
the
old
man
's
handwriting
,
would
seem
,
with
no
great
forcing
,
to
bear
the
construction
,
that
he
arranged
of
his
own
will
,
to
go
,
and
so
went
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
had
next
to
consider
where
and
why
?
<EOS>
and
as
there
was
no
way
whatsoever
that
he
saw
to
the
solution
of
the
first
difficulty
,
he
confined
his
media
-
tuitions
to
the
second
.
  
<EOS>
Remembering
the
old
man
's
curious
manner
,
and
the
farewell
he
had
taken
of
him
;
unaccountably
fervent
at
the
time
,
but
quite
intelligible
now
:
a
terrible
apprehension
strengthened
on
the
Captain
,
that
,
overpowered
by
his
anxieties
and
regrets
for
Walter
,
he
had
been
driven
to
commit
suicide
.
<EOS>
Unequal
to
the
wear
and
tear
of
daily
life
,
as
he
had
often
professed
himself
to
be
,
and
shaken
as
he
no
doubt
<EOS>
was
by
the
uncertainty
and
deferred
hope
he
had
undergone
<EOS>
,
it
seemed
no
violently
strained
misgiving
,
but
only
too
probable
.
  
<EOS>
Free
from
debt
,
and
with
no
fear
for
his
personal

,
or
the
seizure
of
his
goods
,
what
else
but
such

state
of
madness
could

hurried

away
alone
and
secretly
?
<EOS>
As
to
his
carrying
some

with

,
if

had
really
done

---
and
they
were
not
even
sure
of
that
---
he
might
have
done
so
,
the
Captain
argued
,
to
prevent

,
to
distract
attention
from
his
probable
fate
,
or
to
ease
the
very
mind
that
was
now

all
these
possibilities
.
<EOS>
Such
,
reduced
into
plain
language
,
and

within
a
small
compass
,
was
the
final
result
and

of
Captain
Cuttle
's

:
which
took
a
long

to
arrive
at
this
pass
,
and
were
,
like
some
more
public

,
very

and

.
  
<EOS>
Dejected
and
despondent
in
the
extreme
<EOS>
,
Captain
Cuttle
felt
it
just
to
release
Rob
from
the
arrest
in
which
he
had
placed
him
,
and
to
enlarge
him
,
subject
to
a
kind
of
honourable
inspection
which
he
still
resolved
to
exercise
;
and
having
hired
a
man
,
from
Brogley
the
Broker
,
to
sit
in
the
shop
during
their
absence
,
the
Captain
,
taking
Rob
with
him
,
issued
forth
upon
a
dismal
quest
after
the
mortal
remains
of
Solomon
Gills
.
  
<EOS>
Not
a
station
-
house
or
bone
-
house
,
or
work

house
in
the
metropolis
escaped
a
visitation
from
the
hard
glazed
hat
.
<EOS>
Along
the
wharves
,
among
the
shipping
on
the
bank
-
side
,
up
the
river
,
down
the
river
,
here
,
there
,
everywhere
,
it
went
gleaming
where
men
were
thickest
,
like
the
hero
's
helmet
in
an
epic
battle
.
<EOS>
For
a
whole
week
the
Captain
read
of
all
the
found
and
missing
people
in
all
the
newspapers
and

,
and
went
forth
on

at
all

the

to
identify
Solomon
Gills
,
in
poor
little
ship
-
boys
who
had
fallen
over
-
board
,
an
in
tall
foreigners
with
dark

who
had
taken
poison
---
"
to
make
sure
,
"
Captain
Cuttle
said
,
"
that
it
warn't
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
sure
thing
that
it
never
was
,
and
that
the
good
Captain
had
no
other
satisfaction
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
at
last
abandoned
these
attempts
as
hopeless
,
and
set
himself
to
consider
what
was
to
be
done
next
.
<EOS>
After
several
new

of
his
poor
friend
's
letter
,
he
considered
that
the
maintenance
of
"
a
home
in
the
old
place
for
Walter
"
was
the
primary

imposed
upon

.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
the
Captain
's
decision
was
,
that
he
would
keep

on
the

of
Solomon
Gills
himself
,
and
would
go
into
the
instrument
-
business
,
and
see
what
came
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
But

this

involved
the
relinquishment
of

at
Mrs
MacStinger
's
,
and
he

that
resolute
woman
would
never

of
his

them
,
the
Captain
took
the
desperate

of
running
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
look
ye
here
,
my
lad
,
"
said

to

,
when
he

,
"
to
-
morrow
,
I
sha
n't
be
found
in
this
here
roadstead
till
night
---
not
till
arter
midnight
p'rhaps
.
<EOS>
But
you

knock
,
and
the

you
do
,
turn
-
to
,
and
open

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very

,
Captain
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

rated

,
"

,
"

I

<EOS>
but

,

.
<EOS>
But

to
-

,
whatever

,
turn
-
to
and
show

smart

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
you
understand
,
"

,

"

,

,

;

,

show

smart

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Rob
again
assured

Captain
that
he
would
be
prompt
and

;
and
the
Captain
having
made

,
went

Mrs

's
for

.
  
<EOS>
The

had
of

,

,

any

,
was

.
<EOS>
It

,

,
that
Mrs

was
in

---
mild

as
a
house
-

;
and
Captain
Cuttle
's

,
when

.
  
<EOS>
"
A

-

,
Cap'en

,
"

:
"
or
a

's

.
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Come
,
Cap'en
Cuttle!Give

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

,

,
"

very

.
  
<EOS>
"
I'am

're

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Ma'am
<EOS>
,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>

,
"

,

"

's

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

?
"

---

.
  
<EOS>
The

was

.
<EOS>
"

,
Ma'am
,
"

"

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

Cuttle
,
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

,

.
"

,

,

,
"

<EOS>

,

to

,
in

,

'

.
"
  
<EOS>
These
innocent
MacStingers
were
so
many

to
the
Captain
's

,
when
they
appeared
in
a

,
and
tore
at

with
the

he
so
little

.
<EOS>
The
eye
of
Alexander
MacStinger
,
who
had
been
his
favourite
,
was
insupportable
to
the
Captain
;
the
voice
of
Juliana
MacStinger
,
who
was
the
picture
of
her
mother
,
made
a
coward
of

.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
kept
up
appearances
,
nevertheless
,
tolerably
well
,
and
for
an
hour
or
two
was
very
hardly
used
and
roughly
handled
by
the
young
MacStingers
:
who
in

,
did
a
little
damage
also
to
the
glazed
hat
,
by
sitting
in
it
,
two
at
a

,
as
in

nest
,
and
drumming
on
the
inside
of
the
crown
with
their

.
<EOS>
At
length
the
Captain
sorrowfully
dismissed
them
:
taking
leave
of
these
cherubs
with
the
poignant
remorse
and
grief
of
a
man
who
was
going
to
execution
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
silence
of
night
,
the
Captain
packed
up
his
heavier
property
in
a
chest
,
which
he
locked
,
intending
to
leave
it
there
,
in
all
probability
for
ever
,
but
on
the
forlorn
chance
of
one
day
finding
a
man
sufficiently
bold
and
desperate
to
come
and
ask
for
it
.
<EOS>
Of
his
lighter
necessaries
,
the
Captain
made
a
bundle
;
and
disposed
his
plate
about
his
person
,
ready
for
flight
.
<EOS>
At
the
hour
of
midnight
,
when
Brig
Place
was
buried
in
slumber
,
and
Mrs
MacStinger
was
lulled
in
sweet

,
with
her
infants
around
her
,
the
guilty
Captain
,
stealing
down
on

,
in
the
dark
,
opened
the
door
,
closed
it
softly
after
him
,
and
took
to
his
heels
.
  
<EOS>
Pursued
by
the
image
of
Mrs
MacStinger
springing
out
of
bed
,
and
,
regardless
of
costume
,
following
and
bringing
him
back
;
pursued
also
by
a
consciousness
of
his
enormous
crime
;
Captain
Cuttle
held
on
at
a
great
pace
,
and
allowed
no
grass
to
grow
under
his
feet
,
between
Brig
Place
and
the
Instrument
-
maker
's

.
<EOS>
It
opened
when
he
knocked
---
for
Rob
was
on
the
watch
---
and
when
it
was
bolted
and
locked
behind
him
,
Captain
Cuttle
felt
comparatively
safe
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whew
!
"
cried
the
Captain
,
looking
round
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
breather
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
the
matter
,
is
there
,
Captain
?
"
cried
the
gaping
Rob
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
!
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
after
changing

,
and
listening
to
a

in

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
mind
ye
,
my
lad
;
if
any
lady
,
except
either

them
two
as
you
see
t'other

,
ever

Cuttle
,

known
,

;

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
care
,
Captain
,
"
returned
Rob
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
might
say
---
if

,
"
hesitated

Captain
,
"
that
you
'd
read

that

,

,
along

whole

's

as

.
"
  
<EOS>
Rob
nodded
his
understanding
of
these

;
and
Captain
Cuttle
promising
to
make
a
man
of
him
,
if

,
dismissed

,
yawning
,
to
his
bed
under
the
counter
,
and
went
aloft
to
the
chamber
of
Solomon
Gills
.
  
<EOS>
What
the
Captain
suffered
next
day
,
whenever
a
bonnet
passed
,
or
how
often
he
darted
out
of
the
shop
to
elude
imaginary
MacStingers
,
and
sought
safety
in
the
attic
,
can
not
be
told
.
<EOS>
But
to
avoid
the
fatigues
attendant
on
this
means
of
self
-
preservation
,
the
Captain
curtained
the
glass
door
of
communication
between
the
shop
and
parlour
,
on
the
inside
,
fitted
a
key
to
it
from
the
bunch
that
had
been
sent
to
him
:
and
cut
a
small
hole
of
espial
in
the
wall
.
<EOS>
The
advantage
of
this
fortification
is
obvious
.
<EOS>
On
a
bonnet
appearing
,
the
Captain
instantly
slipped
into
his
garrison
,
locked
himself
up
,
and
took
a
secret
observation
of
the
enemy
.
<EOS>
Finding
it
a
false
alarm
,
the
Captain
instantly
slipped
out
again
.
<EOS>
And
the
bonnets
in
the
street
were
so
very
numerous
,
and
alarms
were
so
inseparable
from
their
appearance
,
that
the
Captain
was
almost
incessantly
slipping
in
and
out
all
day
long
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
found
time
,
however
,
in
the
midst
of
this
fatiguing
service
to
inspect
the
stock
;
in
connexion
with
which
he
had
the
general
idea
(
very
laborious
to
Rob
)
that
too
much
friction
could
not
be
bestowed
upon
it
,
and
that
it
could
not
be
made
too
bright
.
<EOS>
He
also
ticketed
a
few
attractive
-
looking
articles
at
a
venture
,
at
prices
ranging
from
ten
shillings
to
fifty
pounds
,
and
exposed
them
in
the
window
to
the
great
astonishment
of
the
public
.
  
<EOS>
After
effecting
these
improvements
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
surrounded
by
the
instruments
,
began
to
feel
scientific
:
and
looked
up
at
the
stars
at
night
,
through
the
skylight
,
when
he
was
smoking
his
pipe
in
the
little
back
parlour
before
going
to
bed
,
as
if
he
had
established
a
kind
of
property
in
them
.
<EOS>
As
a
tradesman
in
the
City
,
too
,
he
began
to
have
an
interest
in
the
Lord
Mayor
,
and
the
Sheriffs
,
and
in
Public
Companies
;
and
felt
bound
to
read
the
quotations
of
the
Funds
every
day
,
though
he
was
unable
to
make
out
,
on
any
principle
of
navigation
,
what
the
figures
meant
,
and
could
have
very
well
dispensed
with
the
fractions
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
the
Captain
waited
on
,
with
his
strange
news
of
Uncle
Sol
,
immediately
after
taking
possession
of
the
Midshipman
;
but
she
was
away
from
home
.
<EOS>
So
the
Captain
sat
himself
down
in
his
altered
station
of
life
,
with
no

but
Rob
the
Grinder
;
and

,

thought

of
Walter
,
and
of
Solomon
Gills
,
and
even
of
Mrs
MacStinger

,
as
among
the
things
that
had
been
.

Chapter
26
.

,

,

.
<EOS>
The
Manager
,
with
his

slightly
raised
,
affected
to
be
glancing
at
his
figures
,
and
to
await

leisure

his
principal
.
<EOS>
He
showed
that
he
affected
this
,
as
if
from
great
delicacy
,
and
with
a
design
to
spare
Mr
Dombey
's
feelings
;
and
the
latter
,
as

looked

,
was
cognizant
of

,
and
felt
that
but

it
,
this
confidential
Carker
would
have
said
a
great
deal
more
,
which
he
,
Mr
Dombey
,
was
too
proud
to
ask
for
.
<EOS>
It
was
his
way
in
business
,
often
.
<EOS>
Little
by
little
,
Mr
Dombey
's
gaze
relaxed
,
and
his
attention
became
diverted
to
the
papers
before
him
;
but
while

with
the

,

frequently

,
and
looked
at

Carker
again
.
<EOS>
Whenever

did

,
Mr
Carker
was
demonstrative
,
as
before
,
in
his
delicacy
,
and
impressed
it
on
his
great
chief
more
and
more
.
  
<EOS>
While
they
were
thus
engaged
;
and
under
the
skilful
culture
of
the
Manager
,
angry
thoughts
in

to
poor
Florence
brooded
and
bred
in

's
breast
,
usurping
the
place
of
the
cold
dislike
that
generally
reigned
there
;
Major
Bagstock
,
much
admired
by
the
old
ladies
of
Leamington
,
and
followed
by
the
Native
,
carrying
the
usual
amount
of
light
baggage
,
straddled
along
the
shady
side
of
the
way
,
to
make
a
morning
call
on
Mrs
Skewton
.
<EOS>
It
being
mid
-
day
when
the
Major
reached
the
bower
of
Cleopatra
,
he
had
the
good
fortune
to
find
his
Princess
on
her
usual
sofa
,
languishing
over
a
cup
of
coffee
,
with
the
room
so
darkened
and
shaded
for
her
more
luxurious
repose
,
that
Withers
,
who
was
in
attendance
on
her
,
loomed
like
a
phantom
page
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
insupportable
creature
is
this
,
coming
in
?
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
bear
it
.
<EOS>
Go
away
,
whoever
you
are
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
the
heart
to
banish
JB
.
<EOS>
Ma'am
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Major
,
halting
midway
,
to
remonstrate
,
with
his
cane
over
his
shoulder
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
it
's
you
,
is
it
?
<EOS>
On
second
thoughts
,
you
may
enter
,
"
observed
Cleopatra
.
  
<EOS>
The
Major
entered
accordingly
,
and
advancing
to
the
sofa
pressed
her
charming
hand
to
his
lips
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
"
said
Cleopatra
,
listlessly
waving
her
fan
,
"
a
long
way
off
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
come
too
near
me
,
for
I
am
frightfully
faint
and
sensitive
this
morning
,
and
you
smell
of
the
Sun
.
<EOS>
You
are
absolutely
tropical
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
George
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
the
time
has
been
when
Joseph
Bagstock
has
been
grilled
and
blistered
by
the
Sun
;
the
time
was
,
when
he
was
forced
,
Ma'am
,
into
such
full
blow
,
by
high
hothouse
heat
in
the
West
Indies
,
that
he
was
known
as
the
Flower
.
<EOS>
A
man
never
heard
of
Bagstock
,
Ma'am
,
in
those
days
;
he
heard
of
the
Flower
---
the
Flower
of
Ours
.
<EOS>
The
Flower
may
have
faded
,
more
or
less
,
Ma'am
,
"
observed
the
Major
,
dropping
into
a
much
nearer
chair
than
had
been
indicated
by
his
cruel
Divinity
,
"
but
it
is
a
tough
plant
yet
,
and
constant
as
the
evergreen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Here
the
Major
,
under
cover
of
the
dark
room
,
shut
up
one
eye
,
rolled
his
head
like
a
Harlequin
,
and
,
in
his
great
self
-
satisfaction
,
perhaps
went
nearer
to
the
confines
of
apoplexy
than
he
had
ever
gone
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Mrs
Granger
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
Cleopatra
of
her
page
.
  
<EOS>
Withers
believed
she
was
in
her
own
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
.
<EOS>
"
Go
away
,
and
shut
the
door
.
<EOS>
I
am
engaged
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
Withers
disappeared
,
Mrs
Skewton
turned
her
head
languidly
towards
the
Major
,
without
otherwise
moving
,
and
asked
him
how
his
friend
was
?
  
<EOS>
"
Dombey
,
Ma'am
,
"
returned
the
Major
,
with
a
facetious
gurgling
in
his
throat
,
"
is
as
well
as
a
man
in
his
condition
can
be
.
<EOS>
His
condition
is
a
desperate
one
,
Ma'am
.
<EOS>
He
is
touched
,
is
Dombey
!
<EOS>
Touched
!
"
cried
the
Major
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
bayonetted
through
the
body
.
"
  
<EOS>
Cleopatra
cast
a
sharp
look
at
the
Major
,
that
contrasted
forcibly
with
the
affected
drawl
in
which
she
presently
said
---
   
"
<EOS>
Major
Bagstock
,
although
I
know
<EOS>
but
little
of
the
world
,
---
nor
can
I
really
regret
my
inexperience
,
for
I
fear
it
is
a
false
place
,
full
of
withering
conventionalities
:
where
Nature
is
but
little
regarded
,
and
where
the
music
of
the
heart
,
and
the
gushing
of
the
soul
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
,
which
is
so
truly
poetical
,
is
seldom
heard
,
---
<EOS>
I
can
not
misunderstand
your
meaning
.
<EOS>
There
is
an
allusion
to
Edith
---
to
my
extremely
dear
child
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
tracing
the
outline
of
her
eyebrows
with
her
forefinger
,
"
in
your
words
,
to
which
the
tenderest
of
chords
vibrates
excessively
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bluntness
,
Ma'am
,
"
returned
the
Major
,
"
has
ever
been
the
characteristic
of
the
Bagstock
breed
.
<EOS>
You
are
right
,
Joe
admits
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
that
allusion
,
"
pursued
Cleopatra
,
"
would
involve
one
of
the
most
---
if
not
positively
the
most
---
touching
,
and
thrilling
,
and
sacred
emotions
of
which
our
sadly
-
fallen
nature
is
susceptible
,
I
conceive
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
laid
his
hand
upon
his
lips
,
and
wafted
a
kiss
to
Cleopatra
,
as
if
to
identify
the
emotion
in
question
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
feel
that
I
am
weak
.
<EOS>
I
feel
that
I
am
wanting
in
that
energy
,
which
should
sustain
a
mama
:
not
to
say
a
parent
:
on
such
a
subject
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
trimming
her
lips
with
the
laced
edge
of
her
pocket
-
handkerchief
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
can
hardly
approach
a
topic
so
excessively
momentous
to
my
dearest
Edith
without
a
feeling
of
faintness
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
bad
man
,
as
you
have
boldly
remarked
upon
it
,
and
as
it
has
occasioned
me
great
anguish
:
"
Mrs
Skewton
touched
her
left
side
with
her
fan
:
"
I
will
not
shrink
from
my
duty
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
,
under
cover
of
the
dimness
,
swelled
,
and
swelled
,
and
rolled
his
purple
face
about
,
and
winked
his
lobster
eye
,
until
he
fell
into
a
fit
of
wheezing
,
which
obliged
him
to
rise
and
take
a
turn
or
two
about
the
room
,
before
his
fair
friend
could
proceed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dombey
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
when
she
at
length
resumed
,
"
was
obliging
enough
,
now
many
weeks
ago
,
to
do
us
the
honour
of
visiting
us
here
;
in
company
,
my
dear
Major
,
with
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
acknowledge
---
<EOS>
let
me
be
open
---
that
it
is
my
failing
to
be
the
creature
of
impulse
,
and
to
wear
my
heart
,
as
it
were
,
outside
.
<EOS>
I
know
my
failing
full
well
.
<EOS>
My
enemy
can
not
know
it
better
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
penitent
;
I
would
rather
not
be
frozen
by
the
heartless
world
,
and
am
content
to
bear
this
imputation
justly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
arranged
her
tucker
,
pinched
her
wiry
throat
to
give
it
a
soft
surface
,
and
went
on
,
with
great
complacency
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
gave
me
(
my
dearest
Edith
too
,
I
am
sure
)
<EOS>
infinite
pleasure
to
receive
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
As
a
friend
of
yours
,
my
dear
Major
,
we
were
naturally
disposed
to
be
prepossessed
in
his

;
and
I
fancied
that
I
observed
an
amount
of
Heart
in
Mr
Dombey
,
that
was
excessively
refreshing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
devilish
little
heart
in
Dombey
now
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wretched
man
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs
Skewton
,
looking
at
him
languidly
,
"
pray
be
silent
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
JB
is
dumb
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dombey
,
"
pursued
Cleopatra
,
smoothing
the
rosy
hue
upon
her
cheeks
,
"
accordingly
repeated
his
visit
;
and
possibly
finding
some
attraction
in
the
simplicity
and
primitiveness
of
our
tastes
---
<EOS>
for
there
is
always
a
charm
in
nature
<EOS>
---
it
is
so
very
sweet
---
became
one
of
our
little
circle
every

.
<EOS>
Little

I
think
of
the
awful
responsibility
into
which
I

when
I

Mr
Dombey
---
to
---
"
   
"
To
beat
up
these
quarters
,
Ma'am
,
"
suggested
Major
Bagstock
.
  
<EOS>
"
Coarse
person
!
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
you
anticipate
my
meaning
,
though
in
odious
language
.
"
  
<EOS>
Here
Mrs
Skewton
rested
her
elbow
on
the
little
table
at
her
side
,
and
suffering
her
wrist
to
droop
in
what
she
considered
a
graceful
and
becoming
manner
,
dangled
her
fan
to
and
fro
,
and
lazily
admired
her
hand
while
speaking
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
agony
I
have
endured
,
"
she
said
mincingly
,
"
as
the
truth
has
by
degrees
dawned
upon
me
,
has
been
too
exceedingly
terrific
to
dilate
upon
.
<EOS>
My
whole
existence
is
bound
up
in
my
sweetest
Edith
;
and
to
see
her
change
from
day
to
day
---
<EOS>
my
beautiful
pet
,
who
has
positively
garnered
up
her
heart
since
the
death
of
that
most
delightful
creature
,
Granger
---
is
the
most
affecting
thing
in
the
world
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
's
world
was
not
a
very
trying
one
,
if
one
might
judge
of
it
by
the
influence
of
its
most
affecting
circumstance
upon
her
;
but
this
by
the
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
Edith
,
"
simpered
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
who
is
the
perfect
pearl
of
my
life
,
is
said
to
resemble
me
.
<EOS>
I
believe
we
are
alike
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
one
man
in
the
world
who
never
will

that
any

resembles
you
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
;
"
and
that
man
's
name
is
Old
Joe
Bagstock
.
"
  
<EOS>
Cleopatra
made
as
if
she
would
brain
the
flatterer
with
her
fan
,
but
relenting
,
smiled
upon
him
and
proceeded
:
  
"
If
my
charming
girl
inherits
any
advantages
from
me
,
wicked
one
!
"
<EOS>
:
the
Major
was
the
wicked
one
:
"
she
inherits
also
my
foolish
nature
.
<EOS>
She
has
great
force
of
character
---
mines
has
been
said
to
be
immense
,
though
I
do
n't
believe
it
---
but
once
moved
,
she
is
susceptible
and
sensitive
to
the
last
extent
.
<EOS>
What
are
my
feelings
when
I
see
her
pining
!
<EOS>
They
destroy
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
advancing
his
double
chin
,
and
pursing
up
his
blue
lips
into
a
soothing
expression
,
affected
the
profoundest
sympathy
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
confidence
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
that
has
subsisted
between
us
---
the
free
development
of
soul
,
and
openness
of

---
is
touching
to
think
of
.
<EOS>
We
have
been
more
like
sisters
than
mama
and
child
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
JB
's
own
sentiment
,
"
observed
the
Major
,
"
expressed
by
JB
fifty
thousand
times
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
not
interrupt
,
rude
man
!
"
said
Cleopatra
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
my
feelings
,
then
,
when
I
find
that
there
is
one
subject
avoided
by
us
!
<EOS>
That
there
is
a
what's
-
his
-
name
---
a

---
opened
between

.
<EOS>
That
my
own
artless
Edith
is
changed
to
<EOS>
me!They
are
of
the
most
poignant
description
,
of
course
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
left
his
chair
,
and
took
one
nearer
to
the
little
table
.
  
<EOS>
"
From
day
to
day
I
see
this
,
my
dear
Major
,
"
proceeded
Mrs
Skewton
.
<EOS>
"
From
day
to
day
I
feel
this
.
<EOS>
From
hour
to
hour
I
reproach
myself
for
that
excess
of
faith
and
trustfulness
which
has
led
to
such
distressing
consequences
;
and
almost
from
minute
to
minute
,
I
hope
that
Mr
Dombey
may
explain
himself
,
and
relieve
the
torture
I
undergo
,
which
is
extremely
wearing
.
<EOS>
But
nothing
happens
,
my
dear
Major
;
I
am
the
salve
of
remorse
---
take
care
of
the
coffee
-
cup
:
<EOS>
you
are
so
very
awkward
---
<EOS>
my
darling
Edith
is
an
altered
being
;
and
I
really
do
n't
see
what
is
to
be
done
,
or
what
good
creature
I
can
advise
with
.
"
  
<EOS>
Major
Bagstock
,
encouraged
perhaps
by
the
softened
and
confidential
tone
into
which
Mrs
Skewton
,
after

times
lapsing
into
it
for

,
seemed

to
have
subsided
for

,

across
the
little

,
and
said

,
  
"
Advise
with
Joe
,
Ma'am
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
you
aggravating
monster
,
"
said
Cleopatra
,
giving
one

to

Major
,
and

with

,
which

held
in

:
"
why
do
n't
you
talk
to
me
?
<EOS>
you
know
what
I
mean
.
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
tell
me
something
to
the
purpose
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
Major
laughed
,
and
kissed
the
hand
she
had
bestowed
upon
him
,
and
laughed
again
immensely
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
there
as
much
Heart
in
Mr
Dombey
as
I
gave
him
credit
for
?
"
languished
Cleopatra
tenderly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
think
he
is
in
earnest
,
my
dear
Major
?
<EOS>
Would
you
recommend
his
being
spoken

,
or
his
being
left
alone
?
<EOS>
Now
tell
me
,
like

dear

,
what

advise
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
marry
him
to
Edith
Granger
,
Ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
chuckled
the
Major
,
hoarsely
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mysterious
creature
!
"
returned

,
bringing
her
fan
to
bear
upon
the
Major
's
nose
.
<EOS>
"
How
can
we
marry
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
marry
him
to
Edith
Granger
,
Ma'am
,
I
say
?
<EOS>
"
chuckled
the
Major
again
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
returned
no
answer
in
words
,
but
smiled
upon
the
Major
with
so
much
archness
and
vivacity
,
that
that
gallant
officer
considering
himself
challenged
,
would
have
imprinted
a
kiss
on
her
exceedingly
red
lips
,
but
for
her
interposing
the
fan
with
a
very
winning
and
juvenile
dexterity
.
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
in
modesty
;
it
might
have
been
in
apprehension
of
some
danger
to
their
bloom
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dombey
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
is
a
great
catch
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
mercenary
wretch
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Cleopatra
,
with
a
little
shriek
,
"
I
am
shocked
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
Dombey
,
Ma'am
,
"
pursued
the
Major
,
thrusting
forward
his
head
,
and
distending
his
eyes
,
"
is
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
Joseph
says
it
;
Bagstock
knows
it
;
JB
keeps
him
to
the
mark
.
<EOS>
Leave
Dombey
to
himself
,
Ma'am
.
<EOS>
Dombey
is
safe
,
Ma'am
.
<EOS>
Do
as
you
have
done
;
do
no
more
;
and
trust
to
JB
for
the
end
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
really
think
so
,
my
dear
Major
?
"
returned
Cleopatra
,
who
had
eyed
him
very
cautiously
,
and
very
searchingly
,
in
spite
of
her
listless
bearing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sure
of
it
,
Ma'am
,
"
rejoined
the
Major
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Cleopatra
the
peerless
,
and
her
Antony
Bagstock
,
will
often
speak
of
this
,
triumphantly
,
when
sharing
the
elegance
and
wealth
of
Edith
Dombey
's
establishment
.
<EOS>
Dombey
's
right
-
hand
man
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
,
stopping

in
a

,
and
becoming
serious
,
"
has
arrived
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
This
morning
?
"
said
Cleopatra
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
morning
,
Ma'am
,
"
returned
the
Major
.
"
<EOS>
And
Dombey
's
anxiety
for
his
arrival
,
ma'am
,
is
to
be
referred
---
take
JB
's
word
for
this
;
for
Joe
is
de
-
vilish
sly
"
---
the
Major
tapped
his
nose
,
and
screwed
up
one
of
his
eyes
tight
:
which
did
not
enhance
his
native
beauty
---
"
to
his
desire
that
what
is
in
the
wind
should
become
known

him
,
without
Dombey
's
telling
and
consulting
him
.
<EOS>
For
Dombey
is
as
proud
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
,
"
as
Lucifer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
charming
quality
,
"
lisped
Mrs
Skewton
;
"
reminding
one
of
dearest
Edith
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
thrown
out
hints
already
,
and
the
right
-
hand
man
understands
'em
;
and
I
'll
throw
out
more
,
before
the
day
is
done
.
<EOS>
Dombey
projected
this
morning
a
ride
to
Warwick
Castle
,
and
to
Kenilworth
,
to
-
morrow
,
to
be
preceded
by
a

with
us
.
<EOS>
I
undertook
the
delivery
of
this

.
<EOS>
Will
you
honour
us
so
far
,
Ma'am
?
"
said
the
Major
,
swelling
with
shortness
of
breath
and
slyness
,
as
he
produced
a
note
,
addressed
to
the
Honourable
Mrs
Skewton
,
by
favour
of
Major
Bagstock
,
wherein
hers
ever
faithfully
,
Paul
Dombey
,
besought
her
and
her
amiable
and
accomplished
daughter
to
consent
to
the
proposed
