leave
off
shaking
hands
with
her
,
until
Sir
Barnet
appeared
:
to
whom
he
immediately
clung
with
the
tenacity
of
desperation
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
losing
,
to
-
day
,
Toots
,
"
said
Sir
Barnet
,
turning
towards
Florence
,
"
the
light
of
our
house
,
I
assure
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
of
no
conseqI
<EOS>
mean
<EOS>
yes
,
to
be
sure
,
"
faltered
the
embarrassed
Toots
.
<EOS>
"
GOODmorning
!
"
  
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
emphatic
nature
of
this
farewell
,
Mr
Toots
,
instead
of
going
away
,
stood
leering
about
him
,
vacantly
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
to
relieve
him
,
bade
adieu
,
with
many
thanks
,
to
Lady
Skettles
,
and
gave
her
arm
to
Sir
Barnet
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
beg
of
you
,
my
dear
Miss
Dombey
,
"
said
her
host
,
as
he
conducted
her
to
the
carriage
,
"
to
present
my
best
compliments
to
your
dear
Papa
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
distressing
to
Florence
to
receive
the
commission
,
for
she
felt
as
if
she
were
imposing
on
Sir
Barnet
by
allowing
him
to
believe
that
a
kindness
rendered
to
her
,
was
rendered
to
her
father
.
<EOS>
As
she
could
not
explain
,
however
,
she
bowed
her
head
and
thanked
him
;
and
again
she
thought
that
the
dull
home
,
free
from
such
embarrassments
,
and
such
reminders
of
her
sorrow
,
was
her
natural
and
best
retreat
.
  
<EOS>
Such
of
her
late
friends
and
companions
as
were
yet
remaining
at
the
villa
,
came
running
from
within
,
and
from
the
garden
,
to
say
<EOS>
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
attached
to
her
,
and
very
earnest
in
taking
leave
of
her
.
<EOS>
Even
the
household
were
sorry
for
her
going
,
and
the
servants
came
nodding
and
curtseying
round
the
carriage
door
.
<EOS>
As
Florence
looked
round
on
the
kind
faces
,
and
saw
among
them
those
of
Sir
Barnet
and
his
lady
,
and
of
Mr
Toots
,
who
was
chuckling
and
staring
at
her
from
a
distance
,
she
was
reminded
of
the
night
when
Paul
and
she
had
come
from
Doctor
Blimber
's
:
and
when
the
carriage
drove
away
,
her
face
was
wet
with
tears
.
  
<EOS>
Sorrowful
tears
,
but
tears
of
consolation
,
too
;
for
all
the
softer
memories
connected
with
the
dull
old
house
to
which
she
was
returning
made
it
dear
to
her
,
as
they
rose
up
.
<EOS>
How
long
it
seemed
since
she
had
wandered
through
the
silent
rooms
:
since
she
had
last
crept
,
softly
and
afraid
,
into
those
her
father
occupied
:
since
she
had
felt
the
solemn
but
yet
soothing
influence
of
the
beloved
dead
in
every
action
of
her
daily
life
!
<EOS>
This
new
farewell
reminded
her
,
besides
,
of
her
parting
with
poor
Walter
:
of
his
looks
and
words
that
night
:
and
of
the
gracious
blending
she
had
noticed
in
him
,
of
tenderness
for
those
he
left
behind
,
with
courage
and
high
spirit
.
<EOS>
His
little
history
was
associated
with
the
old
house
too
,
and
gave
it
a
new
claim
and
hold
upon
her
heart
.
  
<EOS>
Even
Susan
Nipper
softened
towards
the
home
of
so
many
years
,
as
they
were
on
their
way
towards
it
.
<EOS>
Gloomy
as
it
was
,
and
rigid
justice
as
she
rendered
to
its
gloom
<EOS>
,
she
forgave
it
a
great
deal
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
glad
to
see
it
again
,
I
do
n't
deny
,
Miss
,
"
said
the
Nipper
.
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
much
in
it
to
boast
of
,
but
I
would
n't
have
it
burnt
or
pulled
down
,
neither
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
be
glad
to
go
through
the
old
rooms
,
wo
n't
you
,
Susan
?
"
said
Florence
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Miss
,
"
returned
the
Nipper
,
softening
more
and
more
towards
the
house
,
as
they
approached
it
nearer
,
"
I
wo
n't
deny
but
what
I
shall
,
though
I
shall
hate
'em
again
,
to
-
morrow
,
very
likely
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
felt
that
,
for
her
,
there
was
greater
peace
within
it
than
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
It
was
better
and
easier
to
keep
her
secret
shut
up
there
,
among
the
tall
dark
walls
,
than
to
carry
it
abroad
into
the
light
,
and
try
to
hide
it
from
a
crowd
of
happy
eyes
.
<EOS>
It
was
better
to
pursue
the
study
of
her
loving
heart
,
alone
,
and
find
no
new
discouragements
in
loving
hearts
about
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
easier
to
hope
,
and
pray
,
and
love
on
,
all
uncared
for
,
yet
with
constancy
and
patience
,
in
the
tranquil
sanctuary
of
such
remembrances
:
although
it
mouldered
,
rusted
,
and
decayed
about
her
:
than
in
a
new
scene
,
let
its
gaiety
be
what
it
would
.
<EOS>
She
welcomed
back
her
old
enchanted
dream
of
life
,
and
longed
for
the
old
dark
door
to
close
upon
her
,
once
again
.
  
<EOS>
Full
of
such
thoughts
,
they
turned
into
the
long
and
sombre
street
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
not
on
that
side
of
the
carriage
which
was
nearest
to
her
home
,
and
as
the
distance
lessened
between
them
and
it
,
she
looked
out
of
her
window
for
the
children
over
the
way
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
thus
engaged
,
when
an
exclamation
from
Susan
caused
her
to
turn
quickly
round
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Gracious
me
!
"
cried
Susan
,
breathless
,
<EOS>
"
where
's
our
house
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our
house
!
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
Susan
,
drawing
in
her
head
from
the
window
,
thrust
it
out
again
,
drew
it
in
again
as
the
carriage
stopped
,
and
stared
at
her
mistress
in
amazement
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
labyrinth
of
scaffolding
raised
all
round
the
house
from
the
basement
to
the
roof
.
<EOS>
Loads
of
bricks
and
stones
,
and
heaps
of
mortar
,
and
piles
of
wood
,
blocked
up
half
the
width
and
length
of
the
broad
street
at
the
side
.
<EOS>
Ladders
were
raised
against
the
walls
:
labourers
were
climbing
up
and
down
;
men
were
at
work
upon
the
steps
of
the
scaffolding
:
painters
and
decorators
were
busy
inside
;
great
rolls
of
ornamental
paper
were
being
delivered
from
a
cart
at
the
door
;
an
upholsterer
's
waggon
also
stopped
the
way
;
no
furniture
was
to
be
seen
through
the
gaping
and
broken
windows
in
any
of
the
rooms
;
nothing
but
workmen
,
and
the
implements
of
their
several
trades
swarming
from
the
kitchens
to
the
garrets
.
<EOS>
Inside
and
outside
alike
:
bricklayers
,
painters
,
carpenters
,
masons
:
hammer
,
hod
,
brush
,
pickaxe
,
saw
,
and
trowel
:
all
at
work
together
,
in
full
chorus
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
descended
from
the
coach
,
half
doubting
if
it
were
,
or
could
be
the
right
house
,
until
she
recognized
Towlinson
,
with
a
sun
-
burnt
face
,
standing
at
the
door
to
receive
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
Miss.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
are
great
alterations
going
on
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Miss
,
great
alterations
,
"
said
Towlinson
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
passed
him
as
if
she
were
in
a
dream
,
and
hurried
up
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
garish
light
was
in
the
long
-
darkened
drawing
-
room
,
and
there
were
steps
and
platforms
,
and
men
in
paper
caps
,
in
the
high
places
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
's
picture
was
gone
with
the
rest
of
the
moveables
,
and
on
the
mark
where
it
had
been
,
was
scrawled
in
chalk
,
"
<EOS>
this
room
in
-
panel
.
<EOS>
Green
and
gold
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
staircase
was
a
labyrinth
of
posts
and
planks
like
the
out
-
side
of
the
house
,
and
a
whole
Olympus
of
plumbers
and
glaziers
was
reclining
in
various
attitudes
,
on
the
skylight
.
<EOS>
Her
own
room
was
not
yet
touched
within
,
but
there
were
beams
and
boards
raised
against
it
without
,
baulking
the
daylight
.
<EOS>
She
went
up
swiftly
to
that
other
bedroom
,
where
the
little
bed
was
;
and
a
dark
giant
of
a
man
with
a
pipe
in
his
mouth
,
and
his
head
tied
up
in
a
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
was
staring
in
at
the
window
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
here
that
Susan
Nipper
,
who
had
been
in
quest
of
Florence
,
found
her
,
and
said
,
would
she
go
down
stairs
to
her
Papa
,
who
wished
to
speak
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
home
!
<EOS>
and
wishing
to
speak
to
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Florence
,
trembling
.
  
<EOS>
Susan
,
who
was
infinitely
more
distraught
than
Florence
herself
,
repeated
her
errand
;
and
Florence
,
pale
and
agitated
,
hurried
down
again
,
without
a
moment
's
hesitation
.
<EOS>
She
thought
upon
the
way
down
,
would
she
dare
to
kiss
him
?
<EOS>
The
longing
of
her
heart
resolved
her
,
and
she
thought
she
would
.
  
<EOS>
Her
father
might
have
heard
that
heart
beat
,
when
it
came
into
his
presence
.
<EOS>
One
instant
,
and
it
would
have
beat
against
his
breast
---
   
<EOS>
But
he
was
not
alone
.
<EOS>
There
were
two
ladies
there
;
and
Florence
stopped
.
<EOS>
Striving
so
hard
with
her
emotion
,
that
if
her
brute
friend
Di
had
not
burst
in
and
overwhelmed
her
with
his
caresses
as
a
welcome
home
---
at
which
one
of
the
ladies
gave
a
little
scream
,
and
that
diverted
her
attention
from
herself
---
she
would
have
swooned
upon
the
floor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
,
"
said
her
father
,
putting
out
his
hand
:
<EOS>
so
stiffly
that
it
held
her
off
:
"
how
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
took
the
hand
between
her
own
,
and
putting
it
timidly
to
her
lips
,
yielded
to
its
withdrawal
.
<EOS>
It
touched
the
door
in
shutting
it
,
with
quite
as
much
endearment
as
it
had
touched
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
dog
is
that
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
displeased
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
dog
,
Papa
---
from
Brighton
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
;
and
a
cloud
passed
over
his
face
,
for
he
understood
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
very
good
-
tempered
,
"
said
Florence
,
addressing
herself
with
her
natural
grace
and
sweetness
to
the
two
lady
strangers
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
only
glad
to
see
me
.
<EOS>
Pray
forgive
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
saw
in
the
glance
they
interchanged
,
that
the
lady
who
had
screamed
,
and
who
was
seated
,
was
old
;
and
that
the
other
lady
,
who
stood
near
her
Papa
,
was
very
beautiful
,
and
of
an
elegant
figure
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
said
her
father
,
turning
to
the
first
,
and
holding
out
his
hand
,
"
this
is
my
daughter
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charming
,
I
am
sure
,
"
observed
the
lady
,
putting
up
her
glass
.
"
<EOS>
So
natural
!
<EOS>
My
darling
Florence
,
you
must
kiss
me
,
if
you
please
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
having
done
so
,
turned
towards
the
other
lady
,
by
whom
her
father
stood
waiting
.
  
<EOS>
"
Edith
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
this
is
my
daughter
Florence
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
this
lady
will
soon
be
your
Mama
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
started
,
and
looked
up
at
the
beautiful
face
in
a
conflict
of
emotions
,
among
which
the
tears
that
name
awakened
,
struggled
for
a
moment
with
surprise
,
interest
,
admiration
,
and
an
indefinable
sort
of
fear
.
<EOS>
Then
she
cried
out
,
"
Oh
,
Papa
,
may
you
be
happy
!
<EOS>
may
you
be
very
,
very
happy
all
your
life
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
fell
weeping
on
the
lady
's
bosom
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
short
silence
.
<EOS>
The
beautiful
lady
,
who
at
first
had
seemed
to
hesitate
whether
or
no
she
should
advance
to
Florence
,
held
her
to
her
breast
,
and
pressed
the
hand
with
which
she
clasped
her
,
close
about
her
waist
,
as
if
to
reassure
her
and
comfort
her
.
<EOS>
Not
one
word
passed
the
lady
's
lips
.
<EOS>
She
bent
her
head
down
over
Florence
,
and
she
kissed
her
on
the
cheek
,
but
she
said
no
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
go
on
through
the
rooms
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
and
see
how
our
workmen
are
doing
?
<EOS>
Pray
allow
me
,
my
dear
madam
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
said
this
in
offering
his
arm
to
Mrs
Skewton
,
who
had
been
looking
at
Florence
through
her
glass
,
as
though
picturing
to
herself
what
she
might
be
made
,
by
the
fashion
---
from
her
own
copious
storehouse
,
no
doubt
---
of
a
little
more
Heart
and
Nature
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
still
sobbing
on
the
lady
's
breast
,
and
holding
to
her
,
when
Mr
Dombey
was
heard
to
say
from
the
Conservatory
:
  
"
Let
us
ask
Edith
.
<EOS>
Dear
me
,
where
is
she
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Edith
,
my
dear
!
"
cried
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
where
are
you
?
<EOS>
Looking
for
Mr
Dombey
somewhere
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
We
are
here
,
my
love
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
beautiful
lady
released
her
hold
of
Florence
,
and
pressing
her
lips
once
more
upon
her
face
,
withdrew
hurriedly
,
and
joined
them
.
<EOS>
Florence
remained
standing
in
the
same
place
:
happy
,
sorry
,
joyful
,
and
in
tears
,
she
knew
not
how
,
or
how
long
,
but
all
at
once
:
when
her
new
Mama
came
back
,
and
took
her
in
her
arms
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
,
"
said
the
lady
,
hurriedly
,
and
looking
into
her
face
with
great
earnestness
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
begin
by
hating
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
hating
you
,
Mama
?
"
cried
Florence
,
winding
her
arm
round
her
neck
,
and
returning
the
look
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
<EOS>
Begin
by
thinking
well
of
me
,
"
said
the
beautiful
lady
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Begin
by
believing
that
I
will
try
to
make
you
happy
,
and
that
I
am
prepared
to
love
you
,
Florence
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
We
shall
meet
again
soon
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
stay
here
,
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Again
she
pressed
her
to
her
breast
---
she
had
spoken
in
a
rapid
manner
,
but
firmly
---
and
Florence
saw
her
rejoin
them
in
the
other
room
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
Florence
began
to
hope
that
she
would
learn
from
her
new
and
beautiful
Mama
,
how
to
gain
her
father
's
love
;
and
in
her
sleep
that
night
,
in
her
lost
old
home
,
her
own
Mama
smiled
radiantly
upon
the
hope
,
and
blessed
it
.
<EOS>
Dreaming
Florence
!
   
<EOS>
Chapter
29
.
<EOS>
The
Opening
of
the
Eyes
of
Mrs
Chick
 
MISS
TOX
,
all
unconscious
of
any
such
rare
appearances
in
connexion
with
Mr
Dombey
's
house
,
as
scaffoldings
and
ladders
,
and
men
with
their
heads
tied
up
in
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
,
glaring
in
at
the
windows
like
flying
genii
or
strange
birds
,
---
having
breakfasted
one
morning
at
about
this
eventful
period
of
time
,
on
her
customary
viands
;
to
wit
,
one
French
roll
rasped
,
one
egg
new
laid
(
or
warranted
to
be
)
,
and
one
little
pot
of
tea
,
<EOS>
wherein
was
infused
one
little
silver
scoopful
of
that
herb
on
behalf
of
Miss
Tox
,
and
one
little
silver
scoopful
on
behalf
of
the
teapot
---
a
flight
of
fancy
in
which
good
housekeepers
delight
;
went
up
stairs
to
set
forth
the
bird
waltz
on
the
harpsichord
,
to
water
and
arrange
the
plants
,
to
dust
the
nick
-
nacks
,
and
according
to
her
daily
custom
,
to
make
her
little
drawing
-
room
the
garland
of
Princess
's
Place
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
endued
herself
with
a
pair
of
ancient
gloves
,
like
dead
leaves
,
in
which
she
was
accustomed
to
perform
these
avocations
---
hidden
from
human
sight
at
other
times
in
a
table
drawer
---
and
went
methodically
to
work
;
beginning
with
the
bird
waltz
;
passing
,
by
a
natural
association
of
ideas
,
to
her
bird
---
a
very
high
-
shouldered
canary
,
stricken
in
years
,
and
much
rumpled
,
but
a
piercing
singer
,
as
Princess
's
Place
well
knew
;
taking
,
next
in
order
,
the
little
china
ornaments
,
paper
fly
-
cages
,
and
so
forth
;
and
coming
round
,
in
good
time
,
to
the
plants
,
which
generally
required
to
be
snipped
here
and
there
with
a
pair
of
scissors
,
for
some
botanical
reason
that
was
very
powerful
with
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
was
slow
in
coming
to
the
plants
,
this
morning
.
<EOS>
The
weather
was
warm
,
the
wind
southerly
;
and
there
was
a
sigh
of
the
summer
-
time
in
Princess
's
Place
,
that
turned
Miss
Tox
's
thoughts
upon
the
country
.
<EOS>
The
pot
-
boy
attached
to
the
Princess
's
Arms
had
come
out
with
a
can
and
trickled
water
,
in
a
flowing
pattern
,
all
over
Princess
's
Place
,
and
it
gave
the
weedy
ground
a
fresh
scent
---
quite
a
growing
scent
,
Miss
Tox
said
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
tiny
blink
of
sun
peeping
in
from
the
great
street
round
the
corner
,
and
the
smoky
sparrows
hopped
over
it
and
back
again
,
brightening
as
they
passed
:
or
bathed
in
it
,
like
a
stream
,
and
became
glorified
sparrows
,
unconnected
with
chimneys
.
<EOS>
Legends
in
praise
of
Ginger
-
Beer
,
with
pictorial
representations
of
thirsty
customers
submerged
in
the
effervescence
,
or
stunned
by
the
flying
corks
,
were
conspicuous
in
the
window
of
the
Princess
's
Arms
.
<EOS>
They
were
making
late
hay
,
somewhere
out
of
town
;
and
though
the
fragrance
had
a
long
way
to
come
,
and
many
counter
fragrances
to
contend
with
among
the
dwellings
of
the
poor
<EOS>
(
may
God
reward
the
worthy
gentlemen
who
stickle
for
the
Plague
as
part
and
parcel
of
the
wisdom
of
our
ancestors
,
and
who
do
their
little
best
to
keep
those
dwellings
miserable
!
)
,
yet
it
was
wafted
faintly
into
Princess
's
Place
,
whispering
of
Nature
and
her
wholesome
air
,
as
such
things
will
,
even
unto
prisoners
and
captives
,
and
those
who
are
desolate
and
oppressed
,
in
very
spite
of
aldermen
and
knights
to
boot
:
at
whose
sage
nod
---
and
how
they
nod
!
---
the
rolling
world
stands
still
!
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
sat
down
upon
the
widow
-
seat
,
and
thought
of
her
good
papa
deceased
---
<EOS>
Mr
Tox
,
of
the
Customs
Department
of
the
public
service
;
and
of
her
childhood
,
passed
at
a
seaport
,
among
a
considerable
quantity
of
cold
tar
,
and
some
rusticity
.
<EOS>
She
fell
into
a
softened
remembrance
of
meadows
,
in
old
time
,
gleaming
with
buttercups
,
like
so
many
inverted
firmaments
of
golden
stars
;
and
how
she
had
made
chains
of
dandelion
-
stalks
for
youthful
vowers
of
eternal
constancy
,
dressed
chiefly
in
nankeen
;
and
how
soon
those
fetters
had
withered
and
broken
.
  
<EOS>
Sitting
on
the
window
-
seat
,
and
looking
out
upon
the
sparrows
and
the
blink
of
sun
,
Miss
Tox
thought
likewise
of
her
good
mama
<EOS>
deceased
---
sister
to
the
owner
of
the
powdered
head
and
pigtail
---
of
her
virtues
and
her
rheumatism
.
<EOS>
And
when
a
man
with
bulgy
legs
,
and
a
rough
voice
,
and
a
heavy
basket
on
his
head
that
crushed
his
hat
into
a
mere
black
muffin
,
came
crying
flowers
down
Princess
's
Place
,
making
his
timid
little
roots
of
daisies
shudder
in
the
vibration
of
every
yell
he
gave
,
as
though
he
had
been
an
ogre
,
hawking
little
children
<EOS>
,
summer
recollections
were
so
strong
upon
Miss
Tox
,
that
she
shook
her
head
,
and
murmured
she
would
be
comparatively
old
before
she
knew
it
---
which
seemed
likely
.
   
<EOS>
In
her
pensive
mood
,
Miss
Tox
's
thoughts
went
wandering
on
Mr
Dombey
's
track
;
probably
because
the
Major
had
returned
home
to
his
lodgings
opposite
,
and
had
just
bowed
to
her
from
his
window
.
<EOS>
What
other
reason
could
Miss
Tox
have
for
connecting
Mr
Dombey
with
her
summer
days
and
dandelion
fetters
?
<EOS>
Was
he
more
cheerful
?
<EOS>
thought
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
Was
he
reconciled
to
the
decrees
of
fate
?
<EOS>
Would
he
ever
marry
again
?
<EOS>
and
if
yes
,
whom
?
<EOS>
What
sort
of
person
now
!
  
<EOS>
A
flush
---
it
was
warm
weather
---
overspread
Miss
Tox
's
face
,
as
,
while
entertaining
these
meditations
,
she
turned
her
head
,
and
was
surprised
by
the
reflection
of
her
thoughtful
image
in
the
chimney
-
glass
.
<EOS>
Another
flush
succeeded
when
she
saw
a
little
carriage
drive
into
Princess
's
Place
,
and
make
straight
for
her
own
door
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
arose
,
took
up
her
scissors
hastily
,
and
so
coming
,
at
last
,
to
the
plants
,
was
very
busy
with
them
when
Mrs
Chick
entered
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
is
my
sweetest
friend
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Tox
,
with
open
arms
.
  
<EOS>
A
little
stateliness
was
mingled
with
Miss
Tox
's
sweetest
friend
's
demeanour
,
but
she
kissed
Miss
Tox
,
and
said
,
"
<EOS>
Lucretia
,
thank
you
,
I
am
pretty
well
.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
the
same
.
<EOS>
Hem
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
was
labouring
under
a
peculiar
little
monosyllabic
cough
;
a
sort
of
primer
,
or
easy
introduction
to
the
art
of
coughing
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
call
very
early
,
and
how
kind
that
is
,
my
dear
!
"
pursued
Miss
Tox
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
have
you
breakfasted
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Lucretia
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
.
<EOS>
I
took
an
early
breakfast
"
---
the
good
lady
seemed
curious
on
the
subject
of
Princess
's
Place
,
and
looked
all
round
it
as
she
spoke
---
"
with
my
brother
,
who
has
come
home
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
better
,
I
trust
,
my
love
,
"
faltered
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
greatly
better
,
thank
you
.
<EOS>
Hem
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Louisa
must
be
careful
of
that
cough
,
"
remarked
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
,
"
returned
Mrs
Chick
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
merely
change
of
weather
.
<EOS>
We
must
expect
change
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Of
weather
?
"
asked
Miss
Tox
,
in
her
simplicity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
everything
,
"
returned
Mrs
Chick
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
we
must
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
world
of
change
.
<EOS>
Any
one
would
surprise
me
very
much
,
Lucretia
,
and
would
greatly
alter
my
opinion
of
their
understanding
,
if
they
attempted
to
contradict
or
evade
what
is
so
perfectly
evident
.
<EOS>
Change
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mrs
Chick
,
with
severe
philosophy
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
gracious
me
,
what
is
there
that
does
not
change
!
<EOS>
even
the
silkworm
,
who
I
am
sure
might
be
supposed
not
to
trouble
itself
about
such
subjects
,
changes
into
all
sorts
of
unexpected
things
continually
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
Louisa
,
"
said
the
mild
Miss
Tox
,
"
is
ever
happy
in
her
illustrations
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
so
kind
,
Lucretia
,
"
returned
Mrs
Chick
,
a
little
softened
,
"
as
to
say
so
,
and
to
think
so
<EOS>
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
I
hope
neither
of
us
may
ever
have
any
cause
to
lessen
our
opinion
of
the
other
,
Lucretia
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
of
it
,
"
returned
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
coughed
as
before
,
and
drew
lines
on
the
carpet
with
the
ivory
end
of
her
parasol
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
,
who
had
experience
of
her
fair
friend
,
and
knew
that
under
the
pressure
of
any
slight
fatigue
or
vexation
she
was
prone
to
a
discursive
kind
of
irritability
,
availed
herself
of
the
pause
,
to
change
the
subject
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
my
dear
Louisa
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
"
but
<EOS>
have
I
caught
sight
of
the
manly
form
of
Mr
Chick
in
the
carriage
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
there
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
"
but
pray
leave
him
there
.
<EOS>
He
has
his
newspaper
,
and
would
be
quite
contented
for
the
next
two
hours
.
<EOS>
Go
on
with
your
flowers
,
Lucretia
,
and
allow
me
to
sit
here
and
rest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
Louisa
knows
,
"
observed
Miss
Tox
,
"
that
between
friends
like
ourselves
,
any
approach
to
ceremony
would
be
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
Therefore
---
"
Therefore
Miss
Tox
finished
the
sentence
,
not
in
words
but
action
;
and
putting
on
her
gloves
again
,
which
she
had
taken
off
,
and
arming
herself
once
more
with
her
scissors
,
began
to
snip
and
clip
among
the
leaves
with
microscopic
industry
.
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
has
returned
home
also
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
after
sitting
silent
for
some
time
,
with
her
head
on
one
side
,
and
her
parasol
sketching
on
the
floor
;
"
and
really
Florence
is
a
great
deal
too
old
now
,
to
continue
to
lead
that
solitary
life
to
which
she
has
been
accustomed
.
<EOS>
Of
course
she
is
.
<EOS>
There
can
be
no
doubt
about
it
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
very
little
respect
,
indeed
,
for
anybody
who
could
advocate
a
different
opinion
.
<EOS>
Whatever
my
wishes
might
be
,
I
could
not
respect
them
.
<EOS>
We
can
not
command
our
feelings
to
such
an
extent
as
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
assented
,
without
being
particular
as
to
the
intelligibility
of
the
proposition
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
she
's
a
strange
girl
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
"
and
if
my
brother
Paul
can
not
feel
perfectly
comfortable
in
her
society
,
after
all
the
sad
things
that
have
happened
,
and
<EOS>
all
the
terrible
disappointments
that
have
been
undergone
,
then
,
what
is
the
reply
?
<EOS>
That
he
must
make
an
effort
.
<EOS>
That
he
is
bound
to
make
an
effort
.
<EOS>
We
have
always
been
a
family
remarkable
for
effort
.
<EOS>
Paul
is
at
the
head
of
the
family
;
almost
the
only
representative
of
it
left
---
for
what
am
I
---
I
am
of
no
consequence
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
love
,
"
remonstrated
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
dried
her
eyes
,
which
were
,
for
the
moment
,
overflowing
;
and
proceeded
:
  
"
<EOS>
And
consequently
he
is
more
than
ever
bound
to
make
an
effort
.
<EOS>
And
though
his
having
done
so
,
comes
upon
me
with
a
sort
of
shock
---
for
mine
is
a
very
weak
and
foolish
nature
;
which
is
anything
but
a
blessing
I
am
sure
;
I
often
wish
my
heart
was
a
marble
slab
,
or
a
paving
-
stone
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
My
sweet
Louisa
,
"
remonstrated
Miss
Tox
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Still
,
it
is
a
triumph
to
me
to
know
that
he
is
so
true
to
himself
,
and
to
his
name
of
Dombey
;
although
,
of
course
,
I
always
knew
he
would
be
.
<EOS>
I
only
hope
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
after
a
pause
,
"
that
she
may
be
worthy
of
the
name
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
filled
a
little
green
watering
-
pot
from
a
jug
,
and
happening
to
look
up
when
she
had
done
so
,
was
so
surprised
by
the
amount
of
expression
Mrs
Chick
had
conveyed
into
her
face
,
and
was
bestowing
upon
her
,
that
she
put
the
little
watering
-
pot
on
the
table
for
the
present
,
and
sat
down
near
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Louisa
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
"
will
it
be
the
least
satisfaction
to
you
,
if
I
venture
to
observe
in
reference
to
that
remark
,
that
I
,
as
a
humble
individual
,
think
your
sweet
niece
in
every
way
most
promising
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
,
Lucretia
?
"
returned
Mrs
Chick
,
with
increased
stateliness
of
manner
.
<EOS>
"
To
what
remark
of
mine
,
my
dear
,
do
you
refer
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Her
being
worthy
of
her
name
,
my
love
.
"
replied
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
with
solemn
patience
,
"
I
have
not
expressed
myself
with
clearness
,
Lucretia
,
the
fault
of
course
is
mine
.
<EOS>
There
is
,
perhaps
,
no
reason
why
I
should
express
myself
at
all
,
except
the
intimacy
that
has
subsisted
between
us
,
and
which
I
very
much
hope
,
Lucretia
---
<EOS>
confidently
hope
---
nothing
will
occur
to
disturb
.
<EOS>
Because
,
why
should
I
do
anything
else
?
<EOS>
There
is
no
reason
;
it
would
be
absurd
.
<EOS>
But
I
wish
to
express
myself
clearly
,
Lucretia
;
and
therefore
to
go
back
to
that
remark
,
I
must
beg
to
say
that
it
was
not
intended
to
relate
to
Florence
,
in
any
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Indeed
!
"
returned
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
shortly
and
decisively
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
my
dear
,
"
rejoined
her
meek
friend
;
"
but
I
can
not
have
understood
it
.
<EOS>
I
fear
I
am
dull
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
looked
round
the
room
and
over
the
way
;
at
the
plants
,
at
the
bird
,
at
the
watering
-
pot
,
at
almost
everything
within
view
,
except
Miss
Tox
;
and
finally
dropping
her

upon
Miss
Tox
,
for
a
moment
,
on
its
way
to
the
ground
,
said
,
looking
meanwhile
with
elevated
eyebrows
at
the
carpet
:
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
speak
,
Lucretia
,
of
her
being
worthy
of
the
name
,
I
speak
of
my
brother
Paul
's
second
wife
.
<EOS>
I
believe
I
have
already
said
,
in
effect
,
if
not
in
the
very
words
I
now
use
,
that
it
is
his
intention
to
marry
a
second
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
left
her
seat
in
a
hurry
,
and
returned
to
her
plants
;
clipping
among
the
stems
and
leaves
,
with
as
little
favour
as
a
barber
working
at
so
many
pauper
heads
of
hair
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whether
she
will
be
fully
sensible
of
the
distinction
conferred
upon
her
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
in
a
lofty
tone
,
"
is
quite
another
question
.
<EOS>
I
hope
she
may
be
.
<EOS>
We
are
bound
to
think
well
of
one
another
in
this
world
,
and
I
hope
she
may
be
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
advised
with
myself
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
been
advised
with
,
I
have
no
doubt
my
advice
would
have
been
cavalierly
received
,
and
therefore
it
is
infinitely
better
as
it
is
.
<EOS>
I
much
prefer
it
as
it
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
,
with
head
bent
down
,
still
clipped
among
the
plants
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
,
with
energetic
shakings
of
her
own
head
from
time
to
time
,
continued
to
hold
forth
,
as
if
in
defiance
of
somebody
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
my
brother
Paul
had
consulted
with
me
,
which
he
sometimes
does
---
or
rather
,
sometimes
used
to
do
;
for
he
will
naturally
do
that
no
more
now
,
and
this
is
a
circumstance
which
I
regard
as
a
relief
from
responsibility
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
hysterically
,
"
for
I
thank
Heaven
<EOS>
I
am
not
jealous
---
"

and
as
a
connexion
by
marriage
of
my
brother
's
wife
's
mother
---
may
I
be
permitted
to
add
,
as
a
Dombey
?
<EOS>
---
I
can
wish
you
nothing
else
but
good
morning
.
"
  
<EOS>
These
words
,
delivered
with
cutting
suavity
,
tempered
and
chastened
by
a
lofty
air
of
moral
rectitude
,
carried
the
speaker
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
There
she
inclined
her
head
in
a
ghostly
and
statue
-
like
manner
,
and
so
withdrew
to
her
carriage
,
to
seek
comfort
and
consolation
in
the
arms
of
Mr
Chick
her
lord
.
  
<EOS>
Figuratively
speaking
,
that
is
to
say
:
for
the
arms
of
Mr
Chick
were
full
of
his
newspaper
.
<EOS>
Neither
did
that
gentleman
address
his
eyes
towards
his
wife
otherwise
than
by
stealth
.
<EOS>
Neither
did
he
offer
any
consolation
whatever
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
he
sat
reading
,
and
humming
fag
ends
of
tunes
,
and
sometimes
glancing
furtively
at
her
without
delivering
himself
of
a
word
,
good
,
bad
,
or
indifferent
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Mrs
Chick
sat
swelling
and
bridling
,
and
tossing
her
head
,
as
if
she
were
still
repeating
that
solemn
formula
of
farewell
to
Lucretia
Tox
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
she
said
aloud
,
"
Oh
the
extent
to
which
her
eyes
had
been
opened
that
day
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
which
your
eyes
have
been
opened
,
,
my
dear
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mr
Chick
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
n't
talk
to
me
!
"
said
Mrs
Chick
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
can
bear
to
see
me
in
this
state
,
and
not
ask
me
what
the
matter
is
,
you
had
better
hold
your
tongue
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
,
my
dear
?
"
asked
Mr
Chick
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
think
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
in
a
state
of
soliloquy
,
"
that
she
should
ever
have
conceived
the
base
idea
of
connecting
herself
with
our
family
by
a
marriage
with
Paul
!
<EOS>
To
think
that
when
she
was
playing
at
horses
with
that
dear
child
who
is
now
in
his
grave
---
I
never
liked
it
at
the
time
---
she
should
have
been
hiding
such
a
double
-
faced
design
!
<EOS>
I
wonder
she
was
never
afraid
that
something
would
happen
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
is
fortunate
if
nothing
does
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
thought
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Chick
slowly
,
after
rubbing
the
bridge
of
his
nose
for
some
time
with
his
newspaper
,
"
that
you
had
gone
on
the
same
tack
yourself
,
all
along
,
until
this
morning
;
and
had
thought
it
would
be
a
convenient
thing
enough
,
if
it
could
have
been
brought
about
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
instantly
burst
into
tears
,
and
told
Mr
Chick
that
if
he
wished
to
trample
upon
her
with
his
boots
,
he
had
better
do
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
with
Lucretia
Tox
I
have
done
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
after
abandoning
herself
to
her
feelings
for
some
minutes
,
to
Mr
Chick
's
great
terror
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
bear
to
resign
Paul
's
confidence
in
favour
of
one
<EOS>
who
,
I
hope
and
trust
,
may
be
deserving
of
it
,
and
with
whom
he
has
a
perfect
right
to
replace
poor
Fanny
if
he
chooses
;
I
can
bear
to
be
informed
,
in
Paul
's
cool
manner
,
of
such
a
change
in
his
plans
,
and
never
to
be
consulted
until
all
is
settled
and
determined
;
but
deceit
I
can
not
bear
,
and
with
Lucretia
Tox
I
have
done
.
<EOS>
It
is
better
as
it
is
,
"
said
Mrs
Chick
,
piously
;
"
much
better
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
a
long
time
before
I
could
have
accommodated
myself
comfortably
with
her
,
after
this
;
and
I
really
do
n't
know
,
as
Paul
is
going
to
be
very
grand
,
and
these
are
people
of
condition
,
that
she
would
have
been
quite
presentable
,
and
might
not
have
compromised
myself
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
providence
in
everything
;
everything
works
for
the
best
;
I
have
been
triedto
-
day
,
but
,
upon
the
whole
I
do
n't
regret
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
which
Christian
spirit
,
Mrs
Chick
dried
her
eyes
,
and
smoothed
her
lap
,
and
sat
as
became
a
person
calm
under
a
great
wrong
.
<EOS>
Mr
Chick
,
feeling
his
unworthiness
no
doubt
,
took
an
early
opportunity
of
being
set
down
at
a
street
corner
and
walking
away
,
whistling
,
with
his
shoulders
very
much
raised
,
and
his
hands
in
his
pockets
.
  
<EOS>
While
poor
excommunicated
Miss
Tox
,
who
,
if
she
were
a
fawner
and
toad
-
eater
,
was
at
least
an
honest
and
a
constant
one
,
and
had
ever
borne
a
faithful
friendship
towards
her
impeacher
,
and
had
been
truly
absorbed
and
swallowed
up
in
devotion
to
the
magnificence
of
Mr
Dombey
---
while
poor
excommunicated
Miss
Tox
watered
her
plants
with
her
tears
,
and
felt
that
it
was
winter
in
Princess
's
Place
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
30
.
<EOS>
The
Interval
before
the
Marriage
 
<EOS>
ALTHOUGH
<EOS>
the
enchanted
house
was
not
more
,
and
the
working
world
had
broken
into
it
,
and
was
hammering
and
crashing
and
tramping
up
and
down
stairs
all
day
long
,
keeping
Diogenes
in
an
incessant
paroxysm
of
barking
,
from
sunrise
to
sunset
---
evidently
convinced
that
his
enemy
had
got
the
better
of
him
at
last
,
and
was
then
sacking
the
premises
in
triumphant
defiance
<EOS>
---
there
was
,
at
first
,
no
other
great
change
in
the
method
of
Florence
's
life
.
<EOS>
At
night
,
when
the
work
-
people
went
away
,
the
house
was
dreary
and
deserted
again
;
and
Florence
,
listening
to
their
voices
echoing
through
the
hall
and
staircase
as
they
departed
,
pictured
to
herself
the
cheerful
homes
to
which
they
were
returning
,
and
the
children
who
were
waiting
for
them
,
and
was
glad
to
think
that
they
were
merry
and
well
pleased
to
go
.
  
<EOS>
She
welcomed
back
the
evening
silence
as
on
old
friend
,
but
it
came
now
with
an
altered
face
,
and
looked
more
kindly
on
her
.
<EOS>
Fresh
hope
was
in
it
.
<EOS>
The
beautiful
lady
who
had
soothed
and
caressed
her
,
in
the
very
room
in
which
her
heart
had
been
so
wrung
,
was
a
spirit
of
promise
to
her
.
<EOS>
Soft
shadows
of
the
bright
life
dawning
,
when
her
father
's
affection
should
be
gradually
won
,
and
all
,
or
much
should
be
restored
,
of
what
she
had
lost
on
the
dark
day
when
a
mother
's
love
had
faded
with
a
mother
's
last
breath
on
her
cheek
,
moved
about
her
in
the
twilight
and
were
welcome
company
.
<EOS>
Peeping
at
the
rosy
children
her
neighbours
,
it
was
a
new
and
precious
sensation
to
think
that
they
might
soon
speak
together
and
know
each
other
;
when
she
would
not
fear
,
as
of
old
,
to
show
herself
before
them
,
lest
they
should
be
grieved
to
see
her
in
her
black
dress
sitting
there
alone
!
  
<EOS>
In
her
thoughts
of
her
new
mother
,
and
in
the
love
and
trust
overflowing
her
pure
heart
towards
her
,
Florence
loved
her
own
dead
mother
more
and
more
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
fear
of
setting
up
a
rival
in
her
breast
.
<EOS>
The
new
flower
sprang
from
the
deep
-
planted
and
long
-
cherished
root
,
she
knew
.
<EOS>
Every
gentle
word
that
had
fallen
from
the
lips
of
the
beautiful
lady
,
sounded
to
Florence
like
an
echo
of
the
voice
long
hushed
and
silent
.
<EOS>
How
could
she
love
that
memory
less
for
living
tenderness
,
when
it
was
her
memory
of
all
parental
tenderness
and
love
!
  
<EOS>
Florence
was
,
one
day
,
sitting
reading
in
her
room
,
and
thinking
of
the
lady
and
her
promised
visit
soon
---
for
her
book
turned
on
a
kindred
subject
---
<EOS>
when
,
raising
her
eyes
,
she
saw
her
standing
in
the
doorway
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mama
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Florence
,
joyfully
meeting
her
.
<EOS>
"
Come
again
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
Mama
yet
,
"
returned
the
lady
,
with
a
serious
smile
,
as
she
encircled
Florence
's
neck
with
her
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
very
soon
to
be
,
"
cried
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
soon
now
,
Florence
:
very
soon
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
bent
her
head
a
little
,
so
as
to
press
the
blooming
cheek
of
Florence
against
her
own
,
and
for
some
few
moments
remained
thus
silent
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
so
very
tender
in
her
manner
,
that
Florence
was
even
more
sensible
of
it
than
on
the
first
occasion
of
their
meeting
.
  
<EOS>
She
led
Florence
to
a
chair
beside
her
,
and
sat
down
:
Florence
looking
in
her
face
,
quite
wondering
at
its
beauty
,
and
willingly
leaving
her
hand
in
hers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
been
alone
,
Florence
,
since
I
was
here
last
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
!
"
smiled
Florence
,
hastily
.
  
<EOS>
She
hesitated
and
cast
down
her
eyes
;
for
her
new
Mama
was
very
earnest
in
her
look
,
and
the
look
was
intently
and
thoughtfully
fixed
upon
her
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
---
am
used
to
be
alone
,
"
said
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mind
it
at
all
.
<EOS>
Di
and
I
pass
whole
days
together
,
sometimes
.
<EOS>
"
Florence
might
have
said
,
whole
weeks
and
months
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Di
your
maid
,
love
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dog
,
Mama
,
"
said
Florence
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
Susan
is
my
maid
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
these
are
your
rooms
,
"
said
Edith
,
looking
round
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
shown
these
rooms
the
other
day
.
<EOS>
We
must
have
them
improved
,
Florence
.
<EOS>
They
shall
be
made
the
prettiest
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
might
change
them
,
Mama
,
"
returned
Florence
;
"
there
is
one
up
stairs
<EOS>
I
should
like
much
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
this
not
high
enough
,
dear
girl
?
"
asked
Edith
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
other
was
my
brother
's
room
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
and
I
am
very
fond
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
would
have
spoken
to
Papa
about
it
when
I
came
home
,
and
found
the
workmen
here
,
and
everything
changing
:
<EOS>
but
---
"
  
Florence
dropped
her
eyes
,
lest
the
same
look
should
make
her
falter
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
---
but
I
was
afraid
it
might
distress
him
;
and
as
you
said
you
would
be
here
again
soon
,
Mama
,
and
are
the
mistress
of
everything
,
I
determined
to
take
courage
and
ask
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
sat
looking
at
her
,
with
her
brilliant
eyes
intent
upon
her
face
,
until
Florence
raising
her
own
,
she
,
in
her
turn
,
withdrew
her
gaze
,
and
turned
it
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
It
was
then
that
Florence
thought
how
different
this
lady
's
beauty
was
,
from
what
she
had
supposed
.
<EOS>
She
had
thought
it
of
a
proud
and
lofty
kind
;
yet
her
manner
was
so
subdued
and
gentle
,
that
if
she
had
been
of
Florence
's
own
age
and
character
,
it
scarcely
could
have
invited
confidence
more
.
  
<EOS>
Except
when
a
constrained
and
singular
reserve
crept
over
her
;
and
then
she
seemed
(
but
Florence
hardly
understood
this
,
though
she
could
not
choose
but
notice
it
,
and
think
about
it
)
as
if
she
were
humbled
before
Florence
,
and
ill
at
ease
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
said
that
she
was
not
her
Mama
yet
,
and
when
Florence
had
called
her
the
mistress
of
everything
there
,
this
change
in
her
was
quick
and
startling
;
and
now
,
while
the
eyes
of
Florence
rested
on
her
face
,
she
sat
as
though
she
would
have
shrunk
and
hidden
from
her
,
rather
than
as
one
about
to
love
and
cherish
her
,
in
right
of
such
a
near
connexion
.
  
<EOS>
She
gave
Florence
her
ready
promise
,
about
her
new
room
,
and
said
she
would
give
directions
about
it
herself
.
<EOS>
She
then
asked
some
questions
concerning
poor
Paul
;
and
when
they
had
sat
in
conversation
for
some
time
,
told
Florence
she
had
come
to
take
her
to
her
own
home
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
come
to
London
now
,
my
mother
and
I
,
"
said
Edith
,
"
and
you
shall
stay
with
us
until
I
am
married
.
<EOS>
I
wish
that
we
should
know
and
trust
each
other
,
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
kind
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
said
Florence
,
"
dear
Mama
.
<EOS>
How
much
I
thank
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
say
now
,
for
it
may
be
the
best
opportunity
,
"
continued
Edith
,
looking
round
to
see
that
they
were
quite
alone
,
and
speaking
in
a
lower
voice
,
"
that
when
I
am
married
,
and
have
gone
away
for
some
weeks
,
I
shall
be
easier
at
heart
if
you
will
come
home
here
.
<EOS>
No
matter
who
invites
you
to
stay
elsewhere
,
come
home
here
.
<EOS>
It
is
better
to
be
alone
then
---
what
I
would
say
is
,
"
she
added
,
checking
herself
,
"
<EOS>
that
I
know
well
you
are
best
at
home
,
dear
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
come
home
on
the
very
day
,
Mama
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
so
.
<EOS>
I
rely
on
that
promise
.
<EOS>
Now
,
prepare
to
come
with
me
,
dear
girl
.
<EOS>
You
will
find
me
down
stairs
when
you
are
ready
.
"
   
<EOS>
Slowly
and
<EOS>
thoughtfully
did
Edith
wander
alone
through
the
mansion
of
which
she
was
so
soon
to
be
the
lady
:
and
little
heed
took
she
of
all
the
elegance
and
splendour
<EOS>
it
began
to
display
.
<EOS>
The
same
indomitable
haughtiness
of
soul
,
the
same
proud
scorn
expressed
in
eye
and
lip
,
the
same
fierce
beauty
,
only
tamed
by
a
sense
of
its
own
little
worth
,
and
of
the
little
worth
of
everything
around
it
,
went
through
the
grand
saloons
and
halls
,
that
had
got
loose
among
the
shady
trees
,
and
raged
and
rent
themselves
.
<EOS>
The
mimic
roses
on
the
walls
and
floors
were
set
round
with
sharp
thorns
,
that
tore
her
breast
;
in
every
scrap
of
gold
so
dazzling
to
the
eye
,
she
saw
some
hateful
atom
of
her
purchase
-
money
;
the
broad
high
mirrors
showed
her
,
at
full
length
,
a
women
with
a
noble
quality
yet
dwelling
in
her
nature
,
who
was
too
false
to
her
better
self
,
and
too
debased
and
lost
,
to
save
herself
.
<EOS>
She
believed
that
all
this
was
so
plain
,
more
or
less
,
to
all
eyes
,
that
she
had
no
resource
or
power
of
self
-
assertion
but
in
pride
:
and
with
this
pride
,
which
tortured
her
own
heart
night
and
day
,
she
fought
her
fate
out
,
braved
it
,
and
defied
it
.
  
<EOS>
Was
this
the
woman
whom
Florence
---
an
innocent
girl
,
strong
only
in
her
earnestness
and
simple
truth
---
could
so
impress
and
quell
,
that
by
her
side
she
was
another
creature
,
with
her
tempest
of
passion
hushed
,
and
<EOS>
her
very
pride
itself
subdued
?
<EOS>
Was
this
the
woman
who
now
sat
beside
her
in
a
carriage
,
with
her
arms
entwined
,
and
who
,
while
she
courted
and
entreated
her
to
love
and
trust
her
,
drew
her
fair
head
to
nestle
on
her
breast
,
and
would
have
laid
down
life
to
shield
it
from
wrong
or
harm
?
  
<EOS>
Oh
,
Edith
!
<EOS>
it
were
well
to
die
,
indeed
,
at
such
a
time!Better
and
happier
far
,
perhaps
,
to
die
so
,
Edith
,
than
to
live
on
to
the
end
!
  
<EOS>
The
Honourable
Mrs
Skewton
,
who
was
thinking
of
anything
rather
than
of
such
sentiments
---
for
,
like
many
genteel
persons
who
have
existed
at
various
times
,
she
set
her
face
against
death
altogether
,
and
objected
to
the
mention
of
any
such
low
and
levelling
upstart
---
had
borrowed
a
house
in
Brook
Street
,
Grosvenor
Square
,
from
a
stately
relative
(
one
of
the
Feenix
brood
)
,
who
was
out
of
town
,
and
who
did
not
object
to
lending
it
,
in
the
handsomest
manner
,
for
nuptial
purposes
,
as
the
loan
implied
his
final
release
and
acquittance
from
all
further
loans
and
gifts
to
Mrs
Skewton
and
her
daughter
.
<EOS>
It
being
necessary
for
the
credit
of
the
family
to
make
a
handsome
appearance
at
such
a
time
,
Mrs
Skewton
,
with
the
assistance
of
an
accommodating
tradesman
resident
in
the
parish
of
Mary
-
le
-
bone
,
who
lent
out
all
sorts
of
articles
to
the
nobility
and
gentry
,
from
a
service
of
plate
to
an
army
of
foot
-
men
,
clapped
into
this
house
a
silver
-
headed
butler
(
who
was
charged
extra
on
that
account
,
as
having
the
appearance
of
an
ancient
family
retainer
)
,
two
very
tall
young
men
in
livery
,
and
a
select
staff
of
kitchen
-
servants
;
so
that
a
legend
arose
,
downstairs
,
that
Withers
the
page
,
released
at
once
from
his
numerous
household
duties
,
and
from
the
propulsion
of
the
wheeled
-
chair
(
inconsistent
with
the
metropolis
)
,
<EOS>
had
been
several
times
observed
to
rub
his
eyes
and
pinch
his
limbs
,
as
if
he
misdoubted
his
having
overslept
himself
at
the
Leamington
milkman
's
,
and
being
still
in
a
celestial
dream
.
<EOS>
A
variety
of
requisites
in
plate
and
china
being
also
conveyed
to
the
same
establishment
from
the
same
convenient
source
,
with
several
miscellaneous
articles
,
including
a
neat
chariot
and
a
pair
of
bays
,
Mrs
Skewton
cushioned
herself
on
the
principal
sofa
,
in
the
Cleopatra
attitude
,
and
held
her
court
in
fair
state
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
,
"
said
Mr
Skewton
,
on
the
entrance
of
her
daughter
and
her
charge
,
"
is
my
charming
Florence
?
<EOS>
You
must
come
and
kiss
me
,
Florence
,
if
you
please
,
my
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
Florence
was
timidly
stooping
to
pick
out
a
place
in
the
white
part
of
Mrs
Skewton
's
face
,
when
that
lady
presented
her
ear
,
and
relieved
her
of
her
difficulty
.
  
<EOS>
"
Edith
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
positively
,
I
---
stand
a
little
more
in
the
light
,
my
sweetest
Florence
,
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
blushingly
complied
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
remember
,
dearest
Edith
,
"
said
her
mother
,
"
what
you
were
when
you
were
about
the
same
age
as
our
exceedingly
precious
Florence
,
or
a
few
years
younger
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
long
forgotten
,
mother
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
For
positively
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
I
do
think
that
I
see
a
decided
resemblance
to
what
you
were
then
,
in
our
extremely
fascinating
young
friend
.
<EOS>
And
it
shows
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
in
a
lower
voice
,
which
conveyed
her
opinion
that
Florence
was
in
a
very
unfinished
state
,
"
what
cultivation
will
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
does
,
indeed
,
"
was
Edith
's
stern
reply
.
  
<EOS>
Her
mother
eyed
her
sharply
for
a
moment
,
and
feeling
herself
on
unsafe
ground
,
said
,
as
a
diversion
:
  
<EOS>
"
My
charming
Florence
,
you
must
come
and
kiss
me
once
more
,
if
you
please
,
my
love
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
complied
,
of
course
,
and
again
imprinted
her
lips
or
Mrs
Skewton
's
ear
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
have
heard
,
<EOS>
no
doubt
,
my
darling
pet
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
detaining
her
hand
,
"
that
your
Papa
,
whom
we
all
perfectly
adore
and
dote
upon
,
is
to
be
married
to
my
dearest
Edith
this
day
week
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
would
be
very
soon
,
"
returned
Florence
,
"
but
not
exactly
when
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
darling
Edith
,
"
urged
her
mother
,
gaily
,
"
is
it
possible
you
have
not
told
Florence
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
tell
Florence
?
"
<EOS>
She
returned
,
so
suddenly
and
harshly
,
that
Florence
could
scarcely
believe
it
was
the
same
voice
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
then
told
Florence
,
as
another
and
safer
diversion
,
that
her
father
was
coming
to
dinner
,
and
that
he
would
no
doubt
be
charmingly
surprised
to
see
her
;
as
he
had
spoken
last
night
of
dressing
in
the
City
,
and
had
known
nothing
of
Edith
's
design
,
the
execution
of
which
,
according
to
Mrs
Skewton
's
expectation
,
would
throw
him
into
a
perfect
ecstasy
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
troubled
to
hear
this
;
and
her
distress
became
so
keen
,
as
the
dinner
-
hour
approached
,
that
if
she
had
known
how
to
frame
an
entreaty
to
be
suffered
to
return
home
,
without
involving
her
father
in
her
explanation
,
she
would
have
hurried
back
on
foot
,
bareheaded
,
breathless
,
and
alone
,
rather
than
incur
the
risk
of
meeting
his
displeasure
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
time
drew
nearer
,
she
could
hardly
breathe
.
<EOS>
She
dared
not
approach
a
window
,
lest
he
should
see
her
from
the
street
.
<EOS>
She
dared
not
go
up
stairs
to
hide
her
emotion
,
lest
,
in
passing
out
at
the
door
,
she
should
meet
him
unexpectedly
;
besides
which
dread
,
she
left
as
though
she
never
could
come
back
again
if
she
were
summoned
to
his
presence
.
<EOS>
In
this
conflict
of
fears
,
she
was
sitting
by
Cleopatra
's
couch
,
endeavouring
to
understand
and
to
reply
to
the
bald
discourse
of
that
lady
,
when
she
heard
his
foot
upon
the
stair
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hear
him
now
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Florence
,
starting
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
coming
!
"
  
<EOS>
Cleopatra
,
who
in
her
juvenility
was
always
playfully
disposed
,
and
who
in
her
self
-
engrossment
did
not
trouble
herself
about
the
nature
of
this
agitation
,
pushed
Florence
behind
her
couch
,
and
dropped
a
shawl
over
her
,
preparatory
to
giving
Mr
Dombey
a
rapture
of
surprise
.
<EOS>
It
was
so
quickly
done
,
that
in
a
moment
Florence
heard
his
awful
step
in
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
He
saluted
his
intended
mother
-
in
-
law
,
and
his
intended
bride
.
<EOS>
The
strange
sound
of
his
voice
thrilled
through
the
whole
frame
of
his
child
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Dombey
,
"
said
Cleopatra
,
"
come
here
and
tell
me
how
your
pretty
Florence
is
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
is
very
well
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
advancing
towards
the
couch
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
home
?
"
  
"
At
home
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Dombey
,
"
returned
Cleopatra
,
with
bewitching
vivacity
;
"
now
are
you
sure
you
are
not
deceiving
me
?
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
my
dearest
Edith
will
say
to
me
when
I
make
such
a
declaration
,
but
upon
my
honour
I
am
afraid
you
are
the
falsest
of
men
,
my
dear
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Though
he
had
been
;
and
had
been
detected
on
the
spot
,
in
the
most
enormous
falsehood
that
was
ever
said
or
done
;
he
could
hardly
have
been
more
disconcerted
than
he
was
,
when
Mrs
Skewton
plucked
the
shawl
away
,
and
Florence
,
pale
and
trembling
,
rose
before
him
like
a
ghost
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
yet
recovered
his
presence
of
mind
,
when
Florence
had
run
up
to
him
,
clasped
her
hands
round
his
neck
,
kissed
his
face
,
and
hurried
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
looked
round
as
if
to
refer
the
matter
to
somebody
else
,
but
Edith
had
gone
after
Florence
,
instantly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
confess
,
my
dear
Dombey
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
giving
him
her
hand
,
"
that
you
never
were
more
surprised
and
pleased
in
your
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
was
more
surprised
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
pleased
,
my
dearest
Dombey
?
"
returned
Mrs
Skewton
,
holding
up
her
fan
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
---
yes
,
I
am
exceedingly
glad
to
meet
Florence
here
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
consider
gravely
about
it
for
a
moment
,
and
then
said
,
more
decidedly
,
"
Yes
,
I
really
am
very
glad
indeed
to
meet
Florence
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
wonder
how
she
comes
here
?
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
do
n't
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Edith
,
perhaps
---
"
suggested
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
wicked
guesser
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Cleopatra
,
shaking
her
head
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
cunning
,
cunning
man
!
<EOS>
One
should
n't
tell
these
things
;
your
sex
,
my
dear
Dombey
,
are
so
vain
,
and
so
apt
to
abuse
our
weaknesses
;
but
you
know
my
open
soul
---
very
well
;
immediately
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
addressed
to
one
of
the
very
tall
young
men
who
announced
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
Edith
,
my
dear
Dombey
,
"
she
continued
in
a
whisper
,
"
when
she
can
not
have
you
near
her
---
and
as
I
tell
her
,
she
can
not
expect
that
always
---
will
at
least
have
near
her
something
or
somebody
belonging
to
you
.
<EOS>
Well
,
how
extremely
natural
that
is
!
<EOS>
And
in
this
spirit
,
nothing
would
keep
her
from
riding
off
to
-
day
to
fetch
our
darling
Florence
.
<EOS>
Well
,
how
excessively
charming
that
is
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
waited
for
an
answer
,
Mr
Dombey
answered
,
"
Eminently
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
,
my
dear
Dombey
,
for
that
proof
of
heart
!
"
cried
Cleopatra
,
squeezing
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
growing
too
serious!Take
me
down
stairs
,
like
an
angel
,
and
let
us
see
what
these
people
intend
to
give
us
for
dinner
.
<EOS>
Bless
you
,
dear
Dombey
!
"
  
<EOS>
Cleopatra
skipping
off
her
couch
with
tolerable
briskness
,
after
the
last
benediction
,
Mr
Dombey
took
her
arm
in
his
and
led
her
ceremoniously
down
stairs
;
one
of
the
very
tall
young
men
on
hire
,
whose
organ
of
veneration
was
imperfectly
developed
,
thrusting
his
tongue
into
his
cheek
,
for
the
entertainment
of
the
other
very
tall
young
man
on
hire
,
as
the
couple
turned
into
the
dining
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
and
Edith
were
already
there
,
and
sitting
side
by
side
.
<EOS>
Florence
would
have
risen
when
her
father
entered
,
to
resign
her
chair
to
him
;
but
Edith
openly
put
her
hand
upon
her
arm
,
and
Mr
Dombey
took
an
opposite
place
at
the
round
table
.
  
<EOS>
The
conversation
was
almost
entirely
sustained
by
Mrs
Skewton
.
<EOS>
Florence
hardly
dared
to
raise
her
eyes
,
lest
they
should
reveal
the
traces
of
tears
;
far
less
dared
to
speak
;
and
Edith
never
uttered
one
word
,
unless
in
answer
to
a
question
.
<EOS>
Verily
,
Cleopatra
worked
hard
,
for
the
establishment
that
was
so
nearly
clutched
;
and
verily
it
should
have
been
a
rich
one
to
reward
her
!
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
your
preparations
are
nearly
finished
at
last
,
my
dear
Dombey
?
<EOS>
"
said
Cleopatra
,
when
the
dessert
was
put
upon
the
table
,
and
the
silver
-
headed
butler
had
withdrawn
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Even
the
lawyers
'
preparations
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
madam
,
"
replied
Mr
Dombey
;
"
the
deed
of
settlement
,
the
professional
gentlemen
inform
me
,
is
now
ready
,
and
as
I
was
mentioning
to
you
,
<EOS>
Edith
has
only
to
do
us
the
favour
to
suggest
her
own
time
for
its
execution
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
sat
like
a
handsome
statue
;
as
cold
,
as
silent
,
and
as
still
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
love
,
"
said
Cleopatra
,
"
do
you
hear
what
Mr
Dombey
says
?
<EOS>
Ah
,
my
dear
Dombey
!
"
<EOS>
aside
to
that
gentleman
,
"
how
her
absence
,
as
the
time
approaches
,
reminds
me
of
the
days
,
when
that
most
agreeable
of
creatures
,
her
papa
,
was
in
your
situation
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
to
suggest
.
<EOS>
It
shall
be
when
you
please
,
"
said
Edith
,
scarcely
looking
over
the
table
at
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
?
"
suggested
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Or
would
next
day
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
suit
your
engagements
better
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
engagements
.
<EOS>
I
am
always
at
your
disposal
.
<EOS>
Let
it
be
when
you
like
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
engagements
,
my
dear
Edith
!
"
remonstrated
her
mother
,
"
when
you
are
in
a
most
terrible
state
of
flurry
all
day
long
,
and
have
a
thousand
and
one
appointments
with
all
sorts
of
tradespeople
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
of
your
making
,
"
returned
Edith
,
turning
on
her
with
a
slight
contraction
of
her
brow
.
<EOS>
"
You
and
Mr
Dombey
can
arrange
between
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
true
indeed
,
my
love
,
and
most
considerate
of
you
!
"
said
Cleopatra
.
<EOS>
"
My
darling
Florence
,
you
must
really
come
and
kiss
me
once
more
,
if
you
please
,
my
dear
!
"
  
<EOS>
Singular
coincidence
,
that
these
gushes
of
interest
in
Florence
hurried
Cleopatra
away
from
almost
every
dialogue
in
which
Edith
had
a
share
,
however
trifling
!
<EOS>
Florence
had
certainly
never
undergone
so
much
embracing
,
and
perhaps
had
never
been
,
unconsciously
,
so
useful
in
her
life
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
was
far
from
quarrelling
,
in
his
own
breast
,
with
the
manner
of
his
beautiful
betrothed
.
<EOS>
He
had
that
good
reason
for
sympathy
with
haughtiness
and
coldness
,
which
is
found
in
a
fellow
-
feeling
.
<EOS>
It
flattered
him
to
think
how
these
deferred
to
him
,
in
Edith
's
case
,
and
seemed
to
have
no
will
apart
from
his
.
<EOS>
It
flattered
him
to
picture
to
himself
,
this
proud
and
stately
woman
doing
the
honours
of
his
house
,
and
chilling
his
guests
after
his
own
manner
.
<EOS>
The
dignity
of
Dombey
and
Son
would
be
heightened
and
maintained
,
indeed
,
in
such
hands
.
  
<EOS>
So
thought
Mr
Dombey
,
when
he
was
left
alone
at
the
dining
-
table
,
and
mused
upon
his
past
and
future
fortunes
:
finding
no
uncongeniality
in
an
air
of
scant
and
gloomy
state
that
pervaded
the
room
,
in
colour
a
dark
brown
,
with
black
hatchments
of
pictures
blotching
the
walls
,
and
twenty
-
four
black
chairs
,
with
almost
as
many
nails
in
them
as
so
many
coffins
,
waiting
like
mutes
,
upon
the
threshold
of
the
Turkey
carpet
;
and
two
exhausted
negroes
holding
up
two
withered
branches
of
candelabra
on
the
sideboard
,
and
a
musty
smell
prevailing
as
if
the
ashes
of
ten
thousand
dinners
were
entombed
in
the
sarcophagus
below
it
.
<EOS>
The
owner
of
the
house
lived
much
abroad
;
the
air
of
England
seldom
agreed
long
with
a
member
of
the
Feenix
family
;
and
the
room
had
gradually
put
itself
into
deeper
and
still
deeper
mourning
for
him
,
until
it
was
become
so
funereal
as
to
want
nothing
but
a
body
in
it
to
be
quite
complete
.
  
<EOS>
No
bad
representation
of
the
body
,
for
the
nonce
,
in
his
unbending
form
,
if
not
in
his
attitude
,
Mr
Dombey
looked
down
into
the
cold
depths
of
the
dead
sea
of
mahogany
on
which
the
fruit
dishes
and
decanters
lay
at
anchor
:
as
if
the
subjects
of
his
thoughts
were
rising
towards
the
surface
one
by
one
,
and
plunging
down
again
.
<EOS>
Edith
was
there
in
all
her
majesty
of
brow
and
figure
;
and
close
to
her
came
Florence
,
with
her
timid
head
turned
to
him
,
as
it
had
been
,
for
an
instant
,
when
she
left
the
room
;
and
Edith
's
eyes
upon
her
,
and
Edith
's
hand
put
out
protectingly
.
<EOS>
A
little
figure
in
a
low
arm
-
chair
came
springing
next
into
the
light
,
and
looked
upon
him
wonderingly
,
with
its
bright
eyes
and
its
old
-
young
face
,
gleaming
as
in
the
flickering
of
an
evening
fire
.
<EOS>
Again
came
Florence
close
upon
it
,
and
absorbed
his
whole
attention
.
<EOS>
Whether
as
a
fore
-
doomed
difficulty
and
disappointment
to
him
;
whether
as
a
rival
who
had
crossed
him
in
his
way
,
and
might
again
;
whether
as
his
child
,
of
whom
,
in
his
successful
wooing
,
he
could
stoop
to
think
,
as
claiming
,
at
such
a
time
,
to
be
no
more
estranged
;
or
whether
as
a
hint
to
him
that
the
mere
appearance
of
caring
for
his
own
blood
should
be
maintained
in
his
new
relations
;
he
best
knew
.
<EOS>
Indifferently
well
,
perhaps
,
at
best
;
for
marriage
company
and
marriage
altars
,
and
ambitious
scenes
---
still
blotted
here
and
there
with
Florence
---
always
Florence
---
turned
up
so
fast
,
and
so
confusedly
,
that
he
rose
,
and
went
up
stairs
,
to
escape
them
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
quite
late
at
night
before
candles
were
brought
;
for
at
present
they
made
Mrs
Skewton
's
head
ache
,
she
complained
;
and
in
the
meantime
Florence
and
Mrs
Skewton
talked
together
(
Cleopatra
being
very
anxious
to
keep
her
close
to
herself
)
,
or
Florence
touched
the
piano
softly
for
Mrs
Skewton
's
delight
;
to
make
no
mention
of
a
few
occasions
in
the
course
of
the
evening
,
when
that
affectionate
lady
was
impelled
to
solicit
another
kiss
,
and
which
always
happened
after
Edith
had
said
anything
.
<EOS>
They
were
not
many
,
however
,
for
Edith
sat
apart
by
an
open
window
during
the
whole
time
(
in
spite
of
her
mother
's
fears
that
she
would
take
cold
)
,
and
remained
there
until
Mr
Dombey
took
leave
.
<EOS>
He
was
serenely
gracious
to
Florence
when
he
did
so
;
and
Florence
went
to
bed
in
a
room
within
Edith
's
,
so
happy
and
hopeful
,
that
she
thought
of
her
late
self
as
if
it
were
some
other
poor
deserted
girl
who
was
to
be
pitied
for
her
sorrow
;
and
in
her
pity
,
sobbed
herself
to
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
The
week
fled
fast
.
<EOS>
There
were
drives
to
milliners
,
dress
-
makers
,
jewellers
,
lawyers
,
florists
,
pastry
-
cooks
;
and
Florence
was
always
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
to
go
to
the
wedding
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
to
cast
off
her
mourning
,
and
to
wear
a
brilliant
dress
on
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
The
milliner
's
intentions
on
the
subject
of
this
dress
<EOS>
---
the
milliner
was
a
Frenchwoman
,
and
greatly
resembled
Mrs
Skewton
---
were
so
chaste
and
elegant
,
that
Mrs
Skewton
bespoke
one
like
it
for
herself
.
<EOS>
The
milliner
said
it
would
become
her
to
admiration
,
and
that
all
the
world
would
take
her
for
the
young
lady
's
sister
.
  
<EOS>
The
week
fled
faster
.
<EOS>
Edith
looked
at
nothing
and
cared
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
Her
rich
dresses
came
home
,
and
were
tried
on
,
and
were
loudly
commended
by
Mrs
Skewton
and
the
milliners
,
and
were
put
away
without
a
word
from
her
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
made
their
plans
for
every
day
,
and
executed
them
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
Edith
sat
in
the
carriage
when
they
went
to
make
purchases
;
sometimes
,
when
it
was
absolutely
necessary
,
she
went
into
the
shops
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Skewton
conducted
the
whole
business
,
whatever
it
happened
to
be
:
and
Edith
looked
on
as
uninterested
and
with
as
much
apparent
indifference
as
if
she
had
no
concern
in
it
.
<EOS>
Florence
might
perhaps
have
thought
she
was
haughty
and
listless
,
but
that
she
was
never
so
to
her
.
<EOS>
So
Florence
quenched
her
wonder
in
her
gratitude
whenever
it
broke
out
,
and
soon
subdued
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
week
fled
faster
.
<EOS>
It
had
nearly
winged
its
flight
away
.
<EOS>
The
last
night
of
the
week
,
the
night
before
the
marriage
was
come
.
<EOS>
In
the
dark
room
---
for
Mrs
Skewton
's
head
was
no
better
yet
,
though
she
expected
to
recover
permanently
to
-
morrow
---
were
that
lady
,
Edith
,
and
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
Edith
was
at
her
open
window
looking
out
into
the
street
;
Mr
Dombey
and
Cleopatra
were
talking
softly
on
the
sofa
.
<EOS>
It
was
growing
late
;
and
Florence
being
fatigued
,
had
gone
to
bed
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Dombey
,
"
said
Cleopatra
,
"
you
will
leave
me
Florence
to
-
morrow
,
when
you
deprive
me
of
my
sweetest
Edith
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
said
he
would
,
with
pleasure
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
have
her
about
me
,
here
,
while
you
are
both
at
Paris
,
and
to
think
that
,
at
her
age
,
I
am
assisting
in
the
formation
of
her
mind
,
my
dear
Dombey
,
"
said
Cleopatra
,
"
will
be
a
perfect
balm
to
me
in
the
extremely
shattered
state
to
which
I
shall
be
reduced
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
turned
her
head
suddenly
.
<EOS>
Her
listless
manner
was
exchanged
,
in
a
moment
,
to
one
of
burning
interest
,
and
,
unseen
in
the
darkness
,
she
attended
closely
to
their
conversation
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
would
be
delighted
to
leave
Florence
in
such
admirable
guardianship
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Dombey
,
"
returned
Cleopatra
,
"
a
thousand
thanks
for
your
good
opinion
.
<EOS>
I
feared
you
were
going
,
with
malice
aforethought
,
as
the
dreadful
lawyers
say
---
those
horrid
proses
!
<EOS>
---
to
condemn
me
to
utter
solitude
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
me
so
great
an
injustice
,
my
dear
madam
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
my
charming
Florence
tells
me
so
positively
she
must
go
home
to
-
morrow
,
"
returned
Cleopatra
,
"
that
I
began
to
be
afraid
,
my
dearest
Dombey
,
you
were
quite
a
Bashaw
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
assure
you
,
madam
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
I
have
laid
no
commands
on
Florence
;
and
if
I
had
,
there
are
no
commands
like
your
wish
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Dombey
,
"
replied
Cleopatra
,
"
what
a
courtier
you
are
!
<EOS>
Though
I
'll
not
say
so
,
either
;
for
courtiers
have
no
heart
,
and
yours
pervades
your
charming
life
and
character
.
<EOS>
And
are
you
really
going
so
early
,
my
dear
Dombey
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
it
was
late
,
and
Mr
Dombey
feared
he
must
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
this
a
fact
,
or
is
it
all
a
dream
!
"
lisped
Cleopatra
.
"
<EOS>
Can
I
believe
,
my
dearest
Dombey
,
that
you
are
coming
back
to
-
morrow
morning
to
deprive
me
of
my
sweet
companion
;
my
own
Edith
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
who
was
accustomed
to
take
things
literally
,
reminded
Mrs
Skewton
that
they
were
to
meet
first
at
the
church
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
pang
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
of
consigning
a
child
,
even
to
you
,
my
dear
Dombey
,
is
one
of
the
most
excruciating
imaginable
;
and
combined
with
a
naturally
delicate
constitution
,
and
the
extreme
stupidity
of
the
pastry
-
cook
who
has
undertaken
the
breakfast
,
is
almost
too
much
for
my
poor
strength
.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
rally
,
my
dear
Dombey
,
in
the
morning
;
do
not
fear
for
me
,
or
be
uneasy
on
my
account
.
<EOS>
Heaven
bless
you
!
<EOS>
My
dearest
Edith
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
archly
.
<EOS>
"
Somebody
is
going
,
pet
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
,
who
had
turned
her
head
again
towards
the
window
,
and
whose
interest
in
their
conversation
had
ceased
,
rose
up
in
her
place
,
but
made
no
advance
towards
him
,
and
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
with
a
lofty
gallantry
adapted
to
his
dignity
and
the
occasion
,
betook
his
creaking
boots
towards
her
,
put
her
hand
to
his
lips
,
said
,
"
To
-
morrow
morning
<EOS>
I
shall
have
the
happiness
of
claiming
this
hand
as
Mrs
Dombey
's
,
"
and
bowed
himself
solemnly
out
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
rang
for
candles
as
soon
as
the
house
-
door
had
closed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
With
the
candles
appeared
her
maid
,
with
the
juvenile
dress
that
was
to
delude
the
world
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
The
dress
had
savage
retribution
in
it
,
as
such
dresses
ever
have
,
and
made
her
infinitely
older
and
more
hideous
than
her
greasy
flannel
gown
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Skewton
tried
it
on
with
mincing
satisfaction
;
smirked
at
her
cadaverous
self
in
the
glass
,
as
she
thought
of
its
killing
effect
upon
the
Major
;
and
suffering
her
maid
to
take
it
off
again
,
and
to
prepare
her
for
repose
,
tumbled
into
ruins
like
a
house
of
painted
cards
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
Edith
remained
at
the
dark
window
looking
out
into
the
street
.
<EOS>
When
she
and
her
mother
were
at
last
left
alone
,
she
moved
from
it
for
the
first
time
that
evening
,
and
came
opposite
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
yawning
,
shaking
,
peevish
figure
of
the
mother
,
with
her
eyes
raised
to
confront
the
proud
erect
form
of
the
daughter
,
whose
glance
of
fire
was
bent
downward
upon
her
,
had
a
conscious
air
upon
it
,
that
no
levity
or
temper
could
conceal
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
tired
to
death
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
be
trusted
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
You
are
worse
than
a
child
.
<EOS>
Child
!
<EOS>
No
child
would
be
half
so
obstinate
and
undutiful
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Listen
to
me
,
mother
,
"
returned
Edith
,
passing
these
words
by
with
a
scorn
that
would
not
descend
to
trifle
with
them
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
remain
alone
here
,
until
I
return
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Must
remain
alone
here
,
Edith
,
until
you
return
!
"
repeated
her
mother
.
  
<EOS>
"
Or
in
that
name
upon
which
I
shall
call
to
-
morrow
to
witness
what
I
do
,
so
falsely
,
and
so
shamefully
,
I
swear
I
will
refuse
the
hand
of
this
man
in
the
church
.
<EOS>
If
I
do
not
,
may
I
fall
dead
upon
the
pavement
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
mother
answered
with
a
look
of
quick
alarm
,
in
no
degree
diminished
by
the
look
she
met
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
enough
,
"
said
Edith
,
steadily
,
"
that
we
are
what
we
are
.
<EOS>
I
will
have
no
youth
and
truth
dragged
down
to
my
level
.
<EOS>
I
will
have
no
guileless
nature
undermined
,
corrupted
,
and
perverted
,
to
amuse
the
leisure
of
a
world
of
mothers
.
<EOS>
You
know
my
meaning
.
<EOS>
Florence
must
go
home
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
an
idiot
,
Edith
,
"
cried
her
angry
mother
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
expect
there
can
ever
be
peace
for
you
in
that
house
,
till
she
is
married
,
and
away
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ask
me
,
or
ask
yourself
,
if
I
ever
expect
peace
in
that
house
,
"
said
her
daughter
,
"
and
you
know
the
answer
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
am
I
to
be
told
to
-
night
,
after
all
my
pains
and
labour
,
and
when
you
are
going
,
through
me
,
to
be
rendered
independent
,
"
her
mother
almost
shrieked
in
her
passion
,
while
her
palsied
head
shook
like
a
leaf
,
"
that
there
is
corruption
and
contagion
in
me
,
and
that
I
am
not
fit
company
for
a
girl!What
<EOS>
are
you
,
pray
?
<EOS>
What
are
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
put
the
question
to
myself
,
"
said
Edith
,
ashy
pale
,
and
pointing
to
the
window
,
"
more
than
once
when
I
have
been
sitting
there
,
and
something
in
the
faded
likeness
of
my
sex
has
wandered
past
outside
;
and
God
knows
I
have
met
with
my
reply
.
<EOS>
Oh
mother
,
mother
,
if
you
had
but
left
me
to
my
natural
heart
when
I
too
was
a
girl
---
a
younger
girl
than
Florence
---
how
different
I
might
have
been
!
"
  
<EOS>
Sensible
that
any
show
of
anger
was
useless
here
,
her
mother
restrained
herself
,
and
fell
a
whimpering
,
and
bewailed
that
she
had
lived
too
long
,
and
that
her
only
child
had
cast
her
off
,
and
that
duty
towards
parents
was
forgotten
in
these
evil
days
,
and
that
she
had
heard
unnatural
taunts
,
and
cared
for
life
no
longer
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
one
is
to
go
on
living
through
continual
scenes
like
this
,
"
she
whined
,
"
I
am
sure
it
would
be
much
better
for
me
to
think
of
some
means
of
putting
an
end
to
my
existence
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
The
idea
of
your
being
my
daughter
,
Edith
,
and
addressing
me
in
such
a
strain
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Between
us
,
mother
,
"
returned
Edith
,
mournfully
,
"
the
time
for
mutual
reproaches
is
past
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
do
you
revive
it
?
<EOS>
"
whimpered
her
mother
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
that
you
are
lacerating
me
in
the
cruellest
manner
.
<EOS>
You
know
how
sensitive
I
am
to
unkindness
.
<EOS>
At
such
a
moment
,
too
,
when
I
have
so
much
to
think
of
,
and
am
naturally
anxious
to
appear
to
the
best
advantage
!
<EOS>
I
wonder
at
you
,
Edith
.
<EOS>
To
make
your
mother
a
fright
upon
your
wedding
-
day
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
bent
the
same
fixed
look
upon
her
,
as
she
sobbed
and
rubbed
her
eyes
;
and
said
in
the
same
low
steady
voice
,
which
had
neither
risen
nor
fallen
since
she
first
addressed
her
,
"
I
have
said
that
Florence
must
go
home
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
her
go
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
afflicted
and
affrighted
parent
,
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
am
willing
she
should
go
.
<EOS>
What
is
the
girl
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
so
much
to
me
,
that
rather
than
communicate
,
or
suffer
to
be
communicated
to
her
,
one
grain
of
the
evil
that
is
in
my
breast
,
mother
,
I
would
renounce
you
,
as
I
would
(
if
you
gave
me
cause
)
<EOS>
renounce
him
in
the
church
to
-
morrow
,
"
replied
Edith
.
"
<EOS>
Leave
her
alone
.
<EOS>
She
shall
not
,
while
I
can
interpose
,
be
tampered
with
and
tainted
by
the
lessons
I
have
learned
.
<EOS>
This
is
no
hard
condition
on
this
bitter
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
proposed
it
in
a
filial
manner
,
Edith
,
"
whined
her
mother
,
"
perhaps
not
;
very
likely
not
.
<EOS>
But
such
extremely
cutting
words
---
"
  
"
They
are
past
and
at
an
end
between
us
now
,
"
said
Edith
.
<EOS>
"
Take
your
own
way
,
mother
;
share
as
you
please
in
what
you
have
gained
;
spend
,
enjoy
,
make
much
of
it
;
and
be
as
happy
as
you
will
.
<EOS>
The
object
of
our
lives
is
won
.
<EOS>
Henceforth
let
us
wear
it
silently
.
<EOS>
My
lips
are
closed
upon
the
past
from
this
hour
.
<EOS>
I
forgive
you
your
part
in
to
-
morrow
's
wickedness
.
<EOS>
May
God
forgive
my
own
!
"
  
<EOS>
Without
a
tremor
in
her
voice
,
or
frame
,
and
passing
onward
with
a
foot
that
set
itself
upon
the
neck
of
every
soft
emotion
,
she
bade
her
mother
good
night
,
and
repaired
to
her
own
room
.
  
<EOS>
But
not
to
rest
;
for
there
was
no
rest
in
the
tumult
of
her
agitation
when
alone
.
<EOS>
To
and
fro
,
and
to
and
fro
,
and
to
and
fro
again
,
five
hundred
times
,
among
the
splendid
preparations
for
her
adornment
on
the
morrow
;
with
her
dark
hair
shaken
down
,
her
dark
eyes
flashing
with
a
raging
light
,
her
broad
white
bosom
red
with
the
cruel
grasp
of
the
relentless
hand
with
which
she
spurned
it
from
her
,
pacing
up
and
down
with
an
averted
head
,
as
if
she
would
avoid
the
sight
of
her
own
fair
person
,
and
divorce
herself
from
its
companionship
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
in
the
dead
time
of
the
night
before
her
bridal
,
Edith
Granger
wrestled
with
her
unquiet
spirit
,
tearless
,
friendless
,
silent
,
proud
,
and
uncomplaining
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
it
happened
that
she
touched
the
open
door
which
led
into
the
room
where
Florence
lay
.
  
<EOS>
She
started
,
stopped
,
and
looked
in
.
  
<EOS>
A
light
was
burning
there
,
and
showed
her
Florence
in
her
bloom
of
innocence
and
beauty
,
fast
asleep
.
<EOS>
Edith
held
her
breath
,
and
felt
herself
drawn
on
towards
her
.
  
<EOS>
Drawn
nearer
,
nearer
,
nearer
yet
;
at
last
,
drawn
so
near
,
that
stooping
down
,
she
pressed
her
lips
to
the
gentle
hand
that
lay
outside
the
bed
,
and
put
it
softly
to
her
neck
.
<EOS>
Its
touch
was
like
the
prophet
's
rod
of
old
upon
the
rock
.
<EOS>
Her
tears
sprung
forth
beneath
it
,
as
she
sunk
upon
her
knees
,
and
laid
her
aching
head
and
streaming
hair
upon
the
pillow
by
its
side
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
Edith
Granger
passed
the
night
before
her
bridal
.
<EOS>
Thus
the
sun
found
her
on
her
bridal
morning
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
31
.
<EOS>
The
Wedding
 
DAWN
,
with
its
passionless
blank
face
,
steals
shivering
to
the
church
beneath
which
lies
the
dust
of
little
Paul
and
his
mother
,
and
looks
in
at
the
windows
.
<EOS>
It
is
cold
and
dark
.
<EOS>
Night
crouches
yet
,
upon
the
pavement
,
and
broods
,
sombre
and
heavy
,
in
nooks
and
corners
of
the
building
.
<EOS>
The
steeple
-
clock
,
perched
up
above
the
houses
,
emerging
from
beneath
another
of
the
countless
ripples
in
the
tide
of
time
that
regularly
roll
and
break
on
the
eternal
shore
,
is
greyly
visible
,
like
a
stone
beacon
,
recording
how
the
sea
flows
on
;
but
within
doors
,
dawn
,
at
first
,
can
only
peep
at
night
,
and
see
that
it
is
there
.
  
<EOS>
Hovering
feebly
round
the
church
,
and
looking
in
,
dawn
moans
and
weeps
for
its
short
reign
,
and
its
tears
trickle
on
the
window
-
glass
,
and
the
trees
against
the
church
-
wall
bow
their
heads
,
and
wring
their
many
hands
in
sympathy
.
<EOS>
Night
,
growing
pale
before
it
,
gradually
fades
out
of
the
church
,
but
lingers
in
the
vaults
below
,
and
sits
upon
the
coffins
.
<EOS>
And
now
comes
bright
day
,
burnishing
the
steeple
-
clock
,
and
reddening
the
spire
,
and
drying
up
the
tears
of
dawn
,
and
stifling
its
complaining
;
and
the
scared
dawn
,
following
the
night
,
and
chasing
it
from
its
last
refuge
,
shrinks
into
the
vaults
itself
and
hides
,
with
a
frightened
face
,
among
the
dead
,
until
night
returns
,
refreshed
,
to
drive
it
out
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
,
the
mice
,
who
have
been
busier
with
the
prayer
-
books
than
their
proper
owners
,
and
with
the
hassocks
,
more
worn
by
their
little
teeth
by
human
knees
,
hide
their
bright
eyes
in
their
holes
,
and
gather
close
together
in
affright
at
the
resounding
clashing
of
the
church
-
door
.
<EOS>
For
the
beadle
,
that
man
of
power
,
comes
early
this
morning
with
the
sexton
;
and
Mrs
Miff
,
the
wheezy
little
pew
-
opener
---
a
mighty
dry
old
lady
,
sparely
dressed
,
with
not
an
inch
of
fulness
anywhere
about
her
---
is
also
here
,
and
has
been
waiting
at
the
church
-
gate
half
-
an
-
hour
,
as
her
place
is
,
for
the
beadle
.
  
<EOS>
A
vinegary
face
has
Mrs
Miff
,
and
a
mortified
bonnet
,
and
eke
a
thirsty
soul
for
sixpences
and
shillings
.
<EOS>
Beckoning
to
stray
people
to
come
into
pews
,
has
given
Mrs
Miff
an
air
of
mystery
;
and
there
is
reservation
in
the
eye
of
Mrs
Miff
,
as
always
knowing
of
a
softer
seat
,
but
having
her
suspicions
of
the
fee
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
such
fact
as
Mr
Miff
,
nor
has
there
been
,
these
twenty
years
,
and
Mrs
Miff
would
rather
not
allude
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
held
some
bad
opinions
,
it
would
seem
,
about
free
seats
,
and
though
Mrs
Miff
hopes
he
may
be
gone
upwards
,
she
could
n't
positively
undertake
to
say
so
.
  
<EOS>
Busy
is
Mrs
Miff
this
morning
at
the
church
-
door
,
beating
and
dusting
the
altar
-
cloth
,
the
carpet
,
and
the
cushions
;
and
much
has
Mrs
Miff
to
say
,
about
the
wedding
they
are
going
to
have
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Miff
is
told
,
that
the
new
furniture
and
alterations
in
the
house
cost
full
five
thousand
pound
if
they
cost
a
penny
;
and
Mrs
Miff
has
heard
,
upon
the
best
authority
,
that
the
lady
has
n't
got
a
sixpence
wherewithal
to
bless
herself
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Miff
remembers
,
likewise
,
as
if
it
had
happened
yesterday
,
the
first
wife
's
funeral
,
and
then
the
christening
,
and
then
the
other
funeral
;
and
Mrs
Miff
says

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
