was
moved
,
and
put
the
hand
she
held
out
,
to
his
lips
,
much
as
a
tender
father
might
kiss
the
hand
of
a
dutiful
child
.
<EOS>
But
more
reverently
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
the
day
should
ever
come
,
"
said
Harriet
,
"
when
he
is
restored
,
in
part
,
to
the
position
he
lost
"
  
"
Restored
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
gentleman
,
quickly
.
<EOS>
"
How
can
that
be
hoped
for
?
<EOS>
In
whose
hands
does
the
power
of
any
restoration
lie
?
<EOS>
It
is
no
mistake
of
mine
,
surely
,
to
suppose
that
his
having
gained
the
priceless
blessing
of
his
life
,
is
one
cause
of
the
animosity
shown
to
him
by
his
brother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
touch
upon
a
subject
that
is
never
breathed
between
us
;
not
even
between
us
,
"
said
Harriet
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
forgiveness
,
"
said
the
visitor
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
known
it
.
<EOS>
I
entreat
to
you
to
forget
that
I
have
done
so
,
inadvertently
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
as
I
dare
urge
no
more
---
as
I
am
no
sure
that
I
have
a
right
to
do
so
---
though
Heaven
knows
,
even
that
doubt
may
be
habit
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
rubbing
his
head
,
as
despondently
as
before
,
"
let
me
;
though
a
stranger
,
yet
no
stranger
;
ask
two
favours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
are
they
?
"
<EOS>
she
inquired
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
first
,
that
if
you
should
see
cause
to
change
your
resolution
,
you
will
suffer
me
to
be
as
your
right
hand
.
<EOS>
My
name
shall
then
be
at
your
service
:
it
is
useless
now
,
and
always
insignificant
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our
choice
of
friends
,
"
she
answered
,
smiling
faintly
,
"
is
not
so
great
,
that
I
need
any
time
for
consideration
.
<EOS>
I
can
promise
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
second
,
that
you
will
allow
me
sometimes
,
say
every
Monday
morning
,
at
nine
o'clock
---
<EOS>
habit
again
---
I
must
be
business
-
like
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
with
a
whimsical
inclination
to
quarrel
with
himself
on
that
head
,
"
in
walking
past
,
to
see
you
at
the
door
or
window
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
ask
to
come
in
,
as
your
brother
will
be
gone
out
at
that
hour
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
ask
to
speak
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
merely
ask
to
see
,
for
the
satisfaction
of
my
own
mind
,
that
you
are
well
,
and
without
intrusion
to
remind
you
,
by
the
sight
of
me
,
that
you
have
a
friend
---
an
elderly
friend
,
grey
-
haired
already
,
and
fast
growing
greyer
---
whom
you
may
ever
command
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
cordial
face
looked
up
in
his
;
confided
in
it
;
and
promised
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
understand
,
as
before
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
rising
,
"
that
you
purpose
not
to
mention
my
visit
to
John
Carker
,
lest
he
should
be
at
all
distressed
by
my
acquaintance
with
his
history
.
<EOS>
I
am
glad
of
it
,
for
it
is
out
of
the
ordinary
course
of
things
,
and
---
habit
again
!
"
said
the
gentleman
,
checking
himself
impatiently
,
"
as
if
there
were
no
better
course
than
the
ordinary
course
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
he
turned
to
go
,
and
walking
,
bareheaded
,
to
the
outside
of
the
little
porch
,
took
leave
of
her
with
such
a
happy
mixture
of
unconstrained
respect
and
unaffected
interest
,
as
no
breeding
could
have
taught
,
no
truth
mistrusted
,
and
nothing
but
a
pure
and
single
heart
expressed
.
  
<EOS>
Many
half
-
forgotten
emotions
were
awakened
in
the
sister
's
mind
by
this
visit
.
<EOS>
It
was
so
very
long
since
any
other
visitor
had
crossed
their
threshold
;
it
was
so
very
long
since
any
voice
of
sympathy
had
made
sad
music
in
her
ears
;
that
the
stranger
's
figure
remained
present
to
her
,
hours
afterwards
,
when
she
sat
at
the
window
,
plying
her
needle
;
and
his
words
seemed
newly
spoken
,
again
and
again
.
<EOS>
He
had
touched
the
spring
that
opened
her
whole
life
;
and
if
she
lost
him
for
a
short
space
,
it
was
only
among
the
many
shapes
of
the
one
great
recollection
of
which
that
life
was
made
.
  
<EOS>
Musing
and
working
by
turns
;
now
constraining
herself
to
be
steady
at
her
needle
for
a
long
time
together
,
and
now
letting
her
work
fall
,
unregarded
,
on
her
lap
,
and
straying
wheresoever
her
busier
thoughts
led
,
Harriet
Carker
found
the
hours
glide
by
her
,
and
the
day
steal
on
.
<EOS>
The
morning
,
which
had
been
bright
and
clear
,
gradually
became
overcast
;
a
sharp
wind
set
in
;
the
rain
fell
heavily
;
and
a
dark
mist
drooping
over
the
distant
town
,
hid
it
from
the
view
.
  
<EOS>
She
often
looked
with
compassion
,
at
such
a
time
,
upon
the
stragglers
who
came
wandering
into
London
,
by
the
great
highway
hard
by
,
and
who
,
footsore
and
weary
,
and
gazing
fearfully
at
the
huge
town
before
them
,
as
if
foreboding
that
their
misery
there
would
be
but
as
a
drop
of
water
in
the
sea
,
or
as
a
grain
of
sea
-
sand
on
the
shore
,
went
shrinking
on
,
cowering
before
the
angry
weather
,
and
looking
as
if
the
very
elements
rejected
them
.
<EOS>
Day
after
day
,
such
travellers
crept
past
,
but
always
,
as
she
thought
,
in
one
direction
---
always
towards
the
town
.
<EOS>
Swallowed
up
in
one
phase
or
other
of
its
immensity
,
towards
which
they
seemed
impelled
by
a
desperate
fascination
,
they
never
returned
.
<EOS>
Food
for
the
hospitals
,
the
churchyards
,
the
prisons
,
the
river
,
fever
,
madness
,
vice
,
and
death
,
---
they
passed
on
to
the
monster
,
roaring
in
the
distance
,
and
were
lost
.
  
<EOS>
The
chill
wind
was
howling
,
and
the
rain
was
falling
,
and
the
day
was
darkening
moodily
,
when
Harriet
,
raising
her
eyes
from
the
work
on
which
she
had
long
since
been
engaged
with
unremitting
constancy
,
saw
one
of
these
travellers
approaching
.
  
<EOS>
A
woman
.
<EOS>
A
solitary
woman
of
some
thirty
years
of
age
;
tall
;
well
formed
;
handsome
;
miserably
dressed
;
the
soil
of
many
country
roads
in
varied
weather
---
dust
,
chalk
,
clay
,
gravel
---
clotted
on
her
grey
cloak
by
the
streaming
wet
;
no
bonnet
on
her
head
,
nothing
to
defend
her
rich
black
hair
from
the
rain
,
but
a
torn
handkerchief
;
with
the
fluttering
ends
of
which
,
and
with
her
hair
,
the
wind
blinded
her
so
that
she
often
stopped
to
push
them
back
,
and
look
upon
the
way
she
was
going
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
in
the
act
of
doing
so
,
when
Harriet
observed
her
.
<EOS>
As
her
hands
,
parting
on
her
sunburnt
forehead
,
swept
across
her
face
,
and
threw
aside
the
hindrances
that
encroached
upon
it
,
there
was
a
reckless
and
regardless
beauty
in
it
:
a
dauntless
and
depraved
indifference
to
more
than
weather
:
a
carelessness
of
what
was
cast
upon
her
bare
head
from
Heaven
or
earth
:
that
coupled
with
her
misery
and
loneliness
,
touched
the
heart
of
her
fellow
-
woman
.
<EOS>
She
thought
of
all
that
was
perverted
and
debased
within
her
,
no
less
than
without
:
of
modest
graces
of
the
mind
,
hardened
and
steeled
,
like
these
attractions
of
the
person
:
of
the
many
gifts
of
the
Creator
flung
to
the
winds
like
the
wild
hair
;
of
all
the
beautiful
ruin
upon
which
the
storm
was
beating
and
the
night
was
coming
.
  
<EOS>
Thinking
of
this
,
she
did
not
turn
away
with
a
delicate
indignation
---
too
many
of
her
own
compassionate
and
tender
sex
too
often
do
---
but
pitied
her
.
  
<EOS>
Her
fallen
sister
came
on
,
looking
far
before
her
,
trying
with
her
eager
eyes
to
pierce
the
mist
in
which
the
city
was
enshrouded
,
and
glancing
,
now
and
then
,
from
side
to
side
,
with
the
bewildered
and
uncertain
aspect
of
a
stranger
.
<EOS>
Though
her
tread
was
bold
and
courageous
,
she
was
fatigued
,
and
after
a
moment
of
irresolution
,
sat
down
upon
a
heap
of
stones
;
seeking
no
shelter
from
the
rain
,
but
letting
it
rain
on
her
as
it
would
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
now
opposite
the
house
;
raising
her
head
after
resting
it
for
a
moment
on
both
hands
,
her
eyes
met
those
of
Harriet
.
  
<EOS>
In
a
moment
,
Harriet
was
at
the
door
:
and
the
other
,
rising
from
her
seat
at
her
beck
,
came
slowly
,
and
with
no
conciliatory
look
,
towards
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
rest
in
the
rain
?
"
said
Harriet
,
gently
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
have
no
other
resting
-
place
,
"
was
the
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
there
are
many
places
of
shelter
near
here
.
<EOS>
This
,
"
referring
to
the
little
porch
,
"
is
better
than
where
you
were
.
<EOS>
You
are
very
welcome
to
rest
here
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
wanderer
looked
at
her
,
in
doubt
and
surprise
,
but
without
any
expression
of
thankfulness
;
and
sitting
down
,
and
taking
off
one
of
her
worn
shoes
to
beat
out
the
fragments
of
stone
and
dust
that
were
inside
,
showed
that
her
foot
was
cut
and
bleeding
.
  
<EOS>
Harriet
uttering
an
expression
of
pity
,
the
traveller
looked
up
with
a
contemptuous
and
incredulous
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
's
a
torn
foot
to
such
as
me
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
And
what
's
a
torn
foot
in
such
as
me
,
to
such
as
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
in
and
wash
it
,
"
answered
Harriet
,
mildly
,
"
and
let
me
give
you
something
to
bind
it
up
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
woman
caught
her
arm
,
and
drawing
it
before
her
own
eyes
,
hid
them
against
it
,
and
wept
.
<EOS>
Not
like
a
woman
,
but
like
a
stern
man
surprised
into
that
weakness
;
with
a
violent
heaving
of
her
breast
,
and
struggle
for
recovery
,
that
showed
how
unusual
the
emotion
was
with
her
.
  
<EOS>
She
submitted
to
be
led
into
the
house
,
and
,
evidently
more
in
gratitude
than
in
any
care
for
herself
,
washed
and
bound
the
injured
place
.
<EOS>
Harriet
then
put
before
her
fragments
of
her
own
frugal
dinner
,
and
when
she
had
eaten
of
them
,
though
sparingly
,
besought
her
,
before
resuming
her
road
(
which
she
showed
her
anxiety
to
do
)
,
to
dry
her
clothes
before
the
fire
.
<EOS>
Again
,
more
in
gratitude
than
with
any
evidence
of
concern
in
her
own
behalf
,
she
sat
down
in
front
of
it
,
and
unbinding
the
handkerchief
about
her
head
,
and
letting
her
thick
wet
hair
fall
down
below
her
waist
,
sat
drying
it
with
the
palms
of
her
hands
,
and
looking
at
the
blaze
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
you
are
thinking
"
she
said
,
lifting
her
head
suddenly
,
"
that
I
used
to
be
handsome
,
once
.
<EOS>
I
believe
I
was
---
<EOS>
I
know
I
was
.
<EOS>
Look
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
held
up
her
hair
roughly
with
both
hands
;
seizing
it
as
if
she
would
have
torn
it
out
;
then
,
threw
it
down
again
,
and
flung
it
back
as
though
it
were
a
heap
of
serpents
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
a
stranger
in
this
place
?
"
asked
Harriet
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
stranger
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
returned
,
stopping
between
each
short
reply
,
and
looking
at
the
fire
.
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Ten
or
a
dozen
years
a
stranger
.
<EOS>
I
have
had
no
almanack
where
I
have
been
.
<EOS>
Ten
or
a
dozen
years
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
this
part
.
<EOS>
It
's
much
altered
since
I
went
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
been
far
?
"
  
"
Very
far
.
<EOS>
Months
upon
months
over
the
sea
,
and
far
away
even
then
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
where
convicts
go
,
"
she
added
looking
full
upon
her
entertainer
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
one
myself
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven
help
you
and
forgive
you
!
"
<EOS>
was
the
gentle
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
Heaven
help
me
and
forgive
me
!
"
<EOS>
she
returned
,
nodding
her
head
at
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"
If
man
would
help
some
of
us
a
little
more
,
God
would
forgive
us
all
the
sooner
perhaps
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
she
was
softened
by
the
earnest
manner
,
and
the
cordial
face
so
full
of
mildness
and
so
free
from
judgment
,
of
her
,
and
said
,
less
hardily
:
  
<EOS>
"
We
may
be
about
the
same
age
,
you
and
me
.
<EOS>
If
I
am
older
,
it
is
not
above
a
year
or
two
.
<EOS>
Oh
think
of
that
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
opened
her
arms
,
as
though
the
exhibition
of
her
outward
form
would
show
the
moral
wretch
she
was
;
and
letting
them
drop
at
her
sides
,
hung
down
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
we
may
not
hope
to
repair
;
it
is
never
too
late
to
amend
,
"
said
Harriet
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
penitent
---
"
  
"
No
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
!
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
be
.
<EOS>
I
am
no
such
thing
.
<EOS>
Why
should
Ibe
penitent
,
and
all
the
world
go
free
?
<EOS>
They
talk
to
me
of
my
penitence
.
<EOS>
Who
's
penitent
for
the
wrongs
that
have
been
done
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
rose
up
,
bound
her
handkerchief
about
her
head
,
and
turned
to
move
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
"
said
Harriet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yonder
,
"
she
answered
,
pointing
with
her
hand
.
"
<EOS>
To
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have
you
any
home
to
go
to
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
have
a
mother
.
<EOS>
She
's
as
much
a
mother
,
as
her
dwelling
is
a
home
,
"
she
answered
with
a
bitter
laugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Take
this
,
"
cried
Harriet
,
putting
money
in
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Try
to
do
well
.
<EOS>
It
is
very
little
,
but
for
one
day
it
may
keep
you
from
harm
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
married
?
"
said
the
other
,
faintly
,
as
she
took
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
live
here
with
my
brother
.
<EOS>
We
have
not
much
to
spare
,
or
I
would
give
you
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
let
me
kiss
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Seeing
no
scorn
or
repugnance
in
her
face
,
the
object
of
her
charity
bent
over
her
as
she
asked
the
question
,
and
pressed
her
lips
against
her
cheek
.
<EOS>
Once
more
she
caught
her
arm
,
and
covered
her
eyes
with
it
;
and
then
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
Gone
into
the
deepening
night
,
and
howling
wind
,
and
pelting
rain
;
urging
her
way
on
towards
the
mist
-
enshrouded
city
where
the
blurred
lights
gleamed
;
and
with
her
black
hair
,
and
disordered
head
-
gear
,
fluttering
round
her
reckless
face
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
34
.
<EOS>
Another
Mother
and
Daughter
 
IN
an
ugly
and
dark
room
,
an
old
woman
,
ugly
and
dark
too
,
sat
listening
to
the
wind
and
rain
,
and
crouching
over
a
meagre
fire
.
<EOS>
More
constant
to
the
last
-
named
occupation
than
the
first
,
she
never
changed
her
attitude
,
unless
,
when
any
stray
drops
of
rain
fell
hissing
on
the
smouldering
embers
,
to
raise
her
head
with
an
awakened
attention
to
the
whistling
and
pattering
outside
,
and
gradually
to
let
it
fall
again
lower
and
lower
and
lower
as
she
sunk
into
a
brooding
state
of
thought
,
in
which
the
noises
of
the
night
were
as
indistinctly
regarded
as
is
the
monotonous
rolling
of
a
sea
by
one
who
sits
in
contemplation
on
its
shore
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
no
light
in
the
room
<EOS>
save
that
which
the
fire
afforded
.
<EOS>
Glaring
sullenly
from
time
to
time
like
the
eye
of
a
fierce
beast
half
asleep
,
it
revealed
no
objects
that
needed
to
be
jealous
of
a
better
display
.
<EOS>
A
heap
of
rags
,
a
heap
of
bones
,
a
wretched
bed
,
two
or
three
mutilated
chairs
or
stools
,
the
black
walls
and
blacker
ceiling
,
were
all
its
winking
brightness
shone
upon
.
<EOS>
As
the
old
woman
,
with
a
gigantic
and
distorted
image
of
herself
thrown
half
upon
the
wall
behind
her
,
half
upon
the
roof
above
,
sat
bending
over
the
few
loose
bricks
within
which
it
was
pent
,
on
the
damp
hearth
of
the
chimney
---
<EOS>
for
there
was
no
stove
<EOS>
---
she
looked
as
if
she
were
watching
at
some
witch
's
altar
for
a
favourable
token
;
and
but
that
the
movement
of
her
chattering
jaws
and
trembling
chin
was
too
frequent
and
too
fast
for
the
slow
flickering
of
the
fire
,
it
would
have
seemed
an
illusion
wrought
by
the
light
,
as
it
came
and
went
,
upon
a
face
as
motionless
as
the
form
to
which
it
belonged
.
  
<EOS>
If
Florence
could
have
stood
within
the
room
and
looked
upon
the
original
of
the
shadow
thrown
upon
the
wall
and
roof
,
as
it
cowered
thus
over
the
fire
,
a
glance
might
have
sufficed
to
recall
the
figure
of
Good
Mrs
Brown
;
notwithstanding
that
her
childish
recollection
of
that
terrible
old
woman
was
as
grotesque
and
exaggerated
a
presentment
of
the
truth
,
perhaps
,
as
the
shadow
on
the
wall
.
<EOS>
But
Florence
was
not
there
to
look
on
;
and
Good
Mrs
Brown
remained
unrecognised
,
and
sat
staring
at
her
fire
,
unobserved
.
  
<EOS>
Attracted
by
a
louder
sputtering
than
usual
,
as
the
rain
came
hissing
down
the
chimney
in
a
little
stream
,
the
old
woman
raised
her
head
,
impatiently
,
to
listen
afresh
.
<EOS>
And
this
time
she
did
not
drop
it
again
;
for
there
was
a
hand
upon
the
door
,
and
a
footstep
in
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
looking
over
her
shoulder
.
  
<EOS>
"
One
who
brings
you
news
,
"
was
the
answer
,
in
a
woman
's
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
News
?
<EOS>
Where
from
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
From
abroad
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
From
beyond
seas
?
"
cried
the
old
woman
,
starting
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
from
beyond
seas
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
raked
the
fire
together
,
hurriedly
,
and
going
close
to
her
visitor
who
had
entered
,
and
shut
the
door
,
and
who
now
stood
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
put
her
hand
upon
the
drenched
cloak
,
and
turned
the
unresisting
figure
,
so
as
to
have
it
in
the
full
light
of
the
fire
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
find
what
she
had
expected
,
whatever
that
might
be
;
for
she
let
the
cloak
go
again
,
and
uttered
a
querulous
cry
of
disappointment
and
misery
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
asked
her
visitor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
Oho
!
"
cried
old
woman
,
turning
her
face
upward
,
with
a
terrible
howl
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
asked
the
visitor
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
my
gal
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
old
woman
,
tossing
up
her
arms
,
and
clasping
her
hands
above
her
head
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
my
Alice
?
<EOS>
Where
's
my
handsome
daughter
?
<EOS>
They
've
been
the
death
of
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
've
not
been
the
death
of
her
yet
,
if
your
name
's
Marwood
,
"
said
the
visitor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen
my
gal
,
then
?
"
cried
the
old
woman
.
"
<EOS>
Has
she
wrote
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
said
you
could
n't
read
,
"
returned
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
more
I
can
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
old
woman
,
wringing
her
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
no
light
here
?
"
said
the
other
,
looking
round
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
,
mumbling
and
shaking
her
head
,
and
muttering
to
herself
about
her
handsome
daughter
,
brought
a
candle
from
a
cupboard
in
the
corner
,
and
thrusting
it
into
the
fire
with
a
trembling
hand
,
lighted
it
with
some
difficulty
and
set
it
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
Its
dirty
wick
burnt
dimly
at
first
,
being
choked
in
its
own
grease
;
and
when
the
bleared
eyes
and
failing
sight
of
the
old
woman
could
distinguish
anything
by
its
light
,
her
visitor
was
sitting
with
her
arms
folded
,
her
eyes
turned
downwards
,
and
a
handkerchief
she
had
worn
upon
her
head
lying
on
the
table
by
her
side
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
sent
to
me
by
word
of
mouth
then
,
my
gal
,
Alice
?
<EOS>
"
mumbled
the
old
woman
,
after
waiting
for
some
moments
.
<EOS>
"
What
did
she
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Look
,
"
returned
the
visitor
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
repeated
the
word
in
a
scared
uncertain
way
;
and
,
shading
her
eyes
,
looked
at
the
speaker
,
round
the
room
,
and
at
the
speaker
once
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
said
look
again
,
mother
;
"
and
the
speaker
fixed
her
eyes
upon
her
.
  
<EOS>
Again
the
old
woman
looked
round
the
room
,
and
at
her
visitor
,
and
round
the
room
once
more
.
<EOS>
Hastily
seizing
the
candle
,
and
rising
from
her
seat
,
she
held
it
to
the
visitor
's
face
,
uttered
a
loud
cry
,
set
down
the
light
,
and
fell
upon
her
neck
!
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
my
gal
!
<EOS>
It
's
my
Alice
!
<EOS>
It
's
my
handsome
daughter
,
living
an
come
back
!
"
<EOS>
screamed
the
old
woman
,
rocking
herself
to
and
fro
upon
the
breast
that
coldly
suffered
her
embrace
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
my
gal
!
<EOS>
It
's
my
Alice
!
<EOS>
It
's
my
handsome
daughter
,
living
and
come
back
!
"
<EOS>
she
screamed
again
,
dropping
on
the
floor
before
her
,
clasping
her
knees
,
laying
her
head
against
them
,
and
still
rocking
herself
to
and
fro
with
every
frantic
demonstration
of
which
her
vitality
was
capable
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
mother
,
"
returned
Alice
,
stooping
forward
for
a
moment
and
kissing
her
,
but
endeavouring
,
even
in
the
act
,
to
disengage
herself
from
her
embrace
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
here
,
at
last
.
<EOS>
Let
go
,
mother
;
let
go
.
<EOS>
Get
up
,
and
sit
in
your
chair
.
<EOS>
What
good
does
this
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
's
come
back
harder
than
she
went
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
mother
,
looking
up
in
her
face
,
and
still
holding
to
her
knees
.
<EOS>
"
She
do
n't
care
for
me
!
<EOS>
after
all
these
years
,
and
all
the
wretched
life
I
've
led
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
mother
!
"
said
Alice
,
shaking
her
ragged
skirts
to
detach
the
old
woman
from
them
:
"
there
are
two
sides
to
that
.
<EOS>
There
have
been
years
for
me
as
well
as
you
,
and
there
has
been
wretchedness
for
me
as
well
as
you
.
<EOS>
Get
up
,
get
up
!
"
  
<EOS>
Her
mother
rose
,
and
cried
,
and
wrung
her
hands
,
and
stood
at
a
little
distance
gazing
on
her
.
<EOS>
Then
she
took
the
candle
again
,
and
going
round
her
,
surveyed
her
from
head
to
foot
,
making
a
low
moaning
all
the
time
.
<EOS>
Then
she
put
the
candle
down
,
resumed
her
chair
,
and
beating
her
hands
together
to
a
kind
of
weary
tune
,
and
rolling
herself
from
side
to
side
,
continued
moaning
and
wailing
to
herself
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
got
up
,
took
off
her
wet
cloak
,
and
laid
it
aside
.
<EOS>
That
done
,
she
sat
down
as
before
,
and
with
her
arms
folded
,
and
her
eyes
gazing
at
the
fire
,
remained
silently
listening
with
a
contemptuous
face
to
her
old
mother
's
inarticulate
complainings
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
expect
to
see
me
return
as
youthful
as
I
went
away
,
mother
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
at
length
,
turning
her
eyes
upon
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
Did
you
think
a
foreign
life
,
like
mine
,
was
good
for
good
looks
?
<EOS>
One
would
believe
so
,
to
hear
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
an't
that
!
"
cried
the
mother
.
<EOS>
"
She
knows
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
then
?
"
returned
the
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
It
had
best
be
something
that
do
n't
last
,
mother
,
or
my
way
out
<EOS>
is
easier
than
my
way
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hear
that
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
mother
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
all
these
years
she
threatens
to
desert
me
in
the
moment
of
her
coming
back
again
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
mother
,
for
the
second

,
there
have
been
years
for
me
as
well
as
you
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
Come
back
harder
?
<EOS>
Of
course
I
have
come
back
harder
.
<EOS>
What
else
did
you
expect
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Harder
to
me
!
<EOS>
To
her
own
dear
mother
!
"
cried
the
old
woman
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
who
began
to
harden
me
,
if
my
own
dear
mother
did
n't
,
"
she
returned
,
sitting
with
her
folded
arms
,
and
knitted
brows
,
and
compressed
lips
as
if
she
were
bent
on
excluding
,
by
force
,
every
softer
feeling
from
her
breast
.
"
<EOS>
Listen
,
mother
,
to
a
word
or
two
.
<EOS>
If
we
understand
each
other
now
,
we
shall
not
fall
out
any
more
,
perhaps
.
<EOS>
I
went
away
a
girl
,
and
have
come
back
a
woman
.
<EOS>
I
went
away
undutiful
enough
,
and
have
come
back
not
better
,
you
may
swear
.
<EOS>
But
have
you
been
very
dutiful
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
!
"
cried
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
my
gal
!
<EOS>
A
mother
dutiful
to
her
own
child
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
sounds
unnatural
,
do
n't
it
?
"
returned
the
daughter
,
looking
coldly
on
her
with
her
stern
,
regardless
,
hardy
,
beautiful
face
;
"
but
I
have
thought
of
it
sometimes
,
in
the
course
of
my
lone
years
,
till
I
have
got
used
to
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
heard
some
talk
about
duty
first
and
last
;
but
it
has
always
been
of
my
duty
to
other
people
.
<EOS>
I
have
wondered
now
and
then
---
to
pass
away
the
time
---
whether
no
one
ever
owed
any
duty
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
mother
sat
mowing
,
and
mumbling
,
and
shaking
her
head
,
but
whether
angrily
or
remorsefully
,
or
in
denial
,
or
only
in
her
physical
infirmity
,
did
not
appear
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
child
called
Alice
Marwood
,
"
said
the
daughter
,
with
a
laugh
,
and
looking
down
at
herself
in
terrible
derision
of
herself
,
"
born
,
among
poverty
and
neglect
,
and
nursed
in
it
.
<EOS>
Nobody
taught
her
,
nobody
stepped
forward
to
help
her
,
nobody
cared
for
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nobody
!
"
echoed
the
mother
,
pointing
to
herself
,
and
striking
her
breast
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
only
care
she
knew
,
"
returned
the
daughter
,
"
was
to
be
beaten
,
and
stinted
,
and
abused
sometimes
;
and
she
might
have
done
better
without
that
.
<EOS>
She
lived
in
homes
like
this
,
and
in
the
streets
,
with
a
crowd
of
little
wretches
like
herself
;
and
yet
she
brought
good
looks
out
of
this
childhood
.
<EOS>
So
much
the
worse
for
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
better
have
been
hunted
and
worried
to
death
for
ugliness
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go
on
!
<EOS>
go
on
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
mother
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
on
,
"
returned
the
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
girl
called
Alice
Marwood
.
<EOS>
She
was
handsome
.
<EOS>
She
was
taught
too
late
,
and
taught
all
wrong
.
<EOS>
She
was
too
well
cared
for
,
too
well
trained
,
too
well
helped
on
,
too
much
looked
after
.
<EOS>
You
were
very
fond
of
her
---
you
were
better
off
then
.
<EOS>
What
came
to
that
girl
comes
to
thousands
every
year
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
ruin
,
and
she
was
born
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
After
all
these
years
!
"
whined
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
My
gal
begins
with
this
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
'll
soon
have
ended
,
"
said
the
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
criminal
called
Alice
Marwood
---
a
girl
still
,
but
deserted
and
an
outcast
.
<EOS>
And
she
was
tried
,
and
she
was
sentenced
.
<EOS>
And
lord
,
how
the
gentlemen
in
the
Court
talked
about
it
!
<EOS>
and
how
grave
the
judge
was
on
her
duty
,
and
on
her
having
perverted
the
gifts
of
nature
---
as
if
he
did
n't
know
better
than
anybody
there
,
that
they
had
been
made
curses
to
her
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
how
he
preached
about
the
strong
arm
of
the
Law
---
<EOS>
so
very
strong
to
save
her
,
when
she
was
an
innocent
and
helpless
little
wretch
;
and
how
solemn
and
religious
it
all
was
.
<EOS>
I
have
thought
of
that
,
many
times
since
,
to
be
sure
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
folded
her
arms
tightly
on
her
breast
,
and
laughed
in
a
tone
that
made
the
howl
of
the
old
woman
musical
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
Alice
Marwood
was
transported
,
mother
,
"
she
pursued
,
"
and
was
sent
to
learn
her
duty
,
where
there
was
twenty
times
less
duty
,
and
more
wickedness
,
and
wrong
,
and
infamy
,
than
here
.
<EOS>
And
Alice
Marwood
is
come
back
a
woman
.
<EOS>
Such
a
woman
as
she
ought
to
be
,
after
all
this
.
<EOS>
In
good
time
,
there
will
be
more
solemnity
,
and
more
fine
talk
,
and
more
strong
arm
,
most
likely
,
and
there
will
be
an
end
of
her
;
but
the
gentlemen
need
n't
be
afraid
of
being
thrown
out
of
work
.
<EOS>
There
's
crowds
of
little
wretches
,
boy
and
girl
,
growing
up
in
any
of
the
streets
they
live
in
,
that
'll
keep
them
to
till
they
've
made
their
fortunes
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
leaned
her
elbows
on
the
table
,
and
resting
her
face
upon
her
two
hands
,
made
a
show
of
being
in
great
distress
---
or
really
was
,
perhaps
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
I
have
done
,
mother
,
"
said
the
daughter
,
with
a
motion
of
her
head
,
as
if
in
dismissal
of
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
enough
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
you
and
I
talk
of
being
dutiful
,
whatever
we
do
.
<EOS>
Your
childhood
was
like
mine
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
So
much
the
worse
for
both
of
us
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
to
blame
you
,
or
to
defend
myself
;
why
should
I
?
<EOS>
That
's
all
over
long
ago
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
a
woman
---
not
a
girl
,
now
---
and
you
and
I
need
n't
make
a
show

our
history
,
like
the
gentlemen
in
the
Court
.
<EOS>
We
know
all
about
it
well
enough
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lost
and
degraded
as
she
was
,
there
was
a
beauty
in
her
,
both
of
face
and
form
,
which
,
even
in
its
worst
expression
,
could
not
but
be
recognised
as
such
by
any

regarding
her
with
the
least

.
<EOS>
As
she
subsided
into

,
and
her
face
which
had
been
harshly

,
quieted
down
;
while
her
dark

,
fixed
upon
the
fire
,
exchanged

reckless
light
that
had
animated
them
,
for
one
that
was
softened
by
something
like
sorrow
;
there
shone
through
all
her
wayworn
misery
and

,
a
ray
of
the
departed
radiance
of
the
fallen

.
  
<EOS>
Her
mother
,
after
watching
her
for
some
time
without
speaking
,
ventured
to
steal
her
withered
hand
a
little
nearer
to
her
across
the
table
;
and
finding
that
she
permitted
this
,
to
touch
her
face
and
smooth
her
hair
.
<EOS>
With
the
feeling
as
it
seemed
,
that
the
old
woman
was
at
least
sincere
in
this
show
of
interest
,
Alice
made
no

to
check
her
;
so
,
advancing
by

,
she
bound
up
her
daughter
's
hair
afresh
,
took
off
her
wet
shoes
,
if
they
deserved
the
name
,
spread
something
dry
upon
her
shoulders
,
and
hovered
humbly
about
her
,
muttering
to
herself
,
as
she
recognised
her
old
features
and
expression
more
and
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
poor
,
mother
,
I
see
,
"
said
Alice
,
looking
round
,
when
she
had
sat
thus
for
some
time
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bitter
poor
,
my
deary
,
"
replied
the
old
woman
.
  
<EOS>
She
admired
her
daughter
,
and
was
afraid
of
her
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
her
admiration
,
such
as
it
was
,
had
originated
long
ago
,
when
she
first
found
anything
that
was
beautiful
appearing
in
the
midst
of
the
squalid
fight
of
her
existence
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
her
fear
was
referable
,
in
some
sort
,
to
the
retrospect
she
had
so
lately
heard
.
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
might
,
she
stood
,
submissively
and
deferentially
,
before
her
child
,
and
inclined

,
as
if
in
a

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
have
you
lived
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
begging
,
my
deary
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
pilfering
,
mother
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
,
Ally
---
in
a
very
small
way
.
<EOS>
I
am
old
and
timid
.
<EOS>
I
have
taken
trifles
from
children
now
and
then
,
my
deary
,
but
not
often
.
<EOS>
I
have
tramped
about
the
country
,
pet
,
and
I
know
what
I
know
.
<EOS>
I
have
watched
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Watched
?
"
returned
the
daughter
,
looking
at
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
hung
about
a
family
,
my
deary
,
"
said
the
mother
,
even
more

and

than

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
family
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
darling
,
Do
n't
be
angry
with

,
I
did
it
for
the

.
<EOS>
In
memory

my
poor
gal
beyond

.
<EOS>
"
She
put

,
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Years

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
came

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whose

?
"
  
"
Not

,
Alice

;
do

;

.
<EOS>
How
could

?
<EOS>
You

has

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whose

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
You
said
his
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
Ally
;
you
frighten
me
,

.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
---
only
Mr
Dombey
's
.
<EOS>
Since
then
,
darling
,
I
have
seen
them
often
.
<EOS>
I
have
seen
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
In

his

,
the
old
woman
shrunk
and

,
as
if

her
daughter
would

.
<EOS>
But

the
daughter
's

was
fixed
upon
her
,
and
expressed
the
most

,

:

as

by
that

doing

to

,
or
some

,
in
the
blind

of

that

possessed

.
  
<EOS>
"
Little
he
thought
who
I
was
!
"
said
the
old
woman
,
shaking
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
little
he
cared
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
her
daughter
,
between

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
there
we
were
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
"
face
to
face
.
<EOS>
I
spoke
to
him
,
and
he
spoke
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
sat
and
watched
him
as
he
went
away
down
a
long
grove
of
trees
:
and
at
every
step
he
took
<EOS>
,
I
cursed
him
soul
and
body
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
will
thrive
in
spite
of
that
,
"
returned
the
daughter
disdainfully
.
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
he
is
thriving
,
"
said
the
mother
.
  
<EOS>
She
held
her
peace
;
for
the
face
and
form
before
her
were
unshaped
by
range
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
if
the
bosom
would
burst
with
the
emotions
that
strove
within
it
.
<EOS>
The
effort
that
constrained
and
held
it
pent
up
,
was
no

formidable
than
the
rage
itself
:
no
less
bespeaking
the
violent
and
dangerous
character
of
the
woman
who
made
it
.
<EOS>
But
it
succeeded
,
and
she
asked
,
after
a
silence
:
  
"
Is
he
married
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
deary
,
"
said
the
mother
.
  
<EOS>
"
Going
to
be
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
that
I
know
of
,
deary
.
<EOS>
But
his
master
and
friend
is
married
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
we
may
give
him
joy
!
<EOS>
We
may
give
'em
all
joy
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
old
woman
,
hugging
herself
with
her
lean
arms
in
her

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nothing
but
joy
to
us
will
come
of
that
marriage
.
<EOS>
Mind
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
daughter
looked
at
her
for
an
explanation
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
wet
and
tired
:
hungry
and
thirsty
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
hobbling
to
the
cupboard
;
"
and
there
's
little
here
,
and
little
"
---
diving
down
into
her
pocket
,
and
jingling

few
half
-
pence
on
the
table
---
"
little
here
.
<EOS>
Have
you
any
money
,
Alice
,
deary
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
covetous
,
sharp
,
eager
face
with
which
she
asked
the
question
and
looked
on
,
as
her
daughter
took
out
of
her
bosom
the
little
gift
she
had
so

received
,
told
almost
as
much
of
the

of
this
parent

the
child

told

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
said

mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
more
.
<EOS>
I
should
not
have
this
,
but
for
charity
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
for
charity
,
eh
,
deary
?
"
said
the
old
woman
,
bending
greedily
over
the
table
to
look
at
the
money
,
which
she
appeared
distrustful
of
her
daughter
's
still
retaining
in
her
hand
,
and
gazing
on
.
"
<EOS>
Humph
!
<EOS>
six
and
six
is
twelve
,
and
six
eighteen
 
<EOS>
---
so
---
we
must
take
the
most
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
'll
go
buy
something
to
eat
and

.
"
  
<EOS>
With
greater

than
might
have

---
for

---
she
began
to
occupy
her

in
tying

old

on

,
and
folding
a

about

:
still

the
money
in

daughter
's

,
with
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
joy
is
to
come
to

of

,
mother
?
"
asked

daughter
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
told

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
joy
,
"
she

,
attiring
herself
,
with

,
"
of
no

at
all
,
and
much

,
my

.
<EOS>
The
joy
of
confusion
and
strife
among
'em
,
proud
as
they
are
,
and
of
daughter
-
danger
,
Alice
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
danger
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
what
I
have
seen
.
<EOS>
I
know
what
I
know
!
"
chuckled
the
mother
.
<EOS>
"
Let
some
look
to
it
.
<EOS>
Let
some
be
upon
their
guard
.
<EOS>
My
gal
may
keep
good
company
yet
!
"
  
<EOS>
Then
,
seeing
that
in
the
wondering
earnestness
with
which
her
daughter
regarded
her
,
her
hand
involuntarily
closed
upon
the
money
,
the
old
woman
made
more
speed
to
secure
it
,
and
hurriedly
added
,
"
but
I
'll
go
buy
something
;
I
'll
go
buy
something
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
stood
with
her
hand
stretched
out
before
her
daughter
,
her
daughter
,
glancing
again
at
the
money
,
put
it
to
her
lips
before
parting
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
Ally
!
<EOS>
Do
you
kiss
it
?
<EOS>
"
chuckled
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
like
me
---
I
often
do
,
<EOS>
Oh
,
it
's
so
good
to
us
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
squeezing
her
own
tarnished
halfpence
up
to
her
bag
of
a
throat
,
"
so
good
to
us
in
everything
but
not
coming
in
heaps
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
kiss
it
,
mother
,
"
said
the
daughter
,
"
or
<EOS>
I
did
then
<EOS>
---
I
do
n't
know
that
I
ever
did
before
---
for
the
giver
's
sake
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
giver
,
eh
,
deary
?
<EOS>
"
retorted
the
old
woman
,
whose
dimmed

glistened
as
she
took
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Aye
!
<EOS>
I
'll
kiss
it
for
the
giver
's
sake
,
too
,
when
the
giver
can
make
it
go
farther
.
<EOS>
But
I
'll
go
spend
it
,
deary
.
<EOS>
I
'll
be
back
directly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
seem
to
say
you
know
a
great
deal
,
mother
,
"
said
the
daughter
,
following
her
to
the
door
with
her

.
<EOS>
"
You
have
grown
very
wise
since
we
parted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Know
!
"
croaked
the
old
woman
,
coming
back
a
step
or
two
,
"
I
know
more
than
you
think
.
<EOS>
I
know
more
than
he
thinks
,
deary
,
as
I
'll
tell
you
by
and
bye
.
<EOS>
I
know
all
about
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
daughter
smiled
incredulously
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
of
his
brother
,
Alice
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
stretching
out
her
neck
with
a

of
malice
absolutely
frightful
,
"
who
might
have
been
where
you
have
been
---
for
stealing
money
---
and
who
lives
with
his
sister
,
over
yonder
,
by
the
north
road
out
of
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
  
"
By
the
north
road
out
of
London
,
deary
.
<EOS>
You
shall
see
the
house
if
you
like
.
<EOS>
It
an't
much
to
boast
of
,
genteel
as
his
own
is
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
,
"
cried
the
old
woman
,
shaking

and
laughing
;
for
her
daughter
had
started
up
,
"
not
now
;
it
's
too
far

;
it
's
by

,
where
the
stones

heaped
;
---
to
-

,
deary
,
if
it
's
fine
,
and
you
are
in
the
humour
.
<EOS>
But
I
'll
go
spend
---
"
  
"
Stop
!
"
and
the
daughter
flung
herself
upon
her
,
with
her
former
passion
raging
like
a
fire
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
sister
is
a
fair
-

Devil
,
with
brown
hair
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
,
amazed
and

,
nodded
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
see
the
shadow
of
him
in
her
face
!
<EOS>
It
's
a
red
house
standing
by
itself
.
<EOS>
Before
the
door
there
is
a
small
green
porch
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
the
old
woman
nodded
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
which
I
sat
to
-
day
!
<EOS>
Give
me
back
the
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
!
<EOS>
Deary
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Give
me
back
the
money
,
or
you
'll
be
hurt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
forced
it
from
the
old
woman
's
hand
as
she
spoke
,
and
utterly
indifferent
to
her
complainings
and
entreaties
,
threw
on
the
garments
she
had
taken
of
,
and
hurried
out
,
with
headlong
speed
.
  
<EOS>
The
mother
followed
,
limping
after
her
as
she
could
,
and
expostulating
with
no
more
effect
upon
her
than
upon
the
wind
and
rain
and
darkness
that
encompassed
them
.
<EOS>
Obdurate
and
fierce
in
her
own
purpose
,
and
indifferent
to
all
besides
,
the
daughter
defied
the
weather
and
the
distance
,
as
if
she
had
known
no
travel
or
fatigue
,
and
made
for
the
house
where
she
had
been
relieved
.
<EOS>
After
some
quarter
of
an
hour
's
walking
,
the
old
woman
,
spent
and
out
of
breath
,
ventured
to
hold
by
her
skirts
;
but
she
ventured
no
more
,
and
they
travelled
on
in
silence
through
the
wet
and
gloom
.
<EOS>
If
the
mother
now
and
then
uttered
a
word
of
complaint
,
she
stifled
it
lest
her
daughter
should
break
away
from
her
and
leave
her
behind
;
and
the
daughter
was
dumb
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
within
an
hour
or
so
of
midnight
,
when
they
left
the
regular
streets
behind
them
,
and
entered
on
the
deeper
gloom
of
that
neutral
ground
where
the
house
was
situated
.
<EOS>
The
town
lay
in
the
distance
,
lurid
and
lowering
;
the
bleak
wind
howled
over
the
open
space
;
all
around
was
black
,
wild
,
desolate
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
fit
place
for
me
!
"
said
the
daughter
,
stopping
to
look
back
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
so
,
when
I
was
here
before
,
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Alice
,
my
deary
,
"
cried
the
mother
,
pulling
her
gently
by
the
skirt
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
now
,
mother
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
give
the
money
back
,
my
darling
;
please
do
n't
.
<EOS>
We
ca
n't
afford

.
<EOS>
We
want
supper
,
deary
.
<EOS>
Money
is
money
,
whoever
gives
it
.
<EOS>
Say
what
you
will
,
but
keep
the
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
See
there
!
"
<EOS>
was
all
the
daughter
's
answer
.
<EOS>
"
That
is
the
house
I
mean
.
<EOS>
Is
that
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
nodded
in
the
affirmative
;
and
a
few
more
paces
brought
them
to
the
threshold
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
light
of
fire
and
candle
in
the
room
where
Alice
had
sat
to
dry
her
clothes
;
and
on
her
knocking
at
the
door
,
John
Carker
appeared
from
that
room
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
surprised
to
see
such
visitors
at
such
an
hour
,
and
asked
Alice
what
she
wanted
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
your
sister
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
The
woman
who
gave
me
money
to
-
day
.
"
  
<EOS>
At
the
sound
of
her
raised
voice
,
Harriet
came
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
here
!
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she
answered
,
wondering
.
  
<EOS>
The
face
that
had
humbled
itself
before
her
,
looked
on
her
now
with
such
invincible
hatred
and
defiance
;
and
the
hand
that
had
gently
touched
her
arm
,
was
clenched
with
such
a
show
of
evil
purpose
,
as
if
it
would
gladly
strangle
her
;
that
she
drew
close
to
her
brother
for
protection
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
I
could
speak
with
you
,
and
not
know
you
!
<EOS>
That
I
could
come
near
you
,
and
not
feel
what
blood
was
running
in
your
veins
,
by
the
tingling
of
my
own
!
"
<EOS>
said
Alice
,
with
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
What
have
I
done
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Done
!
"
returned
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
sat
me
by
your
fire
;
you
have
given
me
food
and
money
;
you
have
bestowed
your
compassion
on
me
!
<EOS>
You
!
<EOS>
whose
name
I
spit
upon
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
,
with
a
malevolence
that
made
her
ugliness
quite
awful
,
shook
her
withered
hand
at
the
brother
and
sister
in
confirmation
of
her
daughter
,
but
plucked
her
by
the
skirts
again
,
nevertheless
,
imploring
her
to
keep
the
money
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
dropped
a
tear
upon
your
hand
,
may
it
wither
<EOS>
it
<EOS>
up!If
<EOS>
I
spoke
a
gentle
word
in
your
hearing
<EOS>
,
may
it
deafen
you!If
<EOS>
I
touched
you
with
my
lips
,
may
the
touch
be
poison
to
you!A
curse
upon
this
roof
that
gave
me
shelter
!
<EOS>
Sorrow
and
shame
upon
your
head
!
<EOS>
Ruin
upon
all
belonging
to
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
said
the
words
,
she
threw
the
money
down
upon
the
ground
,
and
spurned
it
with
her
foot
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
tread
it
in
the
dust
:
I
would
n't
take
it
if
it
paved
my
way
to
Heaven
!
<EOS>
I
would
the
bleeding
foot
that
brought
me
here
to
-
day
,
had
rotted
off
,
before
it
led
me
to
your
house
!
"
  
<EOS>
Harriet
,
pale
and
trembling
,
restrained
her
brother
,
and
suffered
her
to
go
on
uninterrupted
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
well
that
I
should
be
pitied
and
forgiven
by
you
,
or
any
one
of
your
name
,
in
the
first
hour
of
my
return
!
<EOS>
It
was
well
that
you
should
act
the
kind
good
lady
to
me
!
<EOS>
I
'll
thank
you
when
I
die
;
I
'll
pray
for
you
,
and
all
your
race
,
you
may
be
sure
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
a
fierce
action
of
her
hand
,
as
if
she
sprinkled
hatred
on
the
ground
,
and
with
it
devoted
those
who
were
standing
there
to
destruction
,
she
looked
up
once
at
the
black
sky
,
and
strode
out
into
the
wild
night
.
  
<EOS>
The
mother
,
who
had
plucked
at
her
skirts
again
and
again
in
vain
,
and
had
eyed
the
money
lying
on
the
threshold
with
an
absorbing
greed
that
seemed
to
concentrate
her
faculties
upon
it
,
would
have
prowled
about
,
until
the
house
was
dark
,
and
then
groped
in
the
mire
on
the
chance
of
repossessing
herself
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
the
daughter
drew
her
away
,
and
they
set
forth
,
straight
,
on
their
return
to
their
dwelling
;
the
old
woman
whimpering
and
bemoaning
their
loss
upon
the
road
,
are
fretfully
bewailing
,
as
openly
as
she
dared
,
the
undutiful
conduct
of
her
handsome
girl
in
depriving
her
of
a
supper
,
on
the
very
first
night
of
their
reunion
.
  
<EOS>
Supperless
to
bed
she
went
,
saving
for
a
few
coarse
fragments
;
and
those
she
sat
mumbling
and
munching
over
a
scrap
of
fire
,
long
after
her
undutiful
daughter
lay
asleep
.
  
<EOS>
Were
this
miserable
mother
,
and
this
miserable
daughter
,
only
the
reduction
to
their
lowest
grade
,
of
certain
social
vices
sometimes
prevailing
higher
up
?
<EOS>
In
this
round
world
of
many
circles
within
circles
,
do
we
make
a
weary
journey
from
the
high
grade
to
the
low
,
to
find
at
last
that
they
lie
close
together
,
that
the
two
extremes
touch
,
and
that
our
journey
's
end
is
but
our
starting
-
place
?
<EOS>
Allowing
for
great
difference
of
stuff
and
texture
,
was
the
pattern
of
this
woof
repeated
among
gentle
blood
at
all
?
  
<EOS>
Say
,
Edith
Dombey
!
<EOS>
And
Cleopatra
,
best
of
mothers
,
let
us
have
your
testimony
!
   
<EOS>
Chapter
35
.
<EOS>
The
Happy
Pair
 
<EOS>
THE
dark
blot
on
the
street
is
gone
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
mansion
,
if
it
be
a
gap
among
the
other
houses
any
longer
,
is
only
so
because
it
is
not
to
be
vied
with
in
its
brightness
,
and
haughtily
casts
them
off
.
<EOS>
The
saying
is
,
that
home
is
home
,
be
it
never
so
homely
.
<EOS>
If
it
hold
good
in
the
opposite
contingency
,
and
home
is
home
<EOS>
be
it
<EOS>
never
so
stately
,
what
an
altar
to
the
Household
Gods
is
raised
up
here
!
  
<EOS>
Lights
are
sparkling
in
the
windows
this
evening
,
and
the
ruddy
glow
of
fires
is
warm
and
bright
upon
the
hangings
and
soft
carpets
,
and
the
dinner
waits
to
be
served
,
and
the
dinnertable
is
handsomely
set
forth
,
though
only
for
four
persons
,
and
the
sideboard
is
cumbrous
with
plate
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
first
time
that
the
house
has
been
arranged
for
occupation
since
its
late
changes
,
and
the
happy
pair
are
looked
for
every
minute
.
  
<EOS>
Only
second
to
the
wedding
morning
,
in
the
interest
and
expectation
it
engenders
among
the
household
,
is
this
evening
of
the
coming
home
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Perch
is
in
the
kitchen
taking
tea
;
and
has
made
the
tour
of
the
establishment
,
and
priced
the
silks
and
damasks
by
the
yard
,
and
exhausted
every
interjection
in
the
dictionary
and
out
of
it
expressive
of
admiration
and
wonder
.
<EOS>
The
upholsterer
's
foreman
,
who
has
left
his
hat
,
with
a
pocket
-
handkerchief
in
it
,
both
smelling
strongly
of
varnish
,
under
a
chair
in
the
hall
,
lurks
about
the
house
,
gazing
upwards
at
the
cornices
,
and
downward
at
the
carpets
,
and
occasionally
,
in
a
silent
transport
of
enjoyment
,
taking
a
rule
out
of
his
pocket
,
and
skirmishingly
measuring
expensive
objects
,
with
unutterable
feelings
.
<EOS>
Cook
is
in
high
spirits
,
and
says
give
her
a
place
where
there
's
plenty
of
company
(
as
she
'll
bet
you
sixpence
there
will
be
now
)
,
for
she
is
of
a
lively
disposition
,
and
she
always
was
from
a
child
,
and
she
do
n't
mind
who
knows
it
;
<EOS>
which
sentiment
elicits
from
the
breast
of
Mrs
Perch
a
responsive
murmur
of
support
and
approbation
.
<EOS>
All
the
housemaid
hopes
is
,
happiness
for
'em
---
but
marriage
is
a
lottery
,
and
the
more
she
thinks
about
it
,
the
more
she
feels
the
independence
and
the
safety
of
a
single
life
.
<EOS>
Mr
Towlinson
is
saturnine
and
grim
,
and
says
that
's
his
opinion
too
,
and
give
him
War
besides
,
and
down
with
the
French
---
for
this
young
man
has
a
general
impression
that
every
foreigner
is
a
Frenchman
and
must
be
by
the
laws
of
nature
.
  
<EOS>
At
each
new
sound
of
wheels
,
they
all
stop
,
whatever
they
are
saying
,
and
listen
;
and
more
than
once
there
is
a
general
starting
up
and
a
cry
of
"
Here
they
are
!
"
<EOS>
But
here
they
are
not
yet
;
and
Cook
begins
to
mourn
over
the
dinner
,
which
has
been
put
back
twice
,
and
the
upholsterer
's
foreman
still
goes
lurking
about
the
rooms
,
undisturbed
in
his
blissful
reverie
!
  
<EOS>
Florence
is
ready
to
receive
her
father
and
her
new
mama
.
<EOS>
Whether
the
emotions
that
are
throbbing
in
her
breast
originate
in
pleasure
or
in
pain
,
she
hardly
knows
.
<EOS>
But
the
fluttering
heart
sends
added
colour
to
her
cheeks
,
and
brightness
to
her
eyes
;
and
they
say
down
stairs
,
drawing
their
heads
together
<EOS>
---
for
they
always
speak
softly
when
they
speak
of
her
---
how
beautiful
Miss
Florence
looks
to
-
night
,
and
what
a
sweet
young
lady
she
has
grown
,
poor
dear
!
<EOS>
A
pause
succeeds
;
and
then
Cook
,
feeling
,
as
president
,
that
her
sentiments
are
waited
for
,
wonders
whether
---
and
there
stops
.
<EOS>
The
housemaid
wonders
too
,
and
so
does
Mrs
Perch
,
who
has
the
happy
social
faculty
of
always
wondering
when
other
people
wonder
,
without
being
at
all
particular
what
she
wonders
at
.
<EOS>
Mr
Towlinson
,
who
now
descries
an
opportunity
of
bringing
down
the
spirits
of
the
ladies
to
his
own
level
,
says
wait
and
see
<EOS>
;
he
wishes
some
people
were
well
out
of
this
.
<EOS>
Cook
leads
a
sigh
then
,
and
a
murmur
of
"
Ah
,
it
's
a
strange
world
,
it
is
indeed
!
"
<EOS>
and
when
it
has
gone
round
the
table
,
adds
persuasively
,
"
but
Miss
Florence
ca
n't
well
be
the
worse
for
any
change
,
Tom
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Towlinson
's
rejoinder
,
pregnant
with
frightful
meaning
,
is
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
ca
n't
she
though
!
"
<EOS>
and
sensible
that
a
mere
man
can
scarcely
be
more
prophetic
,
or
improve
upon
that
,
he
holds
his
peace
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
,
prepared
to
greet
her
darling
daughter
and
dear
son
-
in
-
law
with
open
arms
,
is
appropriately
attired
for
that
purpose
in
a
very
youthful
costume
,
with
short
sleeves
.
<EOS>
At
present
,
however
,
her
ripe
charms
are
blooming
in
the
shade
of
her
own
apartments
,
whence
she
has
not
emerged
since
she
took
possession
of
them
a
few
hours
ago
,
and
where
she
is
fast
growing
fretful
,
on
account
of
the
postponement
of
dinner
.
<EOS>
The
maid
who
ought
to
be
a
skeleton
,
but
is
in
truth
a
buxom
damsel
,
is
,
on
the
other
hand
,
in
a
most
amiable
state
:
considering
her
quarterly
stipend
much
safer
than
heretofore
,
and
foreseeing
a
great
improvement
in
her
board
and
lodging
.
  
<EOS>
Where
are
the
happy
pair
,
for
whom
this
brave
home
is
waiting
?
<EOS>
Do
steam
,
tide
,
wind
,
and
horses
,
all
abate
their
speed
,
to
linger
on
such
happiness
?
<EOS>
Does
the
swarm
of
loves
and
graces
hovering
about
them
retard
their
progress
by
its
numbers
?
<EOS>
Are
there
so
many
flowers
in
their
happy
path
,
that
they
can
scarcely
move
along
,
without
entanglement
in
thornless
roses
,
and
sweetest
briar
?
  
<EOS>
They
are
here
at
last
!
<EOS>
The
noise
of
wheels
is
heard
,
grows
louder
,
and
a
carriage
drives
up
to
the
door
!
<EOS>
A
thundering
knock
from
the
obnoxious
foreigner
anticipates
the
rush
of
Mr
Towlinson
and
party
to
open
it
;
and
Mr
Dombey
and
his
bride
alight
,
and
walk
in
arm
in
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
sweetest
Edith
!
<EOS>
"
cries
an
agitated
voice
upon
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dearest
Dombey
!
"
<EOS>
and
the
short
sleeves
wreath
themselves
about
the
happy
couple
in
turn
,
and
embrace
them
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
had
come
down
to
the
hall
too
,
but
did
not
advance
:
reserving
her
timid
welcome
until
these
nearer
and
dearer
transports
should
subside
.
<EOS>
But
the
eyes
of
Edith
sought
her
out
,
upon
the
threshold
;
and
dismissing
her
sensitive
parent
with
a
slight
kiss
on
the
cheek
,
she
hurried
on
to
Florence
and
embraced
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Florence
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
putting
out
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
As
Florence
,
trembling
,
raised
it
to
her
lips
,
she
met
his
glance
.
<EOS>
The
look
was
cold
and
distant
enough
,
but
it
stirred
her
heart
to
think
that
she
observed
in
it
something
more
of
interest
than
he
had
ever
shown
before
.
<EOS>
It
even
expressed
a
kind
of
faint
surprise
,
and
not
a
disagreeable
surprise
,
at
sight
of
her
.
<EOS>
She
dared
not
raise
her
eyes
to
his
any
more
;
but
she
felt
that
he
looked
at
her
once
again
,
and
hot
less
favourably
.
<EOS>
Oh
what
a
thrill
of
joy
shot
through
her
,
awakened
by
even
this
intangible
and
baseless
confirmation
of
her
hope
that
she
would
learn
to
win
him
,
through
her
new
and
beautiful
mama
!
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
be
long
dressing
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
I
presume
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
ready
immediately
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
them
send
up
dinner
in
a
quarter
of
an
hour
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
Mr
Dombey
stalked
away
to
his
own
dressingroom
,
and
Mrs
Dombey
went
upstairs
to
hers
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
and
Florence
repaired
to
the
drawing
-
room
,
where
that
excellent
mother
considered
it
incumbent
on
her
to
shed
a
few
irrepressible
tears
,
supposed
to
be
forced
from
her
by
her
daughter
's
felicity
;
and
which
she
was
still
drying
,
very

,
with
a
laced

of
her
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
when
her
son
-
in
-
law
appeared
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
,
my
dearest
Dombey
,
did
you
find
that
delightfullest
of
cities
,
Paris
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
,
subduing
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
cold
,
"
returned
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gay
as
ever
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
of
course
.
"
  
"
Not
particularly
.
<EOS>
I
thought
it
dull
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Fie
,
my
dearest
Dombey
!
"
<EOS>
archly
;
"
dull
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
made
that
impression
upon
me
,
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
with
grave
politeness
.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
Mrs
Dombey
found
it
dull
too
.
<EOS>
She
mentioned
once
or
twice
that
she
thought
it
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
naughty
girl
!
"
cried
Mrs
Skewton
,
rallying
her
dear
child
,
who
now
entered
,
"
what
dreadfully
heretical
things
have
you
been
saying
about
Paris
?
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
raised
her
eyebrows
with
an
air
of
weariness
;
and
passing
the
folding
-
doors
which
were
thrown
open
to
display
the
suite
of
rooms
in
their
new
and
handsome
garniture
,
and
barely
glancing
at
them
as
she

,
sat
down
by
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Dombey
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
how
charmingly
these
people
have
carried
out
every
idea
that
we
hinted
.
<EOS>
They
have
made
a
perfect
palace
of
the
house
,
positively
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
handsome
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
looking
round
.
<EOS>
"
I
directed
that
no
expense
should
be
spared
;
and
all
that
money
could
do
,
has
been
done
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
what
can
it
not
do
,
dear
Dombey
?
"
observed
Cleopatra
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
powerful
,
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
He
looked
in
his
solemn
way
towards
his
wife
,
but
not
a
word
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
"
addressing
her
after
a
moment
's
silence
,
with
especial
distinctness
;
"
that
these
alterations
meet
with
your
approval
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
as
handsome
as
they
can
be
,
"
she
returned
,
with
haughty
carelessness
.
<EOS>
"
They
should
be
so
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
And
I
suppose
they
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
An
expression
of
scorn
was
habitual
to
the
proud
face
,
and
seemed
inseparable
from
it
;
but
the
contempt
with
which
it
received
any
appeal
to
admiration
,
respect
,
or
consideration
on
the
ground
of
his
riches
,
no
matter
how
slight
or
ordinary
in
itself
,
was
a
new
and
different
expression
,
unequalled
in
intensity
by
any
other
of
which
it
was
capable
.
<EOS>
Whether
Mr
Dombey
,
wrapped
in
his
own
greatness
,
was
at
all
aware
of
this
,
or
no
,
there
had
not
been
wanting
opportunities
already
for
his
complete
enlightenment
;
and
at
that
moment
it
might
have
been
effected
by
the
one
glance
of
the
dark
eye
that
lighted
on
him
,
after
it
had
rapidly
and
scornfully
surveyed
the
theme
of
his
self
-
glorification
.
<EOS>
He
might
have
read
in
that
one
glance
that
nothing
that
his
wealth
could
do
,
though
it
were
increased
ten
thousand
fold
,
could
win
him
for
its
own
sake
,
one
look
of
softened
recognition
from
the
defiant
woman
,
linked
to
him
,
but
arrayed
with
her
whole
soul
against
him
.
<EOS>
He
might
have
read
in
that
one
glance
that
even
for
its
sordid
and
mercenary
influence
upon
herself
,
she
spurned
it
,
while
she
claimed
its
utmost
power
as
her
right
,
her
bargain
---
as
the
base
and
worthless
recompense
for
which
she
had
become
his
wife
.
<EOS>
He
might
have
read
in
it
that
,
ever
baring
her
own
head
for
the
lightning
of
her
own
contempt
and
pride
to
strike
,
the
most
innocent
allusion
to
the
power
of
his
riches
degraded
her
anew
,
sunk
her
deeper
in
her
own
respect
,
and
made
the
blight
and
waste
within
her
more
complete
.
  
<EOS>
But
dinner
was
announced
,
and
Mr
Dombey
led
down
Cleopatra
;
Edith
and
his
daughter
following
.
<EOS>
Sweeping
past
the
gold
and
silver
demonstration
on
the
sideboard
as
if
it
were
heaped
-
up
dirt
,
and
deigning
to
bestow
no
look
upon
the
elegancies
around
her
,
she
took
her
place
at
his
board
for
the
first
time
,
and
sat
,
like
a
statue
,
at
the
feast
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
being
a
good
deal
in
the
statue
way
himself
,
was
well
enough
pleased
to
see
his
handsome
wife
immovable
and
proud
and
cold
.
<EOS>
Her
deportment
being
always
elegant
and
graceful
,
this
as
a
general
behavior
was
agreeable
and
congenial
to
him
.
<EOS>
Presiding
,
therefore
,
with
his
accustomed
dignity
,
and
not
at
all
reflecting
on
his
wife
by
any
warmth
or
hilarity
of
his
own
,
he
performed
his
share
of
the
honours
of
the
table
with
a
cool
satisfaction
;
and
the
installation
dinner
,
though
not
regarded
downstairs
as
a
great
success
,
or
very
promising
beginning
,
passed
off
,
above
,
in
a
sufficiently
polite
,
genteel
,
and
frosty
manner
.
  
<EOS>
Soon
after
tea
,
Mrs
Skewton
,
who
affected
to
be
quite
overcome
and
worn
out
by
her
emotions
of
happiness
,
arising
in
the
contemplation
of
her
dear
child
united
to
the
man
of
her
heart
,
but
who
,
there
is
reason
to
suppose
,
found
this
family
party
somewhat
dull
,
as
she
yawned
for
one
hour
continually
behind
her
fan
,
retired
to
bed
.
<EOS>
Edith
,
also
,
silently
withdrew
and
came
back
no
more
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
it
happened
that
Florence
,
who
had
been
upstairs
to
have
some
conversation
with
Diogenes
,
returning
to
the
drawing
-
room
with
her
little
work
-
basket
,
found
no
one
there
but
her
father
,
who
was
walking
to
and
fro
,
in
dreary
magnificence
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
go
away
,
papa
?
"
said
Florence
faintly
,
hesitating
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned
Mr
Dombey
,
looking
round
over
his
shoulder
;
"
you
can
come
and
go
here
,
Florence
,
as
you
please
.
<EOS>
This
is
not
my
private
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
entered
,
and
sat
down
at
a
distant
little
table
with
her
work
:
finding
herself
for
the
first
time
in
her
life
---
for
the
very
first
time
within
her
memory
from
her
infancy
to
that
hour
---
alone
with
her
father
,
as
his
companion
.
<EOS>
She
,
his
natural
companion
,
his
only
child
,
who
in
her
lonely
life
and
grief
had
known
the
suffering
of
a
breaking
heart
;
who
,
in
her
rejected
love
,
had
never
breathed
his
name
to
God
at
night
,
but
with
a
tearful
blessing
,
heavier
on
him
than
a
curse
;
who
had
prayed
to
die
young
,
so
she
might
only
die
in
his
arms
;
who
had
,
all
through
,
repaid
the
agony
of
slight
and
coldness
,
and
dislike
,
with
patient
unexacting
love
,
excusing
him
,
and
pleading
for
him
,
like
his
better
angel
!
  
<EOS>
She
trembled
,
and
her
eyes
were
dim
.
<EOS>
His
figure
seemed
to
grow
in
height
and
bulk
before
her
as
he
paced
the
room
:
now
it
was
all
blurred
and
indistinct
;
now
clear
again
,
and
plain
;
and
now
she
seemed
to
think
that
this
had
happened
,
just
the
same
,
a
multitude
of
years
ago
.
<EOS>
She
yearned
towards
him
,
and
yet
shrunk
from
his
approach
.
<EOS>
Unnatural
emotion
in
a
child
,
innocent
of
wrong
!
<EOS>
Unnatural
the
hand
that
had
directed
the
sharp
plough
,
which
furrowed
up
her
gentle
nature
for
the
sowing
of
its
seeds
!
  
<EOS>
Bent
upon
not
distressing
or
offending
him
by
her
distress
,
Florence
controlled
herself
,
and
sat
quietly
at
her
work
.
<EOS>
After
a
few
more
turns
across
and
across
the
room
,
he
left
off
pacing
it
;
and
withdrawing
into
a
shadowy
corner
at
some
distance
,
where
there
was
an
easy
chair
,
covered
his
head
with
a
handkerchief
,
and
composed
himself
to
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
enough
for
Florence
to
sit
there
watching
him
;
turning
her
eyes
towards
his
chair
from
time
to
time
;
watching
him
with
her
thoughts
,
when
her
face
was
intent
upon
her
work
;
and
sorrowfully
glad
to
think
that
he
could
sleep
,
while
she
was
there
,
and
that
he
was
not
made
restless
by
her
strange
and
long
-
forbidden
presence
.
  
<EOS>
What
would
have
been
her
thoughts
if
she
had
known
that
he
was
steadily
regarding
her
;
that
the
veil
upon
his
face
,
by
accident
or
by
design
,
was
so
adjusted
that
his
sight
was
free
,
and
that
it
never
wandered
from
her
face
an
instant
!
<EOS>
That
when
she
looked
towards
him
,
in
the
obscure
dark
corner
,
her
speaking
eyes
,
more
earnest
and
pathetic
in
their
voiceless
speech
than
all
the
orators
of
all
the
world
,
and
impeaching
him
more
nearly
in
their
mute
address
,
met
his
,
and
did
not
know
it
!
<EOS>
That
when
she
bent
her
head
again
over
her
work
,
he
drew
his
breath
more
easily
,
but
with
the
same
attention
looked
upon
her
still
---
upon
her
white
brow
and
her
falling
hair
,
and
busy
hands
;
and
once
attracted
,
seemed
to
have
no
power
to
turn
his
eyes
away
!
  
<EOS>
And
what
were
his
thoughts
meanwhile
?
<EOS>
With
what
emotions
did
he
prolong
the
attentive
gaze
covertly
directed
on
his
unknown
daughter
?
<EOS>
Was
there
reproach
to
him
in
the
quiet
figure
and
the
mild
eyes
?
<EOS>
Had
he
begun
to
feel
her
disregarded
claims
,
and
did
they
touch
him
home
at
last
,
and
waken
him
to
some
sense
of
his
cruel
injustice
?
  
<EOS>
There
are
yielding
moments
in
the
lives
of
the
sternest
and
harshest
men
,
though
such
men
often
keep
their
secret
well
.
<EOS>
The
sight
of
her
in
her
beauty
,
almost
changed
into
a
woman
without
his
knowledge
,
may
have
struck
out
some
such
moments
even
in
his
life
of
pride
.
<EOS>
Some
passing
thought
that
he
had
had
a
happy
home
within
his
reach
---
had
had
a
household
spirit
bending
at
his
feet
---
had
overlooked
it
in
his
stiffnecked
sullen
arrogance
,
and
wandered
away
and
lost
himself
,
may
have
engendered
them
.
<EOS>
Some
simple
eloquence
distinctly
heard
,
though
only
uttered
in
her
eyes
,
unconscious
that
he
read
them
,
as
"
By
the
death
-
beds
I
have
tended
,
by
the
childhood
I
have
suffered
,
by
our
meeting
in
this
dreary
house
at
midnight
,
by
the
cry
wrung
from
me
in
the
anguish
of
my
heart
,
oh
,
father
,
turn
to
me
and
seek
a
refuge
in
my
love
before
it
is
too
late
!
"
may
have
arrested
them
.
<EOS>
Meaner
and
lower
thoughts
,
as
that
his
dead
boy
was
now
superseded
by
new
ties
,
and
he
could
forgive
the
having
been
supplanted
in
his
affection
,
may
have
occasioned
them
.
<EOS>
The
mere
association
of
her
as
an
ornament
,
with
all
the
ornament
and
pomp
about
him
,
may
have
been
sufficient
.
<EOS>
But
as
he
looked
,
he
softened
to
her
,
more
and
more
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
,
she
became
blended
with
the
child
he
had
loved
,
and
he
could
hardly
separate
the
two
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
,
he
saw
her
for
an
instant
by
a
clearer
and
a
brighter
light
,
not
bending
over
that
child
's
pillow
as
his
rival
---
monstrous
thought
---
<EOS>
but
as
the
spirit
of
his
home
,
and
in
the
action
tending
himself
no
less
,
as
he
sat
once
more
with
his
bowed
-
down
head
upon
his
hand
at
the
foot
of
the
little
bed
.
<EOS>
He
felt
inclined
to
speak
to
her
,
and
call
her
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
words
"
Florence
,
come
here
!
"
were
rising
to
his
lips
---
but
slowly
and
with
difficulty
,
they
were
so
very
strange
---
when
they
were
checked
and
stifled
by
a
footstep
on
the
stair
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
his
wife
's
.
<EOS>
She
had
exchanged
her
dinner
dress
for
a
loose
robe
,
and
unbound
her
hair
,
which
fell
freely
about
her
neck
.
<EOS>
But
this
was
not
the
change
in
her
that
startled
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
,
dear
,
"
she
said
,
"
I
have
been
looking
for
you
everywhere
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
sat
down
by
the
side
of
Florence
,
she
stooped
and
kissed
her
hand
.
<EOS>
He
hardly
knew
his
wife
.
<EOS>
She
was
so
changed
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
merely
that
her
smile
was
new
to
him
---
though
that
he
had
never
seen
:
but
her
manner
,
the
tone
of
her
voice
,
the
light
of
her
eyes
,
the
interest
,
and
confidence
,
and
winning
wish
to
please
,
expressed
in
all
<EOS>
---
this
was
not
Edith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Softly
,
dear
Mama
.
<EOS>
Papa
is
asleep
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
Edith
now
.
<EOS>
She
looked
towards
the
corner
where
he
was
,
and
he
knew
that
face
and
manner
very
well
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
scarcely
thought
you
could
be
here
,
Florence
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
,
how
altered
and
how
softened
,
in
an
instant
!
  
<EOS>
"
I
left
here
early
,
"
pursued
Edith
,
"
purposely
to
sit
up
stairs
and
talk
with
you
.
<EOS>
But
,
going
to
your
room
,
I
found
my
bird
was
flown
,
and
I
have
been
waiting
there
ever
since
,
expecting
its
return
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
If
it
had
been
a
bird
,
indeed
,
she
could
not
have
taken
it
more
tenderly
and
gently
to
her
breast
,
than
she
did
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
dear
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
will
not
expect
to
find
me
,
I
suppose
,
when
he
wakes
,
"
hesitated
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
he
will
,
Florence
?
"
said
Edith
,
looking
full
upon
her
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
drooped
her
head
,
and
rose
,
and
put
up
her
workbasket
.
<EOS>
Edith
drew
her
hand
through
her
arm
,
and
they
went
out
of
the
room
like
sisters
.
<EOS>
Her
very
step
was
different
and
new
to
him
,
Mr
Dombey
thought
,
as
his
eyes
followed
her
to
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
He
sat
in
his
shadowy
corner
so
long
,
that
the
church
clocks
struck
the
hour
three
times
before
he
moved
that
night
.
<EOS>
All
that
while
his
face
was
still
intent
upon
the
spot
where
Florence
had
been
seated
.
<EOS>
The
room
grew
darker
,
as
the
candles
waned
and
went
out
;
but
a
darkness
gathered
on
his
face
,
exceeding
any
that
the
night
could
cast
,
and
rested
there
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
and
Edith
,
seated
before
the
fire
in
the
remote
room
where
little
Paul
had
died
,
talked
together
for
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
Diogenes
,
who
was
of
the
party
,
had
at
first
objected
to
the
admission
of
Edith
,
and
,
even
in
deference
to
his
mistress
's
wish
,
had
only
permitted
it
under
growling
protest
.
<EOS>
But
,
emerging
by
little
and
little
from
the
ante
-
room
,
whither
he
had
retired
in
dudgeon
,
he
soon
appeared
to
comprehend
,
that
with
the
most
amiable
intensions
he
had
made
one
of
those
mistakes
which
will
occasionally
arise
in
the
best
-
regulated
dogs
'
minds
;
as
a
friendly
apology
for
which
he
stuck
himself
up
on
end
between
the
two
,
in
a
very
hot
place
in
front
of
the
fire
,
and
sat
panting
at
it
,
with
his
tongue
out
,
and
a
most
imbecile
expression
of
countenance
,
listening
to
the
conversation
.
  
<EOS>
It
turned
,
at
first
,
on
Florence
's
books
and
favourite
pursuits
,
and
on
the
manner
in
which
she
had
beguiled
the
interval
since
the
marriage
.
<EOS>
The
last
theme
opened
up
to
her
a
subject
which
lay
very
near
her
heart
,
and
she
said
,
with
the
tears
starting
to
her
eyes
:
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mama
!
<EOS>
I
have
had
a
great
sorrow
since
that
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
a
great
sorrow
,
Florence
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Poor
Walter
is
drowned
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
spread
her
hands
before
her
face
,
and
wept
with
all
her
heart
.
<EOS>
Many
as
were
the
secret
tears
which
Walter
's
fate
had
cost
her
,
they
flowed
yet
,
when
she
thought
or
spoke
of
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
tell
me
,
dear
,
"
said
Edith
,
soothing
her
.
<EOS>
"
Who
was
Walter
?
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
my
brother
,
Mama
.
<EOS>
After
dear
Paul
died
,
we
said
we
would
be
brother
and
sister
.
<EOS>
I
had
known
him
a
long
time
---
from
a
little
child
.
<EOS>
He
knew
Paul
,
who
liked
him
very
much
;
Paul
said
,
almost
at
the
last
,
"
Take
care
of
Walter
,
dear
papa!I
was
fond
of
him
!
"
<EOS>
Walter
had
been
brought
in
to
see
him
,
and
was
there
then
---
in
this
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
did
he
take
care
of
Walter
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Edith
,
sternly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
?
<EOS>
He
appointed
him
to
go
abroad
.
<EOS>
He
was
drowned
in
shipwreck
on
his
voyage
,
"
said
Florence
,
sobbing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Does
he
know
that
he
is
dead
?
"
asked
Edith
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
tell
,
Mama
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
means
of
knowing
.
<EOS>
Dear
Mama
!
"
cried
Florence
,
clinging
to
her
as
for
help
,
and
hiding
her
face
upon
her
bosom
,
"
I
know
that
you
have
seen
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Stay
!
<EOS>
Stop
,
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
Edith
turned
so
pale
,
and
spoke
so
earnestly
,
that
Florence
did
not
need
her
restraining
hand
upon
her
lips
.
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
all
about
Walter
first
;
let
me
understand
this
history
all
through
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
related
it
,
and
everything
belonging
to
it
,
even
down
to
the
friendship
of
Mr
Toots
,
of
whom
she
could
hardly
speak
in
her
distress
without
a
tearful
smile
,
although
she
was
deeply
grateful
to
him
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
concluded
her
account
,
to
the
whole
of
which
Edith
,
holding
her
hand
,
listened
with
close
attention
,
and
when
a
silence
had
succeeded
,
Edith
said
:
  
"
What
is
it
that
you
know
I
have
seen
,
Florence
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
I
am
not
,
"
said
Florence
,
with
the
same
mute
appeal
,
and
the
same
quick
concealment
of
her
face
as
before
,
"
that
I
am
not
a
favourite
child
,
Mama
.
<EOS>
I
never
have
been
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
known
how
to
be
.
<EOS>
I
have
missed
the
way
,
and
had
no
one
to
show
it
to
me
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
let
me
learn
from
you
how
to
become
dearer
to
Papa
.
<EOS>
Teach
me
!
<EOS>
you
,
who
can
so
well
!
"
and
clinging
close
to
her
,
with
some
broken
fervent
words
of
gratitude
and
endearment
,
Florence
,
relived
of
her
sad
secret
,
wept
long
,
but
not
as
painfully
as
of
yore
,
within
the
encircling
arms
of
her
new
mother
.
  
<EOS>
Pale
even
to
her
lips
,
and
with
a
face
that
strove
for
composure
until
its
proud
beauty
was
as
fixed
as
death
<EOS>
,
Edith
looked
down
upon
the
weeping
girl
,
and
once
kissed
her
.
<EOS>
Then
gradually
disengaging
herself
,
and
putting
Florence
away
,
she
said
,
stately
,
and
quiet
as
a
marble
image
,
and
in
a
voice
that
deepened
as
she
spoke
,
but
had
no
other
token
of
emotion
in
it
:
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
,
you
do
not
know
me
!
<EOS>
Heaven
forbid
that
you
should
learn
from
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
learn
from
you
?
"
<EOS>
repeated
Florence
,
in
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
I
should
teach
you
how
to
love
,
or
be
loved
,
Heaven
forbid
!
"
said
Edith
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
could
teach
me
,
that
were
better
;
but
it
is
too
late
.
<EOS>
You
are
dear
to
me
,
Florence
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
think
that
anything
could
ever
be
so

to
me
,
as
you
are
in
this
little
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
saw
that
Florence
would
have
spoken
here
,
so
checked
her
with
her
hand
,
and
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
be
your
true
friend
always
.
<EOS>
I
will
cherish
you
,
as
much
,
if

.
<EOS>
You
may
trust
in
me
---
I
know
it
<EOS>
and
I
say

,

,
---
with
the
whole

even
of
your
pure

.
<EOS>
There
are
hosts
of
women
whom
he
might
have
married
,
better

all

I

,
Florence
;
but

here
,
his
wife
,
whose

could
beat
with
greater

mine

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
dear
Mama
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
that
first
most
happy
day
I
have
known
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Most
happy
day
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Edith
seemed
to
repeat

,
and
went
on
.
"
<EOS>
Though
the

not

,
for
I
thought
little

until

,

.
<EOS>
And

---

;
I
am
led
on
as
it
is
best
I

,
to
say

for
the
first

.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
,
without

,
felt
almost

to

,
but
kept
her

riveted
on
the
beautiful
face
so

upon

.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
seek
to
find
in
me
,
"
said

,

,
"
what
is
not
here
.
<EOS>
Never

,
Florence
,

not

.
<EOS>
Little

will

,

when
you
will

,

.
<EOS>
Then
,

as
lenient

you
can
,
and
do
not
turn
to
bitterness
the
only

I
shall
have
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
tears
that
were

fixed
on
Florence
,
showed
that
the
composed
face
was
but
as

;
but
she
preserved

,
and

:
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen

,

know

.
<EOS>
But

---

,

---

,
Florence
,

Never

,

of

,
more
.
<EOS>
There
should
be
,
so
far
,
as
division
,
and
a

between

two
,
like
the
grave
itself
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
sat
for
some

;
Florence
scarcely
venturing
to
breathe
meanwhile
,
as
dim
and
imperfect
shadows
of
the
truth
,
and
all
its
daily

,
chased
each
other
through
her
terrified
,
yet

.
<EOS>
Almost

's

began
to
subside
from
its

that

more

,
which
it
usually

.
<EOS>
She
shaded

,
after
this

,
with

;
and
when

,
and
with

,
went

,
and
without

.
  
<EOS>
But
when
Florence
was
in
bed
,
and
the
room
was
dark
except
for
the
glow

the
fire
,
Edith
returned
,
and
saying
that
she
could
not
sleep
,
and
that
her
dressing
-
room
was
lonely
,
drew
a
chair
upon
the
hearth
,
and
watched
the
embers
as
they
died
away
.
<EOS>
Florence
watched
them
too
from
her
bed
,
until
they
,
and
the
noble
figure
before

,
crowned
with

,

in

reflecting
back

,
became
confused
and

,
and
finally
were
lost
in

.
  
<EOS>
In
her
sleep
,
however
,
Florence
could
not
lose
an
undefined
impression
of
what
had
so
recently
passed
.
<EOS>
It
formed
the
subject
of
her
dreams
,
and
haunted
her
;
now
in
one
shape
,
now
in
another
;
but
always
oppressively
;
and
with
a
sense
of
fear
.
<EOS>
She
dreamed
of
seeking
her
father
in
wildernesses
,
of
following
his
track
up
fearful
heights
,
and
down
into
deep
mines
and
caverns
;
of
being
charged
with
something
that
would
release
him
from
extraordinary
suffering
---
she
knew
not
what
,
or
why
---
yet
never
being
able
to
attain
the
goal
and
set
him
free
.
<EOS>
Then
she
saw
him
dead
,
upon
that
very
bed
,
and
in
that
very
room
,
and
knew
that
he
had
never
loved
her
to
the
last
,
and
fell
upon
his
cold
breast
,
passionately

.
<EOS>
Then
a
prospect
opened
,
and
a
river

,
and
a

she
knew
,
cried
,
"
It
is
running
on
,
Floy
!
<EOS>
It
has
never
stopped
!
<EOS>
You
are
moving
with
it
!
"
<EOS>
And
she
saw

at
a
distance

,
while
a
figure
such
as
Walter
's
used
to
be
,

,

.
<EOS>
In

,
Edith
came
and
went
,
sometimes

,
sometimes

,
until

were
along
upon

,
and
Edith

,

and
saw
---
<EOS>
what
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
another
Edith
lying
at

bottom
.
  
<EOS>
In

this

,

,
she

.
<EOS>
A

,
<EOS>
"
Florence
,
dear
Florence
,

nothing

!
"
and

new

,
who

.
<EOS>
In

,
Florence
sat

;
but

,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
So
passed
the
night
on
which
the
happy
pair
came
home
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
36
.
<EOS>
Housewarming
 
MANY
succeeding
days
passed
in
like
manner
;
except
that
there
were
numerous
visits
received
and
paid
,
and
that
Mrs
Skewton
held
little
levees
in
her
own
apartments
,
at
which
Major
Bagstock
was
a
frequent
attendant
,
and
that
Florence
encountered
no
second
look
from
her
father
,
although
she
saw
him
every
day
.
<EOS>
Nor
had
she
much
communication
in
words
with
her
new
mama
,
who
was
imperious
and
proud
to
all
the
house
but
her
<EOS>
---
Florence
could
not
but
observe
that
---
and
who
,
although
she
always
sent
for
her
or
went

her
when
she
came
home
from
visiting
,
and
would
always

into
her
room
at

,
before
retiring
to
rest
,
however
late
the
hour
,
and
never
lost
an
opportunity
of
being
with
her
,
was
often
her
silent
and
thoughtful
companion
for
a
long

together
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
,
who
had
hoped
for
so
much
from
this

,
could
not
help
sometimes
comparing
the
bright
house
with
the
faded
dreary
place
out
of
which
it
had

,
and

when
,

,

would

home
;
for
that

was
no

,
for
any

,
though
everything

on

,
she
had
always
a
secret

.
<EOS>
Many
an

by

,
and
many

,

bestowed
upon
the
assurance
her
new

had
given

so

,
that

no

to

to
win

's

.
<EOS>
And
soon
Florence
began
to
think
---
resolved
to
think
would
be
the
truer
phrase
<EOS>
---
that
as
no

,
how

of
being
subdued

changed
her
father
's

to
her
was
,
so
she
had
given
her
this
warning
,
and
forbidden

subject
in
very

.
<EOS>
Unselfish
here
,
as

her
every

and

,
Florence
preferred
to
bear
the
pain
of
this
new

,
rather

encourage
any

of
the
truth
as

her
father
;
tender
of
him
,
even

.
<EOS>
As

his
home
,
she
hoped

would
become
a
better
one
,
when
its
state
of
novelty
and
transition
should
be
over
;
and
for
herself
,
thought
little
and
lamented
less
.
  
<EOS>
If
none
of
the
new
family
were
particularly
at
home
in
private
,
it
was
resolved
that
Mrs
Dombey
at
least
should
be
at
home
in

,

delay
.
<EOS>
A

of

in

,

in

,

,

;

's

,

<EOS>

and

's

.
  
<EOS>
Accordingly
,

;

,
acting

,

,

,

Cousin
Feenix
,
not

Baden
-

,

;

,
who
had
,

,

light
of
her
fair
daughter
,

,

.
<EOS>
Florence

---

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

commenced

Mr
Dombey
,

,

;

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

Dombey
,

;

's

,

not

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

a
Bank
Director
,

be
able

---
human
Nature

,

,

,

"

,

<EOS>
Ladies

.

Carrying

,

,

,

.

It

:
and

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Now
Mrs
Dombey
appeared
,
beautiful

,
and
as

all
as

.
<EOS>
With

was
Florence
.
<EOS>
When

entered

,

of
the

of
the
return
again

Dombey
's

.
<EOS>
But

:
for
Florence
did
not
venture
to
raise
her
eyes
to
his
,
and
Edith
's
indifference
was
too
supreme
to
take
the
least
heed
of
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
arrivals
quickly
became
numerous
.
<EOS>
More
directors
,
chairmen
of
public
companies
,
elderly
ladies
carrying
burdens
on
their
heads
for
full
dress
,
Cousin
Feenix
,
Major
Bagstock
,
friends
of
Mrs
Skewton
,
with
the
same
bright
bloom
on
their
complexion
,
and
very
precious
necklaces
on
very
withered
necks
.
<EOS>
Among
these
,
a
young
lady
of
sixty
-
five
,
remarkably
coolly
dressed
as
to
her
back
and
shoulders
,
who
spoke
with
an
engaging
lisp
,
and
whose
eyelids
would
n't
keep
up
well
,
without
a
great
deal
of
trouble
on
her
part
,
and
whose
manners
had
that
indefinable
charm
which
so
frequently
attaches
to
the
giddiness
of
youth
.
<EOS>
As
the
greater
part
of
Mr
Dombey
's
list
were
disposed
to
be
taciturn
,
and
the
greater
part
of
Mrs
Dombey
's
list
were
disposed
to
be
talkative
,
and
there
was
no
sympathy
between
them
,
Mrs
Dombey
's
list
,
by
magnetic
agreement
,
entered
into
a
bond
of
union
against
Mr
Dombey
's
list
,
who
,
wandering
about
the
rooms
in
a
desolate
manner
,
or
seeking
refuge
in
corners
,
entangled
themselves
with
company
coming
in
,
and
became
barricaded
behind
sofas
,
and
had
doors
opened
smartly
from
without
against
their
heads
,
and
under
went
every
sort
of
discomfiture
.
  
<EOS>
When
dinner
was
announced
,
Mr
Dombey
took
down
an
old
lady
like
a
crimson
velvet
pincushion
stuffed
with
bank
notes
,
who
might
have
been
the
identical
old
lady
of
Threadneedle
Street
,
she
was
so
rich
,
and
looked
so
unaccommodating
;
Cousin
Feenix
took
down
Mrs
Dombey
;
Major
Bagstock
took
down
Mrs
Skewton
;
the
young
thing
with
the
shoulders
was
bestowed
,
as
an
extinguisher
,
upon
the
East
India
Director
;
and
the
remaining
ladies
were
left
on
view
in
the
drawing
-
room
by
remaining
gentlemen
,
until
a
forlorn
hope
volunteered
to
conduct
them
downstairs
,
and
those
brave
spirits
with
their
captives
blocked
up
the
dining
-
room
door
,
shutting
out
seven
mild
men
in
the
stony
-
hearted
hall
.
<EOS>
When
all
the
rest
were
got
in
and
were
seated
,
one
of
these
mild
men
still
appeared
,
in
smiling

,
totally
destitute
and
unprovided
for
,
and
escorted
by
the
butler
,
made
the
complete
circuit
of
the
table
twice
before
his
chair
could
be
found
,
which
it
finally
was
,
on
Mrs
Dombey
's
left
hand
;
after
which
the
mild
man
never
held
up
his
head
again
.
  
<EOS>
Now
,
the
spacious
dining
-
room
,
with
the
company
seated
round
the
glittering
table
,
busy
with
their
glittering
spoons
,
and

and

,
and
plates
,
might
have
been
taken
for
a
grown

of
Tom
Tiddler
's

,
where
children
pick
up
gold

.
<EOS>
MrDombey
,
as
Tiddler
,
looked
his
character
to
admiration
;
and
the
long

of
precious

,

from
Mrs
Dombey
,
whereon
frosted
Cupids
offered
scentless

to
each

them
,
<EOS>
was
allegorical
to
see
.
  
<EOS>
Cousin
Feenix
was
in
great
force
,
and
looked
astonishingly
young
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
sometimes
thoughtless
in
his
good
humour
---
his
memory
occasionally
wandering
like
his
legs
---
and
on
this
occasion
caused
the
company
to
shudder
.
<EOS>
It
happened
thus
.
<EOS>
The
young
lady
with
the
back
,
who
regarded
Cousin
Feenix
with

of

,
had

the
East
India
Director
into
leading
her
to
the
Chair
next

;
in
return
for
which
good

,

the
Director
,
who
,

a

female
with
a
fan
,
yielded
to
a
depression
of
spirits
and
withdrew
into

.
<EOS>
Cousin
Feenix
and
the
young
lady
were
very
lively
and
humorous
,
and
the
young
lady
laughed
so
much
at
something

Feenix
related
to
her
,
that
Major
Bagstock
begged
leave
to
inquire
on

of
Mrs
Skewton
<EOS>
(
they
were
sitting
opposite
,
a

lower
down
)
,
whether
that
might
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
upon
my
life
,
"
said

Feenix
,
"
there
's
nothing
in

;
it
really

;

Jack

.
<EOS>
I
dare

my
friend
Dombey
;
"
for

;
"
may

Jack
Adams
,
Jack
Adams
,
not
Joe
;

.
<EOS>
Jack
---
little
Jack
---
man
with

,

---
man

.
<EOS>
We

W

Adams
,

Pan
for

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

,

was
as

,

.
<EOS>

"
always

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,

at

down

.
<EOS>
"
That

Jack
.
<EOS>
Joe
wore
---
"
  
"
Tops
!
"
<EOS>
cried

,
rising

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of

"

,
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
With

wine
.
  
<EOS>
"
Devilish

fellow
,
Jack
!
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Excellent
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
One
of

I

.
"
  
"
No

have

story
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
know
,
"
replied
the
bold

man
,
"
when
I
have
heard
your
Ludship
tell

.
<EOS>
"

,
he

,
as
knowing
it
by
heart
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
In

,

"

,
"
and

.
<EOS>
But

's

.
<EOS>
The

,
that
Jack

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shropshire
,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Was

?
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
In

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
my
friend

in
Anyshire
,
"
with

,
"

.
<EOS>
Just

,

.
<EOS>
---
Goes
---
Jack
goes
.
<EOS>
Now
,

,

,

did

,

,

.
<EOS>
When
Jack

,

,

,

"
"
<EOS>
Well

,

"
<EOS>
"
Illmatched
,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
It
's

.
<EOS>
She

,

oath
<EOS>
he

!
"
<EOS>
"
  
In

,

,

.
<EOS>
Not

,
appeared

.
<EOS>
A

ensued
;
and
the

,

had

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
face
was
a

one
,
and
being
cast

of

that

,
showed

other

story
,

,

"
Very
good
.
<EOS>
"
There
was

Edith
towards
Florence
,
but
otherwise

remained
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Through
the
various

of
rich

and

,
continual

,
dainties

earth
,
air

,

-

,

in
Mr

's

---
ice
---
the

slowly

:
the
later

being
achieved
to
the

of
incessant

,

visitors
,
whose

was
limited
to
the

thereof
.
<EOS>
When
Mrs
Dombey
rose
,
it
was
a
sight
to

her

,
with

and

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
was
a
grave
sight
,
being
the
decanters
,
in
a
state
of

;
and
the
East
India
Director
was
a
forlorn

near

the

,

;

was

,

six

(
the
ambitious

)
;
and

Bank
Director
was

,

a
pinery
,

,
for

;
and
Cousin
Feenix
was
a

,
as

long

and

.
<EOS>
But
all

sights
were
of

,

up
by

,

.
  
<EOS>
There

state
-
rooms
upstairs
,
increasing

;
but
still
Mr
Dombey
's

of
visitors
appeared

of

with
Mrs
Dombey
's
list
,
and
no

.
<EOS>
The

rule

Mr
Carker
,
who
now

,

,

---

---
appeared

,
and
not

.
  
<EOS>
Florence
had
a
dread
of
him
,
which
made
his
presence
in
the
room
a
nightmare
to

.
<EOS>
She
could
not
avoid
the
recollection
of
it
,
for
her
eyes
were
drawn
towards
him
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
,
by
an
attraction
of
dislike
and
