that
she
could
not
resist
.
<EOS>
Yet
her
thoughts
were
busy
with
other
things
;
for
as

sat
apart
---
not

or

,

---
she
felt
how
little
part
her
father
had
in
what
was
going
on
,
and
saw
,
with

,

ill

he
seemed
to
be
,

how
little

was
as

about
near

,
for

whom
he
wished
to
distinguish
with
particular
attention
,
and
took

up
to

to

wife
,
who
received

with

,
but

no

or

to
please
,
and
never
,
after

bare

of

,
in

of

,
or

of

,
opened
her

.
<EOS>
It
was
not
the
less
perplexing
or
painful
to
Florence
,
that
she
who
acted
thus
,
treated
her
so

and
with
such

,
that

almost

an
ungrateful
return
on
her

even
to

what
was
passing

.
  
<EOS>
Happy
Florence
would
have
been
,
might

to

father
company
,
by
so
much

look
:
and
happy
Florence
was
,
in

the
main

of

.
<EOS>
But
afraid
of
seeming
to
know

,

should

;
and

,

Edith
<EOS>
;

.
<EOS>
Anxious
and
unhappy
for
them
both
<EOS>
,
the
thought
stole
on
her
through
the
crowd
,
that
it
might
have
been
better
for
them
if
this
noise
of
tongues
and

had
never
come
there
,
---

old

,

had

in

,
but

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
had
some

too
,
but
they
were
not
so
quietly

in

.
<EOS>
This
good
matron
had
been
outraged
in
the
first

by
not

an

.
<EOS>
That
blow
partially

,
she

before

Dombey
at

,

,

heap

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
"

,
"
of
no

!
<EOS>
Who
takes

?
<EOS>
No

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

,

"

Mrs
Chick

,
and
could

.
  
<EOS>
"
Does

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Paul

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
Mr

.
  
<EOS>
"
Unless

,

,
"

"
do

.
<EOS>
How

is
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
But

's

)

,

,

.
<EOS>
All

;

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
Hardly

,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

with

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
The

,
that

.
<EOS>
Nay

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
At

,

,

;

,

,

,

:

.
<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

What

<EOS>
None
.
<EOS>
Therefore

---

,

Nature
,

,

---

"
  
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
That

<EOS>
"

Carker

"
  
<EOS>
Mr

the
Bride
,
whose

;

raised

,

.
  
<EOS>
If
his

wife
had

,
or

,
or

,

,

(
for

)
,
Mr

would

.
<EOS>
But
the

,

,

,

,

,

,

---
<EOS>
the
cold

with
which
her

seemed

,
and

by
---
these
<EOS>
,

no

against
;
and

,
with

concentrated
on

.
  
<EOS>
Was
he
coward
enough
to
watch
her
,
an

,
on
the
old
well

,
where
he
had

in

,

Paul
?
<EOS>
Or

in
the
dark

,
when

,

,

,

the

so

,
which
he

?
  
<EOS>
But
it
could
never
alter
as
his
own
did
.
<EOS>
It
never
,
in

,

;
and
often

;
and
which
deepened

now

.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
37
.
<EOS>
More
Warnings
than
One
 
FLORENCE
,
Edith
,
and
Mrs
Skewton
were
together
next
day
,
and
the
carriage
was
waiting
at
the
door
to
take
them
out
.
<EOS>
For
Cleopatra
had
her
galley
again
now
,
and
Withers
,
no
longer
the
wan
,
stood
upright
in
a
pigeon
-
breasted
jacket
and
military
trousers
,
behind
her
wheel
-
less
chair
at
dinner
-
time
,
and
butted
no
more
.
<EOS>
The
hair
of
Withers
was
radiant
with
pomatum
,
in
these
days
of
down
,
and
he
wore
kid
gloves
and
smelt
of
the
water
of
Cologne
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
assembled
in
Cleopatra
's
room
.
<EOS>
The
Serpent
of
old
Nile
(
not
to
mention
her
disrespectfully
)
was
reposing
on
her
sofa
,
sipping
her
morning
chocolate
at
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
,
and
Flowers
the
Maid
was
fastening
on
her
youthful
cuffs
and
frills
,
and
performing
a
kind
of
private
coronation
ceremony
on
her
,
with
a
peach
-
coloured
velvet
bonnet
;
the
artificial
roses
in
which
nodded
to
uncommon
advantage
,
as
the
palsy
trifled
with
them
,
like
a
breeze
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
am
a
little
nervous
this
morning
,
Flowers
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
.
<EOS>
"
My
hand
quite
shakes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
the
life
of
the
party
last
night
,
<EOS>
Ma'am
,
you
know
,
"
returned
Flowers
,
"
and
you
suffer
for
it
,
to
-
day
,
you
see
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
,
who
had
beckoned
Florence
to
the
window
,
and
was
looking
out
,
with
her
back
turned
on
the
toilet
of
her
esteemed
mother
,
suddenly
withdrew
from
it
,
as
if
it
had
lightened
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
darling
child
,
"
cried
Cleopatra
,
languidly
,
"
you
are
not
nervous
?
<EOS>
Do
n't
tell
me
,
my
dear
Edith
,
that
you
,
so
enviably
self
-
possessed
,
are
beginning
to
be
a
martyr
too
,
like
your
unfortunately
constituted
mother
!
<EOS>
Withers
,
some
one
at
the
door
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Card
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
Withers
,
taking
it
towards
Mrs
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
out
,
"
she
said
without
looking
at
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
love
,
"
drawled
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
how
very
odd
to
send
that
message
without
seeing
the
name
!
<EOS>
Bring
it
here
,
Withers
.
<EOS>
Dear
me
,
my
love
;
Mr
Carker
,
too
!
<EOS>
That
very
sensible
person
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
out
,
"
repeated
Edith
,
in
so
imperious
a
tone
that
Withers
,
going
to
the
door
,
imperiously
informed
the
servant
who
was
waiting
,
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Dombey
is
going
out
.
<EOS>
Get
along
with
you
,
"
and
shut
it
on
him
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
servant
came
back
after
a
short
absence
,
and
whispered
to
Withers
again
,
who
once
more
,
and
not
very
willingly
,
presented
himself
before
Mrs
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
Ma'am
,
Mr
Carker
sends
his
respectful
compliments
,
and
begs
you
would
spare
him
one
minute
,
if
you
could
---
for
business
,
Ma'am
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Really
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
in
her
mildest
manner
;
for
her
daughter
's
face
was
threatening
;
"
if
you
would
allow
me
to
offer
a
word
,
I
should
recommend
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Show
him
this
way
,
"
said
Edith
.
<EOS>
As
Withers
disappeared
to
execute
the
command
,
she
added
,
frowning
on
her
mother
,
"
As
he
comes
at
your
recommendation
,
let
him
come
to
your
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
---
shall
I
go
away
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Florence
,
hurriedly
.
  
<EOS>
Edith
nodded
<EOS>
yes
,
but
on
her
way
to
the
door
Florence
met
the
visitor
coming
in
.
<EOS>
With
the
same
disagreeable
mixture
of
familiarity
and
forbearance
with
which
he
had
first
addressed
her
,
he
addressed
her
now
in
his
softest
manner
---
hoped
she
was
quite
well
---
needed
not
to
ask
,
with
such
looks
to
anticipate
the
answer
---
had
scarcely
had
the
honour
to
know
her
,
last
night
,
she
was
so
greatly
changed
---
and
held
the
door
open
for
her
to
pass
out
;
with
a
secret
sense
of
power
in
her
shrinking
from
him
,
that
all
the
deference
and
politeness
of
his
manner
could
not
quite
conceal
.
  
<EOS>
He
then
bowed
himself
for
a
moment
over
Mrs
Skewton
's
condescending
hand
,
and
lastly
bowed
to
Edith
.
<EOS>
Coldly
returning
his
salute
without
looking
at
him
,
and
neither
seating
herself
nor
inviting
him
to
be
seated
,
she
waited
for
him
to
speak
.
  
<EOS>
Entrenched
in
her
pride
and
power
,
and
with
all
the
obduracy
of
her
spirit
summoned
about
her
,
still
her
old
conviction
that
she
and
her
mother
had
been
known
by
this
man
in
their
worst
colours
,
from
their
first
acquaintance
;
that
every
degradation
she
had
suffered
in
her
own
eyes
was
plain
to
him
as
to
herself
;
that
he
read
her
life
as
though
it
were
a
vile
book
,
and
fluttered
the
leaves
before
her
in
slight
looks
and
tones
of
voice
which
no
one
else
could
detect
;
weakened
and
undermined
her
.
<EOS>
Proudly
as
she
opposed
herself
to
him
,
with
her
commanding
face
exacting
his
humility
,
her
disdainful
lip
repulsing
him
,
her
bosom
angry
at
his
intrusion
,
and
the
dark
lashes
of
her
eyes
sullenly
veiling
their
light
,
that
no
ray
of
it
might
shine
upon
him
---
and
submissively
as
he
stood
before
her
,
with
an
entreating
injured
manner
,
but
with
complete
submission
to
her
will
---
she
knew
,
in
her
own
soul
,
that
the
cases
were
reversed
,
and
that
the
triumph
and
superiority
were
his
,
and
that
he
knew
it
full
well
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
presumed
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
"
to
solicit
an
interview
,
and
I
have
ventured
to
describe
it
as
being
one
of
business
,
because
---
"
  
"
Perhaps
you
are
charged
by
Mr
Dombey
with
some
message
of
reproof
,
"
said
Edith
.
<EOS>
"
You
possess
Mr
Dombey
's
confidence
in
such
an
unusual
degree
,
Sir
,
that
you
would
scarcely
surprise
me
if
that
were
your
business
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
message
to
the
lady
who
sheds
a
lustre
upon
his
name
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
entreat
that
lady
,
on
my
own
behalf
,
to
be
just
to
a
very
humble
claimant
for
justice
at
her
hands
---
a
mere
dependant
of
Mr
Dombey
's
---
which
is
a
position
of
humility
;
and
to
reflect
upon
my
perfect
helplessness
last
night
,
and
the
impossibility
of
my
avoiding
the
share
that
was
forced
upon
me
in
a
very
painful
occasion
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
Edith
,
"
hinted
Cleopatra
in
a
low
voice
,
as
she
held
her
eye
-
glass
aside
,
"
<EOS>
really
very
charming
of
Mr
What'shis
-
name
.
<EOS>
And
full
of
heart
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
I
do
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
appealing
to
Mrs
Skewton
with
a
look
of
grateful
deference
,
---
<EOS>
"
I
do
venture
to
call
it
a
painful
occasion
,
though
merely
because
it
was
so
to
me
,
who
had
the
misfortune
to
be
present
.
<EOS>
So
light
a
difference
,
as
between
the
principals
---
between
those
who
love
each
other
with
disinterested
devotion
,
and
would
make
any
sacrifice
of
self
,
in
such
a
cause
---
is
nothing
.
<EOS>
As
Mrs
Skewton
herself
expressed
,
with
so
much
truth
and
feeling
last
night
,
it
is
nothing
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
could
not
look
at
him
,
but
she
said
after
a
few
moments
,
  
"
And
<EOS>
your
business
,
Sir
---
"
  
"
Edith
,
my
pet
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
all
this
time
Mr
Carker
is
standing
!
<EOS>
My
dear
Mr
Carker
,
take
a
seat
,
I
beg
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
offered
no
reply
to
the
mother
,
but
fixed
his
eyes
on
the
proud
daughter
,
as
though
he
would
only
be
bidden
by
her
,
and
was
resolved
to
be
bidden
by
her
.
<EOS>
Edith
,
in
spite
of
herself
,
sat
down
,
and
slightly
motioned
with
her
hand
to
him
to
be
seated
too
.
<EOS>
No
action
could
be
colder
,
haughtier
,
more
insolent
in
its
air
of
supremacy
and
disrespect
,
but
she
had
struggled
against
even
that
concession
ineffectually
,
and
it
was
wrested
from
her
.
<EOS>
That
was
enough
!
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
sat
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
be
allowed
,
Madam
,
"
said
Carker
,
turning
his
white
teeth
on
Mrs
Skewton
like
a
light
---
<EOS>
"
a
lady
of
your
excellent
sense
and
quick
feeling
will
give
me
credit
,
for
good
reason
,
I
am
sure
---
to
address
what
I
have
to
say
,
to
Mrs
Dombey
,
and
to
leave
her
to
impart
it
to
you
who
are
her
best
and
dearest
friend
---
next
to
Mr
Dombey
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
would
have
retired
,
but
Edith
stopped
her
.
<EOS>
Edith
would
have
stopped
him
too
,
and
indignantly
ordered
him
to
speak
openly
or
not
at
all
,
but
that
he
said
,
in
a
low
voice
---
"
Miss
Florence
---
the
young
lady
who
has
just
left
the
room
---
"
  
Edith
suffered
him
to
proceed
.
<EOS>
She
looked
at
him
now
.
<EOS>
As
he
bent
forward
,
to
be
nearer
,
with
the
utmost
show
of
delicacy
and
respect
,
and
with
his
teeth
persuasively
arrayed
,
in
a
selfdepreciating
smile
,
she
felt
as
if
she
could
have
struck
him
dead
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Florence
's
position
<EOS>
,
"
he
began
,
"
has
been
an
unfortunate
one
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
difficulty
in
alluding
to
it
to
you
,
whose
attachment
to
her
father
is
naturally
watchful
and
jealous
of
every
word
that
applies
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
Always
distinct
and
soft
in
speech
,
no
language
could
describe
the
extent
of
his
distinctness
and
softness
,
when
he
said
these
words
,
or
came
to
any
others
of
a
similar
import
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
as
one
who
is
devoted
to
Mr
Dombey
in
his
different
way
,
and
whose
life
is
passed
in
admiration
of
Mr
Dombey
's
character
,
may
I
say
,
without

to
your
tenderness
as

,
that
Miss
Florence
has
unhappily
been
neglected
---
by
her
father
?
<EOS>
May
I
say
by
her
father
?
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
replied
,
"
I
know
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
it
!
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
with
a
great
appearance
of
relief
.
<EOS>
"
It
removes
a
mountain
from
my
breast
.
<EOS>
May
I
hope
you
know
how
the
neglect
originated
;
in
what
an
amiable
phase
of
Mr
Dombey
's
pride
---
character
I
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
pass
that
by
,
Sir
,
"
she
returned
,
"
and
come
the
sooner
to
the
end
of
what
you

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Indeed
,
I
am
sensible
,
Madam
,
"
replied
Carker
,
---
"
trust
me
,
I
am
deeply
sensible
,
that
Mr
Dombey
can
require
no
justification
in
anything
to
you
.
<EOS>
But
,
kindly
judge
of
my
breast
by
your
own
,
and
you
will
forgive
my
interest
in
him
,
if
in
its
excess
,
it
goes
at
all
astray
.
"
  
<EOS>
What
a
stab
to
her
proud
heart
,
to
sit
there
,
face
to
face
with
him
,
and
have
him
tendering
her
false
oath
at
the
altar
again
and
again
for
her
acceptance
,
and
pressing
it
upon
her
like
the
dregs
of
a
sickening
cup
<EOS>
she
could
not
own
her
loathing
of
,
or
turn
away
from
!
<EOS>
How
shame
,
remorse
,
and
passion
raged
within
her
,
when
,
upright
and
majestic
in
her
beauty
before
him
,
she
knew
that
in
her
spirit
she
was
down
at
his
feet
!
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Florence
,
"
said
Carker
,
"
left
to
the
care
---
if
one
may
call
it
care
---
of
servants
and
mercenary
people
,
in
every
way
her
inferiors
,
necessarily
wanted
some
guide
and
compass
in
her
younger
days
,
and
,
naturally
,
for
want
of
them
,
has
been
indiscreet
,
and
has
in
some
degree
forgotten
her
station
.
<EOS>
There
was
some
folly
about
one
Walter
,
a
common
lad
,
who
is
fortunately
dead
now
:
and
some
very
undesirable
association
,
I
regret
to
say
,
with
certain
coasting
sailors
,
of
anything
but
good
repute
,
and
a
runaway
old
bankrupt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
the
circumstances
,
Sir
,
"
said
Edith
,
flashing
her
disdainful
glance
upon
him
,
"
<EOS>
and
I
know
that
you
pervert
them
.
<EOS>
You
may
not
know
it
,
I
hope
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
"
I
believe
that
nobody
knows
them
so
well
as
I.
Your
generous
and
ardent
nature
,
Madam
---
the
same
nature
which
is
so
nobly
imperative
in
vindication
of
your
beloved
and
honoured
husband
,
and
which
has
blessed
him
as
even
his
merits
deserve
<EOS>
---
I
must
respect
,
defer
to
,
bow
before
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
regards
the
circumstances
,
which
is
indeed
the
business
I
presumed
to
solicit
your
attention
to
,
I
can
have
no
doubt
,
since
,
in
the
execution
of
my
trust
as
Mr
Dombey
's

---
I
presume
to
say
---
friend
,
I
have
fully
ascertained
them
.
<EOS>
In
my
execution
of
that
trust
;
in
my
deep
concern
,
which
you
can
so
well
understand
,
for
everything

to
him
,
intensified
,
if
you

(
for

)
,
by

lower

of

to
prove

,
and

the
more

;
I
have
long
pursued
these
circumstances
by
myself
and
trustworthy

,
and
have
innumerable
and
most
minute

.
"
  
<EOS>
She
raised
her

no
higher
than
his
mouth
,
but
she
saw
the
means
of
mischief
vaunted
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon

,
Madam
<EOS>
,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
I

Miss

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
was
there
in
her
he
had
not
observed
,
and
did
not
know
?
<EOS>
Humbled

yet
maddened
by
the

,
in
every

of
it
<EOS>
,
however
faint
,

upon

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
This

,
Madam
---
so

an
evidence

Mr
Dombey

---

pause

make

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It
so
far

,
if
I

,
in

,
that
on
the

of
the
least

to
that
effect
from
you
,
I
would
suppress

.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
raised
her

quickly
,
and
starting
back
,
bent
her
dark
glance
upon
him
.
<EOS>
He
met
it
with
his
blandest
and
most
deferential

,
and
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
say
that
as
I
describe
them
,
they
are
perverted
.
<EOS>
I
fear
not
---
I
fear
not
:
but
let
us
assume
that
they
are
.
<EOS>
The

I
have
for
some

on

,

:
that
the
mere

of
such
association
often

,
on

Miss
Florence
,
however

,

Mr
Dombey
,
already

,
and
would

<EOS>
(
I

)

.
<EOS>
Madam
,

,
and
remember

Mr
Dombey
,
and
my

of
him
,
and
my

,
almost

,
when

,

is
a

,

that
noble

,
and

;

;
and
which
grows

from

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
bent
her

upon
him
still
;
but
,
look
as
steadfast
as
she
would
,
her
haughty
nostrils
dilated
,
and
her

somewhat

,
and
her
lip
would
slightly
curl
,
as
he
described
that
in
his

to

must

.
<EOS>
He
saw
it
;
and
though
his

not

,
she
knew

saw

.
  
<EOS>
"
Even
so
slight

as
last
night
's
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
,
"

I
might

,
would
serve
to

meaning
,
better
than

.
<EOS>
Dombey
and
Son
know
neither

,
nor

,
nor
season
,
but
bear

all
down
.
<EOS>
But
I
rejoice

,
for

to
approach
Mrs
Dombey
with
this

to
-
day
,
even

.
<EOS>
Madam
,

,
I
was

Mr
Dombey

.
<EOS>
There
I
saw
you
.
<EOS>
There
I
could
not

knowing
what
relation
you
would
shortly

towards
him
---
to
his

.
<EOS>
There
I
resolved
to
await

of
your

at

,
and
to
do

I

.
<EOS>
I
have
,
at
heart
,
no

Mr
Dombey
,
<EOS>
if

;
for

as

.
<EOS>
I
can

,

,
by
confidence
,
on

theme
,

you

.
<EOS>
For

I

.
<EOS>
May

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
He
long
remembered
the

she

---
who
could

,
and

?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
the
struggle
that

within

.
<EOS>
At

:
  
"
I

,
Sir
.
<EOS>
You

to

,
and
that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
bowed
low
,
and
rose
.
<EOS>
She
rose
too
,
and
he
took
leave
with
all
humility
.
<EOS>
But
Withers
,
meeting
him
on
the
stairs
,
stood
amazed
at
the
beauty
of
his
teeth
,
and
at
his
brilliant
smile
;
and
as
he
rode
away
upon
his
white
-
legged
horse
,
the
people
took
him
for
a
dentist
,
<EOS>
such
was
the
dazzling
show
he
made
.
<EOS>
The
people
took
her
,
when
she
rode
out
in
her
carriage
presently
,
for
a
great
lady
,
as
happy
as
she
was
rich
and
fine
.
<EOS>
But
they
had
not
seen
her
,
just
before
,
in
her
own
room
with
no
one
by
;
and
they
had
not
heard
her
utterance
of
the
three
words
,
"
Oh
Florence
,
Florence
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
,
reposing
on
her
sofa
,
and
sipping
her
chocolate
,
had
heard
nothing
but
the
low
word
business
,
for
which
she
had
a
mortal
aversion
,
insomuch
that
she
had
long
banished
it
from
her

,
and
had
gone
nigh
,
in
a
charming

and
with
an

of
heart
,
to
say
nothing
of
soul
,
to
ruin
divers
milliners
and
others
in

.
<EOS>
Therefore
Mrs
Skewton
asked
no
questions
,
and
showed
no
curiosity
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
peach
-
velvet
bonnet
gave
her
sufficient
occupation
out
of
doors
;
for
being
perched
on
the
back

head
,
and
the

being
rather

,
it
was
frantic
to
escape
from
Mrs

's

,
and
would

into
no

.
<EOS>
When

was
closed
,

,

;
and
altogether
Mrs
Skewton
had
enough
to
do
,
and

.
  
<EOS>
She
got

no

;
for
when

Dombey
,
in
her
dressing
-

,

,

,

,

(

)
,
<EOS>
Flowers

,

"
If

,

ca
n't

with
missis
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Ma'am
,
"

,
"
I
hardly
know
.
<EOS>
She
's
making
faces
!
"
  
<EOS>
Edith

with
her
to

mother
's

.
<EOS>
Cleopatra
was
arrayed
in
full

,
with
the

,
short

,

,

,

,

;
but
Paralysis
was
not
to

,
had
known
her
for
the
object
of

,
and
had
struck
her
at

,
where
she
lay
like

.
  
<EOS>
They
took
her
to
pieces
in
very

,
and
put
the
little
of
her
that
was
real
on
a

.
<EOS>
Doctors
were
sent
for
,
and
soon
came
.
<EOS>
Powerful
remedies
were
resorted
to
;
opinions
given
that
she
would
rally
from
this

,
but
would
not

another
;
and
there
she
lay

,
and

for

;
sometimes

in

,

:
sometimes

either

.
  
<EOS>
At

began
to
recover

,
and
in
some
degree
the
power
of

,
though

.
<EOS>
One

the
use
of
her
right
hand
returned
;
and
showing
it
to
her
maid
who
was
in

on
her
,
and
appearing
very
uneasy
in
her
mind
,
she
made

for

and
some

.
<EOS>
This
the
maid
immediately
provided
,
thinking
she
was
going
to
make
a
will
,
or

some
last

;
and
Mrs
Dombey
being
from
home
,
the
maid
awaited
the
result
with
solemn

.
  
<EOS>
After

and

,
and

in
of

,
which

of
their

,

produced
this

:
  
"
Rose
-
coloured
curtains
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
maid
being
perfectly
transfixed
,
and
with
tolerable
reason
,
Cleopatra
amended
the
manuscript
by
adding
two

more
,
when

:
  
"
Rose
-
coloured
curtains
for
doctors
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
maid
now
perceived
remotely
that
she
wished
these
articles
to
be
provided
for
the
better
presentation
of
her
complexion
to
the

;
and
as
those
in
the
house
who
knew
her
best
,
had
no

of
the

of
this
opinion
,
which
she
was
soon

to
establish
for

,

-

were
added
to

,

she

from

.
<EOS>
She
was
soon
able
to
sit
up
,
in

and

night

,
and
to
have

little
artificial

dropped
into
the

of
her

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
tremendous
sight
to
see
this
old
woman
in
her
finery
leering
and
mincing
at
Death
,
and
playing
off
her
youthful
tricks
upon
him
as
if
he
had
been
the
Major
;
but
an
alteration
in
her
mind
that
ensued
on
the
paralytic
stroke
was
fraught
with
as
much
matter
for
reflection
,
and
was
quite
as
ghastly
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
the
weakening
of
her
intellect
made
her
more
cunning
and
false
than
before
,
or
whether
it
confused
her
between
what
she
had
assumed
to
be
and
what
she
really
had
been
,
or
whether
it
had
awakened
any
glimmering
of

,
which
could
neither
struggle
into

nor

,
or
whether
,
in
the

her

,
a

effects
had

,
which
is
perhaps

more
likely

,
the
result
was
this
:
---
That
she
became
hugely
exacting
in
respect
of
Edith
's
affection
and
gratitude
and
attention
to
her
;
highly

herself
as
a
most

parent
;
and
very
jealous
of
having
any
rival
in
Edith
's
regard
.
<EOS>
Further
,
in
place
of
remembering
that
compact
made
between
them
for
an
avoidance
of
the
subject
,
she
constantly
alluded
to
her
daughter
's

as

of
her
being
an

;
and
all
this
,
with
the

and

of
such

,
always
serving
for
a

on
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Mrs
Dombey
?
<EOS>
"
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
Gone

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gone

!
<EOS>
Does

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
La

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Florence
.
<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>
Do

Miss
Florence
.
<EOS>
What
's
Miss
Florence
to
her
,
compared

me
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
apposite
display
of
the
diamonds
,
or
the

-

(
she
sat
in
the

to

,
weeks
before

)
,

up

,
usually

that
began

flow
hereabouts
;
and
she
would

until

to

;
when
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
am
sure
,
Edith
!
"
<EOS>
she
would
cry
,
shaking

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
,
mother
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Matter
!
<EOS>
I
really
do
n't
know
what
is
the
matter
.
<EOS>
The
world
is
coming
to
such
an
artificial
and

,
that
I
begin
to
think
there
's
no
Heart
---
or
anything

---
left
in
it
,
positively
.
<EOS>
Withers
is
more
a
child
to
me
than
you
are
.
<EOS>
He
attends
to
me
much
more
than
my
own
daughter
.
<EOS>
I
almost
wish
I
did
n't
look
so
young
---
and
all
that
kind
of
thing
---
and
then
perhaps
I
should
be
more
considered
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
what
would
you
have
,
mother
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
a
great
deal
,
Edith
,
"
impatiently
.
  
"
Is
there
anything
you
want
that
you
have
not
?
<EOS>
It
is
your
own
fault
if
there
be
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
own
fault
!
"
<EOS>
beginning
to
whimper
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
parent
I
have
been
to
you
,
Edith
:
making
you
a
companion
from
your
cradle!And
when
you
neglect
me
,
and
have
no
more
natural
affection
for
me
than
if
I
was
a
stranger
---
not
a
twentieth
part
of
the
affection
that
you
have
for
Florence
---
<EOS>
but
I
am
only
your
mother
,
and
should
corrupt
her
in
a
day
!
<EOS>
---
you
reproach
me
with
its
being
my
own
fault
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
mother
,
I
reproach
you
with
nothing
.
<EOS>
Why
will
you
always
dwell
on
this
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
n't
it
natural
that
I
should
dwell
on
this
,
when
I
am
all
affection
and
sensitiveness
,
and
am
wounded
in
the

way
,
whenever
you
look
at
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
mean
to
wound
you
,
mother
.
<EOS>
Have
you
no
remembrance
of
what
has
been
said
between

?
<EOS>
Let
the
Past
rest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
rest
!
<EOS>
And
let
gratitude
to
me
rest
;
and
let
affection
for
me

;
and
let

rest
in
my
out
-
of
-
the
-
way

,
with
no

no

,
while
you
find
new

to
make
much
of
,
who

no
earthly

upon

!
<EOS>
Good

,
Edith
,
do
you
know
what
an
elegant
establishment
you
are
at
the
head
of
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Hush
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
that
gentlemanly
creature
,
Dombey
?
<EOS>
Do
you
know
that
you
are
married
to
him
,
Edith
,
and
that
you
have
a
settlement
,
and
a
position
,
and
a

,
and
I
do
n't
know

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
I
know
it
,
mother
;
<EOS>
well
.
"
  
?
?
?
<EOS>
"
As
you
would
have
had
with
that
delightful
good
soul
---
what
did
they
call
him
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Granger
---
if
he
had
n't
died
.
<EOS>
And
who
have
you
to
thank
for
all

,
Edith
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
,
mother
;
you
.
"
  
"
Then
put
your
arms
round
my
neck
,
and
kiss

;
and
show
me
,
Edith
,
that
you
know
there
never
was
a
better
mama
than
I
have
been

.
<EOS>
And
do
n't
let
me

a
perfect

and

at
your

,
or
<EOS>
when
I
'm
out
again
in
society
<EOS>
no
soul
will
know
me
,
not
even
that
hateful
animal
,
the
Major
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
sometimes
,
when
Edith
went
nearer
to
her
,
and
bending
down
her
stately
head
,
put
her
cold
cheek
to
hers
,
the
mother
would
draw
back
as
if
she
were
afraid
of
her
,
and
would
fall
into
a
fit
of
trembling
,
and
cry
out
that
there
was
a
wandering
in
her
wits
.
<EOS>
And
sometimes
she
would
entreat
her
,
with
humility
,
to
sit
down
on
the
chair
beside
her
bed
,
and
would
look
at
her
(
as
she
sat
there
brooding
)
with
a
face
that
even
the
rosecoloured
curtains
could
not
make
otherwise
than
seared
and
wild
.
  
<EOS>
The
rose
-
coloured
curtains
blushed
,
in
course
of
time
,
on
Cleopatra
's
bodily
recovery
,
and
on
her
dress
---
more
juvenile
than
ever
to
repair
the
ravages
of
illness
---
and
on
the
rouge
,
and
on
the
teeth
,
and
on
the
curls
,
and
on
the

,
and
the
short

,
and
the
whole

of
the
doll
that
had
tumbled
down

.
<EOS>
They
blushed
,
too
,
now
and
then
,
upon
an
indistinctness
in
her
speech
which
she
turned
off
with
a
girlish

,
and
on
an
occasional
failing
in
her
memory
,
that
had
no
rule
in
it
,
but
came
and
went
fantastically
,
as
if
in
mockery
of
her
fantastic
self
.
  
<EOS>
But
they
never
blushed
upon
a
change
in
the
new
manner
of
her
thought
and
speech
towards
her
daughter
.
<EOS>
And
though
that
daughter
often
came
within
their
influence
,
they
never
blushed
upon
her
loveliness
irradiated
by
a
smile
,
or
softened
by
the
light
of
filial
love
,
in
its
stern
beauty
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
38
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
improves
an
Old
Acquaintance
 
<EOS>
THE
forlorn
Miss
Tox
,
abandoned
by
her
friend
Louisa
Chick
,
and
bereft
of
Mr
Dombey
's
countenance
---
for
on
delicate
pair
of
wedding
cards
,
united
by
a
silver
thread
,
graced
the
chimney
-
glass
in
Princess
's
Place
,
or
the
harpsichord
,
or
any
of
those
little
posts
of
display
which
Lucretia
reserved
for
holiday
occupation
---
became
depressed
in
her
spirits
,
and
suffered
much
from
melancholy
.
<EOS>
For
a
time
the
Bird
Waltz
was
unheard
in
Princess
's
Place
,
the
plants
were
neglected
,
and
dust
collected
on
the
miniature
of
Miss
Tox
's
ancestor
with
the
powdered
head
and
pigtail
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
,
however
,
was
not
of
an
age
or
of
a
disposition
long
to
abandon
herself
to
unavailing
regrets
.
<EOS>
Only
two
notes
of
the
harpsichord
were
dumb
from
disuse
when
the
Bird
Waltz
again
warbled
and
trilled
in
the
crooked
drawing
-
room
:
only
one
slip
of
geranium
fell
a
victim
to
imperfect
nursing
,
before
she
was
gardening
at
her
green
baskets
again
,
regularly
every
morning
;
the
powdered
-
headed
ancestor
had
not
been
under
a
cloud
for
more
than
six
weeks
,
when
Miss
Tox
breathed
on
his
benignant
visage
,
and
polished
him
up
with
a
piece
of
wash
-
leather
.
  
<EOS>
Still
,
Miss
Tox
was
lonely
,
and
at
a
loss
.
<EOS>
Her
attachments
,
however
ludicrously
shown
,
were
real
and
strong
;
and
she
was
,
as
she
expressed
it
,
"
deeply
hurt
by
the
unmerited
contumely
she
had
met
with
from
Louisa
.
"
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
such
thing
as
anger
in
Miss
Tox
's
composition
.
<EOS>
If
she
had
ambled
on
through
life
,
in
her
soft
-
spoken
way
,
without
any
opinions
,
she
had
,
at
least
,
got
so
far
without
any
harsh
passions
.
<EOS>
The
mere
sight
of
Louisa
Chick
in
the
street
one
day
,
at
a
considerable
distance
,
so
overpowered
her
milky
nature
,
that
she
was
fain
to
seek
immediate
refuge
in
a
pastrycook
's
,
and
there
,
in
a
musty
little
back
room
usually
devoted
to
the
consumption
of
soups
,
and
pervaded
by
an
ox
-
tail
atmosphere
,
relieve
her
feelings
by
weeping
plentifully
.
  
<EOS>
Against
Mr
Dombey
Miss
Tox
hardly
felt
that
she
had
any
reason
of
complaint
.
<EOS>
Her
sense
of
that
gentleman
's
magnificence
was
such
,
that
once
removed
from
him
,
she
felt
as
if
her
distance
always
had
been
immeasurable
,
and
as
if
he
had
greatly
condescended
in
tolerating
her
at
all
.
<EOS>
No
wife
could
be
too
handsome
or
too
stately
for
him
,
according
to
Miss
Tox
's
sincere
opinion
.
<EOS>
It
was
perfectly
natural
that
in
looking
for
one
,
he
should
look
high
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
with
tears
laid
down
this
proposition
,
and
fully
admitted
it
,
twenty
times
a
day
.
<EOS>
She
never
recalled
the
lofty
manner
in
which
Mr
Dombey
had
made
her
subservient
to
his
convenience
and
caprices
,
and
had
graciously
permitted
her
to
be
one
of
the
nurses
of
his
little
son
.
<EOS>
She
only
thought
,
in
her
own
words
,
"
that
she
had
passed
a
great
many
happy
hours
in
that
house
,
which
she
must
ever
remember
with
gratification
,
and
that
she
could
never
cease
to
regard
Mr
Dombey
as
one
of
the
most
impressive
and
dignified
to
men
.
"
  
<EOS>
Cut
off
,
however
,
from
the
implacable
Louisa
,
and
being
shy
of
the
Major
(
whom
she
viewed
with
some
distrust
now
)
,
Miss
Tox
found
it
very
irksome
to
know
nothing
of
what
was
going
on
in
Mr
Dombey
's
establishment
.
<EOS>
And
as
she
really
had
got
into
the
habit
of
considering
Dombey
and
Son
as
the
pivot
on
which
the
world
in
general
turned
,
she
resolved
,
rather
than
be
ignorant
of
intelligence
which
so
strongly
interested
her
,
to
cultivate
her
old
acquaintance
,
Mrs
Richards
,
who
she
knew
,
since
her
last
memorable
appearance
before
Mr
Dombey
,
was
in
the
habit
of
sometimes
holding
communication
with
his
servants
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
Miss
Tox
,
in
seeking
out
the
Toodle
family
,
had
the
tender
motive
hidden
in
her
breast
of
having
somebody
to
whom
she
could
talk
about
Mr
Dombey
,
no
matter
how
humble
that
somebody
might
be
.
  
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
towards
the
Toodle
habitation
Miss
Tox
directed
her
steps
one
evening
,
what
time
Mr
Toodle
,
cindery
and
swart
,
was
refreshing
himself
with
tea
,
in
the
bosom
of
his
family
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toodle
had
only
three
stages
of
existence
.
<EOS>
He
was
either
taking
refreshment
in
the
bosom
just
mentioned
,
or
he
was
tearing
through
the
country
at
from
twenty
-
five
to
fifty
miles
an
hour
,
or
he
was
sleeping
after
his
fatigues
.
<EOS>
He
was
always
in
a
whirlwind
or
a
calm
,
and
a
peaceable
,
contented
,
easy
-
going
man
<EOS>
Mr
Toodle
was
in
either
state
,
who
seemed
to
have
made
over
all
his
own
inheritance
of
fuming
and
fretting
to
the
engines
with
which
he
was
connected
,
which
panted
,
and
gasped
,
and
chafed
,
and
wore
themselves
out
,
in
a
most
unsparing
manner
,
while
Mr
Toodle
led
a
mild
and
equable
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
Polly
,
my
gal
,
"
said
Mr
Toodle
,
with
a
young
Toodle
on
each
knee
,
and
two
more
making
tea
for
him
,
and
plenty
more
scattered
about
---
<EOS>
Mr
Toodle
was
never
out
of
children
,
but
always
kept
a
good
supply
on
hand
---
"
you
an't
seen
our
Biler
lately
,
have
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Polly
,
"
but
he
's
almost
certain
to
look
in
tonight
.
<EOS>
It
's
his
right
evening
,
and
he
's
very
regular
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
"
said
Mr
Toodle
,
relishing
his
meal
infinitely
,
"
as
our
Biler
is
a
doin'
now
about
as
well
as
a
boy
can
do
,
eh
,
Polly
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
he
's
a
doing
beautiful
!
"
<EOS>
responded
Polly
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
an't
got
to
be
at
all
secret
-
like
---
<EOS>
has
he
,
Polly
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
Mr
Toodle
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
Mrs
Toodle
,
plumply
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
he
an't
got
to
be
at
all
secret
-
like
,
Polly
,
"
observed
Mr
Toodle
in
his
slow
and
measured
way
,
and
shovelling
in
his
bread
and
butter
with
a
clasp
knife
,
as
if
he
were
stoking
himself
,
"
because
that
do
n't
look
well
;
do
it
,
Polly
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
of
course
it
do
n't
,
father
.
<EOS>
How
can
you
ask
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
my
boys
and
gals
,
"
said
Mr
Toodle
,
looking
round
upon
his
family
,
"
wotever
you
're
up
to
in
a
honest
way
<EOS>
,
it
's
my
opinion
as
you
ca
n't
do
better
than
be
open
.
<EOS>
If
you
find
yourselves
in
cuttings
or
in
tunnels
,
do
n't
you
play
no
secret
games
.
<EOS>
Keep
your
whistles
going
,
and
let
's
know
where
you
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
rising
Toodles
set
up
a
shrill
murmur
,
expressive
of
their
resolution
to
profit
by
the
paternal
advice
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
makes
you
say
this
along
of
Rob
,
father
?
"
asked
his
wife
,
anxiously
.
  
<EOS>
"
Polly
,
old
'
ooman
,
"
said
Mr
Toodle
,
"
I
do
n't
know
as
I
said
it
partickler
along
o
'
Rob
<EOS>
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
I
starts
light
with
Rob
only
;
I
comes
to
a
branch
;
I
takes
on
what
I
finds
there
;
and
a
whole
train
of
ideas
gets
coupled
on
to
him
,
afore
<EOS>
I
knows
where
I
am
,
or
where
they
comes
from
.
<EOS>
What
a
Junction
a
man
's
thoughts
is
,
"
said
Mr
Toodle
,
"
to
-
be
-
sure
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
profound
reflection
Mr
Toodle
washed
down
with
a
pint
mug
of
tea
,
and
proceeded
to
solidify
with
a
great
weight
of
bread
and
butter
;
charging
his
young
daughters
meanwhile
,
to
keep
plenty
of
hot
water
in
the
pot
,
as
he
was
uncommon
dry
,
and
should
take
the
indefinite
quantity
of
"
a
sight
of
mugs
,
"
before
his
thirst
was
appeased
.
  
<EOS>
In
satisfying
himself
,
however
,
Mr
Toodle
was
not
regardless
of
the
younger
branches
about
him
,
who
,
although
they
had
made
their
own
evening
repast
,
were
on
the
look
-
out
for
irregular
morsels
,
as
possessing
a
relish
.
<EOS>
These
he
distributed
now
and
then
to
the
expectant
circle
,
by
holding
out
great
wedges
of
bread
and
butter
,
to
be
bitten
at
by
the
family
in
lawful
succession
,
and
by
serving
out
small
doses
of
tea
in
like
manner
with
a
spoon
;
which
snacks
had
such
a
relish
in
the
mouths
of
these
young
Toodles
,
that
,
after
partaking
of
the
same
,
they
performed
private
dances
of
ecstasy
among
themselves
,
and
stood
on
one
leg
apiece
,
and
hopped
,
and
indulged
in
other
saltatory
tokens
of
gladness
.
<EOS>
These
vents
for
their
excitement
found
,
they
gradually
closed
about
Mr
Toodle
again
,
and
eyed
him
hard
as
he
got
through
more
bread
and
butter
and
tea
;
affecting
,
however
,
to
have
no
further
expectations
of
their
own
in
reference
to
those
viands
,
but
to
be
conversing
on
foreign
subjects
,
and
whispering
confidently
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toodle
,
in
the
midst
of
this
family
group
,
and
setting
an
awful
example
to
his
children
in
the
way
of
appetite
,
was
conveying
the
two
young
Toodles
on
his
knees
to
Birmingham
by
special
engine
,
and
was
contemplating
the
rest
over
a
barrier
of
bread
and
butter
,
when
Rob
the
Grinder
,
in
his
sou'wester
hat
and
mourning
slops
,
presented
himself
,
and
was
received
with
a
general
rush
of
brothers
and
sisters
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
mother
!
<EOS>
"
said
Rob
,
dutifully
kissing
her
;
"
how
are
you
,
mother
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
my
boy
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Polly
,
giving
him
a
hug
and
a
pat
on
the
back
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Secret
!
<EOS>
Bless
you
,
father
,
not
he
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
intended
for
Mr
Toodle
's
private
edification
,
but
<EOS>
Rob
the
Grinder
,
whose
withers
were
not
unwrung
,
caught
the
words
as
they
were
spoken
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
father
's
been
a
saying
something
more
again
me
,
has
he
?
"
cried
the
injured
innocent
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
a
hard
thing
it
is
that
when
a
cove
has
once
gone
a

,
a

's
own
father
should
be
always
a
throwing
it
in
his
face
behind

back
!
<EOS>
It
's
enough
,
"
cried
Rob
,
resorting

,
"
to
make

cove
go
and

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
poor
boy
!
"
<EOS>
cried

<EOS>
,
"
father
did
n't
mean
anything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

go

<EOS>
Nobody

so

.
<EOS>
What

!
<EOS>
I
wish

take

.
<EOS>
Father

,

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

all

youngest
Toodle

,

under

for

.
  
<EOS>
Matters

,
and
the

of
his
son

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Will

,
Biler
,

?
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
No
,

,

.
<EOS>
Master

had
tea

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

do
n't

,

;

.
<EOS>
There
ai

<EOS>

<EOS>

friends

<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

,

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
have

.
<EOS>
May

?
"
   
<EOS>
The
cheery

of

Richards
shone
with

,

Tox
,
accepting

,

,

,

said

the

must

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
ill
-

youngest
Toodle
but
one
,

would

,
from
the

,

,

(

)
deep

,

,

;

in

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Being

,

was

to

,
and
red
,

;
and

<EOS>
"
You

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

,
"

"

will
take
this
,
as
I
mean
it
,
like
a
good
-
humoured
creature
,
as
you
always
were
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Polly
was
gratified
,
and
showed
it
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toodle
did
n't
know
whether
he
was
gratified
or
not
,
and
preserved
a
stolid
calmness
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Mrs
Richards
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
---
"
<EOS>
and
I
hope
you
see
too
<EOS>
,
Sir
---
there

many
little
ways
in
which
I
can

,
if
you

;
and

.
<EOS>
For

,
I
can

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

of

now

<EOS>

,

---
<EOS>
dear

,

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toodle
,
who
had
a

for
learning
,
jerked
his

at
his
wife
,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
not

,
I

's

,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
"

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Richards
will

,

,

,

,

,
Sir
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
Mum
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very

,

,
"

,
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

;
and

,

of

children
all
roundwhich
Mr

much

---
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

,

prolonged

until
after

usual

of

,
and
detained
Mrs
Tox
at
the
Toodle

until

.
<EOS>
The
gallant
Grinder
,

,

,

;
and

to

to

a

whom
Mr

had

inducted
into
those
manly

which
are
rarely

by
name
,
she
very

the

.
  
<EOS>
After

with
Mr

,

,
Miss
Tox
left
the

,
therefore
,

unlimited

,
and

so
light

that
it
might
have
given
Mrs
Chick

if
that

.
  
<EOS>
Rob
the
Grinder
,
in
his

,
would

,
but
Miss
Tox
desired

to
keep
beside

,
for

;
and
,
as

to

,
"
drew

out
"
upon

.
  
<EOS>
He

out
so
bright
,
and

,
and

,
that
Miss

.
<EOS>
The

Tox
drew

,

he

---
like

.
<EOS>
There

better

more
<EOS>
promising

---

,

<EOS>
than

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

,
"

,
"

!
"
   
<EOS>
Who
ran
sniggering
off
to
get
change
,
and
tossed
it
way
with
a
pieman
.
<EOS>
But
they
never
taught
honour
at
the
Grinders'School
,
where
the
system
that
prevailed
was
particularly
strong
in
the
engendering
of
hypocrisy
.
<EOS>
Insomuch
,
that
many

the
friends

of
past

said
,
if

came

,

.
  
<EOS>
Some

said
,
let
us
have

.
<EOS>
But

of

'

were
always

,
by

had

,
in

,
and
roundly

.
<EOS>
Which
settled
the
business
of
those
objectors
out

hand
,
and
established
the
glory
of
the
Grinders
'
Institution
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
39
.
<EOS>
Further
Adventures
of
Captain
Edward
Cuttle
,
Mariner
 
TIME
,
sure
of
foot
and
strong
of
will
,
had
so
pressed
onward
,
that
the
year
enjoined
by
the
old
Instrument
-
maker
,
as
the
term
during
which
his
friend
should
refrain
from
opening
the
sealed
packet
accompanying
the
letter
he
had
left
for
him
,
was
now
nearly
expired
,
and
Captain
Cuttle
began
to
look
at
it
,
of
an
evening
,
with
feelings
of
mystery
and
uneasiness
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
in
his
honour
,
would
as
soon
have
thought
of
opening
the
parcel
one
hour
before
the
expiration
of
the
term
,
as
he
would
have
thought
of
opening
himself
,
to
study
his
own
anatomy
.
<EOS>
He
merely
brought
it
out
,
at
a
certain
stage
of
his
first
evening
pipe
,
laid
it
on
the
table
,
and
sat
gazing
at
the
outside
of
it
,
through
the
smoke
,
in
silent
gravity
,
for
two
or
three
hours
at
a
spell
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
when
he
had
contemplated
it
thus
for
a
pretty
long
while
,
the
Captain
would
hitch
his
chair
,
by
degrees
,
farther
and
farther
off
,
as
if
to
get
beyond
the
range
of
its
fascination
;
but
if
this
were
his
design
,
he
never
succeeded
:
for
even
when
he
was
brought
up
by
the
parlour
wall
,
the
packet
still
attracted
him
;
or
if
his
eyes
,
in
thoughtful
wandering
,
roved
to
the
ceiling
or
the
fire
,
its
image
immediately
followed
,
and
posted
itself
conspicuously
among
the
coals
,
or
took
up
an
advantageous
position
on
the
whitewash
.
  
<EOS>
In
respect
of
Heart
's
Delight
,
the
Captain
's
parental
regard
and
admiration
knew
no
change
.
<EOS>
But
since
his
last
interview
with
Mr
Carker
,
Captain
Cuttle
had
come
to
entertain
doubts
whether
his
former
intervention
in
behalf
of
that
young
lady
and
his
dear
boy
Wal'r
,
had
proved
altogether
so
favourable
as
he
could
have
wished
,
and
as
he
at
the
time
believed
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
troubled
with
a
serious
misgiving
that
he
had
done
more
harm
than
good
,
in
short
;
and
in
his
remorse
and
modesty
he
made
the
best
atonement
he
could
think
of
,
by
putting
himself
out
of
the
way
doing
any
harm
to
any
one
,
and
,
as
it
were
,
throwing
himself
overboard
for
a
dangerous
person
.
  
<EOS>
Self
-
buried
,
therefore
,
among
the
instruments
,
the
Captain
never
went
near
Mr
Dombey
's
house
,
or
reported
himself
in
any
way
to
Florence
or
Miss
Nipper
.
<EOS>
He
even
severed
himself
from
Mr
Perch
,
on
the
occasion
of
his
next
visit
,
by
dryly
informing
that
gentleman
,
that
the
thanked
him
for
his
company
,
but
had
cut
himself
adrift
from
all
such
acquaintance
,
as
he
did
n't
know
what
magazine
he
might
n't
blow
up
,
without
meaning
of
it
.
<EOS>
In
this
self
-
imposed
retirement
,
the
Captain
passed
whole
days
and
weeks
without
interchanging
a
word
with
any
one
<EOS>
but
Rob
the
Grinder
,
whom
he
esteemed
as
a
pattern
of
disinterested
attachment
and
fidelity
.
<EOS>
In
this
retirement
,
the
Captain
,
gazing
at
the
packet
of
an
evening
,
would
sit
smoking
,
and
thinking
of
Florence
and
poor
Walter
,
until
they
both
seemed
to
his
homely
fancy
to
be
dead
,
and
to
have
passed
away
into
eternal
youth
,
the
beautiful
and
innocent
children
of
his
first
remembrance
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
did
not
,
however
,
in
his
musings
,
neglect
his
own
improvement
,
or
the
mental
culture
of
Rob
the
Grinder
.
<EOS>
That
young
man
was
generally
required
to
read
out
of
some
book
to
the
Captain
,
for
one
hour
,
every
evening
;
and
as
the
Captain
implicitly
believed
that
all
books
were
true
,
he
accumulated
,
by
this
means
,
many
remarkable
facts
.
<EOS>
On
Sunday
nights
,
the
Captain
always
read
for
himself
,
before
going
to
bed
,
a
certain
Divine
Sermon
once
delivered
on
a
Mount
;
and
although
he
was
accustomed
to
quote
the
text
,
without
book
,
after
his
own
manner
,
he
appeared
to
read
it
with
as
reverent
an
understanding
of
its
heavenly
spirit
,
as
if
he
had
got
it
all
by
heart
in
Greek
,
and
had
been
able
to
write
any
number
of
fierce
theological
disquisitions
on
its
every
phrase
.
  
<EOS>
Rob
the
Grinder
,
whose
reverence
for
the
inspired
writings
,
under
the
admirable
system
of
the
Grinders
'
School
,
had
been
developed
by
a
perpetual
bruising
of
his
intellectual
shins
against
all
the
proper
names
of
all
the
tribes
of
Judah
,
and
by
the
monotonous
repetition
of
hard
verses
,
especially
by
way
of
punishment
,
and
by
the
parading
of
him
at
six
years
old
in
leather
breeches
,
three
times
a
Sunday
,
very
high
up
,
in
a
very
hot
church
,
with
a
great
organ
buzzing
against
his
drowsy
head
,
like
an
exceedingly
busy
bee
---
Rob
the
Grinder
made
a
mighty
show
of
being
edified
when
the
Captain
ceased
to
read
,
and
generally
yawned
and
nodded
while
the
reading
was
in
progress
.
<EOS>
The
latter
fact
being
never
so
much
as
suspected
by
the
good
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
also
,
as
a
man
of
business
,
took
to
keeping
books
.
<EOS>
In
these
he
entered
observations
on
the
weather
,
and
on
the
currents
of
the
waggons
and
other
vehicles
:
which
he
observed
,
in
that
quarter
,
to
set
westward
in
the
morning
and
during
the
greater
part
of
the
day
,
and
eastward
towards
the
evening
.
<EOS>
Two
or
three
stragglers
appearing
in
one
week
,
who
"
spoke
him
"
---
so
the
captain
entered
it
---
on
the
subject
of
spectacles
,
and
who
,
without
positively
purchasing
,
said
they
would
look
in
again
,
the
Captain
decided
that
the
business
was
improving
,
and
made
an
entry
in
the
day
-
book
to
that
effect
:
the
wind
then
blowing
(
which
he
first
recorded
)
pretty
fresh
,
west
and
by
north
;
having
changed
in
the
night
.
  
<EOS>
One
of
the
Captain
's
chief
difficulties
was
Mr
Toots
,
who
called
frequently
,
and
who
without
saying
much
seemed
to
have
an
idea
that
the
little
back
parlour
was
an
eligible
room
to
chuckle
in
,
as
he
would
sit
and
avail
himself
of
its
accommodations
in
that
regard
by
the
half
-
hour
together
,
without
at
all
advancing
in
intimacy
with
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
rendered
cautious
by
his
late
experience
,
was
unable
quite
to
satisfy
his
mind
<EOS>
whether
Mr
Toots
was
the
mild
subject
he
appeared
to
be
,
or
was
a
profoundly
artful
and
dissimulating
hypocrite
.
<EOS>
His
frequent
reference
to
Miss
Dombey
was
suspicious
;
but
the
Captain
had
a
secret
kindness
for
Mr
Toots
's
apparent
reliance
on
him
,
and
forbore
to
decide
against
him
for
the
present
;
merely
eyeing
him
,
with
a
sagacity
not
to
be
described
,
whenever
he
approached
the
subject
that
was
nearest
to
his
heart
.
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Gills
,
"
blurted
out
Mr
Toots
,
one
day
all
at
once
,
as
his
manner
was
,
"
do
you
think
you
could
think
favourably
of
that
proposition
of
mine
,
and
give
me
the
pleasure
of
your
acquaintance
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
tell
you
what
it
is
,
my
lad
,
"
replied
the
Captain
,
who
had
at
length
concluded
on
a
course
of
action
;
"
I
've
been
turning
that
there
over
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Captain
Gills
,
it
's
very
kind
of
you
,
"
retorted
Mr
Toots
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm

you
.
<EOS>
Upon

,
Captain
Gills
,

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

"
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

never

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

Hey

"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

I

"

<EOS>

But

,

<EOS>

;
then
he
ascended
to
the
roof
of
the
house
and
filled
his
hat
and
pockets
with
pigeons
;
then
,
came
down
to
his
bed
under
the
counter
and
made
up
his
bundle
,
snivelling
and
sobbing
louder
as
if
he
were
cut
to
the
heart
by
old
associations
;
then
he
whined
,
"
Good
night
,
Captain
.
<EOS>
I
leave
you
without
malice
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
,
going
out
upon
the
door
-
step
,
pulled
the
little
Midshipman
's
nose
as
a
parting
indignity
,
and
went
away
down
the
street
grinning
triumph
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
left
to
himself
,
resumed
his
perusal
of
the
news
as
if
nothing
unusual
or
unexpected
had
taken
place
,
and
went
reading
on
with
the
greatest
assiduity
.
<EOS>
But
never
a
word
did
Captain
Cuttle
understand
,
though
he
read
a
vast
number
,
for
Rob
the
Grinder
was
scampering
up
one
column
and
down
another
all
through
the
newspaper
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
doubtful
whether
the
worthy
Captain
had
ever
felt
himself
quite
abandoned
until
now
;
but
now
,
old
Sol
Gills
,
Walter
,
and
Heart
's
Delight
were
lost
to
him
indeed
,
and
now
Mr
Carker
deceived
and
jeered
him
cruelly
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
represented
in
the
false
Rob
,
to
whom
he
had
held
forth
many
a
time
on
the
recollections
that
were
warm
within
him
;
he
had
believed
in
the
false
Rob
,
and
had
been
glad
to
believe
in
him
;
he
had
made
a
companion
of
him
as
the
last
of
the
old
ship
's
company
;
he
had
taken
the
command
of
the
little
Midshipman
with
him
at
his
right
hand
;
he
had
meant
to
do
his
duty
by
him
,
and
had
felt
almost
as
kindly
towards
the
boy
as
if
they
had
been
shipwrecked
and
cast
upon
a
desert
place
together
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
that
the
false
Rob
had
brought
distrust
,
treachery
,
and
meanness
into
the
very
parlour
,
which
was
a
kind
of
sacred
place
,
Captain
Cuttle
felt
as
if
the
parlour
might
have
gone
down
next
,
and
not
surprised
him
much
by
its
sinking
,
or
given
him
any
very
great
concern
.
  
<EOS>
Therefore
Captain
Cuttle
read
the
newspaper
with
profound
attention
and
no
comprehension
,
and
therefore
Captain
Cuttle
said
nothing
whatever
about
Rob
to
himself
,
or
admitted
to
himself
that
he
was
thinking
about
him
,
or
would
recognise
in
the
most
distant
manner
that
Rob
had
anything
to
do
with
his
feeling
as
lonely
as
Robinson
Crusoe
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
same
composed
,
business
-
like
way
,
the
Captain
stepped
over
to
Leadenhall
Market
in
the
dusk
,
and
effected
an
arrangement
with
a
private
watchman
on
duty
there
,
to
come
and
put
up
and
take
down
the
shutters
of
the
Wooden
Midshipman
every
night
and
morning
.
<EOS>
He
then
called
in
at
the
eating
-
house
to
diminish
by
one
half
the
daily
rations
theretofore
supplied
to
the
Midshipman
,
and
at
the
publichouse
to
stop
the
traitor
's
beer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
young
man
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
in
explanation
to
the
young
lady
at
the
bar
,
"
my
young
man
having
bettered
himself
,
<EOS>
Miss.
"
<EOS>
Lastly
,
the
Captain
resolved
to
take
possession
of
the
bed
under
the
counter
,
and
to
turn
in
there
o
'
nights
instead
of
up
stairs
,
as
sole
guardian
of
the
property
.
  
<EOS>
From
this
,
bed
Captain
Cuttle
daily
rose
thenceforth
,
and
clapped
on
his
glazed
hat
at
six
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
with
the
solitary
air
of
Crusoe
finishing
his
toilet
with
his
goat
-
skin
cap
;
and
although
his
fears
of
a
visitation
from
the
savage
tribe
,
MacStinger
,
were
somewhat
cooled
,
as
similar
apprehensions
on
the
part
of
that
lone
mariner
used
to
be
by
the
lapse
of
a
long
interval
without
any
symptoms
of
the
cannibals
,
he
still
observed
a
regular
routine
of
defensive
operations
,
and
never
encountered
a
bonnet
without
previous
survey
from
his
castle
of
retreat
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
(
during
which
he
received
no
call
from
Mr
Toots
,
who
wrote
to
say
he
was
out
of
town
)
<EOS>
his
own
voice
began
to
have
a
strange
sound
in
his
ears
;
and
he
acquired
such
habits
of
profound
meditation
from
much
polishing
and
stowing
away
of
the
stock
,
and
from
much
sitting
behind
the
counter
reading
,
or
looking
out
of
window
,
that
the
red
rim
made
on
his
forehead
by
the
hard
glazed
hat
,
sometimes
ached
again
with
excess
of
reflection
.
  
<EOS>
The
year
being
now
expired
,
Captain
Cuttle
deemed
it
expedient
to
open
the
packet
;
but
as
he
had
always
designed
doing
this
in
the
presence
of
Rob
the
Grinder
,
who
had
brought
it
to
him
,
and
as
he
had
an
idea
that
it
would
be
regular
and
<EOS>
ship
-
shape
to
open
it
in
the
presence
of
somebody
,
he
was
sadly
put
to
it
for
want
of
a
witness
.
<EOS>
In
this
difficulty
,
he
hailed
one
day
with
unusual
delight
the
announcement
in
the
Shipping
Intelligence
of
the
arrival
of
the
Cautious
Clara
,
Captain
John
Bunsby
,
from
a
coasting
voyage
;
and
to
that
philosopher
immediately
dispatched
a
letter
by
post
,
enjoining
inviolable
secrecy
as
to
his
place
of
residence
,
and
requesting
to
be
favoured
with
an
early
visit
,
in
the
evening
season
.
  
<EOS>
Bunsby
,
who
was
one
of
those
sages
who
act
upon
conviction
,
took
some
days
to
get
the
conviction
thoroughly
into
his
mind
,
that
he
had
received
a
letter
to
this
effect
.
<EOS>
But
when
he
had
grappled
with
the
fact
,
and
mastered
it
,
he
promptly
sent
his
boy
with
the
message
,
"
He
's
a
coming
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
Who
being
instructed
to
deliver
those
words
and
disappear
,
fulfilled
his
mission
like
a
tarry
spirit
,
charged
with
a
mysterious
warning
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
well
pleased
to
receive
it
,
made
preparation
of
pipes
and
rum
and
water
,
and
awaited
his
visitor
in
the
back
parlour
.
<EOS>
At
the
hour
of
eight
,
a
deep
lowing
,
as
of
a
nautical
Bull
,
outside
the
shop
-
door
,
succeeded
by
the
knocking
of
a
stick
on
the
panel
,
announced
to
the
listening
ear
of
Captain
Cuttle
,
that
Bunsby
was
alongside
:
whom
he
instantly
admitted
,
shaggy
and
loose
,
and
with
his
stolid
mahogany
visage
,
as
usual
,
appearing
to
have
no
consciousness
of
anything
before
it
,
but
to
be
attentively
observing
something
that
was
taking
place
in
quite
another
part
of
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bunsby
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
grasping
him
by
the
hand
,
"
what
cheer
,
my
lad
,
what
cheer
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shipmet
,
"
replied
the
voice
within
Bunsby
,
unaccompanied
by
any
sign
on
the
part
of
the
Commander
himself
,
"
hearty
,
hearty
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bunsby
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
rendering
irrepressible
homage
to
his
genius
,
"
here
you
are
!
<EOS>
a
man
as
can
give
an
opinion
as
is
brighter
than
di'monds
---
and
give
me
the
lad
with
the
tarry
trousers
as
shines
to
me
like
di'monds
bright
,
for
which
you
'll
overhaul
the
Stanfell
's
Budget
,
and
when
found
make
a
note
.
<EOS>
Here
you
are
,
a
man
as
gave
an
opinion
in
this
here
very
place
,
that
has
come
true
,
every
letter
on
it
,
"
which
the
Captain
sincerely
believed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
?
"
growled
Bunsby
.
  
<EOS>
"
Every
letter
,
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
why
?
"
growled
Bunsby
,
looking
at
his
friend
for
the
first
time
.
"
Which
way
?
<EOS>
If
so
,
why
not
?
<EOS>
Therefore
.
<EOS>
"
With
these
oracular
words
---
they
seemed
almost
to
make
the
Captain
giddy
;
they
launched
him
upon
such
a
sea
of
speculation
and
conjecture
---
the
sage
submitted
to
be
helped
off
with
his
pilotcoat
,
and
accompanied
his
friend
into
the
back
parlour
,
where
his
hand
presently
alighted
on
the
rum
-
bottle
,
from
which
he
brewed
a
stiff
glass
of
grog
;
and
presently
afterwards
on
a
pipe
,
which
he
filled
,
lighted
,
and
began
to
smoke
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
imitating
his
visitor
in
the
matter
of
these
particulars
,
though
the
rapt
and
imperturbable
manner
of
the
great
Commander
was
far
above
his
powers
,
sat
in
the
opposite
corner
of
the
fireside
,
observing
him
respectfully
,
and
as
if
he
waited
for
some
encouragement
or
expression
of
curiosity
on
Bunsby
's
part
which
should
lead
him
to
his
own
affairs
.
<EOS>
But
as
the
mahogany
philosopher
gave
no
evidence
of
being
sentient
of
anything
but
warmth
and
tobacco
,
except
once
,
when
taking
his
pipe
from
his
lips
to
make
room
for
his
glass
,
he
incidentally
remarked
with
exceeding
gruffness
,
that
his
name
was
Jack
Bunsby
---
a
declaration
that
presented
but
small
opening
for
conversation
---
the
Captain
bespeaking
his
attention
in
a
short
complimentary
exordium
,
narrated
the
whole
history
of
Uncle
Sol
's
departure
,
with
the
change
it
had
produced
in
his
own
life
and
fortunes
;
and
concluded
by
placing
the
packet
on
the
table
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
long
pause
,
Mr
Bunsby
nodded
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Open
?
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
Bunsby
nodded
again
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
accordingly
broke
the
seal
,
and
disclosed
to
view
two
folded
papers
,
of
which
he
severally
read
the
endorsements
,
thus
:
"
Last
Will
and
Testament
of
Solomon
Gills
.
"
<EOS>
"
Letter
for
Ned
Cuttle
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bunsby
,
with
his
eye
on
the
coast
of
Greenland
,
seemed
to
listen
for
the
contents
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
therefore
hemmed
to
clear
his
throat
,
and
read
the
letter
aloud
.
  
<EOS>
"
"
My
dear
Ned
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
When
I
left
home
for
the
West
Indies
"
"
  
Here
the
Captain
stopped
,
and
looked
hard
at
Bunsby
,
who
looked
fixedly
at
the
coast
of
Greenland
.
   
---
"
"
in
forlorn
search
of
intelligence
of
my
dear
boy
,
I
knew
that
if
you
were
acquainted
with
my
design
,
you
would
thwart
it
,
or
accompany
me
;
and
therefore
I
kept
it
secret
.
<EOS>
If
you
ever
read
this
letter
,
Ned
,
I
am
likely
to
be
dead
.
<EOS>
You
will
easily
forgive
an
old
friend
's
folly
then
,
and
will
feel
for
the
restlessness
and
uncertainty
in
which
he
wandered
away
on
such
a
wild
voyage
.
<EOS>
So
no
more
of
that
.
<EOS>
I
have
little
hope
that
my
poor
boy
will
ever
read
these
words
,
or
gladden
your
eyes
with
the
sight
of
his
frank
face
any
more
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
;
no
more
,
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
sorrowfully
meditating
;
"
no
more
.
<EOS>
There
he
lays
,
all
his
days
---
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Bunsby
,
who
had
a
musical
ear
,
suddenly
bellowed
,
"
In
the
Bays
of
Biscay
,
O
!
"
<EOS>
which
so
affected
the
good
Captain
,
as
an
appropriate
tribute
to
departed
worth
,
that
he
shook
him
by
the
hand
in
acknowledgment
,
and
was
fain
to
wipe
his
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
said
the
Captain
with
a
sigh
,
as
the
Lament
of
Bunsby
ceased
to
ring
and
vibrate
in
the
skylight
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Affliction
sore
,
long
time
he
bore
,
and
let
us
overhaul
the
wollume
,
and
there
find
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Physicians
,
"
observed
Bunsby
,
"
was
in
vain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
,
to
be
sure
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
"
what
's
the
good
o
'
<EOS>
them
in
two
or
three
hundred
fathoms
o
'
water
!
"
<EOS>
Then
returning
to
the
letter
,
he
read
on
:
---
"
<EOS>
"
But
if
he
should
be
by
,
when
it
is
opened
;
"
"
the
Captain
involuntarily
looked
round
,
and
shook
his
head
;
"
"
or
should
know
of
it
at
any
other
time
;
"
"
the
Captain
shook
his
head
again
;
"
"
my
blessing
on
him
!
<EOS>
In
case
the
accompanying
paper
is
not
legally
written
,
it
matters
very
little
,
for
there
is
no
one
interested
but
you
and
he
,
and
my
plain
wish
is
,
that
if
he
is
living
he
should
have
what
little
there
may
be
,
and
if
(
as
I
fear
)
<EOS>
otherwise
,
that
you
should
have
it
,
Ned
.
<EOS>
You
will
respect
my
wish
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
God
bless
you
for
it
,
and
for
all
your
friendliness
besides
,
to
SOLOMON
GILLS
.
<EOS>
"
Bunsby
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
appealing
to
him
solemnly
,
"
what
do
you
make
of
this
?
<EOS>
There
you
sit
,
a
man
as
has
had
his
head
broke
from
infancy
up'ards
,
and
has
got
a
new
opinion
into
it
at
every
seam
as
has
been
opened
.
<EOS>
Now
,
what
do
you
make
o
'
this
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
so
be
,
"
returned
Bunsby
,
with
unusual
promptitude
,
"
as
he
's
dead
,
my
opinion
is
he
wo
n't
come
back
no
more
.
<EOS>
If
so
be
as
he
's
alive
,
my
opinion
is
he
will
.
<EOS>
Do
I
say
he
will
?
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Why
not
?
<EOS>
Because
the
bearings
of
this
obserwation
lays
in
the
application
on
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bunsby
!
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
who
would
seem
to
have
estimated
the
value
of
his
distinguished
friend
's
opinions
in
proportion
to
the
immensity
of
the
difficulty
he
experienced

knew

for
the
chest
he
had
left
at
Mrs
MacStinger
's
house
,
and
looking
,
candle
in
hand
,
at
Bunsby
more
attentively
,
believed
that
he
was
three
sheets
in
the
wind
,
or
,
it
plain
words
,
drunk
.
<EOS>
It
was
difficult
,
however
,
to
be
sure
of
this
;
the
Commander
having
no
trace
of
expression
in
his
face
when
sober
.
  
<EOS>
"
Cuttle
,
"
said
the
Commander
,
getting
off
the
chest
,
and
opening
the
lid
,
"
are
these
here
your
traps
?
"
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
looked
in
and
identified
his
property
.
  
<EOS>
"
Done
pretty
taut
and
trim
,
hey
,
shipmet
?
"
said
Bunsby
.
  
<EOS>
The
grateful
and
bewildered
Captain
grasped
him
by
the
hand
,
and
was
launching
into
a
reply
expressive
of
his
astonished
feelings
,
when
Bunsby
disengaged
himself
by
a
jerk
of
his
wrist
,
and
seemed
to
make
an
effort
to
wink
with
his
revolving
eye
,
the
only
effect
of
which
attempt
,
in
his
condition
,
was
nearly
to
overbalance
him
.
<EOS>
He
then
abruptly
opened
the
door
,
and
shot
away
to
rejoin
the
Cautious
Clara
with
all
speed
---
supposed
to
be
his
invariable
custom
,
whenever
he
considered
he
had
made
a
point
.
  
<EOS>
As
it
was
not
his
humour
to
be
often
sought
,
Captain
Cuttle
decided
not
to
go
or
send
to
him
next
day
,
or
until
he
should
make
his
gracious
pleasure
known
in
such
wise
,
or
failing
that
,
until
some
little
time
should
have
elapsed
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
therefore
,
renewed
his
solitary
life
next
morning
,
and
thought
profoundly
,
many
mornings
,
noons
,
and
nights
,
of
old
Sol
Gills
,
and
Bunsby
's
sentiments
concerning
him
,
and
the
hopes
there
were
of
his
return
.
<EOS>
Much
of
such
thinking
strengthened
Captain
Cuttle
's
hopes
;
and
he
humoured
them
and
himself
by
watching
for
the
Instrument
-
maker
at
the
door
as
he
ventured
to
do
now
,
in
his
strange

---
and
setting
his
chair
in
its
place
,
and
arranging
the
little
parlour
as
it
used
to
be
,
in
case

come

.
<EOS>
He
likewise
,
in

,
took

a
certain

miniature
of
Walter
as
a

,
from
its
accustomed
nail
,
lest
it
should
shock
the
old
man
on

.
<EOS>
The
Captain
had
his
presentiments
,
too
,
sometimes
,
that
he
would
come
on
such

day
;
and
one

,
even
ordered
a

of

,
he

so

.
<EOS>
But
come
,
old
Solomon
did
not
;
and
still
the
neighbours
noticed
how
the
seafaring
man
in

,
stood
at
the
shop

door
of
an

,
looking
up

down

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
40
.
<EOS>
Domestic
Relations
 
<EOS>
IT
was
not
in
the
nature
of
things
that
a
man
of
Mr
Dombey
's
mood
,
opposed
to
such
a
spirit
as
he
had
raised
against
himself
,
should
be
softened
in
the
imperious
asperity
of
his
temper
;
or
that
the
cold
hard
armour
of
pride
in
which
he
lived
encased
,
should
be
made
more
flexible
by
constant
collision
with
haughty
scorn
and
defiance
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
curse
of
such
a
nature
---
it
is
a
main
part
of
the
heavy
retribution
on
itself
it
bears
within
itself
---
<EOS>
that
while
deference
and
concession
swell
its
evil
qualities
,
and
are
the
food
it
grows
upon
,
resistance
and
a
questioning
of
its
exacting
claims
,
foster
it
too
,
no
less
.
<EOS>
The
evil
that
is
in
it
finds
equally
its
means
of
growth
and
propagation
in
opposites
.
<EOS>
It
draws
support
and
life
from
sweets
and
bitters
;
bowed
down
before
,
or
unacknowledged
,
it
still
enslaves
the
breast
in
which
it
has
its
throne
;
and
,
worshipped
or
rejected
,
is
as
hard
a
master
as
the
Devil
in
dark
fables
.
  
<EOS>
Towards
his
first
wife
,
Mr
Dombey
,
in
his
cold
and
lofty
arrogance
,
had
borne
himself
like
the
removed
Being
he
almost
conceived
himself
to
be
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
"
Mr
Dombey
"
with
her
when
she
first
saw
him
,
and
he
was
"
Mr
Dombey
"
when
she
died
.
<EOS>
He
had
asserted
his
greatness
during
their
whole
married
life
,
and
she
had
meekly
recognised
it
.
<EOS>
He
had
kept
his
distant
seat
of
state
on
the
top
of
his
throne
,
and
she
her
humble
station
on
its
lowest
step
;
and
much
good
it
had
done
him
,
so
to
live
in
solitary
bondage
to
his
one
idea
!
<EOS>
He
had
imagined
that
the
proud
character
of
his
second
wife
would
have
been
added
to
his
own
---
would
have
merged
into
it
,
and
exalted
his
greatness
.
<EOS>
He
had
pictured
himself
haughtier
than
ever
,
with
Edith
's
haughtiness
subservient
to
his
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
entertained
the
possibility
of
its
arraying
itself
against
him
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
when
he
found
it
rising
in
his
path
at
every
step
and
turn
of
his
daily
life
,
fixing
its
cold
,
defiant
,
and
contemptuous
face
upon
him
,
this
pride
of
his
,
instead
of
withering
,
or
hanging
down
its
head
beneath
the
shock
,
put
forth
new
shoots
,
became
more
concentrated
and
intense
,
more
gloomy
,
sullen
,
irksome
,
and
unyielding
,
than
it
had
ever
been
before
.
  
<EOS>
Who
wears
such
armour
,
too
,
bears
with
him
ever
another
heavy
retribution
.
<EOS>
It
is
of
proof
against
conciliation
,
love
,
and
confidence
!
<EOS>
against
all
gentle
sympathy
from
without
,
all
trust
,
all
tenderness
,
all
soft
emotion
;
but
to
deep
stabs
in
the
selflove
,
it
is
as
vulnerable
as
the
bare
breast
to
steel
;
and
such
tormenting
festers
rankle
there
,
as
follow
on
no
other
wounds
,
no
,
though
dealt
with
the
mailed
hand
of
Pride
itself
,
on
weaker
pride
,
disarmed
and
thrown
down
.
  
<EOS>
Such
wounds
were
his
.
<EOS>
He
felt
them
sharply
,
in
the
solitude
of
his
old
rooms
;
whither
he
now
began
often
to
retire
again
,
and
pass
long
solitary
hours
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
his
fate
to
be
ever
proud
and
powerful
;
ever
humbled
and
powerless
where
he
would
be
most
strong
.
<EOS>
Who
seemed
fated
to
work
out
that
doom
?
  
<EOS>
Who
?
<EOS>
Who
was
it
who
could
win
his
wife
as
she
had
won
his
boy
?
<EOS>
Who
was
it
who
had
shown
him
that
new
victory
,
as
he
sat
in
the
dark
corner
?
<EOS>
Who
was
it
<EOS>
whose
least
word
did
what
his
utmost
means
could
not
?
<EOS>
Who
was
it
who
,
unaided
by
his
love
,
regard
or
notice
,
thrived
and
grew
beautiful
when
those
so
aided
died
?
<EOS>
Who
could
it
be
,
but
the
same
child
at
whom
he
had
often
glanced
uneasily
in
her
motherless
infancy
,
with
a
kind
of
dread
,
lest
he
might
come
to
hate
her
;
and
of
whom
his
foreboding
was
fulfilled
,
for
he
DID
hate
her
in
his
heart
?
  
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
he
would
have
it
hatred
,
and
he
made
it
hatred
,
though
some
sparkles
of
the
light
in
which
she
had
appeared
before
him
on
the
memorable

of
his
return
home
with
his
Bride
,
occasionally
hung
about
her
still
.
<EOS>
He
knew
now
that
she
was
beautiful
;
he
did
not
dispute
that
she
was
graceful
and
winning
,
and
that
in
the
bright
dawn
of
her
womanhood
she
had
come
upon
him
,
a
surprise
.
<EOS>
But
he
turned
even
this
against
her
.
<EOS>
In
his
sullen
and
unwholesome
brooding
,
the
unhappy
man
,
with
a
dull
perception
of
his
alienation
from
all
hearts
,
and
a
vague
yearning
for
what
he
had
all
his
life
repelled
,
made
a
distorted
picture
of
his
rights
and
wrongs
,
and
justified
himself
with
it
against
her
.
<EOS>
The
worthier
she
promised
to
be
of
him
<EOS>
,
the
greater
claim
he
was
disposed
to
ante
-
date
upon
her
duty
and
submission
?
<EOS>
When
had
she
ever
shown
him
duty
and
submission
?
<EOS>
Did
she
grace
his
life
---
or
Edith
's
?
<EOS>
Had
her
attractions
been
manifested
first
to
him
---
or
Edith
?
<EOS>
Why
,
he
and
she
had
never
been
,
from
her
birth
,
like
father
and
child
!
<EOS>
They
had
always
been
estranged
.
<EOS>
She
had
crossed
him
every
way
and
everywhere
.
<EOS>
She
was
leagued
against
him
now
.
<EOS>
Her
very
beauty
softened
natures
that
were
obdurate
to
him
,
and
insulted
him
with
an
unnatural
triumph
.
  
<EOS>
It
may
have
been
that
in
all
this
there
were
mutterings
of
an
awakened

in
his

,
however
selfishly

by
his
position
of
disadvantage
,
in
comparison
with
what
she
might
have
made
his
life
.
<EOS>
But
he
silenced
the
distant
thunder
with
the
rolling
of
his
sea
of
pride
.
<EOS>
He
would
bear
nothing
but
his
pride
.
<EOS>
And
in
his
pride
,
a
heap
of
inconsistency
,
and
misery
,
and
self
-
inflicted
torment
,
he
hated
her
.
  
<EOS>
To
the
moody
,
stubborn
,
sullen
demon
,
that
possessed
him
,
his
wife
opposed
her
different
pride
in
its
full
force
.
<EOS>
They
never
could
have
led
a
happy
life
together
;
but
nothing
could
have
made
it
more
unhappy
,
than
the
wilful
and
determined
warfare
of
such
elements
.
<EOS>
His
pride
was
set
upon
maintaining
his
magnificent
supremacy
,
and
forcing
recognition
of
it
from
her
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
been
racked
to
death
,
and
turned
but
<EOS>
her
haughty
glance
of
calm
inflexible
disdain
upon
him
,
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
Such
recognition
from
Edith
!
<EOS>
He
little
knew
through
what
a
storm
and
struggle
she
had
been
driven
onward
to
the
crowning
honour
of
his
hand
.
<EOS>
He
little
knew
how
much
she
thought
she
had
conceded
,
when
she
suffered
him
to
call
her
wife
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
was
resolved
to
show
her
that
he
was
supreme
.
<EOS>
There
must
be
no
will
but
his
.
<EOS>
Proud
<EOS>
he
desired
that
she
should
be
,
but
she
must
be
proud
for
,
not
against
him
.
<EOS>
As
he
sat
alone
,
hardening
,
he
would
often
hear
her
go
out
and
come
home
,
treading
the
round
of
London
life
with
no
more
heed
of
his
liking
or
disliking
,
pleasure
or
displeasure
,
than
if
he
had
been
her

.
<EOS>
Her
cold
supreme
indifference
---
his
own
unquestioned
attribute
usurped
---
stung
him
more
than
any
other
kind
of
treatment
could
have
done
;
and
he
determined
to
bend
her
to
his
magnificent
and
stately
will
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
long
communing
with
these

,
when
one
night
he
sought
her
in
her
own

,
after
he
had
heard
her
return
home

.
<EOS>
She
was
alone
,
in
her
brilliant
dress
,
and
had
but
that
moment
come
from
her
mother
's
room
.
<EOS>
Her
face
was
melancholy
and
pensive
,
when
he
came
upon
her
;
but
it
marked
him
at
the
door
;
for
,

at
the
mirror
before
it
,
he
saw
immediately
,
as
in
a
picture
-
frame
,
the
knitted

,
and
darkened

that
he
knew
so
well
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Dombey
,
"
he
said
,
entering
,
"
I
must
beg
leave
to
have
a
few
words
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
,
"
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
time
like
the
present
,
Madam
,
"
he
returned
.
<EOS>
"
You
mistake
your
position
.
<EOS>
I
am
used
to
choose
my
own
times
;
not
to
have
them
chosen
for
me
.
<EOS>
I
think
you
scarcely
understand
who
and
what
I
am
,
Mrs
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
she
answered
,
"
that
I
understand
you
very
well
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
looked
upon
him
as
she
said
so
,
and
folding
her
white
arms
,
sparkling
with
gold
and
gems
,
upon
her
swelling
breast
,
turned
away
her
