.
  
<EOS>
If
she
had
been
less
handsome
,
and
less
stately
in
her
cold
composure
,
she
might
not
have
had
the
power
of
impressing
him
with
the
sense
of
disadvantage
that
penetrated
through
his
utmost
pride
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
the
power
,
and
he
felt
it
keenly
.
<EOS>
He
glanced
round
the
room
:
saw
how
the
splendid
means
of
personal
adornment
,
and
the
luxuries
of
dress
,
were
scattered
here
and
there
,
and
disregarded
;
<EOS>
not
in
mere
caprice
and
carelessness
(
or
so
he
thought
)
,
<EOS>
but
in
a
steadfast
haughty
disregard
of
costly
things
:
and
felt
it
more
and
more
.
<EOS>
Chaplets
of
flowers
,
plumes
of
feathers
,
jewels
,
laces
,
silks
and
satins
;
look
where
he
would
,
he
saw
riches
,
despised
,
poured
out
,
and
made
of
no
account
.
<EOS>
The
very
diamonds
---
a
marriage
gift
---
that
rose
and
fell
impatiently
upon
her
bosom
,
seemed
to
pant
to
break
the
chain
that
clasped
them
round
her
neck
,
and
roll
down
on
the
floor
where
she
might
tread
upon
them
.
  
<EOS>
He
felt
his
disadvantage
,
and
he
showed
it
.
<EOS>
Solemn
and
strange
among
his
wealth
of
colour
and
voluptuous
glitter
,
strange
and
constrained
towards
its
haughty
mistress
,
whose
repellent
beauty
it
repeated
,
and
presented
all
around
him
,
as
in
so
many
fragments
of
a
mirror
<EOS>
,
he
was
conscious
of
embarrassment
and
awkwardness
.
<EOS>
Nothing
that
ministered
to
her
disdainful
self
-
possession
could
fail
to
gall
him
.
<EOS>
Galled
and
irritated
with
himself
,
he
sat
down
,
and
went
on
in
no
improved
humour
:
  
"
Mrs
Dombey
,
it
is
very
necessary
that
there
should
be
some
understanding
arrived
at
between
us
.
<EOS>
Your
conduct
does
not
please
Me
,
madam
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
merely
glanced
at
him
again
,
and
again
averted
her
eyes
;
but
she
might
have
spoken
for
an
hour
,
and
expressed
less
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
repeat
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
does
not
please
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
already
taken
occasion
to
request
that
it
may
be
corrected
.
<EOS>
I
now
insist
upon
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
chose
a
fitting
occasion
for
your
first
remonstrance
,
Sir
,
and
you
adopt
a
fitting
manner
,
and
a
fitting
word
for
your
second
.
<EOS>
You
insist
!
<EOS>
To
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
with
his
most
offensive
air
of
state
,
"
I
have
made
you
my
wife
.
<EOS>
You
bear
my
name
.
<EOS>
You
are
associated
with
my
position
and
my
reputation
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
that
the
world
in
general
may
be
disposed
to
think
you
honoured
by
that
association
;
but
I
will
say
that
I
am
accustomed
to
"
insist
,
"
to
my
connections
and
dependents
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Which
may
you
be
pleased
to
consider
me
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Possibly
I
may
think
that
my
wife
should
partake
---
or
does
partake
,
and
can
not
help
herself
---
of
both
characters
,
Mrs
Dombey
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
bent
her
eyes
upon
him
steadily
,
and
set
her
trembling
lips
.
<EOS>
He
saw
her
bosom
throb
,
and
saw
her
face
flush
and
turn
white
.
<EOS>
All
this
he
could
know
,
and
did
:
<EOS>
but
he
could
not
know
that
one
word
was
whispering
in
the
deep
recesses
of
her
heart
,
to
keep
her
quiet
;
and
that
the
word
was
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
Blind
idiot
,
rushing
to
a
precipice
!
<EOS>
He
thought
she
stood
in
awe
of
him
!
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
too
expensive
,
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
extravagant
.
<EOS>
You
waste
a
great
deal
of
money
---
or
what
would
be
a
great
deal
in
the
pockets
of
most
gentlemen
---
in
cultivating
a
kind
of
society
that
is
useless
to
me
,
and
,
indeed
,
that
upon
the
whole
is
disagreeable
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
to
insist
upon
a
total
change
in
all
these
respects
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
in
the
novelty
of
possessing
a
tithe
of
such
means
as
Fortune
has
placed
at
your
disposal
,
ladies
are
apt
to
run
into
a
sudden
extreme
.
<EOS>
There
has
been
more
than
enough
of
that
extreme
.
<EOS>
I
beg
that
Mrs
Granger
's
very
different
experiences
may
now
come
to
the
instruction
of
Mrs
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Still
the
fixed
look
,
the
trembling
lips
,
the
throbbing
breast
,
the
face
now
crimson
and
now
white
;
and
still
the
deep
whisper
Florence
,
Florence
,
speaking
to
her
in
the
beating
of
her
heart
.
  
<EOS>
His
insolence
of
self
-
importance
dilated
as
he
saw
this
alteration
in
her
.
<EOS>
Swollen
no
less
by
her
past
scorn
of
him
,
and
his
so
recent
feeling
of
disadvantage
,
than
by
her
present
submission
(
as
he
took
it
to
be
)
,
it
became
too
mighty
for
his
breast
,
and
burst
all
bounds
.
<EOS>
Why
,
who
could
long
resist
his
lofty
will
and
pleasure
!
<EOS>
He
had
resolved
to
conquer
her
,
and
look
here
!
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
further
please
,
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
in
a
tone
of
sovereign
command
,
"
to
understand
distinctly
,
that
I
am
to
be
deferred
to
and
obeyed
.
<EOS>
That
I
must
have
a
positive
show
and
confession
of
deference
before
the
world
,
Madam
.
<EOS>
I
am
used
to
this
.
<EOS>
I
require
it
as
my
right
.
<EOS>
In
short
I
will
have
it
.
<EOS>
I
consider
it
no
unreasonable
return
for
the
worldly
advancement
that
has
befallen
you
;
and
I
believe
nobody
will
be
surprised
,
either
at
its
being
required
from
you
,
or
at
your
making
it
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
To
Me
---
To
Me
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
with
emphasis
.
  
<EOS>
No
word
from
her
.
<EOS>
No
change
in
her
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
upon
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
learnt
from
your
mother
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
with
magisterial
importance
,
"
what
no
doubt
you
know
,
namely
,
that
Brighton
is
recommended
for
her
health
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
has
been
so
good
"
  
<EOS>
She
changed
suddenly
.
<EOS>
Her
face
and
bosom
glowed
as
if
the
red
light
of
an
angry
sunset
had
been
flung
upon
them
.
<EOS>
Not
unobservant
of
the
change
,
and
putting
his
own
interpretation
upon
it
,
Mr
Dombey
resumed
:
  
"
Mr
Carker
has
been
so
good
as
to
go
down
and
secure
a
house
there
,
for
a
time
.
<EOS>
On
the
return
of
the
establishment
to
London
,
I
shall
take
such
steps
for
its
better
management
as
I
consider
necessary
.
<EOS>
One
of
these
,
will
be
the
engagement
at
Brighton
<EOS>
(
if
it
is
to
be
effected
)
,
of
a
very
respectable
reduced
person
there
,
a
Mrs
Pipchin
,
formerly
employed
in
a
situation
of
trust
in
my
family
,
to
act
as
housekeeper
.
<EOS>
An
establishment
like
this
,
presided
over
but
nominally
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
requires
a
competent
head
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
changed
her
attitude
before
he
arrived
at
these
words
,
and
now
sat
---
still
looking
at
him
fixedly
---
turning
a
bracelet
round
and
round
upon
her
arm
;
not
winding
it
about
with
a
light
,
womanly
touch
,
but
pressing
and
dragging
it
over
the
smooth
skin
,
until
the
white
limb
showed
a
bar
of
red
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
observed
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
---
"
and
this
concludes
what
I
deem
it
necessary
to
say
to
you
at
present
,
Mrs
Dombey
<EOS>
---
I
observed
a
moment
ago
,
Madam
,
that
my
allusion
to
Mr
Carker
was
received
in
a
peculiar
manner
.
<EOS>
On
the
occasion
of
my
happening
to
point
out
to
you
,
before
that
confidential
agent
,
the
objection
I
had
to
your
mode
of
receiving
my
visitors
,
you
were
pleased
to
object
to
his
presence
.
<EOS>
You
will
have
to
get
the
better
of
that
objection
,
Madam
,
and
to
accustom
yourself
to
it
very
probably
on
many
similar
occasions
;
unless
you
adopt
the
remedy
which
is
in
your
own
hands
,
of
giving
me
no
cause
of
complaint
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
who
,
after
the
emotion
he
had
just
seen
,
set
great
store
by
this
means
of
reducing
his
proud
wife
,
and
who
was
perhaps
sufficiently
willing
to
exhibit
his
power
to
that
gentleman
in
a
new
and
triumphant
aspect
,
"
Mr
Carker
being
in
my
confidence
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
may
very
well
be
in
yours
to
such
an
extent
.
<EOS>
I
hope
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
"
he
continued
,
after
a
few
moments
,
during
which
,
in
his
increasing
haughtiness
,
he
had
improved
on
his
idea
,
"
I
may
not
find
it
necessary
ever
to
intrust
Mr
Carker
with
any
message
of
objection
or
remonstrance
to
you
;
but
as
it
would
be
derogatory
to
my
position
and
reputation
to
be
frequently
holding
trivial
disputes
with
a
lady
upon
whom
I
have
conferred
the
highest
distinction
that
it
is
in
my
power
to
bestow
,
I
shall
not
scruple
to
avail
myself
of
his
services
if
I
see
occasion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
he
thought
,
rising
in
his
moral
magnificence
,
and
rising
a
stiffer
and
more
impenetrable
man
than
ever
,
"
she
knows
me
and
my
resolution
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
hand
that
had
so
pressed
the
bracelet
was
laid
heavily
upon
her
breast
,
but
she
looked
at
him
still
,
with
an
unaltered
face
,
and
said
in
a
low
voice
:
  
"
<EOS>
Wait
!
<EOS>
For
God
's
sake
!
<EOS>
I
must
speak
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Why
did
she
not
,
and
what
was
the
inward
struggle
that
rendered
her
incapable
of
doing
so
,
for
minutes
,
while
,
in
the
strong
constraint
she
put
upon
her
face
,
it
was
as
fixed
as
any
statue
's
---
looking
upon
him
with
neither
yielding
nor
unyielding
,
liking
nor
hatred
,
pride
nor
humility
:
nothing
but
a
searching
gaze
?
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
ever
tempt
you
to
seek
my
hand
?
<EOS>
Did
I
ever
use
any
art
to
win
you
?
<EOS>
Was
I
ever
more
conciliating
to
you
when
you
pursued
me
,
than
I
have
been
since
our
marriage
?
<EOS>
Was
I
ever
other
to
you
than
I
am
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
wholly
unnecessary
,
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
to
enter
upon
such
discussions
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
think
I
loved
you
?
<EOS>
Did
you
know
I
did
not
?
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
care
,
Man
!
<EOS>
for
my
heart
,
or
propose
to
yourself
to
win
the
worthless
thing
?
<EOS>
Was
there
any
poor
pretence
of
any
in
our
bargain
?
<EOS>
Upon
your
side
,
or
on
mine
?
"
  
"
These
questions
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
are
all
wide
of
the
purpose
,
Madam
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
moved
between
him
and
the
door
to
prevent
his
going
away
,
and
drawing
her
majestic
figure
to
its
height
,
looked
steadily
upon
him
still
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
answer
each
of
them
.
<EOS>
You
answer
me
before
I
speak
,
I
see
.
<EOS>
How
can
you
help
it
;
you
who
know
the
miserable
truth
as
well
as
I
?
<EOS>
Now
,
tell
me
.
<EOS>
If
I
loved
you
to
devotion
,
could
I
do
more
than
render
up
my
whole
will
and
being
to
you
,
as
you
have
just
demanded
?
<EOS>
If
my
heart
were
pure
and
all
untried
,
and
you
its
idol
,
could
you
ask
more
;
could
you
have
more
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Possibly
not
,
Madam
,
"
he
returned
coolly
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
how
different
I
am
.
<EOS>
You
see
me
looking
on
you
now
,
and
you
can
read
the
warmth
of
passion
for
you
that
is
breathing
in
my
face
.
"
<EOS>
Not
a
curl
of
the
proud
lip
,
not
a
flash
of
the
dark
eye
,
nothing
but
the
same
intent
and
searching
look
,
accompanied
these
words
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
my
general
history
.
<EOS>
You
have
spoken
of
my
mother
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
you
can
degrade
,
or
bend
or
break
,
me
to
submission
and
obedience
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
smiled
,
as
he
might
have
smiled
at
an
inquiry
whether
he
thought
he
could
raise
ten
thousand
pounds
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
there
is
anything
unusual
here
,
"
she
said
,
with
a
slight
motion
of
her
hand
before
her
brow
,
which
did
not
for
a
moment
flinch
from
its
immovable
and
otherwise
expressionless
gaze
,
"
as
I
know
there
are
unusual
feelings
here
,
"
raising
the
hand
she
pressed
upon
her
bosom
,
and
heavily
returning
it
,
"
consider
that
there
is
no
common
meaning
in
the
appeal
I
am
going
to
make
you
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
for
I
am
going
;
"
she
said
it
as
in
prompt
reply
to
something
in
his
face
;
"
to
appeal
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
with
a
slightly
condescending
bend
of
his
chin
that
rustled
and
crackled
his
stiff
cravat
,
sat
down
on
a
sofa
that
was
near
him
,
to
hear
the
appeal
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
can
believe
that
I
am
of
such
a
nature
now
,
"
---
he
fancied
he
saw
tears
glistening
in
her
eyes
,
and
he
thought
,
complacently
,
that
he
had
forced
them
from
her
,
though
none
fell
on
her
cheek
,
and
she
regarded
him
as
steadily
as
ever
,
---
"
as
would
make
what
I
now
say
almost
incredible
to
myself
,
said
to
any
man
who
had
become
my
husband
,
but
,
above
all
,
said
to
you
,
<EOS>
you
may
,
perhaps
,
attach
the
greater
weight
to
it
.
<EOS>
In
the
dark
end
to
which
we
are
tending
,
and
may
come
,
we
shall
not
involve
ourselves
alone
(
that
might
not
be
much
)
but
others
.
"
  
<EOS>
Others
!
<EOS>
He
knew
at
whom
that
word
pointed
,
and
frowned
heavily
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
speak
to
you
for
the
sake
of
others
.
<EOS>
Also
your
own
sake
;
and
for
mine
.
<EOS>
Since
our
marriage
,
you
have
been
arrogant
to
me
;
and
I
have
repaid
you
in
kind
.
<EOS>
You
have
shown
to
me
and
every
one
around
us
,
every
day
and
hour
,
that
you
think
I
am
graced
and
distinguished
by
your
alliance
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
so
,
and
have
shown
that
too
.
<EOS>
It
seems
you
do
not
understand
,
or
(
so
far
as
your
power
can
go
)
intend
that
each
of
us
shall
take
a
separate
course
;
and
you
expect
from
me
instead
,
a
homage
you
will
never
have
.
"
  
<EOS>
Although
her
face
was
still
the
same
,
there
was
emphatic
confirmation
of
this
"
Never
"
in
the
very
breath
she
drew
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
feel
no
tenderness
towards
you
;
that
you
know
.
<EOS>
You
would
care
nothing
for
it
,
if
I
did
or
could
.
<EOS>
I
know
as
well
that
you
feel
none
towards
me
.
<EOS>
But
we
are
linked
together
;
and
in
the
knot
that
ties
us
,
as
I
have
said
,
others
are
bound
up
.
<EOS>
We
must
both
die
;
we
are
both
connected
with
the
dead
already
,
each
by
a
little
child
.
<EOS>
Let
us
forbear
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
took
a
long
respiration
,
as
if
he
would
have
said
,
Oh
!
<EOS>
was
this
all
!
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
wealth
,
"
she
went
on
,
turning
paler
as
she
watched
him
,
while
her
eyes
grew
yet
more
lustrous
in
their
earnestness
,
"
that
could
buy
these
words
of
me
,
and
the
meaning
that
belongs
to
them
.
<EOS>
Once
cast
away
as
idle
breath
,
no
wealth
or
power
can
bring
them
back
.
<EOS>
I
mean
them
;
I
have
weighed
them
;
and
I
will
be
true
to
what
I
undertake
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
promise
to
forbear
on
your
part
,
I
will
promise
to
forbear
on
mine
.
<EOS>
We
are
a
most
unhappy
pair
,
in
whom
,
from
different
causes
,
every
sentiment
that
blesses
marriage
,
or
justifies

,
is
rooted
out
;
but
in
the
course
of
time
,
some
friendship
,
or
some
fitness
for
each
other
,
may
arise
between
us
.
<EOS>
I
will
try
to
hope
so
,
if
you
will
make
the
endeavour
too
;
and
I
will
look
forward
to
a
better
and
a
happier
use
of
age
than
I
have
made
of
youth
or
prime
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Throughout
she
had
spoken
in
a
low
plain
voice
,
that
neither
rose
nor
fell
;
ceasing
<EOS>
,
she
dropped
the
hand
with
which
she
had
enforced
herself
to
be
so
passionless
and
distinct
,
but
not
the
eyes
with
which
she
had
so
steadily
observed
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
with
his
utmost
dignity
,
"
I
can
not
entertain
any
proposal
of
this
extraordinary
nature
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
looked
at
him
yet
,
without
the
least
change
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
rising
as
he
spoke
,
"
consent
to
temporise
or
treat
with
you
,
Mrs
Dombey
,
upon
a
subject
as
to
which
you
are
in
possession
of
my

and
expectations
.
<EOS>
I
have
stated
my
ultimatum
,
Madam
,
and
have
only
to
request
your
very
serious
attention
to
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
To
see
the
face
change
to
its
old
expression
,
deepened
in
intensity
!
<EOS>
To
see
the
eyes
droop
as
from
some
mean
and
odious
object
!
<EOS>
To
see
the
lighting
of
the
haughty
brow
!
<EOS>
To
see
scorn
,
anger
,
indignation
,
and
abhorrence
starting
into
sight
,
and
the
pale
blank
earnestness
vanish
like
a
mist
!
<EOS>
He
could
not
choose
but
look
,
although
he
looked
to
his
dismay
.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
,
Sir
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
pointing
with
an
imperious
hand
towards
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
Our
first
and
last
confidence
is
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
Nothing
can
make
us
stranger
to
each
other
than
we
are
henceforth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
take
my
rightful
course
,
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
undeterred
,
you
may
be
sure
,
by
any
general
declamation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
turned
her
back
upon
him
,
and
,
without
reply
,
sat
down
before
her
glass
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
place
my
reliance
on
your
improved
sense
of
duty
,
and
more
correct
feeling
,
and
better
reflection
,
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
She
answered
not
one
word
.
<EOS>
He
saw
no
more
expression
of
any
heed
of
him
,
in
the
mirror
,
than
if
he
had
been
an
unseen
spider
on
the
wall
,
or
beetle
on
the
floor
,
or
rather
,
than
if
he
had
been
the
one
or
other
,
seen
and
crushed
when
she
last
turned
from
him
,
and
forgotten
among
the
ignominious
and
dead
vermin
of
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
He
looked
back
,
as
he
went
out
at
the
door
,
upon
the
welllighted
and
luxurious
room
,
the
beautiful
and
glittering
objects
everywhere
displayed
,
the
shape
of
Edith
in
its
rich

seated
before
her

,
and
the
face
of
Edith
as
the
glass
presented
it
to
him
;
and
betook
himself
to
his
old
chamber
of
cogitation
,
carrying
away
with
him
a
vivid
picture
in
his
mind
of
all
these
things
,
and
a
rambling
and
unaccountable
speculation
(
such
as
sometimes
comes
into
a
man
's
head
)
<EOS>
how
they
would
all
look
when
he
saw
them
next
.
  
<EOS>
For
the
rest
,
Mr
Dombey
was
very
taciturn
,
and
very
dignified
,
and
very
confident
of
carrying
out
his
purpose
;
and
remained
so
.
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
design
accompanying
the
family
to
Brighton
;
but
he
graciously
informed
Cleopatra
at

,
on
the
morning
of

,
which
arrived
a

or
two

,
that
he
might
be
expected
down
,
soon
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
time
to
be
lost
in
getting
Cleopatra
to
any
place
recommended
as
being
salutary
;
for
,
indeed
,
she
seemed
upon
the
wane
,
and
turning
of
the
earth
,
earthy
.
  
<EOS>
Without
having
undergone
any
decided
second
attack
of
her
malady
,
the
old
woman
seemed
to
have
crawled
backward
in
her
recovery
from
the
first
.
<EOS>
She
was
more
lean
and
shrunken
,
more
uncertain
in
her
imbecility
,
and
made
stranger
confusions
in
her
mind
and
memory
.
<EOS>
Among
other
symptoms
of
this
last
affliction
,
she
fell
into
the
habit
of
confounding
the
names
of
her
two
sons
-
in
-
law
,
the
living
and
the
deceased
;
and
in
general
called
Mr
Dombey
,
either
"
Grangeby
,
"
or
"
Domber
,
"
or
indifferently
,
both
.
  
<EOS>
But
she
was
youthful
,
very
youthful
still
;
and
in
her
youthfulness
appeared
at
breakfast
,
before
going
away
,
in
a
new
bonnet
made
express
,
and
a
travelling
robe
that
was
embroidered
and
braided
like
an
old
baby
's
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
easy
to
put
her
into
a
fly
-
away
bonnet
now
,
or
to
keep
the
bonnet
in
its
place
on
the
back
of
her
poor
nodding
head
,
when
it
was
got
on
.
<EOS>
In
this
instance
,
it
had
not
only
the
extraneous
effect
of
being
always
on
one
side
,
but
of
being
perpetually
tapped
on
the
crown
by
Flowers
the
maid
,
who
attended
in

background

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dearest
Grangeby
,
"
said
Mrs
Skewton
,
"
you
must
posively
prom
,
<EOS>
"
she
cut
some
of
her
words
short
,
and
cut

,
"
come
down

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
said
just

,

,
"

,
loudly

,
"
that
I
am
coming
in
a

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
,
Domber
!
"
  
<EOS>
Here
the
Major
,
who
was

to

,
and

"
<EOS>
Begad
,

,

to

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sterious

,

's

?
"
lisped

.
<EOS>
But

from

,

,
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
You
mean

,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Devilish

,
Sir
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Bad

.
<EOS>
Never
did
wrap

;
"
the

.
<EOS>
"
Why

JB
mean
by
Joe
,
but
old
Joe

---
Joseph
---

---
Joe
,

?
<EOS>
Here!Here
's

man
!
<EOS>
Here

,

!
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

---
Grangeby
---

,
"

,

"

---
"
  
"
Bagstock
!
JB
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Edith
,

,

---
what

?
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
most
trordinry

that
so
many

to

.
<EOS>
I
'm

.
<EOS>
I
'm

.
<EOS>
Surely
they
can

,
till
I
come
back
!
"
  
<EOS>
Cleopatra
looked
all
round
the
table
as
she

,
and
appeared
very

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
have
visitors
---
really
do
n't

,
"
she

;
"
little

---
and
all

sort

---
is
what
I
quire
.
<EOS>
No

brutes
must
proach
me
till
I
've
shaken
off
this

;
"
and
in

,

Major
with

,
but
overset
Mr
Dombey
's
breakfast
cup
instead
,
which
was
in
quite
a
different
direction
.
  
<EOS>
Then
she
called
for
Withers
,
and
charged
him
to
see
particularly
that
word
was
left
about
some
trivial

in
her
room
,
which
must
be
all
made
before
she
came

,
and
which
must

set
about
immediately
,
as

was
no
saying
how
soon
she
might
come
back
;
for
she
had
a
great
many
engagements
,
and
all
sorts
of
people
to
call
upon
.
<EOS>
Withers
received
these
directions
with
becoming

,
and
gave
his

for
their
execution
;
but
when
he
withdrew
a
pace
or
two
behind
her
,
it
appeared
as
if
he
could
n't
help
looking
strangely
at
the
Major
,
who
could
n't
help
looking
strangely
at
Mr
Dombey
,
who
could
n't
help
looking
strangely
at
Cleopatra
,
who
could
n't
help
nodding
her
bonnet
over
one
eye
,
and
rattling
her
knife
and
fork
upon
her
plate
in
using
them
,
as
if
she
were
playing
castanets
.
  
<EOS>
Edith
alone
never
lifted
her
eyes
to
any
face
at
the
table
,
and
never
seemed
dismayed
by
anything
her
mother
said
or
did
.
<EOS>
She
listened
to
her
disjointed
talk
,
or
at
least
,
turned
her
head
towards
her
when
addressed
;
replied
in
a
few
low
words
when
necessary
;
and
sometimes
stopped
her
when
she
was
rambling
,
or
brought
her
thoughts
back
with
a
monosyllable
,
to
the
point
from
which
they
had
strayed
.
<EOS>
The
mother
,
however
unsteady
in
other
things
,
was
constant
in
this
---
that
she
was
always
observant
of
her
.
<EOS>
She
would
look
at
the
beautiful
face
,
in
its
marble
stillness
and
severity
,
now
with
a
kind
of
fearful
admiration
;
now
in
a
giggling
foolish
effort
to
move
it
to
a
smile
;
now
with
capricious
tears
and
jealous
shakings
of
her
head
,
as
imagining
herself
neglected
by
it
;
always
with
an
attraction
towards
it
,
that
never
fluctuated
like
her
other
ideas
,
but
had
constant
possession
of
her
.
<EOS>
From
Edith
she
would
sometimes
look
at
Florence
,
and
back
again
at
Edith
,
in
a
manner
that
was
wild
enough
;
and
sometimes
she
would
try
to
look
elsewhere
,
as
if
to
escape
from
her
daughter
's
face
;
but
back
to
it
she
seemed
forced
to
come
,
although
it
never
sought
hers
unless
sought
,
or
troubled
her
with
one
single
glance
.
  
<EOS>
The
breakfast
concluded
,
Mrs
Skewton
,
affecting
to
lean
girlishly
upon
the
Major
's
arm
,
but
heavily
supported
on
the
other
side
by
Flowers
the
maid
,
and
propped
up
behind
by
Withers
the
page
,
was
conducted
to
the
carriage
,
which
was
to
take
her
,
Florence
,
and
Edith
to
Brighton
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
is
Joseph
absolutely
banished
?
"
said
the
Major
,
thrusting
in
his
purple
face
over
the
steps
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Damme
,
Ma'am
,
is
Cleopatra
so
hard
-
hearted
as
to
forbid
her
faithful
Antony
Bagstock
to
approach
the
presence
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go
along
!
"
<EOS>
said
Cleopatra
,
"
I
ca
n't
bear
you
.
<EOS>
You
shall
see
me
when
I
come
back
,
if
you
are
very
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
Joseph
,
he
may
live
in

,
Ma'am
,
"
said
the
Major
;
"
or
he
'll
die
in

.
"
   
<EOS>
Cleopatra

,
and
leaned
back
.
<EOS>
"
Edith
,
my
dear
,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
Tell

---
"
  
"
What
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Such
dreadful
words
,
"
said
Cleopatra
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
uses
such
dreadful
words
!
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
signed
to
him
to
retire
,
gave
the
word
to
go

,
and
left
the
objectionable
Major
to
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
To
whom
he
returned
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
Major
,
with
his

,
and
his

very

asunder
,
"
a
fair

ours
has
removed

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
,
Major
?
"
inquired

Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
say
,
Dombey
,
"
returned
the
Major
,
"
that
you
'll
soon
be
an
orphan
-
in
-
law
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey

the

,
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
Damme
,

,
"

,
"
there

no
use
in

a

.
<EOS>
Joe

,

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
If

Josh

;
and
a
de

.
<EOS>
Dombey

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
After

,

,

"

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
Cleopatra
,
at
one

,

self

,
sometimes

,

,

,
fell

as

,

was
put
away
in

;
where

might

pictured
a

than
the
maid
,
who

one
,
watching
at
the
rose
-

,
which
were
carried
down
to

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
settled
in
high
council
of
medical

that
she
should
take
a
carriage
airing
every
day
,
and
that
it
was

should
get

every

,
and
walk
if
she

.
<EOS>
Edith
was
ready
to
attend

---
always
ready
to
attend
her
,
with
the
same
mechanical
attention
and
immoveable

---
and
they
drove

;
for
Edith
had
an

the

of
Florence
,
now
that
her
mother
was
worse
,
and
told
Florence
,
with
a

,
that
she
would

they
two

alone
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Skewton
,
on
one

,
was
in
the

,
exacting
,
jealous
temper
that
had
developed
itself
on
her

.
<EOS>
After

in

for
some

,
she
took
her

and
kissed

.
<EOS>
The
hand
was
neither
given
nor
withdrawn
,
but
simply
yielded
to
her
raising
of

,
and

,

down

,

.
<EOS>
At

she
began
to

,
and
say
what
a
mother
she
had
been
,
and
how
she
was

!
<EOS>
This

do

,

:

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a

,

,
and

out

Downs

.
<EOS>
The

,
with

,

from

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Almost

;

which

<EOS>
That

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

,

in

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
As

.
<EOS>
Not

,

,

.
<EOS>
They

,

,
as

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're

,
"

,

;
"
but
good

wo
n't

.
<EOS>
And
you
're

;

wo

.
<EOS>
We
had
need

meet

!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
41
.
<EOS>
New
Voices
in
the
Waves
 
<EOS>
ALL
is
going
on
as
it
was
wo
nt
.
<EOS>
The
waves
are
hoarse
with
repetition
of
their
mystery
;
the
dust
lies
piled
upon
the
shore
;
the
sea
-
birds
soar
and
hover
;
the
winds
and
clouds
go
forth
upon
their
trackless
flight
;
the
white
arms
beckon
,
in
the
moonlight
to
the
invisible
country
far
away
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
tender
melancholy
pleasure
,
Florence
finds
herself
again
on
the
old
ground
so
sadly
trodden
,
yet
so
happily
,
and
thinks
of
him
in
the
quiet
place
,
where
he
and
she
have
many
and
many
a
time
conversed
together
,
with
the
water
welling
up
about
his
couch
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
as
she
sits
pensive
there
,
she
hears
in
the
wild
low
murmur
of
the
sea
,
his
little
story
told
again
,
his
very
words
repeated
;
and
finds
that
all
her
life
and
hopes
,
and
griefs
,
since
---
in
the
solitary
house
,
and
in
the
pageant
it
has
changed
to
---
have
a
portion
in
the
burden
of
the
marvellous
song
.
  
<EOS>
And
gentle
Mr
Toots
,
who
wanders
at
a
distance
,
looking
wistfully
towards
the
figure
that
he
dotes
upon
,
and
has
followed
there
,
but
can
not
in
his
delicacy
disturb
at
such
a
time
,
likewise
hears
the
requiem
of
little
Dombey
on
the
waters
,
rising
and
falling
in
the
lulls
of
their
eternal
madrigal
in
praise
of
Florence
.
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
and
he
faintly
understands
,
poor
Mr
Toots
,
that
they
are
saying
something
of
a
time
when
he
was
sensible
of
being
brighter
and
not
addle
-
brained
;
and
the
tears
rising
in
his
eyes
when
he
fears
that
he
is
dull
and
stupid
now
,
and
good
for
little
but
to
be
laughed
at
,
diminish
his
satisfaction
in
their
soothing
reminder
that
he
is
relieved
from
present
responsibility
to
the
Chicken
,
by
the
absence
of
that
game
head
of
poultry
in
the
country
,
training
(
at
Toots
's
cost
)
for
his
great
mill
with
the
Larkey
Boy
.
  
<EOS>
But
Mr
Toots
takes
courage
,
when
they
whisper
a
kind
thought
to
him
;
and
by
slow
degrees
and
with
many
indecisive
stoppages
on
the
way
,
approaches
Florence
.
<EOS>
Stammering
and
blushing
,
Mr
Toots
affects
amazement
when
he
comes
near
her
,
and
says
(
having
followed
close
on
the
carriage
in
which
she
travelled
,
every
inch
of
the
way
from
London
,
loving
even
to
be
choked
by
the
dust
of
its
wheels
)
that
he
never
was
so
surprised
in
all
his
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
've
brought
Diogenes
,
too
,
Miss
Dombey
!
"
says
Mr
Toots
,
thrilled
through
and
through
by
the
touch
of
the
small
hand
so
pleasantly
and
frankly
given
him
.
  
<EOS>
No
doubt
Diogenes
is
there
,
and
no
doubt
Mr
Toots
has
reason
to
observe
him
,
for
he
comes
straightway
at
Mr
Toots
's
legs
,
and
tumbles
over
himself
in
the
desperation
with
which
he
makes
at
him
,
like
a
very
dog
of
Montargis
.
<EOS>
But
he
is
checked
by
his
sweet
mistress
.
  
<EOS>
"
Down
,
Di
,
down
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
remember
who
first
made
us
friends
,
Di
?
<EOS>
For
shame
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Well
may
Di
lay
his
loving
cheek
against
her
hand
,
and
run
off
,
and
run
back
,
and
run
round
her
,
barking
,
and
run
headlong
at
anybody
coming
by
,
to
show
his
devotion
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
would
run
headlong
at
anybody
,
too
.
<EOS>
A
military
gentleman
goes
past
,
and
Mr
Toots
would
like
nothing
better
than
to
run
at
him
,
full
tilt
.
  
<EOS>
"
Diogenes
is
quite
in
his
native
air
,
is
n't
he
,
Miss
Dombey
?
"
says
Mr
Toots
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
assents
,
with
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dombey
,
"
says
Mr

,
"
beg

,
but
if
you
would
like
to
walk
to
Blimber
's
,
I
---
I
'm
going

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
puts
her
arm
in
that
of
Mr
Toots
without
a

,
and
they
walk
away
together
,
with
Diogenes
going
on
before
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
's
legs
shake
under
him
;
and
though
he
is
splendidly
dressed
,
he
feels
misfits
,
and
sees
wrinkles
,
in
the
masterpieces
of
Burgess
and
Co.
,
and
wishes
he
had
put
on
that
brightest
pair
of
boots
.
  
<EOS>
Doctor
Blimber
's
house
,
outside
,
has
as
scholastic
and
studious
an
air
as
ever
:
and
up
there
is
the
window
where
she
used
to
look
for
the
pale
face
,
and
where
the
pale
face
brightened
when
it
saw
her
,
and
the
wasted
little
hand
waved
kisses
as
she
passed
.
<EOS>
The
door
is
opened
by
the
same
weakeyed
young
man
,
whose
imbecility
of
grin
at
sight
of
Mr
Toots
is
feebleness
of
character
personified
.
<EOS>
They
are
shown
into
the
Doctor
's
study
,
where
blind
Homer
and
Minerva
give
them
audience
as
of
yore
,
to
the
sober
ticking
of
the
great
clock
in
the
hall
;
and
where
the
globes
stand
still
in
their

,
as
if
the
world
were
stationary
too
,
and
nothing
in
it
ever
perished
in

to
the
universal
law
,
that
,
while
it
keeps
it
on
the
roll
,
calls
everything
to
earth
.
  
<EOS>
And
here
is
Doctor
Blimber
,
with
his
learned

;
and
here

Mrs
Blimber
,
with
her
sky

blue

;
and
here

Cornelia
,
with
her
sandy
little
row
of
curls
,
and
her
bright
spectacles
,
still
working
like
a

in
the
graves
of
languages
.
<EOS>
Here
is
the
table
upon
which
he
sat
forlorn
and

,
the
"
new
boy
"
of
the
school
;
and
hither

distant

of
the
old
boys
,
at
their
old
lives
in
the
old
room
on
the
old
principle
!
  
<EOS>
"
Toots
,
"
says
Doctor
Blimber
,
"
I
am
very

to
see
you
,
Toots
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
chuckles
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Also
to
see
you
,
Toots
,
in
such

,
"
says

.
  
<EOS>
Mr

,
with

,

by

,
and

Miss

,

,
to
see

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
like
,
"

,
"
to
step

,
Miss
Dombey
,
no

.
<EOS>
All

-

,
Toots
,
once
.
<EOS>
I

"

<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Bitherstone
is

.
"
  
<EOS>
New

,

,

;
for
,
in

,
Bitherstone
---
no

Master
Bitherstone
of
Mrs

's
---
shows
in

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
born
beneath
some

of
ill
-
omen
,

;
and
his

has
got
so
dropsical
from
constant

,
that
it
wo
n't
shut
,
and
yawns
as

really
could
not

.
<EOS>
So
does
Bitherstone
its

,
forced
at

's

;
but

of
Bitherstone
there

malice
and

,
and
he
has
been
heard
to
say
that
he
wishes

"
old
Blimber
"

.
<EOS>
He
'd
precious
soon

up

(
Bitherstone
's
)
Coolies
,
and
handed
over
to
the
Thugs
;
he

.
  
<EOS>
Briggs
is
still

in
the
mill

knowledge
;
and
Tozer
,
too
;
and
Johnson
,
too
;
and
all

rest
;
the

being

in

,

,
everything

.
<EOS>
All

as

;
and

,
Mr
Feeder
,
BA
,
with

,
is

hard

:
with

stop
on
just
at
present
,
and
his

barrels
on

.
  
<EOS>
A

is

,
even

,

;
who

,
as
one

has
passed

,
and
is

come

,
and

whose

,
and

whose

,

about
,
behind

;
the
bilious
Bitherstone
,
who
is
not
of
Mr
Toots
's
time
,
affecting
to
despise
the
latter
to
the

,
and
saying
he
knows

,
and
that

coming
that
sort

thing
in
Bengal
,
where
his
mother
has
got
an
emerald
belonging
to

that
was
taken

of
the
footstool
of
a

.
<EOS>
Come
now
!
  
<EOS>
Bewildering

are

also
by

Florence
,
with
whom

,

:
except
,

,

,

,
out

.
<EOS>
Black

of
Mr
Toots
arise
,
and
Briggs
is
of

that
he
an't
so

old
after

.
<EOS>
But

is

Mr
Feeder
,
BA
,
"

,
Feeder
?
"
and

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

's

;

,

,

and

<EOS>
withdraw

;

is

as

,

,
"
Gentlemen
,

.
<EOS>
"
For

is
what
the

hears
the
sea
say
,
or
has

all

.
  
<EOS>
Florence
then

away
and

old

Mrs

;
Mr
Toots
,

,

,

,

ever
thought

a

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Florence
soon
comes
down
and

;
Mr

takes

;
and
Diogenes
,
who
has
been

weak

,
shoots
out

,

;
while
'

,

,

"

,
"

of

,
"
<EOS>
But

though
,
now
---
ai

she
like
her
brother
<EOS>
,

prettier
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

,

saw

that

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

by

she

,

about

all
,

.
<EOS>
What
with
the

,

her

,

Mr
Dombey
's

,

Mr
Toots
must

,

not
a

of
free
-
will
left
;
when

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dombey
,

,
"

,

---
to
---
"
  
The

.
  
<EOS>
"

---

---

hope
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
Florence

.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dombey
,
"

Mr

,

in
for

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
I
am

.
<EOS>
If

was
n't
at
the
corner

the
Square
at
present
,
I

,

,

,

---

---
"
  
"

,

,

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
Mr

.
<EOS>
Stop
,

.
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
As

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
is
dreadfully

,
and

opens
.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,
"
I

,

to

you
for
being

kind

to

,
and
I
do

so
much
:
"
<EOS>
and
here
the
ingenuous
face
smiles

with

pleasantest

world
;
"
that
I
am

!
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly

,
"

,

---

---
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good

!
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-

,
Miss
Dombey
!
"
<EOS>
stammers

Toots
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
wo
n't

anything

.
<EOS>
It

---
<EOS>
it

no

,

.
<EOS>
It
's

least

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Mr
Toots
goes
home

Hotel
in

,
locks

,

,

;
as

,

.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Feeder
,
BA
,
is
coming
to

,
which
happens
well
for
Mr
Toots
,
or
there

no

when
he
might

.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
is
obliged
to
get
up
to

,

to

.
  
<EOS>
And

of
that

,
hospitality
(
to
make

of
wine
and
good

)
,
opens
Mr
Toots
's

,
and
warms

to

.
<EOS>
He

not

Mr
Feeder
,
BA
,
what
passed
at

corner

the
Square
;
but

Feeder
asks

"
When

?
"
<EOS>
Mr

,
"
that

certain
subjects
"
---
which

Mr
Feeder
down

peg

.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
adds
,
that
he
do
n't

what
right
Blimber
had
to

Miss

's

,

,

'd

out
,
Doctor

;

only

.
<EOS>
Mr
Feeder
says

no

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Feeder
,
however
,
as
an
intimate
friend
,
is
not

from

.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
merely
requires
that
it
should
be
mentioned
mysteriously
,
and

.
<EOS>
After
a
few
glasses
of
wine
,
he
gives
Miss
Dombey
's
health
,
observing
,
"
Feeder
,
you
have
no
idea
of
the
sentiments
with
which
I
propose
that
toast
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Feeder
replies
,
"
Oh
,
yes
,
I
have
,
my
dear
Toots
;
and
greatly
they
redound
to
your
honour
,
old
boy
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Feeder
is
then
agitated
by
friendship
,
and
shakes

;
and
says
,
if
ever
Toots
wants
a
brother
,
he
knows
where
to
find

,
either
by

.
<EOS>
Mr
Feeder
likewise

,
that
if
he
may

,
he
would

Mr
Toots
to
learn

,
or
,

;
for
women
like
music
,
when
you
are
paying
your
addresses
to
'em
,
and
he
has
found
the
advantage
of
it
himself
.
  
<EOS>
This
brings
Mr
Feeder
,
BA
,
to
the
confession
that
he
has
his
eye
upon
Cornelia
Blimber
.
<EOS>
He
informs
Mr
Toots
that
he
do
n't
object
to
spectacles
,
and
that
if
the
Doctor
were
to
do
the
handsome
thing
and
give
up
the
business
,
why
,
there
they
are
---
provided
for
.
<EOS>
He

it
's
his

that
when
a
man
has
made
a
handsome
sum
by
his
business
,
he
is
bound
to
give

;
and
that
Cornelia
would
be
an
assistance
in
it
which
any
man
might

.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots

by

out

Miss

's

,
and
by
insinuations
that
sometimes

should
like
to

.
<EOS>
Mr
Feeder
strongly

that
it
would

a

,
and
shows
him
,
as

to
existence
,
Cornelia
's
portrait
,
spectacles
and
all
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
these
quiet

pass
the

;
and
when

has
yielded
place

,
Mr
Toots
walks

Feeder
,
and
parts

's

.
<EOS>
But

Feeder

,

,

,

,

think

.
<EOS>
Mr
Feeder
plainly
hears
the
waves
informing
him
,
as
he
loiters
along
,
that
Doctor
Blimber
will
give

;
and

in

house
,
and
thinking
that
the
Doctor
will
first

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
is
likewise

,

;
and

,

a

a
light
,
and
which
he
has
no
doubt
<EOS>
is
Florence
's
.
<EOS>
But

is
not
,
for

Mrs

's
room
;
and
<EOS>
while

,

,

,

,

's

,

!
---

,

.
<EOS>
Ugly

;

,

.
<EOS>
What

,

<EOS>
"
Edith
,

?
<EOS>
Do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

!

<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Should

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Unmoved
?
"
<EOS>
looking

---
"

---

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sorry
!
<EOS>
You
seem

.
<EOS>
But

!
"
  
<EOS>
With

,
and
the
mother
she

,
and
the
mother
<EOS>
the
good

was
,

,

return
the

.
<EOS>

daughter
,
cries

her

going
,

.
  
<EOS>
Edith
,
in

,

.
<EOS>
The

,
  
<EOS>
"
Edith
!
<EOS>
we

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

---
what's
-
his

,

---
Major
---
that

,

<EOS>
Edith
!
"
<EOS>
with

"
it
's
not

.
"
  
<EOS>
Night

,
the

burn

,
and
the

lies
upon

bed
,
and
Edith
sits
beside

,
and
the
restless
waves
are
calling
to
them
both
the

long
.
<EOS>
Night
after
night
,
the
waves
are
hoarse
with
repetition
of
their

;
the
dust
lies
piled
upon

;
the
sea
-
birds

and

;
the
winds
and
clouds
are
on
their

;
the
white

,
in

,
to
the

country
far

.
  
<EOS>
And

the
sick
old
woman
looks
into

,
where
the
stone
arm
---
part
of
a
figure
of
some
tomb
,
she

---
is
raised
to
strike
her
.
<EOS>
At
last

falls
;
and
then
a
dumb
old
woman
lies
upon
the
bed
,
and
she
is
crooked
and
shrunk
up
,
and
half
of
her
is
dead
.
  
<EOS>
Such
is
the
figure
,
painted
and
patched
for
the
sun
to
mock
,
that
is
drawn

through
the
crowd
from
day
to

;
looking
,
as

,
for
the
good
old
creature
who
was
such
a
mother
,
and
making
mouths
as
it
peers
among
the
crowd
in
vain
.
<EOS>
Such
is
the
figure
that
is
often
wheeled
down
to
the
margin
of
the
sea
,
and
stationed
there
;
but
on
which
no
wind
can
blow
freshness
,
and
for
which
the
murmur
of
the
ocean
has
no

.
<EOS>
She
lies
and
listens
to
it
by
the
hour
;
but
its
speech
is
dark
and
gloomy
to
her
,
and
a
dread
is
on
her
face
,
and
when
her
eyes
wander
over
the
expanse
,
they
see
but
a
broad

of

between

and

.
  
<EOS>
Florence
she
seldom
sees
,
and
when
she
does
,
is
angry
with
and
mows
at
.
<EOS>
Edith
is
beside
her
always
,
and
keeps
Florence
away
;
and
Florence
,
in
her
bed
at

,
trembles
at
the
thought
of
death
in
such
a
shape
,
and
often
wakes
and
listens
,
thinking
it
has
come
.
<EOS>
No

attends
on
her
<EOS>
but
Edith
.
<EOS>
It
is
better
that
few
eyes
should
see
her
;
and
her
daughter
watches
alone

.
  
<EOS>
A

even

that

,

even

the

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
Her

upon

and

her
daughter
;

,

---

,
"
For
I

!
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
,

,

:
  
"
<EOS>
Mother
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
Staring

<EOS>
"
Can

night

I
married
?
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

then
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
Edith

<EOS>
A

<EOS>
Draw

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
Draw
the
rosecoloured

!
  
<EOS>
Intelligence

Mr

.
<EOS>
A

,

<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
My

!
<EOS>
She

.
"
   
<EOS>

.

"

.
<EOS>
I

.

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Therefore

,

;
"

"
Not

.
"
  
<EOS>
At

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Cousin
Feenix
,

-

,

so
catlike
and
vigilant
,
but
the
eye
of
his
great
chief
passed
from
that
,
as
from
the
others
,
and
appeared
no
more
impressed
by
it
than
by
the
rest
.
  
<EOS>
Carker
looked
at
it
---
it
was
the
picture
that
resembled
Edith
---
as
if
it
were
a
living
thing
;
and
with
a
wicked
,
silent
laugh
upon
his
face
,
that
seemed
in
part
addressed
to
it
,
though
it
was
all
derisive
of
the
great
man
standing
so
unconscious
beside
him
.
<EOS>
Breakfast
was
soon
set
upon
the
table
:
and
,
inviting
Mr
Dombey
to
a
chair
which
had
its
back
towards
this
picture
,
he
took
his
own
seat
opposite
to
it
as
usual
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
was
even
graver
than
it
was
his
custom
to
be
,
and
quite
silent
.
<EOS>
The
parrot
,
swinging
in
the
gilded
hoop
within
her
gaudy
cage
,
attempted
in
vain
to
attract
notice
,
for
Carker
was
too
observant
of
his
visitor
to
heed
her
;
and
the
visitor
,
abstracted
in
meditation
,
looked
fixedly
,
not
to
say
sullenly
,
over
his
stiff
neckcloth
,
without
raising
his
eyes
from
the
table
-
cloth
.
<EOS>
As
to
Rob
,
who
was
in
attendance
,
all
his
faculties
and
energies
were
so
locked
up
in
observation
of
his
master
,
that
he
scarcely
ventured
to
give
shelter
to
the
thought
that
the
visitor
was
the
great
gentleman
before
whom
he
had
been
carried
as
a
certificate
of
the
family
health
,
in
his
childhood
,
and
to
whom
he
had
been
indebted
for
his
leather
smalls
.
  
<EOS>
"
Allow
me
,
"
said
Carker
suddenly
,
"
to
ask
how
Mrs
Dombey
is
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
leaned
forward
obsequiously
,
as
he
made
the
inquiry
,
with
his
chin
resting
on
his
hand
;
and
at
the
same
time
his
eyes
went
up
to
the
picture
,
as
if
he
said
to
it
,
"
Now
,
see
,
how
I
will
lead
him
on
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
reddened
as
he
answered
:
  
"
Mrs
Dombey
is
quite
well
.
<EOS>
You
remind
me
,
Carker
,
of
some
conversation
that
I
wish
to
have
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Robin
,
you
can
leave
us
,
"
said
his
master
,
at
whose

Robin
started
and
disappeared
,
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
his
patron
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
remember
that
boy
,
of
course
?
"
he
added
,
when
the
immeshed
Grinder
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
with
magnificent

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
likely
that
a
man
like
you
would
.
<EOS>
Hardly
possible
,
"
murmured
Carker
.
"
<EOS>
But
he
is
one
of
that
family
from
whom
you
took
a
nurse
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
may
remember
having
generously
charged

his

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
that
boy
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
with
a

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
does
little
credit
to
his
education
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
he
is
a
young
rip
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
returned
Carker
,
with

.
"
<EOS>
He
bears
that
character
.
<EOS>
But
the
truth

,
I
took

into

because
,

able

,
he
conceived
(
had
been
taught

home
<EOS>
,
I
dare

)

,
and

dog

.
<EOS>
And

defined

,
still

,
<EOS>
that
---
"

,
as

led

Dombey
far

.
<EOS>
And

,

his

,

picture
.
  
<EOS>
"
Carker
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
I
am
sensible
that
you
do
not
limit
your
---
"
  
"
Service
,
"
suggested
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
prefer
to

your
regard
,
"
observed
Mr
Dombey
;
very
sensible
,
as

,
that

was

,
"
to
our

.
<EOS>
Your

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

to

,
Carker
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
bent
his

slowly
,
and
very

,
as
if
he
were

by
any

disturb

current
of
Mr
Dombey
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
allusion
to
it
is

,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,

;
"
for
it
prepares
the

to
what
I
was

to

,

that

no

between

,
although

may

more

than

hitherto
---
"
  
"
Distinguished
me
with
,
"
suggested
Carker
,
bending
his

again
:
"
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
to
you
how
honoured
I
am
;
for
a
man
like
you
well
knows
how
much

he

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mrs
Dombey
and
myself
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
passing
this

with
august
self
-

,
"
are
not
quite
agreed
upon
some
points
.
<EOS>
We
do
not
appear
to
understand
each
other
yet
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Dombey
has
something
to
learn
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mrs
Dombey
is
distinguished
by
many
rare
attractions
;
and
has
been
accustomed
,
no
doubt
,
to
receive
much
adulation
,
"
said
the
smooth
,
sleek
watcher
of
his
slightest
look
and

.
<EOS>
"
But
where
there
is
affection
,
duty
,
and
respect
,
any
little
mistakes
engendered
by
such
causes
are
soon
set

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's

instinctively
flew
back
to
the
face
that
had
looked
at
him
in
his
wife
's
dressing
-
room
,
when
an
imperious
hand
was
stretched
towards
the
door
;
and
remembering
the
affection
,
duty
,
and
respect
,
expressed
in

,

felt
the

rush
to
his
own

quite
as
plainly
as
the
watchful

upon

saw

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Dombey
and
myself
,
"
he
went
on
to
say
,
"
had
some
discussion
,
before
Mrs

's

,
upon
the
cause
of
my
dissatisfaction
;
of
which
you
will
have
formed

from
having

what
passed
between
Mrs
Dombeyand
myself
on
the

when
you

at

---
at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
so
much
regretted
being
present
,
"
said
the
smiling
Carker
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Proud
as
a
man
in
my
position
necessarily
must
be
of
your
familiar
notice
---
though
I
give
you
no
credit
for
it
;
you
may
do
anything
you
please
without
losing
caste
-
and
honoured

I

by
an
early

Mrs
Dombey
,

by
bearing
your
name
<EOS>
,
I
almost
regretted
that
night
,
I

,
that
I

such
especial

.
"
  
<EOS>
That

,

,
regret

his

,
was

which
Mr
Dombey
could
not

.
<EOS>
He
therefore
responded
,
with
a
considerable

.
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
<EOS>
And
why
,
Carker
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
,
"
returned
the
confidential
agent
,
"
that
Mrs
Dombey
,
never
very

regard
me
with
favourable

---
<EOS>
one

my
position
could
not
expect

,
from
a
lady
naturally
proud
,
and
whose
pride
becomes
her
so

---
may
not

forgive
my
innocent

in

.
<EOS>
Your

is
no
light

,
you

;
and

---
"
  
"
Carker
,
"

,

;
<EOS>
"
I

the

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Can

?
<EOS>
"
replied

other
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Dombey

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

?
"

?

"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
Mrs

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Dombey

,
"

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
I

Mrs

,
some

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Blended

,

,

picture

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
"

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Mrs

,

.
<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
Mrs

"
   
"

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
if

,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
in

of

;
"
and

I

Mrs
Dombey
does

,

.
<EOS>
There

;
that

:
Mrs

,
"

,

"

Me

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

,

,
"

Carker
,

<EOS>
"
You

,
"

Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope

.
<EOS>
Though
,

,

Dombey

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
delivered

with

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
That

greatly

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

Dombey
lived

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
first
Mrs
Dombey
had
great
good
sense
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
in
a
gentlemanly
toleration
of
the
dead
,
"
and
very
correct
feeling
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Miss
Dombey
like
her
mother
,
do
you
think
?
"
said
Carker
.
  
<EOS>
Swiftly
and
darkly
,
Mr
Dombey
's
face
changed
.
<EOS>
His
confidential
agent
eyed
it
keenly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
approached
a
painful
subject
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
soft
regretful
tone
of
voice
,
irreconcilable
with
his
eager
eye
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
forgive
me
.
<EOS>
I
forget
these
chains
of
association
in
the
interest
I
have
.
<EOS>
Pray
forgive
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
for
all
he
said
,
his
eager
eye
scanned
Mr
Dombey
's
downcast
face
none
the
less
closely
;
and
then
it
shot
a
strange
triumphant
look
at
the
picture
,
as
appealing
to
it
to
bear
witness
how
he
led
him
on
again
,
and
what
was
coming
.
  
<EOS>
"
Carker
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
looking
here
and
there
upon
the
table
,
and
speaking
in
a
somewhat
altered
and
more
hurried
voice
,
and
with
a
paler
lip
,
"
there
is
no
occasion
for
apology
.
<EOS>
You
mistake
.
<EOS>
The
association
is
with
the
matter
in
hand
,
and
not
with
any
recollection
,
as
you
suppose
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
approve
of
Mrs
Dombey
's
behaviour
towards
my
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,
"
I
do
n't
quite
understand
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Understand
then
,
"
returned
Mr
Dombey
,
"
that
you
may
make
that
---
that
you
will
make
that
,
if
you
please
---
matter
of
direct
objection
from
me
to
Mrs
Dombey
.
<EOS>
You
will
please
to
tell
her
that
her
show
of
devotion
for
my
daughter
is
disagreeable
to
me
.
<EOS>
It
is
likely
to
be
noticed
.
<EOS>
It
is
likely
to
induce
people
to
contrast
Mrs
Dombey
in
her
relation
towards
my
daughter
,
with
Mrs
Dombey
in
her
relation
towards
myself
.
<EOS>
You
will
have
the
goodness
to
let
Mrs
Dombey
know
,
plainly
,
that
I
object
to
it
;
and
that
I
expect
her
to
defer
,
immediately
,
to
my
objection
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Dombey
may
be
in
earnest
,
or
she
may
be
pursuing
a
whim
,
or
she
may
be
opposing
me
;
but
I
object
to
it
in
any
case
,
and
in
every
case
.
<EOS>
If
Mrs
Dombey
is
in
earnest
,
so
much
the
less
reluctant
<EOS>
should
she
be
to
desist
;
for
she
will
not
serve
my
daughter
by
any
such
display
.
<EOS>
If
my
wife
has
any
superfluous
gentleness
and
duty
over
and
above
her
proper
submission
to
me
,
she
may
bestow
themwhere
<EOS>
she
pleases
,
perhaps
;
but
I
will
have
submission
first
!
<EOS>
---
Carker
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
checking
the
unusual
emotion
with
which
he
had
spoken
,
and
falling
into
a
tone
more
like
that
in
which
he
was
accustomed
to
assert
his
greatness
,
"
you
will
have
the
goodness
not
to
omit
or
slur
this
point
,
but
to
consider
it
a
very
important
part
of
your
instructions
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
bowed
his
head
,
and
rising
from
the
table
,
and
standing
thoughtfully
before
the
fire
,
with
his
hand
to
his
smooth
chin
,
looked
down
at
Mr
Dombey
with
the
evil
slyness
of
some
monkish
carving
,
half
human
and
half
brute
;
or
like
a
leering

on
an
old
water
-

.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
recovering
his
composure
by
degrees
,
or
cooling
his
emotion
in
his
sense
of
having
taken
a
high
position
,
sat
gradually

again
,
and
looking
at
the
parrot
as
she
swung
to
and
fro
,
in
her
great

ring
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
said
Carker
,
after
a

,

his

,
and
drawing

opposite
to
Mr
Dombey
's
,
"
but
let
me
understand
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Dombey
is
aware
of

of
your
making
me
the
organ

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
rejoined
Carker
,

;
"
but
why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
!
"
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
repeated
,
not
without
hesitation
.
"
Because
I
told
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
"
replied
Carker
.
<EOS>
"
But
why
did
you
tell
her
?
<EOS>
You
see
,
"
he
continued
with
a

,
and

,

,

;
"
if
I
perfectly
understand
what
is

,
I
am
so
much
more
likely
to
be
useful
,
and
to
have

being
effectually
employed
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
do
understand
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
honour
of
Mrs
Dombey
's
good
opinion
.
<EOS>
In
my
position
,
I
have
no

to
expect
it
;
but
I
take
the

,
that
I
have

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Possibly
not
,
"

Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Consequently
,
"
pursued
Carker
,
"
your

to
Mrs
Dombey
through
me
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"
said

Dombey
,
with

,

yet

"

Mrs

's
views
upon
the

form
no

as

you

,
Carker
.
<EOS>
But

may

so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
---

---
do

,
"

,
"

descry

,
a

humbling
Mrs
Dombey
's
pride
---
I
use

as

of

which
,

,
adorns

---
and
,
not

of

,
but

<EOS>
you

?
"
   
"
I

,
Carker
,

,
"

,
"
to

such

for
any

conduct
<EOS>
I
think

,
but

.
<EOS>
If

to
found

,
that

,

will

.
<EOS>
But
I

,
I

,

,

---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
degraded
!
"

Carker
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In

!
<EOS>
"
  
"
---
or

place

,
"
pursued
Mr
Dombey
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
in
a
false

!
"

Carker
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall

---

---

.
<EOS>
I
could

,

,

my

---
for

<EOS>
---
<EOS>
no

;

,

.
<EOS>
Besides

,

,
I

,

,

---
<EOS>
my

---

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
seemed
,
at
the
moment
,
again
to
see
her
with
her
hand
<EOS>
stretched

the

,
and

,
"
Nothing

!
"
<EOS>
But

shook
off

fancy
,
and
did

in

,
and

,
"
Certainly
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

,

---
for

---
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,
"
but
this
.
<EOS>
You
will

,
Carker
,
that
no

to
Mrs
Dombey
with
which

or

,

.
<EOS>
You
will
be
good

to
bring
me
no

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Dombey
is
informed
that
it
does
not
become
me
to
temporise
or
treat
upon
any
matter
that
is
at
issue
between
us
,
and
that
what
I
say
is
final
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
signified
his
understanding
of
these
credentials
,
and
they
fell
to
breakfast
with
what
appetite
they
might
.
<EOS>
The
Grinder
also
,
in
due
time
,
reappeared
,
keeping
his
eyes
upon
his
master
without
a
moment
's
respite
,
and
passing
the
time
in
a
reverie
of
worshipful
terror
.
<EOS>
Breakfast
concluded
,
Mr
Dombey
's
horse
was
ordered
out
again
,
and
Mr
Carker
mounting
his
own
,
they
rode
off
for
the
City
together
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
was
in
capital
spirits
,
and
talked
much
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
received
his
conversation
with
the
sovereign
air
of
a
man
who
had
a
right
to
be
talked
to
,
and
occasionally
condescended
to
throw
in
a
few
words
to
carry
on
the
conversation
.
<EOS>
So
they
rode
on
characteristically
enough
.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Dombey
,
in
his
dignity
,
rode
with
very
long
stirrups
,
and
a
very
loose
rein
,
and
very
rarely
deigned
to
look
down
to
see
where
his
horse
went
.
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
which
it
happened
that
Mr
Dombey
's
horse
,
while
going
at
a
round
trot
,
stumbled
on
some
loose
stones
,
threw
him
,
rolled
over
him
,
and
lashing
out
with
his
iron
-
shod
feet
,
in
his
struggles
to
get
up
,
kicked
him
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
,
quick
of
eye
,
steady
of
hand
,
and
a
good
horseman
,
was
afoot
,
and
had
the
struggling
animal
upon
his
legs
and
by
the
bridle
,
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Otherwise
that
morning
's
confidence
would
have
been
Mr
Dombey
's
last
.
<EOS>
Yet
even
with
the
flush
and
hurry
of
this
action
red
upon
him
,
he
bent
over
his
prostrate
chief
with
every
tooth
disclosed
,
and
muttered
as
he
stooped
down
<EOS>
,
"
I
have
given
good
cause
of
offence
to
Mrs
Dombey
now
,
if
she
knew
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
being
insensible
,
and
bleeding
from
the
head
and
face
,
was
carried
by
certain
menders
of
the
road
,
under
Carker
's
direction
,
to
the
nearest
public
-
house
,
which
was
not
far
off
,
and
where
he
was
soon
attended
by
divers
surgeons
,
who
arrived
in
quick
succession
from
all
parts
,
and
who
seemed
to
come
by
some
mysterious
instinct
,
as
vultures
are
said
to
gather
about
a
camel
who
dies
in
the
desert
.
<EOS>
After
being
at
some
pains
to
restore
him
to
consciousness
,
these
gentlemen
examined
into
the
nature
of
his
injuries
.
<EOS>
One
surgeon
who
lived
hard
by
was
strong
for
a
compound
fracture
of
the
leg
,
which
was
the
landlord
's
opinion
also
;
but
two
surgeons
who
lived
at
a
distance
,
and
were
only
in
that
neighbourhood
by
accident
,
combated
this
opinion
so
disinterestedly
,
that
it
was
decided
at
last
that
the
patient
,
though
severely
cut
and
bruised
,
had
broken
no
bones
but
a
lesser
rib
or
so
,
and
might
be
carefully
taken
home
before
night
.
<EOS>
His
injuries
being
dressed
and
bandaged
,
which
was
a
long
operation
,
and
he
at
length
left
to
repose
,
Mr
Carker
mounted
his
horse
again
,
and
rode
away
to
carry
the
intelligence
home
.
  
<EOS>
Crafty
and
cruel
as
his
face
was
at
the
best
of
times
,
though
it
was
a
sufficiently
fair
face
as
to
form
and
regularity
of
feature
<EOS>
,
it
was
at
its
worst
when
he
set
forth
on
this
errand
;
animated
by
the
craft
and
cruelty
of
thoughts
within
him
,
suggestions
of
remote
possibility
rather
than
of
design
or
plot
,
that
made
him
ride
as
if
he
hunted
men
and
women
.
<EOS>
Drawing
rein
at
length
,
and
slackening
in
his
speed
,
as
he
came
into
the
more
public
roads
,
he
checked
his
white
-
legged
horse
into
picking
his
way
along
as
usual
,
and
hid
himself
beneath
his
sleek
,
hushed
,
crouched
manner
,
and
his
ivory
smile
,
as
he
best
could
.
  
<EOS>
He
rode
direct
to
Mr
Dombey
's
house
,
alighted
at
the
door
,
and
begged
to
see
Mrs
Dombey
on
an
affair
of
importance
.
<EOS>
The
servant
who
showed
him
to
Mr
Dombey
's
own
room
,
soon
returned
to
say
that
it
was
not
Mrs
Dombey
's
hour
for
receiving
visitors
,
and
that
he
begged
pardon
for
not
having
mentioned
it
before
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
,
who
was
quite
prepared
for
a
cold
reception
,
wrote
upon
a
card
that
he
must
take
the
liberty
of
pressing
for
an
interview
,
and
that
he
would
not
be
so
bold
as
to
do
so
,
for
the
second
time
(
this
he
underlined
)
,
if
he
were
not
equally
sure
of
the
occasion
being
sufficient
for
his
justification
.
<EOS>
After
a
trifling
delay
,
Mrs
Dombey
's
maid
appeared
,
and
conducted
him
to
a
morning
room
upstairs
,
where
Edith
and
Florence
were
together
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
never
thought
Edith
half
so
beautiful
before
.
<EOS>
Much
as
he
admired
the
graces
of
her
face
and
form
,
and
freshly
as
they
dwelt
within
his
sensual
remembrance
,
he
had
never
thought
her
half
so
beautiful
.
  
<EOS>
Her
glance
fell
haughtily
upon
him
in
the
doorway
;
but
he
looked
at
Florence
---
though
only
in
the
act
of
bending
his
head
,
as
he
came
in
---
with
some
irrepressible
expression
of
the
new
power
he
held
;
and
it
was
his
triumph
to
see
the
glance
droop
and
falter
,
and
to
see
that
Edith
half
rose
up
to
receive
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
very
sorry
<EOS>
,
he
was
deeply
grieved
;
he
could
n't
say
with
what
unwillingness
he
came
to
prepare
her
for
the
intelligence
of
a
very
slight
accident
.
<EOS>
He
entreated
Mrs
Dombey
to
compose
herself
.
<EOS>
Upon
his
sacred
word
of
honour
,
there
was
no
cause
of
alarm
.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Dombey
  
Florence
uttered
a
sudden
cry
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
look
at
her
,
but
at
Edith
.
<EOS>
Edith
composed
and
reassured
her
.
<EOS>
She
uttered
no
cry
of
distress
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
had
met
with
an
accident
in
riding
.
<EOS>
His
horse
had
slipped
,
and
he
had
been
thrown
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
wildly
exclaimed
that
he
was
badly
hurt
;
that
he
was
killed
!
  
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Upon
his
honour
,
Mr
Dombey
,
though
stunned
at
first
,
was
soon
recovered
,
and
though
certainly
hurt
was
in
no
kind

danger
.
<EOS>
If
this
were
not
the
truth
,
he
,
the
distressed
intruder
,
never

had

present

before
Mrs
Dombey
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
truth

,
he
solemnly
assured

.
  
<EOS>
All

he
said
as
if
he
were

Edith
,
and
not

,
and
with
his

his

.
  
<EOS>
He
then
went
on
to

where

Dombey
was

and
to

that
a
carriage

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mama
,
"
faltered

in

"
if

might

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
,
having
his

on

,
gave

a
secret

.
<EOS>
He
saw

she
battled

she
answered

with
her
handsome

,
but
he
wrested

answer
from
her
<EOS>
---
he
showed

that

would

,
or

Florence
to

---
and
she

.
<EOS>
As

had

picture
in

,
so
he
looked

,
when
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
directed
to
request
,
"
he

,
"
that
the
new
housekeeper
---
Mrs
Pipchin
,
I
think
,

---
"
  
Nothing

.
<EOS>
He
saw
in

instant
,
that
she
was
another
slight
of
Mr
Dombey
's
on

wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
may

Dombey

,

.
<EOS>
I
shall
return

Mr
Dombey
almost

.
<EOS>
That

,
and

,
I

.
<EOS>
Let

,

.
<EOS>
Even

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
bowed

,
with

;
and

Dombey
's

,
and
there

a
carriage

sent

to
the
City
,
mounted

again
,
and
rode

.
<EOS>
He
was
very
thoughtful
as
he
went
along
,
and
very
thoughtful
there
,
and
very
thoughtful
in
the
carriage
on

Mr
Dombey
had

.
<EOS>
It

only
when

by
that

's

that
he
was
quite
himself
again
,
and
conscious
of
his
teeth
.
  
<EOS>
About
the
time
of
twilight
,
Mr
Dombey
,
grievously

with
aches
and
pains
,
was
helped
into

,
and
propped

and

on
one

,
while
his
confidential
agent
bore
him
company
upon
the
other
.
<EOS>
As
he
was
not
to
be
shaken
,
they
moved
at
little
more
than
a
foot
pace
;
and
hence
it
was
quite
dark
when
he
was
brought
home
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
,
bitter
and
grim
,
and
not
oblivious
of
the
Peruvian
mines
,
as
the
establishment
in
general
had
good
reason
to
know
,
received
him
at
the
door
,
and
freshened
the
domestics
with
several
little

of
wordy
vinegar
,
while
they
assisted
in

him
to

room
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
remained
in
attendance
until
he
was
safe
in
bed
,
and
then
,
as
he
declined
to
receive
any
female
visitor
,
but
the
excellent
Ogress
who
presided
over
his

,
waited
on
Mrs
Dombey
once
more
,
with
his
report
on
her

's

.
  
<EOS>
He
again
found
Edith
alone
with
Florence
,
and
he
again
addressed
the
whole
of
his
soothing
speech
to
Edith
,
as
if
she
were
a
prey
to
the
liveliest
and
most

.
<EOS>
So
earnest
he
was
in
his
respectful

,
that
on

,
he
ventured
---
with
one
more

towards
Florence
at
the
moment
---
to
take
her
hand
,
and
bending
over
it
,
to
touch
it
with
his
lips
.
  
<EOS>
Edith
did
not
withdraw
the
hand
,
nor
did
she
strike
his
fair
face
with
it
,
despite
the
flush
upon
her
cheek
,
the
bright
light
in
her
eyes
,
and
the
dilation
of
her
whole
form
.
<EOS>
But
when
she
was
alone
in
her
own
room
,
she
struck
it
on
the
marble
chimney
-
shelf
,
so
that
,
at
one
blow
,
it
was
bruised
,
and
bled
;
and
held
it
from
her
,
near
the
shining
fire
,
as
if
she
could
have
thrust
it
in
and
burned
it
.
  
<EOS>
Far
into
the
night
she
sat
alone
,
by
the
sinking
blaze
,
in
dark
and
threatening
beauty
,
watching
the
murky
shadows
looming
on
the
wall
,
as
if
her
thoughts
were
tangible
,
and
cast
them
there
.
<EOS>
Whatever
shapes
of
outrage
and
affront
,
and
black
foreshadowings
of
things
that
might
happen
,
flickered
,
indistinct
and
giant
-
like
,
before
her
,
one
resented
figure
marshalled
them
against
her
.
<EOS>
And
that
figure
was
her
husband
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
43
.
<EOS>
The
Watches
of
the
Night
 
FLORENCE
,
long
since
awakened
from
her
dream
,
mournfully
observed
the
estrangement
between
her
father
and
Edith
,
and
saw
it
widen
more
and
more
,
and
knew
that
there
was
greater
bitterness
between
them
every
day
.
<EOS>
Each
day
's
added
knowledge
deepened
the
shade
upon
her
love
and
hope
,
roused
up
the
old
sorrow
that
had
slumbered
for
a
little
time
,
and
made
it
even
heavier
to
bear
than
it
had
been
before
.
  
<EOS>
It
had
been
hard
---
how
hard
may
none
but
Florence
ever
know
!
---
to
have
the
natural
affection
of
a
true
and
earnest
nature
turned
to
agony
;
and
slight
,
or
stern
repulse
,
substituted
for
the
tenderest
protection
and
the
dearest
care
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
hard
to
feel
in
her
deep
heart
what
she
had
felt
,
and
never
know
the
happiness
of
one
touch
of
response
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
much
more
hard
to
be
compelled
to
doubt
either
her
father
or
Edith
,
so
affectionate
and
dear
to
her
,
and
to
think
of
her
love
for
each
of
them
,
by
turns
,
with
fear
,
distrust
,
and
wonder
.
  
<EOS>
Yet
Florence
now
began
to
do
so
;
and
the
doing
of
it
was
a
task
imposed
upon
her
by
the
very
purity
of
her
soul
,
as
one
she
could
not
fly
from
.
<EOS>
She
saw
her
father
cold
and
obdurate
to
Edith
,
as
to
her
;
hard
,
inflexible
,
unyielding
.
<EOS>
Could
it
be
,
she
asked
herself
with
starting
tears
,
that
her
own
dear
mother
had
been
made
unhappy
by
such
treatment
,
and
had
pined
away
and
died
?
<EOS>
Then
she
would
think
how
proud
and
stately
Edith
was
to
every
one
but
her
,
with
what
disdain
<EOS>
she
treated
him
,
how
distantly
she
kept
apart
from
him
,
and
what
she
had
said
on
the
night
when
she
came
home
;
and
quickly
it
would
come
on
Florence
,
almost
as
a
crime
,
that
she
loved
one
who
was
set
in
opposition
to
her
father
,
and
that
her
father
knowing
of
it
,
must
think
of
her
in
his
solitary
room
as
the
unnatural
child
who
added
this
wrong
to
the
old
fault
,
so
much
wept
for
,
of
never
having
won
his
fatherly
affection
from
her
birth
.
<EOS>
The
next
kind
word
from
Edith
,
the
next
kind
glance
,
would
shake
these
thoughts
again
,
and
make
them
seem
like
black
ingratitude
;
for
who
<EOS>
but
she
had
cheered
the
drooping
heart
of
Florence
,
so
lonely
and
so
hurt
,
and
been
its
best
of
comforters
!
<EOS>
Thus
,
with
her
gentle
nature
yearning
to
them
both
,
feeling
the
misery
of
both
,
and
whispering
doubts
of
her
own
duty
to
both
,
Florence
in
her
wider

,
and
by

Edith
,
endured
more
than
when
she
had

in
the

,
and
her

Mama
had
never

upon
it
.
  
<EOS>
One
exquisite
unhappiness
that
would
have
far
outweighed
this
,
Florence
was
spared
.
<EOS>
She
never
had
the
least
suspicion
that
Edith
by
her

for
her
widened
the
separation
from
her
father
,
or
gave

dislike
.
<EOS>
If

had
conceived

possibility
of
such
an
effect
being
wrought
by
such

,
what

she
would
have
felt
,
what

would
have
tried
to
make
,
poor
loving
girl
,
how
fast
and
sure
her
quiet
passage
might
have
been
beneath
it
to
the
presence
of
that
higher
Father
who
does
not
reject
his
children
's
love
,
or
spurn
their
tried
and
broken
hearts
,
Heaven
knows!But
<EOS>
it
was
otherwise
,
and
that
was
well
.
  
<EOS>
No
word
was
ever
spoken
between
Florence
and
Edith
now
,
on
these
subjects
.
<EOS>
Edith
had
said
there
ought
to
be
between
them
,
in
that
wise
,
a
division
and
a
silence
like
the
grave
itself
:
and
Florence
felt
that
she
was
right
.
  
<EOS>
In
this
state
of
affairs
her
father
was
brought
home
suffering
and
disabled
:
and
gloomily
retired
to
his
own
rooms
,
where
he
was
tended
by

,
not
approached
by
Edith
,
and
had
no
friend
or
companion
but
Mr
Carker
,
who
withdrew
near
midnight
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
nice
company
he
is
,
Miss
Floy
,
"
said
Susan
Nipper
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
he
's
a
precious

of

!
<EOS>
If
ever
he
wants
a
character
do
n't
let
him
come
to
me
whatever
he
does
<EOS>
,

's
all
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Susan
,
"
urged

,
"
do

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
very
well
to

"
do

"
Miss
Floy
,
"
returned

,
much

"
but

're

,

.
<EOS>
Do

,
Miss
Floy
<EOS>
,

ma
-

-
law
who
has

as

<EOS>
should

high

I

!
)
<EOS>
we

!
"
  
<EOS>

Papa

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
Pray

n't
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
Miss

,
"

,
"
when

,
I
never
do
I
hope
<EOS>
but
Mrs
Pipchin
acts
like
early
gooseberries
upon
me
Miss
,
and
nothing
less
.
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
was
unusually
emphatic
and
destitute
of

in
her
discourse
on
this

,
which
was

night

Mr
Dombey
's

,

,

,

Mrs
Pipchin
;
who
,

in
to
Mr
Dombey
,

to
return
what
Miss
Nipper

a

,
on
her

.
<EOS>
This
,
Susan
Nipper
construed
into
presumption

that

by
the

,
and
a
deed

upon

,
that

;

<EOS>

"

late
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Edith
,
fondly
putting
back
the
curls
that
mingled
with
her
own
dark
hair
,
and
strayed
upon
her
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
late
.
<EOS>
Near
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Near
day
!
<EOS>
"
she
repeated
in
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Mama
,
what
have
you
done
to
your
hand
?
"
said
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
Edith
drew
it
suddenly
away
,
and
,
for
a
moment
,
looked
at
her
with
the
same
strange
dread
<EOS>
(
there
was
a
sort

wild
avoidance
in
it
)
as
before
;
but
she
presently
said
,
"
Nothing
,
nothing
.
<EOS>
A
blow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
then
she
said
,
"
<EOS>
My
Florence
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
her
bosom
heaved
,
and
she
was
weeping
passionately
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mama
!
"
said
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
Mama
,
what
can
I
do
,
what
should
I
do
,
to
make
us
happier
?
<EOS>
Is
there
anything
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
sure
of
that
?
<EOS>
Can
it
never
be
?
<EOS>
If
I
speak
now
of
what
is
in

,

what
we
have
agreed
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
you
will
not

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
useless
,
"
she
replied
,
"
useless
.
<EOS>
I
have
told
you
,
dear
,
that
I
have
had
bad
dreams
.
<EOS>
Nothing
can
change
them
,
or
prevent
their
coming
back
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
understand
,
"
said
Florence
,
gazing
on
her
agitated
face
,
which
seemed
to
darken
as
she
looked
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
dreamed
,
"
said
Edith
in
a
low
voice
,
"
of
a
pride
that
is
all
powerless
for
good
,
all
powerful
for
evil
;
of
a
pride
that
has
been
galled
and
goaded
,
through
many
shameful
years
,
and
has
never
recoiled
except
upon
itself
;
a
pride
that
has
debased
its
owner
with
the
consciousness
of
deep
humiliation
,
and
never
helped
its
owner
boldly
to
resent
it
or
avoid
it
,
or
to
say
,
"
This
shall
not
be
!
"
<EOS>
a
pride
that
,
rightly

,
might
have
led
perhaps
to
better
things
,
but
which
,
misdirected
and
perverted
,
like
all

to
the
same

,
has
been
self
-
contempt
,
mere
hardihood
,
and
ruin
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
neither
looked
nor
spoke
to
Florence
now
,
but
went
on
as
if
she
were
alone
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
dreamed
,
"
she
said
,
"
of
such
indifference
and
callousness
,
arising

this
self

;
this
wretched
,
inefficient

miserable

;
that
it
has
gone
on
with
listless

even
to
the
altar
,
yielding
to
the
old
,
familiar
,
beckoning
finger
,
---
<EOS>
oh
mother
,
<EOS>
oh
mother
!
<EOS>
---
while
it
spurned
it
;
and
willing
to
be
hateful
to
itself
for
once

for
all
,
rather
than
to
be
stung
daily
in
some
new
form
.
<EOS>
Mean
,
poor
thing
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
now
with
gathering
and
darkening

,
she
looked
as
she
had
looked
when
Florence
entered
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
have
dreamed
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
in
a
first
late

to

,
it
has
been
trodden

,
and
trodden

by

,
but

upon

.
<EOS>
I
have

that
it
is
wounded
,

,
set
upon

dogs
,
but
that
it
stands
at

,
and
will
not

;
<EOS>
no
,
that
it
can
not
if
it
would
;
but
that
it
is
urged
on
to
hate
him
,
rise

him
,
and
defy

!
"
  
<EOS>
Her
clenched

on

trembling

she
had
in
hers
,
and
as

looked

on
the
alarmed
and

face
,
her
own
subsided
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
Florence
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
I
think
I
have
been
nearly
mad
to
-
night
!
"
and
humbled
her
proud
head
upon
her
neck
,
and
wept
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
leave
me
!
<EOS>
be
near
me
!
<EOS>
I
have
no
hope
but
in
you
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
These
words
she
said
a
score
of
times
.
  
<EOS>
Soon
she
grew
calmer
,
and
was
full
of
pity
for
the
tears
of
Florence
,
and
for
her
waking
at
such
untimely

.
<EOS>
And
the
day
now
drawing
,
Edith
folded
her
in
her
arms
and
laid
her
down
upon
her
bed
,
and
,
not
lying
down
herself
,
sat
by
her
,
and
bade
her
try
to
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
you
are
weary
,
dearest
,
and
unhappy
,
and
should
rest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
indeed
unhappy
,
dear
Mama
,
to
-
night
,
"
said
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
weary
and
unhappy
,
too
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
when
you
lie
asleep
so
near
me
,
sweet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
kissed
each
other
,
and
Florence
,
worn

,
gradually
fell
into
a
gentle
slumber
;
but
as
her

closed
on
the
face

her
,
it
was
so
sad
to
think
upon
the
face
down
stairs
,
that
her
hand
drew
closer
to
Edith
for
some
comfort
;
yet
,
even
in
the
act
,
it
faltered
,
lest
it
should
he
deserting
him
.
<EOS>
So
,
in
her

,
she
tried
to
reconcile
the
two
together
,
and
to
show
them
that
she
loved
them
both
,
but
could
not
do
it
,
and
her
waking
grief
was
part
of
her
dreams
.
   
<EOS>
Edith
,
sitting
by
,
looked
down
at
the
dark
eyelashes
lying
wet
on
the
flushed
cheeks
,
and
looked
with
gentleness
and
pity
,
for
she
knew
the
truth
.
<EOS>
But
no
sleep
hung
upon
her
own
eyes
.
<EOS>
As
the
day
came
on
she
still
sat
watching
and
waking
,
with
the
placid
hand
in
hers
,
and
sometimes

,
as
she
looked
at
the
hushed
face
,
"
Be
near
me
,
Florence
,
I
have
no
hope
<EOS>
but
in
you
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
44
.
<EOS>
A
Separation
 
WITH
the
day
,
though
not
so
early
as
the
sun
,
uprose
Miss
Susan
Nipper
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
heaviness
in
this
young
maiden
's
exceedingly
sharp
black
eyes
,
that
abated
somewhat
of
their
sparkling
,
and
suggested
---
which
was
not
their
usual
character
---
the
possibility
of
their
being
sometimes
shut
.
<EOS>
There
was
likewise
a
swollen
look
about
them
,
as
if
they
had
been
crying
over
-
night
.
<EOS>
But
the
Nipper
,
so
far
from
being
cast
down
,
was
singularly
brisk
and
bold
,
and
all
her
energies
appeared
to
be
braced
up
for
some
great
feat
.
<EOS>
This
was
noticeable
even
in
her
dress
,
which
was
much
more
tight
and
trim
than
usual
;
and
in
occasional
twitches
of
her
head
as
she
went
about
the
house
,
which
were
mightily
expressive
of
determination
.
  
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
she
had
formed
a
determination
,
and
an
aspiring
one
:
it
being
nothing
less
than
this
---
to
penetrate
to
Mr
Dombey
's
presence
,
and
have
speech
of
that
gentleman
alone
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
often
said
I
would
,
"
she
remarked
,
in
a
threatening
manner
,
to
herself
,
that
morning
,
with
many
twitches
of
her
head
,
"
and
now
I
will
!
"
  
<EOS>
Spurring
herself
on
to
the
accomplishment
of
this
desperate
design
,
with
a
sharpness
that
was
peculiar
to
herself
,
Susan
Nipper
haunted
the
hall
and
staircase
during
the
whole
forenoon
,
without
finding
a
favourable
opportunity
for
the
assault
.
<EOS>
Not
at
all
baffled
by
this
discomfiture
,
which
indeed
had
a
stimulating
effect
,
and
put
her
on
her
mettle
,
she
diminished
nothing
of
her
vigilance
;
and
at
last
discovered
,
towards
evening
,
that
her
sworn
foe
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
,
under
pretence
of
having
sat
up
all
night
,
was
dozing
in
her
own
room
,
and
that
Mr
Dombey
was
lying
on
his
sofa
,
unattended
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
twitch
---
not
of
her
head
merely
,
this
time
,
but
of
her
whole
self
---
the
Nipper
went
on
tiptoe
to
Mr
Dombey
's
door
,
and
knocked
.
<EOS>
"
Come
in
!
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
Susan
encouraged
herself
with
a
final
twitch
,
and
went
in
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
who
was
eyeing
the
fire
,
gave
an
amazed
look
at
his
visitor
,
and
raised
himself
a
little
on
his
arm
.
<EOS>
The
Nipper
dropped
a
curtsey
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
Sir
,
I
wish
to
speak
to
you
.
"
said
Susan
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
moved
his
lips
as
if
he
were
repeating
the
words
,
but
he
seemed
so
lost
in
astonishment
at
the
presumption
of
the
young
woman
as
to
be
incapable
of
giving
them
utterance
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
in
your
service
,
Sir
,
"
said
Susan
Nipper
,
with
her
usual
rapidity
,
"
now
twelve
year
a
waiting
on
Miss
Floy
<EOS>
my
own
young
lady
who
could
n't
speak
plain
when
I
first
come
here
<EOS>
and
I
was
old
in
this
house
when
Mrs
Richards
was
new
<EOS>
,
I
may
not
be
Meethosalem
,
but
I
am
not
a
child
in
arms
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
raised
upon
his
arm
and
looking
at
her
,
offered
no
comment
on
this
preparatory
statement
of
facts
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
never
was
a
dearer
or
a
blesseder
young
lady
than
is
my
young
lady
,
Sir
,
"
said
Susan
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
ought
to
know

great
deal
better
than
some
for
<EOS>
I
have
seen
her
in
her

<EOS>
and
I

in
her
joy
<EOS>
(
there
's

)
and
I

seen

brother
<EOS>
and
I
have

and
some
have
never

,
and
I
say
to
some
and
all
---
I
do
!
"
<EOS>
and
here
the
black
-
eyed
shook
her
head
,
and
slightly
stamped
her
foot
;
"
that
she
's
blessedest
and
dearest
angel
is
Miss
Floy
that
ever
drew
the

,
the
more
that
I
was
torn

pieces
Sir
<EOS>
the
more
I
'd
say
it
though
I
may
not
be
a
Fox
's
Martyr
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
turned
yet
paler
than
his
fall
had
made
him
,
with
indignation
and
astonishment
;
and
kept

upon
the
speaker
as
if

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
one
could
be
anything
but
true

to
Miss
Floy
,
Sir
,
"
pursued

,
"
and
I
take
no
merit
for
my

of
twelve
year
,
for
I
love
her
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
yes
,
I
say
to
some

all
I
do
!
"
<EOS>
---
and
here
the
black
-
eyed
shook
her
head
again
,
and
slightly
stamped
her
foot
again
,
and
checked
a
sob
;
"
but
true
and
faithful
service
gives
me
right
to
speak
<EOS>
I
hope
,
and
speak
I
must
and
will
now
,
right

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you

,
woman
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
,

.
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
dare
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
I

,

,

,
but
out
,
and
how
I
dare
<EOS>
I
know
<EOS>
not
<EOS>
but
I

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
do
n't
know
my
young
lady
<EOS>
Sir
you
do
n't
indeed
,
you
'd
never
know
so
little
of
her
,
if
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
in
a

,
put

the
bell

;
but
there

on
that

fire
,
and
he
could
not
rise
and
cross
to

without

.
<EOS>
The
quick
eye
of
the
Nipper
detected
his

immediately
,
and
now
,
as
she
afterwards
observed
,
she
felt
she
had
got
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Floy
,
"
said
Susan
Nipper
,
"
is
the
most
devoted
and
most
patient
and
most
dutiful
and
beautiful
of
daughters
,
there
an't
<EOS>
no
gentleman
,
no
Sir
,
though
as
great
and

as
all
the

and

of
England
put
together
,
but
might
be
proud
of
her
and
would
and
ought
.
<EOS>
If
he

her
value
right
,
he
'd
rather
lose
his
greatness
and
his

piece
by

and
beg
his
way
in
rags
from
door
to
door
,
I
say
to
some
and
all
,
he
would
!
"
<EOS>
cried

Nipper
,
bursting
into

,
"
than
bring
the
sorrow
on
her
tender
heart
that
I
have
seen
it
suffer
in
this
house
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Woman
,
"
cried
Mr
Dombey
,
"
leave
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Begging
your
pardon
,
not
even
if
I
am
to
leave
the
situation
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
steadfast
Nipper
,
"
in
which
I
have
been
so
many
years
and
seen

much
---
although
I
hope
you
'd
never

heart

send
me
from
Miss
Floy
for
such
a
cause
<EOS>
---
will
I
go
now
till
I
have
said
the
rest
,

which
was
opportunely
broken
by
the
voice
of
Mrs
Pipchin
talking
down
stairs
;
on
hearing
which
,
she
dried
her
red
and
swollen
eyes
,
and
made
a
melancholy
feint
of
calling
jauntily
to
Mr
Towlinson
to
fetch
a
cab
and
carry
down
her
boxes
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
,
pale
and
hurried
and
distressed
,
but
withheld
from
useless
interference
even
here
,
by
her
dread
of
causing
any
new
division
between
her
father
and
his
wife
(
whose
stern
,
indignant
face
had
been
a
warning
to
her
a
few
moments
since
)
,
and
by
her
apprehension
of
being
in
some
way
unconsciously
connected
already
with
the
dismissal
of
her
old
servant
and
friend
,
followed
,
weeping
,
down
stairs
to
Edith
's
dressingroom
,
whither
Susan
betook
herself
to
make
her
parting
curtsey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
here
's
the
cab
,
and
here
's
the
boxes
,
get
along
with
you
,
do
!
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
,
presenting
herself
at
the
same
moment
.
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
ma'am
,
but
Mr
Dombey
's
orders
are
imperative
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
,
sitting
under
the
hands
of
her
maid
<EOS>
---
she
was
going
out
to
dinner
---
preserved
her
haughty
face
,
and
took
not
the
least
notice
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
your
money
,
"
said
Mrs
Pipchin
,
who
in
pursuance
of
her
system
,
and
in
recollection
of
the
mines
,
was
accustomed
to
rout
the
servants
about
,
as
she
had
routed
her
young
Brighton
boarders
;
to
the
everlasting
acidulation
of
Master
Bitherstone
,
"
and
the
sooner
this
house
sees
your
back
the
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
had
no
spirits
even
for
the
look
that
belonged
to
Mrs
Pipchin
by
right
;
so
she
dropped
her
curtsey
to
Mrs
Dombey
(
who
inclined
her
head
without
one
word
,
and
whose
eye
avoided
every
one
but
Florence
)
,
and
gave
one
last
parting
hug
to
her
young
mistress
,
and
received
her
parting
embrace
in
return
.
<EOS>
Poor
Susan
's
face
at
this
crisis
,
in
the
intensity
of
her
feelings
and
the
determined
suffocation
of
her
sobs
,
lest
one
should
become
audible
and
be
a
triumph
to
Mrs
Pipchin
,
presented
a
series
of
the
most
extraordinary
physiognomical
phenomena
ever
witnessed
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Miss
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
said
Towlinson
,
outside
the
door
with
the
boxes
,
addressing
Florence
,
"
but
Mr
Toots
is
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
sends
his
compliments
,
and
begs
to
know
how
Diogenes
and
Master
is
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Quick
as
thought
,
Florence
glided
out
and
hastened
down
stairs
,
where
Mr
Toots
,
in
the
most
splendid
vestments
,
was
breathing
very
hard
with
doubt
and
agitation
on
the
subject
of
her
coming
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
how
de
do
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
God
bless
my
soul
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
last
ejaculation
was
occasioned
by
Mr
Toots
's
deep
concern
at
the
distress
he
saw
in
Florence
's
face
;
which
caused
him
to
stop
short
in
a
fit
of
chuckles
,
and
become
an
image
of
despair
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Mr
Toots
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
you
are
so
friendly
to
me
,
and
so
honest
,
that
I
am
sure
I
may
ask
a
favour
of
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dombey
,
"
returned
Mr
Toots
,
"
if
you
'll
only
name
one
,
<EOS>
you
'll
---
you
'll
give
me
an
appetite
.
<EOS>
To
which
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
with
some
sentiment
,
"
I
have
long
been
a
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Susan
,
who
is
an
old
friend
of

,
the
oldest
friend

have
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
is
about
to
leave
here

,
and
quite
alone
,
poor
girl
.
<EOS>
She
is
going
home
,
a
little
way
into
the
country
.
<EOS>
Might
I
ask
you
to
take
care

her
until
she
is
in

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Miss
Dombey
,
"
returned
Mr
Toots
,
"
you
really
do
me
an
honour
and

.
<EOS>
This
proof
of
your
confidence
,
after
the
manner

I
was
Beast

to

---
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
"
said

,

---
<EOS>
"
no
---
do

.
<EOS>
Then

---
to

?
<EOS>
and

?
<EOS>
Thank

<EOS>
a

.
<EOS>
She
does

.
<EOS>
You

,
or
what
a
good
friend
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
And
Florence
in
her
earnestness
thanked
him
again
and
again
;
and
Mr
Toots
,
in
his
earnestness
,
hurried
away
---
but
backwards
,
that
he
might
lose
no
glimpse
of
her
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
had
not
the
courage
to
go
out
,
when
she
saw
poor
Susan
in
the
hall
,
with
Mrs
Pipchin
driving
her
forth
,
and
Diogenes
jumping
about
her
,
and
terrifying
Mrs
Pipchin
to
the
last

by
making
snaps
at
her
bombazeen
skirts
,
and
howling
with
anguish
at
the
sound
of
her
voice
---
for
the
good
duenna
was
the
dearest
and
most
cherished
aversion
of
his
breast
.
<EOS>
But
she
saw
Susan
shake
hands
with
the
servants
all
round
,
and
turn
once
to
look
at
her
old
home
;
and
she
saw
Diogenes
bound
out
after
the
cab
,
and
want
to
follow
it
,
and
testify
an
impossibility
of
conviction
that
he
had
no
longer
any
property
in
the
fare
;
and
the
door
was
shut
,
and
the
hurry
over
,
and
her
tears
flowed
fast
for
the
loss
of
an
old
friend
,
whom
no
one
could
replace
.
<EOS>
No
one
.
<EOS>
No
one
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
,
like
the
leal
and
trusty
soul
<EOS>
he
was
,
stopped
the
cabriolet
in
a

,
and
told
Susan
Nipper
of
his
commission
,
at
which
she
cried
more
than
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
soul
and
body
!
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
taking

beside
her
,
"
I
feel
for
you
.
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
and
honour
I
think
you
can
hardly
know
your
own
feelings
better
than
I
imagine
them
.
<EOS>
I
can
conceive
nothing
more
dreadful
than
to
have
to
leave
Miss
Dombey
.
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
abandoned
herself
to
her
grief
now
,
and
it
really
was
touching
to
see
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
now
,
do
n't
!
<EOS>
at
least
I
mean
now
do
,
you
know
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
what
,
Mr
Toots
?
"
cried

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
come
home
to
my

,
and
have

,
"
said
Mr
Toots
.
<EOS>
"
My
cook
's
a
most

woman
---
one
of

I

---
and
she
'll

to

.
<EOS>
Her
son
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
as

,
"
was
educated
in
the
Blue
-

School
,
and
blown
up
in
a

-
