.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
accepting
this
kind
offer
,
Mr
Toots
conducted
her
to
his
dwelling
,
where
they
were
received
by
the
Matron
in
question
who
fully
justified
his
character
of
her
,
and
by
the
Chicken
,
who
at
first
supposed
,
on
seeing
a
lady
in
the
vehicle
,
that
Mr
Dombey
had
been
doubled
up
,
agreeably
to
his
old
recommendation
,
and
Miss
Dombey
abducted
.
<EOS>
This
gentleman
awakened
in
Miss
Nipper
some
considerable
astonishment
;
for
,
having
been
defeated
by
the
Larkey
Boy
,
his
visage
was
in
a
state
of
such
great
dilapidation
,
as
to
be
hardly
presentable
in
society
with
comfort
to
the
beholders
.
<EOS>
The
Chicken
himself
attributed
this
punishment
to
his
having
had
the
misfortune
to
get
into
Chancery
early
in
the
proceedings
,
when
he
was
severely
fibbed
by
the
Larkey
one
,
and
heavily
grassed
.
<EOS>
But
it
appeared
from
the
published
records
of
that
great
contest
that
the
Larkey
Boy
had
had
it
all
his
own
way
from
the
beginning
,
and
that
the
Chicken
had
been
tapped
,
and
bunged
,
and
had
received
pepper
,
and
had
been
made
groggy
,
and
had
come
up
piping
,
and
had
endured
a
complication
of
similar
strange
inconveniences
,
until
he
had
been
gone
into
and
finished
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
good
repast
,
and
much
hospitality
,
Susan
set
out
for
the
coach
-
office
in
another
cabriolet
,
with
Mr
Toots
inside
,
as
before
,
and
the
Chicken
on
the
box
,
who
,
whatever
distinction
he
conferred
on
the
little
party
by
the
moral
weight
and
heroism
of
his
character
,
was
scarcely
ornamental
to
it
,
physically
speaking
,
on
account
of
his
plasters
;
which
were
numerous
.
<EOS>
But
the
Chicken
had
registered
a
vow
,
in
secret
,
that
he
would
never
leave
Mr
Toots
(
who
was
secretly
pining
to
get
rid
of
him
)
,
for
any
less
consideration
than
the
good
-
will
and
fixtures
of
a
public
-
house
;
and
being
ambitious
to
go
into
that
line
,
and
drink
himself
to
death
as
soon
as
possible
,
he
felt
it
his
cue
to
make
his
company
unacceptable
.
   
<EOS>
The
night
-
coach
by
which
Susan
was
to
go
,
was
on
the
point
of
departure
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
having
put
per
inside
,
lingered
by
the
window
,
irresolutely
,
until
the
driver
was
about
to
mount
;
when
,
standing
on

,
and
putting
in
a
face
that
by

of

lamp
was
anxious
and

,
he
said

:
  
"
I
say
,
Susan
!
<EOS>
Miss
Dombey
,
you
know
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

she
could
---
you
know
---
eh
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Mr
Toots
,
"
said

,
"
but
<EOS>
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,

---

,

<EOS>
There

"

.
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
Ne
---

!
"
  
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Good

.
<EOS>
It

,

!
"
    
Chapter
45
.
<EOS>
The
Trusty
Agent
 
EDITH
went
out
alone
that
day
,
and
returned
home
early
.
<EOS>
It
was
but
a
few
minutes
after
ten
o'clock
,
when
her
carriage
rolled
along
the
street
in
which
she
lived
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
the
same
enforced
composure
on
her
face
,
that
there
had
been
when
she
was
dressing
;
and
the
wreath
upon
her
head
encircled
the
same
cold
and
steady
brow
.
<EOS>
But
it
would
have
been
better
to
have
seen
its
leaves
and
flowers
reft
into
fragments
by
her
passionate
hand
,
or
rendered
shapeless
by
the
fitful
searches
of
a
throbbing
and
bewildered
brain
for
any
resting
-
place
,
than
adorning
such
tranquillity
.
<EOS>
So
obdurate
,
so
unapproachable
,
so
unrelenting
,
one
would
have
thought
that
nothing
could
soften
such
a
woman
's
nature
,
and
that
everything
in
life
had
hardened
it
.
  
<EOS>
Arrived
at
her
own
door
,
she
was
alighting
,
when
some
one
coming
quietly
from
the
hall
,
and
standing
bareheaded
,
offered
her
his
arm
.
<EOS>
The
servant
being
thrust
aside
,
she
had
no
choice
but
to
touch
it
;
and
she
then
knew
whose
arm
it
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
is
your
patient
,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
with
a
curled
lip
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
better
,
"
returned
Carker
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
doing
very
well
.
<EOS>
I
have
left
him
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
bent
her
head
,
and
was
passing
up
the
staircase
,
when
he
followed
and
said
,
speaking
at
the
bottom
:
  
"
Madam
!
<EOS>
May
I
beg
the
favour
of
a
minute
's
audience
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
stopped
and
turned
her
eyes
back
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
an
unreasonable
time
,
Sir
,
and
I
am
fatigued
.
<EOS>
Is
your
business
urgent
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
urgent
,
"
returned
Carker
.
<EOS>
"
As
I
am
so
fortunate
as
to
have
met
you
,
let
me
press
my
petition
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
looked
down
for
a
moment
at
his
glistening
mouth
;
and
he
looked
up
at
her
,
standing
above
him
in
her
stately
dress
,
and
thought
,
again
,
how
beautiful
she
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Miss
Dombey
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
the
servant
,
aloud
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
the
morning
room
,
Ma'am
.
"
  
"
Show
the
way
there
!
"
<EOS>
Turning
her
eyes
again
on
the
attentive
gentleman
at
the
bottom
of
the
stairs
,
and
informing
him
with
a
slight
motion
of
her
head
,
that
he
was
at
liberty
to
follow
,
she
passed
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
!
<EOS>
Madam
!
<EOS>
Mrs
Dombey
!
"
cried
the
soft
and
nimble
Carker
at
her
side
in
a
moment
.
"
<EOS>
May
I
be
permitted
to
entreat
that
Miss
Dombey
is
not
present
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
confronted
him
,
with
a
quick
look
,
but
with
the
same
self
-
possession
and
steadiness
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
spare
Miss
Dombey
,
"
said
Carker
,
in
a
low
voice
,
"
the
knowledge
of
what
I
have
to
say
.
<EOS>
At
least
,
Madam
,
I
would
leave
it
to
you
to
decide
whether
she
shall
know
of
it
or
not
.
<EOS>
I
owe
that
to
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
my
bounden
duty
to
you
.
<EOS>
After
our
former
interview
,
it
would
be
monstrous
in
me
if
I
did
otherwise
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
slowly
withdrew
her
eyes
from
his
face
,
and
turning
to
the
servant
,
said
,
"
<EOS>
Some
other
room
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
led
the
way
to
a
drawing
-
room
,
which
he
speedily
lighted
up
and
then
left
them
.
<EOS>
While
he
remained
,
not
a
word
was
spoken
.
<EOS>
Edith
enthroned
herself
upon
a
couch
by
the
fire
;
and
Mr
Carker
,
with
his
hat
in
his
hand
and
his
eyes
bent
upon
the

,
stood
before
her
,
at
some
little
distance
.
  
<EOS>
"
Before
I
hear
you
,
Sir
,
"
said
Edith
,
when
the
door
was
closed
,
"
I
wish
you
to
hear
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
be
addressed
by
Mrs
Dombey
,
"
he
returned
,
"
even
in
accents
of
unmerited
reproach
,
is
an
honour
I
so
greatly
esteem
,
that
although
I
were
not
her
servant
in
all
things
,
I
should
defer
to
such
a
wish
,
most
readily
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
charged
by
the
man
whom
you
have
just
now
left
,
Sir
;
"
Mr
Carker
raised
his

,
as
if

were

,
but
she
met
them
,
and
stopped
him
,
if
such
were
his
intention
;
"
with
any
message
to
me
,
do
not
attempt
to
deliver

,
for
I
will
not
receive

.
<EOS>
I
need
scarcely
ask
you
if
you
are
come
on
such
an
errand
.
<EOS>
I
have
expected
you
some
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
misfortune
,
"
he

,
"
to
be
here
,
wholly
against
my

,
for
such

.
<EOS>
Allow
me
to
say
that
I
am
here
for
two
purposes
.
<EOS>
That
is
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
one
,
Sir
,
"
she
returned
,
"
is
ended
.
<EOS>
Or
,
if
you
return
to
it
"
  
"
Can
Mrs
Dombey
believe
,
"
said
Carker
,
coming
nearer
,
"
that
I
would
return
to
it
in
the
face
of
her
prohibition
?
<EOS>
Is
it
possible
that
Mrs
Dombey
,
having
no
regard
to
my
unfortunate
position
,
is
so
determined
to
consider
me
inseparable
from
my
instructor
as
to
do
me
great
and
wilful
injustice
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returned
Edith
,
bending
her
dark
gaze
full
upon
him
,
and
speaking
with
a
rising
passion
that
inflated
her
proud
nostril
and
her
swelling
neck
,
and
stirred
the
delicate
white
down
upon
a
robe
she
wore
,
thrown
loosely
over
shoulders
that
could
bear
its
snowy
neighbourhood
.
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
present
yourself
to
me
,
as
you
have
done
,
and
speak
to
me
of
love
and
duty
to
my
husband
,
and
pretend
to
think
that
I
am
happily
married
,
and
that
I
honour
him
?
<EOS>
How
dare
you
venture
so
to
affront
me
,
when
you
know
<EOS>
---
I
do
not
know
better
,
Sir
:
I
have
seen
it
in
your
every
glance
,
and
heard
it
in
your
every
word
---
that
in
place
of
affection
between
us
<EOS>
there
is
aversion
and
contempt
,
and
that
I
despise
him
hardly
less
than
I
despise
myself
for
being
his
!
<EOS>
Injustice
!
<EOS>
If
I
had
done
justice
to
the
torment
you
have
made
me
feel
,
and
to
my
sense
of
the
insult
you
have
put
upon
me
,
I
should
have
slain
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
asked
him
why
he
did
this
.
<EOS>
Had
she
not
been
blinded
by
her
pride
and
wrath
,
and
self
-
humiliation
,
---
which
she
was
,
fiercely
as
she
bent
her

upon
him
,
---
she
would
have
been
the
answer
in
his
face
.
<EOS>
To
bring
her
to
this
declaration
.
  
<EOS>
She
saw
it
not
,
and
cared
not
whether
it
was
there
or
no
.
<EOS>
She
saw
only
the
indignities
and
struggles
she
had
undergone
,
and
had
to
undergo
,
and
was
writhing
under
them
.
<EOS>
As
she
sat
looking
fixedly
at
them
,
rather
than

him
,
she
plucked
the

from
a
pinion
of
some
rare

beautiful

,
which
hung
from
her
wrist
by
a
golden
thread
,
to
serve
her
as

fan
,
and
rained
them
on
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
shrink
beneath
her
gaze
,
but
stood
,
until
such
outward
signs
of
her
anger
as
had
escaped
her
control
subsided
,
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
had
his
sufficient
reply
in
reserve
and
would
presently
deliver
it
.
<EOS>
And
he
then
spoke
,
looking
straight
into
her
kindling

.
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
know
,
and
knew
before
to
-
day
,
that
I
have
found
no
favour
with
you
;
and
I
knew
why
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
knew
why
.
<EOS>
You
have
spoken
so
openly
to
me
;
I
am
so
relieved
by
the
possession
of
your
confidence
"
  
"
Confidence
!
"
<EOS>
she
repeated
,
with
disdain
.
  
<EOS>
He
passed
it
over
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
that
I
will
make
no

of
concealment
.
<EOS>
I
did
see
from
the
first
,
that
there
was
no
affection
on
your
part
for
Mr
Dombey
<EOS>
---
how

possibly
exist
between
such
different

?
<EOS>
And
I
have
seen
,
since
,
that
stronger
feelings
than
indifference
have
been
engendered
in
your
breast
<EOS>
---
how
could
that
possibly
be
otherwise
,
either
,

as
you
have

?
<EOS>
But
was
it

to
presume

avow
this
knowledge

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was

,
Sir
,
"

,

,
and

thrust

one
<EOS>
me

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
it
was
,
"
he

.
"
If
I

,

,

,

first

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
To

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

,
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Counsellor
,
---

,
"

.
<EOS>
Flatterer
,
---
no
.
<EOS>
A
little
reservation
<EOS>
I
fear
I
must
confess
to
.
<EOS>
But
our
interest
and

commonly
oblige
many

us
to

that
we
can
not

.
<EOS>
We
have
partnerships
of
interest
and
convenience
,
friendships
of
interest
and
convenience
,
dealings
of
interest
and
convenience
,
marriages
of
interest
and
convenience
,
every

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
bit
her
blood

red

;
but
without

in

dark
,
stern

she
kept

.
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Carker
,

,
with

,
<EOS>
"
why
should

,

,

?
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
had
never
any

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
proud
undaunted
face
showed
him
it
was
resolute
to
wear
no
mask
he
offered
,
but
was
set
upon
a
reckless

of
itself
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
At

,
"

,
"
that

should
deem

quite

with
Mr
Dombey
as
his
wife
,
at
once
without

,

.
<EOS>
But
,
Madam
,
you
did
not

Mr
Dombey
(
as
you
have
since
ascertained
)
,
when
you
thought
that
.
<EOS>
You
did
not
know
how
exacting
and
how
proud
he
is
,
or
how
he
is
,
if
I
may

so
,
the
slave
of
his
own

,
and
goes
yoked
to
his
own

like

of

,
with
no
idea
on
earth
<EOS>
but
that
it
is
behind

and
is
to

drawn

,
over
everything
and
through

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
teeth
gleamed
through
his
malicious

of
this
conceit
,
as
he
went
on
talking
:
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dombey
is
really
capable
of
no

true

for
you
,
Madam
,

.
<EOS>
The

is
an

;
I

to

;
but
quite
just
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
in
the

,

---
I
had
it
from
his
own
lips
yesterday

---
to

his

to
you
,
because

,

;

,
that

,

,

---

;

no

---
<EOS>
but

,
a

,
to

.
<EOS>
You
may

how
regardless

me
,

any

he

,

,

,

I

so

.
<EOS>
You

how
perfectly
indifferent

your

he

,

.
<EOS>
As
you
,
of

,
have

that

did
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
watched
him
still
attentively
.
<EOS>
But
he
watched
her
too
;
and
he
saw
that
this
indication
of
a
knowledge
on
his
part
,
of
something
that
had
passed
between
herself
and
her
husband
,
rankled

in

,
like

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
recall
all
this
to

breach
between
yourself
and
Mr
Dombey
,
Madam
---
<EOS>
Heaven
forbid
!
<EOS>
what
would
it
profit
me
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
but
as
an
example
of
the
hopelessness
of
impressing
Mr
Dombey
with
a
sense
that
anybody
is
to
be
considered
when
he
is

.
<EOS>
We
who
are
about
him
,
have
,
in

various

,
done
our
part
,
I
dare

,
to
confirm

;
but

,
others
would
---
or

not

been
about
him
;
and
it
has
always
been
from

,
the

.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
has
had
to
deal
,
in

,
with
none
but
submissive
and

persons
,
who
have

,

,
before

.
<EOS>
He
has
never
known
what
it
is
to
have
angry
pride
and
strong

opposed

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
will
know
it
now
!
<EOS>
"
she
seemed
to
say
;
though
her
lips
did
not

,
not
her

.
<EOS>
He
saw
the
soft
down
tremble
once
again
,
and
he
saw
her
lay
the
plumage
of
the
beautiful
bird
against

for
a

;
and
he
unfolded
one
more
ring
of
the
coil
into
which
he
had
gathered
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dombey
,
though
a
most
honourable
gentleman
,
"
he
said
,
"
is
so
prone
to
pervert

to
his
own

,
when
he
is
at
all

,
in

of
the
warp
in
his
mind
,
that
he
---
can
I
give

better

than
this
!
<EOS>
---
he
sincerely
believes
(
you
will
excuse
the
folly
of
what
I
am
about

say
;
it
not

<EOS>
Chapter
46
.
<EOS>
Recognizant
and
Reflective
 
AMONG
sundry
minor
alterations
in
Mr
Carker
's
life
and
habits
that
began
to
take
place
at
this
time
,
none
was
more
remarkable
than
the
extraordinary
diligence
with
which
he
applied
himself
to
business
,
and
the
closeness
with
which
he
investigated
every
detail
that
the
affairs
of
the
House
laid
open
to
him
.
<EOS>
Always
active
and
penetrating
in
such
matters
,
his
lynx
-
eyed
vigilance
now
increased
twenty
-
fold
.
<EOS>
Not
only
did
his
weary
watch
keep
pace
with
every
present
point
that
every
day
presented
to
him
in
some
new
form
,
but
in
the
midst
of
these
engrossing
occupations
he
found
leisure
---
that
is
,
he
made
it
---
to
review
the
past
transactions
of
the
Firm
,
and
his
share
in
them
,
during
a
long
series
of
years
.
<EOS>
Frequently
when
the
clerks
were
all
gone
,
the
offices
dark
and
empty
,
and
all
similar
places
of
business
shut
up
,
Mr
Carker
,
with
the
whole
anatomy
of
the
iron
room
laid
bare
before
him
,
would
explore
the
mysteries
of
books
and
papers
,
with
the
patient
progress
of
a
man
who
was
dissecting
the
minutest
nerves
and
fibres
of
his
subject
.
<EOS>
Perch
,
the
messenger
,
who
usually
remained
on
these
occasions
,
to
entertain
himself
with
the
perusal
of
the
Price
Current
by
the
light
of
one
candle
,
or
to
doze
over
the
fire
in
the
outer
office
,
at
the
imminent
risk
every
moment
of
diving
head
foremost
into
the
coal
-
box
,
could
not
withhold
the
tribute
of
his
admiration
from
this
zealous
conduct
,
although
it
much
contracted
his
domestic
enjoyments
;
and
again
,
and
again
,
expatiated
to
Mrs
Perch
(
now
nursing
twins
)
on
the
industry
and
acuteness
of
their
managing
gentleman
in
the
City
.
  
<EOS>
The
same
increased
and
sharp
attention
that
Mr
Carker
bestowed
on
the
business
of
the
House
,
he
applied
to
his
own
personal
affairs
.
<EOS>
Though
not
a
partner
in
the
concern
---
a
distinction
hitherto
reserved
solely
to
inheritors
of
the
great
name
of
Dombey
---
he
was
in
the
receipt
of
some
per
centage
on
its
dealings
;
and
,
participating
in
all
its

for
the
employment
of
money
to
advantage
,
was
considered
,
by
the
minnows
among
the
tritons
of
the
East
,
a
rich
man
.
<EOS>
It
began
to
be
said
,
among
these
shrewd

,
that
Jem
Carker
,
of
Dombey
's
,
was
looking
about
him
to
see
what
he
was
worth
;
and
that
he
was
calling
in
his
money
at
a
good
time
,
like
the
long
-
headed
fellow
he
was
;
and
bets
were
even
offered
on
the
Stock
Exchange
that
Jem
was
going
to
marry
a
rich
widow
.
  
<EOS>
Yet
these

did
not
in
the

with
Mr
Carker
's
watching
of
his
chief
,
or

his

,

,

,
or
any

he

.
<EOS>
It

not
so

in

,
in

,

was

.
<EOS>
Everything
that
had

observable
in
him
before
,
was
observable
now
,
but
with
a
greater

.
<EOS>
He
did
each
single

,
as
if
he
did
nothing
else
---
a
pretty
certain
indication
in
a

that
range
of
ability
and
purpose
,
that
he
is
doing
something
which
sharpens
and
keeps
alive
his
keenest
powers
.
  
<EOS>
The
only
decided
alteration
in
him
was
,
that
as
he
rode
to
and
fro
along
the
streets
,

would

deep

of

,
like

had
come

Mr

's

,

's

.
<EOS>
At

,
he
would
keep
clear
of
the
obstacles
in
his
way
,
mechanically
;
and
would
appear

see
and
hear
nothing
until
arrival
at
his
destination
,
or
some

or

.
  
<EOS>
Walking

,

-

of
Dombey
and
Son
one

,

as

Rob

,

,
in

,

,

's

,

.

"
See

!
"

.

Mrs

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?

<EOS>

And
of
it
,
"
said
her
daughter
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
mud
,
underneath
his
horse
's
feet
.
<EOS>
What
should
we
be
?
"
  
<EOS>
In
the
intentness
with
which
she
looked
after
him
again
,
she
made
a
hasty
gesture
with
her
hand
when
the
old
woman
began
to
reply
,
as
if
her
view
could
be
obstructed
by
mere
sound
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
watching
her
,
and
not
him
,
remained
silent
;
until
her
kindling
glance
subsided
,
and
she
drew
a
long
breath
,
as
if
in
the
relief
of
his
being
gone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Deary
!
"
said
the
old
woman
then
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
!
<EOS>
Handsome
gal!Ally
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
gently
shook
her
sleeve
to
arouse
her
attention
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Will
you
let
him
go
like
that
,
when
you
can
wring
money
from
him
?
<EOS>
Why
,
it
's
a
wickedness
,
my
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
n't
I
told
you
,
that
,
I
will
not
have
money
from
him
?
"
she
returned
.
"
<EOS>
And
do
n't
you
yet
believe
me
?
<EOS>
Did
I
take
his
sister
's
money
?
<EOS>
Would
I
touch
a
penny
,
if
I
knew
it
,
that
had
gone
through
his
white
hands
---
unless
it
was
,

,
that
I
could
poison

,
and
send

to

?
<EOS>
Peace
,
mother
,
and
come

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
him
so
rich
?
<EOS>
"
murmured
the
old
woman
.
"
<EOS>
And
us
so
poor
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
in
not
being
able
to
pay
him
any
of

harm
we
owe

,
"
returned
her
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
give
me
that
sort

riches
,
and
I
'll
take
them
from
him
,
and
use
them
.
<EOS>
Come
away
.
<EOS>
It
's
no
good
looking
at
his
horse
.
<EOS>
Come
away
,
mother
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
the
old
woman
,
for
whom
the
spectacle
of
Rob
the
Grinder
returning
down
the
street
,
leading
the
riderless
horse
,
appeared
to
have
some
extraneous
interest
that
it
did
not
possess
in

,
surveyed
that
young
man
with
the

;
and
seeming
to
have
whatever

she
entertained
,
resolved
as
he
drew
nearer
,
glanced

her
daughter
with

and
with
her
finger
on

,
and
emerging
from
the

,
touched

on

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
where
's
my
sprightly
<EOS>
Rob
been
,
all
this
time
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
as
he
turned
round
.
  
<EOS>
The
sprightly
Rob
,
whose
sprightliness
was
very
much
diminished
by
the
salutation
,
looked
exceedingly

,
and
said
,
with
the
water
rising
in

:
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
why
ca
n't
you
leave
a
poor
cove
alone
,
Misses
Brown
,
when
he
's
getting
an
honest
livelihood
and
conducting
himself
respectable
?
<EOS>
What
do
you
come
and
deprive
a
cove
of
his
character
for
,
by
talking
to
him
in
the
streets
,
when
he
's
taking
his
master
's
horse
to
a
honest
stable
---
a
horse
you
'd
go
and
sell
for
cats
'
and
dogs
'
meat
if
you
had
your
way
!
<EOS>
Why
,
I
thought
,
"
said
the
Grinder
,
producing
his

as
if

were
the

of
all
his
injuries
,
"
that
you
was
dead
long
ago
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
way
,
"
cried
the
old
woman
,

to
her
daughter
,
"
that
he
talks
to
me
,
who
knew
him
weeks

,
my
deary
,
and
have
stood
his
friend
many
and

a

among
the
pigeon
-

and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
the
birds
be
,
will
you
,
Misses
Brown
?
"
retorted
Rob
,
in
a
tone
of
the
acutest

.
<EOS>
"
I
think
a
cove
had
better
have
to
do
with
lions
than
them
little
creeturs
,
for
they
're
always
flying
back
in
your
face
<EOS>
when
you
least

.
<EOS>
Well
,
how
d'ye
do
and
what

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
These
polite

the
Grinder
uttered
,
as
it
were
under

,
and
with
great

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hark
how
he
speaks
to
an
old

,

!
"
said
Mrs
Brown
,

.
<EOS>
"
But
there
's
some

his
old

no

.
<EOS>
If
I
was
to
tell
some
that
he
knows
,
and
has
sported
and
cheated
with
,
where
to
find

---
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
hold
your

,
Misses
Brown
?
"
<EOS>
interrupted
the
miserable
Grinder
,
glancing

,
as

excepted
to

master
's

.
<EOS>
"
What

you
take

pleasure

?
<EOS>
At
your
time

life
too
!
<EOS>
when

ought

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
gallant
hours
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
woman
,
patting

animal
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
alone
,

,
Misses
Brown
?
"
cried
Rob
,

.
<EOS>
"
You
're
enough
to
drive

mad
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
hurt
do
I
do

,
child
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hurt
?
"
said
Rob
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
got
a
master
that
would
find
it
out
if
he
was
touched
with
a
straw
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
blew
upon

where
the
old
woman
's
hand
had
rested
for
a

,
and
smoothed

,
as

.
  
<EOS>
The

woman
looking
back
to
mumble

mouth

,
who

,
kept

Rob
's

with

;
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
good
place
,
Rob
,
eh
?
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
You
're
luck
,

child
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
do
n't
talk
about

,
Misses
Brown
,
"
returned

wretched
Grinder
,
facing

and

.
<EOS>
"
If
you
'd
never
come
,

,

.
<EOS>
Ca

,
Misses
Brown
,

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
If

's

,
why
do

take

,
instead

make

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
croaked

,

,
with

.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
deny
your
old
chum!Have
you
lurked
to
my
house
fifty
times
,
and
slept
sound
in
a
corner
when
you
had
no
other

but

-
stones
,
and

!
<EOS>
Have

,

in

business
,
schoolboy
,
sneak
,

what

,

go

!
<EOS>
Could

old
company

to
-

,

follow
you
to
ruin

,

!
<EOS>
I
'll

.
<EOS>
Come
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
Misses
Brown
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
What

doing

?
<EOS>
Do

!
<EOS>
Do

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>
Besides
,
"

,

<EOS>

's
prad
<EOS>
a
wanting
to

took

,
and

up

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Come

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,
followed

.
<EOS>
The
daughter
followed
.
  
<EOS>
Turning
into

-

that

,

's

,

's

,

,
Rob
the

delivered

;

,
soon

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
's
master
---
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
,
child
!
"
said

old
woman
,

,
as
her

before

.
"
<EOS>
Lord

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
did
n't
tell
you
who
he
was
?
"
<EOS>
observed

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
know

by

,
"

Brown
,
whose

stopped

,

.
<EOS>
"
We

,

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
---
"
What
's

?
<EOS>
Wo

?
"
  
<EOS>
This

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"

;
"
she

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

---
"
  
"

!
"

,

,

from

,
Mr

.

<EOS>
Softly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

ai

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

Rob
,
whose

,
as

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good

?
<EOS>
"

Brown
.
  
<EOS>
Rod

;
and

,
in

,
"
precious
sharp
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lives
out

,
do

,
lovey
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
When

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Lodgings
;
up

Mr
Dombey
's
"

.
  
<EOS>
The

woman
fixed

,

,
that
Rob

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dombey
---

,

,
"
said
Rob

.
<EOS>
"
You
used
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

woman

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mr
Dombey
,
he
's

a

,
"
said
Rob
,

;
"

,

,

,

Dombey
,

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are

,
lovey
?
"
<EOS>

woman
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
retorted
Rob
.
  
<EOS>
"
He

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
Mr
and

Dombey
?
"
said
Rob
.
<EOS>
"
How
should
I

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
them
---
Master
and
Mrs
Dombey
,
chick
,
"
replied

old
woman
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

know
,
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

for

is
not
far
off
)
,
who
would
n't
be
glad
at
heart
to
see
his
master
humbled
:
who
does
not
hate
him
,
secretly
:
who
does
not
wish
him
evil
rather
than
good
:
and
who
would
not
turn
upon
him
,
if
he
had
the
power
and
boldness
.
<EOS>
The
nearer
to
his
favour
,
the
nearer
to
his
insolence
;
the
closer
to
him
,
the
farther
from
him
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
creed
here
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
his
brother
,
whose
roused
feelings
had
soon
yielded
to
surprise
,
"
who
may
have
abused
your
ear
with
such
representations
;
or
why
have
chosen
to
try
me
,
rather
than
another
.
<EOS>
But
that
you
have
been
trying
me
,
and
tampering
with
me
,
I
am
now
sure
.
<EOS>
You
have
a
different
manner
and
a
different
aspect
from
any
that
I
ever
saw
in
you
.
<EOS>
I
will
only
say
to
you
,
once
more
,
you
are
deceived
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
am
,
"
said
the
Manager
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
told
you
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
by
me
,
"
returned
his
brother
.
<EOS>
"
By
your
informant
,
if
you
have
one
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
by
your
own
thoughts
and
suspicious
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
suspicions
,
"
said
the
Manager
.
<EOS>
"
Mine
are
certainties
.
<EOS>
You
pusillanimous
,
abject
,
cringing
dogs
!
<EOS>
All
making
the
same
show
,
all
canting
the
same
story
,
all
whining
the
same
professions
,
all
harbouring
the
same
transparent
secret
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
brother
withdrew
,
without
saying
more
,
and
shut
the
door
as
he
concluded
.
<EOS>
Mr
Carker
the
Manager
drew
a
chair
close
before
the
fire
,
and
fell
to
beating
the
coals
softly
with
the
poker
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
faint
-
hearted
,
fawning
knaves
,
"
he
muttered
,
with
his
two
shining
rows
of
teeth
laid
bare
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
not
one
among
them
,
who
would
n't
feign
to
be
so
shocked
and
outraged
---
!
<EOS>
Bah
!
<EOS>
There
's
not
one
among
them
,
but
if
he
had
at

power
,

to

,
would
scatter
Dombey
's

and
lay

,
as

I

ashes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As

up
and

,
he
looked
on

a

at

was
doing
.
<EOS>
"
Without
the
same
queen
beckoner
too
!
"
he
added

;
"
and
there
is
pride
there
,
not
to
be
forgotten
---
witness
our
own
acquaintance
!
"
<EOS>
With

he
fell
into

deeper

,
and
sat
pondering
over
the
blackening
grate
,
until
he
rose
up
like
a
man
who
had
been
absorbed
in
a
book
,
and
looking
round
<EOS>
him
took
his
hat
and
gloves
,
went
to
where
his
horse
was
waiting
,
mounted
,
and
rode
away
through
the
lighted
streets
,
for
it
was

.
  
<EOS>
He
rode
near
Mr
Dombey
's
house
;
and
falling
into
a
walk
as
he
approached
it
,
looked
up

.
<EOS>
The
window
where
he
had
once
seen
Florence
sitting
with
her
dog
,
attracted

attention
first
,
though
there

no

in

;
but
he

as

carried

up

tall

,
and
seemed

leave
that

superciliously

.
  
<EOS>
"
Time
was
,
"
he
said
,
"
when
it
was
well
to
watch
even
your
rising
little

,
and
know

there
were
clouds
,
to
shadow
you
if
needful
.
<EOS>
But
a
planet
has
arisen
,
and
you
are
lost
in
its
light
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
turned
the
White
-
legged
horse
round
the
street
corner
,
and
sought
one
shining
window
from
among
those
at
the
back
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
Associated
with
it
was
a
certain

,
a
gloved

,
the
remembrance
how
the
feathers
of
a
beautiful
bird
's

had
been
showered
down
upon

,
and
how

light
white

upon

stirred

,
as
in

rising

a

.
<EOS>
These
were
the

he
carried
with

as
he
turned
away
again
,
and
rode
through
the
darkening
and
deserted
Parks
at
a
quick
rate
.
  
<EOS>
In
fatal
truth
,
these
were
associated
with
a
woman
,
a
proud
woman
,
who
hated
him
,
but
who
by
slow
and
sure
degrees
had
been
led
on
by
his
craft
,
and
her
pride
and
resentment
,
to
endure
his
company
,
and
little
by
little
to
receive
him
as
one
who
had
the

to
talk
to
her
of
her
own
defiant
disregard
of
her
own
husband
,
and
her
abandonment
of
high
consideration
for
herself
.
<EOS>
They
were
associated
with
a
woman
who
hated
him
deeply
,
and
who
knew
him
,
and
who
mistrusted
him
because
she
knew
him
,
and
because
he
knew
her
;
but
who
fed
her
fierce
resentment
by
suffering
him
to
draw
nearer
and
yet
nearer
to
her
every
day
,
in
spite
of
the
hate
she
cherished
for
him
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
it
!
<EOS>
For
that
very
reason
;
since
in
its
depths
,
too
far
down
for
her
threatening
eye
to
pierce
,
though
she
could
see
into
them
dimly
,
lay
the
dark
retaliation
,
whose
faintest
shadow
seen
once
and
shuddered
at
,
and
never
seen
again
,
would
have
been
sufficient
stain
upon
her
soul
.
  
<EOS>
Did
the
phantom
of
such
a
woman
flit
about
him
on
his
ride
;
true
to
the
reality
,
and
obvious
to

?
  
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
He
was
her
in
his
mind
,
exactly
as
she
was
.
<EOS>
She
bore
him
company
with
her
pride
,
resentment
,
hatred
,
all
as
plain
to
him
as
her

;
with
nothing

to
him
than
her
hatred
of
him
.
<EOS>
He
saw
her
sometimes
haughty
and
repellent
at
his
side
,
and
sometimes
down
among
his
horse
's
feet
,
fallen
and
in

dust
.
<EOS>
But
he
always
saw
her
as
she
was
,
without
disguise
,
and
watched
her
on
the
dangerous
way
that
she
was
going
.
  
<EOS>
And
when
his
ride
was
over
,
and
he
was
newly

,
and
came
into
the
light
of
her
bright
room
with
his
bent

,
soft

,
and
soothing

,
he
saw
her
yet
as
plainly
.
<EOS>
He
even
suspected
the
mystery
of
the
gloved
hand
,
and
held
it
all
the
longer
in
his
own
for
that
suspicion
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
dangerous
way
that
she
was
going
,
he
was
still
;
and
not
a
footprint
<EOS>
did
she
mark
upon
it
,
but
he
set
his
own
there
,
straight
.
    
Chapter
48
.
<EOS>
The
Flight
of
Florence
 
IN
the
wildness
of
her
sorrow
,
shame
,
and
terror
,
the
forlorn
girl
hurried
through
the
sunshine
of
a
bright
morning
,
as
if
it
were
the
darkness
of
a
winter
night
.
<EOS>
Wringing
her
hands
and
weeping
bitterly
,
insensible
to
everything
<EOS>
but
the
deep
wound
in
her
breast
,
stunned
by
the
loss
of
all
she
loved
,
left
like
the
sole
survivor
on
a
lonely
shore
from
the
wreck
of
a
great
vessel
,
she
fled
without
a
thought
,
without
a
hope
,
without
a
purpose
,
but
to
fly
somewhere
---
anywhere
.
  
<EOS>
The
cheerful
vista
of
the
long
street
,
burnished
by
the
morning
light
,
the
sight
of
the
blue
sky
and
airy
clouds
,
the
vigorous
freshness
of
the
day
,
so
flushed
and
rosy
in
its
conquest
of
the
night
,
awakened
no
responsive
feelings
in
her
so
hurt
bosom
.
<EOS>
Somewhere
,
anywhere
,
to
hide
her
head
!
<EOS>
somewhere
,
anywhere
,
for
refuge
,
never
more
to
look
upon
the
place
from
which
she
fled
!
  
<EOS>
But
there
were
people
going
to
and
fro
;
there
were
opening
shops
,
and
servants
at
the
doors
of
houses
;
there
was
the
rising
clash
and
roar
of
the
day
's
struggle
.
<EOS>
Florence
saw
surprise
and
curiosity
in
the
faces
flitting
past
her
;
saw
long
shadows
coming
back
upon
the
pavement
;
and
heard
voices
that
were
strange
to
her
asking
her
where
she
went
,
and
what
the
matter
was
;
and
though
these
frightened
her
the
more
at
first
,
and
made
her
hurry
on
the
faster
,
they
did
her
the
good
service
of
recalling
her
in
some
degree
to
herself
,
and
reminding
her
of
the
necessity
of
greater
composure
.
  
<EOS>
Where
to
go
?
<EOS>
Still
somewhere
,
anywhere
!
<EOS>
still
going
on
;
but
where
!
<EOS>
She
thought
of
the
only
other
time
she
had
been
lost
in
the
wild
wilderness
of
London
---
though
not
lost
as
now
---
and
went
that
way
.
<EOS>
To
the
home
of
Walter
's
uncle
.
  
<EOS>
Checking
her
sobs
,
and
drying
her
swollen
eyes
,
and
endeavouring
to
calm
the
agitation
of
her
manner
,
so
as
to
avoid
attracting
notice
,
Florence
,
resolving
to
keep
to
the
more
quiet
streets
as
long
as
she
could
,
was
going
on
more
quietly
herself
,
when
a
familiar
little
shadow
darted
past
upon
the
sunny

,
stopped
short
,
wheeled
about
,
came
close
to
her
,
made
off
again
,
bounded
round
and
round
her
,
and
Diogenes
,
panting
for
breath
,
and
yet
making
the
street
ring
with
his
glad

,
was
at
her
feet
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Di
!
<EOS>
oh
,
dear
,
true
,
faithful
Di
,
how
did
you
come
here
?
<EOS>
How
could
I
ever
leave
you
,
Di
,
who
would
never
leave
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
Florence
bent
down
on
the

,
and
laid
his
rough
,
old
,
loving
,
foolish
head
against
her

,
and
they
got
up
together
,
and
went
on
together
;
Di
more
off
the
ground
than
on
it
,
endeavouring
to
kiss
his
mistress
flying
,
tumbling
over
and
getting
up
again
without
the
least

,
dashing
at
big
dogs
in
a
jocose

of
his
species
,
terrifying
with
touches
of
his
nose
young
housemaids
who
were
cleaning
doorsteps
,
and
continually
stopping
,
in
the
midst
of
a
thousand
extravagances
,
to
look
back
at
Florence
,
and
bark
until
all
the
dogs
within
hearing
answered
,
and
all
the
dogs
who
could
come
out
,
came
out
to
stare
at
him
.
  
<EOS>
With
this
last
adherent
,
Florence
hurried
away
in
the
advancing
morning
,
and
the
strengthening
sunshine
,
to
the
City
.
<EOS>
The
roar
soon
grew
more
loud
,
the
passengers
more
numerous
,
the
shops
more
busy
,
until
she
was
carried
onward
in
a
stream
of
life
setting
that
way
,
and
flowing
,
indifferently
,
past
marts
and

,
prisons
,
churches
,
market
-
places
,
wealth
,
poverty
,
good
,
and
evil
,
like
the
broad
river
side
by
side
with

,
awakened
from
its
dreams
of
rushes
,
willows
,
and
green

,
and
rolling
on
,
turbid
and

,
among
the
works
and

of
men
,
to
the
deep
sea
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
the
quarters
of
the
little
Midshipman
arose
in
view
.
<EOS>
Nearer
yet
,
and
the
little
Midshipman
himself
was
seen
upon
his
post
,
intent
as
ever
on
his
observations
.
<EOS>
Nearer
yet
,
and
the
door
stood
open
,
inviting
her
to
enter
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
who
had
again
quickened
her
pace
,
as
she
approached
the
end
of
her
journey
,
ran
across
the
road
(
closely

by
Diogenes
,
whom
the
bustle
had
somewhat
confused
)
,
ran
in
,
and
sank
upon
the
threshold
of
the
well
-
remembered
little
parlour
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
in
his
glazed
hat
,
was
standing
over
the
fire
,
making
his
morning
's
cocoa
,
with
that
elegant
trifle
,
his
watch
,
upon
the
chimney
-
piece
,
for
easy
reference
during
the
progress
of
the
cookery
.
<EOS>
Hearing
a
footstep
and
the
rustle
of
a
dress
,
the
Captain
turned
with
a
palpitating
remembrance
of
the
dreadful
Mrs
MacStinger
,
at
the
instant
when
Florence
made
a
motion
with
her

towards

,
reeled
,
and
fell
upon
the

.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
pale
as
Florence
,
pale
in
the
very

upon

,
raised
her
like
a

,
and
laid

on
the
same
old
sofa
upon
which
she
had
slumbered
long
ago
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
Heart
's
Delight
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
looking
intently
in
her
face
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
sweet
creetur
grow'd
<EOS>
a
woman
!
"
   
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
was
so
respectful
of
her
,
and
had
such
a
reverence
for
her
,
in
this
new

,
that
he
would
not
have
held
her
in

,
while
she
was
unconscious
,
for
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
Heart
's
Delight
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Captain
,
withdrawing
to
a
little
distance
,
with
the
greatest
alarm
and
sympathy
depicted
on
his
countenance
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
can
hail
Ned
Cuttle
with
a
finger
,
do
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
Florence
did
not
stir
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
Heart
's
Delight
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
trembling
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
For
the
sake
of
Wal'r
drownded
in
the
briny
deep
,
turn
to
,
and
histe
up
something
or
another
,
if
able
.
"
  
<EOS>
Finding
her
insensible
to
this
impressive
adjuration
also
,
Captain
Cuttle
snatched
from
his
breakfast
-
table
a
basin
of
cold
water
,
and
sprinkled
some
upon
her
face
.
<EOS>
Yielding
to
the
urgency
of
the
case
,
the
Captain
then
,
using
his
immense
hand
with
extraordinary
gentleness
,
relieved
her
of
her
bonnet
,
moistened
her
lips
and
forehead
,
put
back
her
hair
,
covered
her
feet
with
his
own
coat
which
he
pulled
off
for
the
purpose
,
patted
her
hand
---
so
small
in
his
,
that
he
was
struck
with
wonder
when
he
touched
it
---
and
seeing
that
her
eyelids
quivered
,
and
that
her
lips
began
to
move
,
continued
these
restorative
applications
with
a
better
heart
.
  
<EOS>
"
Cheerily
,
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Cheerily
!
<EOS>
Stand
by
,
my
pretty
one
,
stand
by
!
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
You
're
better
now
.
<EOS>
Steady
's
the
word
,
and
steady
it
is
.
<EOS>
Keep
her
so
!
<EOS>
Drink
a
little
drop
<EOS>
o
'
this
here
,
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
There
you
are
!
<EOS>
What
cheer
now
,
my
pretty
,
what
cheer
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
stage
of
her
recovery
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
with
an
imperfect
association
of
a
Watch
with
a
Physician
's
treatment
of
a
patient
,
took
his
own
down
from
the
mantel
-
shelf
,
and
holding
it
out
on
his
hook
,
and
taking
Florence
's
hand
in
his
,
looked
steadily
from
one
to
the
other
,
as
expecting
the
dial
to
do
something
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
cheer
,
my
pretty
?
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
What
cheer
now
?
<EOS>
You
've
done
her
some
good
,
my
lad
<EOS>
,
I
believe
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
under
his
breath
,
and
throwing
an
approving
glance
upon
his
watch
.
<EOS>
"
Put
you
back
half
-
an
-
hour
every
morning
,
and
about
another
quarter
towards
the
afternoon
,
and
you
're
a
watch
as
can
be
ekalled
by
few
and
excelled
by
none
.
<EOS>
What
cheer
,
my
lady
lass
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Cuttle
!
<EOS>
Is
it
you
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Florence
,
raising
herself
a
little
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
my
lady
lass
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
hastily
deciding
in
his
own
mind
upon
the
superior
elegance
of
that
form
of
address
,
as
the
most
courtly
he
could
think
of
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Walter
's
uncle
here
?
"
asked
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,
pretty
?
"
returned
the
Captain
.
"
<EOS>
He
an't
been
here
this
many
a
long
day
.
<EOS>
He
an't
been
heerd
on
,
since
he
sheered
off
arter
poor
Wal'r
.
<EOS>
But
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
as
a
quotation
,
"
Though
lost
to
sight
,
to
memory
dear
,
and
England
,
Home
,
and
Beauty
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
live
here
?
"
asked
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
lady
lass
,
"
returned
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Captain
Cuttle
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Florence
,
putting
her
hands
together
,
and
speaking
wildly
.
"
<EOS>
Save
me
!
<EOS>
keep
me
here
!
<EOS>
Let
no
one
know
where
I
am
!
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
what
has
happened
by
-
and
-
by
,
when
I
can
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
one
in
the
world
to
go
to
.
<EOS>
Do
not
send
me
away
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Send
you
away
,
my
lady
lass
!
"
exclaimed
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
You
,
my
Heart
's
Delight
!
<EOS>
Stay
a
bit
!
<EOS>
We
'll
put
up
this
here
deadlight
,
and
take
a
double
turn
on
the
key
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
the
Captain
,
using
his
one
hand
and
his
hook
with
the
greatest
dexterity
,
got
out
the
shutter
of
the
door
,
put
it
up
,
made
it
all
fast
,
and
locked
the
door
itself
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
came
back
to
the
side
of
Florence
,
she
took
his
hand
,
and
kissed
it
.
<EOS>
The
helplessness
of
the
action
,
the
appeal
it
made
to
him
,
the
confidence
it
expressed
,
the
unspeakable
sorrow
in
her
face
,
the
pain
of
mind
she
had
too
plainly
suffered
,
and
was
suffering
then
,
his
knowledge
of
her
past
history
,
her
present
lonely
,
worn
,
and
unprotected
appearance
,
all
so
rushed
upon
the
good
Captain
together
,
that
he
fairly
overflowed
with
compassion
and
gentleness
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lady
lass
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
polishing
the
bridge
of
his
nose
with
his
arm
until
it
shone
like
burnished
copper
,
"
do
n't
you
say
a
word
to
Ed'ard
<EOS>
Cuttle
,
until
such
times
as
you
finds
yourself
a
riding
smooth
and
easy
;
which
wo
n't
be
to
-
day
,
nor
yet
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
And
as
to
giving
of
you
up
,
or
reporting
where
you
are
,
yes
verily
,
and
by
God
's
help
,
so
I
wo
n't
,
Church
catechism
,
make
a
note
on
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
the
Captain
said
,
reference
and
all
,
in
one
breath
,
and
with
much
solemnity
;
taking
off
his
hat
at
"
yes
verily
,
"
and
putting
it
on
again
,
when
he
had
quite
concluded
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
could
do
but
one
thing
more
to
thank
him
,
and
to
show
him
how
she
trusted
in
him
;
and
she
did
it
.
<EOS>
Clinging
to
this
rough
creature
as
the
last
asylum
of
her
bleeding
heart
,
she
laid
her
head
upon
his
honest
shoulder
,
and
clasped
him
round
his
neck
,
and
would
have
kneeled
down
to
bless
him
,
but
that
he
divined
her
purpose
,
and
held
her
up
like
a
true
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Steady
!
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Steady
!
<EOS>
You
're
too
weak
to
stand
,
you
see
,
my
pretty
,
and
must
lie
down
here
again
.
<EOS>
There
,
there
!
<EOS>
"
To
see
the
Captain
lift
her
on
the
sofa
,
and
cover
her
with
his
coat
,
would
have
been
worth
a
hundred
state
sights
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
"
you
must
take
some
breakfast
,
lady
lass
,
and
the
dog
shall
have
some
too
.
<EOS>
And
arter
that
you
shall
go
aloft
to
old
<EOS>
Sol
Gills
's
room
,
and
fall
asleep
there
,
like
a
angel
.
"
   
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
patted
Diogenes
when
he
made
allusion
to
him
,
and
Diogenes
met
that
overture
graciously
,
half
-
way
.
<EOS>
During
the
administration
of
the
restoratives
he
had
clearly
been
in
two
minds
whether
to
fly
at
the
Captain
or
to
offer
him
his
friendship
;
and
he
had
expressed
that
conflict
of
feeling
by
alternate
waggings
of
his
tail
,
and
displays
of
his
teeth
,
with
now
and
then
a
growl
or
so
.
<EOS>
But
by
this
time
his
doubts
were
all
removed
.
<EOS>
It
was
plain
that
he
considered
the
Captain
one
of
the
most
amiable
of
men
,
and
a
man
whom
it
was
an
honour
to
a
dog
to
know
.
  
<EOS>
In
evidence
of
these
convictions
,
Diogenes
attended
on
the
Captain
while
he
made
some
tea
and
toast
,
and
showed
a
lively
interest
in
his
housekeeping
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
in
vain
for
the
kind
Captain
to
make
such
preparations
for
Florence
,
who
sorely
tried
to
do
some
honour
to
them
,
but
could
touch
nothing
,
and
could
only
weep
and
weep
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
said
the
compassionate
Captain
,
"
arter
turning
in
,
my
Heart
's
Delight
<EOS>
,
you
'll
get
more
way
upon
you
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
'll
serve
out
your
allowance
,
my
lad
.
"
<EOS>
To
Diogenes
.
<EOS>
"
And
you
shall
keep
guard
on
your
mistress
aloft
.
"
  
<EOS>
Diogenes
,
however
,
although
he
had
been
eyeing
his
intended
breakfast
with
a
watering
mouth
and
glistening
eyes
,
instead
of
falling
to
,
ravenously
,
when
it
was
put
before
him
,
pricked
up
his
ears
,
darted
to
the
shop
-
door
,
and
barked
there
furiously
:
burrowing
with
his
head
at
the
bottom
,
as
if
he
were
bent
on
mining
his
way
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
Can
there
be
anybody
there
!
"
<EOS>
asked
Florence
,
in
alarm
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
lady
lass
,
"
returned
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
Who
'd
stay
there
,
without
making
any
noise
!
<EOS>
Keep
up
a
good
heart
,
pretty
.
<EOS>
It
's
only
people
going
by
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
for
all
that
,
Diogenes
barked
and
barked
,
and
burrowed
and
burrowed
,
with
pertinacious
fury
;
and
whenever
he
stopped
to
listen
,
appeared
to
receive
some
new
conviction
into
his
mind
,
for
he
set
to
,
barking
and
burrowing
again
,
a
dozen
times
.
<EOS>
Even
when
he
was
persuaded
to
return
to
his
breakfast
,
he
came
jogging
back
to
it
,
with
a
very
doubtful
air
;
and
was
off
again
,
in
another
paroxysm
,
before
touching
a
morsel
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
there
should
be
some
one
listening
and
watching
,
"
whispered
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
Some
one
who
saw
me
come
---
who
followed
me
,
perhaps
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
an't
<EOS>
the
young
woman
,
lady
lass
,
is
it
?
"
said
the
Captain
,
taken
with
a
bright
idea
.
  
<EOS>
"
Susan
?
"
said
Florence
,
shaking
her
head
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
no
!
<EOS>
Susan
has
been
gone
from
me
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
deserted
,
I
hope
?
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
that
that
there
young
woman
's
run
,
my
pretty
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
no
!
"
cried
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
one
of
the
truest
hearts
in
the
world
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
greatly
relieved
by
this
reply
,
and
expressed
his
satisfaction
by
taking
off
his
hard
glazed
hat
,
and
dabbing
his
head
all
over
with
his
handkerchief
,
rolled
up
like
a
ball
,
observing
several
times
,
with
infinite
complacency
,
and
with
a
beaming
countenance
,
that
he
know'd
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
you
're
quiet
now
,
are
you
,
brother
?
"
said
the
Captain
to
Diogenes
.
<EOS>
"
There
warn't
nobody
there
,
my
lady
lass
,
bless
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
Diogenes
was
not
so
sure
of
that
.
<EOS>
The
door
still
had
an
attraction
for
him
at
intervals
;
and
he
went
snuffing
about
it
,
and
growling
to
himself
,
unable
to
forget
the
subject
.
<EOS>
This
incident
,
coupled
with
the
Captain
's
observation
of
Florence
's
fatigue
and
faintness
,
decided
him
to
prepare
Sol
Gills
's
chamber
as
a
place
of
retirement
for
her
immediately
.
<EOS>
He
therefore
hastily
betook
himself
to
the
top
of
the
house
,
and
made
the
best
arrangement
of
it
that
his
imagination
and
his
means
suggested
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
very
clean
already
;
and
the
Captain
being
an
orderly
man
,
and
accustomed
to
make
things
ship
-
shape
,
converted
the
bed
into
a
couch
,
by
covering
it
all
over
with
a
clean
white
drapery
.
<EOS>
By
a
similar
contrivance
,
the
Captain
converted
the
little
dressing
-
table
into
a
species
of
alter
,
on
which
he
set
forth
two
silver
teaspoons
,
a
flower
-
pot
,
a
telescope
,
his
celebrated
watch
,
a
pocket
-
comb
,
and
a
song
-
book
,
as
a
small
collection
of
rarities
,
that
made
a
choice
appearance
.
<EOS>
Having
darkened
the
window
,
and
straightened
the
pieces
of
carpet
on
the
floor
,
the
Captain
surveyed
these
preparations
with
great
delight
,
and
descended
to
the
little
parlour
again
,
to
bring
Florence
to
her
bower
.
  
<EOS>
Nothing
would
induce
the
Captain
to
believe
that
it
was
possible
for
Florence
to
walk
upstairs
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
have
got
the
idea
into
his
head
,
he
would
have
considered
it
an
outrageous
breach
of
hospitality
to
allow
her
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
Florence
was
too
weak
to
dispute
the
point
,
and
the
Captain
carried
her
up
out
of
hand
,
laid
her
down
,
and
covered
her
with
a
great
watch
-
coat
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lady
lass
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
"
you
're
as
safe
here
as
if
you
was
at
the
top
of
St
Paul
's
Cathedral
,
with
the
ladder
cast
off
.
<EOS>
Sleep
is
what
you
want
,
afore
all
other
things
,
and
may
you
be
able
to
show
yourself
smart
with
that
there
balsam
for
the
still
small
woice
of
a
wownded
mind
!
<EOS>
When
there
's
anything
you
want
,
my
Heart
's
Delight
,
as
this
here
humble
house
or
town
can
offer
,
pass
the
word
to
Ed'ard
Cuttle
,
as'll
stand
off
and
on
outside
that
door
,
and
that
there
man
will
wibrate
with
joy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Captain
concluded
by
kissing
the
hand
that
Florence
stretched
out
to
him
,
with
the
chivalry
of
any
old
knight
-
errant
,
and
walking
on
tip
-
toe
out
of
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
Descending
to
the
little
parlour
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
after
holding
a
hasty
council
with
himself
,
decided
to
open
the
shopdoor
for
a
few
minutes
,
and
satisfy
himself
that
now
,
at
all
events
,
there
was
no
one
loitering
about
it
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
he
set
it
open
,
and
stood
upon
the
threshold
,
keeping
a
bright
look
-
out
,
and
sweeping
the
whole
street
with
his
spectacles
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
de
do
,
Captain
Gills
?
<EOS>
"
said
a
voice
beside
him
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
looking
down
,
found
that
he
had
been
boarded
by
Mr
Toots
while
sweeping
the
horizon
.
  
<EOS>
"

?

Well

<EOS>
Mr

in

"
  
<EOS>
The

's

.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
,
who
himself

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
At

Captain
decided
,

Brogley
's

:

that

"

<EOS>
The

thanked

,

,

.
<EOS>
Poor

,
left
to

,

,
little

who

.
  
<EOS>
It

that

;
for

,

<EOS>
When

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

dram

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

"
I
hope

there

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
Quite

<EOS>
"

You

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

"

.
<EOS>
"

.

"

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
If

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
removed

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
.
<EOS>
Only

.
<EOS>
I

"

"

"

<EOS>
Thank'ee
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

,
"

Captain
,

.
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
There
's
more
than
one
sweet
creetur
in
the
world
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
to
me
,
Captain
Gills
,
"
replied
Mr
Toots
gravely
.
<EOS>
"
Not
to
me
,
I
assure
you
.
<EOS>
The
state
of
my
feelings
towards
Miss
Dombey
is
of
that
unspeakable
description
,
that
my
heart
is
a
desert
island
,
and
she
lives
in
it
alone
.
<EOS>
I
'm
getting
more
used
up
every
day
,
and
I
'm
proud
to
be
so
.
<EOS>
If
you
could
see
my
legs
when
I
take
my
boots
off
,
you
'd
form
some
idea
of
what
unrequited
affection
is
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
prescribed
bark
,
but
I
do
n't
take
it
,
for
I
do
n't
wish
to
have
any
tone
whatever
given
to
my
constitution
.
<EOS>
I
'd
rather
not
.
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
is
forbidden
ground
.
<EOS>
Captain
Gills
,
good
-
bye
!
"
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
cordially
reciprocating
the
warmth
of
Mr
Toots
's
farewell
,
locked
the
door
behind
him
,
and
shaking
his
head
with
the
same
remarkable
expression
of
pity
and
tenderness
as
he
had
regarded
him
with
before
,
went
up
to
see
if
Florence
wanted
him
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
an
entire
change
in
the
Captain
's
face
as
he
went
upstairs
.
<EOS>
He
wiped
his
eyes
with
his
handkerchief
,
and
he
polished
the
bridge
of
his
nose
with
his
sleeve
as
he
had
done
already
that
morning
,
but
his
face
was
absolutely
changed
.
<EOS>
Now
,
he
might
have
been
thought
supremely
happy
;
now
,
he
might
have
been
thought
sad
;
but
the
kind
of
gravity
that
sat
upon
his
features
was
quite
new
to
them
,
and
was
as
great
an
improvement
to
them
as
if
they
had
undergone
some
sublimating
process
.
  
<EOS>
He
knocked
softly
,
with
his
hook
,
at
Florence
's
door
,
twice
or
thrice
;
but
,
receiving
no
answer
,
ventured
first
to
peep
in
,
and
then
to
enter
:
emboldened
to
take
the
latter
step
,
perhaps
,
by
the
familiar
recognition
of
Diogenes
,
who
,
stretched
upon
the
ground
by
the
side
of
her
couch
,
wagged
his
tail
,
and
winked
his
eyes
at
the
Captain
,
without
being
at
the
trouble
of
getting
up
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
sleeping
heavily
,
and
moaning
in
her
sleep
;
and
Captain
Cuttle
,
with
a
perfect
awe
of
her
youth
and
beauty
,
and
her
sorrow
,
raised
her
head
,
and
adjusted
the
coat
that
covered
her
,
where
it
had
fallen
off
,
and
darkened
the
window
a
little
more
that
she
might
sleep
on
,
and
crept
out
again
,
and
took
his
post
of
watch
upon
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
All
this
,
with
a
touch
and
tread
as
light
as
Florence
's
own
.
  
<EOS>
Long
may
it
remain
in
this
mixed
world
a
point
not
easy
of
decision
,
which
is
the
more
beautiful
evidence
of
the
Almighty
's
goodness
---
the
delicate
fingers
that
are
formed
for
sensitiveness
and
sympathy
of
touch
,
and
made
to
minister
to
pain
and
grief
,
or
the
rough
hard
Captain
Cuttle
hand
,
that
the
heart
teaches
,
guides
,
and
softens
in
a
moment
!
  
<EOS>
Florence
slept
upon
her
couch
,
forgetful
of
her
homelessness
and
orphanage
,
and
Captain
Cuttle
watched
upon
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
A
louder
sob
or
moan
than
usual
,
brought
him
sometimes
to
her
door
;
but
by
degrees
she
slept
more
peacefully
,
and
the
Captain
's
watch
was
undisturbed
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
49
.
<EOS>
The
Midshipman
makes
a
Discovery
 
IT
was
long
before
Florence
awoke
.
<EOS>
The
day
was
in
its
prime
,
the
day
was
in
its
wane
,
and
still
,
uneasy
in
mind
and
body
,
she
slept
on
;
unconscious
of
her
strange
bed
,
of
the
noise
and
turmoil
in
the
street
,
and
of
the
light
that
shone
outside
the
shaded
window
.
<EOS>
Perfect
unconsciousness
of
what
had
happened
in
the
home
that
existed
no
more
,
even
the
deep
slumber
of
exhaustion
could
not
produce
.
<EOS>
Some
undefined
and
mournful
recollection
of
it
,
dozing
uneasily
but
never
sleeping
,
pervaded
all
her
rest
.
<EOS>
A
dull
sorrow
,
like
a
half
-
lulled
sense
of
pain
,
was
always
present
to
her
;
and
her
pale
cheek
was
oftener
wet
with
tears
than
the
honest
Captain
,
softly
putting
in
his
head
from
time
to
time
at
the
half
-
closed
door
,
<EOS>
could
have
desired
to
see
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
sun
was
getting
low
in
the
west
,
and
glancing
out
of
a
red
mist
,
pierced
with
its
rays
opposite
loop
-
holes
and
pieces
of
fret
-
work
in
the
spires
of
city
churches
,
as
if
with
golden
arrows
that
struck
through
and
through
them
---
and
far
away
athwart
the
river
and
its
flat
blanks
,
it
was
gleaming
like
a
path
of
fire
---
and
<EOS>
out
at
sea
it
was
irradiating
sails
of
ships
---
and
,
looked
towards
,
from
quiet
churchyards
,
upon
hill
-
tops
in
the
country
,
it
was
steeping
distant
prospects
in
a
flush
and
glow
that
seemed
to
mingle
earth
and
sky
together
in
one
glorious
suffusion
---
when
Florence
,
opening
her
heavy
eyes
,
lay
at
first
,
looking
without
interest
or
recognition
at
the
unfamiliar
walls
around
her
,
and
listening
in
the
same
regardless
manner
to
the
noises
in
the
street
.
<EOS>
But
presently
she
started
up
upon
her
couch
,
gazed
round
with
a
surprised
and
vacant
look
,
and
recollected
all
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
pretty
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
knocking
at
the
door
,
"
what
cheer
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
friend
,
"
cried
Florence
,
hurrying
to
him
,
"
is
it
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
felt
so
much
pride
in
the
name
,
and
was
so
pleased
by
the
gleam
of
pleasure
in
her
face
,
<EOS>
when
she
saw
him
,
that
he
kissed
his
hook
,
by
way

reply
,
in
speechless
gratification
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
cheer
,
bright
di'mond
?
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
surely
slept
very
long
,
"
returned
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
When
did
I
come
here
?
<EOS>
Yesterday
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
here
blessed
day
,
my
lady
lass
,
"
replied
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Has
there
been
no
night
?
<EOS>
Is
it
still
day
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Getting
on
for
evening
now
,
my
pretty
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
drawing
back
the
curtain
of
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
See
!
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
,
with
her
hand
upon
the
Captain
's
arm
,
so
sorrowful
and
timid
,
and
the
Captain
with
his
rough
face
and

,
so
quietly
protective
of

,
stood
in
the
rosy

of
the
bright

sky
,
without
saying

.
<EOS>
However
strange
the
form

speech
into
which
he
might
have
fashioned
the
feeling
,
if
he
had
had

,
the
Captain
felt
,
as
sensibly
as
the
most

of

could

,
that
there
was
something
in
the
tranquil
time
and
in
its
softened
beauty
that
would
make
the
wounded
heart
of
Florence
overflow
;
and
that
it
was
better
that
such
tears
should
have
their
way
.
<EOS>
So
not
a
word
spake
Captain
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
But
when
he
felt
his
arm
clasped
closer
,
and
when
he
felt
the
lonely
head
come
nearer
to
it
,
and
lay
itself
against
his
homely
coarse
blue
sleeve
,
he
pressed
it
gently
with
his
rugged
hand
,
and
understood
it
,
and
was
understood
.
  
<EOS>
"
Better
now
,
my
pretty
!
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Cheerily
,
cheerily
;
I
'll
go
down
below
,
and
get
some
dinner
ready
.
<EOS>
Will
you
come
down
of
your
own
self
,
arterwards
,
pretty
,
or
shall
Ed'ard
<EOS>
Cuttle
come
and
fetch
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
As
Florence
assured
him
that
she
was
quite
able
to
walk
down
stairs
,
the
Captain
,
though
evidently
doubtful
of
his
own
hospitality
in
permitting
it
,
left
her
to
do
so
,
and
immediately
set
about
roasting
a
fowl
at
the
fire
in
the
little
parlour
.
<EOS>
To
achieve
his
cookery
with
the
greater
skill
,
he
pulled
off
his
coat
,
tucked
up
his
wristbands
,
and
put
on
his
glazed
hat
,
without
which
assistant
he
never
applied
himself
to
any
nice
or
difficult
undertaking
.
  
<EOS>
After
cooling
her
aching
head
and
burning
face
in
the
fresh
water
which
the
Captain
's
care
had
provided
for
her
while
she
slept
,
Florence
went
to
the
little
mirror
to
bind
up
her
disordered
hair
.
<EOS>
Then
she
knew
---
in
a
moment
,
for
she
shunned
it
instantly
---
that
on
her
breast
there
was
the
darkening
mark
of
any
angry
hand
.
  
<EOS>
Her
tears
burst
forth
afresh
at
the
sight
;
she
was
ashamed
and
afraid
of
it
;
but
it
moved
her
to
no
anger
against
him
.
<EOS>
Homeless
and
fatherless
<EOS>
,
she
forgave
him
everything
;
hardly
thought
that
she
had
need
to
forgive
him
,
or
that
she
did
;
but
she
fled
from
the
idea
of
him
as
she
had
fled
from
the
reality
,
and
he
was
utterly
gone
and
lost
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
such
Being
in
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
What
to
do
,
or
where
to
live
,
Florence
---
poor
,
inexperienced
girl
!
<EOS>
---
could
not
yet
consider
.
<EOS>
She
had
indistinct
dreams
of
finding
,
a
long
way
off
,
some
little
sisters
to
instruct
,
who
would
be
gentle
with
her
,
and
to
whom
,
under
some
feigned
name
,
she
might
attach
herself
,
and
who
would
grow
up
in
their
happy
home
,
and
marry
,
and
be
good
to
their
old
governess
,
and
perhaps
intrust
her
,
in
time
,
with
the
education
of
their
own
daughters
.
<EOS>
And
she
thought
how
strange
and
sorrowful
it
would
be
,
thus
to
become
a
grey
-
haired
woman
,
carrying
her
secret
to
the
grave
,
when
Florence
Dombey
was
forgotten
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
all
dim
and
clouded
to
her
now
.
<EOS>
She
only
knew
that
she
had
no
Father
upon
earth
,
and
she
said
so
,
many
times
,
with
her
suppliant
head
hidden
from
all
,
but
her
Father
who
was
in
Heaven
.
  
<EOS>
Her
little
stock
of
money
amounted
to
<EOS>
but
a
few
guineas
.
<EOS>
With
a
part
of
this
,
it
would
be
necessary
to
buy
some
clothes
,
for
she
had
none
but
those
she
wore
.
<EOS>
She
was
too
desolate
to
think
how
soon
her
money
would
be
gone
---
too
much
a
child
in
worldly
matters
to
be
greatly
troubled
on
that
score
yet
,
even
if
her
other
trouble
had
been
less
.
<EOS>
She
tried
to
calm
her
thoughts
and
stay
her
tears
;
to
quiet
the
hurry
in
her
throbbing
head
,
and
bring
herself
to
believe
that
what
had
happened
were
<EOS>
but
the
events
of
a
few
hours
ago
,
instead
of
weeks
or
months
,
as
they
appeared
;
and
went
down
to
her
kind
protector
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
had
spread
the
cloth
with
great
care
,
and
was
making
some
egg
-
sauce
in
a
little
saucepan
:
basting
the
fowl
from
time
to
time
during
the
process
with
a
strong
interest
,
as
it
turned
and
browned
on
a
string
before
the
fire
.
<EOS>
Having
propped
Florence
up
with
cushions
on
the
sofa
,
which
was
already
wheeled
into
a
warm
corner
for
her
greater
comfort
,
the
Captain
pursued
his
cooking
with
extraordinary
skill
,
making
hot
gravy
in
a
second
little
saucepan
,
boiling
a
handful
of
potatoes
in
a
third
,
never
forgetting
the
egg
-
sauce
in
the
first
,
and
making
an
impartial
round
of
basting
and
stirring
with
the
most
useful
of
spoons
every

.
<EOS>
Besides
these
cares
,
the
Captain
had
to
keep
his
eye
on
a
diminutive
fryingpan
,
in
which
some

were

and

in
a
most

;
and
there
was
never
such
a
radiant
cook
as
the
Captain
looked
,
in
the
height
and
heat
of
these
functions
:
it
being

to
say
whether
his
face
or
his
glazed
hat
shone
the
brighter
.
  
<EOS>
The
dinner
being
at
length
quite
ready
,
Captain
Cuttle
dished
and
served

,
with
no
less

than
he
had

.
<EOS>
He
then
dressed
for

,
by
taking

his
glazed
hat
and
putting
on

.
<EOS>
That

,
he
wheeled

close
against
Florence
on

,
said

,
unscrewed

,
screwed

fork
into

place
,
and
did

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lady
lass
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
"
cheer
up
,
and
try
to
eat
a
deal
.
<EOS>
Stand
by
,
my
deary
!
<EOS>
Liver
wing
it
is
.
<EOS>
Sarse
it
is
.
<EOS>
Sassage
it
is
.
<EOS>
And
potato
!
"
<EOS>
all

Captain
ranged

on

,
and

with

,
set
before

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

row
o
'
dead
lights

,

,

,
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
Try

,

.
<EOS>
If

---
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
If

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

!
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
"

,
"
awast

!
<EOS>
He

nat'ral

,

,
Pet
?
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

,
"
Oh
,

,

!
<EOS>
oh
,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

,

,

,

!
<EOS>
I

,
the
wery

as
he
was
rated
on
them
<EOS>
Dombey

,

.
<EOS>
Well
,

<EOS>
If

,

---
<EOS>

---

,
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

"

<EOS>
my

,

,

.
<EOS>
Whereby

,

's

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
essayed
to

,
for

's

.
<EOS>
The
Captain
,

,
who
seemed

own

,
laid

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
was
a
trim
lad
,
warn't
<EOS>
he
,
precious
?
"
said

Captain
,
after
sitting

rubbing

,
with

fixed
upon

,
"
and
a

lad
,
and
a

lad
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
tearfully

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
he
's
drownded
,
Beauty
,
an't
he
?
"
said
the
Captain
,
in
a
soothing
voice
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
could
not
but
assent
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
older
than
you
,
my
lady
lass
,
"
pursued
the
Captain
,
"
but
you
was
like
two
children
together
,
at
first
;
<EOS>
warn't
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
answered
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
Wal'r
's
drownded
,
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
An't
he
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
repetition
of
this
inquiry
was
a
curious
source
of
consolation
,
but
it
seemed
to
be
one
to
Captain
Cuttle
,
for
he
came
back
to
it
again
and
again
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
fain
to
push
from
her
her
untasted
dinner
,
and
to
lie
back
on
her
sofa
,
gave
him
her
hand
,
feeling
that
she
had
disappointed
him
,
though
truly
wishing
to
have
pleased
him
after
all
his
trouble
,
but
he
held
it
in
his
own
(
which
shook
as
he
held
it
)
,
and
appearing
to
have
quite
forgotten
all
about
the
dinner
and
her
want
of
appetite
,
went
on
growling
at
intervals
,
in
a
ruminating
tone
of
sympathy
,
"
Poor
Wal'r
.
<EOS>
Aye
,
aye
!
<EOS>
Drownded
.
<EOS>
An't
he
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
always
waited
for
her
answer
,
in
which
the
great
point
of
these
singular
reflections
appeared
to
consist
.
  
<EOS>
The
fowl
and
sausages
were
cold
,
and
the
gravy
and
the
egg
-
sauce
stagnant
,
before
the
Captain
remembered
that
they
were
on
the
board
,
and
fell
to
with
the
assistance
of
Diogenes
,
whose
united
efforts
quickly
dispatched
the
banquet
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
delight
and
wonder
at
the
quiet
housewifery
of
Florence
in
assisting
to
clear
the
table
,
arrange
the
parlour
,
and
sweep
up
the
hearth
---
only
to
be
equalled
by
the
fervency
of
his
protest
when
she
began
to
assist
him
---
were
gradually
raised
to
that
degree
,
that
at
last
he
could
not
choose
but
do
nothing
himself
,
and
stand
looking
at
her
as
if
she
were
some
Fairy
,
daintily
performing
these
offices
for
him
;
the
red
rim
on
his
forehead
glowing
again
,
in
his
unspeakable
admiration
.
  
<EOS>
But
when
Florence
,
taking
down
his
pipe
from
the
mantelshelf
gave
it
into
his
hand
,
and
entreated
him
to
smoke
it
,
the
good
Captain
was
so
bewildered
by
her
attention
that
he
held
it
as
if
he
had
never
held
a
pipe
in
all
his
life
.
<EOS>
Likewise
,
when
Florence
,
looking
into
the
little
cupboard
,
took
out
the
casebottle
and
mixed
a
perfect
glass
of
grog
for
him
,
unasked
,
and
set
it
at
his
elbow
,
his
ruddy
nose
turned
pale
,
he
felt
himself
so
graced
and
honoured
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
filled
his
pipe
in
an
absolute
reverie
of
satisfaction
,
Florence
lighted
it
for
him
---
the
Captain
having
no
power
to
object
,
or
to
prevent
her
---
and
resuming
her
place
on
the
old
sofa
,
looked
at
him
with
a
smile
so
loving
and
so
grateful
,
a
smile
that
showed
him
so
plainly
how
her
forlorn
heart
turned
to
him
,
as
her
face
did
,
through
grief
,
that
the
smoke
of
the
pipe
got
into
the
Captain
's
throat
and
made
him
cough
,
and
got
into
the
Captain
's
eyes
,
and
made
them
blink
and
water
.
  
<EOS>
The
manner
in
which
the
Captain
tried
to
make
believe
that
the
cause
of
these
effects
lay
hidden
in
the
pipe
itself
,
and
the
way
in
which
he
looked
into
the
bowl
for
it
,
and
not
finding
it
there
,
pretended
to
blow
it
out
of
the
stem
,
was
wonderfully
pleasant
.
<EOS>
The
pipe
soon
getting
into
better
condition
,
he
fell
into
that
state
of
repose
becoming
a
good
smoker
;
but
sat
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
Florence
,
and
,
with
a
beaming
placidity
not
to
be
described
,
and
stopping
every
now
and
then
to
discharge
a
little
cloud
from
his
lips
,
slowly
puffed
it
forth
,
as
if
it
were
a
scroll
coming
out
of
his
mouth
,
bearing
the
legend
<EOS>
"
Poor
Wal'r
,
aye
,
aye
.
<EOS>
Drownded
,
an't
he
?
"
<EOS>
after
which
he
would
resume
his
smoking
with
infinite
gentleness
.
  
<EOS>
Unlike
as
they
were
externally
---
and
there
could
scarcely
be
a
more
decided
contrast
than
between
Florence
in
her
delicate
youth
and
beauty
,
and
Captain
Cuttle
with
his
knobby
face
,
his
great
broad
weather
-
beaten
person
,
and
his
gruff
voice
---
in
simple
innocence
of
the
world
's
ways
and
the
world
's
perplexities
and
dangers
,
they
were
nearly
on
a
level
.
<EOS>
No
child
could
have
surpassed
Captain
Cuttle
in
inexperience
of
everything
but
wind
and
weather
;
in
simplicity
,
credulity
,
and
generous
trustfulness
.
<EOS>
Faith
,
hope
,
and
charity
,
shared
his
whole
nature
among
them
.
<EOS>
An
odd
sort
of
romance
,
perfectly
unimaginative
,
yet
perfectly
unreal
,
and
subject
to
no
considerations
of
worldly
prudence
or
practicability
,
was
the
only
partner
they
had
in
his
character
.
<EOS>
As
the
Captain
sat
,
and
smoked
,
and
looked
at
Florence
,
God
knows
what
impossible
pictures
,
in
which
she
was
the
principal
figure
,
presented
themselves
to
his
mind
.
<EOS>
Equally
vague
and
uncertain
,
though
not
so
sanguine
,
were
her
own
thoughts
of
the
life
before
her
;
and
even
as
her
tears
made
prismatic
colours
in
the
light
she
gazed
at
so
,
through
her
new
and
heavy
grief
,
she
already
saw
a
rainbow
faintly
shining
in
the
far
-
off
sky
.
<EOS>
A
wandering
princess
and
a
good
monster
in
a
story
-
book
might
have
sat
by
the
fireside
,
and
talked
as
Captain
Cuttle
and
poor
Florence
thought
---
and
not
have
looked
very
much
unlike
them
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
not
troubled
with
the
faintest
idea
of
any
difficulty
in
retaining
Florence
,
or
of
any
responsibility
thereby
incurred
.
<EOS>
Having
put
up
the
shutters
and
locked
the
door
,
he
was
quite
satisfied
on
this
head
.
<EOS>
If
she
had
been
a
Ward
in
Chancery
,
it
would
have
made
no
difference
at
all
to
Captain
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
last
man
in
the
world
to
be
troubled
by
any
such
considerations
.
  
<EOS>
So
the
Captain
smoked
his
pipe
very
comfortably
,
and
Florence
and
he
meditated
after
their
own
manner
.
<EOS>
When
the
pipe
was
out
,
they
had
some
tea
;
and
then
Florence
entreated
him
to
take
her
to
some
neighbouring
shop
,
where
she
could
buy
the
few
necessaries
she
immediately
wanted
.
<EOS>
It
being
quite
dark
,
the
Captain
consented
;
peeping
carefully
out
first
,
as
he
had
been
wo
nt
to
do
in
his
time
of
hiding
from
Mrs
MacStinger
;
and
arming
himself
with
his
large
stick
,
in
case
of
an
appeal
to
arms
being
rendered
necessary
by
any
unforeseen
circumstance
.
  
<EOS>
The
pride
Captain
Cuttle
had
,
in
giving
his
arm
to
Florence
,
and
escorting
her
some
two
or
three
hundred
yards
,
keeping
a
bright
look
-
out
all
the
time
,
and
attracting
the
attention
of
every
one
who
passed
them
,
by
his
great
vigilance
and
numerous
precautions
,
was
extreme
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
the
shop
,
the
Captain
felt
it
a
point
of
delicacy
to
retire
during
the
making
of
the
purchases
,
as
they
were
to
consist
of
wearing
apparel
;
but
he
previously
deposited
his
tin
canister
on
the
counter
,
and
informing
the
young
lady
of
the
establishment
that
it
contained
fourteen
pound
two
,
requested
her
,
in
case
that
amount
of
property
should
not
be
sufficient
to
defray
the
expenses
of
his
niece
's
little
outfit
---
at
the
word
"
niece
,
"
he
bestowed
a
most
significant
look
on
Florence
,
accompanied
with
pantomime
,
expressive
of
sagacity
and
mystery
---
to
have
the
goodness
to
"
sing
out
,
"
and
he
would
make
up
the
difference
from
his
pocket
.
<EOS>
Casually
consulting
his
big
watch
,
as
a
deep
means
of
dazzling
the
establishment
,
and
impressing
it
with
a
sense
of
property
,
the
Captain
then
kissed
his
hook
to
his
niece
,
and
retired
outside
the
window
,
where
it
was
a
choice
sight
to
see
his
great
face
looking
in
from
time
to
time
,
among
the
silks
and
ribbons
,
with
an
obvious
misgiving
that
Florence
had
been
spirited
away
by
a
back
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
said
Florence
,
when
she
came
out
with
a
parcel
,
the
size
of
which
greatly
disappointed
the
Captain
,
who
had
expected
to
see
a
porter
following
with
a
bale
of

,
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
this
money
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
spent
any
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
money
of
my
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
lady
lass
,
"
returned
the
baffled
Captain
,
looking
straight
down
the
street
before
them
,
"
take
care
on
it
for
me
<EOS>
,
will
you
be
so
good
,
till
such
time
as
I
ask
ye
for
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
put
it
back
in
its
usual
place
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
and
keep
it
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
not
at
all
gratified
by
this
proposal
,
but
he
answered
,
"
<EOS>
Aye
,
aye
,
put
it
anywheres
,
my
lady
lass
,
so
long
as
you
know
where
to
find
it
again
.
<EOS>
It
an't
<EOS>
o
'
<EOS>
no
use
to
me
,
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
I
have
n't
chucked
it
away
afore
now
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
quite
disheartened
for
the
moment
,
but
he
revived
at
the
first
touch
of
Florence
's
arm
,
and
they
returned
with
the
same
precautions
as
they
had
come
;
the
Captain
opening
the
door
of
the
little
Midshipman
's
berth
,
and
diving
in
,
with
a
suddenness
which
his
great
practice
only
could
have
taught
him
.
<EOS>
During
Florence
's
slumber
in
the
morning
,
he
had
engaged
the
daughter
of
an
elderly
lady
,
who
usually
sat
under
a
blue
umbrella
in
Leadenhall
Market
,
selling
poultry
,
to
come
and
put
her
room
in
order
,
and
render
her
any
little
services
she
required
;
and
this
damsel
now
appearing
,
Florence
found
everything
about
her
as
convenient
and
orderly
,
if
not
as
handsome
,
as
in
the
terrible
dream
she
had
once
called
Home
.
  
<EOS>
When
they
were
alone
again
,
the
Captain
insisted
on
her
eating
a
slice
of
dry
toast
,
and
drinking
a
glass
of
spiced
negus
(
which
he
made
to
perfection
)
;
and
,
encouraging
her
with
every
kind
word
and
inconsequential
quotation
he
could
possibly
think
of
,
led
her
upstairs
to
her
bedroom
.
<EOS>
But
he
too
had
something
on
his
mind
,
and
was
not
easy
in
his
manner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
dear
heart
,
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
to
her
at
her
chamber
-
door
.
   
<EOS>
Florence
raised
his
lips
to
his
face
,
and
kissed
him
.
  
<EOS>
At
any
other
time
the
Captain
would
have
been
overbalanced
by
such
a
token
of
her
affection
and
gratitude
;
but
now
,
although
he
was
very
sensible
of
it
,
he
looked
in
her
face
with
even
more
uneasiness
than
he
had
testified
before
,
and
seemed
unwilling
to
leave
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
Wal'r
!
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
,
poor
Walter
!
<EOS>
"
sighed
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Drownded
,
an't
he
?
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
shook
her
head
,
and
sighed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
my
lady
lass
!
"
said
Captain
Cuttle
,
putting
out
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
,
dear
,
kind
friend
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
the
Captain
lingered
still
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
anything
the
matter
,
dear
Captain
Cuttle
?
"
said
Florence
,
easily
alarmed
in
her
then
state
of
mind
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
anything
to
tell
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
tell
you
,
lady
lass
!
"
replied
the
Captain
,
meeting
her
eyes
in
confusion
.
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
;
what
should
I
have
to
tell
you
,
pretty
!
<EOS>
You
do
n't
expect
as
I
've
got
anything
good
to
tell
you
,
sure
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
Florence
,
shaking
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
looked
at
her
wistfully
,
and
repeated
"
No
,
"
---
still
lingering
,
and
still
showing
embarrassment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
Wal'r
!
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
My
Wal'r
,
as
I
used
to
call
you
!
<EOS>
Old
Sol
Gills
's
nevy
!
<EOS>
Welcome
to
all
as
knowed
you
,
as
the
flowers
in
May
!
<EOS>
Where
are
you
got
to
,
brave
boy
?
<EOS>
Drownded
,
an't
he
?
"
  
<EOS>
Concluding
his
apostrophe
with
this
abrupt
appeal
to
Florence
,
the
Captain
bade
her
good
night
,
and
descended
the
stairs
,
while
Florence
remained
at
the
top
,
holding
the
candle
out
to
light
him
down
.
<EOS>
He
was
lost
in
the
obscurity
,
and
,
judging
from
the
sound
of
his
receding
footsteps
,
was
in
the
act
of
turning
into
the
little
parlour
,
when
his
head
and
shoulders
unexpectedly
emerged
again
,
as
from
the
deep
,
apparently
for
no
other
purpose
than
to
repeat
,
"
Drownded
,
an't
<EOS>
he
,
pretty
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
when
he
had
said
that
in
a
tone
of
tender
condolence
,
he
disappeared
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
was
very
sorry
that
she
should
unwittingly
,
though
naturally
,
have
awakened
these
associations
in
the
mind
of
her
protector
,
by
taking
refuge
there
;
and
sitting
down
before
the
little
table
where
the
Captain
had
arranged
the
telescope
and
song
-
book
,
and
those
other
rarities
,
thought
of
Walter
,
and
of
all
that
was
connected
with
him
in
the
past
,
until
she
could
have
almost
wished
to
lie
down
on
her
bed
and
fade
away
.
<EOS>
But
in
her
lonely
yearning
to
the
dead
whom
she
had
loved
,
no
thought
of
home
---
no
possibility
of
going
back
---
no
presentation
of
it
as
yet
existing
,
or
as
sheltering
her
father
---
once
entered
her
thoughts
.
<EOS>
She
had
seen
the
murder
done
.
<EOS>
In
the
last
lingering
natural
aspect
in
which
she
had
cherished
him
through
so
much
,
he
had
been
torn
out
of
her
heart
,
defaced
,
and
slain
.
<EOS>
The
thought
of
it
was
so
appalling
to
her
,
that
she
covered
her
eyes
,
and
shrunk
trembling
from
the
least
remembrance
of
the
deed
,
or
of
the
cruel
hand
that
did
it
.
<EOS>
If
her
fond
heart
could
have
held
his
image
after
that
,
it
must
have
broken
;
but
it
could
not
;
and
the
void
was
filled
with
a
wild
dread
that
fled
from
all
confronting
with
its
shattered
fragments
---
with
such
a
dread
as
could
have
risen
out
of
nothing
but
the
depths
of
such
a
love
,
so
wronged
.
  
<EOS>
She
dared
not
look
into
the
glass
;
for
the
sight
of
the
darkening
mark
upon
her
bosom
made
her
afraid
of
herself
,
as
if
she
bore
about
her
something
wicked
.
<EOS>
She
covered
it
up
,
with
a
hasty
,
faltering
hand
,
and
in
the
dark
;
and
laid
her
weary
head
down
,
weeping
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
did
not
go
to
bed
for
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
He
walked
to
and
fro
in
the
shop
and
in
the
little
parlour
,
for
a
full
hour
,
and
,
appearing
to
have
composed
himself
by
that
exercise
,
sat
down
with
a
grave
and

face
,
and
read
out
of
a
Prayer
-
book
<EOS>
the
forms
of
prayer
appointed
to
be
used
at
sea
.
<EOS>
These
were
not
easily
disposed
of
;
the
good
Captain
being
a
mighty
slow
,
gruff
reader
,
and
frequently
stopping
at
a
hard
word
to
give
himself
such

as
"
Now
,
my
lad!With
a
will
!
"
<EOS>
or
,
"
Steady
,
Ed'ard
Cuttle
,
steady
!
"
which
had
a
great
effect
in
helping

out

any

.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
his

greatly

with
his
powers
of

.
<EOS>
But
notwithstanding
these
drawbacks
,
the
Captain
,
being
heartily
in

,
read
the
service
to
the

,
and
with
genuine

too
;
and

very

(
but

,
and

's

)

with

,
and

most

.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
turned

several

the

,
to

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Are

,
di'mond
?
"
  
<EOS>

,

Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
The

Poor

!
<EOS>
Drownded
,

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
Nor

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

left
,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Days

---
No

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
with

!
<EOS>
---

the

"
   
"

<EOS>
"
Yes

.
<EOS>
"
Steady

!
<EOS>
courage!Don't

<EOS>
See

!
<EOS>
upon

!
"
  
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
She

,

behind

!
  
<EOS>
She

him

but

"

!
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh

,

!
<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>
She

,

not

,
and
held
him
in

.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
in
a

,
attempted

with
the
blackened

upon

:
and
finding

an

on

,
essayed
to

a

of
Lovely
Peg
,
broke

the

,

shop
,

express

"
Wal'r
,

lad
,

property
as
I
should
wish
to
make
over
,
jintly
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
hastily
produced
the

,

,

,

into

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
But
Walter
sought

out
,
and
brought

;
and
then
the
Captain
's
great

was
,
that
Florence
would
suffer

.
<EOS>
He
felt

so

,
that
he
turned
quite
rational
,
and
positively
interdicted
any

's

for
some

come
.
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
then

sufficiently

to
relieve
himself
of
the

,
and
to
take

at
the

;
but
finding

's

,

and

on

,

,
and
was
missing
for
a
good

.
  
<EOS>
But
never
in
all
his

had

's

<EOS>
so
shone
and

<EOS>
,
as

,

tea

,
looking

to

,
and
from

to

.
<EOS>
Nor

produced
or
at

by
the
immense

of

he
had
administered
to

with

during

.
<EOS>
It

solely
the
effect
of

.
<EOS>
There
was
a
glory
and
delight
within
the
Captain
that
spread
itself
over
his
whole
visage
,
and
made
a
perfect

there
.
  
<EOS>
The
Pride
with
which
the
Captain
looked
upon
the
bronzed

and
the

of
his
recovered
boy
;
with

he
saw

generous

of

,

,

once

,

,

,
and
the

,
would
have
kindled
something
of
this
light
in

.
<EOS>
The

and

with

turned

on

,
whose

,
grace
,

could
have
won

,

.
<EOS>
But

together
,

,

came

,

.
  
<EOS>
How

Sol
,

;

;

,

,

,
fully

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

<EOS>
He

in

They

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
"
Going
,

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

"
round

<EOS>
Within

,

"

---

---

"

"

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

!
"
<EOS>

"

"

!
<EOS>

!
"

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dear

!
<EOS>
Show

---

,
and

<EOS>
Oh

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dombey
!
<EOS>
Florence
!
<EOS>
I
would
die
to

.
<EOS>
But
your
friends
are
proud

.
<EOS>
Your
father
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
!
<EOS>
Walter
!
"
<EOS>
She

,
and
put

,
in

that
transfixed

.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

that
word
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
never
,
from
that

,
forgot
the
voice
and

stopped

.
<EOS>
He
felt
that

he
were

,
he

.
  
<EOS>
Somewhere
---
anywhere
---
but
never
home
!
<EOS>
All
past
,
all

,
all

,
and
broken
up
!
<EOS>
The
whole

of
her
untold

and

was
in

cry
and

;
and
he
felt
he
never
could
forget
it
,
and
he
never

.
  
<EOS>
She
laid
her
gentle
face
upon
the
Captain
's
shoulder
,
and
related
how
and
why
she
had
fled
.
<EOS>
If
every

she
shed
in

,
had

curse
upon
the
head
of
him
she
never

,

would

,
Walter

,
with

than

such

strength

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
precious
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
when
she

;
and
deep
attention
the
Captain
had

to
her
while
she

;
listening
,
with
his

hat
all

and

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Awast
,
awast
,
my

!
<EOS>
Wal'r
,
dear
lad
,
sheer
off
for
to
-
night
,
and
leave

pretty
one
to
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
took
her
hand
in
both
of
his
,
and
put
it
to
his

,
and
kissed

.
<EOS>
He
knew
now
that
she
was
,
indeed
,
a
homeless

fugitive
;
but
,
richer
to
him
so
,
than

all

wealth
and
