of
her
right
station
,
she
seemed
farther
off
than
even
on
the
height
that
had
made
him
giddy
in
his
boyish
dreams
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
perplexed
by
no
such
meditations
,
guarded
Florence
to
her
room
,
and
watched
at
intervals
upon
the
charmed
ground
outside
her
door
---
for
such
it
truly
was
to
him
---
until
he
felt
sufficiently
easy
in
his
mind
about
her
,
to
turn
in
under
the
counter
.
<EOS>
On
abandoning
his
watch
for
that
purpose
,
he
could
not
help
calling
once
,
rapturously
,
through
the
keyhole
,
"
Drownded
.
<EOS>
An't
<EOS>
he
,
pretty
?
"
<EOS>
---
or
,
when
he
got
down
stairs
,
making
another
trial
at
that
verse
of
Lovely
Peg
.
<EOS>
But
it
stuck
in
his
throat
somehow
,
and
he
could
make
nothing
of
it
;
so
he
went
to
bed
,
and
dreamed
that
old
Sol
Gills
was
married
to
Mrs
MacStinger
,
and
kept
prisoner
by
that
lady
in
a
secret
chamber
on
a
short
allowance
of
victuals
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
50
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
's
Complaint
 
<EOS>
THERE
was
an
empty
room
above
-
stairs
at
the
Wooden
Midshipman
's
,
which
,
in
days
of
yore
,
had
been
Walter
's
bedroom
.
<EOS>
Walter
,
rousing
up
the
Captain
betimes
in
the
morning
,
proposed
that
they
should
carry
thither
such
furniture
out
of
the
little
parlour
as
would
grace
it
best
,
so
that
Florence
might
take
possession
of
it
when
she
rose
.
<EOS>
As
nothing
could
be
more
agreeable
to
Captain
Cuttle
than
making
himself
very
red
and
short
of
breath
in
such
a
cause
,
he
turned
to
(
as
he
himself
said
)
with
a
will
;
and
,
in
a
couple
of
hours
,
this
garret
was
transformed
into
a
species
of
land
-
cabin
,
adorned
with
all
the
choicest
moveables
out
of
the
parlour
,
inclusive
even
of
the
Tartar
frigate
,
which
the
Captain
hung
up
over
the
chimneypiece
with
such
extreme
delight
,
that
he
could
do
nothing
for
half
-
an
-
hour
afterwards
but
walk
backward
from
it
,
lost
in
admiration
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
could
be
induced
by
no
persuasion
of
Walter
's
to
wind
up
the
big
watch
,
or
to
take
back
the
canister
,
or
to
touch
the
sugar
-
tongs
and
teaspoons
.
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
my
lad
,
"
was
the
Captain
's
invariable
reply
to
any
solicitation
of
the
kind
,
"
I
've
made
that
there
little
property
over
,
jintly
.
<EOS>
"
These
words
he
repeated
with
great
unction
and
gravity
,
evidently
believing
that
they
had
the
virtue
of
an
Act
of
Parliament
,
and
that
unless
he
committed
himself
by
some
new
admission
of
ownership
,
no
flaw
could
be
found
in
such
a
form
of
conveyance
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
an
advantage
of
the
new
arrangement
,
that
besides
the
greater
seclusion
it
afforded
Florence
<EOS>
,
it
admitted
of
the
Midshipman
being
restored
to
his
usual
post
of
observation
,
and
also
of
the
shop
shutters
being
taken
down
.
<EOS>
The
latter
ceremony
,
however
little
importance
the
unconscious
Captain
attached
to
it
,
was
not
wholly
superfluous
;
for
,
on
the
previous
day
,
so
much
excitement
had
been
occasioned
in
the
neighbourhood
,
by
the
shutters
remaining
unopened
,
that
the
Instrument
-
maker
's
house
had
been
honoured
with
an
unusual
share
of
public
observation
,
and
had
been
intently
stared
at
from
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
,
by
groups
of
hungry
gazers
,
at
any
time
between
sunrise
and
sunset
.
<EOS>
The
idlers
and
vagabonds
had
been
particularly
interested
in
the
Captain
's
fate
;
constantly
grovelling
in
the
mud
to
apply
their
eyes
to
the
cellar
-
grating
,
under
the
shop
-
window
,
and
delighting
their
imaginations
with
the
fancy
that
they
could
see
a
piece
of
his
coat
as
he
hung
in
a
corner
;
though
this
settlement
of
him
was
stoutly
disputed
by
an
opposite
faction
,
who
were
of
opinion
that
he
lay
murdered
with
a
hammer
,
on
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
without
exciting
some
discontent
,
therefore
,
that
the
subject
of
these
rumours
was
seen
early
in
the
morning
standing
at
his
shop
-
door
as
hale
and
hearty
as
if
nothing
had
happened
;
and
the
beadle
of
that
quarter
,
a
man
of
an
ambitious
character
,
who
had
expected
to
have
the
distinction
of
being
present
at
the
breaking
open
of
the
door
,
and
of
giving
evidence
in
full
uniform
before
the
corner
,
went
so
far
as
to
say
to
an
opposite
neighbour
,
that
the
chap
in
the
glazed
hat
had
better
not
try
it
on
there
---
without
more
particularly
mentioning
<EOS>
what
---
and
further
,
that
he
,
the
Beadle
,
would
keep
his
eye
upon
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
said
Walter
,
musing
,
when
they
stood
resting
from
their
labours
at
the
shop
-
door
,
looking
down
the
old
familiar
street
;
it
being
still
early
in
the
morning
;
"
nothing
at
all
of
Uncle
Sol
,
in
all
that
time
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
at
all
,
my
lad
,
"
replied
the
Captain
,
shaking
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gone
in
search
of
me
,
dear
,
kind
old
man
,
"
said
Walter
:
"
yet
never
write
to
you
!
<EOS>
But
why
not
?
<EOS>
He
says
,
in
effect
,
in
this
packet
that
you
gave
me
,
"
taking
the
paper
from
his
pocket
,
which
had
been
opened
in
the
presence
of
the
enlightened
Bunsby
,
"
that
if
you
never
hear
from
him
before
opening
it
,
you
may
believe
him
dead
.
<EOS>
Heaven
forbid
!
<EOS>
But
you
would
have
heard
of
him
,
even
if
he
were
dead
!
<EOS>
Some
one
would
have
written
,
surely
,
by
his
desire
,
if
he
could
not
;
and
have
said
,
"
on
such
a
day
,
there
died
in
my
house
,
"
or
"
under
my
care
,
"
or
so
forth
,
"
Mr
Solomon
Gills
of
London
,
who
left
this
last
remembrance
and
this
last
request
to
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
The
Captain
,
who
had
never
climbed
to
such
a
clear
height
of
probability
before
,
was
greatly
impressed
by
the
wide
prospect
it
opened
,
and
answered
,
with
a
thoughtful
shake
of
his
head
,
"
Well
said
,
my
lad
;
wery
well
said
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
have
been
thinking
of
this
,
or
,
at
least
,
"
said
Walter
,
colouring
,
"
I
have
been
thinking
of
one
thing
and
another
,
all
through
a
sleepless
night
,
and
I
can
not
believe
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
but
that
my
Uncle
Sol
(
Lord
bless
him
!
)
is
alive
,
and
will
return
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
so
much
wonder
at
his
going
away
,
because
,
leaving
out
of
consideration
that
spice
of
the
marvellous
which
was
always
in
his
character
,
and
his
great
affection
for
me
,
before
which
every
other
consideration
of
his
life
became
nothing
,
as
no
one
ought
to
know
so
well
as
I
who
had
the
best
of
fathers
in
him
,
"
<EOS>
---
Walter
's
voice
was
indistinct
and
husky
here
,
and
he
looked
away
,
along
the
street
,
---
"
leaving
that
out
of
consideration
<EOS>
,
I
say
,
I
have
often
read
and
heard
of
people
who
,
having
some
near
and
dear
relative
,
who
was
supposed
to
be
shipwrecked
at
sea
,
have
gone
down
to
live
on
that
part
of
the
sea
-
shore
where
any
tidings
of
the
missing
ship
might
be
expected
to
arrive
,
though
only
an
hour
or
two
sooner
than
elsewhere
,
or
have
even
gone
upon
her
track
to
the
place
<EOS>
whither
she
was
bound
,
as
if
their
going
would
create
intelligence
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
should
do
such
a
thing
myself
,
as
soon
as
another
,
or
sooner
than
many
,
perhaps
.
<EOS>
But
why
my
uncle
should
n't
write
to
you
,
when
he
so
clearly
intended
to
do
so
,
or
how
he
should
die
abroad
,
and
you
not
know
it
through
some
other
hand
,
I
can
not
make
out
.
"
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
observed
,
with
a
shake
of
his
head
,
that
Jack
Bunsby
himself
had
n't
made
it
out
,
and
that
he
was
a
man
as
could
give
a
pretty
taut
opinion
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
my
uncle
had
been
a
heedless
young
man
,
likely
to
be
entrapped
by
jovial
company
to
some
drinking
-
place
,
where
he
was
to
be
got
rid
of
for
the
sake
of
what
money
he
might
have
about
him
,
"
said
Walter
;
"
or
if
he
had
been
a
reckless
sailor
,
going
ashore
with
two
or
three
months
'
pay
in
his
pocket
,
I
could
understand
his
disappearing
,
and
leaving
no
trace
behind
.
<EOS>
But
,
being
what
he
was
---
and
is
,
I
hope
---
I
ca
n't
believe
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
,
my
lad
,
"
inquired
the
Captain
wistfully
eyeing
him
as
he
pondered
and
pondered
,
"
What
do
you
make
of
it
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
returned
Walter
,
"
I
do
n't
know
what
to
make
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
he
never
has
written
!
<EOS>
There
is
no
doubt
about
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
so
be
as
Sol
Gills
wrote
,
my
lad
,
"
replied
the
Captain
,
argumentatively
,
"
<EOS>
where
's
his
dispatch
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say
that
he
intrusted
it
to
some
private
hand
,
"
suggested
Walter
,
"
and
that
it
has
been
forgotten
,
or
carelessly
thrown
aside
,
or
lost
.
<EOS>
Even
that
is
more
probable
to
me
,
than
the
other
event
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
I
not
only
can
not
bear
to
contemplate
that
other
event
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
but
I
ca
n't
,
and
wo
n't
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hope
,
you
see
,
Wal'r
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
sagely
,
"
Hope
.
<EOS>
It
's
that
as
animates
you
.
<EOS>
Hope
is
a
buoy
,
for
which
you
overhaul
your
Little
Warbler
,
sentimental
diwision
,
but
Lord
,
my
lad
,
like
any
other
buoy
,
it
only
floats
;
it
ca
n't
be
steered
nowhere
.
<EOS>
Along
with
the
figure
-
head
of
Hope
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
"
there
's
a
anchor
;
but
what
's
the
good
of
my
having
a
anchor
,
if
I
ca
n't
find
no
bottom
to
let
it
go
in
?
"
  
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
said
this
rather
in
his
character
of
a
sagacious
citizen
and
householder
,
bound
to
impart
a
morsel
from
his
stores
of
wisdom
,
to
an
inexperienced
youth
,
than
in
his
own
proper
person
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
his
face
was
quite
luminous
as
he
spoke
,
with
new
hope
,
caught
from
Walter
;
and
he
appropriately
concluded
by
slapping
him
on
the
back
;
and
saying
,
with
enthusiasm
,
"
Hooroar
,
my
lad
!
<EOS>
Indiwidually
,
I
'm
o
'
your
opinion
.
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
,
with
his
cheerful
laugh
,
returned
the
salutation
,
and
said
:
  
"
Only
one
word
more
about
my
uncle
at
present
,
Captain
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
is
impossible
that
he
can
have
written
in
the
ordinary
course
---
by
mail
packet
,
or
ship
letter
,
you
understand
---
"
  
"
Aye
,
aye
,
my
lad
,
"
said
the
Captain
approvingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
And
that
you
have
missed
the
letter
any
how
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Wal'r
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
turning
his
eyes
upon
him
with
a
faint
approach
to
a
severe
expression
,
"
an't
<EOS>
I
been
on
the
look
out
for
any
tidings
of
that
man
o
'
science
,
old
Sol
Gills
,
your
uncle
,
day
and
night
,
ever
since
I
lost

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
An't
<EOS>
my
heart
been
heavy
and
watchful
always
,
along
of
him
and
you
?
<EOS>
Sleeping
and
waking
,
an't
<EOS>
I
been
upon
my
post
,
and
would
n't
I
scorn
to
quit
it
while
this
here
Midshipman
held
together
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Captain
Cuttle
,
"
replied
Walter
,
grasping

,
"
I
know
you
would
,
and
I
know
how
faithful
and
earnest
all
you
say
and
feel
is
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
of
it
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
doubt
that
I
am
as

as
I

that
my

is
again

this
door
-
step
or
that

again
have
hold

this
true
hand
.
<EOS>
Do
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
Wal'r
,
"
returned
the
Captain
,
with
his
beaming
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
hazard
no
more
conjectures
,
"
said
Walter
,
fervently
shaking
the
hard
hand
of
the
Captain
,
who
shook
his
with
no
less
good
-
will
.
<EOS>
"
All
I
will
add
is
,
Heaven
forbid
that
I
should
touch
my
uncle
's
possessions
,
Captain
Cuttle
!
<EOS>
Everything
that
he
left
here
,
shall
remain
in
the
care
of
the
truest
of
stewards
and
kindest
of
men
---
and
if
his
name
is
not
Cuttle
,
he
has
no
name
!
<EOS>
Now
,
best
of
friends
,
about
---
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
change
in
Walter
's
manner
,
as
he
came
to
these
two
words
;
and
when
he
uttered
them
,
all
his
confidence
and
cheerfulness
appeared
to
have
deserted
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
,
before
Miss
Dombey
stopped
me
when
I
spoke
of
her
father
last
night
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
---
<EOS>
you
remember
how
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
well
remembered
,
and
shook
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
before
that
,
that
we
had
but
one
hard
duty
to
perform
,
and
that
it
was
,
to
prevail
upon
her
to
communicate
with
her
friends
,
and
to
return
home
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
muttered
a
feeble
"
Awast
!
"
or
a
"
Stand
by
!
"
or
something
or
other
,
equally
pertinent
to
the
occasion
;
but
it
was
rendered
so
extremely
feeble
by
the
total
discomfiture
with
which
he
received
this
announcement
,
that
what
it
was
,
is
mere
matter
of
conjecture
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
that
is
over
.
<EOS>
I
think
so
no
longer
.
<EOS>
I
would
sooner
be
put
back
again
upon
that
piece
of
wreck
,
on
which
I
have
so
often
floated
,
since
my
preservation
,
in
my
dreams
,
and
there
left
to
drift
,
and
drive
,
and
die
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hooroar
,
my
lad
!
"
exclaimed
the
Captain
,
in
a
burst
of
uncontrollable
satisfaction
.
"
<EOS>
Hooroar
!
<EOS>
hooroar
!
<EOS>
hooroar
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
think
that

<EOS>

yours
,
"
said
Walter
,
not
at
all
slow
in
returning
his
greeting
,
"
to
find
that
you
can
render
service
to
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
will
you
have
the
kindness
to
take
Mr
Toots
up
stairs
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
beckoned
to
Mr
Toots
,
who
followed
him
with
a
bewildered
countenance
,
and
,
ascending
to
the
top
of
the
house
,
was
introduced
,
without
a
word
of
preparation
from
his
conductor
,
into
Florence
's
new
retreat
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Mr
Toots
's
amazement
and
pleasure
at
sight
of
her
were
such
,
that
they
could
find
a
vent
in
nothing
but
extravagance
.
<EOS>
He
ran
up
to
her
,
seized
her
hand
,
kissed
it
,
dropped
it
,
seized
it
again
,
fell
upon
one
knee
,
shed
tears
,
chuckled
,
and
was
quite
regardless
of
his
danger
of
being
pinned
by
Diogenes
,
who
,
inspired
by
the
belief
that
there
was
something
hostile
to
his
mistress
in
these
demonstrations
,
worked
round
and
round
him
,
as
if
only
undecided
at
what
particular
point
to
go
in
for
the
assault
,
but
quite
resolved
to
do
him
a
fearful
mischief
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Di
,
you
bad
,
forgetful
dog
!
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Toots
,
I
am
so
rejoiced
to
see
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
I
am
pretty
well
,
I
'm
much
obliged
to
you
,
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
I
hope
all
the
family
are
the
same
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
said
this
without
the
least
notion
of
what
he
was
talking
about
,
and
sat
down
on
a
chair
,
staring
at
Florence
with
the
liveliest
contention
of
delight
and
despair
going
on
in
his
face
that
any
face
could
exhibit
.
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Gills
and
Lieutenant
Walters
have
mentioned
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
gasped
Mr
Toots
,
"
that
I
can
do
you
some
service
.
<EOS>
If
I
could
by
any
means
wash
out
the
remembrance
of
that
day
at
Brighton
,
when
I
conducted
myself
---
much
more
like
a
Parricide
than
a
person
of
independent
property
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
with
severe
self
-
accusation
,
"
I
should
sink
into
the
silent
tomb
with
a
gleam
of
joy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
Mr
Toots
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
do
not
wish
me
to
forget
anything
in
our
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
I
never
can
,
believe
me
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
far
too
kind
and
good
to
me
always
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Miss
Dombey
,
"
returned
Mr
Toots
,
"
your
consideration
for
my
feelings
is
a
part
of
your
angelic
character
.
<EOS>
Thank
you
a
thousand
times
.
<EOS>
It
's
of
no
consequence
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
we
thought
of
asking
you
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
is
,
whether
you
remember
where
Susan
,
whom
you
were
so
kind
as
to
accompany
to
the
coach
-
office
when
she
left
me
,
is
to
be
found
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
I
do
not
certainly
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
after
a
little
consideration
,
"
remember
the
exact
name
of
the
place
that
was
on
the
coach
;
and
I
do
recollect
that
she
said
she
was
not
going
to
stop
there
,
but
was
going
farther
on
.
<EOS>
But
,
Miss
Dombey
,
if
your
object
is
to
find
her
,
and
to
have
her
here
,
myself
and
the
Chicken
will
produce
her
with
every
dispatch
that
devotion
on
my
part
,
and
great
intelligence
on
the
Chicken
's
,
can
insure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
was
so
manifestly
delighted
and
revived
by
the
prospect
of
being
useful
,
and
the
disinterested
sincerity
of
his
devotion
was
so
unquestionable
,
that
it
would
have
been
cruel
to
refuse
him
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
with
an
instinctive
delicacy
,
forbore
to
urge
the
least
obstacle
,
though
she
did
not
forbear
to
over
-
power
him
with
thanks
;
and
Mr
Toots
proudly
took
the
commission
upon
himself
for
immediate
execution
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dombey
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
touching
her
proffered
hand
,
with
a
pang
of
hopeless
love
visibly
shooting
through
him
,
and
flashing
out
in
his
face
,
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
Allow
me
to
take
the
liberty
of
saying
,
that
your
misfortunes
make
me
perfectly
wretched
,
and
that
you
may
trust
me
,
next
to
Captain
Gills
himself
.
<EOS>
I
am
quite
aware
,
Miss
Dombey
,
of
my
own
deficiencies
---
they
're
not
of
the
least
consequence
,
thank
you
---
<EOS>
but
I
am
entirely
to
be
relied
upon
,
I
do
assure
you
,
Miss
Dombey
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
Mr
Toots
came
out
of
the
room
,
again
accompanied
by
the
Captain
,
who
,
standing
at
a
little
distance
,
holding
his
hat
under
his
arm
and
arranging
his
scattered
locks
with
his
hook
,
had
been
a
not
uninterested
witness
of
what
passed
.
<EOS>
And
when
the
door
closed
behind
them
,
the
light
of
Mr
Toots
's
life
was
darkly
clouded
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Gills
,
"
said
that
gentleman
,
stopping
near
the
bottom
of
the
stairs
,
and
turning
round
,
"
to
tell
you
the
truth
,
I
am
not
in
a
frame
of
mind
at
the
present
moment
,
in
which
I
could
see
Lieutenant
Walters
with
that
entirely
friendly
feeling
towards
him
that
I
should
wish
to
harbour
in
my
breast
.
<EOS>
We
can
not
always
command
our
feelings
,
Captain
Gills
,
and
I
should
take
it
as
a
particular
favour
if
you
'd
let
me
out
at
the
private
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
"
returned
the
Captain
,
"
you
shall
shape
your
own
course
.
<EOS>
Wotever
course
you
take
,
is
plain
and
seamanlike
,
I
'm
wery
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Captain
Gills
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
you
're
extremely
kind
.
<EOS>
Your
good
opinion
is
a
consolation
to
me
.
<EOS>
There
is
one
thing
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
standing
in
the
passage
,
behind
the
half
-
opened
door
,
"
that
I
hope
you
'll
bear
in
mind
,
Captain
Gills
,
and
that
I
should
wish
Lieutenant
Walters
to
be
made
acquainted
with
.
<EOS>
I
have
quite
come
into
my
property
now
,
you
know
,
and
---
<EOS>
and
I
do
n't
know
what
to
do
with
it
.
<EOS>
If
I
could
be
at
all
useful
in
a
pecuniary
point
of
view
,
I
should
glide
into
the
silent
tomb
with
ease
and
smoothness
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
said
no
more
,
but
slipped
out
quietly
and
shut
the
door
upon
himself
,
to
cut
the
Captain
off
from
any
reply
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
thought
of
this
good
creature
,
long
after
he
had
left
her
,
with
mingled
emotions
of
pain
and
pleasure
.
<EOS>
He
was
so
honest
and
warm
-
hearted
,
that
to
see
him
again
and
be
assured
of
his
truth
to
her
in
her
distress
,
was
a
joy
and
comfort
beyond
all
price
;
but
for
that
very
reason
,
it
was
so
affecting
to
think
that
she
caused
him
a
moment
's
unhappiness
,
or
ruffled
,
by
a
breath
,
the
harmless
current
of
his
life
,
that
her
eyes
filled
with
tears
,
and
her
bosom
overflowed
with
pity
.
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
,
in
his
different
way
,
thought
much
of
Mr
Toots
too
;
and
so
did
Walter
;
and
when
the
evening
came
,
and
they
were
all
sitting
together
in
Florence
's
new
room
,
Walter
praised
him
in
a
most
impassioned
manner
,
and
told
Florence
what
he
had
said
on
leaving
the
house
,
with
every
graceful
setting
-
off
in
the
way
of
comment
and
appreciation
that
his
own
honesty
and
sympathy
could
surround
it
with
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
did
not
return
upon
the
next
day
,
or
the
next
,
or
for
several
days
;
and
in
the
meanwhile
Florence
,
without
any
new
alarm
,
live
like
a
quiet
bird
in
a
cage
,
at
the
top
of
the
old
Instrument
-
maker
's
house
.
<EOS>
But
Florence
drooped
and
hung
her
head
more
and
more
plainly
,
as
the
days
went
on
;
and
the
expression
that
had
been
seen
in
the
face
of
the
dead
child
,
was
often
turned
to
the
sky
from
her
high
window
,
as
if
it
sought
his
angel
out
,
on
the
bright
shore
of
which
he
had
spoken
:
lying
on
his
little
bed
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
had
been
weak
and
delicate
of
late
,
and
the
agitation
she
had
undergone
was
not
without
its
influences
on
her
health
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
no
bodily
illness
that
affected
her
now
.
<EOS>
She
was
distressed
in
mind
;
and
the
cause
of
her
distress
was
Walter
.
  
<EOS>
Interested
in
her
,
anxious
for
her
,
proud
and
glad
to
serve
her
,
and
showing
all
this
with
the
enthusiasm
and
ardour
of
his
character
<EOS>
,
Florence
saw
that
he
avoided
her
.
<EOS>
All
the
long
day
through
,
he
seldom
approached
her
room
.
<EOS>
If
she
asked
for
him
,
he
came
,
again
for
the
moment
as
earnest
and
as
bright
as
she
remembered
him
when
she
was
a
lost
child
in
the
staring
streets
;
but
he
soon
became
constrained
---
her
quick
affection
was
too
watchful
not
to
know
it
---
and
uneasy
,
and
soon
left
her
.
<EOS>
Unsought
,
he
never
came
,
all
day
,
between
the
morning
and
the
night
.
<EOS>
When
the
evening
closed
in
,
he
was
always
there
,
and
that
was
her
happiest
time
,
<EOS>
for
then
she
half
believed
that
the
old
Walter
of
her
childhood
was
not
changed
.
<EOS>
But
,
even
then
,
some
trivial
word
,
look
,
or
circumstance
would
show
her
that
there
was
an
indefinable
division
between
them
which
could
not
be
passed
.
  
<EOS>
And
she
could
not
but
see
that
these
revealings
of
a
great
alteration
in
Walter
manifested
themselves
in
despite
of
his
utmost
efforts
to
hide
them
.
<EOS>
In
his
consideration
for
her
,
she
thought
,
and
in
the
earnestness
of
his
desire
to
spare
her
any
wound
from
his
kind
hand
,
he
resorted
to
innumerable
little
artifices
and
disguises
.
<EOS>
So
much
the
more
did
Florence
feel
the
greatness
of
the
alteration
in
him
;
so
much
the
oftener
<EOS>
did
she
weep
at
this
estrangement
of
her
brother
.
  
<EOS>
The
good
Captain
---
<EOS>
her
untiring
,
tender
,
ever
zealous
friend
---
saw
it
,
too
,
Florence
thought
,
and
it
pained
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
less
cheerful
and
hopeful
than
he
had
been
at
first
,
and
would
steal
looks
at
her
and
Walter
,
by
turns
,
when
they
were
all
three
together
of
an
evening
,
with
quite
a
sad
face
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
resolved
,
at
last
,
to
speak
to
Walter
.
<EOS>
She
believed
she
knew
now
what
the
cause
of
his
estrangement
was
,
and
she
thought
it
would
be
a
relief
to
her
full
heart
,
and
would
set
him
more
at
ease
,
if
she
told
him
she
had
found
it
out
,
and
quite
submitted
to
it
,
and
did
not
reproach
him
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
on
a
certain
Sunday
afternoon
,
that
Florence
took
this
resolution
.
<EOS>
The
faithful
Captain
,
in
an
amazing
shirt
-
collar
,
was
sitting
by
her
,
reading
with
his
spectacles
on
,
and
she
asked
him
where
Walter
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
's
down
below
,
my
lady
lass
,
"
returned
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
speak
to
him
,
"
said
Florence
,
rising
hurriedly
as
if
to
go
down
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
rouse
him
up
here
,
Beauty
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
"
in
a
trice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Thereupon
the
Captain
,
with
much
alacrity
,
shouldered
his
book
---
<EOS>
for
he
made
it
a
point
of
duty
to
read
none
but
very
large
books
on
a
Sunday
,
as
having
a
more
staid
appearance
:
and
had
bargained
,
years
ago
,
for
a
prodigious
volume
at
a
book
-
stall
,
five
lines
of
which
utterly
confounded
him
at
any
time
,
insomuch
that
he
had
not
yet
ascertained
of
what
subject
it
treated
---
and
withdrew
.
<EOS>
Walter
soon
appeared
.
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Cuttle
tells
me
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
he
eagerly
began
on
coming
in
---
but
stopped
when
he
saw
her
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
so
well
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
You
look
distressed
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
weeping
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
spoke
so
kindly
,
and
with
such
a
fervent
tremor
in
his
voice
,
that
the
tears
gushed
into
her
eyes
at
the
sound
of
his
words
.
  
<EOS>
"
Walter
,
"
said
Florence
,
gently
,
"
I
am
not
quite
well
,
and
I
have
been
weeping
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
speak
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
sat
down
opposite
to
her
,
looking
at
her
beautiful
and
innocent
face
:
and
his
own
turned
pale
,
and
his
lips
trembled
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
said
,
upon
the
night
when
I
knew
that
you
were
saved
---
<EOS>
and
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
dear
Walter
,
what
I
felt
that
night
,
and
what
I
hoped
!
"
<EOS>
---
   
<EOS>
He
put
his
trembling
hand
upon
the
table
between
them
,
and
sat
looking
at
her
.
   
<EOS>
---
"
that
I
was
changed
.
<EOS>
I
was
surprised
to
hear
you
say
so
,
but
I
understand
,
now
,
that
I
am
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
angry
with
me
,
Walter
.
<EOS>
I
was
too
much
overjoyed
to
think
of
it
,
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
seemed
a
child
to
him
again
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
ingenuous
,
confiding
,
loving
child
he
saw
and
heard
.
<EOS>
Not
the
dear
woman
,
at
whose
feet
he
would
have
laid
the
riches
of
the
earth
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
remember
the
last
time
I
saw
you
,
Walter
,
before
you
went
away
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
put
his
hand
into
his
breast
,
and
took
out
a
little
purse
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
worn
it
round
my
neck
!
<EOS>
If
I
had
gone
down
in
the
deep
,
it
would
have
been
with
me
at
the
bottom
of
the
sea
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
wear
it
still
,
Walter
,
for
my
old
sake
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Until
I
die
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
laid
her
hand
on
his
,
as
fearlessly
and
simply
,
as
if
not
a
day
had
intervened
since
she
gave
him
the
little
token
of
remembrance
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
that
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
always
glad
to
think
so
,
Walter
.
<EOS>
Do
you
recollect
that
a
thought
of
this
change
seemed
to
come
into
our
minds
at
the
same
time
that
evening
,
when
we
were
talking
together
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
<EOS>
he
answered
,
in
a
wondering
tone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Walter
.
<EOS>
I
had
been
the
means
of
injuring
your
hopes
and
prospects
even
then
.
<EOS>
I
feared
to
think
so
,
then
,
but
I
know
it
now
.
<EOS>
If
you
were
able
,
then
,
in
your
generosity
,
to
hide
from
me
that
you
knew
it
too
,
you
can
not
do
so
now
,
although
you
try
as
generously
as
before
.
<EOS>
You
do
.
<EOS>
I
thank
you
for
it
,
Walter
,
deeply
,
truly
;
but
you
can
not
succeed
.
<EOS>
You
have
suffered
too
much
in
your
own
hardships
,
and
in
those
of
your
dearest
relation
,
quite
to
overlook
the
innocent
cause
of
all
the
peril
and
affliction
that
has
befallen
you
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
quite
forget
me
in
that
character
,
and
we
can
be
brother
and
sister
no
longer
.
<EOS>
But
,
dear
Walter
,
do
not
think
that
I
complain
of
you
in
this
.
<EOS>
I
might
have
known
it
---
ought
to
have
known
it
---
but
forgot
it
in
my
joy
.
<EOS>
All
I
hope
is
that
you
may
think
of
me
less
irksomely
when
this
feeling
is
no
more
a
secret
one
;
and
all
I
ask
is
,
Walter
,
in
the
name
of
the
poor
child
who
was
your
sister
once
,
that
you
will
not
struggle
with
yourself
,
and
pain
yourself
,
for
my
sake
,
now
that
I
know
all
!
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
had
looked
upon
her
while
she
said
this
,
with
a
face
so
full
of
wonder
and
amazement
,
that
it
had
room
for
nothing
else
.
<EOS>
Now
he
caught
up
the
hand
that
touched
his
,
so
entreatingly
,
and
held
it
between
his
own
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Miss
Dombey
,
"
he
said
,
"
is
it
possible
that
while
I
have
been
suffering
so

,
in
striving
with
my
sense
of
what
is
due
to
you
,
and
must
be
rendered
to
you
,
I
have
made
you
suffer
what
your
words
disclose
to

?
<EOS>
Never
,
never
,
before
Heaven
,
have
I
thought

you
but
as
the
single
,
bright
,

,

of
my

and
my

.
<EOS>
Never
have
I
from
the
first
,
and
never

I
to

,

your

in
my

,
but
as
something
sacred
,
never
to
be
lightly

of
,
never
to
be
esteemed

,
never
,
until

,

be

.
<EOS>
Again

see

look
,
and

,

you

on
that
night
when
we
parted
,
is
happiness
to

that
there

no
words
to
utter
;
and
to
be
loved
and
trusted
as
your
brother
,
is
the
next
great
gift
I
could
receive
and
prize
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Walter
,
"
said
Florence
,
looking
at
him
earnestly
,
but
with
a
changing
face
<EOS>
,
"
what
is
that
which
is
due
to
me
,
and
must

rendered

,
at
the

all
this
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Respect
,
"
said
Walter
,
in
a
low
tone
.
<EOS>
"
Reverence
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
colour
dawned
in
her
face
,
and
she
timidly
and

withdrew
her

;
still

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
a
brother
's
right
,
"
said
Walter
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
a
brother
's
claim
.
<EOS>
I
left
a
child
.
<EOS>
I
find
a
woman
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
colour
overspread
her
face
.
<EOS>
She
made
a

as
if
of
entreaty
that
he
would
say
no
more
,
and
her
face
dropped
upon

.
  
<EOS>
They
were
both

for
a

;
she
weeping
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
owe
it
to

,

,

,
"
said

,
"

,

I
rend
my
own
.
<EOS>
How
dare
I
say

is
my
sister
's
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
weeping
still
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
been
happy
;
surrounded
as
you

by

,

station
you

enviable
,
"

;
"
and
if

,
then
,

your

of
the
past
,
I
could

,
with
no

that
I

your
spotless

.
<EOS>
But
here
---

!
"
---
   
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
thank

,
Walter
!
<EOS>
Forgive

so

.
<EOS>
I
had
no
one
to

.
<EOS>
I
am
quite
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
!
"
said
Walter
,
passionately
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
hurried
on
to
say
,
what
I
thought
,
but
a

ago
,
nothing
could
have
forced
from

.
<EOS>
If
I
had
been

;
if

being
one

able

;

---

,

---

in

,

.
<EOS>
I

have

that
it

that

,

;
but
that

,

,
that
the
undivided
truth
and
fervour
of

would
poorly

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
head
was
still

,
the

still

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Florence
!
<EOS>
Dearest
Florence
!
<EOS>
whom
I
called
so
in
my

before
I

and

.
<EOS>
One
last

let

call
you
by

own

,
and
touch
this
gentle

in

of

I

said
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
raised

,
and
spoke

with

;

;
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Walter
,
I
can
not
forget
it
.
<EOS>
I
would
not

it
,

the
world
.
<EOS>
Are

---

very

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
but

,
"
said
Walter
,
"
making
voyages

.
<EOS>
That

now
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Are
you
soon
going
away
again
,
Walter
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Very
soon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
sat

at

for

;
then
timidly

her

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you

take

wife
,
Walter
,
I

.
<EOS>
If

me

with

,
Walter
,
I
will

to
the
world
's
end

.
<EOS>
I
can

nothing
for
you
---
<EOS>
I
have
nothing

,
and
no

;
but

,
and
with

last

I
will

your
name
to
God
if
I

sense
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
caught
her
to
his
heart
,
and
laid
her

against

own
,
and
now
,
no

,
no

,
she
wept

,
upon

of
her

.
  
<EOS>
Blessed
Sunday
Bells
,
ringing
so

in
their
entranced
and
happy

!
<EOS>
Blessed
Sunday
peace
and
quiet
,
harmonising
with
the
calmness
in
their

,
and
making

around

!
<EOS>
Blessed
twilight
stealing

,
and
shading

so

and

,
as
she
falls

,
like

,
upon

bosom

!
  
<EOS>
Oh
load
of
love
and
trustfulness
that
lies
so
lightly
there!Aye
,
look
down
on
the
closed

,
Walter
,

;
for
in
all
the
wide
wide
world
they
seek
but
thee
now
---
only
thee
!
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
remained
in
the
little
parlour
until
it
was
quite
dark
.
<EOS>
He
took
the
chair
on
which
Walter
had
been
sitting
,
and
looked
up
at
the
skylight
,
until
the
day
,
by

and

,
faded

,
and
the

peeped
down
.
<EOS>
He
lighted
a

,
lighted

pipe
,
smoked

,
and
wondered
what
on
earth
was
going
on
up
stairs
,
and
why
they
did
n't
call
him
to
tea
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
came
to
his
side
while
he
was
in
the
height

.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
lady
lass
!
"
cried

Captain
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
and
Wal'r
have
had
a
long
spell
o
'
talk
,
my
beauty
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
put
her
little

round
one
of
the
great
buttons
of

coat
,
and
said
,
looking
down
into

:
  
"
Dear
Captain
,
I
want

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
raised

,

.
<EOS>
Catching

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
Heart
's
Delight
!
"
cried

Captain
,
suddenly

.
"
<EOS>
Is
it
that
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
said
Florence
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Wal'r
!
<EOS>
Husband
!
<EOS>
THAT
?
<EOS>
"
roared

Captain
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Florence
,
laughing
and
crying
together
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
immediately
hugged
her
;
and
then
,
picking
up
the
glazed
hat
and
putting
it
on
,
drew
her
arm
through
his
,
and
conducted
her
up
stairs
again
;
where
he
felt
that
the
great
joke
of
his
life
was
now
to
be
made
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
Wal'r
my
lad
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
looking
in
at
the
door
,
with
his
face
like
an
amiable
warming
-
pan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
there
ai
n't
NO
other
character
,
ai
n't
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
like
to
have
suffocated
himself
with
this
pleasantry
,
which
he
repeated
at
least
forty
times
during
tea
;
polishing
his
radiant
face
with
the

of
his
coat
,
and
dabbing
his

all
over
with
his
pocket

handkerchief
,
in

.
<EOS>
But
he
was
not
without
a
graver

of

to
fall
back
upon
,
when
so
disposed
,
for
he

repeatedly

say
in
an
under

,
as

:
  
"
<EOS>
Ed'ard
<EOS>
Cuttle
,
my
lad
<EOS>
,
you
never
shaped
a
better

in
your
life
,
than
when
you
made
that
there
little
property
over
,
jintly
!
"
    
Chapter
51
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
and
the
World
 
<EOS>
WHAT
is
the
proud
man
doing
,
while
the
days
go
by
?
<EOS>
Does
he
ever
think
of
his
daughter
,
or
wonder
where
she
is
gone
?
<EOS>
Does
he
suppose
she
has
come
home
,
and
is
leading
her
old
life
in
the
weary
house
?
<EOS>
No
one
can
answer
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
has
never
utter
her
name
,
since
.
<EOS>
His
household
dread
him
too
much
to
approach
a
subject
on
which
he
is
resolutely
dumb
;
and
the
only
person
who
dares
question
him
,
he
silences
immediately
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Paul
!
<EOS>
"
murmurs
his
sister
,
sidling
into
the
room
,
on
the
day
of
Florence
's
departure
,
"
your
wife
!
<EOS>
that
upstart
woman
!
<EOS>
Is
it
possible
that
what
I
hear
confusedly
,
is
true
,
and
that

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
My

!
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
Mrs

,

degenerate

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
He

,

,

,

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
  
<EOS>
But

;
he
does

.
<EOS>
He

of

.
<EOS>
He

,
seeing

,

patient

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The
root

,

<EOS>
The

.
  
<EOS>

hide

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

her
old
acquaintance
with
Mrs
Pipchin
,
in
order
to
get
certain
information
of
the
state
of
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
does
he
bear
it
,
my
dear
creature
?
"
asks
Miss
Tox
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
says
Mrs
Pipchin
,
in
her
snappish
way
,
"
he
's
pretty
much
as
usual
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Externally
,
"
suggests
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
But
what
he
feels
within
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
's
hard
grey
eye
looks
doubtful
as
she
answers
,
in
three
distinct
jerks
,
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
Perhaps
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
tell
you
my
mind
,
Lucretia
,
"
says
Mrs
Pipchin
;
she
still
calls
Miss
Tox
Lucretia
,
on
account
of
having
made
her
first
experiments
in
the
child
-
quelling
line
of
business
on
that
lady
,
when
an
unfortunate
and
weazen
little
girl
of
tender
years
;
"
to
tell
you
my
mind
,
Lucretia
<EOS>
,
I
think
it
's
a
good
riddance
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
any
of
your
brazen
faces
here
,
myself
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Brazen
indeed
!
<EOS>
Well
may
you
say
brazen
,
Mrs
Pipchin
!
<EOS>
"
returns
Miss
Tox
.
"
<EOS>
To
leave
him
!
<EOS>
Such
a
noble
figure
of
a
man
!
"
<EOS>
And
here
Miss
Tox
is
overcome
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
about
noble
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
observes
Mrs
Pipchin
,
irascibly
rubbing
her
nose
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
know
this
---
that
when
people
meet
with
trails
,
they
must
bear
'em
.
<EOS>
Hoity
,
toity!I
have
had
enough
to
bear
myself
,
in
my
time
!
<EOS>
What
a
fuss
there
is
!
<EOS>
She
's
gone
and
well
got
rid
of
.
<EOS>
Nobody
wants
her
back
,
I
should
think
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
hint
of
the
Peruvian
Mines
,
causes
Miss
Tox
to
rise
to
go
away
;
when
Mrs
Pipchin
rings
the
bell
for
Towlinson
to
show
her

.
<EOS>
Mr
Towlinson
,
not
having
seen
Miss
Tox
for
ages
,
grins
,
and
hopes
she
's
well
;
observing
that
he
did
n't
know
her
at
first
,
in
that
bonnet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
Towlinson
,
I
thank
you
,
"
says
Miss
Tox
.
<EOS>
"
I
beg
you
'll
have
the
goodness
,
when
you
happen
to
see
me
here
,
not
to
mention
it
.
<EOS>
My
visits
are
merely
to
Mrs
Pipchin
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very
good
,
Miss
,
"
says
Towlinson
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shocking
circumstances
occur
,
Towlinson
,
"
says
Miss
Tox
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
much
so
indeed
,
Miss
,
"
rejoins
Towlinson
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
Towlinson
,
"
says
Miss
Tox
,
who
,
in
her
instruction
of
the
Toodle
family
,
has
acquired
an
admonitorial
tone
,
and
a
habit
of
improving
passing

,
"
that
what
has
happened
here
,
will
be
a
warning
to
you
,
Towlinson
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Miss
,
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
,
"
says
Towlinson
.
  
<EOS>
He
appears
to
be
falling
into
a

of
the
manner

which
this
warning
ought
to
operate
in
his

case
,
when
the
vinegary
Mrs
Pipchin
,
suddenly
stirring
him
up
with

"
What
are
you
doing
?
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
show
the
lady
to
the
door
?
<EOS>
"
he
ushers
Miss
Tox
forth
.
<EOS>
As
she
passes
Mr
Dombey
's
room
,
she
shrinks
into
the
inmost
depths
of
the
black
bonnet
,
and
walks
on
tip
-
toe
;
and
there
is
not
another
atom
in
the
world
which
haunts
him
so
<EOS>
,
that
feels
such
sorrow
and
solicitude
about
him
,
as
Miss
Tox
takes
out
under
the
black
bonnet
into
the
street
,
and
tries
to
carry
home
shadowed
from
the
newly
-
lighted
lamps
.
  
<EOS>
But
Miss
Tox
is
not
a
part
of
Mr
Dombey
's
world
.
<EOS>
She
comes
back
every
evening
at
dusk
;
adding
clogs
and
an
umbrella
to
the
bonnet
on
wet

;
and
bears
the
grins
of
Towlinson
,
and
the
huffs
and
rebuffs
of
Mrs
Pipchin
,
and
all
to
ask
how
he
does
,
and
how
he
bears
his
misfortune
:
but
she
has
nothing
to
do
with
Mr
Dombey
's
world
.
<EOS>
Exacting
and
harassing
as
ever
,
it
goes
on
without
her
;
and
she
,
a
by
no
means
bright
or
particular
star
,
moves
in
her
little
orbit
in
the
corner
of
another
system
,
and
knows
it
quite
well
,
and
comes
,
and
cries
,
and
goes
away
,
and
is
satisfied
.
<EOS>
Verily
Miss
Tox
is
easier
of
satisfaction
than
the
world
that
troubles
Mr
Dombey
so
much
!
  
<EOS>
At
the
Counting
House
,
the
clerks
discuss
the
great
disaster
in
all
its
lights
and
shades
,
but
chiefly
wonder
who
will
get
Mr
Carker
's
place
.
<EOS>
They
are
generally
of
opinion
that
it
will
be
shorn
of
some
of
its
emoluments
,
and
made
uncomfortable
by
newly
-
devised
checks
and
restriction
;
and
those
who
are
beyond
all
hope
of
it
,
are
quite
sure
they
would
rather
not
have
it
,
and
do
n't
at
all
envy
the
person
for
whom
it
may
prove
to
be
reserved
.
<EOS>
Nothing
like
the
prevailing
sensation
has
existed
in
the
Counting
House
since
Mr
Dombey
's
little
son
died
;
but
all
such
excitements
there
take
a
social
,
not
to
say
a
jovial
turn
,
and
lead
to
the
cultivation
of
good
fellowship
.
<EOS>
A
reconciliation
is
established
on
this
propitious
occasion
between
the
acknowledged
wit
of
the
Counting
House
and
an
aspiring
rival
,
with
whom
he
has
been
at
deadly
feud
for
months
;
and
a
little
dinner
being
proposed
,
in
commemoration
of
their
happily
restored
amity
,
takes
place
at
a
neighbouring
tavern
;
the
wit
in
the
chair
;
the
rival
acting
as
Vice
-
President
.
<EOS>
The
orations
following
the
removal
of
the
cloth
are
opened
by
the
Chair
,
who
says
,
Gentlemen
,
he
ca
n't
disguise
from
himself
that
this
is
not
a
time
for
private
dissensions
.
<EOS>
Recent
occurrences
to
which
he
need
not
more
particularly
allude
,
but
which
have
not
been
altogether
without
notice
in
some
Sunday
Papers
,
and
in
a
daily
paper
which
he
need
not
name
(
here
every
other
member
of
the
company
names
it
in
an
audible

)
,
have
caused
him
to
reflect
;
and
he
feels
that
for
him
and
Robinson
to
have
any
personal
differences
at
such
a
moment
,
would
be
for
ever
to
deny
that
good
feeling
in
the
general
cause
,
for
which
he
has
reason
to
think
and
hope
that
the
gentlemen
in
Dombey
's
House
have
always
been
distinguished
.
<EOS>
Robinson
replies
to
this
like
a
man
and
a
brother
;
and
one
gentleman
who
has
been
in
the
office
three
years
,
under
continual
notice
to
quit
on
account
of
lapses
in
his
arithmetic
,
appears
in
a
perfectly
new
light
,
suddenly

out
with
a

speech
,
in
which
he
says
,
May
their
respected
chief
never
again
know
the
desolation
which
has
fallen
on
his
hearth
!
<EOS>
and
says
a
great
variety
of
things
,
beginning
with
"
May
he
never
again
,
"
which
are
received
with
thunders
of
applause
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
a
most
delightful
evening
is
passed
,
only
interrupted
by
a
difference
between
two
juniors
,
who
,
quarrelling
about
the
probable
amount
of
Mr
Carker
's
late
receipts
per
annum
,
defy
each
other
with
decanters
,
and
are
taken
out
greatly
excited
.
<EOS>
Soda
water
is
in
general
request
at
the
office
next
day
,
and
most
of
the
party
deem
the
bill
an
imposition
.
  
<EOS>
As
to
Perch
,
the
messenger
,
he
is
in
a
fair
way
of
being
ruined
for
life
.
<EOS>
He
finds
himself
again
constantly
in
bars
of
public
-
houses
,
being
treated
and
lying
dreadfully
.
<EOS>
It
appears
that
he
met
everybody
concerned
in
the
late
transaction
,
everywhere
,
and
said
to
them
,
"
Sir
,
"
or
"
Madam
,
"
as

case
was
"
why
do

look
so

?
"
at
which
each
shuddered
from
head
to

,
and
said
,
"
Oh
,
Perch
!
"
and
ran
away
.
<EOS>
Either
the
consciousness
of
these
enormities
,
or
the
reaction
consequent
on
liquor
,
reduces
Mr
Perch
to
an
extreme
state
of
low
spirits
at
that
hour
of
the
evening
when
he
usually
seeks
consolation
in
the
society
of
Mrs
Perch
at
Balls
Pond
;
and
Mrs
Perch
frets
a
good
deal
,
for
she
fears
his
confidence
in
woman
is
shaken
now
,
and
that
he
half
expects
on
coming
home
at
night
to
find
her
gone
off
with
some
Viscount
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
's
servants
are
becoming
,
at
the
same
time
,
quite
dissipated
,
and
unfit
for
other
service
.
<EOS>
They
have
hot
suppers
every
night
,
and
"
talk
it
over
"
with
smoking
drinks
upon
the
board
.
<EOS>
Mr
Towlinson
is
always
maudlin
after
halfpast
ten
,
and
frequently
begs
to
know
whether
he
did
n't
say
that
no
good
would
ever
come
of
living
in
a
corner
house
?
<EOS>
They
whisper
about
Miss
Florence
,
and
wonder
where
she
is
;
but
agree
that
if
Mr
Dombey
do
n't
know
,
Mrs
Dombey
does
.
<EOS>
This
brings
them
to
the
latter
,
of
whom
Cook
says
,
She
had
a
stately
way
though
,
had
n't
she
?
<EOS>
But
she
was
too
high
!
<EOS>
They
all
agree
that
she
was
too
high
,
and
Mr
Towlinson
's
old
flame
,
the
housemaid
(
who
is
very
virtuous
)
,
entreats
that
you
will
never
talk

any
more
about
people
who
hold
their
heads
up
,
as
if
the
ground
was
n't
good
enough
for
'em
.
  
<EOS>
Everything
that
is
said
and
done
about
it
,
except
by
Mr
Dombey
,
is
done
in
chorus
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
and
the
world
are
alone
together
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
52
.
<EOS>
Secret
Intelligence
 
<EOS>
GOOD
<EOS>
Mrs
Brown
and
her
daughter
Alice
kept
silent
company
together
,
in
their
own
dwelling
.
<EOS>
It
was
early
in
the
evening
,
and
late
in
the
spring
.
<EOS>
But
a
few
days
had
elapsed
since
Mr
Dombey
had
told
major
Bagstock
of
his
singular
intelligence
,
singularly
obtained
,
which
might
turn
out
to
be
valueless
,
and
might
turn
out
to
be
true
;
and
the
world
was
not
satisfied
yet
.
  
<EOS>
The
mother
and
daughter
sat
for
a
long
time
without
inter
-
changing
a
word
:
almost
without
motion
.
<EOS>
The
old
woman
's
face
was
shrewdly
anxious
and
expectant
;
that
of
her
daughter
was
expectant
too
,
but
in
a
less
sharp
degree
,
and
sometimes
it
darkened
,
as
if
with
gathering
disappointment
and
incredulity
.
<EOS>
The
old
woman
,
without
heeding
these
changes
in
its
expression
,
though
her
eyes
were
often
turned
towards
it
,
sat
mumbling
and
munching
,
and
listening
confidently
.
  
<EOS>
Their
abode
,
though
poor
and
miserable
,
was
not
so
utterly
wretched
as
in
the
days
when
only
Good
Mrs
Brown
inhabited
it
.
<EOS>
Some
few
attempts
at
cleanliness
and
order
were
manifest
,
though
made
in
a
reckless
,
gipsy
way
,
that
might
have
connected
them
,
at
a
glance
,
with
the
younger
woman
.
<EOS>
The
shades
of
evening
thickened
and
deepened
as
the
two
kept
silence
,
until
the
blackened
walls
were
nearly
lost
in
the
prevailing
gloom
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Alice
broke
the
silence
which
had
lasted
so
long
,
and
said
:
  
"
You
may
give
him
up
,
mother
.
<EOS>
He
'll
not
come
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Death
give
him
up
!
"
returned
the
old
woman
,
impatiently
.
"
<EOS>
He
will
come
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
him
,
"
returned
her
mother
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
doomsday
,
"
said
the
daughter
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
think
I
'm
in
my
second
childhood
,
I
know
!
"
croaked
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
respect
and
duty
that
I
get
from
my
own
gal
,
but
I
'm
wiser
than
you
take
me
for
.
<EOS>
He
'll
come
.
<EOS>
T'other
day
when
I
touched
his
coat
in
the
street
,
he
looked
round
as
if
I
was
a
toad
.
<EOS>
But
Lord
,
to
see
him
when
I
said
their
names
,
and
asked
him
if
he
'd
like
to
find
out
where
they
was
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
it
so
angry
?
"
<EOS>
asked
her
daughter
,
roused
to
interest
in
a
moment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Angry
?
<EOS>
ask
if
it
was
bloody
.
<EOS>
That
's
more
like
the
word
.
<EOS>
Angry
?
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
<EOS>
To
call
that
only
angry
!
"
said
the
old
woman
,
hobbling
to
the
cupboard
,
and
lighting
a
candle
,
which
displayed
the
workings
of
her
mouth
to
ugly
advantage
,
as
she
brought
it
to
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
I
might
as
well
call
your
face
only
angry
,
when
you
think
or
talk
about
'
em
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
something
different
from
that
,
truly
,
as
she
sat
as
still
as
a
crouched
tigress
,
with
her
kindling
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
"
said
the
old
woman
,
triumphantly
.
<EOS>
"
I
hear
a
step
coming
.
<EOS>
It
's
not
the
tread
of
any
one
that
lives
about
here
,
or
comes
this
way
often
.
<EOS>
We
do
n't
walk
like
that
.
<EOS>
We
should
grow
proud
on
such
neighbours
!
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
you
are
right
,
mother
,
"
replied
Alice
,
in
a
low
voice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Peace
!
open
the
door
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
drew
herself
within
her
shawl
,
and
gathered
it
about
her
,
the
old
woman
complied
;
and
peering
out
,
and
beckoning
,
gave
admission
to
Mr
Dombey
,
who
stopped
when
he
had
set
his
foot
within
the
door
,
and
looked
distrustfully
around
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
poor
place
for
a
great
gentleman
like
your
worship
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
curtseying
and
chattering
.
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
so
,
but
there
's
no
harm
in
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
that
?
"
asked
Mr
Dombey
,
looking
at
her
companion
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
my
handsome
daughter
,
"
said
the
old
woman
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
worship
wo
n't
mind
her
.
<EOS>
She
knows
all
about
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
shadow
fell
upon
his
face
not
less
expressive
than
if
he
had
groaned
aloud
,
"
Who
does
not
know
all
about
it
!
"
<EOS>
but
he
looked
at
her
steadily
,
and
<EOS>
she
,
without
any
acknowledgment
of
his
presence
,
looked
at
him
.
<EOS>
The
shadow
on
his
face
was
darker
when
he
turned
his
glance
away
from
her
;
and
even
then
it
wandered
back
again
,
furtively
,
as
if
he
were
haunted
by
her
bold
eyes
,
and
some
remembrance
they
inspired
.
  
<EOS>
"
Woman
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
to
the
old
witch
who
was
chuckling
and
leering
close
at
his
elbow
,
and
who
,
when
he
turned
to
address
her
,
pointed
stealthily
at
her
daughter
,
and
rubbed
her
hands
,
and
pointed
again
,
"
Woman
!
<EOS>
I
believe
that
I
am
weak
and
forgetful
of
my
station
in
coming
here
,
but
you
know
why
I
come
,
and
what
you
offered
when
you
stopped
me
in
the
street
the
other
day
.
<EOS>
What
is
it
that
you
have
to
tell
me
concerning
what
I
want
to
know
;
and
how
does
it
happen
that
I
can
find
voluntary
intelligence
in
a
hovel
like
this
,
"
with
a
disdainful
glance
about
him
,
"
when
I
have
exerted
my
power
and
means
to
obtain
it
in
vain
?
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
,
"
he
said
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
,
during
which
he
had
observed
her
,
sternly
,
"
that
you
are
so
audacious
as
to
mean
to
trifle
with
me
,
or
endeavour
to
impose
upon
me
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
have
that
purpose
,
you
had
better
stop
on
the
threshold
of
your
scheme
.
<EOS>
My
humour
is
not
a
trifling
one
,
and
my
acknowledgment
will
be
severe
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
a
proud
,
hard
gentleman
!
<EOS>
"
chuckled
the
old
woman
,
shaking
her
head
,
and
rubbing
her
shrivelled
hands
,
"
oh
hard
,
hard
,
hard
!
<EOS>
But
you
worship
shall
see
with
your
own
eyes
and
hear
with
your
own
ears
;
not
with
ours
---
and
if
your
worship
's
put
upon
their
track
,
you
wo
n't
mind
paying
something
for
it
,
will
you
,
honourable
deary
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Money
,
"
returned
Mr
Dombey
,
apparently
relieved
,
and
reassured
by
this
inquiry
,
"
will
bring
about
unlikely
things
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
It
may
turn
even
means
as
unexpected
and
unpromising
as
these
,
to
account
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
For
and
reliable
information
I
receive
,
I
will
pay
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
have
the
information
first
,
and
judge
for
myself
of
its
value
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
nothing
more
powerful
than
money
?
"
asked
the
younger
woman
,
without
rising
,
or
altering
her
attitude
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
here
,
I
should
imagine
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
know
of
something
that
is
more
powerful
elsewhere
,
as
I
judge
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
nothing
of
a
woman
's
anger
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
saucy
tongue
,
Jade
,
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
usually
,
"
she
answered
,
without
any
show
of
emotion
:
"
I
speak
to
you
now
,
that
you
may
understand
us
better
,
and
rely
more
on
us
.
<EOS>
A
woman
's
anger
is
pretty
much
the
same
here
,
as
in
your
fine
house
.
<EOS>
I
am
angry
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
so
,
many
years
.
<EOS>
I
have
as
good
cause
for
my
anger
as
you
have
for
yours
,
and
its
object
is
the
same
man
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
started
,
in
spite
of
himself
,
and
looked
at
her
with
astonishment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she
said
,
with
a
kind
of
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wide
as
the
distance
may
seem
between
us
,
it
is
so
.
<EOS>
How
it
is
so
,
is
no
matter
;
that
is
my
story
,
and
I
keep
my
story
to
myself
.
<EOS>
I
would
bring
you
and
him
together
,
because
I
have
a
rage
against
him
.
<EOS>
My
mother
there
,
is
avaricious
and
poor
;
and
she
would
sell
any
tidings
she
could
glean
,
or
anything
,
or
anybody
,
for
money
.
<EOS>
It
is
fair
enough
,
perhaps
,
that
you
should
pay
her
some
,
if
she
can
help
you
to
what
you
want
to
know
.
<EOS>
But
that
is
not
my
motive
.
<EOS>
I
have
told
you
what
mine
is
,
and
it
would
be
as
strong
and
all
-
sufficient
with
me
if
you
haggled
and
bargained
with
her
for
a
sixpence
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
.
<EOS>
My
saucy
tongue
says
no
more
,
if
you
wait
here
till
sunrise
to
-
morrow
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
woman
,
who
had
shown
great
uneasiness
during
this
speech
,
which
had
a
tendency
to
depreciate
her
expected
gains
,
pulled
Mr
Dombey
softly
by
the
sleeve
,
and
whispered
to
him
not
to
mind
her
.
<EOS>
He
glanced
at
them
both
,
by
turns
,
with
a
haggard
look
,
and
said
,
in
a
deeper
voice
than
was
usual
with
him
:
  
"
Go
on
---
what
do
you
know
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
not
so
fast
,
your
worship
!
<EOS>
we
must
wait
for
some
one
,
"
answered
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
to
be
got
from
some
one
else
---
wormed
out
---
screwed
and
twisted
from
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
said
Mr
Dombey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Patience
,
"
she
croaked
,
laying
her
hand
,
like
a
claw
,
upon
his
arm
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Patience
.
<EOS>
I
'll
get
at
it
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
can
!
<EOS>
If
he
was
to
hold
it
back
from
me
,
"
said
Good
Mrs
Brown
,
crooking
her
ten
fingers
,
"
I
'd
tear
it
out
of
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
followed
her
with
his
eyes
as
she
hobbled
to
the
door
,
and
looked
out
again
:
and
then
his
glance
sought
her
daughter
;
but
she
remained
impassive
,
silent
,
and
regardless
of
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
tell
me
,
woman
,
"
he
said
,
when
the
bent
figure
of
Mrs
Brown
came
back
,
shaking
its
head
and
chattering
to
itself
,
"
that
there
is
another
person
expected
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
said
the
old
woman
,
looking
up
into
his
face
,
and
nodding
.
  
<EOS>
"
From
whom
you
are
to
exact
the
intelligence
that
is
to
be
useful
to
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
nodding
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
stranger
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Chut
!
"
said
the
old
woman
,
with
a
shrill
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
signifies
!
<EOS>
Well
,
well
;
no
.
<EOS>
No
stranger
to
your
worship
.
<EOS>
But
he
wo
n't
see
you
.
<EOS>
He
'd
be
afraid
of
you
,
and
would
n't
talk
.
<EOS>
You
'll
stand
behind
that
door
,
and
judge
him
for
yourself
.
<EOS>
We
do
n't
ask
to
be
believed
on
trust
.
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
Your
worship
doubts
the
room
behind
the
door
?
<EOS>
Oh
the
suspicion
of
you
rich
gentlefolks
!
<EOS>
Look
at
it
,
then
.
"
  
<EOS>
Her
sharp
eye
had
detected
an
involuntary
expression
of
this
feeling
on
his
part
,
which
was
not
unreasonable
under
the
circumstances
.
<EOS>
In
satisfaction
of
it
she
now
took
the
candle
to
the
door
she
spoke
of
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
looked
in
;
assured
himself
that
it
was
an
empty
,
crazy
room
;
and
signed
to
her
to
put
the
light
back
in
its
place
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
long
,
"
he
asked
,
"
before
this
person
comes
?
"
  
"
Not
long
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
Would
your
worship
sit
down
for
a
few
odd
minutes
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
made
no
answer
;
but
began
pacing
the
room
with
an
irresolute
air
,
as
if
he
were
undecided
whether
to
remain
or
depart
,
and
as
if
he
had
some
quarrel
with
himself
for
being
there
at
all
.
<EOS>
But
soon
his
tread
grew
slower
and
heavier
,
and
his
face
more
sternly
thoughtful
:
as
the
object
with
which
he
had
come
,
fixed
itself
in
his
mind
,
and
dilated
there
again
.
  
<EOS>
While
he
thus
walked
up
and
down
with
his
eyes
on
the
ground
,
Mrs
Brown
,
in
the
chair
from
which
she
had
risen
to
receive
him
,
sat
listening
anew
.
<EOS>
The
monotony
of
his
step
,
or
the
uncertainty
of
age
,
made
her
so
slow
of
hearing
,
that
a
footfall
without
had
sounded
in
her
daughter
's
ears
for
some
moments
,
and
she
had
looked
up
hastily
to
warn
her
mother
of
its
approach
,
before
the
old
woman
was
roused
by
it
.
<EOS>
But
then
she
started
from
her
seat
,
and
whispering
"
Here
he
is
!
"
<EOS>
hurried
her
visitor
to
his
place
of
observation
,
and
put
a
bottle
and
glass
upon
the
table
,
with
such
alacrity
as
to
be
ready
to
fling
her
arms
round
the
neck
of
Rob
the
Grinder
on
his
appearance
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
here
's
my
bonny
boy
,
"
cried
Mrs
Brown
,
"
at
last
!
<EOS>
---
oho
,
oho
!
<EOS>
You
're
like
my
own
son
,
Robby
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
Misses
Brown
!
"
remonstrated
the
Grinder
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Don't!Can't
<EOS>
you
be
fond
of
a
cove
without
squeedging
and
throttling
of
him
?
<EOS>
Take
care
of
the
birdcage
in
my
hand
,
will
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thinks
of
a
birdcage
,
afore
me
!
"
cried
the
old
woman
,
apostrophizing
the
ceiling
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Me
that
feels
more
than
a
mother
for
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
'm
sure
I
'm
very
much
obliged
to
you
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
said
the
unfortunate
youth
,
greatly
aggravated
;
"
but
you
're
so
jealous
of
a
cove
.
<EOS>
I
'm
very
fond
of
you
myself
,
and
all
that
,
of
course
;
but
I
do
n't
smother
you
,
do
I
,
Misses
Brown
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
and
spoke
as
if
he
would
have
been
far
from
objecting
to
do
so
,
however
,
on
a
favourable
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
to
talk
about
birdcages
,
too
!
<EOS>
"
whimpered
the
Grinder
.
<EOS>
"
As
if
that
was
a
crime
!
<EOS>
Why
,
look'ee
here
!
<EOS>
Do
you
know
who
this
belongs
to
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
Master
,
dear
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
woman
with
a
grin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
replied
the
Grinder
,
lifting
a
large
cage
tied
up
in
a
wrapper
,
on
the
table
,
and
untying
it
with
his
teeth
and
hands
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
our
parrot
,
this
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Carker
's
parrot
,
Rob
?
"
  
"
Will
you
hold
your
tongue
,
Misses
Brown
?
"
returned
the
goaded
Grinder
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
go
naming
names
for
?
<EOS>
I
'm
blest
,
"
said
Rob
,
pulling
his
hair
with
both
hands
in
the
exasperation
of
his
feelings
,
"
if
she
an't
enough
to
make
a
cove
run
wild
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
Do
you
snub
me
,
thankless
boy
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
old
woman
,
with
ready
vehemence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
,
Misses
Brown
,
no
!
"
returned
the
Grinder
,
with
tears
in
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Was
there
ever
such
a
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
I
dote
upon
you
,
Misses
Brown
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
,
sweet
Rob
?
<EOS>
Do
you
truly
,
chickabiddy
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
that
,
Mrs
Brown
held
him
in
her
fond
embrace
once
more
;
and
did
not
release
him
until
he
had
made
several
violent
and
ineffectual
struggles
with
his
legs
,
and
his
hair
was
standing
on
end
all
over
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
returned
the
Grinder
,
"
what
a
thing
it
is
to
be
perfectly
pitched
into
with
affection
like
this
here
.
<EOS>
I
wish
she
wasHow
have
you
been
,
Misses
Brown
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
Not
here
since
this
night
week
!
"
said
the
old
woman
,
contemplating
him
with
a
look
of
reproach
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
returned
the
Grinder
,
"
I
said
to
-
night
's
a
week
,
that
I
'd
come
to
-
night
,
did
n't
I
?
<EOS>
And
here
I
am
.
<EOS>
How
you
do
go
on
!
<EOS>
I
wish
you
'd
be
a
little
rational
,
Misses
Brown
.
<EOS>
I
'm
hoarse
with
saying
things
in
my
defence
,
and
my
very
face
is
shiny
with
being
hugged
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
rubbed
it
hard
with
his
sleeve
,
as
if
to
remove
the
tender
polish
in
question
.
  
<EOS>
"
Drink
a
little
drop
to
comfort
you
,
my
Robin
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
filling
the
glass
from
the
bottle
and
giving
it
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
returned
the
Grinder
.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
your
health
.
<EOS>
And
long
may
you
---
et
ceterer
.
<EOS>
"
Which
to
judge
from
the
expression
of
his
face
,
did
not
include
any
very
choice
blessing
.
"
<EOS>
And
here
's
her
health
,
"
said
the
Grinder
,
glancing
at
Alice
,
who
sat
with
her
eyes
fixed
,
as
it
seemed
to
him
,
on
the
wall
behind
him
,
but
in
reality
on
Mr
Dombey
's
face
at
the
door
,
"
and
wishing
her
the
same
and
many
of
'
em
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
drained
the
glass
to
these
two
sentiments
,
and
set
it
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
say
,
Misses
Brown
!
"
<EOS>
he
proceeded
.
"
<EOS>
To
go
on
a
little
rational
now
.
<EOS>
You
're
a
judge
of
birds
,
and
up
to
their
ways
,
as
I
know
to
my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Cost
!
"
repeated
Mrs
Brown
.
  
<EOS>
"
Satisfaction
,
I
mean
,
"
returned

Grinder
.
<EOS>
"
How
you
do
take

cove
,
Misses
Brown
!
<EOS>
You
've
put
it
all
out
of
my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Judge
of
birds
,
Robby
,
"
suggested

old
woman
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
the
Grinder
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
've
got
to
take
care
of
this
parrot
---
certain

being
sold
,
and
a
certain
establishment
broke

---
and
as
I
do

no
notice
took
at
present
,
I
wish

to
her
for
a
week

,
and

board

<EOS>
,

?
<EOS>
If

backwards
and
forwards
,
"
mused

Grinder
with

,
"
I
may
as

something
to
come
for
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Something
to
come
for
?
"
screamed

old
woman
.
  
<EOS>
"
Besides
you
,
I
mean
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
returned
the
craven
Rob
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
that
I
want
any
inducement
but
yourself
,
Misses
Brown
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
begin
again
,
for
goodness
'
sake
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
do
n't
care
for

!
<EOS>
He
do
n't
care
for
me
,
as
I
care
for
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried

Brown
,
lifting

.
<EOS>
"
But
I
'll
take
care
of
his
bird
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Take
good

it

,

,
Mrs
Brown
,
"
said
Rob
,
shaking

.
<EOS>
"
If
you
was
so
much
as

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
so
sharp
as
that
,
Rob
?
"
said
Mrs
Brown
,
quickly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sharp
,
Misses
Brown
!
"
repeated
Rob
.
"
<EOS>
But
this
is
not
to
be
talked
about
.
"
  
<EOS>
Checking
himself
abruptly
,
and
not
without
a

across
the
room
,
rob
filled
the
glass
again
,
and
having
slowly
emptied

,
shook
his
head
,
and
began
to
draw
his
fingers
across
and
across
the
wires
of
the
parrot
's
cage
by
way
of
a
diversion
from
the
dangerous
theme
that
had
just
been
broached
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
eyed
him
slily
,
and
hitching
her
chair
nearer
his
,
and
looking
in
at
the
parrot
,
who
came
down
from
the
gilded
dome
at
her
call
,
said
:
  
"
Out
of
place
now
,
Robby
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
you
mind
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
returned
the
Grinder
,
shortly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Board
wages
,
perhaps
,
Rob
?
"
said
Mrs
Brown
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pretty
Polly
!
"
said
the
Grinder
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
darted
a
glance
at
him
that
might
have
warned
him
to
consider
his
ears
in
danger
,
but
it
was
his
turn
to
look
in
at
the
parrot
now
,
and
however
expressive
his
imagination
may
have
made
her
angry
scowl
,
it
was
unseen
by
his
bodily
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
Master
did
n't
take
you
with
him
,
Rob
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
in
a
wheedling
voice
,
but
with
increased
malignity
of
aspect
.
  
<EOS>
Rob
was
so
absorbed
in
contemplation
of
the
parrot
,
and
in
trolling
his
forefinger
on
the
wires
,
that
he
made
no
answer
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
had
her
clutch
within
a
hair
's
breadth
of
his
shock
of
hair
as
it
stooped
over
the
table
;
but
she
restrained
her
fingers
,
and
said
,
in
a
voice
that
choked
with
its

to
be

:
  
<EOS>
"
Robby
,
my
child
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
returned
the
Grinder
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
I
wonder
Master
did
n't
take
you
with
him
,
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
you
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
returned
the
Grinder
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Brown
instantly
directed
the
clutch
of
her
right
hand
at
his
hair
,
and
the
clutch
of
her
left
hand
at
his
throat
,
and
held
on
to
the
object
of
her
fond
affection
with
such

,
that
his
face
began
to
blacken
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Misses
Brown
!
"
exclaimed
the
Grinder
,
"
let
go
,
will
you
?
<EOS>
What
are
you
doing
of
?
<EOS>
Help
,
young
woman
!
<EOS>
Misses
Brow
---
Brow
---
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
young
woman
,
however
,
equally
unmoved
by
his
direct
appeal
to
her
,
and
by
his
inarticulate
utterance
,
remained
quite
neutral
,
until
,
after

with
his

into
a
corner
,
Rob
disengaged
himself
,
and
stood
there
panting
and
fenced
in
by
his
own

,
while
the
old
woman
,
panting
too
,
and
stamping
with
rage
and

,
appeared
to
be
collecting
her
energies
for
another
swoop
upon
him
.
<EOS>
At
this
crisis
Alice
interposed
her
voice
,
but
not
in
the
Grinder
's
favour
,
by
saying
,
  
"
Well
done
,
mother
.
<EOS>
Tear
him
to
pieces
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
young
woman
!
"
<EOS>
blubbered
Rob
;
"
are
you
against
me
too
?
<EOS>
What
have
I
been
and
done
?
<EOS>
What
am
I
to
be
tore
to
pieces
for
,
I
should
like

?
<EOS>
Why
do
you
take
and
choke
a
cove
who
has
never
done
you
any

,
neither

?
<EOS>
Call

females
,
too
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
frightened
and

Grinder
,
with

coat
-

at

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
surprised
at

!
<EOS>
Where
's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
thankless
dog
!
<EOS>
"
gasped
Mrs
Brown
.
<EOS>
"
You

dog
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
been
and
done
to
go
and
give

,
Misses
Brown
?
"
<EOS>
retorted

fearful
Rob
.
<EOS>
"
You
was
very
much
attached
to
me
a

ago
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
cut
me
off
with

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Me
!
<EOS>
Because

to
have

of

about
Master
and
the
lady
,
to
dare

fast

!
<EOS>
But
I
'll

no

,
my

.
<EOS>
Now
go
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
returned

abject

,
"
<EOS>
I
never
insiniwated
that
I
wished

go
.
<EOS>
Do

like

,
Misses
Brown
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
talk
at
all
,
"
said
Mrs
Brown
,
with
an

her

that
made

into
half
his
natural

in

corner
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
another
word
with
him
shall

.
<EOS>
He
's

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Now
let
him
go
!
<EOS>
And
I
'll
slip
those

him
that
shall
talk
too
much
;
that
wo
n't
be
shook

;
that
'll
hang

like

,

slink
arter

like

.
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
He
knows
'em
.
<EOS>
He
knows
his
old
games
and
his
old

.
<EOS>
If
he
's
forgotten
'em
,
they
'll
soon

.
<EOS>
Now
let
him
go
,
and
see

he
'll
do
Master
's

,
and
keep
Master
's

,
with
such

up

.
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha!He'll
find
'em
a
different
sort
from
you
and
me
,
Ally
;
close

he
is
with

and
me
.
<EOS>
Now
let
him
go
,
now
let
him
go
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
,
to
the
unspeakable

of
the
Grinder
,
walked
her
twisted
figure
round
and
round
,
in
a
ring
of
some
four
feet
in
diameter
,
constantly
repeating
these
words
,
and
shaking
her
fist
above
her
head
,
and
working
her
mouth
about
.
  
<EOS>
"
Misses
Brown
,
"
pleaded
Rob
,
coming
a
little
out
of
his
corner
,
"
I
'm
sure
you
would
n't
injure
a
cove
,
on
second
thoughts
,
and
in
cold
blood
,
would
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
talk
to
me
,
"
said
Mrs
Brown
,
still
wrathfully
pursuing
her
circle
.
<EOS>
"
Now
let
him
go
,
now
let
him
go
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Misses
Brown
,
"
urged
the
tormented
Grinder
,
"
I
did
n't
mean
to
---
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
a
thing
it
is
for
a
cove
to
get
into
such
a
line
as
this
!
<EOS>
---
I
was
only
careful
of
talking
,
Misses
Brown
,
because
I
always
am
,
on
account
of
his
being
up
to
everything
;
but
I
might
have
known
it
would
n't
have
gone
any
further
.
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
I
'm
quite
agreeable
,
"
with
a

face
,
"
for
any
little
bit
of
gossip
,
Misses
Brown
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
go
on
like
this
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
could
n't
you
have
the
goodness
to
put
in
a
word
for
a
miserable
cove
,
here
?
"
said
the
Grinder
,
appealing
in
desperation
to
the
daughter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
mother
<EOS>
,
you
hear
what
he
says
,
"
she
interposed
,
in
her
stern
voice
,
and
with
an
impatient
action
of
her
head
;
"
try
him
once
more
,
and
if
you
fall
out
with
him
again
,
ruin
him
,
if
you
like
,
and
have
done
with
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Brown
,
moved
as
it
seemed
by
this
very
tender
exhortation
,
presently
began
to
howl
;
and
softening
by
degrees
,
took
the
apologetic
Grinder
to
her
arms
,
who
embraced
her
with
a
face
of
unutterable
woe
,
and
like
a
victim
as
he
was
,
resumed
his
former
seat
,
close
by
the
side
of
his
venerable
friend
,
whom
he
suffered
,
not
without
much
constrained
sweetness
of
countenance
,
combating
very
expressive
physiognomical
revelations
of
an
opposite
character
,
to
draw
his
arm
through
hers
,
and
keep
it
there
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
's
Master
<EOS>
,
deary
dear
?
"
said
Mrs
Brown
,
when
,
sitting
in
this
amicable
posture
,
they
had
pledged
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
<EOS>
If
you
'd
be
so
good
,
Misses
Brown
,
as
to
speak
a
little
lower
,
"
Rob
implored
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
he
's
pretty
well
,
thank'ee
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
out
of
place
,
Robby
?
"
said
Mrs
Brown
in
a
wheedling
tone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
'm
not
exactly
out
of
place
,
nor
in
,
"
faltered
Rob
.
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
'm
still
in
pay
,
Misses
Brown
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
nothing
to
do
,
Rob
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
particular
to
do
just
now
,
Misses
Brown
,
but
to
---
keep
my
eyes
open
,
"
said
the
Grinder
,
rolling
them
in
a
forlorn
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
Masters
abroad
,
Rob
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
for
goodness
'
sake
,
Misses
Brown
,
could
n't
you
gossip
with
a
cove
about
anything
else
?
"
cried
the
Grinder
,
in
a
burst
of

.
  
<EOS>
The
impetuous
Mrs
Brown
rising
directly
,
the
tortured
Grinder
detained
her
,
stammering
"
Ye
-
es
,
Misses
Brown
<EOS>
,
I
believe
he
's
abroad
.
<EOS>
What
's
she
staring
at
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
in
allusion
to
the
daughter
,
whose

were
fixed
upon
the
face
that
now
again

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

mind
her
,
lad
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
holding
him
closer
to
prevent
his
turning
round
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
her
way
---
her
way
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
,
Rob
.
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
see
the
lady
,
deary
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Misses
Brown
,
what
lady
?
"
cried
the
Grinder
in
a
tone
of
piteous

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
lady
?
<EOS>
"
she
retorted
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
lady
;
Mrs
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
believe
I
see
her
once
,
"
replied
Rob
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
night
she
went
away
,
Robby
,
eh
?
"
said
the
old
woman
in
his
ear
,
and
taking
note
of
every
change
in
his
face
.
"
<EOS>
Aha!I
know
it
was
that
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
if
you
know

was
that
night
,
you
know
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
replied
Rob
,
"
it
's
no

putting

into

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
did

?
<EOS>
Straight

?
<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>
Where

?
<EOS>
Did

?
<EOS>
Did

?
<EOS>
Tell

,
"

,
holding

,
patting
the

that
was
drawn
through

against
her

,
and

.
"
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Begin
!
<EOS>
I
want
to
be
told
all
about

.
<EOS>
What
,
Rob
,
boy
!
<EOS>
You
and
me
can
keep

,

?
<EOS>
We
've
done
so
before
now
.
<EOS>
Where
did
they
go
first
,
Rob
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
wretched
Grinder
made
a
gasp
,
and
a
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
dumb
?
"
said
the
old
woman
,
angrily
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
,
Misses
Brown
,
no
!
<EOS>
You
expect
a
cove
to
be
a
flash
of
lightning
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
was
the
electric
fluency
,
"
muttered

Grinder
.
<EOS>
"
I
'd
have
a
shock
at
somebody
,
that
would
settle

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
?
<EOS>
"

,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
wishing
my
love
to
you
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
returned
the
false
Rob
,
seeking

in

glass
.
<EOS>
"
Where
did
they
go
to
first
,
was

?
<EOS>
Him

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
!
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Them
two
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
they
did

go
nowhere
---
not

,

,
"
answered
Rob
.
  
<EOS>
The
old

looked
at

,

<EOS>
"
That

"

,

<EOS>
They

"

"

<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

<EOS>
Well
?

,

,

<EOS>
"
What
,

?
"
<EOS>

,
who

his

,

,

on

,

he

-
cuff
into
one

of

,

uttered

.
<EOS>
"
Did
she

that

,

?
<EOS>
Did

,
Misses
Brown
?
"
  
"
Or

?
<EOS>
"
added

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Neither
,
"
said

Grinder
.
<EOS>
"
She
kept
as

when
she
and
me
---
<EOS>
oh
,
I
see
you
will
have
it

,
<EOS>
Misses
Brown!But
take
your
solemn
oath
now
,
that
you

never
tell
anybody
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
Mrs
Brown
very
readily

:

naturally

;
and
having
no

.
  
<EOS>
"
She

as

,

,

,
"

,
"
as

.
<EOS>
In

she
was

,
Misses
Brown
.
<EOS>
And

went

in
the
packet
before

,
by
herself
---
me

to
be

,
and
seeing

safe

---
she
was
just

.
<EOS>
Now
,

,
Misses
Brown
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Rob
.
<EOS>
Not

,
"
answered
Mrs
Brown
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
here
's
a
woman
for

!
"
<EOS>
cried

Rob
,
in

over

.
<EOS>
"
What
did

wish

,
Misses
Brown
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
became

Master
?
<EOS>
Where

he
go
?
<EOS>
"
she

,
still
holding

,
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
soul
,
I
do
n't
know
,
Misses
Brown
,
"
answered
Rob
.
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
soul
I
do

what

did
,
nor

,
nor

.
<EOS>
I
only

,

;

,

,

,
that
sooner

-

,

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have

I

,
"

,
"

wo

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
'm

,
Misses
Brown
.
"

Rob
,
somewhat

,
and
not

.
<EOS>
"
For
your
own
sake
quite
as
much
as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
at
her
as
he
gave
her
this
friendly
caution
,
and
emphasized
it
with
a
nodding
of
his

;
but
finding

uncomfortable
to
encounter
the
yellow
face
with

,
and

with
their

old

,

close
to

,

,
as
if

were

to
bring

to
a
sullen

that
he
would
answer
no

.
<EOS>
The
old
woman
,
still
holding
him
as

,
took
this

of
raising

of
her

,
in

,
as

to

observer
to

to

was
about

.
  
<EOS>
"
Rob
,
"
she
said
,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
,
Misses
Brown
<EOS>
,
what
's
the

now
?
"
returned

.
  
<EOS>
"
Rob
!
<EOS>
where
did
the
lady
and
Master
appoint
to
meet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Rob
shuffled
more
and
more
,
and
looked
up
and
looked
down
,
and
bit
his
thumb
,
and
dried
it
on
his

,
and
finally

,

his

,
"
How
should
I
know
,
Misses
Brown
?
"
  
<EOS>
The

woman
held
up

finger
again
,
as
before
,
and
replying
,
"
Come
,
lad
!
<EOS>
It
's
no
use
leading
me
to
that
,
and
there
leaving
me
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
know
"
---
waited
for

.
  
<EOS>
Rob
,
after
a

,
suddenly

with
,
"
How
can
I
pronounce

,
Mrs

?
<EOS>
What

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
Robby
,
"
she
retorted

,
"
and
you

it
sounded

.
<EOS>
Come
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
heard

,
Misses

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
retorted

,
"
you
have

,
and
you
can

.
"
  
<EOS>
Rob
,
with

between

---
for

was

with
some

Mrs

's

,

---
after
some

in

,
produced

a
little

of

.
<EOS>
The
old
woman
's
eyes
sparkled
when
she
saw
it
between
his
thumb
and
finger
,
and
hastily

on

,
that
he
might

word
there
,
she
once
more

her

with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
I
tell
you
beforehand
what

,
Misses
Brown
,
"
said
Rob
,
<EOS>
"
it
's
no
use

me
anything
else
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
answer
anything
else
;
I
ca
n't
.
<EOS>
How
long

was
to
be

they
met
,
or
whose

it
was
that
they
was
to

away
alone

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Shall

?

<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Rob
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well

,

Brown
.
<EOS>
The
way
---
now

wo

,

?
"

,

,

were

fast

,
upon

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well

,
the

was
this
.
<EOS>
When

left

lady

,
he

with

in

,

was
in

.
<EOS>
She
was

,
for
she

as

his
back

turned
,
and

I

,
I

<EOS>
---

.
<EOS>
There

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Brown
knew
that
,
she

.
<EOS>
Rob
,
having
nothing
more
to
say
,
began
to
chalk
,
slowly

,
on
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
"
D
,
"
<EOS>
"
the
old
woman
read

,
when
he
had

.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
hold
your
tongue
,
Misses
Brown
?
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
covering
it
with
his
hand
,
and
turning
impatiently
upon
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
have
it
read

.
<EOS>
Be
quiet
,

you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
write
large
,
Rob
,
"
she
returned
,
repeating
her
secret
signal
;
"
for
my
eyes
are
not
good
,
even
at
print
.
"
  
<EOS>
Muttering
to
himself
,
and
returning
to
his
work
with
an
ill
will
,
Rob
went
on
with
the
word
.
<EOS>
As
he
bent
his
head
down
,
the
person
for
whose
information
he
so
unconsciously
laboured
,
moved
from
the
door
behind
him
to
within
a
short
stride
of
his
shoulder
,
and
looked
eagerly
towards
the
creeping
track
of
his
hand
upon
the
table
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
Alice
,
from
her
opposite
chair
,
watched
it
narrowly
as
it
shaped
the
letters
,
and
repeated
each
one
on
her
lips
as
he
made
it
,
without
articulating
it
aloud
.
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
every
letter
her
eyes
and
Mr
Dombey
's
met
,
as
if
each
of
them
sought
to
be
confirmed
by
the
other
;
and
thus
they
both
spelt
D*I*J*O*N.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
the
Grinder
,
moistening
the
palm
of
his
hand
hastily
,
to
obliterate
the
word
;
and
not
content
with
smearing
it
out
,
rubbing
and
planing
all
trace
of
it
away
with
his
coat
-
sleeve
,
until
the
very
colour
of
the
chalk
was
gone
from
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
I
hope
you
're
contented
,
Misses
Brown
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
woman
,
in
token
of
her
being
so
,
released
his
arm
and
patted
his
back
;
and
the
Grinder
,
overcome
with
mortification
,
cross
-
examination
,
and
liquor
,
folded
his
arms
on
the
table
,
laid
his
head
upon
them
,
and
fell
asleep
.
  
<EOS>
Not
until
he
had
been
heavily
asleep
some
time
,
and
was
snoring
roundly
,
did
the
old
woman
turn
towards
the
door
,
where
Mr
Dombey
stood
concealed
,
and
beckon
him
to
come
through
the
room
,
and
pass
out
.
<EOS>
Even
then
,
she
hovered
over
Rob
,
ready
to
blind
him
with
her
hands
,
or
strike
his
head
down
,
if
he
should
raise
it
while
the
secret
step
was
crossing
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
But
though
her
glance
took
sharp
cognizance
of
the
sleeper
,
it
was
sharp
too
for
the
waking
man
;
and
when
he
touched
her
hand
with
his
,
and
in
spite
of
all
his
caution
,
made
a
chinking
,
golden
sound
,
it
was
as
bright
and
greedy
as
a
raven
's
.
  
<EOS>
The
daughter
's
dark
gaze
followed
him
to
the
door
,
and
noted
well
how
pale
he
was
,
and
how
his
hurried
tread
indicated
that
the
least
delay
was
an
insupportable
restraint
upon
him
,
and
how
he
was
burning
to
be
active
and
away
.
<EOS>
As
he
closed
the
door
behind
him
,
she
looked
round
at
her
mother
.
<EOS>
The
old
woman
trotted
to
her
;
opened
her
hand
to
show
what
was
within
;
and
,
tightly
closing
it
again
in
her
jealousy
and
avarice
,
whispered
:
  
"
<EOS>
What
will
he
do
,
Ally
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mischief
,
"
said
the
daughter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Murder
?
"
asked
the
old
woman
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
madman
,
in
his
wounded
pride
,
and
may
do
that
,
for
anything
we
can
say
,
or
he
either
.
"
  
<EOS>
Her
glance
was
brighter
than
her
mother
's
,
and
the
fire
that
shone
in
it
was
fiercer
;
but
her
face
was
colourless
,
even
to
her
lips
.
  
<EOS>
They
said
no
more
,
but
sat
apart
;
the
mother
communing
with
her
money
;
the
daughter
with
her
thoughts
;
the
glance
of
each
,
shining
in
the
gloom
of
the
feebly
lighted
room
.
<EOS>
Rob
slept
and
snored
.
<EOS>
The
disregarded
parrot
only
was
in
action
.
<EOS>
It
twisted
and
pulled
at
the
wires
of
its
cage
,
with
its
crooked
beak
,
and
crawled
up
to
the
dome
,
and
along
its
roof
like
a
fly
,
and
down
again
head
foremost
,
and
shook
,
and
bit
,
and
rattled
at
every
slender
bar
,
as
if
it
knew
its
master
's
danger
,
and
was
wild
to
force
a
passage
out
,
and
fly
away
to
warn
him
of
it
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
53
.
<EOS>
More
Intelligence
 
<EOS>
THERE
were
two
of
the
traitor
's
own
blood
---
his
renounced
brother
and
sister
---
on
whom
the
weight
of
his
guilt
rested
almost
more
heavily
,
at
this
time
,
than
on
the
man
whom
he
had
so
deeply
injured
.
<EOS>
Prying
and
tormenting
as
the
world
was
,
it
did
Mr
Dombey
the
service
of
nerving
him
to
pursuit
and
revenge
.
<EOS>
It
roused
his
passion
,
stung
his
pride
,
twisted
the
one
idea
of
his
life
into
a
new
shape
,
and
made
some
gratification
of
his
wrath
,
the
object
into
which
his
whole
intellectual
existence
resolved
itself
.
<EOS>
All
the
stubbornness
and
implacability
of
his
nature
,
all
its
hard
impenetrable
quality
,
all
its
gloom
and
moroseness
,
all
its
exaggerated
sense
of
personal
importance
,
all
its
jealous
disposition
to
resent
the
least
flaw
in
the
ample
recognition
of
his
importance
by
others
,
set
this
way
like
many
streams
united
into
one
,
and
bore
him
on
upon
their
tide
.
<EOS>
The
most
impetuously
passionate
and
violently
impulsive
of
mankind
would
have
been
a
milder
enemy
to
encounter
than
the
sullen
Mr
Dombey
wrought
to
this
.
<EOS>
A
wild
beast
would
have
been
easier
turned
or
soothed
than
the
grave
gentleman
without
a
wrinkle
in
his
starched
cravat
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
very
intensity
of
his
purpose
became
almost
a
substitute
for
action
in
it
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
yet
uninformed
of
the
traitor
's
retreat
,
it
served
to
divert
his
mind
from
his
own
calamity
,
and
to
entertain
it
with
another
prospect
.
<EOS>
The
brother
and
sister
of
his
false
favourite
had
no
such
relief
;
everything
in
their
history
,
past
and
present
,
gave
his
delinquency
a
more
afflicting
meaning
to
them
.
  
<EOS>
The
sister
may
have
sometimes
sadly
thought
that
if
she
had
remained
with
him
,
the
companion
and
friend
she
had
been
once
,
he
might
have
escaped
the
crime
into
which
he
had
fallen
.
<EOS>
If
she
ever
thought
so
,
it
was
still
without
regret
for
what
she
had
done
,
without
the
least
doubt
of
her
duty
,
without
any
pricing
and
enhancing
of
her
self
-
devotion
.
<EOS>
But
when
this
possibility
presented
itself
to
the
erring
and
repentant
brother
,
as
it
sometimes
did
,
it
smote
upon
his
heart
with
such
a
keen
,
reproachful
touch
as
he
could
hardly
bear
.
<EOS>
No
idea
of
retort
upon
his
cruel
brother
came
into
his
mind
.
<EOS>
New
accusation
of
himself
,
fresh
inward
lamentings
over
his
own
unworthiness
,
and
the
ruin
in
which
it
was
at
once
his
consolation
and
his
self
-
reproach
that
he
did
not
stand
alone
,
were
the
sole
kind
of
reflections
to
which
the
discovery
gave
rise
in
him
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
on
the
very
same
day
whose
evening
set
upon
the
last
chapter
,
and
when
Mr
Dombey
's
world
was
busiest
with
the
elopement
of
his
wife
,
that
the
window
of
the
room
in
which
the
brother

sister
sat
at

early

,
was
darkened
by
the
unexpected
shadow
of

man

to

little
porch
:
which
man
was
Perch
the
Messenger
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've

over

Balls

,
"

Perch
,

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
They

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
"

,

"

health
<EOS>
Mrs
P
,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

ill
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"
said

Perch
,

"

House

,
<EOS>
Miss.

,

,

.
<EOS>
Not

,

.
<EOS>
You

yourself
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Harriet

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,

,
"

Perch

,
"
<EOS>
in

I

n't

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
I

feels
every

-

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Perch
's

.
<EOS>
There

,

;

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Therefore

,
"

,

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
Here

;

,

.
<EOS>
This

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
If

"

,

<EOS>
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John

,

"
No
.
<EOS>
No

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
The
Papers
,

.
<EOS>
One

ones
,

,

---
need

?
---

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.

Another

,
"

.
<EOS>

,

,

.

<EOS>
But

The

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

No

<EOS>

!
"
  
<EOS>

"
"

"
"

,

,
"
"

"

of
another
,
"
she
replied
gently
,
"
yes
'
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
an
ill
-
omened
race
to
him
,
"
said
John
Carker
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
has
reason
to
shrink
from
the
sound
of
our
name
,
and
to
think
that
there
is
something
cursed

.
<EOS>
I
should
almost

too
,
Harriet
,
but
for
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
do
n't

like

.
<EOS>
If

have
any

,
as
you
say

have
,
and
think

have
---
though

,
No
!
---
to
love

,
spare

such

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
covered
his
face
with

hands
;
but
soon
permitted
her
,
coming
near

,
to
take
one
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
After
so

,
this

,
I
know
,
"
said
his
sister
,
"
and

.
<EOS>
We
have
to

,

,
and
must

for

.
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
<EOS>
We
can
do
so
,
undismayed
.
<EOS>
It
is
our
pride
,
not
our
trouble
,
to
strive
,
John
,
and
to
strive

!
"
  
<EOS>
A
smile
played
on
her

,
as
she
kissed

cheek
,
and
entreated

to
be
of
good

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dearest
sister
!
<EOS>
Tied
,
of
your
own
noble
will
,
to
a
ruined
man
!
<EOS>
whose
reputation
is
blighted
;
who
has
no
friend
himself
,
and
has
driven
every
friend
of

away
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
John
!
"
<EOS>
she
laid
her
hand
hastily
upon
his
lips
,
"
for
my
sake!In
remembrance
of
our
long
companionship
!
"
<EOS>
He
was
silent
.
"
<EOS>
Now
let
me
tell
you
,
dear
,
"
quietly
sitting

side
,
"
I
have
,
as
you
have
,
expected
this
;
and
when
I
have
been

,

,
as

,
I

,

,
that

a
secret
from

,
and
that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
's

's

,
Harriet
?
"
<EOS>
he

with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
I
do
n't

,

:
and

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Harriet
!
"

"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Neither
do

,
"
