"
<EOS>
But
he
knows

,

---
all

,
John
.
<EOS>
That

<EOS>
"
Here
!
<EOS>
Has

,
Harriet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,

this

.
<EOS>
Once
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
kind

?
"
  
"
Not

.
"
<EOS>
Grey

,
"
as

,
"
and

.
"
<EOS>
But

,

,

good
,

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
In

only

,
"

,

"
but
when

,

once

as

,
in

our

well
,
and

<EOS>
For

,

---
which

---
that

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
once
a
week
"
  
"
Once

then
,

,

he

;
always

towards

;
and

.
<EOS>
He

that

when

,
and

)
<EOS>
it
very

,

.
<EOS>
Last

---
the

---
he

;
and
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
I
have

;
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
When

,

John
,
let

that
I
have
at

,

let

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
His

he
might

to
smooth

;
and
I

my

that

,
I

.
<EOS>
Then
his

was
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Harriet
,
"
said
her

,

,
"
describe
his
gentleman
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
surely
ought
to
know

who

.
"
   
<EOS>
His

painted
,
as

,
the

,

;
but
John
Carker
,
either
from

the

,

.
  
<EOS>
However
,

original
when

.
<EOS>
This

,

,

,
to

;
and

grey

,
late
Junior
of
Dombey
's
,
devoted
the
first
day
of
his

to

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
quite
late
at

,
and
the
brother
was
reading

while
the
sister
plied
her

,
when

.
<EOS>
In

of

that
lowered

in

their

,
this

,

,

.
<EOS>
The
brother
going
to

,
the

.
<EOS>
Some

,
and
he

and

;
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Harriet
,
"

,

,

"
Mr

---
the

so
long
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
In

,

<EOS>
"
John
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
It

I

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

,

,
"

"

:

,
of

.
<EOS>
Mr

,
I

.
<EOS>
You

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
That
's
reasonable

.
<EOS>
If

such

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
By

,

which

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
There

"

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
As

of

since
(
which

)
,

.
<EOS>
They
soon

into

;
and
we
are
creatures
of

---
creatures
of
habit
!
"
  
<EOS>
Putting
his
hands
into

,
and

,
he

as

;
and

to

,

:
"
<EOS>
It
's

habit
that
confirms
some

us
,
who

better

,
in
Lucifer
's
own
pride

---
<EOS>
that
confirms

others

us
in
villany
---
more
of
us
in

---
<EOS>
that
hardens
us
from
day
to

,
according
to
the
temper
of
our
clay
,
like
images
,
and
leaves
us
as

to
new

and

.
<EOS>
You
shall
judge
of
its

on

,
John
.
<EOS>
For

I
need

,
I

small
,
and
exactly

share
,
in
the
management
of
Dombey
's
House
,
and
saw
your
brother
(
who
has
proved

a

!
<EOS>
Your
sister
will

mention

)
extending

,
until

were
his

;
and

toiling

every

;
and
was

to
be
as
little

as
I
might

,
out

my
own

of

,
and
to
let

,

,

,
like

---
that
was
its

and

---
and
to
take

all
for

,
and

all
right
.
<EOS>
My
Wednesday
nights
came
regularly
round
,
our
quartette
parties
came
regularly
off
,
my
violoncello
was
in
good
tune
,
and
there
was
nothing
wrong
in
my
world
---
or
if
anything
not
much
---
or
little
or
much
,
it
was
no

of
mine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
answer

being
more

and

during

time

in

House
,
Sir
,
"
said
John
Carker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pooh
!
<EOS>
Good
-
natured
and
easy
enough
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
a
habit
I
had
.
<EOS>
It
suited
the
Manager
;
it
suited
the
man
he
managed
:
it
suited
me
best
of
all
.
<EOS>
I
did
what
was
allotted
to
me
to
do
,
made
no
court
to
either
of
them
,
and
was
glad
to
occupy
a
station
in
which
none
was
required
.
<EOS>
So
I
should
have
gone
on
till
now
,
but
that
my
room
had
a
thin
wall
.
<EOS>
You
can
tell
your
sister
that
it
was
divided
from
the
Manager
's
room
by

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
were
adjoining
rooms
;
had
been
one
,
perhaps
,

;
and
were
separated
,
as
Mr
Morfin
says
,
"
said
her
brother
,
looking

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
whistled
,
hummed

,
gone
accurately
through
the
whole

Beethoven
's
Sonata
in
B
,
to

that
I
was
within

,
"
said
Mr
Morfin
;
"
but
he
never
heeded

.
<EOS>
It
happened
seldom
enough
that
I
was
within
hearing
of
anything
of
a
private
nature
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
But
when
I
was
,
and
could
n't
otherwise
avoid

something
of
it
,
I
walked
out
.
<EOS>
I

out
once
,
John
,
during

between
two

,
to
which
,
in

,
young
Walter
Gay
was
a

.
<EOS>
But
I

.
<EOS>
You
remember
it
sufficiently
,
perhaps
,
to
tell
your
sister
what
its
nature
was
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
referred
,
Harriet
,
"
said
her
brother
in
a
low

,
"
to
the
past
,
and
to
our
relative
positions
in
the
House
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Its
matter
was
not
new
to
me
,
but
was

in

new

.
<EOS>
It
shook
me
in
my
habit
---
the
habit
of
nine
-
tenths
of
the
world
---
of
believing
that
all
was
right
about
me
,

,
"
said
their
visitor
;
"
and

of
the
two
brothers
,
and
to
ponder
on
it
.
<EOS>
I
think
it
was
almost
the
first
time
in
my
life
when
I

into
this
train
of
reflection
<EOS>
---
how
will
many

,
and

to

now
,

,

<EOS>
I
was
something

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"

same
two

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I
considered

mine

.
<EOS>
After

.
<EOS>
The

and
<EOS>
I

mistrusted

.
<EOS>
The

;
came

;
and
said

.
<EOS>
Your

,

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

;

.
<EOS>
Undertakings

,

,

'

,

might

.
<EOS>
In

,

:

<EOS>
But

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
in

no

.
  
<EOS>
The

,
until

;
made

,

,

,
when

old
in

,

.
<EOS>
But
another

kept

.
<EOS>
The

out

this
light
had
broken
on

gathered

;
and
the
shadow
of
their
guilty
brother
was
in

house
where
his
foot
had
never

.
  
<EOS>
Nor
was

to

,

.
<EOS>
Next

;

;

.
<EOS>
Darkest
and
most

at

,

.
  
<EOS>
John
Carker
had
gone

,
in

,

.
<EOS>
She
had
been
alone
some
houses
.
<EOS>
A

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

that
,

,

room
,
lest

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Once

,

---

,

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

,
the

;
and

if

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
Close

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let

!
<EOS>
Let

!
<EOS>
I

to
speak
to
you
!
"
<EOS>
and

.
  
<EOS>
She

the
woman

,

.
<EOS>
Naturally

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
Let

!
<EOS>
Let

!
<EOS>
I

---
quiet
---

---
<EOS>
anything

<EOS>
But

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

akin

condition

.
<EOS>
She

it
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
come
in
,
or
shall
I
speak
here
?
"
said
the
woman
,
catching
at
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
that
you
want
?
<EOS>
What
is
it
that
you
have
to
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
much
,
but
let
me
say
it
out
,
or
I
shall
never
say
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
tempted
now
to
go
away
.
<EOS>
There
seem
to
be
hands
dragging
me
from
the
door
.
<EOS>
Let
me
come
in
,
if
you
can
trust
me
for
this
once
!
"
  
<EOS>
Her
energy
again
prevailed
,
and
they
passed
into
the
firelight
of
the
little
kitchen
,
where
she
had
before
sat
,
and
ate
,
and
dried
her
clothes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sit
there
,
"
said
Alice
,
kneeling
down
beside
her
,
"
and
look
at
me
.
<EOS>
You
remember
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
remember
what
I
told
you
I
had
been
,
and
where
I
came
from
,
ragged
and
lame
,
with
the
fierce
wind
and
weather
beating
on
my
head
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
how
I
came
back
that
night
,
and
threw
your
money
in
the
dirt
,
and
cursed
you
and
your
race
.
<EOS>
Now
,
see
me
here
,
upon
my
knees
.
<EOS>
Am
I
less
earnest
now
,
than
I
was
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
what
you
ask
,
"
said
Harriet
,
gently
,
"
is
forgiveness
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
it
's
not
!
"
returned
the
other
,
with
a
proud
,
fierce
look
.
<EOS>
"
What
I
ask
is
to
be
believed
.
<EOS>
Now
you
shall
judge
if
I
am
worthy
of
belief
,
both
as
I
was
,
and
as
I
am
.
"
  
<EOS>
Still
upon
her
knees
,
and
with
her
eyes
upon
the
fire
,
and
the
fire
shining
on
her
ruined
beauty
and
her
wild
black
hair
,
one
long
trees
of
which
she
pulled
over
her
shoulder
,
and
wound
about
her
hand
,
and
thoughtfully
bit
and
tore
while
speaking
,
she
went
on
:
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
was
young
and
pretty
,
and
this
,
"
plucking
contemptuously
at
the
hair
she
held
,
"
was
only
handled
delicately
,
and
could
n't
be
admired
enough
,
my
mother
,
who
had
not
been
very
mindful
of
me
as
a
child
,
found
out
my
merits
,
and
was
fond
of
me
,
and
proud
of
me
.
<EOS>
She
was
covetous
and
poor
,
and
thought
to
make
a
sort
of
property
of
me
.
<EOS>
No
great
lady
ever
thought
that
of
a
daughter
yet
,
I
'm
sure
,
or
acted
as
if
she
did
<EOS>
---
it
's
never
done
,
we
all
know
---
and
that
shows
that
the
only
instances
of
mothers
bringing
up
their
daughters
wrong
,
and
evil
coming
of
it
,
are
among
such
miserable
folks
as
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
Looking
at
the
fire
,
as
if
she
were
forgetful
,
for
the
moment
,
of
having
any
auditor
,
she
continued
in
a
dreamy
way
as
she
wound
the
long
tress
of
hair
tight
round
and
round
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
came
of
that
,
I
need
n't
say
.
<EOS>
Wretched
marriages
do
n't
come
of
such
things
,
in
our
degree
;
only
wretchedness
and
ruin
.
<EOS>
Wretchedness
and
ruin
came
on
me
---
came
on
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Raising
her
eyes
swiftly
from
their
moody
gaze
upon
the
fire
,
to
Harriet
's
face
,
she
said
:
  
"
I
am
wasting
time
,
and
there
is
none
to
spare
;
yet
if
I
had
n't
thought
of
all
,
I
should
n't
be
here
now
.
<EOS>
Wretchedness
and
ruin
came
on
me
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
I
was
made
a
short
-
lived
toy
,
and
flung
aside
more
cruelly
and
carelessly
than
even
such
things
are
.
<EOS>
By
whose
hand
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
ask
me
?
"
said
Harriet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
tremble
?
<EOS>
"
rejoined
Alice
,
with
an
eager
look
.
"
<EOS>
His
usage
made
a
Devil
of
me
.
<EOS>
I
sunk
in
wretchedness
and
ruin
,
lower
and
lower
yet
.
<EOS>
I
was
concerned
in
a
robbery
---
in
every
part
of
it
but
the
gains
---
and
was
found
out
,
and
sent
to
be
tried
,
without
a
friend
,
without
a
penny
.
<EOS>
Though
I
was
but
a
girl
,
I
would
have
gone
to
Death
,
sooner
than
ask
him
for
a
word
,
if
a
word
of
his
could
have
saved
me
.
<EOS>
I
would
!
<EOS>
To
any
death
that
could
have
been
invented
.
<EOS>
But
my
mother
,
covetous
always
,
sent
to
him
in
my
name
,
told
the
true
story
of
my
case
,
and
humbly
prayed
and
petitioned
for
a
small
last
gift
---
for
not
so
many
pounds
as
I
have
fingers
on
this
hand
.
<EOS>
Who
was
it
,
do
you
think
,
who
snapped
his
fingers
at
me
in
my
misery
,
lying
,
as
he
believed
,
at
his
feet
,
and
left
me
without
even
this
poor
sign
of
remembrance
;
well
satisfied
that
I
should
be
sent
abroad
,
beyond
the
reach
of
further
trouble
to
him
,
and
should
die
,
and
rot
there
?
<EOS>
Who
was
this
,
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
ask
me
?
"
repeated
Harriet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
tremble
?
"
said
Alice
,
laying
her
hand
upon
her
arm
,
and
looking
in
her
face
,
"
but
that
the
answer
is
on
your
lips
!
<EOS>
It
was
your
brother
James
.
"
  
<EOS>
Harriet
trembled
more
and
more
,
but
did
not
avert
her
eyes
from
the
eager
look
that
rested
on
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
knew
you
were
his
sister
---
which
was
on
that
night
---
I
came
back
,
weary
and
lame
,
to
spurn
your
gift
.
<EOS>
I
felt
that
night
as
if
I
could
have
travelled
,
weary
and
lame
,
over
the
whole
world
,
to
stab
him
,
if
I
could
have
found
him
in
a
lonely
place
with
no
one
near
.
<EOS>
Do
you
believe
that
I
was
earnest
in
all
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
!
<EOS>
Good
Heaven
,
why
are
you
come
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Since
then
,
"
said
Alice
,
with
the
same
grasp
of
her
arm
,
and
the
same
look
in
her
face
,
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
him
!
<EOS>
I
have
followed
him
with
my
eyes
,
in
the
broad
day
.
<EOS>
If
any
spark
of
my
resentment
slumbered
in
my
bosom
,
it
sprung
into
a
blaze
when
my
eyes
rested
on
him
.
<EOS>
You
know
he
has
wronged
a
proud
man
,
and
made
him
his
deadly
enemy
.
<EOS>
What
if
I
had
given
information
of
him
to
that
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Information
!
"
repeated
Harriet
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
if
I
had
found
out
one
who
knew
your
brother
's
secret
;
who
knew
the
manner
of
his
flight
;
who
knew
where
he
and
the
companion
of
his
flight
were
gone
?
<EOS>
What
<EOS>
if
I
had
made
him
utter
all
his
knowledge
,
<EOS>
word
by
word
,
before
his
enemy
,
concealed
to
hear
it
?
<EOS>
What
if
I
had
sat
by
at
the
time
,
looking
into
this
enemy
's
face
,
and
seeing
it
change
till
it
was
scarcely
human
?
<EOS>
What
<EOS>
if
I
had
seen
him
rush
away
,
mad
,
in
pursuit
?
<EOS>
What
if
I
knew
,
now
,
that
he
was
on
his
road
,
more
fiend
than
man
,
and
must
,
in
so
many
hours
,
come
up
with
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Remove
your
hand
!
"
said
Harriet
,
recoiling
.
<EOS>
"
Go
away!Your
touch
is
dreadful
to
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
this
,
"
pursued
the
other
,
with
her
eager
look
,
regardless
of
the
interruption
.
<EOS>
"
Do
I
speak
and
look
as
if
I
really
had
?
<EOS>
Do
you
believe
what
I
am
saying
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
I
must
.
<EOS>
Let
my
arm
go
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
yet
.
<EOS>
A
moment
more
.
<EOS>
You
can
think
what
my
revengeful
purpose
must
have
been
,
to
last
so
long
,
and
urge
me
to
do
this
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Dreadful
!
"
said
Harriet
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
when
you
see
me
now
,
"
said
Alice
hoarsely
,
"
here
again
,
kneeling
quietly
on
the
ground
,
with
my
touch
upon
your
arm
,
with
my
eyes
upon
your
face
<EOS>
,
you
may
believe
that
there
is
no
common
earnestness
in
what
I
say
,
and
that
no
common
struggle
has
been
battling
in
my
breast
.
<EOS>
I
am
ashamed
to
speak
the
words
,
but
I
relent
.
<EOS>
I
despise
myself
;
I
have
fought
with
myself
all
day
,
and
all
last
night
;
but
I
relent
towards
him
without
reason
,
and
wish
to
repair
what
I
have
done
,
if
it
is
possible
.
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
them
come
together
while
his
pursuer
is
so
blind
and
headlong
.
<EOS>
If
you
had
seen
him
as
he
went
out
last
night
,
you
would
know
the
danger
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
shall
it
be
prevented
?
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
do
?
"
cried
Harriet
.
  
<EOS>
"
All
night
long
,
"
pursued
the
other
,
hurriedly
,
"
I
had
dreams
of
him
---
and
yet
I
did
n't
sleep
---
in
his
blood
.
<EOS>
All
day
,
I
have
had
him
near
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
do
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Harriet
,
shuddering
at
these
words
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
there
is
any
one
who
'll
write
,
or
send
,
or
go
to
him
,
let
them
lose
no
time
.
<EOS>
He
is
at
Dijon
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
the
name
,
and
where
it
is
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Warn
him
that
the
man
he
has
made
his
enemy
is
in
a
frenzy
,
and
that
he
does
n't
know
him
if
he
makes
light
of
his
approach
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
that
he
is
on
the
road
---
<EOS>
I
know
he
is
!
<EOS>
---
and
hurrying
on
.
<EOS>
Urge
him
to
get
away
while
there
is
time
---
if
there
is
time
---
and
not
to
meet
him
yet
.
<EOS>
A
month
or
so
will
make
years
of
difference
.
<EOS>
Let
them
not
encounter
,
through
me
.
<EOS>
Anywhere
but
there
!
<EOS>
Any
time
but
now
!
<EOS>
Let
his
foe
follow
him
,
and
find
him
for
himself
,
but
not
through
me!There
<EOS>
is
enough
upon
my
head
without
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
fire
ceased
to
be
reflected
in
her
jet
black
hair
,
uplifted
face
,
and
eager
eyes
;
her
hand
was
gone
from
Harriet
's
arm
;
and
the
place
where
she
had
been
was
empty
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
54
.
<EOS>
The
Fugitives
 
<EOS>
THE
time
,
an
hour
short
of
midnight
;
the
place
,
a
French
apartment
,
comprising
some
half
-
dozen
rooms
;
---
a
dull
cold
hall
or
corridor
,
a
dining
-
room
a
drawing
-
room
,
a
bed
-
chamber
,
and
an
inner
drawing
-
room
,
or
boudoir
,
smaller
and
more
retired
than
the
rest
.
<EOS>
All
these
shut
in
by
one
large
pair
of
doors
on
the
main
staircase
,
but
each
room
provided
with
two
or
three
pairs
of
doors
of
its
own
,
establishing
several
means
of
communication
with
the
remaining
portion
of
the
apartment
,
or
with
certain
small
passages
within
the
wall
,
leading
,
as
is
not
unusual
in
such
houses
,
to
some
back
stairs
with
an
obscure
outlet
below
.
<EOS>
The
whole
situated
on
the
first
floor
of
so
large
an
Hotel
,
that
it
did
not
absorb
one
entire
row
of
windows
upon
one
side
of
the
square
court
-
yard
in
the
centre
,
upon
which
the
whole
four
sides
of
the
mansion
looked
.
  
<EOS>
An
air
of
splendour
,
sufficiently
faded
to
be
melancholy
,
and
sufficiently
dazzling
to
clog
and
embarrass
the
details
of
life
with
a
show
of
state
,
reigned
in
these
rooms
.
<EOS>
The
walls
and
ceilings
were
gilded
and
painted
;
the
floors
were
waxed
and
polished
;
crimson
drapery
hung
in
festoons
from
window
,
door
,
and
mirror
;
candelabra
,
gnarled
and
intertwisted
,
like
the
branches
of
trees
,
or
horns
of
animals
,
stuck
out
from
the
panels
of
the
wall
.
<EOS>
But
in
the
day
-
time
,
when
the
lattice
-
blinds
(
now
closely
shut
)
were
opened
,
and
the
light
let
in
,
traces
were
discernible
among
this
finery
,
of
wear
and
tear
and
dust
,
of
sun
and
damp
and
smoke
,
and
lengthened
intervals
of
want
of
use
and
habitation
,
when
such
shows
and
toys
of
life
seem
sensitive
like
life
,
and
waste
as
men
shut
up
in
prison
do
.
<EOS>
Even
night
,
and
clusters
of
burning
candles
,
could
not
wholly
efface
them
,
though
the
general
glitter
threw
them
in
the
shade
.
  
<EOS>
The
glitter
of
bright
tapers
,
and
their
reflection
in
looking
-
glasses
,
scraps
of
gilding
and
gay
colours
,
were
confined
,
on
this
night
,
to
one
room
---
that
smaller
room
within
the
rest
,
just
now
enumerated
.
<EOS>
Seen
from
the
hall
,
where
a
lamp
was
feebly
burning
,
through
the
dark
perspective
of
open
doors
,
it
looked
as
shining
and
precious
as
a
gem
.
<EOS>
In
the
heart
of
its
radiance
sat
a
beautiful
woman
---
Edith
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
alone
.
<EOS>
The
same
defiant
,
scornful
woman
still
.
<EOS>
The
cheek
a
little
worn
,
the
eye
a
little
larger
in
appearance
,
and
more
lustrous
,
but
the
haughty
bearing
just
the
same
.
<EOS>
No
shame
upon
her
brow
;
no
late
repentance
bending
her
disdainful
neck
.
<EOS>
Imperious
and
stately
yet
,
and
yet
regardless
of
herself
and
of
all
else
,
she
sat
with
her
dark
eyes
cast
down
,
waiting
for
some
one
.
  
<EOS>
No
book
,
no
work
,
no
occupation
of
any
kind
but
her
own
thought
,
beguiled
the
tardy
time
.
<EOS>
Some
purpose
,
strong
enough
to
fill
up
any
pause
,
possessed
her
.
<EOS>
With
her
lips
pressed
together
,
and
quivering
if
for
a
moment
she
released
them
from
her
control
;
with
her
nostril
inflated
;
her
hands
clasped
in
one
another
;
and
her
purpose
swelling
in
her
breast
;
she
sat
,
and
waited
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
sound
of
a
key
in
the
outer
door
,
and
a
footstep
in
the
hall
,
she
started
up
,
and
cried
"
Who
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
The
answer
was
in
French
,
and
two
men
came
in
with
jingling
trays
,
to
make
preparation
for
supper
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
had
bade
them
to
do
so
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Monsieur
had
commanded
it
,
when
it
was
his
pleasure
to
take
the
apartment
.
<EOS>
Monsieur
had
said
,
when
he
stayed
there
for
an
hour
,
en
route
,
and
left
the
letter
for
Madame
---
Madame
had
received
it
surely
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
thousand
pardons
!
<EOS>
The
sudden
apprehension
that
it
might
have
been
forgotten
had
struck
him
;
"
a
bald
man
,
with
a
large
beard
from
a
neighbouring
restaurant
:
"
with
despair!Monsieur
had
said
that
supper
was
to
be
ready
at
that
hour
:
also
that
he
had
forewarned
Madame
of
the
commands
he
had
given
,
in
his
letter
.
<EOS>
Monsieur
had
done
the
Golden
Head
the
honour
to
request
that
the
supper
should
be
choice
and
delicate
.
<EOS>
Monsieur
would
find
that
his
confidence
in
the
Golden
Head
was
not
misplaced
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
said
no
more
,
but
looked
on
thoughtfully
while
they
prepared
the
table
for
two
persons
,
and
set
the
wine
upon
it
.
<EOS>
She
arose
before
they
had
finished
,
and
taking
a
lamp
,
passed
into
the
bed
-
chamber
and
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
where
she
hurriedly
but
narrowly
examined
all
the
doors
;
particularly
one
in
the
former
room
that
opened
on
the
passage
in
the
wall
.
<EOS>
From
this
she
took
the
key
,
and
put
it
on
the
outer
side
.
<EOS>
She
then
came
back
.
  
<EOS>
The
men
---
the
second
of
whom
was
a
dark
,
bilious
subject
,
in
a
jacket
,
close
shaved
,
and
with
a
black
head
of
hair
close
cropped
---
had
completed
their
preparation
of
the
table
,
and
were
standing
looking
at
it
.
<EOS>
He
who
had
spoken
before
,
inquired
whether
Madame
thought
it
would
be
long
before
Monsieur
arrived
?
  
<EOS>
"
She
could
n't
say
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
!
<EOS>
There
was
the
supper
!
<EOS>
It
should
be
eaten
on
the
instant
.
<EOS>
Monsieur
(
who
spoke
French
like
an
Angel
---
or
a
Frenchman
<EOS>
---
it
was
all
the
same
)
had
spoken
with
great
emphasis
of
his
punctuality
.
<EOS>
But
the
English
nation
had
so
grand
a
genius
for
punctuality
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
what
noise
!
<EOS>
Great
Heaven
,
here
was
Monsieur
.
<EOS>
Behold
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
effect
,
Monsieur
,
admitted
by
the
other
of
the
two
,
came
,
with
his
gleaming
teeth
,
through
the
dark
rooms
,
like
a
mouth
;
and
arriving
in
that
sanctuary
of
light
and
colour
,
a
figure
at
full
length
,
embraced
Madame
,
and
addressed
her
in
the
French
tongue
as
his
charming
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
God
!
<EOS>
Madame
is
going
to
faint
.
<EOS>
Madame
is
overcome
with
joy
!
"
<EOS>
The
bald
man
with
the
beard
observed
it
,
and
cried
out
.
  
<EOS>
Madame
had
only
shrunk
and
shivered
.
<EOS>
Before
the
words
were
spoken
,
she
was
standing
with
her
hand
upon
the
velvet
back
of
a
great
chair
;
her
figure
drawn
up
to
its
full
height
,
and
her
face
immoveable
.
  
<EOS>
"
Francois
has
flown
over
to
the
Golden
Head
for
supper
.
<EOS>
He
flies
on
these
occasions
like
an
angel
or
a
bird
.
<EOS>
The
baggage
of
Monsieur
is
in
his
room
.
<EOS>
All
is
arranged
.
<EOS>
The
supper
will
be
here
this
moment
.
"
<EOS>
These
facts
the
bald
man
notified
with
bows
and
smiles
,
and
presently
the
supper
came
.
  
<EOS>
The
hot
dishes
were
on
a
chafing
-
dish
;
the
cold
already
set
forth
,
with
the
change
of
service
on
a
sideboard
.
<EOS>
Monsieur
was
satisfied
with
this
arrangement
.
<EOS>
The
supper
table
being
small
,
it
pleased
him
very
well
.
<EOS>
Let
them
set
the
chafing
-
dish
upon
the
floor
,
and
go
.
<EOS>
He
would
remove
the
dishes
with
his
own
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
!
"
said
the
bald
man
,
politely
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
impossible
!
"
  
<EOS>
Monsieur
was
of
another
opinion
.
<EOS>
He
required
no
further
attendance
that
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
Madame'the
bald
man
hinted
.
  
<EOS>
"
Madame
,
"
replied
Monsieur
,
"
had
her
own
maid
.
<EOS>
It
was
enough
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
million
pardons
!
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
Madame
had
no
maid
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
came
here
alone
,
"
said
Edith
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
my
choice
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
am
well
used
to
travelling
;
I
want
no
attendance
.
<EOS>
They
need
send
nobody
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Monsieur
accordingly
,
persevering
in
his
first
proposed
impossibility
,
proceeded
to
follow
the
two
attendants
to
the
outer
door
,
and
secure
it
after
them
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
The
bald
man
turning
round
to
bow
,
as
he
went
out
,
observed
that
Madame
still
stood
with
her
hand
upon
the
velvet
back
of
the
great
chair
,
and
that
her
face
was
quite
regardless
of
him
,
though
she
was
looking
straight
before
her
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
sound
of
Carker
's
fastening
the
door
resounded
through
the
intermediate
rooms
,
and
seemed
to
come
hushed
and
stifled
into
that
last
distant
one
,
the
sound
of
the
Cathedral
clock
striking
twelve
mingled
with
it
,
in
Edith
's
ears
.
<EOS>
She
heard
him
pause
,
as
if
he
heard
it
too
and
listened
;
and
then
came
back
towards
her
,
laying
a
long
train
of
footsteps
through
the
silence
,
and
shutting
all
the
doors
behind
him
as
he
came
along
.
<EOS>
Her
hand
,
for
a
moment
,
left
the
velvet
chair
to
bring
a
knife
within
her
reach
upon
the
table
;
then
she
stood
as
she
had
stood
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
strange
to
come
here
by
yourself
,
my
love
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
as
he
entered
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
she
returned
.
  
<EOS>
Her
tone
was
so
harsh
;
the
quick
turn
of
her
head
so
fierce
;
her
attitude
so
repellent
;
and
her
frown
so
black
;
that
he
stood
,
with
the
lamp
in
his
hand
,
looking
at
her
,
as
if
she
had
struck
him
motionless
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
he
at
length
repeated
,
putting
down
the
lamp
,
and
smiling
his
most
courtly
smile
,
"
how
strange
to
come
here
alone
!
<EOS>
It
was
unnecessary
caution
surely
,
and
might
have
defeated
itself
.
<EOS>
You
were
to
have
engaged
an
attendant
at
Havre
or
Rouen
,
and
have
had
abundance
of
time
for
the
purpose
,
though
you
had
been
the
most
capricious
and
difficult
(
as
you
are
the
most
beautiful
,
my
love
)
of
women
.
"
  
<EOS>
Her
eyes
gleamed
strangely
on
him
,
but
she
stood
with
her
hand
resting
on
the
chair
,
and
said
not
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
,
"
resumed
Carker
,
"
seen
you
look
so
handsome
,
as
you
do
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
Even
the
picture
I
have
carried
in
my
mind
during
this
cruel
probation
,
and
which
I
have
contemplated
night
and
day
,
is
exceeded
by
the
reality
.
"
  
<EOS>
Not
a
word
.
<EOS>
Not
a
look
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
completely
hidden
by
their
drooping
lashes
,
but
her
head
held
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hard
,
unrelenting
terms
they
were
!
"
said
Carker
,
with
a
smile
,
"
but
they
are
all
fulfilled
and
passed
,
and
make
the
present
more
delicious
and
more
safe
.
<EOS>
Sicily
shall
be
the
place
of
our
retreat
.
<EOS>
In
the
idlest
and
easiest
part
of
the
world
,
my
soul
,
we
'll
both
seek
compensation
for
old
slavery
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
coming
gaily
towards
her
,
when
,
in
an
instant
,
she
caught
the
knife
up
from
the
table
,
and
started
one
pace
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stand
still
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
or
I
shall
murder
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
sudden
change
in
her
,
the
towering
fury
and
intense
abhorrence
sparkling
in
her
eyes
and
lighting
up
her
brow
,
made
him
stop
as
if
a
fire
had
stopped
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stand
still
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
come
no
nearer
me
,
upon
your
life
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
both
stood
looking
at
each
other
.
<EOS>
Rage
and
astonishment
were
in
his
face
,
but
he
controlled
them
and
said
lightly
,
  
"
<EOS>
Come
,
come
!
<EOS>
Tush
,
we
are
alone
,
and
out
of
everybody
's
sight
and
hearing
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
to
frighten
me
with
these
tricks
of
virtue
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
to
frighten
me
,
"
she
answered
fiercely
,
"
from
any
purpose
that
I
have
,
and
any
course
I
am
resolved
upon
,
by
reminding
me
of
the
solitude
of
this
place
,
and
there
being
no
help
near
?
<EOS>
Me
,
who
am
here
alone
,
designedly
?
<EOS>
If
I
feared
you
,
should
I
not
have
avoided
you
?
<EOS>
If
I
feared
you
,
should
I
be
here
,
in
the
dead
of
night
,
telling
you
to
your
face
what
I
am
going
to
tell
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
what
is
that
,
"
he
said
,
"
you
handsome
shrew
?
<EOS>
Handsomer
so
,
than
any
other
woman
in
her
best
humour
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
nothing
,
"
she
returned
,
"
until
you
go
back
to
that
chair
---
except
this
,
once
again
---
<EOS>
Do
n't
come
near
me
!
<EOS>
Not
a
step
nearer
.
<EOS>
I
tell
you
,
if
you
do
,
as
heaven
sees
us
,
I
shall
murder
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mistake
me
for
your
husband
?
<EOS>
"
he
retorted
,
with
a
grin
.
  
<EOS>
Disdaining
to
reply
,
she
stretched
her
arm
out
,
pointing
to
the
chair
.
<EOS>
He
bit
his
lip
,
frowned
,
laughed
,
and
sat
down
in
it
,
with
a
baffled
,
irresolute
,
impatient
air
,
he
was
unable
to
conceal
;
and
biting
his
nail
nervously
,
and
looking
at
her
sideways
,
with
bitter
discomfiture
,
even
while
he
feigned
to
be
amused
by
her
caprice
.
  
<EOS>
She
put
the
knife
down
upon
the
table
,
and
touching
her
bosom
with
her
hand
,
said
:
  
"
I
have
something
lying
here
that
is
no
love
trinket
;
and
sooner
than
endure
your
touch
once
more
,
I
would
use
it
on
you
---
<EOS>
and
you
know
it
,
while
I
speak
---
with
less
reluctance
than
I
would
on
any
other
creeping
thing
that
lives
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
affected
to
laugh
jestingly
,
and
entreated
her
to
act
her
play
out
quickly
,
for
the
supper
was
growing
cold
.
<EOS>
But
the
secret
look
with
which
he
regarded
her
,
was
more
sullen
and
lowering
,
and
he
struck
his
foot
once
upon
the
floor
with
a
muttered
oath
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
many
times
,
"
said
Edith
,
<EOS>
bending
her
darkest
glance
upon
him
,
"
has
your
bold
knavery
assailed
me
with
outrage
and
insult
?
<EOS>
How
many
times
in
your
smooth
manner
,
and
mocking
words
and
looks
,
have
I
been
twitted
with
my
courtship
and
my
marriage
?
<EOS>
How
many
times
have
you
laid
bare
my
wound
of
love
for
that
sweet
,
injured
girl
,
and
lacerated
it
?
<EOS>
How
often
have
you
fanned
the
fire
on
which
,
for
two
years
,
I
have
writhed
;
and
tempted
me
to
take
a
desperate
revenge
,
when
it
has
most
tortured
me
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
,
Ma'am
,
"
he
replied
,
"
that
you
have
kept
a
good
account
,
and
that
it
's
pretty
accurate
.
<EOS>
Come
,
Edith
.
<EOS>
To
your
husband
,
poor
wretch
,
this
was
well
enough
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
if
,
"
she
said
,
surveying
him
with
a
haughty
contempt
and
disgust
,
that
he
shrunk
under
,
let
him
brave
it
as
he
would
,
"
if
all
my
other
reasons
for
despising
him
could
have
been
blown
away
like

,
his
having
you
for
his
counsellor
and
favourite
,
would
have
almost
been
enough
to
hold
their
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
a
reason
why
you
have
run
away
with
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
her
,
tauntingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
why
we
are
face
to
face
for
the
last
time
.
<EOS>
Wretch!We
meet
to
-
night
,
and
part
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
For
not
one
moment
after
I
have
ceased
to
speak
,
will
I
stay
here
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
turned
upon
her
with
his
ugliest
look
,
and
griped
the
table
with
his
hand
;
but
neither
rose
,
nor
otherwise
answered
or
threatened
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
woman
,
"
she
said
,
confronting
him
steadfastly
,
"
who
from
her
very
childhood
has
been
shamed
and
steeled
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
offered
and
rejected
,
put
up
and
appraised
,
until
my
very
soul
has
sickened
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
had
an

or
grace
that
might
have
been
a

to
me
,
but

been

to

,

had
called

.
<EOS>
My
poor

,
have
looked
on

approved
;
and
every

between

has
been
deadened

.
<EOS>
There
is
not
one
of

care
,
as

.
<EOS>
I
stand
alone

the
world
,
remembering
well
<EOS>
what
a

world
it
has
been
to
me
,
and
what
a
hollow
part
of
it
<EOS>
I
have
been
myself
.
<EOS>
You
know
this
,
and
you
know
that
my
fame
with
it
is
worthless
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
imagined
that
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
calculated
on
it
,
"
she

,
"
and
so
pursued
me
.
<EOS>
Grown
too
indifferent
for
any
opposition
but
indifference
,
to
the
daily

of
the
hands
that
had

;
and

my

up

<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
know

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
calculated
on
it
,
"
she

once

,
"
and
so

.
<EOS>
From
my

,

(

<EOS>
This

my

;
hemmed

with

himself
;

in
,

of

.
<EOS>

---

<EOS>
I

the

!
"
  
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
She

"

"

<EOS>
But

,

"
Aye
!
<EOS>
How

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"
What

?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Hear

!
<EOS>
Proposing

this

---

---

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All

"

"
<EOS>
The

adage
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
On

,
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

,

,

Carker
,

"
See

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

;

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Take

!
"

<EOS>

We

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Edith
!
"

"
<EOS>
Sit

done

!
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Their

<EOS>
False

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
In

,
"

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
I
single

the
meanest
man

I

,
the

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Boast

<EOS>
The

"
Too

"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
For

,

.
<EOS>
For

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Nothing

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

to

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
and
not

.
<EOS>
He
saw

within

that
was

.
<EOS>
He

that
she
was

,
and
that
her

hatred
of
him
would
stop

nothing
.
<EOS>
His

followed
the
hand
that

purpose
into
her
white

,
and
he

that

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

:
but

was

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Lastly
,

my

!
<EOS>
Look
to

!
"
<EOS>
she

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
have

,

.
<EOS>
It
has

that
you

,

.
<EOS>
If

,
I

-

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Strumpet
,

's

!
"
<EOS>
cried
Carker
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
moment
,
the
bell
rang
loudly
in
the
hall
.
<EOS>
He
turned
white
,
as
she
held
her
hand
up
like
an
enchantress
,
at
whose
invocation
the
sound
had
come
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
<EOS>
do
you
hear
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
set
his
back
against
the
door
;
for
he
saw
a
change
in
her
,
and
fancied
she
was
coming
on
to
pass
him
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
a
moment
,
she
was
gone
through
the
opposite
doors
communicating
with
the
bed
-
chamber
,
and
they
shut
upon
her
.
  
<EOS>
Once
turned
,
once
changed
in
her
inflexible
unyielding
look
,
he
felt
that
he
could
cope
with
her
.
<EOS>
He
thought
a
sudden
terror
,
occasioned
by
this
night
-
alarm
,
had
subdued
her
;
not
the
less
readily
,
for
her
overwrought
condition
.
<EOS>
Throwing
open
the
doors
,
he
followed
,
almost
instantly
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
room
was
dark
;
and
as
she
made
no
answer
to
his
call
,
he
was
fain
to
go
back
for
the
lamp
.
<EOS>
He
held
it
up
,
and
looked
round
everywhere
,
expecting
to
see
her
crouching
in
some
corner
;
but
the
room
was
empty
.
<EOS>
So
,
into
the
drawing
-
room
and
dining
-
room
he
went
,
in
succession
,
with
the
uncertain
steps
of
a
man
in
a
strange
place
;
looking
fearfully
about
,
and
prying
behind
screens
and
couches
;
but
she
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
No
,
nor
in
the
hall
,
which
was
so
bare
that
he
could
see
that
,
at
a
glance
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
the
ringing
at
the
bell
was
constantly
renewed
;
and
those
without
were
beating
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
He
put
his
lamp
down
at
a
distance
,
and
going
near
it
,
listened
.
<EOS>
There
were
several
voices
talking
together
:
at
least
two
of
them
in
English
;
and
though
the
door
was
thick
,
and
there
was
great
confusion
,
he
knew
one
of
these
too
well
to
doubt
whose
voice
it
was
.
  
<EOS>
He
took
up
his
lamp
again
,
and
came
back
quickly
through
all
the
rooms
,
stopping
as
he
quitted
each
,
and
looking
round
for
her
,
with
the
light
raised
above
his
head
.
<EOS>
He
was
standing
thus
in
the
bed
-
chamber
,
when
the
door
,
leading
to
the
little
passage
in
the
wall
,
caught
his
eye
.
<EOS>
He
went
to
it
,
and
found
it
fastened
on
the
other
side
;
but
she
had
dropped
a
veil
in
going
through
,
and
shut
it
in
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
time
the
people
on
the
stairs
were
ringing
at
the
bell
,
and
knocking
with
their
hands
and
feet
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
coward
:
but
these
sounds
;
what
had
gone
before
;
the
strangeness
of
the
place
,
which
had
confused
him
,
even
in
his
return
from
the
hall
;
the
frustration
of
his
schemes
(
for
,
strange
to
say
,
he
would
have
been
much
bolder
,
if
they
had
succeeded
)
;
the
unseasonable
time
;
the
recollection
of
having
no
one
near
to
whom
he
could
appeal
for
any
friendly
office
;
above
all
,
the
sudden
sense
,
which
made
even
his
heart
beat
like
lead
,
that
the
man
whose
confidence
he
had
outraged
,
and
whom
he
had
so
treacherously
deceived
,
was
there
to
recognise
and
challenge
him
with
his
mask
plucked
off
his
face
;
struck
a
panic
through
him
.
<EOS>
He
tried
the
door
in
which
the
veil
was
shut
,
but
could
n't
force
it
.
<EOS>
He
opened
one
of
the
windows
,
and
looked
down
through
the
lattice
of
the
blind
,
into
the
court
-
yard
;
but
it
was
a
high
leap
,
and
the
stones
were
pitiless
.
  
<EOS>
The
ringing
and
knocking
still
continuing
---
his
panic
too
---
he
went
back
to
the
door
in
the
bed
-
chamber
,
and
with
some
new
efforts
,
each
more
stubborn
than
the
last
,
wrenched
it
open
.
<EOS>
Seeing
the
little
staircase
not
far
off
,
and
feeling
the
night
-
air
coming
up
,
he
stole
back
for
his
hat
and
coat
,
made
the
door
as
secure
after
him
as
he
could
,
crept
down
lamp
in
hand
,
extinguished
it
on
seeing
the
street
,
and
having
put
it
in
a
corner
,
went
out
where
the
stars
were
shining
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
55
.
<EOS>
Rob
the
Grinder
loses
his
Place
 
<EOS>
THE
porter
at
the
iron
gate
which
shut
the
court
-
yard
from
the
street
,
had
left
the
little
wicket
of
his
house
open
,
and
was
gone
away
;
no
doubt
to
mingle
in
the
distant
noise
at
the
door
of
the
great
staircase
.
<EOS>
Lifting
the
latch
softly
,
Carker
crept
out
,
and
shutting
the
jangling
gate
after
him
with
as
little
noise
as
possible
,
hurried
off
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
fever
of
his
mortification
and
unavailing
rage
,
the
panic
that
had
seized
upon
him
mastered
him
completely
.
<EOS>
It
rose
to
such
a
height
that
he
would
have
blindly
encountered
almost
any
risk
,
rather
than
meet
the
man
of
whom
,
two
hours
ago
,
he
had
been
utterly
regardless
.
<EOS>
His
fierce
arrival
,
which
he
had
never
expected
;
the
sound
of
his
voice
;
their
having
been
so
near
a
meeting
,
face
to
face
,
he
would
have
braved
out
this
,
after
the
first
momentary
shock
of
alarm
,
and
would
have
put
as
bold
a
front
upon
his
guilt
as
any
villain
.
<EOS>
But
the
springing
of
his
mine
upon
himself
,
seemed
to
have
rent
and
shivered
all
his
hardihood
and
self
-
reliance
.
<EOS>
Spurned
like
any
reptile
;
entrapped
and
mocked
;
turned
upon
,
and
trodden
down
by
the
proud
woman
whose
mind
he
had
slowly
poisoned
,
as
he
thought
,
until
she
had
sunk
into
the
mere
creature
of
his
pleasure
;
undeceived
in
his
deceit
,
and
with
his
fox
's
hide
stripped
off
,
he
sneaked
away
,
abashed
,
degraded
,
and
afraid
.
  
<EOS>
Some
other
terror
came
upon
him
quite
removed
from
this
of
being
pursued
,
suddenly
,
like
an
electric
shock
,
as
he
was
creeping
through
the
streets
.
<EOS>
Some
visionary
terror
,
unintelligible
and
inexplicable
,
associated
with
a
trembling
of
the
ground
,
---
a
rush
and
sweep
of
something
through
the
air
,
like
Death
upon
the
wing
.
<EOS>
He
shrunk
,
as
if
to
let
the
thing
go
by
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
gone
,
it
never
had
been
there
,
yet
what
a
startling
horror
it
had
left
behind
.
  
<EOS>
He
raised
his
wicked
face
,
so
full
of
trouble
,
to
the
night
sky
,
where
the
stars
,
so
full
of
peace
,
were
shining
on
him
as
they
had
been
when
he
first
stole
out
into
the
air
;
and
stopped
to
think
what
he
should
do
.
<EOS>
The
dread
of
being
hunted
in
a
strange
remote
place
,
where
the
laws
might
not
protect
him
---
the
novelty
of
the
feeling
that
it
was
strange
and
remote
,
originating
in
his
being
left
alone
so
suddenly
amid
the
ruins
of
his
plans
---
his
greater
dread
of
seeking
refuge
now
,
in
Italy
or
in
Sicily
,
where
men
might
be
hired
to
assassinate
him
,
he
thought
,
at
any
dark
street
corner
---
the
waywardness
of
guilt
and
fear
---
perhaps
some
sympathy
of
action
with
the
turning
back
of
all
his
schemes
---
impelled
him
to
turn
back
too
,
and
go
to
England
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
safer
there
,
in
any
case
.
<EOS>
If
I
should
not
decide
,
"
he
thought
,
"
to
give
this
fool
a
meeting
,
I
am
less
likely
to
be
traced
there
,
than
abroad
here
,
now
.
<EOS>
And
if
I
should
(
this
cursed
fit
being
over
)
,
at
least
I
shall
not
be
alone
,
without
a
soul
to
speak
to
,
or
advise
with
,
or
stand
by
me
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
be
run
in
upon
and
worried
like
a
rat
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
muttered
Edith
's
name
,
and
clenched
his
hand
.
<EOS>
As
he
crept
along
,
in
the
shadow
of
the
massive
buildings
,
he
set
his
teeth
,
and
muttered
dreadful
imprecations
on
her
head
,
and
looked
from
side
to
side
,
as
if
in
search
of
her
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
he
stole
on
to
the
gate
of
an
inn
-
yard
.
<EOS>
The
people
were
a
-
bed
;
but
his
ringing
at
the
bell
soon
produced
a
man
with
a
lantern
,
in
company
with
whom
he
was
presently
in
a
dim
coach
-
house
,
bargaining
for
the
hire
of
an
old
phaeton
,
to
Paris
.
  
<EOS>
The
bargain
was
a
short
one
;
and
the
horses
were
soon
sent
for
.
<EOS>
Leaving
word
that
the
carriage
was
to
follow
him
when
they
came
,
he
stole
away
again
,
beyond
the
town
,
past
the
old
ramparts
,
out
on
the
open
road
,
which
seemed
to
glide
away
along
the
dark
plain
,
like
a
stream
.
  
<EOS>
Whither
did
it
flow
?
<EOS>
What
was
the
end
of
it
?
<EOS>
As
he
paused
,
with
some
such
suggestion
within
him
,
looking
over
the
gloomy
flat
where
the
slender
trees
marked
out
the
way
,
again
that
flight
of
Death
came
rushing
up
,
again
went
on
,
impetuous
and
resistless
,
again
was
nothing
but
a
horror
in
his
mind
,
dark
as
the
scene
and
undefined
as
its
remotest
verge
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
no
wind
;
there
was
no
passing
shadow
on
the
deep
shade
of
the
night
;
there
was
no
noise
.
<EOS>
The
city
lay
behind
him
,
lighted
here
and
there
,
and
starry
worlds
were
hidden
by
the
masonry
of
spire
and
roof
that
hardly
made
out
any
shapes
against
the
sky
.
<EOS>
Dark
and
lonely
distance
lay
around
him
everywhere
,
and
the
clocks
were
faintly
striking
two
.
  
<EOS>
He
went
forward
for
what
appeared
a
long
time
,
and
a
long
way
;
often
stopping
to
listen
.
<EOS>
At
last
the
ringing
of
horses
'
bells
greeted
his
anxious
ears
.
<EOS>
Now
softer
,
and
now
louder
,
now
inaudible
,
now
ringing
very
slowly
over
bad
ground
,
now
brisk
and
merry
,
it
came
on
;
until
with
a
loud
shouting
and
lashing
,
a
shadowy
postillion
muffled
to
the
eyes
,
checked
his
four
struggling
horses
at
his
side
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
goes
there
!
<EOS>
Monsieur
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Monsieur
has
walked
a
long
way
in
the
dark
midnight
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
matter
.
<EOS>
Every
one
to
his
taste
.
<EOS>
Were
there
any
other
horses
ordered
at
the
Post
-
house
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
thousand
devils
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
pardons
!
<EOS>
other
horses
?
<EOS>
at
this
hour
?
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Listen
,
my
friend
.
<EOS>
I
am
much
hurried
.
<EOS>
Let
us
see
how
fast
we
can
travel
!
<EOS>
The
faster
,
the
more
money
there
will
be
to
drink
.
<EOS>
Off
we
go
then
!
<EOS>
Quick
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
<EOS>
whoop
!
<EOS>
Halloa
!
<EOS>
Hi
!
"
<EOS>
Away
,
at
a
gallop
,
over
the
black
landscape
,
scattering
the
dust
and
dirt
like
spray
!
  
<EOS>
The
clatter
and
commotion
echoed
to
the
hurry
and
discordance
of
the
fugitive
's
ideas
.
<EOS>
Nothing
clear
without
,
and
nothing
clear
within
.
<EOS>
Objects
flitting
past
,
merging
into
one
another
,
dimly
descried
,
confusedly
lost
sight
of
,
gone!Beyond
the
changing
scraps
of
fence
and
cottage
immediately
upon
the
road
,
a
lowering
waste
.
<EOS>
Beyond
the
shifting
images
that
rose
up
in
his
mind
and
vanished
as
they
showed
themselves
,
a
black
expanse
of
dread
and
rage
and
baffled
villany
.
<EOS>
Occasionally
,
a
sigh
of
mountain
air
came
from
the
distant
Jura
,
fading
along
the
plain
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
that
rush
which
was
so
furious
and
horrible
,
again
came
sweeping
through
his
fancy
,
passed
away
,
and
left
a
chill
upon
his
blood
.
  
<EOS>
The
lamps
,
gleaming
on
the
medley
of
horses
'
heads
,
jumbled
with
the
shadowy
driver
,
and
the
fluttering
of
his
cloak
,
made
a
thousand
indistinct
shapes
,
answering
to
his
thoughts
.
<EOS>
Shadows
of
familiar
people
,
stooping
at
their
desks
and
books
,
in
their
remembered
attitudes
;
strange
apparitions
of
the
man
whom
he
was
flying
from
,
or
of
Edith
;
repetitions
in
the
ringing
bells
and
rolling
wheels
,
of
words
that
had
been
spoken
;
confusions
of
time
and
place
,
making
last
night
a
month
ago
,
a
month
ago
last
night
---
home
now
distant
beyond
hope
,
now
instantly
accessible
;
commotion
,
discord
,
hurry
,
darkness
,
and
confusion
in
his
mind
,
and
all
around
him
.
<EOS>
---
Hallo
!
<EOS>
Hi
!
<EOS>
away
at
a
gallop
over
the
black
landscape
;
dust
and
dirt
flying
like
spray
,
the
smoking
horses
snorting
and
plunging
as
if
each
of
them
were
ridden
by
a
demon
,
away
in
a
frantic
triumph
on
the
dark
road
---
whither
?
  
<EOS>
Again
the
nameless
shock
comes
speeding
up
,
and
as
it
passes
,
the
bells
ring
in
his
ears
"
whither
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
wheels
roar
in
his
ears
"
whither
?
"
<EOS>
All
the
noise
and
rattle
shapes
itself
into
that
cry
.
<EOS>
The
lights
and
shadows
dance
upon
the
horses
'
heads
like
imps
.
<EOS>
No
stopping
now
<EOS>
:
no
slackening
!
<EOS>
On
,
on
!
<EOS>
Away
with
him
upon
the
dark
road
wildly
!
  
<EOS>
He
could
not
think
to
any
purpose
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
separate
one
subject
of
reflection
from
another
,
sufficiently
to
dwell
upon
it
,
by
itself
,
for
a
minute
at
a
time
.
<EOS>
The
crash
of
his
project
for
the
gaining
of
a
voluptuous
compensation
for
past
restraint
;
the
overthrow
of
his
treachery
to
one
who
had
been
true
and
generous
to
him
,
but
whose
least
proud
word
and
look
he
had
treasured
up
,
at
interest
,
for
years
---
for
false
and
subtle
men
will
always
secretly
despise
and
dislike
the
object
upon
which
they
fawn
,
and
always
resent
the
payment
and
receipt
of
homage
that
they
know
to
be
worthless
;
these
were
the
themes
uppermost
in
his
mind
.
<EOS>
A
lurking
rage
against
the
woman
who
had
so
entrapped
him
and
avenged
herself
was
always
there
;
crude
and
misshapen
schemes
of
retaliation
upon
her
,
floated
in
his
brain
;
but
nothing
was
distinct
.
<EOS>
A
hurry
and
contradiction
pervaded
all
his
thoughts
.
<EOS>
Even
while
he
was
so
busy
with
this
fevered
,
ineffectual
thinking
,
his
one
constant
idea
was
,
that
he
would
postpone
reflection
until
some
indefinite
time
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
the
old
days
before
the
second
marriage
rose
up
in
his
remembrance
.
<EOS>
He
thought
how
jealous
he
had
been
of
the
boy
,
how
jealous
he
had
been
of
the
girl
,
how
artfully
he
had
kept
intruders
at
a
distance
,
and
drawn
a
circle
round
his
dupe
that
none
but
himself
should
cross
;
and
then
he
thought
,
had
he
done
all
this
to
be
flying
now
,
like
a
scared
thief
,
from
only
the
poor
dupe
?
  
<EOS>
He
could
have
laid
hands
upon
himself
for
his
cowardice
,
but
it
was
the
very
shadow
of
his
defeat
,
and
could
not
be
separated
from
it
.
<EOS>
To
have
his
confidence
in
his
own
knavery
so
shattered
at
a
blow
---
to
be
within
his
own
knowledge
such
a
miserable
tool
---
was
like
being
paralysed
.
<EOS>
With
an
impotent
ferocity
he
raged
at
Edith
,
and
hated
Mr
Dombey
and
hated
himself
,
but
still
he
fled
,
and
could
do
nothing
else
.
  
<EOS>
Again
and
again
he
listened
for
the
sound
of
wheels
behind
.
<EOS>
Again
and
again
his
fancy
heard
it
,
coming
on
louder
and
louder
.
<EOS>
At
last
he
was
so
persuaded
of
this
,
that
he
cried
out
,
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>
preferring
even
the
loss
of
ground
to
such
uncertainty
.
  
<EOS>
The
word
soon
brought
carriage
,
horses
,
driver
,
all
in
a
heap
together
,
across
the
road
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
devil
!
"
cried
the
driver
,
looking
over
his
shoulder
,
"
what
's
the
matter
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
<EOS>
What
's
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
noise
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
Heaven
,
be
quiet
,
cursed
brigand
!
"
to
a
horse
who
shook
his
bells
.
<EOS>
"
What
noise
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Behind
.
<EOS>
Is
it
not
another
carriage
at
a
gallop
?
<EOS>
There!what
's
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miscreant
with
a
pig
's
head
,
stand
still
!
"
<EOS>
to
another
horse
,
who
bit
another
,
who
frightened
the
other
two
,
who
plunged
and
backed
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
coming
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nothing
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
nothing
but
the
day
yonder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
I
hear
nothing
now
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
Go
on
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
entangled
equipage
,
half
hidden
in
the
reeking
cloud
from
the
horses
,
goes
on
slowly
at
first
,
for
the
driver
,
checked
unnecessarily
in
his
progress
,
sulkily
takes
out
a
pocket
-
knife
,
and
puts
a
new
lash
to
his
whip
.
<EOS>
Then
"
Hallo
,
whoop
!
<EOS>
Hallo
,
hi
!
"
<EOS>
Away
once
more
,
savagely
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
the
stars
faded
,
and
<EOS>
the
day
glimmered
,
and
standing
in
the
carriage
,
looking
back
,
he
could
discern
the
track
by
which
he
had
come
,
and
see
that
there
was
no
traveller
within
view
,
on
all
the
heavy
expanse
.
<EOS>
And
soon
it
was
broad
day
,
and
the
sun
began
to
shine
on
cornfields
and
vineyards
;
and
solitary
labourers
,
risen
from
little
temporary
huts
by
heaps
of
stones
upon
the
road
,
were
,
here
and
there
,
at
work
repairing
the
highway
,
or
eating
bread
.
<EOS>
By
and
by
,
there
were
peasants
going
to
their
daily
labour
,
or
to
market
,
or
lounging
at
the
doors
of
poor
cottages
,
gazing
idly
at
him
as
he
passed
.
<EOS>
An
then
there
was
a
postyard
,
ankle
-
deep
in
mud
,
with
steaming
dunghills
and
vast
outhouses
half
ruined
;
and
looking
on
this
dainty
prospect
,
an
immense
,
old
shadeless
,
glaring
,
stone
chateau
,
with
half
its
windows
blinded
,
and
green
damp
crawling
lazily
over
it
,
from
the
balustraded
terrace
to
the
taper
tips
of
the
extinguishers
upon
the
turrets
.
  
<EOS>
Gathered
up
moodily
in
a
corner
of
the
carriage
,
and
only
intent
on
going
fast
---
except
when
he
stood
up
,
for
a
mile
together
,
and
looked
back
;
which
he
would
do
whenever
there
was
a
piece
of
open
country
---
he
went
on
,
still
postponing
thought
indefinitely
,
and
still
always
tormented
with
thinking
to
no
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
Shame
,
disappointment
,
and
discomfiture
gnawed
at
his
heart
;
a
constant
apprehension
of
being
overtaken
,
or
met
---
for
he
was
groundlessly
afraid
even
of
travellers
,
who
came
towards
him
by
the
way
he
was
going
---
oppressed
him
heavily
.
<EOS>
The
same
intolerable
awe
and
dread
that
had
come
upon
his
in
the
night
,
returned
unweakened
in
the
day
.
<EOS>
The
monotonous
ringing
of
the
bells
and
tramping
of
the
horses
;
the
monotony
of
his
anxiety
,
and
useless
rage
;
the
monotonous
wheel
of
fear
,
regret
,
and
passion
,
he
kept
turning
round
and
round
;
made
the
journey
like
a
vision
,
in
which
nothing
was
quite
real
but
his
own
torment
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
vision
of
long
roads
;
that
stretched
away
to
an
horizon
,
always
receding
and
never
gained
;
of
ill
-
paved
towns
,
up
hill
and
down
,
where
faces
came
to
dark
doors
and
ill
-
glazed
windows
,
and
where
rows
of
mud
-
bespattered
cows
and
oxen
were
tied
up
for
sale
in
the
long
narrow
streets
,
butting
and
lowing
,
and
receiving
blows
on
their
blunt
heads
from
bludgeons
that
might
have
beaten
them
in
;
of
bridges
,
crosses
,
churches
,
postyards
,
new
horses
being
put
in
against
their
wills
,
and
the
horses
of
the
last
stage
reeking
,
panting
,
and
laying
their
drooping
heads
together
dolefully
at
stable
doors
;
of
little
cemeteries
with
black
crosses
settled
sideways
in
the
graves
,
and
withered
wreaths
upon
them
dropping
away
;
again
of
long
,
long
roads
,
dragging
themselves
out
,
up
hill
and
down
,
to
the
treacherous
horizon
.
  
<EOS>
Of
morning
,
noon
,
and
sunset
;
night
,
and
the
rising
of
an
early
moon
.
<EOS>
Of
long
roads
temporarily
left
behind
,
and
a
rough
pavement
reached
;
of
battering
and
clattering
over
it
,
and
looking
up
,
among
house
-
roofs
,
at
a
great
church
-
tower
;
of
getting
out
and
eating
hastily
,
and
drinking
draughts
of
wine
that
had
no
cheering
influence
;
of
coming
forth
afoot
,
among
a
host
of
beggars
---
blind
men
with
quivering
eyelids
,
led
by
old
women
holding
candles
to
their
faces
;
idiot
girls
;
the
lame
,
the
epileptic
,
and
the
palsied
---
of
passing
through
the
clamour
,
and
looking
from
his
seat
at
the
upturned
countenances
and
outstretched
hands
,
with
a
hurried
dread
of
recognising
some
pursuer
pressing
forward
---
of
galloping
away
again
,
upon
the
long
,
long
road
,
gathered
up
,
dull
and
stunned
,
in
his
corner
,
or
rising
to
see
where
the
moon
shone
faintly
on
a
patch
of
the
same
endless
road
miles
away
,
or
looking
back
to
see
who
followed
.
  
<EOS>
Of
never
sleeping
,
but
sometimes
dozing
with
unclosed
eyes
,
and
springing
up
with
a
start
,
and
a
reply
aloud
to
an
imaginary
voice
.
<EOS>
Of
cursing
himself
for
being
there
,
for
having
fled
,
for
having
let
her
go
,
for
not
having
confronted
and
defied
him
.
<EOS>
Of
having
a
deadly
quarrel
with
the
whole
world
,
but
chiefly
with
himself
.
<EOS>
Of
blighting
everything
with
his
black
mood
as
he
was
carried
on
and
away
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
fevered
vision
of
things
past
and
present
<EOS>
all
confounded
together
;
of
his
life
and
journey
blended
into
one
.
<EOS>
Of
being
madly
hurried
somewhere
,
whither
he
must
go
.
<EOS>
Of
old
scenes
starting
up
among
the
novelties
through
which
he
travelled
.
<EOS>
Of
musing
and
brooding
over
what
was
past
and
distant
,
and
seeming
to
take
no
notice
of
the
actual
objects
he
encountered
,
but
with
a
wearisome
exhausting
consciousness
of
being
bewildered
by
them
,
and
having
their
images
all
crowded
in
his
hot
brain
after
they
were
gone
.
  
<EOS>
A
vision
of
change
upon
change
,
and
still
the
same
monotony
of
bells
and
wheels
,
and
horses
'
feet
,
and
no
rest
.
<EOS>
Of
town
and
country
,
postyards
,
horses
,
drivers
,
hill
and
valley
,
light
and
darkness
,
road
and
pavement
,
height
and
hollow
,
wet
weather
and
dry
,
and
still
the
same
monotony
of
bells
and
wheels
,
and
horses
'
feet
,
and
no
rest
.
<EOS>
A
vision
of
tending
on
at
last
,
towards
the
distant
capital
,
by
busier
roads
,
and
sweeping
round
,
by
old
cathedrals
,
and
dashing
through
small
towns
and
villages
,
less
thinly
scattered
on
the
road
than
formerly
,
and
sitting
shrouded
in
his
corner
,
with
his
cloak
up
to
his
face
,
as
people
passing
by
looked
at
him
.
  
<EOS>
Of
rolling
on
and
on
,
always
postponing
thought
,
and
always
racked
with
thinking
;
of
being
unable
to
reckon
up
the
hours
he
had
been
upon
the
road
,
or
to
comprehend
the
points
of
time
and
place
in
his
journey
.
<EOS>
Of
being
parched
and
giddy
,
and
half
mad
.
<EOS>
Of
pressing
on
,
in
spite
of
all
,
as
if
he
could
not
stop
,
and
coming
into
Paris
,
where
the
turbid
river
held
its
swift
course
undisturbed
,
between
two
brawling
streams
of
life
and
motion
.
  
<EOS>
A
troubled
vision
,
then
,
of
bridges
,
quays
,
interminable
streets
;
of
wine
-
shops
,
water
-
carriers
,
great
crowds
of
people
,
soldiers
,
coaches
,
military
drums
,
arcades
.
<EOS>
Of
the
monotony
of
bells
and
wheels
and
horses
'
feet
being
at
length
lost
in
the
universal
din
and
uproar
.
<EOS>
Of
the
gradual
subsidence
of
that
noise
as
he
passed
out
in
another
carriage
by
a
different
barrier
from
that
by
which
he
had
entered
.
<EOS>
Of
the
restoration
,
as
he
travelled
on
towards
the
sea
-
coast
,
of
the
monotony
of
bells
and
wheels
,
and
horses
'
feet
,
and
no
rest
.
  
<EOS>
Of
sunset
once
again
,
and
nightfall
.
<EOS>
Of
long
roads
again
,
and
dead
of
night
,
and
feeble
lights
in
windows
by
the
road
-
side
;
and
still
the
old
monotony
of
bells
and
wheels
,
and
horses'feet
,
and
no
rest
.
<EOS>
Of
dawn
,
and
daybreak
,
and
the
rising
of
the
sun
.
<EOS>
Of
toiling
slowly
up
a
hill
,
and
feeling
on
its
top
the
fresh
sea
-
breeze
;
and
seeing
the
morning
light
upon
the
edges
of
the
distant
waves
.
<EOS>
Of
coming
down
into
a
harbour
when
the
tide
was
at
its
full
,
and
seeing
fishing
-
boats
float
on
,
and
glad
women
and
children
waiting
for
them
.
<EOS>
Of
nets
and
seamen
's
clothes
spread
out
to
dry
upon
the
shore
;
of
busy
sailors
,
and
their
voices
high
among
ships
'
masts
and
rigging
;
of
the
buoyancy
and
brightness
of
the
water
,
and
the
universal
sparkling
.
  
<EOS>
Of
receding
from
the
coast
,
and
looking
back
upon
it
from
the
deck
when
it
was
a
haze
upon
the
water
,
with
here
<EOS>
and
there
a
little
opening
of
bright
land
where
the
Sun
struck
.
<EOS>
Of
the
swell
,
and
flash
,
and
murmur
of
the
calm
sea
.
<EOS>
Of
another
grey
line
on
the
ocean
,
on
the
vessel
's
track
,
fast
growing
clearer
and
higher
.
<EOS>
Of
cliffs
and
buildings
,
and
a
windmill
,
and
a
church
,
becoming
more
and
more
visible
upon
it
.
<EOS>
Of
steaming
on
at
last
into
smooth
water
,
and
mooring
to
a
pier
whence
groups
of
people
looked
down
,
greeting
friends
on
board
.
<EOS>
Of
disembarking
,
passing
among
them
quickly
,
shunning
every
one
;
and
of
being
at
last
again
in
England
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
thought
,
in
his
dream
,
of
going
down
into
a
remote
country
-
place
he
knew
,
and
lying
quiet
there
,
while
he
secretly
informed
himself
of
what
transpired
,
and
determined
how
to
act
.
<EOS>
Still
in
the
same
stunned
condition
,
he
remembered
a
certain
station
on
the
railway
,
where
he
would
have
to
branch
off
to
his
place
of
destination
,
and
where
there
was
a
quiet
Inn
.
<EOS>
Here
,
he
indistinctly
resolved
to
tarry
and
rest
.
  
<EOS>
With
this
purpose
he
slunk
into
a
railway
carriage
as
quickly
as
he
could
,
and
lying
there
wrapped
in
his
cloak
as
if
he
were
asleep
,
was
soon
borne
far
away
from
the
sea
,
and
deep
into
the
inland
green
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
his
destination
he
looked
out
,
and
surveyed
it
carefully
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
mistaken
in
his
impression
of
the
place
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
retired
spot
,
on
the
borders
of
a
little
wood
.
<EOS>
Only
one
house
,
newly
-
built
or
altered
for
the
purpose
,
stood
there
,
<EOS>
surrounded
by
its
neat
garden
;
the
small
town
that
was
nearest
,
was
some
miles
away
.
<EOS>
Here
he
alighted
then
;
and
going
straight
into
the
tavern
,
unobserved
by
any
one
,
secured
two
rooms
upstairs
communicating
with
each
other
,
sufficiently
retired
.
  
<EOS>
His
object
was
to
rest
,
and
recover
the
command
of
himself
,
and
the
balance
of
his
mind
.
<EOS>
Imbecile
discomfiture
and
rage
---
<EOS>
so
that
,
as
he
walked
about
his
room
,
he
ground
his
teeth
---
had
complete
possession
of
him
.
<EOS>
His
thoughts
,
not
to
be
stopped
or
directed
,
still
wandered
where
they
would
,
and
dragged
him
after
them
.
<EOS>
He
was
stupefied
,
and
he
was
wearied
to
death
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
as
if
there
were
a
curse
upon
him
that
he
should
never
rest
again
,
his
drowsy
senses
would
not
lose
their
consciousness
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
more
influence
with
them
in
this
regard
,
than
if
they
had
been
another
man
's
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
they
forced
him
to
take
note
of
present
sounds
and
objects
,
but
that
they
would
not
be
diverted
from
the
whole
hurried
vision
of
his
journey
.
<EOS>
It
was
constantly
before
him
all
at
once
.
<EOS>
She
stood
there
,
with
her
dark
disdainful
eyes
again
upon
him
;
and
he
was
riding
on
nevertheless
,
through
town
and
country
,
light
and
darkness
,
wet
weather
and
dry
,
over
road
and
pavement
,
hill
and
valley
,
height
and
hollow
,
jaded
and
scared
by
the
monotony
of
bells
and
wheels
,
and
horses
'
feet
,
and
no
rest
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
day
is
this
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
of
the
waiter
,
who
was
making
preparations
for
his
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Day
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
Wednesday
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wednesday
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
No
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Thursday
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
forgot
.
<EOS>
How
goes
the
time
?
<EOS>
My
watch
is
unwound
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wants
a
few
minutes
of
five
o'clock
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Been
travelling
a
long
time
,
Sir
,
perhaps
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
"
By
rail
,
Sir
?
"
  
"
Yes
.
"
  
"
Very
confusing
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Not
much
in
the
habit
of
travelling
by
rail
myself
,
Sir
,
<EOS>
but
gentlemen
frequently
say
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
many
gentlemen
come
here
?
"
  
"
Pretty
well
,
Sir
,
in
general
.
<EOS>
Nobody
here
at
present
.
<EOS>
Rather
slack
just
now
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Everything
is
slack
,
Sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
made
no
answer
;
but
had
risen
into
a
sitting
posture
on
the
sofa
where
he
had
been
lying
,
and
leaned
forward
with
an
arm
on
each
knee
,
staring
at
the
ground
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
master
his
own
attention
for
a
minute
together
.
<EOS>
It
rushed
away
where
it
would
,
but
it
never
,
for
an
instant
,
lost
itself
in
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
He
drank
a
quantity
of
wine
after
dinner
,
in
vain
.
<EOS>
No
such
artificial
means
would
bring
sleep
to
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
His
thoughts
,
more
incoherent
,
dragged
him
more
unmercifully
after
them
---
as
if
a
wretch
,
condemned
to
such
expiation
,
were
drawn
at
the
heels
of
wild
horses
.
<EOS>
No
oblivion
,
and
no
rest
.
  
<EOS>
How
long
he
sat
,
drinking
and
brooding
,
and
being
dragged
in
imagination
hither
and
thither
,
no
one
could
have
told
less
correctly
than
he
.
<EOS>
But
he
knew
that
he
had
been
sitting
a
long
time
by
candle
-
light
,
when
he
started
up
and
listened
,
in
a
sudden
terror
.
  
<EOS>
For
now
,
indeed
,
it
was
no
fancy
.
<EOS>
The
ground
shook
,
the
house
rattled
,
the
fierce
impetuous
rush
was
in
the
air
!
<EOS>
He
felt
it
come
up
,
and
go
darting
by
;
and
even
when
he
had
hurried
to
the
window
,
and
saw
what
it
was
,
he
stood
,
shrinking
from
it
,
as
if
it
were
not
safe
to
look
.
  
<EOS>
A
curse
upon
the
fiery
devil
,
thundering
along
so
smoothly
,
tracked
through
the
distant
valley
by
a
glare
of
light
and
lurid
smoke
,
and
gone
!
<EOS>
He
felt
as
if
he
had
been
plucked
out
of
its
path
,
and
saved
from
being
torn
asunder
.
<EOS>
It
made
him
shrink
and
shudder
even
now
,
when
its
faintest
hum
was
hushed
,
and
when
the
lines
of
iron
road
he
could
trace
in
the
moonlight
,
running
to
a
point
,
were
as
empty
and
as
silent
as
a
desert
.
  
<EOS>
Unable
to
rest
,
and
irresistibly
attracted
<EOS>
---
or
he
thought
so
---
to
this
road
,
he
went
out
and
lounged
on
the
brink
of
it
,
marking
the
way
the
train
had
gone
,
by
the
yet
smoking
cinders
that
were
lying
in
its
track
.
<EOS>
After
a
lounge
of
some
half
hour
in
the
direction
by
which
it
had
disappeared
,
he
turned
and
walked
the
other
way
---
still
keeping
to
the
brink
of
the
road
---
past
the
inn
garden
,
and
a
long
way
down
;
looking
curiously
at
the
bridges
,
signals
,
lamps
,
and
wondering
when
another
Devil
would
come
by
.
  
<EOS>
A
trembling
of
the
ground
,
and
quick
vibration
in
his
ears
;
a
distant
shriek
;
a
dull
light
advancing
,
quickly
changed
to
two
red
eyes
,
and
a
fierce
fire
,
dropping
glowing
coals
;
an
irresistible
bearing
on
of
a
great
roaring
and
dilating
mass
;
a
high
wind
,
and
a
rattle
---
another
come
and
gone
,
and
he
holding
to
a
gate
,
as
if
to
save
himself
!
  
<EOS>
He
waited
for
another
,
and
for
another
.
<EOS>
He
walked
back
to
his
former
point
,
and
back
again
to
that
,
and
still
,
through
the
wearisome
vision
of
his
journey
,
looked
for
these
approaching
monsters
.
<EOS>
He
loitered
about
the
station
,
waiting
until
one
should
stay
to
call
there
;
and
when
one
did
,
and
was
detached
for
water
,
he
stood
parallel
with
it
,
watching
its
heavy
wheels
and
brazen
front
,
and
thinking
what
a
cruel
power
and
might
it
had
.
<EOS>
Ugh
!
<EOS>
To
see
the
great
wheels
slowly
turning
,
and
to
think
of
being
run
down
and
crushed
!
  
<EOS>
Disordered
with
wine
and
want
of
rest
<EOS>
---
that
want
which
nothing
,
although
he
was
so
weary
,
would
appease
---
<EOS>
these
ideas
and
objects
assumed
a
diseased
importance
in
his
thoughts
.
<EOS>
When
he
went
back
to
his
room
,
which
was
not
until
near
midnight
,
they
still
haunted
him
,
and
he
sat
listening
for
the
coming
of
another
.
  
<EOS>
So
in
his
bed
,
whither
he
repaired
with
no
hope
of
sleep
.
<EOS>
He
still
lay
listening
;
and
when
he
felt
the
trembling
and
vibration
,
got
up
and
went
to
the
window
,
to
watch
(
as
he
could
from
its
position
)
the
dull
light
changing
to
the
two
red
eyes
,
and
the
fierce
fire
dropping
glowing
coals
,
and
the
rush
of
the
giant
as
it
fled
past
,
and
the
track
of
glare
and
smoke
along
the
valley
.
<EOS>
Then
he
would
glance
in
the
direction
by
which
he
intended
to
depart
at
sunrise
,
as
there
was
no
rest
for
him
there
;
and
would
lie
down
again
,
to
be
troubled
by
the
vision
of
his
journey
,
and
the
old
monotony
of
bells
and
wheels
and
horses
'
feet
,
until
another
came
.
<EOS>
This
lasted
all
night
.
<EOS>
So
far
from
resuming
the
mastery
of
himself
,
he
seemed
,
if
possible
,
to
lose
it
more
and
more
,
as
the
night
crept
on
.
<EOS>
When
the
dawn
appeared
,
he
was
still
tormented
with
thinking
,
still
postponing
thought
until
he
should
be
in
a
better
state
;
the
past
,
present
,
and
future
,
all
floated
confusedly
before
him
,
and
he
had
lost
all
power
of
looking
steadily
at
any
one
of
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
what
time
,
"
he
asked
the
man
who
had
waited
on
him
over
-
night
,
now
entering
with
a
candle
,
"
do
I
leave
here
,
did
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
About
a
quarter
after
four
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Express
comes
through
at
four
,
Sir
.
---
<EOS>
It
do
n't
stop
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
passed
his
hand
across
his
throbbing
head
,
and
looked
at
his
watch
.
<EOS>
Nearly
half
-
past
three
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nobody
going
with
you
,
Sir
,
probably
,
"
observed
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Two
gentlemen
here
,
Sir
,
but
they
're
waiting
for
the
train
to
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
said
there
was
nobody
here
,
"
said
Carker
,
turning
upon
him
with
the
ghost
of
his
old
smile
,
when
he
was
angry
or
suspicious
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
then
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Two
gentlemen
came
in
the
night
by
the
short
train
that
stops
here
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Warm
water
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
and
take
away
the
candle
.
<EOS>
There
's
day
enough
for
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Having
thrown
himself
upon
the
bed
,
half
-
dressed
,
he
was
at
the
window
as
the
man
left
the
room
.
<EOS>
The
cold
light
of
morning
had
succeeded
to
night
,
and
there
was
already
,
in
the
sky
,
the
red
suffusion
of
the
coming
sun
.
<EOS>
He
bathed
his
head
and
face
with
water
---
there
was
no
cooling
influence
in
it
for
him
---
hurriedly
put
on
his
clothes
,
paid
what
he
owed
,
and
went
out
.
  
<EOS>
The
air
struck
chill
and
comfortless
,
as
it
breathed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
heavy
dew
;
and
,
hot
as
he
was
,
it
made
him
shiver
.
<EOS>
After
a
glance
at
the
place
where
he
had
walked
last
night
,
and
at
the
signal
-
lights
burning
feebly
in
the
morning
,
and
bereft
of
their
significance
,
he
turned
to
where
the
sun
was
rising
,
and
beheld
it
,
in
its
glory
,
as
it
broke
upon
the
scene
.
  
<EOS>
So
awful
,
so
transcendent
in
its
beauty
,
so
divinely
solemn
.
<EOS>
As
he
cast
his
faded
eyes
upon
it
,
where
it
rose
,
tranquil
and
serene
,
unmoved
by
all
the
wrong
and
wickedness
on
which
its
beams
had
shone
since
the
beginning
of
the
world
,
who
shall
say
that
some
weak
sense
of
virtue
upon
Earth
,
and
its
reward
in
Heaven
,
did
not
manifest
itself
,
even
to
him
?
<EOS>
If
ever
he
remembered
sister
or
brother
with
a
touch
of
tenderness
and
remorse
,
who
shall
say
it
was
not
then
?
  
<EOS>
He
needed
some
such
touch
then
.
<EOS>
Death
was
on
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
marked
off
from
the
living
world
,
and
going
down
into
his
grave
.
  
<EOS>
He
paid
the
money
for
his
journey
to
the
country
-
place
he
had
thought
of
;
and
was
walking
to
and
fro
,
alone
,
looking
along
the
lines
of
iron
,
across
the
valley
in
one
direction
,
and
towards
a
dark
bridge
near
at
hand
in
the
other
;
when
,
turning
in
his
walk
,
where
it
was
bounded
by
one
end
of
the
wooden
stage
on
which
he
paced
up
and
down
,
he
saw
the
man
from
whom
he
had
fled
,
emerging
from
the
door
by
which
he
himself
had
entered
there
.
<EOS>
And
their
eyes
met
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
quick
unsteadiness
of
the
surprise
,
he
staggered
,
and
slipped
on
to
the
road
below
him
.
<EOS>
But
recovering
his
feet
immediately
,
he
stepped
back
a
pace
or
two
upon
that
road
,
to
interpose
some
wider
space
between
them
,
and
looked
at
his
pursuer
,
breathing
short
and
quick
.
  
<EOS>
He
heard
a
shout
---
another
---
saw
the
face
change
from
its
vindictive
passion
to
a
faint
sickness
and
terror
---
felt
the
earth
tremble
---
knew
in
a
moment
that
the
rush
was
come
---
uttered
a
shriek
---
<EOS>
looked
round
---
saw
the
red
eyes
,
bleared
and
dim
,
in
the
daylight
,
close
upon
him
---
was
beaten
down
,
caught
up
,
and
whirled
away
upon
a
jagged
mill
,
that
spun
him
round
and
round
,
and
struck
him
limb
from
limb
,
and
licked
his
stream
of
life
up
with
its
fiery
heat
,
and
cast
his
mutilated
fragments
in
the
air
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
traveller
,
who
had
been
recognised
,
recovered
from
a
swoon
,
he
saw
them
bringing
from
a
distance
something
covered
,
that
lay
heavy
and
still
,
upon
a
board
,
between
four
men
,
and
saw
that
others
drove
some
dogs
away
that
sniffed
upon
the
road
,
and
soaked
his
blood
up
,
with
a
train
of
ashes
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
56
.
<EOS>
Several
People
delighted
,
and
the
Game
Chicken

Toots
and
Captain
Cuttle
heaved

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
She

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Them

loved

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

If

<EOS>
Amen

"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
The
honest
Captain
,
with
his
Heart
's
Delight
in
the
house
,
and
Susan
tending
her
,
was
a
beaming
and
a
happy
man
.
<EOS>
As
the
days
flew
by
,
he
grew
more
beaming
and
more
happy
,
every
day
.
<EOS>
After
some
conferences
with
Susan
(
for
whose

the
Captain
had
a

respect
,
and
whose
valiant

of
herself
on
Mrs
MacStinger
he
could
never
forget
)
,
he
proposed
to
Florence
that
the
daughter
of
the
elderly
lady
who
usually
sat
under
the
blue
umbrella
in
Leadenhall
Market
,
should
,
for
prudential

and

,
be

in
the

of
the

,
by
some
one
who
was
not
unknown
to

,
and
in
whom
they
could

.
<EOS>
Susan
,
being
present
,
then
named
,
in

she

previously

to
the
Captain
,
Mrs
Richards
.
<EOS>
Florence
brightened
at

.
<EOS>
And
Susan
,
setting
off
that
very

to
the
Toodle

,
to
sound
Mrs
Richards
,

in

the

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
This

accomplished
;
from

the
Captain
derived
uncommon

,
as
he
did

done
,
whatever

;

.
<EOS>
This

,
as
Miss

,
and
had
fully

that

had

back
never

.
  
<EOS>
"
As

,
"

"

<EOS>

"

"

Alone
?
<EOS>
and

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,

<EOS>
---
He

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Susan

"
<EOS>
Why

,
Miss

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Because
,
"
said

,
"
I

,
to

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Why
,

,
