!
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper
was
so
much
affected
by
the
quiet
fervour
of
these
words
,
and
simple
,
heartfelt
,
all
-
pervading
earnestness
expressed
in
them
,
and
making
the
speaker
's
face
more
beautiful
and
pure
than
ever
,
that
she
could
only
cling
to
her
again
,
crying
<EOS>
Was
her
little
mistress
really
,
really
going
to
be
married
,
and
pitying
,
caressing
,
and
protecting
her
,
as
she
had
done
before
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
Nipper
,
though
susceptible
of
womanly
weaknesses
,
was
almost
as
capable
of
putting
constraint
upon
herself
as
of
attacking
the
redoubtable
MacStinger
.
<EOS>
From
that
time
,
she
never
returned
to
the
subject
,
but
was
always
cheerful
,
active
,
bustling
,
and
hopeful
.
<EOS>
She
did
,
indeed
,
inform
Mr
Toots
privately
,
that
she
was
only
"
keeping
up
"
for
the
time
,
and
that
when
it
was
all
over
,
and
Miss
Dombey
was
gone
,
she
might
be
expected
to
become
a
spectacle
distressful
;
and
Mr
Toots
did
also
express
that
it
was
his
case
too
,
and
that
they
would
mingle
their
tears
together
;
but
she
never
otherwise
indulged
her
private
feelings
in
the
presence
of
Florence
or
within
the
precincts
of
the
Midshipman
.
  
<EOS>
Limited
and
plain
as
Florence
's
wardrobe
was
---
what
a
contrast
to
that
prepared
for
the
last
marriage
in
which
she
had
taken
part
!
<EOS>
---
there
was
a
good
deal
to
do
in
getting
it
ready
,
and
Susan
Nipper
worked
away
at
her
side
,
all
day
,
with
the
concentrated
zeal
of
fifty
sempstresses
.
<EOS>
The
wonderful
contributions
Captain
Cuttle
would
have
made
to
this
branch
of
the
outfit
,
if
he
had
been
permitted
---
as
pink
parasols
,
tinted
silk
stockings
,
blue
shoes
,
and
other
articles
no
less
necessary
on
shipboard
---
would
occupy
some
space
in
the
recital
.
<EOS>
He
was
induced
,
however
,
by
various
fraudulent
representations
,
to
limit
his
contributions
to
a
workbox
and
dressing
-
case
,
of
each
of
which
he
purchased
the
very
largest
specimen
that
could
be
got
for
money
.
<EOS>
For
ten
days
or
a
fortnight
afterwards
,
he
generally
sat
,
during
the
greater
part
of
the
day
,
gazing
at
these
boxes
;
divided
between
extreme
admiration
of
them
,
and
dejected
misgivings
that
they
were
not
gorgeous
enough
,
and
frequently
diving
out
into
the
street
to
purchase
some
wild
article
that
he
deemed
necessary
to
their
completeness
.
<EOS>
But
his
master
-
stroke
was
,
the
bearing
of
them
both
off
,
suddenly
,
one
morning
,
and
getting
the
two
words
FLORENCE
GAY
engraved
upon
a
brass
heart
inlaid
over
the
lid
of
each
.
<EOS>
After
this
,
he
smoked
four
pipes
successively
in
the
little
parlour
by
himself
,
and
was
discovered
chuckling
,
at
the
expiration
of
as
many
hours
.
  
<EOS>
Walter
was
busy
and
away
all
day
,
but
came
there
every
morning
early
to
see
Florence
,
and
always
passed
the
evening
with
her
.
<EOS>
Florence
never
left
her
high
rooms
but
to
steal
downstairs
to
wait
for
him
when
it
was
his
time
to
come
,
or
,
sheltered
by
his
proud
,
encircling
arm
,
to
bear
him
company
to
the
door
again
,
and
sometimes
peep
into
the
street
.
<EOS>
In
the
twilight
they
were
always
together
.
<EOS>
Oh
blessed
time
!
<EOS>
Oh
wandering
heart
at
rest
!
<EOS>
Oh
deep
,
exhaustless
,
mighty
well
of
love
,
in
which
so
much
was
sunk
!
  
<EOS>
The
cruel
mark
was
on
her
bosom
yet
.
<EOS>
It
rose
against
her
father
with
the
breath
she
drew
,
it
lay
between
her
and
her
lover
when
he
pressed
her
to
his
heart
.
<EOS>
But
she
forgot
it
.
<EOS>
In
the
beating
of
that
heart
for
her
,
and
in
the
beating
of
her
own
for
him
,
all
harsher
music
was
unheard
,
all
stern
unloving
hearts
forgotten
.
<EOS>
Fragile
and
delicate
she
was
,
but
with
a
might
of
love
within
her
that
could
,
and
did
,
create
a
world
to
fly
to
,
and
to
rest
in
,
out
of
his
one
image
.
  
<EOS>
How
often
did
the
great
house
,
and
the
old
days
,
come
before
her
in
the
twilight
time
,
when
she
was
sheltered
by
the
arm
,
so
proud
,
so
fond
,
and
,
<EOS>
creeping
closer
to
him
,
shrunk
within
it
at
the
recollection
!
<EOS>
How
often
,
from
remembering
the
night
when
she
went
down
to
that
room
and
met
the
never
-
to
-
be
-
forgotten
look
,
did
she
raise
her
eyes
to
those
that
watched
her
with
such
loving
earnestness
,
and
weep
with
happiness
in
such
a
refuge
!
<EOS>
The
more
she
clung
to
it
,
the
more
the
dear
dead
child
was
in
her
thoughts
:
<EOS>
but
as
if
the
last
time
she
had
seen
her
father
,
had
been
when
he
was
sleeping
and
she
kissed
his
face
,
she
always
left
him
so
,
and
never
,
in
her
fancy
,
passed
that
hour
.
  
<EOS>
"
Walter
,
dear
,
"
said
Florence
,
one
evening
,
when
it
was
almost
dark
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
Know
what
I
have
been
thinking
to
-
day
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thinking
how
the
time
is
flying
on
,
and
how
soon
we
shall
be
upon
the
sea
,
sweet
Florence
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
that
,
Walter
,
though
I
think
of
that
too
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
thinking
what
a
charge
I
am
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
precious
,
sacred
charge
,
dear
heart
!
<EOS>
Why
Ithink
that
sometimes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
laughing
,
Walter
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
's
much
more
in
your
thoughts
than
mine
.
<EOS>
But
I
mean
a
cost
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
cost
,
my
own
?
"
  
"
In
money
,
dear
.
<EOS>
All
these
preparations
that
Susan
and
I
are
so
busy
with
<EOS>
---
I
have
been
able
to
purchase
very
little
for
myself
.
<EOS>
You
were
poor
before
.
<EOS>
But
how
much
poorer
I
shall
make
you
,
Walter
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
much
richer
,
Florence
!
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
laughed
,
and
shook
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
"
said
Walter
,
"
long
ago
---
before
I
went
to
sea
---
I
had
a
little
purse
presented
to
me
,
dearest
,
which
had
money
in
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
!
"
returned
Florence
,
laughing
sorrowfully
,
"
very
little!Very
little
,
Walter
!
<EOS>
But
,
you
must
not
think
,
"
and
here
she
laid
her
light
hand
on
his
shoulder
,
and
looked
into
his
face
,
"
that
I
regret
to
be
this
burden
on
you
.
<EOS>
No
,
dear
love
,
I
am
glad
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
happy
in
it
.
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
it
otherwise
for
all
the
world
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
I
,
indeed
,
dear
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
<EOS>
but
,
Walter
,
you
can
never
feel
it
as
I
do
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
proud
of
you
!
<EOS>
It
makes
my
heart
swell
with
such
delight
to
know
that
those
who
speak
of
you
must
say
you
married
a
poor
disowned
girl
,
who
had
taken
shelter
here
;
who
had
no
other
home
,
no
other
friends
;
who
had
nothing
---
nothing
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
Walter
,
if
I
could
have
brought
you
millions
,
I
never
could
have
been
so
happy
for
your
sake
,
as
I
am
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
,
dear
Florence
?
are
you
nothing
?
"
<EOS>
he
returned
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
nothing
,
Walter
.
<EOS>
Nothing
but
your
wife
.
<EOS>
"
The
light
hand
stole
about
his
neck
,
and
the
voice
came
nearer
---
nearer
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
nothing
any
more
,
that
is
not
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
earthly
hope
any
more
,
that
is
not
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
dear
to
me
any
more
,
that
is
not
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
well
might
Mr
Toots
leave
the
little
company
that
evening
,
and
twice
go
out
to
correct
his
watch
by
the
Royal
Exchange
,
and
once
to
keep
an
appointment
with
a
banker
which
he
suddenly
remembered
,
and
once
to
take
a
little
turn
to
Aldgate
Pump
and
back
!
  
<EOS>
But
before
he
went
upon
these
expeditions
,
or
indeed
before
he
came
,
and
before
lights
were
brought
,
Walter
said
:
  
"
Florence
,
love
,
the
lading
of
our
ship
is
nearly
finished
,
and
probably
on
the
very
day
of
our
marriage
she
will
drop
down
the
river
.
<EOS>
Shall
we
go
away
that
morning
,
and
stay
in
Kent
until
we
go
on
board
at
Gravesend
within
a
week
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
Walter
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
happy
anywhere
.
<EOS>
But
  
"
Yes
,
my
life
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
that
we
shall
have
no
marriage
party
,
and
that
nobody
will
distinguish
us
by
our
dress
from
other
people
.
<EOS>
As
we
leave
the
same
day
,
will
you
---
will
you
take
me
somewhere
that
morning
,
Walter
---
early
---
before
we
go
to
church
?
"
  
<EOS>
Walter
seemed
to
understand
her
,
as
so
true
a
lover
so
truly
loved
should
,
and
confirmed
his
ready
promise
with
a
kiss
---
with
more
than
one
perhaps
,
or
two
or
three
,
or
five
or
six
;
and
in
the
grave
,
peaceful
evening
,
Florence
was
very
happy
.
  
<EOS>
Then
into
the
quiet
room
came
Susan
Nipper
and
the
candles
:
shortly
afterwards
,
the
tea
,
the
Captain
,
and
the
excursive
Mr
Toots
,
who
,
as
above
mentioned
,
was
frequently
on
the
move
afterwards
,
and
passed
but
a
restless
evening
.
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
was
not
his
habit
:
for
he
generally
got
on
very
well
,
by
dint
of
playing
at
cribbage
with
the
Captain
under
the
advice
and
guidance
of
Miss
Nipper
,
and
distracting
his
mind
with
the
calculations
incidental
to
the
game
;
which
he
found
to
be
a
very
effectual
means
of
utterly
confounding
himself
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
visage
on
these
occasions
presented
one
of
the
finest
examples
of
combination
and
succession
of
expression
ever
observed
.
<EOS>
His
instinctive
delicacy
and
his
chivalrous
feeling
towards
Florence
,
taught
him
that
it
was
not
a
time
for
any
boisterous
jollity
,
or
violent
display
of
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
Certain
floating
reminiscences
of
Lovely
Peg
,
on
the
other
hand
,
were
constantly
struggling
for
a
vent
,
and
urging
the
Captain
to
commit
himself
by
some
irreparable
demonstration
.
<EOS>
Anon
,
his
admiration
of
Florence
and
Walter
---
well
-
matched
,
truly
,
and
full
of
grace
and
interest
in
their
youth
,
and
love
,
and
good
looks
,
as
they
sat
apart
---
would
take
such
complete
possession
of
him
,
that
he
would
lay
down
his
cards
,
and
beam
upon
them
,
dabbing
his
head
all
over
with
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
;
until
warned
,
perhaps
,
by
the
sudden
rushing
forth
of
Mr
Toots
,
that
he
had
unconsciously
been
very
instrumental
,
indeed
,
in
making
that
gentleman
miserable
.
<EOS>
This
reflection
would
make
the
Captain
profoundly
melancholy
,
until
the
return
of
Mr
Toots
;
when
he
would
fall
to
his
cards
again
,
with
many
side
winks
and
nods
,
and
polite
waves
of
his
hook
at
Miss
Nipper
,
importing
that
he
was
n't
going
to
do
so
any
more
.
<EOS>
The
state
that
ensued
on
this
,
was
,
perhaps
,
his
best
;
for
then
,
endeavouring
to
discharge
all
expression
from
his
face
,
he
would
sit
,
staring
round
the
room
,
with
all
these
expressions
conveyed
into
it
at
once
,
and
each
wrestling
with
the
other
.
<EOS>
Delighted
admiration
of
Florence
and
Walter
always
overthrew
the
rest
,
and
remained
victorious
and
undisguised
,
unless
Mr
Toots
made
another
rush
into
the
air
,
and
then
the
Captain
would
sit
,
like
a
remorseful
culprit
,
until
he
came
back
again
,
occasionally
calling
upon
himself
,
in
a
low
reproachful
voice
,
to
"
Stand
by
!
"
or
growling
some
remonstrance
to
"
Ed'ard
<EOS>
Cuttle
,
my
lad
,
"
on
the
want
of
caution
observable
in
his
behaviour
.
  
<EOS>
One
of
Mr
Toots
's
hardest
trials
,
however
,
was
of
his
own
seeking
.
<EOS>
On
the
approach
of
the
Sunday
which
was
to
witness
the
last
of
those
askings
in
church
of
which
the
Captain
had
spoken
,
Mr
Toots
thus
stated
his
feelings
to
Susan
Nipper
.
  
<EOS>
"
Susan
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
I
am
drawn
towards
the
building
.
<EOS>
The
words
which
cut
me
off
from
Miss
Dombey
for
ever
,
will
strike
upon
my
ears
like
a
knell
you
know
,
but
upon
my
word
and
honour
,
I
feel
that
I
must
hear
them
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
will
you
accompany
me
to
-
morrow
,
to
the
sacred
edifice
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper
expressed
her
readiness
to
do
so
,
if
that
would
be
any
satisfaction
to
Mr
Toots
,
but
besought
him
to
abandon
his
idea
of
going
.
  
<EOS>
"
Susan
,
"
returned
Mr
Toots
,
with
much
solemnity
,
"
before
my
whiskers
began
to
be
observed
by
anybody
but
myself
,
I
adored
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
While
yet
a
victim
to
the
thraldom
of
Blimber
,
I
adored
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
When
I
could
no
longer
be
kept
out
of
my
property
,
in
a
legal
point
of
view
,
and
---
and
accordingly
came
into
it
---
I
adored
Miss
Dombey
.
<EOS>
The
banns
which
consign
her
to
Lieutenant
Walters
,
and
me
to
---
to
Gloom
,
you
know
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
after
hesitating
for
a
strong
expression
,
"
may
be
dreadful
,
will
be
dreadful
;
but
I
feel
that
I
should
wish
to
hear
them
spoken
.
<EOS>
I
feel
that
I
should
wish
to
know
that
the
ground
was
certainly
cut
from
under
me
,
and
that
I
had
n't
a
hope
to
cherish
,
or
a
---
or
a
leg
,
in
short
,
to
---
to
go
upon
.
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
Nipper
could
only
commiserate
Mr
Toots
's
unfortunate
condition
,
and
agree
,
under
these
circumstances
,
to
accompany
him
;
which
she
did
next
morning
.
  
<EOS>
The
church
Walter
had
chosen
for
the
purpose
,
was
a
mouldy
old
church
in
a
yard
,
hemmed
in
by
a
labyrinth
of
back
streets
and
courts
,
with
a
little
burying
-
ground
round
it
,
and
itself
buried
in
a
kind
of
vault
,
formed
by
the
neighbouring
houses
,
and
paved
with
echoing
stones
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
dim
,
shabby
pile
,
with
high
old
oaken
pews
,
among
which
about
a
score
of
people
lost
themselves
every
Sunday
;
while
the
clergyman
's
voice
drowsily
resounded
through
the
emptiness
,
and
the
organ
rumbled
and
rolled
as
if
the
church
had
got
the
colic
,
for
want
of
a
congregation
to
keep
the
wind
and
damp
out
.
<EOS>
But
so
far
was
this
city
church
from
languishing
for
the
company
of
other
churches
,
that
spires
were
clustered
round
it
,
as
the
masts
of
shipping
cluster
on
the
river
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
hard
to
count
them
from
its
steeple
-
top
,
they
were
so
many
.
<EOS>
In
almost
every
yard
and
blind
-
place
near
,
there
was
a
church
.
<EOS>
The
confusion
of
bells
when
Susan
and
Mr
Toots
betook
themselves
towards
it
on
the
Sunday
morning
,
was
deafening
.
<EOS>
There
were
twenty
churches
close
together
,
clamouring
for
people
to
come
in
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
stray
sheep
in
question
were
penned
by
a
beadle
in
a
commodious
pew
,
and
,
being
early
,
sat
for
some
time
counting
the
congregation
,
listening
to
the
disappointed
bell
high
up
in
the
tower
,
or
looking
at
a
shabby
little
old
man
in
the
porch
behind
the
screen
,
who
was
ringing
the
same
,
like
the
Bull
in
Cock
Robin
,
with
his
foot
in
a
stirrup
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
,
after
a
lengthened
survey
of
the
large
books
on
the
reading
-
desk
,
whispered
Miss
Nipper
that
he
wondered
where
the
banns
were
kept
,
but
that
young
lady
merely
shook
her
head
and
forward
;
repelling
for
the
time
all
approaches
of
a
temporal
nature
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
,
however
,
appearing
unable
to
keep
his
thoughts
from
the
banns
,
was
evidently
looking
out
for
them
during
the
whole
preliminary
portion
of
the
service
.
<EOS>
As
the
time
for
reading
them
approached
,
the
poor
young
gentleman
manifested
great
anxiety
and
trepidation
,
which
was
not
diminished
by
the
unexpected
apparition
of
the
Captain
in
the
front
row
of
the
gallery
.
<EOS>
When
the
clerk
handed
up
a
list
to
the
clergyman
,
Mr
Toots
,
being
then
seated
,
held
on
by
the
seat
of
the
pew
;
but
when
the
names
of
Walter
Gay
and
Florence
Dombey
were
read
aloud
as
being
in
the
third
and
last
stage
of
that
association
,
he
was
so
entirely
conquered
by
his
feelings
as
to
rush
from
the
church
without
his
hat
,
followed
by
the
beadle
and
pew
-
opener
,
and
two
gentlemen
of
the
medical
profession
,
who
happened
to
be
present
;
of
whom
the
first
-
named
presently
returned
for
that
article
,
informing
Miss
Nipper
in
a
whisper
that
she
was
not
to
make
herself
uneasy
about
the
gentleman
,
as
the
gentleman
said
his
indisposition
was
of
no
consequence
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper
,
feeling
that
the
eyes
of
that
integral
portion
of
Europe
which
lost
itself
weekly
among
the
high
-
backed
pews
,
were
upon
her
,
would
have
been
sufficiently
embarrassed
by
this
incident
,
though
it
had
terminated
here
;
the
more
so
,
as
the
Captain
in
the
front
row
of
the
gallery
,
was
in
a
state
of
unmitigated
consciousness
which
could
hardly
fail
to
express
to
the
congregation
that
he
had
some
mysterious
connexion
with
it
.
<EOS>
But
the
extreme
restlessness
of
Mr
Toots
painfully
increased
and
protracted
the
delicacy
of
her
situation
.
<EOS>
That
young
gentleman
,
incapable
,
in
his
state
of
mind
,
of
remaining
alone
in
the
churchyard
,
a
prey
to
solitary
meditation
,
and
also
desirous
,
no
doubt
,
of
testifying
his
respect
for
the
offices
he
had
in
some
measure
interrupted
,
suddenly
returned
---
not
coming
back
to
the
pew
,
but
stationing
himself
on
a
free
seat
in
the
aisle
,
between
two
elderly
females
who
were
in
the
habit
of
receiving
their
portion
of
a
weekly
dole
of
bread
then
set
forth
on
a
shelf
in
the
porch
.
<EOS>
In
this
conjunction
Mr
Toots
remained
,
greatly
disturbing
the
congregation
,
who
felt
it
impossible
to
avoid
looking
at
him
,
until
his
feelings
overcame
him
again
,
when
he
departed
silently
and
suddenly
.
<EOS>
Not
venturing
to
trust
himself
in
the
church
any
more
,
and
yet
wishing
to
have
some
social
participation
in
what
was
going
on
there
,
Mr
Toots
was
after
this
,
seen
from
time
to
time
,
looking
in
,
with
a
lorn
aspect
,
at
one
or
other
of
the
windows
;
and
as
there
were
several
windows
accessible
to
him
from
without
,
and
as
his
restlessness
was
very
great
,
it
not
only
became
difficult
to
conceive
at
which
window
he
would
appear
next
,
but
likewise
became
necessary
,
as
it
were
,
for
the
whole
congregation
to
speculate
upon
the
chances
of
the
different
windows
,
during
the
comparative
leisure
afforded
them
by
the
sermon
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
's
movements
in
the
churchyard
were
so
eccentric
,
that
he
seemed
generally
to
defeat
all
calculation
,
and
to
appear
,
like
the
conjuror
's
figure
,
where
he
was
least
expected
;
and
the
effect
of
these
mysterious
presentations
was
much
increased
by
its
being
difficult
to
him
to
see
in
,
and
easy
to
everybody
else
to
see
out
:
which
occasioned
his
remaining
,
every
time
,
longer
than
might
have
been
expected
,
with
his
face
close
to
the
glass
,
until
he
all
at
once
became
aware
that
all
eyes
were
upon
him
,
and
vanished
.
  
<EOS>
These
proceedings
on
the
part
of
Mr
Toots
,
and
the
strong
individual
consciousness
of
them
that
was
exhibited
by
the
Captain
,
rendered
Miss
Nipper
's
position
so
responsible
a
one
,
that
she
was
mightily
relieved
by
the
conclusion
of
the
service
;
and
was
hardly
so
affable
to
Mr
Toots
as
usual
,
when
he
informed
her
and
the
Captain
,
on
the
way
back
,
that
now
he
was
sure
he
had
no
hope
,
you
know
,
he
felt
more
comfortable
---
at
least
not
exactly
more
comfortable
,
but
more
comfortably
and
completely
miserable
.
  
<EOS>
Swiftly
now
,
indeed
,
the
time
flew
by
until
it
was
the
evening
before
the
day
appointed
for
the
marriage
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
assembled
in
the
upper
room
at
the
Midshipman
's
,
and
had
no
fear
of
interruption
;
for
there
were
no
lodgers
in
the
house
now
,
and
the
Midshipman
had
it
all
to
himself
.
<EOS>
They
were
grave
and
quiet
in
the
prospect
of
to
-
morrow
,
but
moderately
cheerful
too
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
with
Walter
close
beside
her
,
was
finishing
a
little
piece
of
work
intended
as
a
parting
gift
to
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
playing
cribbage
with
Mr
Toots
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
was
taking
counsel
as
to
his
hand
,
of
Susan
Nipper
.
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper
was
giving
it
,
with
all
due
secrecy
and
circumspection
.
<EOS>
Diogenes
was
listening
,
and
occasionally
breaking
out
into
a
gruff
half
-
smothered
fragment
of
a
bark
,
of
which
he
afterwards
seemed
half
-
ashamed
,
as
if
he
doubted
having
any
reason
for
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Steady
,
steady
!
"
said
the
Captain
to
Diogenes
,
"
<EOS>
what
's
amiss
with
you
?
<EOS>
You
do
n't
seem
easy
in
your
mind
to
-
night
,
my
boy
!
"
  
<EOS>
Diogenes
wagged
his
tail
,
but
pricked
up
his
ears
immediately
afterwards
,
and
gave
utterance
to
another
fragment
of
a
bark
;
for
which
he
apologised
to
the
Captain
,
by
again
wagging
his
tail
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
my
opinion
,
Di
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
looking
thoughtfully
at
his
cards
,
and
stroking
his
chin
with
his
hook
,
"
as
you
have
your
doubts
of
Mrs
Richards
;
but
if
you
're
the
animal
I
take
you
to
be
,
you
'll
think
better
o
'
that
;
for
her
looks
is
her
commission
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Brother
:
"
to
Mr
Toots
:
"
if
so
be
as
you
're
ready
,
heave
ahead
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
spoke
with
all
composure
and
attention
to
the
game
,
but
suddenly
his
cards
dropped
out
of
his
hand
,
his
mouth
and
eyes
opened
wide
,
his
legs
drew
themselves
up
and
stuck
out
in
front
of
his
chair
,
and
he
sat
staring
at
the
door
with
blank
amazement
.
<EOS>
Looking
round
upon
the
company
,
and
seeing
that
none
of
them
observed
him
or
the
cause
of
his
astonishment
,
the
Captain
recovered
himself
with
a
great
gasp
,
struck
the
table
a
tremendous
blow
,
cried
in
a
stentorian
roar
,
"
Sol
Gills
ahoy
!
"
and
tumbled
into
the
arms
of
a
weather
-
beaten
pea
-
coat
that
had
come
with
Polly
into
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
In
another
moment
,
Walter
was
in
the
arms
of
the
weather
-
beaten
pea
-
coat
.
<EOS>
In
another
moment
,
Florence
was
in
the
arms
of
the
weather
-
beaten
pea
-
coat
.
<EOS>
In
another
moment
,
Captain
Cuttle
had
embraced
Mrs
Richards
and
Miss
Nipper
,
and
was
violently
shaking
hands
with
Mr
Toots
,
exclaiming
,
as
he
waved
his
hook
above
his
head
,
"
Hooroar
,
my
lad
,
hooroar
!
"
<EOS>
To
which
Mr
Toots
,
wholly
at
a
loss
to
account
for
these
proceedings
,
replied
with
great
politeness
,
"
Certainly
,
Captain
Gills
,
whatever
you
think
proper
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
weather
-
beaten
pea
-
coat
,
and
a
no
less
weather
-
beaten
cap
and
comforter
belonging
to
it
,
turned
from
the
Captain
and
from
Florence
back
to
Walter
,
and
sounds
came
from
the
weather
-
beaten
pea
-
coat
,
cap
,
and
comforter
,
as
of
an
old
man
sobbing
underneath
them
;
while
the
shaggy
sleeves
clasped
Walter
tight
.
<EOS>
During
this
pause
,
there
was
an
universal
silence
,
and
the
Captain
polished
his
nose
with
great
diligence
.
<EOS>
But
when
the
pea
-
coat
,
cap
,
and
comforter
lifted
themselves
up
again
,
Florence
gently
moved
towards
them
;
and
she
and
Walter
taking
them
off
,
disclosed
the
old
Instrument
-
maker
,
a
little
thinner
and
more
careworn
than
of
old
,
in
his
old
Welsh
wig
and
his
old
coffee
-
coloured
coat
and
basket
buttons
,
with
his
old
infallible
chronometer
ticking
away
in
his
pocket
.
  
<EOS>
"
Chock
full
o
'
science
,
"
said
the
radiant
Captain
,
"
as
ever
he
was
!
<EOS>
Sol
Gills
,
Sol
Gills
,
what
have
you
been
up
to
,
for
this
many
a
long
day
,
my
ould
boy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
half
blind
,
Ned
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
and
almost
deaf
and
dumb
with
joy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
His
wery
woice
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
looking
round
with
an
exultation
to
which
even
his
face
could
hardly
render

---
"
his
wery
woice
as
chock
full
o
'
science
as
ever
it
was
!
<EOS>
Sol
Gills
,
lay
to
,
my
lad
,
upon
your
own
wines
and
fig
-
trees
,
like
a
taut
ould
patriark
as
you
are
,
and
overhaul
them
there
<EOS>
adwentures
o
'
yourn
,
in
your
own
formilior
woice
.
'
<EOS>
Tis
the
woice
,
said
the
Captain
,
impressively
,
and
announcing

with

,
"
of
the
sluggard
,
I
heerd
him
complain
,
you
have
woke
me
too
soon
,
I
must
slumber
again
.
<EOS>
Scatter
his
ene
-
mies
,
and
make
'em
fall
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
sat
down
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
had
happily
expressed
the
feeling
of
everybody
present
,
and
immediately
rose
again
to
present
Mr
Toots
,
who
was
much
disconcerted
by
the
arrival
of
anybody
,
appearing
to
prefer
a
claim
to
the
name
of
Gills
.
  
<EOS>
"
Although
,
"
stammered
Mr
Toots
,
"
I
had
not
the
pleasure
of
your
acquaintance
,
Sir
,
before
you
were
---
you
were
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
Lost
to
sight
,
to
memory
dear
,
"
suggested
the
Captain
,
in
a
low
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Exactly
so
,
Captain
Gills
!
"
assented
Mr
Toots
.
<EOS>
"
Although
I
had
not
the

of
your
acquaintance
,
Mr
---
Mr
Sols
,
"
said
Toots
,
hitting
on
that
name
in
the

of
a

,
"
before
that
happened
,
I
have
the
greatest
pleasure
<EOS>
,
I
assure

,
in
---
you
know
,
in
knowing
you
.
<EOS>
I
hope
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
that
you
're
as
well
as
can

expected
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
these
courteous
words
,
Mr
Toots
sat
down
blushing
and

.
  
<EOS>
The
old
Instrument
-
maker
,
seated
in
a
corner
between
Walter
and
Florence
,
and
nodding
at
Polly
,
who
was
looking

,
all

and

,
answered

Captain
thus
:
  
<EOS>
"
Ned
Cuttle
,
my
dear
boy
,
although
I
have
heard
something
of
the
changes
of
events
here
,
from
my
pleasant
friend
there
---
what

face
she
has
to

sure
,
to
welcome
a
wanderer
home
!
"
said
the
old
man
,
breaking
off
,
and
rubbing

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hear
him
!
"
cried
the
Captain
gravely
.
"
<EOS>
'
Tis
woman
as
seduces
all
mankind
.
<EOS>
For
which
,
"
aside
to
Mr
Toots
,
"
you
'll
overhaul
your
Adam
and
Eve
,
brother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
make
a

of
doing

,
Captain
Gills
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
.
  
<EOS>
"
Although
I
have
heard
something
of
the
changes
of
events
,
from
her
,
"
resumed
the
Instrument
-
maker
,
taking
his
old

,

putting

old

,
"
they
are
so

,
and

,

,
"
---

,
and

"
that
I
---
I
ca
n't
say
much
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
But
my
dear
Ned
Cuttle
,
why
did
n't
you
write
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
astonishment
depicted
in
the
Captain
's
features
positively
frightened
Mr
Toots
,
whose
eyes
were
quite
fixed
by
it
,
so
that
he
could
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
Write
!
"
echoed
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
Write
,
Sol
Gills
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
either
to
Barbados
,
or
Jamaica
,
or
Demerara
.
<EOS>
That

what
I
asked
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
you
asked
,
Sol
Gills
?
"
repeated
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
know
,
Ned
?
<EOS>
Sure
you
have
not
forgotten
?
<EOS>
Every
time
I
wrote
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
took
off
his
glazed
hat
,
hung
it
on
his
hook
,
and
smoothing
his

from

,
sat

at
the
group
around
him
:
a
perfect
image
of

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
appear
to
understand
me
,
Ned
!
"
<EOS>
observed
old
Sol
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sol
Gills
,
"
returned
the
Captain
,
after
staring
at
him
and
the
rest
for
a
long

,
without
speaking
,
"
<EOS>
I
'm
gone
about
and
adrift
.
<EOS>
Pay
out
a
word
or
two
respecting
them
adwenturs
,
will
you
!
<EOS>
Ca
n't
I
bring
up
,
nohows
?
<EOS>
Nohows
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
Captain
,
ruminating
,
and
staring
all
round
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
Ned
,
"
said
Sol
Gills
,
"
why
I
left
here
.
<EOS>
Did
you
open
my
packet
,
Ned
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
aye
,
aye
,
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
,
I
opened
the
packet
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
read
it
?
"
said
the
old
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
read
it
,
"
answered
the
Captain
,
eyeing
him

,
and
proceeding
to
quote

from

.
"
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Ned
Cuttle
,
when
I
left
home
for
the
West
Indies
in
forlorn
search
of
intelligence
of
my
dear
---
"
There
he
sits
!
<EOS>
There
's
Wal'r
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
as
if
he
were
relieved
by
getting
hold
of
anything
that
was
real
and
indisputable
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Ned
.
<EOS>
Now
attend
a
moment
!
"
said
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
wrote
first
---
that
was
from
Barbados
---
I
said
that
though
you
would
receive
that
letter
long
before
the
year
was
out
,
I
should
be
glad
if
you
would
open
the
packet
,
as
it
explained
the
reason
of

.
<EOS>
Very

,
Ned
.
<EOS>
When
I
wrote
the
second
,
third
,
and

fourth

---
that

Jamaica
---
I
said
I
was
in
just
the
same
state
,
could
n't

,
and

.
<EOS>
When
I
wrote

---
that
,
I

,
was
from

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

!
"

,

<EOS>
"
---

"

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
Mr

was

,

of

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Either

(

<EOS>

"

,

,
"

"

all

kit
of
'em
dead
out
o
'
wind
and
time
,
are
you
going
to
give
in
?
<EOS>
To
give
in
?
"
said
the
Chicken
,
with
contemptuous
emphasis
.
<EOS>
"
Wy
,
it
's
mean
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Chicken
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
severely
,
"
<EOS>
you
're
a
perfect
Vulture
!
<EOS>
Your
sentiments
are
atrocious
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
sentiments
is
Game
and
Fancy
,
Master
,
"
returned
the
Chicken
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
wot
my
sentiments
is
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
abear
a
meanness
.
<EOS>
I
'm
afore
<EOS>
the
public
<EOS>
,
I
'm
to
be
heerd
on

the

of
the
Little
Helephant
,
and
no
Gov'ner
o
'
mine
must
n't
go
and
do
what
's
mean
.
<EOS>
Wy
,
it
's
mean
,
"
said
the
Chicken
,
with
increased
expression
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
's
where
it
is
.
<EOS>
It
's
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Chicken
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
,
"
You
disgust
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Master
,
"
returned
the
Chicken
,
putting
on
his
hat
,
"
there
's
a
pair
on
us
,
then
.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Here
's
a
offer
!
<EOS>
You
've
spoke
to
me
more
than
once't
or
twice't
about
the
public
line
.
<EOS>
Never
mind
!
<EOS>
Give
me
a
fi'typunnote
to
-
morrow
,
and
let
me
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Chicken
,
"
returned
Mr
Toots
,
"
after
the
odious
sentiments
you
have
expressed
,
I
shall
be
glad
to
part
on
such
terms
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Done
then
,
"
said
the
Chicken
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
bargain
.
<EOS>
This
here
conduct
of
yourn
wo
n't
suit
my
book
,
Master
.
<EOS>
Wy
<EOS>
,
it
's
mean
,
"
said
the
Chicken
;
who
seemed
equally
unable
to
get
beyond
that
point
,
and
to
stop
short
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
's
where
it
is
;
it
's
mean
!
"
  
<EOS>
So
Mr
Toots
and
the
Chicken
agreed
to
part
on
this
incompatibility
of
moral
perception
;
and
Mr
Toots
lying
down
to
sleep
,
dreamed
happily
of
Florence
,
who
had
thought
of
him
as
her
friend
upon
the
last
night
of
her
maiden
life
,
and
who
had
sent
him
her
dear
love
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
57
.
<EOS>
Another
Wedding
 
MR
SOWNDS
the
beadle
,
and
Mrs
Miff
the
pew
-
opener
,
are
early
at
their
posts
in
the
fine
church
where
Mr
Dombey
was
married
.
<EOS>
A
yellow
-
faced
old
gentleman
from
India
,
is
going
to
take
unto
himself
a
young
wife
this
morning
,
and
six
carriages
full
of
company
are
expected
,
and
Mrs
Miff
has
been
informed
that
the
yellow
-
faced
old
gentleman
could
pave
the
road
to
church
with
diamonds
and
hardly
miss
them
.
<EOS>
The
nuptial
benediction
is
to
be
a
superior
one
,
proceeding
from
a
very
reverend
,
a
dean
,
and
the
lady
is
to
be
given
away
,
as
an
extraordinary
present
,
by
somebody
who
comes
express
from
the
Horse
Guards
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Miff
is
more
intolerant
of
common
people
this
morning
,
than
she
generally
is
;
and
she
has
always
strong
opinions
on
that
subject
,
for
it
is
associated
with
free
sittings
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Miff
is
not
a
student
of
political
economy
<EOS>
(
she
thinks
the
science
is
connected
with
dissenters
;
"
Baptists
or
Wesleyans
,
or
some
o'them
,
"
she
says
)
,
but
<EOS>
she
can
never
understand
what
business
your
common
folks
have
to
be
married
.
<EOS>
"
Drat
'
em
,
"
says
Mrs
Miff
,
"
you
read
the
same
things
over
'em
,
and
instead
of
sovereigns
get
sixpences
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Sownds
<EOS>
the
beadle
is
more
liberal
than
Mrs
Miff
---
but
then
he
is
nor
a
pew
-
opener
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
done
,
ma'am
,
"
he
says
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
marry
'em
.
<EOS>
We
must
have
our
national
schools
to
walk
at
the
head
of
,
and
we
must
have
our
standing
armies
.
<EOS>
We
must
marry'em
,
ma'am
,
"
says
Mr
Sownds
,
"
and
keep
the
country
going
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Sownds
is
sitting
on
the
steps
and
Mrs
Miff
is
dusting
in
the
church
,
when
a
young
couple
,
plainly
dressed
,
come
in
.
<EOS>
The
mortified
bonnet
of
Mrs
Miff
is
sharply
turned
towards
them
,
for
she
espies
in
this
early
visit
indications
of
a
runaway
match
.
<EOS>
But
they
do
n't
want
to
be
married
---
"
Only
,
"
says
the
gentleman
,
"
to
walk
round
the
church
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
as
he
slips
a
genteel
compliment
into
the
palm
of
Mrs
Miff
,
her
vinegary
face
relaxes
,
and
her
mortified
bonnet
and
her
spare
dry
figure
dip
and
crackle
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Miff
resumes
her
dusting
and
plumps
up
her
cushions
---
for
the
yellow
-
faced
old
gentleman
is
reported
to
have
tender
knees
---
but
keeps
her
glazed
,
pew
-
opening
eye
on
the
young
couple
who
are
walking
round
the
church
.
<EOS>
"
Ahem
,
"
coughs
Mrs
Miff
,
whose
cough
is
drier
than
the
hay
in
any
hassock
in
her
charge
,
"
you
'll
come
to
us
one
of
these
mornings
,
my
dears
,
unless
I
'm
much
mistaken
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
are
looking
at
a
tablet
on
the
wall
,
erected
to
the
memory
of
some
one
dead
.
<EOS>
They
are
a
long
way
off
from
Mrs
Miff
,
but
Mrs
Miff
can
see
with
half
an
eye
how
she
is
leaning
on
his
arm
,
and
how
his
head
is
bent
down
over
her
.
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
"
says
Mrs
Miff
,
"
you
might
do
worse
.
<EOS>
For
you
're
a
tidy
pair
!
"
  
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
personal
in
Mrs
Miff
's
remark
.
<EOS>
She
merely
speaks
of
stock
-
in
-
trade
.
<EOS>
She
is
hardly
more
curious
in
couples
than
in
coffins
.
<EOS>
She
is
such
a
spare
,
straight
,
dry
old
lady
---
such
a
pew
of
a
woman
---
that
you
should
find
as
many
individual
sympathies
in
a
ship
.
<EOS>
Mr
Sownds
,
now
,
who
is
fleshy
,
and
has
scarlet
in
his
coat
,
is
of
a
different
temperament
.
<EOS>
He
says
,
as
they
stand
upon
the
steps
watching
the
young
couple
away
,
that
she
has
a
pretty
figure
,
has
n't
she
,
and
as
well
as
he
could
se
(
for
she
held
her
head
down
coming
out
)
,
an
uncommon
pretty
face
.
"
<EOS>
Altogether
,
Mrs
Miff
,
"
says
Mr
Sownds
with
a
relish
,
"
she
is
what
you
may
call
a
rose
-
bud
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Miff
assents
with
a
spare
nod
of
her
mortified
bonnet
;
but
approves
of
this
so
little
,
<EOS>
that
she
inwardly
resolves
she
would
n't
be
the
wife
of
Mr
Sownds
for
any
money
he
could
give
her
,
Beadle
as
he
is
.
  
<EOS>
And
what
are
the
young
couple
saying
as
they
leave
the
church
,
and
go
out
at
the
gate
?
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Walter
,
thank
you
!
<EOS>
I
can
go
away
,
now
,
happy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
when
we
come
back
,
Florence
,
we
will
come
and
see
his
grave
again
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
lifts
her
eyes
,
so
bright
with
tears
,
to
his
kind
face
;
and
clasps
her
disengaged
hand
on
that
other
modest
little
hand
which
clasps
his
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
early
,
Walter
,
and
<EOS>
the
streets
are
almost
empty
yet
.
<EOS>
Let
us
walk
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
be
so
tired
,
my
love
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
!
<EOS>
I
was
very
tired
the
first
time
that
we
ever
walked
together
,
but
I
shall
not
be
so
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
thus
---
not
much
changed
<EOS>
---
she
,
as
innocent
and
earnest
-
hearted
---
he
,
as
frank
,
as
hopeful
,
and
more
proud
of
her
---
Florence
and
Walter
,
on
their
bridal
morning
,
walk
through
the
streets
together
.
  
<EOS>
Not
even
in
that
childish
walk
of
long
ago
,
were
they
so
far
removed
from
all
the
world
about
them
as
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
The
childish
feet
of
long
ago
,
did
not
tread
such
enchanted
ground
as
theirs
do
now
.
<EOS>
The
confidence
and
love
of
children
may
be
given
many
times
,
and
will
spring
up
in
many
places
;
but
the
woman
's
heart
of
Florence
,
with
its
undivided
treasure
,
can
be
yielded
only
once
,
and
under
slight
or
change
,
can
only
droop
and
die
.
  
<EOS>
They
take
the
streets
that
are
the
quietest
,
and
do
not
go
near
that
in
which
her
old
home
stands
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
fair
,
warm
summer
morning
,
and
the
sun
shines
on
them
,
as
they
walk
towards
the
darkening
mist
that
overspreads
the
City
.
<EOS>
Riches
are
uncovering
in
shops
;
jewels
,
gold
,
and
silver
flash
in
the
goldsmith
's
sunny
windows
;
and
great
houses
cast
a
stately
shade
upon
them
as
they
pass
.
<EOS>
But
through
the
light
,
and
through
the
shade
,
they
go
on
lovingly
together
,
lost
to
everything
around
;
thinking
of
no
other
riches
,
and
no
prouder
home
,
than
they
have
now
in
one
another
.
  
<EOS>
Gradually
they
come
into
the
darker
,
narrower
streets
,
where
the
sun
,
now
yellow
,
and
now
red
,
is
seen
through
the
mist
,
only
at
street
corners
,
and
in
small
open
spaces
where
there
is
a
tree
,
or
one
of
the
innumerable
churches
,
or
a
paved
way
and
a
flight
of
steps
,
or
a
curious
little
patch
of
garden
,
or
a
burying
-
ground
,
where
the
few
tombs
and
tombstones
are
almost
black
.
<EOS>
Lovingly
and
trustfully
,
through
all
the
narrow
yards
and
alleys
and
the
shady
streets
,
Florence
goes
,
clinging
to
his
arm
,
to
be
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
Her
heart
beats
quicker
now
,
for
Walter
tells
her
that
their
church
is
very
near
.
<EOS>
They
pass
a
few
great
stacks
of
ware
-
houses
,
with
waggons
at
the
doors
,
and
busy
carmen
stopping
up
the
way
---
but
Florence
does
not
see
or
hear
them
---
and
then
the
air
is
quiet
,
and
the
day
is
darkened
,
and
she
is
trembling
in
a
church
which
has
a
strange
smell
like
a
cellar
.
  
<EOS>
The
Shabby
little
old
man
,
ringer
of
the
disappointed
bell
,
is
standing
in
the
porch
,
and
has
put
his
hat
in
the
font
---
for
he
is
quite
at
home
there
,
being
sexton
.
<EOS>
He
ushers
them
into
an
old
brown
,
panelled
,
dusty
vestry
,
like
a
corner
-
cupboard
with
the
shelves
taken
out
;
where
the
wormy
registers
diffuse
a
smell
like
faded
snuff
,
which
has
set
the
tearful
Nipper
sneezing
.
  
<EOS>
Youthful
,
and
how
beautiful
,
the
young
bride
looks
,
in
this
old
dusty
place
,
with
no
kindred
object
near
her
but
her
husband
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
dusty
old
clerk
,
who
keeps
a
sort
of
evaporated
news
shop
underneath
an
archway
opposite
,
behind
a
perfect
fortification
of
posts
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
dusty
old
pew
-
opener
who
only
keeps
herself
,
and
finds
that
quite
enough
to
do
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
dusty
old
beadle
(
these
are
Mr
Toots
's
beadle
and
pew
-
opener
of
last
Sunday
)
,
who
has
something
to
do
with
a
Worshipful
Company
who
have
got
a
Hall
in
the
Next
yard
,
with
a
stained
-
glass
window
in
it
that
no
mortal
ever
saw
.
<EOS>
There
are
dusty
wooden
ledges
and
cornices
poked
in
and
out
over
the
altar
,
and
over
the
screen
and
round
the
gallery
,
and
over
the
inscription
about
what
the
Master
and
Wardens
of
the
Worshipful
Company
did
in
one
thousand
six
hundred
and
ninety
-
four
.
<EOS>
There
are
dusty
old
sounding
-
boards
over
the
pulpit
and
reading
-
desk
,
looking
like
lids
to
be
let
down
on
the
officiating
ministers
,
in
case
of
their
giving
offence
.
<EOS>
There
is
every
possible
provision
for
the
accommodation
of
dust
,
except
in
the
churchyard
,
where
the
facilities
in
that
respect
are
very
limited
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
Uncle
Sol
,
and
Mr
Toots
are
come
;
the
clergyman
is
putting
on
his
surplice
in
the
vestry
,
while
the
clerk
walks
round
him
,
blowing
the
dust
off
it
;
and
the
bride
and
bridegroom
stand
before
the
altar
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
brides
-
maid
,
unless
Susan
Nipper
is
one
;
and
no
better
father
than
Captain
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
A
man
with
a
wooden
leg
,
chewing
a
faint
apple
and
carrying
a
blue
bag
in
his
hand
,
looks
in
to
see
what
is
going
on
;
but
finding
it
nothing
entertaining
,
stumps
off
again
,
and
pegs
his
way
among
the
echoes
out
of
doors
.
  
<EOS>
No
gracious
ray
of
light
is
seen
to
fall
on
Florence
,
kneeling
at
the
altar
with
her
timid
head
bowed
down
.
<EOS>
The
Morning
luminary
is
built
out
,
and
do
n't
shine
there
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
meagre
tree
outside
,
where
the
sparrows
are
chirping
a
little
;
and
there
is
a
blackbird
in
an
eyelet
-
hole
of
sun
in
a
dyer
's
garret
,
over
against
the
window
,
who
whistles
loudly
whilst
the
service
is
performing
;
and
there
is
the
man
with
the
wooden
leg
stumping
away
.
<EOS>
The
amens
of
the
dusty
clerk
appear
,
like
MacBeth
's
,
to
stick
in
his
throat
a
little
;
but
Captain
Cuttle
helps
him
out
,
and
does
it
with
so
much
goodwill
that
he
interpolates
three
entirely
new
responses
of
that
word
,
never
introduced
into
the
service
before
.
   
<EOS>
They
are
married
,
and
have
signed
their
names
in
one
of
the
old
sneezy
registers
,
and
the
clergyman
's
surplice
is
restored
to
the
dust
,
and
the
clergyman
is
gone
home
.
<EOS>
In
a
dark
corner
of
the
dark
church
,
Florence
has
turned
to
Susan
Nipper
,
and
is
weeping
in
her
arms
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
's
eyes
are
red
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
lubricates
his
nose
.
<EOS>
Uncle
Sol
has
pulled
down
his
spectacles
from
his
forehead
,
and
walked
out
to
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
,
Susan
;
dearest
Susan
!
<EOS>
If
you
ever
can
bear
witness
to
the
love
I
have
for
Walter
,
and
the
reason
that
I
have
to
love
him
,
do
it
for
his
sake
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
have
thought
it
better
not
to
go
back
to
the
Midshipman
,
but
to
part
so
;
a
coach
is
waiting
for
them
,
near
at
hand
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper
can
not
speak
;
she
only
sobs
and
chokes
,
and
hugs
her
mistress
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
advances
,
urges
her
to
cheer
up
,
and
takes
charge
of
her
.
<EOS>
Florence
gives
him
her
hand
---
gives
him
,
in
the
fulness
of
her
heart
,
her
lips
---
kisses
Uncle
Sol
,
and
Captain
Cuttle
,
and
is
borne
away
by
her
young
husband
.
  
<EOS>
But
Susan
can
not
bear
that
Florence
should
go
away
with
a
mournful
recollection
of
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
meant
to
be
so
different
,
that
she
reproaches
herself
bitterly
.
<EOS>
Intent
on
making
one
last
effort
to
redeem
her
character
,
she
breaks
from
Mr
Toots
and
runs
away
to
find
the
coach
,
and
show
a

.
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
divining
her
object
,
sets
off
after
her
;
for
he
feels
it
<EOS>
his
duty
also
to
dismiss
them
with
a

,
if
possible
.
<EOS>
Uncle
Sol
and
Mr
Toots
are
left
behind
together
,
outside

church
,
to
wait
for

.
  
<EOS>
The
coach
is
gone
,
but
the
street
is
steep
,
and
narrow
,
and
blocked
up
,
and
Susan
can
see
it
at
a

-
still
in

distance
,
she
is
sure
.
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
follows
her
as
she
flies
down

,
and
waves
his

hat
as
a
general
signal
,
which
may
attract
the
right

and
which
may
not
.
  
<EOS>
Susan
outstrips
the
Captain
,
and
comes
up
with
it
.
<EOS>
She
looks
in
at
the
window
,
sees
Walter
,
with
the

beside

,
and

and

:
  
"
Miss
Floy
,
my

!
<EOS>
look

!
<EOS>
We
are
all
so

now
,

!
<EOS>
One
more
good
-
bye
,
my
precious
,

!
"
  
<EOS>
How
Susan
does

,
she
do

,

she

to

window
,
kisses
her
,
and
has
her

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
We

---

,

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
,
you
wo
n't

.
<EOS>
Now

?
"
<EOS>
"
Angry
,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

<EOS>
;
I

sure
you
wo
n't
.
<EOS>
I
say

wo
n't
,

,

!
"
<EOS>

;
"

---

,

---

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hooroar
,

Heart
's

!
"

Captain
,
with

of

.
<EOS>
"
Hooroar
,
Wal'r
<EOS>
my
lad
.
<EOS>
Hooroar
!
<EOS>
Hooroar
!
"
  
<EOS>
What

the
young

at

,

;
the
Captain

,

Susan
Nipper
holding

;

,

because

;
there

on

.
<EOS>
But
Susan
Nipper
gallantly
maintains

.
<EOS>
She
keeps
a

face
upon
her

,
smiling

,

.
<EOS>
Even

,

to

,

"
Hooroar
,
my
lad
!
<EOS>
Hooroar
,
my
Heart
's
Delight
!
"
<EOS>
with
his
shirt
-

in

violent

of

,
until
it
is
hopeless
to

.
<EOS>
Finally
,

,

,

,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
Uncle
Sol
and
Mr
Toots
wait
patiently

,

,
until

come

.
<EOS>
Neither

,

,
they

,

.
<EOS>
When

again

the
little
Midshipman
,
and

,
nobody
can

.
<EOS>
Captain
Cuttle
makes
a
feint

about
toast
,
but
gives

up
as
a
swindle
.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
says
,
after
breakfast
,
he
will
come
back
in
the
evening
;
and
goes
wandering
about
the
town
all
day
,
with
a
vague

upon

as
if
he
had
n't
been
to

for

.
  
<EOS>
There

a

in

,
and

the
room
,
in
which
they
have
been
used
to

together
,
and
out

so

is

.
<EOS>
It

,

,
the

of

.
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
tells
Susan
Nipper
when
he
comes
at
night
,
that
he
has
n't
been
so
wretched
all
day
long
,
and
yet
he
likes
it
.
<EOS>
He
confides
in
Susan
Nipper
,
being
alone
with
her
,
and
tells
her
what
his

were
when
she
gave

that

as

the

Miss
Dombey
's

.
<EOS>
In

confidence
engendered
by
these
common
recollections
,
and
their
tears
,
Mr
Toots
proposes
that
they
shall
go
out
together
,

.
<EOS>
Miss
Nipper

,

good
many

;
and
,

Mrs

,

out
quite

before
the

.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
and
old
Sol
have
been
on

,
and
have
established
Di
there
,
and

seen

.
<EOS>
They
have
much
to

about
the
popularity

Walter
,

the

he

about

,

,

what

"
a

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
A
admiral
's

,
mind

,
"
says

Captain
,
"
ai
n't
more
trim
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
one

Captain
's
chief

is
,
that
he
knows

big

,
and

-

,

-

,

:

,
"
Ed'ard
<EOS>
Cuttle
,

,

.
<EOS>
You

the
land
bore
,
Ed'ard
,
"

Captain
,
"
and

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

Instrument
-

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
boy
has

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What

!
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

"
Sol
!
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
Would

,

,

Wal'r

?
"
  
<EOS>
The

-

,

,

<EOS>
"
To

,

"
<EOS>
From

.
<EOS>
To

'

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
"
Sir
.
<EOS>
I
am

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
To

her
is

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
"
Why
,

,
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
"

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
"
"
I

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
  
Solomon

,

<EOS>

wo

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not

,
"

Captain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Not
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Susan
and
Mr
Toots
are
of
the
same

.
<EOS>
After
a
silence
they
all
sit
down
to

,
and
drink
to
the
young
husband
and
wife
in
something
else
;
and
the
last

of
the
old
Madeira
still
remains
among
its

and

,

.
  
<EOS>
A
few
days
have
elapsed
,
and
a
stately
ship
is
out
at
sea
,
spreading
its
white
wings
to
the
favouring
wind
.
  
<EOS>
Upon
the
deck
,
image
to
the
roughest
man
on
board
of
something
that
is
graceful
,
beautiful
,
and
harmless
---
something
that
it
is
good
and
pleasant
to
have
there
,
and
that
should
make
the
voyage
prosperous
---
is
Florence
.
<EOS>
It
is
night
,
and
she
and
Walter
sit
alone
,
watching
the
solemn
path
of
light
upon
the
sea
between
them
and
the
moon
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
she
can
not
see
it
plainly
,
for
the
tears
that
fill
her
eyes
;
and
then
she
lays
her
head
down
on
his
breast
,
and
puts
her
arms
around
his
neck
,
saying
,
"
Oh
Walter
,
dearest
love
,
I
am
so
happy
!
"
  
<EOS>
Her
husband
holds
her
to
his
heart
,
and
they
are
very
quiet
,
and
the
stately
ship
goes
on
serenely
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
I
hear
the
sea
,
"
says
Florence
,
"
and
sit
watching
it
,
it
brings
so
many
days
into
my
mind
.
<EOS>
It
makes
me
think
so
much
"
  
"
Of
Paul
,
my
love
.
<EOS>
I
know
it
does
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Of
Paul
and
Walter
.
<EOS>
And
the
voices
in
the
waves
are
always
whispering
to
Florence
,
in
their
ceaseless
murmuring
,
of
love
---
of
love
,
eternal
and
illimitable
,
not
bounded
by
the
confines
of
this
world
,
or
by
the
end
of
time
,
but
ranging
still
,
beyond
the
sea
,
beyond
the
sky
,
to
the
invisible
country
far
away
!
   
<EOS>
Chapter
58
.
<EOS>
After
a
Lapse
 
<EOS>
THE
sea
had
ebbed
and
flowed
,
through
a
whole
year
.
<EOS>
Through
a
whole
year
,
the
winds
and
clouds
had
come
and
gone
;
the
ceaseless
work
of
Time
had
been
performed
,
in
storm
and
sunshine
.
<EOS>
Through
a
whole
year
,
the
tides
of
human
chance
and
change
had
set
in
their
allotted
courses
.
<EOS>
Through
a
whole
year
,
the
famous
House
of
Dombey
and
Son
had
fought
a
fight
for
life
,
against
cross
accidents
,
doubtful
rumours
,
unsuccessful
ventures
,
unpropitious
times
,
and
most
of
all
,
against
the
infatuation
of
its
head
,
who
would
not
contract
its
enterprises
by
a
hair
's
breadth
,
and
would
not
listen
to
a
word
of
warning
that
the
ship
he
strained
so
hard
against
the
storm
,
was
weak
,
and
could
not
bear
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
year
was
out
,
and
the
great
House
was
down
.
  
<EOS>
One
summer
afternoon
;
a
year
,
wanting
some
odd
days
,
after
the
marriage
in
the
City
church
;
there
was
a
buzz
and
whisper
upon
'
Change
of
a
great
failure
.
<EOS>
A
certain
cold
proud
man
,
well
known
there
,
was
not
there
,
nor
was
he
represented
there
.
<EOS>
Next
day
it
was
noised
abroad
that
Dombey
and
Son
had
stopped
,
and
next
night
there
was
a
List
of
Bankrupts
published
,
headed
by
that
name
.
  
<EOS>
The
world
was
very
busy
now
,
in
sooth
,
and
had
a
deal
to
say
.
<EOS>
It
was
an
innocently
credulous
and
a
much
ill
-
used
world
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
world
in
which
there
was
no
other
sort
of
bankruptcy
whatever
.
<EOS>
There
were
no
conspicuous
people
in
it
,
trading
far
and
wide
on
rotten
banks
of
religion
,
patriotism
,
virtue
,
honour
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
amount
worth
mentioning
of
mere
paper
in
circulation
,
on
which
anybody
lived
pretty
handsomely
,
promising
to
pay
great
sums
of
goodness
with
no
effects
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
shortcomings
anywhere
,
in
anything
but
money
.
<EOS>
The
world
was
very
angry
indeed
;
and
the
people
especially
,
who
,
in
a
worse
world
,
might
have
been
supposed
to
be
bankrupt
traders
themselves
in
shows
and
pretences
,
were
observed
to
be
mightily
indignant
.
  
<EOS>
Here
was
a
new
inducement
to
dissipation
,
presented
to
that
sport
of
circumstances
,
Mr
Perch
the
Messenger
!
<EOS>
It
was
apparently
the
fate
of
Mr
Perch
to
be
always
waking
up
,
and
finding
himself
famous
.
<EOS>
He
had
but
yesterday
,
as
one
might
say
,
subsided
into
private
life
from
the
celebrity
of
the
elopement
and
the
events
that
followed
it
;
and
now
he
was
made
a
more
important
man
than
ever
,
by
the
bankruptcy
.
<EOS>
Gliding
from
his
bracket
in
the
outer
office
where
he
now
sat
,
watching
the
strange
faces
of
accountants
and
others
,
who
quickly
superseded
nearly
all
the
old
clerks
,
Mr
Perch
had
but
to
show
himself
in
the
court
outside
,
or
,
at
farthest
,
in
the
bar
of
the
King
's
Arms
,
to
be
asked
a
multitude
of
questions
,
almost
certain
to
include
that
interesting
question
,
what
would
he
take
to
drink
?
<EOS>
Then
would
Mr
Perch
descant
upon
the
hours
of
acute
uneasiness
he
and
Mrs
Perch
had
suffered
out
at
Balls
Pond
,
when
they
first
suspected
"
things
was
going
wrong
.
"
<EOS>
Then
would
Mr
Perch
relate
to
gaping
listeners
,
in
a
low
voice
,
as
if
the
corpse
of
the
deceased
House
were
lying
unburied
in
the
next
room
,
how
Mrs
Perch
had
first
come
to
surmise
that
things
was
going
wrong
by
hearing
him
(
Perch
)
moaning
in
his
sleep
,
"
twelve
and
ninepence
in
the
pound
,
twelve
and
ninepence
in
the
pound
!
"
<EOS>
Which
act
of
somnambulism
he
supposed
to
have
originated
in
the
impression
made
upon
him
by
the
change
in
Mr
Dombey
's
face
.
<EOS>
Then
would
he
inform
them
how
he
had
once
said
,
"
Might
I
make
so
bold
as
ask
,
Sir
,
are
you
unhappy
in
your
mind
?
"
<EOS>
and
how
Mr
Dombey
had
replied
,
"
<EOS>
My
faithful
Perch
---
<EOS>
but
no
,
it
can
not
be
!
"
<EOS>
and
with
that
had
struck
his
hand
upon

,
and
said
,
"
Leave
me
,
Perch
!
"
<EOS>
Then
,
in
short
,
would
Mr
Perch
,
a
victim
to
his
position
,
tell
all
manner
of
lies
;
affecting
himself
to
tears
by
those
that
were
of
a
moving
nature
,
and
really
believing
that
the
inventions
of
yesterday
had
,
on
repetition
,
a
sort
of
truth
about
them
to
-
day
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Perch
always
closed
these
conferences
by
meekly
remarking
,
That
,
of
course
,
whatever
his
suspicions
might
have
been
(
as
if
he
had
ever
had
any
!
)
<EOS>
it
was
n't
for
him
to
betray
his
trust
,
was
it
?
<EOS>
Which
sentiment
(
there
never
being
any
creditors
present
)
was
received
as
doing
as
doing
great
honour
to
his
feelings
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
he
generally
brought
away
a
soothed
conscience
and
left
an
agreeable
impression
behind
him
,
when
he
returned
to
his
bracket
:
again
to
sit
watching
the
strange
faces
of
the
accountants
and
others
,
making
so
free
with
the
great
mysteries
,
the
Books
;
or
now

then
to
go
on

into
Mr
Dombey
's
empty
room
,
and
stir

fire
;
or
to
take
an
airing
at
the
door
,
and
have
a
little
more
doleful
chat
with
any
straggler
whom
he
knew
;
or
to
propitiate
,
with
various
small
attentions
,
the
head
accountant
:
from
whom
Mr
Perch
had
expectations
of
a
messengership
in
a
Fire
Office
,
when
the
affairs
of
the
House
should
be
wound
up
.
  
<EOS>
To
Major
Bagstock
,
the
bankruptcy
was
quite
a
calamity
.
<EOS>
The
Major
was
not
a
sympathetic
character
---
his
attention
being
wholly
concentrated
on
JB
---
nor
was
he
a
man
subject
to
lively
emotions
,
except
in
the
physical
regards
of
gasping
and
choking
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
so
paraded
his
friend
Dombey
at
the
club
;
had
so
flourished
him
at
the
heads
of
the
members
in

,
and
so
put

down
by
continual

of
his

;
that
the
club
,
being
but

,
was

to
retort
upon
the
Major
,
by
asking
him
,
with
a

,
whether
this
tremendous

had
been
at

,
and
how
his

Dombey

.
<EOS>
To

,

Major
,

,
would
reply
that
it
was
a
bad
world
,
Sir
,
altogether
;
that
Joey
knew
a
thing

two
,
but
had
been
done
,
Sir
,
done

;
that

had

,
Sir
,
to
J
Bagstock

Dombey

was

,
J
Bagstock

pooh

---
would

pooh
-
pooh'd
<EOS>
you
,
Sir
,

Lord
!
<EOS>
That
Joe
had

,

,

in
,

,

,

;
insomuch

's

,

,

Josh

,
Sir
.
<EOS>
That

,

,

up
,
JB
infidel

;
and
that

Major
,

,

their

,

!
<EOS>
Sir
,
he
'd
have
a
tub
in
Pall
Mall
to
-

,
to
show
his

!
  
<EOS>
Of

,
and
many

,
the
Major
would

with

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
Native
,
expressing
no
opinion
,
suffered
dreadfully
;
not
merely
in
his

,
which
were

by
the
Major
every
nour

,
and
riddled
through
and
through
,
but
in
his

to
bodily

and

,
which
was

on

.
<EOS>
For
six
entire
weeks
after
the
bankruptcy
,
this
miserable
foreigner
lived
in
a
rainy
season
of
boot
-
jacks
and
brushes
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
had
three
ideas
upon
the
subject
of
the
terrible
reverse
.
<EOS>
The
first
was
that
she
could
not
understand

.
<EOS>
The
second
,
that
her
brother
had
not
made
an

.
<EOS>
The
third
,
that
if
she

first

,
it
never

;
and
that
she

said

,

time
.
  
<EOS>
Nobody
's
opinion
stayed
the
misfortune
,
lightened
it
,
or
made
it
heavier
.
<EOS>
It
was
understood
that
the
affairs
of
the
House
were
to
be

up
as
they
best

;
that
Mr
Dombey
freely

,
and

from
any

.
<EOS>
That
any

of

was
out

,
as
he

no
friendly

having
that

;
that

had
relinquished
every

he
had
held
,
as

man
respected
among

;
that
he
was
dying
,
according

;
that

was
going
melancholy
mad
,
according
to
others
;
that
he
was
a
broken
man
,
according

.
  
<EOS>
The
clerks
dispersed
after
holding
a
little

condolence
among

,
which
was
enlivened
by
comic

,
and
went
off

.
<EOS>
Some
took
places
abroad
,
and
some
engaged
in
other
Houses
at
home
;
some
looked
up
relations
in
the
country
,
for
whom
they
suddenly
remembered
they
had
a
particular
affection
;
and
some
advertised
for
employment
in
the
newspapers
.
<EOS>
Mr
Perch
alone
remained
of
all
the
late
establishment
,
sitting
on
his
bracket
looking
at
the
accountants
,
or
starting
off

,
to

the
head
accountant
,
who
was
to
get
him
into
the
Fire
Office
.
<EOS>
The
Counting
House
soon
got
to
be
dirty
and
neglected
.
<EOS>
The
principal
slipper
and
dogs
'
collar
seller
,
at
the
corner
of
the
court
,
would
have

of

up

to

,
any

,
if
Mr
Dombey

;
and

porter
,

,

good

about
ambition
,
which
(
he
observed
)
was
not
,
in

,
made
to

,
for
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Morfin
,
the
hazel
-

,
with
the
hair
and

sprinkled
with
grey
,
was
perhaps

only

within

of
the
House
---
its
head
,
of

,
excepted
---
<EOS>
who
was
heartily
and
deeply
affected
by
the
disaster
that
had

.
<EOS>
He
had
treated
Mr
Dombey
with
due

and
deference
through
many
years
,
but
he
had
never
disguised
his
natural
character
,
or

to

,

master

for

.
<EOS>
He
had
,
therefore
,
no
self
-
disrespect
to
avenge
;
no
long
-
tightened
springs
to
release
with

.
<EOS>
He
worked
early
and
late
to
unravel
whatever
was
complicated
or

in
the
records
of
the
transactions
of
the
House
;
was
always
in

to
explain
whatever
required

;
sat
in

old
room
sometimes
very
late

,

points
by
his

of
which
he
could
spare
Mr
Dombey

of
being
personally

to
;
and
then
would
go
home
to
Islington
,
and

mind
by
producing
the
most
dismal
and
forlorn
sounds
out
of
his
violoncello
before
going
to
bed
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
solacing
himself
with
this
melodious
grumbler
one
evening
,
and
,
having
been
much
dispirited
by
the
proceedings
of
the
day
,
was
scraping

out
of
its
deepest

,
when
his
landlady
(
who
was
fortunately
deaf
,
and
had
no

consciousness
of
these

than
a

something

bones
)

.
  
<EOS>
"
In
mourning
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
The
violoncello
stopped
immediately
;
and
the
performer
,
laying
it
on
the
sofa
with
great

and
care
,
made
a
sign
that
the
lady
was
to
come
in
.
<EOS>
He
followed

,
and
met

Carker

.
  
<EOS>
"
Alone
!
"
<EOS>
he

,
"
and
John
here
this

!
<EOS>
Is

anything
the
matter
,

?
<EOS>
But
no
,
"
he

,
"
your
face

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

that
you

,

,
"
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

very

,
"
said

;
"
and
,

,
a

,
worth

.
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
believe
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
placed
a

by
this

,

;
the

lying

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

"

when
I
tell
you
why
I
have
come
.
<EOS>
May
I
do
so
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
do
nothing
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
not
busy
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
pointed
to
the
violoncello
lying
on
the
sofa
,
and
said
,
"
I
have
been
,
all
day
.
<EOS>
Here
's
my
witness
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
confiding
all
my
cares
to
it
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
none
but
my
own
to
tell
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Is
the
House
at
an
end
?
"
said
Harriet
,
earnestly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Completely
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
it
never
be
resumed
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
bright
expression
of
her
face
was
not
overshadowed
as
her
lips
silently
repeated
the
word
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
observe
this
with
some
little
involuntary
surprise
:
and
said
again
:
  
"
<EOS>
Never
.
<EOS>
You
remember
what
I
told
you
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
,
all
along
,
impossible
to
convince
him
;
impossible
to
reason
with
him
;
sometimes
,
impossible
even
to
approach
him
.
<EOS>
The
worst
has
happened
;
and
the
House
has
fallen
,
never
to
built
up
any
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
Mr
Dombey
,
is
he
personally
ruined
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ruined
.
"
<EOS>
"
Will
he
have
no
private
fortune
left
?
<EOS>
Nothing
?
"
  
<EOS>
A
certain
eagerness
in
her
voice
,
and
something
that
was
almost
joyful
in
her
look
,
seemed
to
surprise
him
more
and
more
;
to
disappoint
him
too
,
and
jar
discordantly
against
his
own
emotions
.
<EOS>
He
drummed
with
the
fingers
of
one
hand
on
the
table
,
looking
wistfully
at
her
,
and
shaking
his
head
,
said
,
after
a
pause
:
  
"
The
extent
of
Mr
Dombey
's
resources
is
not
accurately
within
my
knowledge
;
but
though
they
are
doubtless
very
large
,
his
obligations
are
enormous
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
gentleman
of
high
honour
and
integrity
.
<EOS>
Any
man
in
his
position
could
,
and
many
a
man
in
his
position
would
,
have
saved
himself
,
by
making
terms
which
would
have
very
slighty
,
almost
insensibly
,
increased
the
losses
of
those
who
had
had
dealings
with
him
,
and
left
him
a
remnant
to
live
upon
.
<EOS>
But
he
is
resolved
on
payment
to
the
last
farthing
of
his
means
.
<EOS>
His
own
words
are
,
that
they
will
clear
,
or
nearly
clear
,
the
House
,
and
that
no
one
can
lose
much
.
<EOS>
Ah
,
Miss
Harriet
,
it
would
do
us
no
harm
to
remember
oftener
than
we
do
,
that
vices
are
sometimes
only
virtues
carried
to
excess
!
<EOS>
His
pride
shows
well
in
this
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
heard
him
with
little
or
no
change
in
her
expression
,
and
with
a
divided
attention
that
showed
her
to
be
busy
with
something
in
her
own
mind
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
silent
,
she
asked
him
hurriedly
:
  
"
Have
you
seen
him
lately
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
one
sees
him
.
<EOS>
When
this
crisis
of
his
affairs
renders
it
necessary
for
him
to
come
out
of
his
house
,
he
comes
out
for
the
occasion
,
and
again
goes
home
,
and
shuts
himself
up
,
and
will
see
no
one
.
<EOS>
He
has
written
me
a
letter
,
acknowledging
our
past
connexion
in
higher
terms
than
it
deserved
,
and
parting
from
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
delicate
of
obtruding
myself
upon
him
now
,
never
having
had
much
intercourse
with
him
in
better
times
;
but
I
have
tried
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
have
written
,
gone
there
,
entreated
.
<EOS>
Quite
in
vain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
watched
her
,
as
in
the
hope
that
she
would
testify
some
greater
concern
than
she
had
yet
shown
;
and
spoke
gravely
and
feelingly
,
as
if
to
impress
her
the
more
;
but
there
was
no
change
in
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
Miss
Harriet
,
"
he
said
,
with
a
disappointed
air
,
"
this
is
not
to
the
purpose
.
<EOS>
You
have
not
come
here
to
hear
this
.
<EOS>
Some
other
and
pleasanter
theme
is
in
your
mind
.
<EOS>
Let
it
be
in
mine
,
too
,
and
we
shall
talk
upon
more
equal
terms
.
<EOS>
Come
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
it
is
the
same
theme
,
"
returned
Harriet
,
with
frank
and
quick
surprise
.
"
<EOS>
Is
it
not
likely
that
it
should
be
?
<EOS>
Is
it
not
natural
that
John
and
I
should
have
been
thinking
and
speaking
very
much
of
late
of
these
great
changes
?
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
,
whom
he
served
so
many
years
---
you
know
upon
what
terms
---
reduced
,
as
you
describe
;
and
we
quite
rich
!
"
  
<EOS>
Good
,
true
face
,
as
that
face
of
hers
was
,
and
pleasant
as
it
had
been
to
him
,
Mr
Morfin
,
the
hazel
-
eyed
bachelor
,
since
the
first
time
he
had
ever
looked
upon
it
,
it
pleased
him
less
at
that
moment
,
lighted
with
a
ray
of
exultation
,
than
it
had
ever
pleased
him
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
need
not
remind
you
,
"
said
Harriet
,
casting
down
her
eyes
upon
her
black
dress
,
"
through
what
means
our
circumstances
changed
.
<EOS>
You
have
not
forgotten
that
our
brother
James
,
upon
that
dreadful
day
,
left
no
will
,
no
relations
but
ourselves
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
face
was
pleasanter
to
him
now
,
though
it
was
pale
and
melancholy
,
than
it
had
been
a
moment
since
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
breathe
more
cheerily
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
"
she
said
,
"
our
history
,
the
history
of
both
my
brothers
,
in
connexion
with
the
unfortunate
,
unhappy
gentleman
,
of
whom
you
have
spoken
so
truly
.
<EOS>
You
know
how
few
our
wants
are
---
John
's
and
mine
---
and
what
little
use
we
have
for
money
,
after
the
life
we
have
led
together
for
so
many
years
;
and
now
that
he
is
earning
an
income
that
is
ample
for
us
,
through
your
kindness
.
<EOS>
You
are
not
unprepared
to
hear
what
favour
<EOS>
I
have
come
to
ask
of
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
know
.
<EOS>
I
was
,
a
minute
ago
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
think
,
I
am
not
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Of
my
dead
brother
I
say
nothing
.
<EOS>
If
the
dead
know
what
we
do
---
but
you
understand
me
.
<EOS>
Of
my
living
brother
I
could
say
much
:
but
what
need
I
say
more
,
than
that
this
act
of
duty
,
in
which
I
have
come
to
ask
your
indispensable
assistance
,
is
his
own
,
and
that
he
can
not
rest
until
it
is
performed
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
raised
her
eyes
again
;
and
the
light
of
exultation
in
her
face
begin
to
appear
beautiful
,
in
the
observant
eyes
that
watched
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
sir
,
"
she
went
on
to
say
,
"
It
must
be
done
very
quietly
and
secretly
.
<EOS>
Your
experience
and
knowledge
will
point
out
a
way
of
doing
it
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
may
,
perhaps
,
be
led
to
believe
that
it
is
something
saved
,
unexpectedly
,
from
the
wreck
of
his
fortunes
;
or
that
it
is
a
voluntary
tribute
to
his
honourable
and
upright
character
,
from
some
of
those
with
whom
he
has
had
great
dealings
;
or
that
it
is
some
old
lost
debt
repaid
.
<EOS>
There
must
be
many
ways
of
doing
it
.
<EOS>
I
know
you
will
choose
the
best
.
<EOS>
The
favour
I
have
come
to
ask
is
,
that
you
will
do
it
for
us
in
your
own
kind
,
generous
,
considerate
manner
.
<EOS>
That
you
will
never
speak
of
it
to
John
,
whose
chief
happiness
in
this
act
of
restitution
is
to
do
it
secretly
,
unknown
,
and
unapproved
of
:
that
only
a
very
small
part
of
the
inheritance
may
be
reserved
to
us
,
until
Mr
Dombey
shall
have
possessed
the
interest
of
the
rest
for
the
remainder
of
his
life
;
that
you
will
keep
our
secret
,
faithfully
---
but
that
I
am
sure
you
will
;
and
that
,
from
this
time
,
it
may
seldom
be
whispered
,
even
between
you
and
me
,
but
may
live
in
any
thoughts
only
as
a
new
reason
for
thankfulness
to
Heaven
,
and
joy
and
pride
in
my
brother
.
"
  
<EOS>
Such
a
look
of
exultation
there
may
be
on
Angels
'
faces
,
when
the
one
repentant
sinner
enters
Heaven
,
among
ninety
-
nine
just
men
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
dimmed
or
tarnished
by
the
joyful
tears
that
filled
her
eyes
,
but
was
the
brighter
for
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Harriet
,
"
said
Mr
Morfin
,
after
a
silence
,
"
I
was
not
prepared
for
this
.
<EOS>
Do
I
understand
you
that
you
wish
to
make
your
own
part
in
the
inheritance
available
for
your
good
purpose
,
as
well
as
John
's
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"
When
we
have
shared
everything
together
for
so
long
a
time
,
and
have
had
no
care
,
hope
,
or
purpose
apart
,
could
I
bear
to
be
excluded
from
my
share
in
this
?
<EOS>
May
I
not
urge
a
claim
to
be
my
brother
's
partner
and
companion
to
the
last
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven
forbid
that
I
should
dispute
it
!
"
<EOS>
he
replied
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
may
rely
on
your
friendly
help
?
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
we
might
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
a
worse
man
than
,
---
than
I
hope
I
am
,
or
would
willingly
believe
myself
,
if
I
could
not
give
you
that
assurance
from
my
heart
and
soul
.
<EOS>
You
may
,
implicitly
.
<EOS>
Upon
my
honour
,
I
will
keep
your
secret
.
<EOS>
And
if
it
should
be
found
that
Mr
Dombey
is
so
reduced
as
I
fear
he
will
be
,
acting
on
a
determination
that
there
seem
to
be
no
means
of
influencing
,
I
will
assist
you
to
accomplish
the
design
,
on
which
you
and
John
are
jointly
resolved
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
gave
him
her
hand
,
and
thanked
him
with
a
cordial
,
happy
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Harriet
,
"
he
said
,
detaining
it
in
his
.
"
<EOS>
To
speak
to
you
of
the
worth
of
any
sacrifice
that
you
can
make
now
---
above
all
,
of
any
sacrifice
of
mere
money
---
would
be
idle
and
presumptuous
.
<EOS>
To
put
before
you
any
appeal
to
reconsider
your
purpose
or
to
set
narrow
limits
to
it
,
would
be
,
I
feel
,
not
less
so
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
right
to
mar
the
great
end
of
a
great
history
,
by
any
obtrusion
of
my
own
weak
self
.
<EOS>
I
have
every
right
to
bend
my
head
before
what
you
confide
to
me
,
satisfied
that
it
comes
from
a
higher
and
better
source
of
inspiration
than
my
poor
worldly
knowledge
.
<EOS>
I
will
say
only
this
:
I
am
your
faithful
steward
;
and
I
would
rather
be
so
,
and
<EOS>
your
chosen
friend
,
than
I
would
be
anybody
in
the
world
,
except
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
thanked
him
again
,
cordially
,
and
wished
him
good
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
home
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
with
you
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
going
home
now
;
I
have
a
visit
to
make
alone
.
<EOS>
Will
you
come
to
-
morrow
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
'll
come
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
I
'll
think
of
this
,
and
how
we
can
best
proceed
.
<EOS>
And
perhaps
you
'll
think
of
it
,
dear
Harriet
,
and
---
<EOS>
and
---
think
of
me
a
little
in
connexion
with
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
handed
her
down
to
a
coach
she
had
in
waiting
at
the
door
;
and
if
his
landlady
had
not
been
deaf
,
she
would
have
heard
him
muttering
as
he
went
back
upstairs
,
when
the
coach
had
driven
off
,
that
we
were
creatures
of
habit
,
and
it
was
a
sorrowful
habit
to
be
an
old
bachelor
.
  
<EOS>
The
violoncello
lying
on
the
sofa
between
the
two
chairs
,
he
took
it
up
,
without
putting
away
the
vacant
chair
,
and
sat
droning
on
it
,
and
slowly
shaking
his
head
at
the
vacant
chair
,
for
a
long
,
long
time
.
<EOS>
The
expression
he
communicated
to
the
instrument
at
first
,
though
monstrously
pathetic
and
bland
,
was
nothing
to
the
expression
he
communicated
to
this
own
face
,
and
bestowed
upon
the
empty
chair
:
which
was
so
sincere
,
that
he
was
obliged
to
have
recourse
to
Captain
Cuttle
's
remedy
more
than
once
,
and
to
rub
his
face
with
his
sleeve
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
however
,
the
violoncello
,
in
unison
with
his
own
frame
of
mind
,
glided
melodiously
into
the
Harmonious
Blacksmith
,
which
he
played
over
and
over
again
,
until
his
ruddy
and
serene
face
gleamed
like
true
metal
on
the
anvil
of
a
veritable
blacksmith
.
<EOS>
In
fine
,
the
violoncello
and
the
empty
chair
were
the
companions
of
his
bachelorhood
until
nearly
midnight
;
and
when
he
took
his
supper
,
the
violoncello
set
up
on
end
in
the
sofa
corner
,
big
with
the
latent
harmony
of
a
whole
foundry
full
of
harmonious
blacksmiths
,
seemed
to
ogle
the
empty
chair
out
of
its
crooked
eyes
,
with
unutterable
intelligence
.
  
<EOS>
When
Harriet
left
the
house
,
the
driver
of

hired

,
taking
a

that
was
evidently
no

,
went
in

bye

,
through
that

,

.
<EOS>
At

,

.
  
<EOS>
Her

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
In

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
,

<EOS>

The

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

!

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I
should

<EOS>

<EOS>
in

<EOS>
Ha

<EOS>
she

,
<EOS>
will

!
"
  
<EOS>
Her

<EOS>
The

of
Alice
had
all

,
whose

<EOS>
She

"
I

.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Harriet

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Harriet

"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
59
.
<EOS>
Retribution
 
CHANGES
have

the
great

in

long

,
once

's

.
<EOS>
It

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Cook

our

's
credit
ai

,

:
<EOS>
and

"

The

,

<EOS>
"

"

,

<EOS>
"
Yes

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
And

"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"
The

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With

;

,
and
a
month
beyond
it
:
and
clutches
the
money
tight
until
a
receipt
for
the
same
is
duly
signed
,
to
the
last
up
-
stroke
;
when
she
grudgingly
lets
it
go
.
<EOS>
This
form
of
proceeding
Mrs
Pipchin
repeats
with
every
member
of
the
household
,
until
are
paid
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
those
that
choose
can
go
about
their
business
,
"
says
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
and
those
that
choose
can
stay
here
on
board
wages
for
a
week
or
so
,
and
make
themselves
useful
.
<EOS>
Except
,
"
says
the
inflammable
Pipchin
,
"
that
slut
of
a
cook
,
who
'll
go
immediately
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
says
Cook
,
"
she
certainly
will
!
<EOS>
I
wish
you
good
day
,
Mrs
Pipchin
,
and
sincerely
wish
I
could
compliment
you
on
the
sweetness
of
your
appearance
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Get
along
with
you
,
"
says
Mrs
Pipchin
,
stamping
her
foot
.
  
<EOS>
Cook
sails
off
with
an
air
of
beneficent
dignity
,
highly
exasperating
to
Mrs
Pipchin
,
and
is
shortly
joined
below
stairs
by
the
rest
of
the
confederation
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Towlinson
then
says
that
,
in
the
first
place
,
he
would
beg
to
propose
a
little
snack
of
something
to
eat
;
and
over
that
snack
would
desire
to
offer
a
suggestion
which
he
thinks
will
meet
the
position
in
which
they
find
themselves
.
<EOS>
The
refreshment
being
produced
,
and
very
heartily
partaken
of
,
Mr
Towlinson
's
suggestion
is
,
in
effect
,
that
Cook
is
going
,
and
that
if
we
are
not
true
to
ourselves
,
nobody
will
be
true
to
us
.
<EOS>
That
they
have
lived
in
that
house
a
long
time
,
and
exerted
themselves
very
much
to
be
sociable
together
.
<EOS>
(
At
this
,
Cook
says
,
with
emotion
,
"
Hear
,
hear
!
"
<EOS>
and
Mrs
Perch
,
who
is
there
again
,
and
full
to
the
throat
,
sheds
tears
)
.
<EOS>
And
that
he
thinks
,
at
the
present
time
,
the
feeling
ought
to
be
"
Go
one
,
go
all
!
"
<EOS>
The
housemaid
is
much
affected
by
this
generous
sentiment
,
and
warmly
seconds
it
.
<EOS>
Cook
says
she
feels
it
's
right
,
and
only
hopes
it
's
not
done
as
a
compliment
to
her
,
but
from
a
sense
of
duty
.
<EOS>
Mr
Towlinson
replies
,
from
a
sense
of
duty
;
and
that
now
he
is
driven
to
express
his
opinions
,
he
will
openly
say
,
that
he
does
not
think
it
over
-
respectable
to
remain
in
a
house
where
Sales
and
such
-
like
are
carrying
forwards
.
<EOS>
The
housemaid
is
sure
of
it
;
and
relates
,
in
confirmation
,
that
a
strange
man
,
in
a
carpet
cap
,
offered
this
very
morning
to
kiss
her
on
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
Hereupon
,
Mr
Towlinson
is
starting
from
his
chair
,
to
seek
and
"
smash
"
the
offender
;
when
he
is
laid
hold
on
by
the
ladies
,
who
beseech
him
to
calm
himself
,
and
to
reflect
that
it
is
easier
and
wiser
to
leave
the
scene
of
such
indecencies
at
once
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Perch
,
presenting
the
case
in
a
new
light
,
even
shows
that
delicacy
towards
Mr
Dombey
,
shut
up
in
his
own
rooms
,
imperatively
demands
precipitate
retreat
.
<EOS>
"
For
what
,
"
says
the
good
woman
,
"
must
his
feelings
be
,
if
he
was
to
come
upon
any
of
the
poor
servants
that
he
once
deceived
into
thinking
him
immensely
rich
!
"
<EOS>
Cook
is
so
struck
by
this
moral
consideration
that
Mrs
Perch
improves
it
with
several
pious
axioms
,
original
and
selected
.
<EOS>
It
becomes
a
clear
case
that
they
must
all
go
.
<EOS>
Boxes
are
packed
,
cabs
fetched
,
and
at
dusk
that
evening
there
is
not
one
member
of
the
party
left
.
  
<EOS>
The
house
stands
,
large
and
weather
-
proof
,
in
the
long
dull
street
;
but
it
is
a
ruin
,
and
the
rats
fly
from
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
men
in
the
carpet
caps
go
on
tumbling
the
furniture
about
;
and
the
gentlemen
with
the
pens
and
ink
make
out
inventories
of
it
,
and
sit
upon
pieces
of
furniture
never
made
to
be
sat
upon
,
and
eat
bread
and
cheese
from
the
public
-
house
on
other
pieces
of
furniture
never
made
to
be
eaten
on
,
and
seem
to
have
a
delight
in
appropriating
precious
articles
to
strange
uses
.
<EOS>
Chaotic
combinations
of
furniture
also
take
place
.
<EOS>
Mattresses
and
bedding
appear
in
the
dining
-
room
;
the
glass
and
china
get
into
the
conservatory
;
the
great
dinner
service
is
set
out
in
heaps
on
the
long
divan
in
the
large
drawing
-
room
;
and
the
stair
-
wires
,
made
into
fasces
,
decorate
the
marble
chimneypieces
.
<EOS>
Finally
,
a
rug
,
with
a
printed
bill
upon
it
,
is
hung
out
from
the
balcony
;
and
a
similar
appendage
graces
either
side
of
the
hall
door
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
all
day
long
,
there
is
a
retinue
of
mouldy
gigs
and
chaise
-
carts
in
the
street
;
and
herds
of
shabby
vampires
,
Jew
and
Christian
,
over
-
run
the
house
,
sounding
the
plate
-
glass
mirrors
with
their
knuckles
,
striking
discordant
octaves
on
the
Grand
Piano
,
drawing
wet
forefingers
over
the
pictures
,
breathing
on
the
blades
of
the
best
dinner
-
knives
,
punching
the
squabs
of
chairs
and
sofas
with
their
dirty
fists
,
touzling
the
feather
beds
,
opening
and
shutting
all
the
drawers
,
balancing
the
silver
spoons
and
forks
,
looking
into
the
very
threads
of
the
drapery
and
linen
,
and
disparaging
everything
.
<EOS>
There
is
not
a
secret
place
in
the
whole
house
.
<EOS>
Fluffy
and
snuffy
strangers
stare
into
the
kitchen
-
range
as
curiously
as
into
the
attic
clothes
-
press
.
<EOS>
Stout
men
with
napless
hats
on
,
look
out
of
the
bedroom
windows
,
and
cut
jokes
with
friends
in
the
street
.
<EOS>
Quiet
,
calculating
spirits
withdraw
into
the
dressing
-
rooms
with
catalogues
,
and
make
marginal
notes
thereon
,
with
stumps
of
pencils
.
<EOS>
Two
brokers
invade
the
very
fire
-
escape
,
and
take
a
panoramic
survey
of
the
neighbourhood
from
the
top
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
The
swarm
and
buzz
,
and
going
up
and
down
,
endure
for
days
.
<EOS>
The
Capital
Modern
Household
Furniture
,
&
c.
,
is
on
view
.
  
<EOS>
Then
there
is
a
palisade
of
tables
made
in
the
best
drawing
-
room
;
and
on
the
capital
,
french
-
polished
,
extending
,
telescopic
range
of
Spanish
mahogany
dining
-
tables
with
turned
legs
,
the
pulpit
of
the
Auctioneer
is
erected
;
and
the
herds
of
shabby
vampires
,
Jew
and
Christian
,
the
strangers
fluffy
and
snuffy
,
and
the
stout
men
with
the
napless
hats
,
congregate
about
it
and
sit
upon
everything
within
reach
,
mantel
-
pieces
included
,
and
begin
to
bid
.
<EOS>
Hot
,
humming
,
and
dusty
are
the
rooms
all
day
;
and
---
high
above
the
heat
,
hum
,
and
dust
---
the
head
and
shoulders
,
voice
and
hammer
,
of
the
Auctioneer
,
are
ever
at
work
.
<EOS>
The
men
in
the
carpet
caps
get
flustered
and
vicious
with
tumbling
the
Lots
about
,
and
still
the
Lots
are
going
,
going
,
gone
;
still
coming
on
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
there
is
joking
and
a
general
roar
.
<EOS>
This
lasts
all
day
and
three
days
following
.
<EOS>
The
Capital
Modern
Household
Furniture
,
&
c.
,
is
on
sale
.
  
<EOS>
Then
the
mouldy
gigs
and
chaise
-
carts
reappear
;
and
with
them
come
spring
-
vans
and
waggons
,
and
an
army
of
porters
with
knots
.
<EOS>
All
day
long
,
the
men
with
carpet
caps
are
screwing
at
screw
-
drivers
and
bed
-
winches
,
or
staggering
by
the
dozen
together
on
the
staircase
under
heavy
burdens
,
or
upheaving
perfect
rocks
of
Spanish
mahogany
,
best
rose
-
wood
,
or
plate
-
glass
,
into
the
gigs
and
chaise
-
carts
,
vans
and
waggons
.
<EOS>
All
sorts
of
vehicles
of
burden
are
in
attendance
,
from
a
tilted
waggon
to
a
wheelbarrow
.
<EOS>
Poor
Paul
's
little
bedstead
is
carried
off
in
a
donkey
-
tandem
.
<EOS>
For
nearly
a
whole
week
,
the
Capital
Modern
Household
Furniture
,
&
c.
,
is
in
course
of
removal
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
it
is
all
gone
.
<EOS>
Nothing
is
left
about
the
house
but
scattered
leaves
of
catalogues
,
littered
scraps
of
straw
and
hay
,
and
a
battery
of
pewter
pots
behind
the
hall
-
door
.
<EOS>
The
men
with
the
carpet
caps
gather
up
their
screw
-
drivers
and
bed
-
winches
into
bags
,
shoulder
them
,
and
walk
off
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
pen
-
and
-
ink
gentlemen
goes
over
the
house
as
a
last
attention
;
sticking
up
bills
in
the
windows
respecting
the
lease
of
this
desirable
family
mansion
,
and
shutting
the
shutters
.
<EOS>
At
length
he
follows
the
men
with
the
carpet
caps
.
<EOS>
None
of
the
invaders
remain
.
<EOS>
The
house
is
a
ruin
,
and
the
rats
fly
from
it
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
's
apartments
,
together
with
those
locked
rooms
on
the
ground
-
floor
where
the
window
-
blinds
are
drawn
down
close
,
have
been
spared
the
general
devastation
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
has
remained
austere
and
stony
during
the
proceedings
in
her
own
room
;
or
has
occasionally
looked
in
at
the
sale
to
see
what
the
goods
are
fetching
,
and
to
bid
for
one
particular
easy
chair
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
has
been
the
highest
bidder
for
the
easy
chair
,
and
sits
upon
her
property
when
Mrs
Chick
comes
to
see
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
is
my
brother
,
Mrs
Pipchin
?
"
says
Mrs
Chick
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
any
more
than
the
deuce
,
"
says
Mrs
Pipchin
.
<EOS>
"
He
never
does
me
the
honour
to
speak
to
me
.
<EOS>
He
has
his
meat
and
drink
put
in
the
next
room
to
his
own
;
and
what
he
takes
,
he
comes
out
and
takes
when
there
's
nobody
there
.
<EOS>
It
's
no
use
asking
me
.
<EOS>
I
know
no
more
about
him
than
the
man
in
the
south
who
burnt
his
mouth
by
eating
cold
plum
porridge
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
the
acrimonious
Pipchin
says
with
a
flounce
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
good
gracious
me
!
"
cries
Mrs
Chick
blandly
.
<EOS>
"
How
long
is
this
to
last
!
<EOS>
If
my
brother
will
not
make
an
effort
,
Mrs
Pipchin
,
what
is
to
become
of
him
?
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
should
have
thought
he
had
seen
enough
of
the
consequences
of
not
making
an
effort
,
by
this
time
,
to
be
warned
against
that
fatal
error
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hoity
toity
!
<EOS>
"
says
Mrs
Pipchin
,
rubbing
her
nose
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
great
fuss
,
I
think
,
about
it
.
<EOS>
It
an't
so
wonderful
a
case
.
<EOS>
People
have
had
misfortunes
before
now
,
and
been
obliged
to
part
with
their
furniture
.
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
I
have
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
brother
,
"
pursues
Mrs
Chick
profoundly
,
"
is
so
peculiar
---
so
strange
a
man
.
<EOS>
He
is
the
most
peculiar
man
I
ever
saw
.
<EOS>
Would
any
one
believe
that
when
he
received
news
of
the
marriage
and
emigration
of
that
unnatural
child
---
it
's
a
comfort
to
me
,
now
,
to
remember
that
I
always
said
there
was
something
extraordinary
about
that
child
:
but
nobody
minds
me
---
<EOS>
would
anybody
believe
,
I
say
,
that
he
should
then
turn
round
upon
me
and
say
he
had
supposed
,
from
my
manner
,
that
she
had
come
to
my
house
?
<EOS>
Why
,
my
gracious
!
<EOS>
And
would
anybody
believe
that
when
I
merely
say
to
him
,
"
Paul
,
I
may
be
very
foolish
,
and
I
have
no
doubt
I
am
,
but
I
can
not
understand
how
your
affairs
can
have
got
into
this
state
,
"
he
should
actually
fly
at
me
,
and
request
that
I
will
come
to
see
him
no
more
until
he
asks
me
!
<EOS>
Why
,
my
goodness
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
says
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
It
's
a
pity
he
had
n't
a
little
more
to
do
with
mines
.
<EOS>
They
'd
have
tried
his
temper
for
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
,
"
resumes
Mrs
Chick
,
quite
regardless
of
Mrs
Pipchin
's
observations
,
"
is
it
to
end
in
?
<EOS>
That
's
what
I
want
to
know
.
<EOS>
What
does
my
brother
mean
to
do
?
<EOS>
He
must
do
something
.
<EOS>
It
's
of
no
use
remaining
shut
up
in
his
own
rooms
.
<EOS>
Business
wo
n't
come
to
him
.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
He
must
go
to
it
.
<EOS>
Then
why
do
n't
he
go
!
<EOS>
He
knows
where
to
go
,
I
suppose
,
having
been
a
man
of
business
all
his
life
.
<EOS>
Very
good
.
<EOS>
Then
why
not
go
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
,
after
forging
this
powerful
chain
of
reasoning
,
remains
silent
for
a
minute
to
admire
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
"
says
the
discreet
lady
,
with
an
argumentative
air
,
"
who
ever
heard
of
such
obstinacy
as
his
staying
shut
up
here
through
all
these
dreadful
disagreeables
?
<EOS>
It
's
not
as
if
there
was
no
place
for
him
to
go
to
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
could
have
come
to
our
house
.
<EOS>
He
knows
he
is
at
home
there
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
Mr
Chick
has
perfectly
bored
about
it
,
and
I
said
with
my
own
lips
,
"
Why
surely
,
Paul
,
you
do
n't
imagine
that
because
your
affairs
have
got
into
this
state
,
you
are
the
less
at
home
to
such
near
relatives
as
ourselves
?
<EOS>
You
do
n't
imagine
that
we
are
like
the
rest
of
the
world
?
"
<EOS>
But
no
<EOS>
;
here
he
stays
all
through
,
and
here

is
.
<EOS>
Why
,
good
gracious
me
,
suppose
the
house
was
to
be
let
!
<EOS>
What
would
he
do

?
<EOS>
He
could

remain

.
<EOS>
If

,
there

ejectment
,
an

Doe
,
and

;
and
then

must

.
<EOS>
Then
why
not
go
at
first
instead

?
<EOS>
And
that
brings
me
back
to
what
I
said
just
now
,
and
I
naturally
ask
what
is
to
be
the
end
