?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
's

,

I

,
"

Pipchin
,
"

enough

.
<EOS>
I
'm
going
to
take
myself
off
in
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
a
which
,
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
says
Mrs
Chick
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
a
jiffy
,
"
retorts
Mrs
Pipchin
sharply
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
well
!
<EOS>
really
I
ca
n't
blame
you
,
Mrs
Pipchin
,
"
says
Mrs
Chick
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
pretty
much
the
same
to
me
,
if
you
could
,
"
replies
the
sardonic
Pipchin
.
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
I
'm
going
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
stop
here
.
<EOS>
I
should
be
dead
in
a
week
.
<EOS>
I
had
to
cook
my
own
pork
chop
yesterday
,
and
I
'm
not
used
to
it
.
<EOS>
My
constitution
will
be
giving
way
next
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
had
a
very
fair
connexion
at
Brighton
when
I
came
here
---
little
Pankey
's
folks
alone
were
worth
a
good
eighty
pounds
a
-
year
to
me
---
and
I
ca
n't
afford
to
throw
it
away
.
<EOS>
I
've
written
to
my
niece
,
and
she
expects
me
by
this
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
spoken
to
my
brother
?
"
inquires
Mrs
Chick
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
it
's
very
easy
to
say
speak
to

,
"
retorts

.
<EOS>
"
How
is
it
done
?
<EOS>
I
called

him
yesterday
,
that
I
was
no
use
here
,
and
that

had

Mrs

.
<EOS>
He
grunted
something

other
that
meant
yes
,
and
I
sent
!
<EOS>
Grunt
indeed
!
<EOS>
If
he
had
been
Mr
Pipchin
,
he
'd
have
had
some
reason
to
grunt
.
<EOS>
Yah
!
<EOS>
I
've
no
patience
with
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Here
this
exemplary
female
,
who
has
pumped
up
so
much
fortitude

from
the
depths
of
the
Peruvian

,
rises
from
her
cushioned

to
see
Mrs
Chick
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Chick
,
deploring
to
the
last
the
peculiar
character
of
her
brother
,
noiselessly
retires
,
much
occupied
with
her
own
sagacity
and

.
  
<EOS>
In

evening
Mr
Toodle
,
being
off

,
arrives

and

box
,
and

,
with

,
in

hall
of
the
empty
house
,
the
retired

of

Mr
Toodle
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,

,

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

an
ingein

,

well

,

,

,

<EOS>
for

past
.
<EOS>
But

past
,

,

.
<EOS>
To
them
which
is
in
adversity
,

,

is
a
cord'l
.
<EOS>
So

's

another

,

.
<EOS>
You

;

views

,

's
right

to

.
<EOS>
Good

,
Polly
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
by
this
time
looms
dark
in
her
black
bombazeen
skirts
,
black
bonnet
,
and
shawl
;
and
has
her
personal
property
packed

;
and
has
her
chair
(
late
a
favourite
chair
of
Mr
Dombey
's
and
the
dead

of

)
ready

;
and

fly
-

,
going
to
-

on

,
which
is
to
call
for
her
,
by
private

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
Presently
it
comes
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
's
wardrobe
being
handed
in
and
stowed
away
,
Mrs
Pipchin
's
chair
is
next
handed
in
,
and
placed
in
a

among
certain

of

;
it
being

the
amiable
woman
to

during

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
herself
is
next
handed
in
,
and
grimly
takes
her

.
<EOS>
There
is
a
snaky

in
her
hard
grey
eye
,
as
of
anticipated
rounds
of
buttered
toast
,
relays
of

,
worryings
and

of
young
children
,
sharp

at
poor
Berry
,
and
all

of

's

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pipchin
almost
laughs
as
the
fly
-
van
drives
off
,
and
she
composes
her
black
bombazeen
skirts
,
and
settles
herself
among
the
cushions
of
her
easy
chair
.
  
<EOS>
The
house
is
such
a
ruin
that
the
rats
have
fled
,
and
there
is
not
one
left
.
  
<EOS>
But
Polly
,
though
alone
in
the
deserted

---
for
there
is
no
companionship
in
the
shut
-
up
rooms
in
which
its
late
master
hides

---
is
not
alone
long
.
<EOS>
It
is
night
;
and
she
is
sitting
at
work
in
the
housekeeper
's
room
,
trying
to
forget
what
a
lonely
house
it
is
,
and
what
a
history
belongs
to
it
;
when
there
is
a
knock
at
the
hall
door
,
as
loud

as
any
knock
can
be
,
striking
into
such

empty

.
<EOS>
Opening

,
she
returns
across

,

by
a
female
figure
in

close
black
bonnet
.
<EOS>
It
is
Miss
Tox
,
and
Miss
Tox
's

are
red
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Polly
,
"

Miss
Tox
,
"

with

just

,
I

message
that
you
left

;

I

,

came

.
<EOS>
Is

here
<EOS>
but

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
not
a

.
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen

?
"
<EOS>

Tox
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bless

,
"
returns

,
"
<EOS>
no
;
he
has
not

this
many

.
<EOS>
They

me
he
never

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

said

ill
?
"
<EOS>

Tox
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

know

,
"
returns

,
"
except
in

.
<EOS>
He
must

very
bad
there
poor

!
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
's
sympathy
is
such
that
she
can
scarcely
speak
.
<EOS>
She
is
no
chicken
,
but
she
has
not
grown
tough
with
age
and

.
<EOS>
Her
heart
is
very
tender
,
her
compassion
very
genuine
,
her
homage
very
real
.
<EOS>
Beneath
the
locket
with
the
fishy
eye
in
it
,
Miss
Tox
bears
better
qualities
than
many
a
less
whimsical
outside
;
such

as
will
outlive
,
by
many

of
the
sun
,
the
best
outsides
and
brightest
husks
that
fall
in
the

of
the
great

.
  
<EOS>
It
is
long
before
Miss
Tox
goes
away
,
and
before
Polly
,
with
a

flaring
on
the

stairs
,
looks
after
her
,
for
company
,
down
the
street
,
and
feels
unwilling
to
go
back
into
the
dreary
house
,
and
jar
its
emptiness
with
the
heavy
fastenings
of
the
door
,
and
glide
away
to
bed
.
<EOS>
But
all
this
Polly
does
;
and
in
the
morning
sets
in
one
of
those
darkened
rooms
such
matters
as
she
has
been
advised
to
prepare
,
and
then
retires
and
enters
them
no
more
until
next
morning
at
the
same
hour
.
<EOS>
There
are
bells
there
,
but
they
never
ring
;
and
though
she
can
sometimes
hear
a
footfall
going
to
and
fro
,
it
never
comes
out
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
returns
early
in
the
day
.
<EOS>
It
then
begins
to
be
Miss
Tox
's
occupation
to
prepare
little
dainties
---
or
what
are
such
to
her
---
to
be
carried
into
these
rooms
next
morning
.
<EOS>
She
derives
so
much
satisfaction
from
the
pursuit
,
that
she
enters
on
it
regularly
from
that
time
;
and
brings
daily
in
her
little
basket
,
various
choice
condiments
selected
from
the
scanty
stores
of
the
deceased
owner
of
the
powered
head
and
pigtail
.
<EOS>
She
likewise
brings
,
in
sheets
of
curl
-
paper
,
morsels
of
cold
meats
,
tongues
of
sheep
,
halves
of
fowls
,
for
her
own
dinner
;
and
sharing
these
collations
with
Polly
,
passes
the
greater
part
of
her
time
in
the
ruined
house
that
the
rats
have
fled
from
:
hiding
,
in
a
fright
at
every
sound
,
stealing
in
and
out
like
a
criminal
;
only
desiring
to
be
true
to
the
fallen
object
of
her
admiration
,
unknown
to
him
,
unknown
to
all
the
world
but
one
poor
simple
woman
.
  
<EOS>
The
Major
knows
it
;
but
no
one
is
the
wiser
for
that
,
though
the
Major
is
much
the
merrier
.
<EOS>
The
Major
,
in
a
fit
of
curiosity
,
has
charged
the
Native
to
watch
the
house
sometimes
,
and
find
out
what
becomes
of
Dombey
.
<EOS>
The
Native
has
reported
Miss
Tox
's
fidelity
,
and
the
Major
has
nearly
choked
himself
dead
with
laughter
.
<EOS>
He
is
permanently
bluer
from
that
hour
,
and
constantly
wheezes
to
himself
,
<EOS>
his
lobster
eyes
starting
out
of
his
head
,
"
Damme
,
Sir
,
the
woman
's
a
born
idiot
!
"
  
<EOS>
And
the
ruined
man
.
<EOS>
How
does
he
pass
the
hours
,
alone
?
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
remember
it
in
that
room
,
years
to
come
!
"
<EOS>
He
did
remember
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
heavy
on
his
mind
now
;
heavier
than
all
the
rest
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
remember
it
in
that
room
,
years
to
come
!
<EOS>
The
rain
that
falls
upon
the
roof
,
the
wind
that
mourns
outside
the
door
,
may
have
foreknowledge
in
their
melancholy
sound
.
<EOS>
Let
him
remember
it
in
that
room
,
years
to
come
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
did
remember
it
.
<EOS>
In
the
miserable
night
he
thought
of
it
;
in
the
dreary
day
,
the
wretched
dawn
,
the
ghostly
,
memory
-
haunted
twilight
.
<EOS>
He
did
remember
it
.
<EOS>
In
agony
,
in
sorrow
,
in
remorse
,
in
despair
!
"
<EOS>
Papa
!
<EOS>
papa
!
<EOS>
Speak
to
me
,
dear
papa
!
"
<EOS>
He
heard
the
words
again
,
and
saw
the
face
.
<EOS>
He
saw
it
fall
upon
the
trembling
hands
,
and
heard
the
one
prolonged
low
cry
go
upward
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
fallen
,
never
to
be
raised
up
any
more
.
<EOS>
For
the
night
of
his
worldly
ruin
there
was
no
to
-
morrow
's
sun
;
for
the
stain
of
his
domestic
shame
there
was
no
purification
;
nothing
,
thank
Heaven
,
could
bring
his
dead
child
back
to
life
.
<EOS>
But
that
which
he
might
have
made
so
different
in
all
the
Past
---
which
might
have
made
the
Past
itself
so
different
,
though
this
he
hardly
thought
of
now
---
that
which
was
his
own
work
,
that
which
he
could
so
easily
have
wrought
into
a
blessing
,
and
had
set
himself
so
steadily
for
years
to
form
into
a
curse
:
that
was
the
sharp
grief
of
his
soul
.
  
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
He
did
remember
it
!
<EOS>
The
rain
that
fell
upon
the
roof
,
the
wind
that
mourned
outside
the
door
that
night
,
had
had
foreknowledge
in
their
melancholy
sound
.
<EOS>
He
knew
,
now
,
what
he
had
done
.
<EOS>
He
knew
,
now
,
that
he
had
called
down
that
upon
his
head
,
which
bowed
it
lower
that
the
heaviest
stroke
of
fortune
.
<EOS>
He
knew
,
now
,
what
it
was
to
be
rejected
and
deserted
;
now
,
when
every
loving
blossom
he
had
withered
in
his
innocent
daughter
's
heart
was
snowing
down
in
ashes
on
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
thought
of
her
,
as
she
had
been
that
night
when
he
and
his
bride
came
home
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
her
as
she
had
been
,
in
all
the
home
-
events
,
of
the
abandoned
House
.
<EOS>
He
thought
,
now
,
that
of
all
around
him
,
she
alone
had
never
changed
.
<EOS>
His
boy
had
faded
into
dust
,
his
proud
wife
had
sunk
into
a
polluted
creature
,
his
flatterer
and
friend
had
been
transformed
into
the
worst
of
villains
,
his
riches
had
melted
away
,
the
very
walls
that
sheltered
him
looked
on
him
as
a
stranger
;
she
alone
had
turned
the
same
mild
gentle
look
upon
him
always
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
to
the
latest
and
the
last
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
changed
to
him
---
nor
had
he
ever
changed
to
her
---
and
she
was
lost
.
  
<EOS>
As
,
one
by
one
,
they
fell
away
before
his
mind
---
<EOS>
his
baby
-
hope
,
his
wife
,
his
friend
,
his
fortune
---
oh
how
the
mist
,
through
which
he
had
seen
her
,
cleared
,
and
showed
him
her
true
self
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
how
much
better
than
this
that
he
had
loved
her
as
had
hid
boy
,
and
lost
her
as
he
had
his
boy
,
and
laid
them
in
their
early
grave
together
!
  
<EOS>
In
his
pride
---
for
he
was
proud
yet
---
<EOS>
he
let
the
world
go
from
him
freely
.
<EOS>
As
it
fell
away
,
he
shook
it
off
.
<EOS>
Whether
he
imagined
its
face
as
expressing
pity
for
him
,
or
indifference
to
him
,
he
shunned
it
alike
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
same
degree
to
be
avoided
,
in
either
aspect
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
idea
of
any
one
companion
in
his
misery
,
but
the
one
he
had
driven
away
.
<EOS>
What
he
would
have
said
to
her
,
or
what
consolation
submitted
to
receive
from
her
,
he
never
pictured
to
himself
.
<EOS>
But
he
always
knew
she
would
have
been
true
to
him
,
if
he
had
suffered
her
.
<EOS>
He
always
knew
she
would
have
loved
him
better
now
,
than
at
any
other
time
:
he
was
as
certain
that
it
was
in
her
nature
,
as
he
was
that
there
was
a
sky
above
him
;
and
he
sat
thinking
so
,
in
his
loneliness
,
from
hour
to
hour
.
<EOS>
Day
after
day
uttered
this
speech
;
night
after
night
showed
him
this
knowledge
.
  
<EOS>
It
began
,
beyond
all
doubt
(
however
slow
it
advanced
for
some
time
)
,
in
the
receipt
of
her
young
husband
's
letter
,
and
the
certainty
that
she
was
gone
.
<EOS>
And
yet
---
so
proud
he
was
in
his
ruin
,
or
so
reminiscent
of
her
,
only
as
something
that
might
have
been
his
,
but
was
lost
beyond
redemption
---
that
if
he
could
have
heard
her
voice
in
an
adjoining
room
,
he
would
not
have
gone
to
her
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
have
seen
her
in
the
street
,
and
she
had
done
no
more
than
look
at
him
as
she
had
been
used
to
look
,
he
would
have
passed
on
with
his
old
cold
unforgiving
face
,
and
not
addressed
her
,
or
relaxed
it
,
though
his
heart
should
have
broken
soon
afterwards
.
<EOS>
However
turbulent
his
thoughts
,
or
harsh
is
anger
had
been
,
at
first
,
concerning
her
marriage
,
or
her
husband
<EOS>
,
that
was
all
past
now
.
<EOS>
He
chiefly
thought
of
what
might
have
been
,
and
what
was
not
.
<EOS>
What
was
,
was
all
summed
up
in
this
:
that
she
was
lost
,
and
he
bowed
down
with
sorrow
and
remorse
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
he
felt
that
he
had
had
two
children
born
to
him
in
that
house
,
and
that
between
him
and
the
bare
wide
empty
walls
there
was
a
tie
,
mournful
,
but
hard
to
rend
asunder
,
connected
with
a
double
childhood
,
and
a
double
loss
.
<EOS>
He
had
thought
to
leave
the
house
---
knowing
he
must
go
,
not
knowing
whither
---
upon
the
evening
of
the
day
on
which
this
feeling
first
struck
root
in
his
breast
;
but
he
resolved
to
stay
another
night
,
and
in
the
night
to
ramble
through
the
rooms
once
more
.
  
<EOS>
He
came
out
of
his
solitude
when
it
was
the
dead
of
night
,
and
with
a
candle
in
his
hand
went
softly
up
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
Of
all
the
footmarks
there
,
making
them
as
common
as
the
common
street
,
there
was
not
one
,
he
thought
,
but
had
seemed
at
the
time
to
set
itself
upon
his
brain
while
he
had
kept
close
,
listening
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at
their
number
,
and
their
hurry
,
and
contention
---
foot
treading
foot
out
,
and
upward
track
and
downward
jostling
one
another
---
and
thought
,
with
absolute
dread
and
wonder
,
how
much
he
must
have
suffered
during
that
trial
,
and
what
a
changed
man
he
had
cause
to
be
.
<EOS>
He
thought
,
besides
,
oh
was
there
,
somewhere
in
the
world
,
a
light
footstep
that
might
have
worn
out
in
a
moment
half
those
marks
!
---
and
bent
his
head
,
and
wept
as
he
went
up
.
  
<EOS>
He
almost
saw
it
,
going
on
before
.
<EOS>
He
stopped
,
looking
up
towards
the
skylight
;
and
a
figure
,
childish
itself
,
but
carrying
a
child
,
and
singing
as
it
went
,
seemed
to
be
there
again
.
<EOS>
Anon
,
it
was
the
same
figure
,
alone
,
stopping
for
an
instant
,
with
suspended
breath
;
the
bright
hair
clustering
loosely
round
its
tearful
face
;
and
looking
back
at
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
wandered
through
the
rooms
:
lately
so
luxurious
;
now
so
bare
and
dismal
and
so
changed
,
apparently
,
even
in
their
shape
and
size
.
<EOS>
The
press
of
footsteps
was
as
thick
here
;
and
the
same
consideration
of
the
suffering
he
had
had
,
perplexed
and
terrified
him
.
<EOS>
He
began
to
fear
that
all
this
intricacy
in
his
brain
would
drive
him
mad
;
and
that
his
thoughts
already
lost
coherence
as
the
footprints
did
,
and
were
pieced
on
to
one
another
,
with
the
same
trackless
involutions
,
and
varieties
of
indistinct
shapes
.
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
so
much
as
know
in
which
of
these
rooms
she
had
lived
,
when
she
was
alone
.
<EOS>
He
was
glad
to
leave
them
,
and
go
wandering
higher
up
.
<EOS>
Abundance
of
associations
were
here
,
connected
with
his
false
wife
,
his
false
friend
and
servant
,
his
false
grounds
of
pride
;
but
he
put
them
all
by
now
,
and
only
recalled
miserably
,
weakly
,
fondly
,
his
two
children
.
  
<EOS>
Everywhere
,
the
footsteps
!
<EOS>
They
had
had
no
respect
for
the
old
room
high
up
,
where
the
little
bed
had
been
;
he
could
hardly
find
a
clear
space
there
,
to
throw
himself
down
,
on
the
floor
,
against
the
wall
,
poor
broken
man
,
and
let
his
tears
flow
as
they
would
.
<EOS>
He
had
shed
so
many
tears
here
,
long
ago
,
that
he
was
less
ashamed
of
his
weakness
in
this
place
than
in
any
other
---
perhaps
,
with
that
consciousness
,
had
made
excuses
to
himself
for
coming
here
.
<EOS>
Here
,
with
stooping
shoulders
,
and
his
chin
dropped
on
his
breast
,
he
had
come
.
<EOS>
Here
,
thrown
upon
the
bare
boards
,
in
the
dead
of
night
,
he
wept
,
alone
---
a
proud
man
,
even
then
;
who
,
if
a
kind
hand
could
have
been
stretched
out
,
or
a
kind
face
could
have
looked
in
would
have
risen
up
,
and
turned
away
,
and
gone
down
to
his
cell
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
day
broke
he
was
shut
up
in
his
rooms
again
.
<EOS>
He
had
meant
to
go
away
to
-
day
,
but
clung
to
this
tie
in
the
house
as
<EOS>
the
last
and
only
thing
left
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
would
go
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
came
.
<EOS>
He
would
go
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Every
night
,
within
the
knowledge
of
no
human
creature
,
he
came
forth
,
and
wandered
through
the
despoiled
house
like
a
ghost
.
<EOS>
Many
a
morning
when
the
day
broke
,
his
altered
face
,
drooping
behind
the
closed
blind
in
his
window
,
imperfectly
transparent
to
the
light
as
yet
,
pondered
on
the
loss
of
his
two
children
.
<EOS>
It
was
one
child
no
more
.
<EOS>
He
reunited
them
in
his
thoughts
,
and
they
were
never
asunder
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
that
he
could
have
united
them
in
his
past
love
,
and
in
death
,
and
that
one
had
not
been
so
much
worse
than
dead
!
  
<EOS>
Strong
mental
agitation
and
disturbance
was
no
novelty
to
him
,
even
before
his
late
suffering
.
<EOS>
It
never
is
,
to
obstinate
and
sullen
natures
;
for
they
struggle
hard
to
be
such
.
<EOS>
Ground
,
long
undermined
,
will
often
fall
down
in
a
moment
;
what
was
undermined
here
in
so
many
ways
,
weakened
,
and
crumbled
,
little
by
little
,
more
and
more
,
as
the
hand
moved
on
the
dial
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
he
began
to
think
he
need
not
go
at
all
.
<EOS>
He
might
yet
give
up
what
his
creditors
had
spared
him
(
that
they
had
not
spared
him
more
,
was
his
own
act
)
,
and
only
sever
the
tie
between
him
and
the
ruined
house
,
by
severing
that
other
link
  
<EOS>
It
was
then
that
his
footfall
was
audible
in
the
late
house
-
keeper
's
room
,
as
he
walked
to
and
fro
;
but
not
audible
in
its
true
meaning
,
or
it
would
have
had
an
appalling
sound
.
  
<EOS>
The
world
was
very
busy
and
restless
about
him
.
<EOS>
He
became
aware
of
that
again
.
<EOS>
It
was
whispering
and
babbling
.
<EOS>
It
was
never
quiet
.
<EOS>
This
,
and
the
intricacy
and
complication
of
the
footsteps
,
harassed
him
to
death
.
<EOS>
Objects
began
to
take
a
bleared
and
russet
colour
in
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
Dombey
and
Son
was
no
more
---
his
children
no
more
.
<EOS>
This
must
be
thought
of
,
well
,
to
-
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
He
thought
of
it
to
-
morrow
;
and
sitting
thinking
in
his
chair
,
saw
in
the
glass
,
from
time
to
time
,
this
picture
:
  
A
spectral
,
haggard
,
wasted
likeness
of
himself
,
brooded
and
brooded
over
the
empty
fireplace
.
<EOS>
Now
it
lifted
up
its
head
,
examining
the
lines
and
hollows
in
its
face
;
now
hung
it
down
again
,
and
brooded
afresh
.
<EOS>
Now
it
rose
and
walked
about
;
now
passed
into
the
next
room
,
and
came
back
with
something
from
the
dressing
-
table
in
its
breast
.
<EOS>
Now
,
it
was
looking
at
the
bottom
of
the
door
,
and
thinking
.
   
<EOS>
---
Hush
!
<EOS>
what
?
  
<EOS>
It
was
thinking
that
if
blood
were
to
trickle
that
way
,
and
to
leak
out
into
the
hall
,
it
must
be
a
long
time
going
so
far
.
<EOS>
It
would
move
so
stealthily
and
slowly
,
creeping
on
,
with
her
a
lazy
little
pool
,
and
there
a
start
,
and
then
another
little
pool
,
that
a
desperately
wounded
man
could
only
be
discovered
through
its
means
,
either
dead
or
dying
.
<EOS>
When
it
had
thought
of
this
a
long
while
,
it
got
up
again
,
and
walked
to
and
fro
with
its
hand
in
its
breast
.
<EOS>
He
glanced
at
it
occasionally
,
very
curious
to
watch
its
motions
,
and
he
marked
how
wicked
and
murderous
that
hand
looked
.
  
<EOS>
Now
it
was
thinking
again
!
<EOS>
What
was
it
thinking
?
  
<EOS>
Whether
they
would
tread
in
the
blood
when
it
crept
so
far
,
and
carry
it
about
the
house
among
those
many
prints
of
feet
,
or
even
out
into
the
street
.
  
<EOS>
It
sat
down
,
with
its
eyes
upon
the
empty
fireplace
,
and
as
it
lost
itself
in
thought
there
shone
into
the
room
a
gleam
of
light
;
a
ray
of
sun
.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
unmindful
,
and
sat
thinking
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
it
rose
,
with
a
terrible
face
,
and
that
guilty
hand
grasping
what
was
in
its
breast
.
<EOS>
Then
it
was
arrested
by
a
cry
---
a
wild
,
loud
,
piercing
,
loving
rapturous
cry
---
and
he
only
saw
his
own
reflection
in
the
glass
,
and
at
his
knees
,
his
daughter
!
  
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
His
daughter
!
<EOS>
Look
at
her
!
<EOS>
Look
here
!
<EOS>
Down
upon
the
ground
,
clinging
to
him
,
calling
to
him
,
folding
her
hands
,
praying
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
!
<EOS>
Dearest
papa
!
<EOS>
Pardon
me
,
forgive
me
!
<EOS>
I
have
come
back
to
ask
forgiveness
on
my
knees
.
<EOS>
I
never
can
be
happy
more
,
without
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Unchanged
still
.
<EOS>
Of
all
the
world
,
unchanged
.
<EOS>
Raising
the
same
face
to
his
,
as
on
that
miserable
night
.
<EOS>
Asking
his
forgiveness
!
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
papa
,
oh
do
n't
look
strangely
on
me
!
<EOS>
I
never
meant
to
leave
you
.
<EOS>
I
never
thought
of
it
,
before
or
afterwards
.
<EOS>
I
was
frightened
when
I
went
away
,
and
could
not
think
.
<EOS>
Papa
,
dear
,
I
am
changed
.
<EOS>
I
am
penitent
.
<EOS>
I
know
my
fault
.
<EOS>
I
know
my
duty
better
now
.
<EOS>
Papa
,
do
n't
cast
me
off
,
or
I
shall
die
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
tottered
to
his
chair
.
<EOS>
He
felt
her
draw
his
arms
about
her
neck
;
he
felt
her
put
her
own
round
his
;
he
felt
her
kisses
on
his
face
;
he
felt
her
wet
cheek
laid
against
his
own
;
he
felt
---
<EOS>
oh
,
how
deeply
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
all
that
he
had
done
.
  
<EOS>
Upon
the
breast
that
he
had
bruised
,
against
the
heart
that
he
had
almost
broken
,
she
laid
his
face
,
now
covered
with
his
hands
,
and
said
,
sobbing
:
  
"
Papa
,
love
,
I
am
a
mother
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
child
who
will
soon
call
Walter
by
the
name
by
which
I
call
you
.
<EOS>
When
it
was
born
,
and
when
I
knew
how
much
I
loved
it
,
I
knew
what
I
had
done
in
leaving
you
.
<EOS>
Forgive
me
,
dear
Papa
!
<EOS>
oh
say
God
bless
me
,
and
my
little
child
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
would
have
said
it
,
if
he
could
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
raised
his
hands
and
besought
her
for
pardon
,
but
she
caught
them
in
her
own
,
and
put
them
down
,
hurriedly
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
little
child
was
born
at
sea
,
Papa
.
<EOS>
I
prayed
to
God
(
and
so
did
Walter
for
me
)
to
spare
me
,
that
I
might
come
home
.
<EOS>
The
moment
I
could
land
,
I
came
back
to
you
.
<EOS>
Never
let
us
be
parted
any
more
,
Papa
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
head
,
now
grey
,
was
encircled
by
her
arm
;
and
he
groaned
to
think
that
never
,
never
,
had
it
rested
so
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
come
home
with
me
,
Papa
,
and
see
my
baby
.
<EOS>
A
boy
,
Papa
.
<EOS>
His
name
is
Paul
.
<EOS>
I
think
---
<EOS>
I
hope
---
he
's
like
---
"
  
Her
tears
stopped
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Papa
,
for
the
sake
of
my
child
,
for
the
sake
of
the
name
we
have
given
him
,
for
my
sake
,
pardon
Walter
.
<EOS>
He
is
so
kind
and
tender
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
happy
with
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
his
fault
that
we
were
married
.
<EOS>
It
was
mine
.
<EOS>
I
loved
him
so
much
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
clung
closer
to
him
,
more
endearing
and
more
earnest
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
the
darling
of
my
heart
,
Papa
.
<EOS>
I
would
die
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
will
love
and
honour
your
as
I
will
.
<EOS>
We
will
teach
our
little
child
to
love
and
honour
you
;
and
we
will
tell
him
,
when
he
can
understand
,
that
you
had
a
son
of
that
name
once
,
and
that
he
died
,
and
you
were
very
sorry
;
but
that
he
is
gone
to
Heaven
,
where
we
all
hope
to
see
him
when
our
time
for
resting
comes
.
<EOS>
Kiss
me
,
Papa
,
as
a
promise
that
you
will
be
reconciled
to
Walter
---
to
my
dearest
husband
---
to
the
father
of
the
little
child
who
taught
me
to
come
back
,
Papa
.
<EOS>
Who
taught
me
to
come
back
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
clung
closer
to
him
,
in
another
burst
of
tears
,
he
kissed
her
on
her
lips
,
and
,
lifting
up
his
eyes
,
said
,
"
Oh
my
God
,
forgive
me
,
for
I
need
it
very
much
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
he
dropped
his
head
again
,
lamenting
over
and
caressing
her
,
and
there
was
not
a
sound
in
all
the
house
for
a
long
,
long
time
;
they
remaining
clasped
in
one
another
's
arms
,
in
the
glorious
sunshine
that
had
crept
in
with
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
He
dressed
himself
for
going
out
,
with
a
docile
submission
to
her
entreaty
;
and
walking
with
a
feeble
gait
,
and
looking
back
,
with
a
tremble
,
at
the
room
in
which
he
had
been
so
long
shut
up
,
and
where
he
had
seen
the
picture
in
the
glass
,
passed
out
with
her
into
the
hall
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
hardly
glancing
round
her
,
lest
she
should
remind
him
freshly
of
their
last
parting
---
for
their
feet
were
on
the
very
stones
where
he
had
struck
her
in
his
madness
---
and
keeping
close
to
him
,
with
her
eyes
upon
his
face
,
and
his
arm
about
her
,
led
him
out
to
a
coach
that
was
waiting
at
the
door
,
and
carried
him
away
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
Miss
Tox
and
Polly
came
out
of
their
concealment
,
and
exulted
tearfully
.
<EOS>
And
then
they
packed
his
clothes
,
and
books
,
and
so
forth
,
with
great
care
;
and
consigned
them
in
due
course
to
certain
persons
sent
by
Florence
in
the
evening
,
to
fetch
them
.
<EOS>
And
then
they
took
a
last
cup
of
tea
in
the
lonely
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
Dombey
and
Son
,
as
I
observed
upon
a
certain
sad
occasion
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
winding
up
a
host
of
recollections
,
"
is
indeed
a
daughter
,
Polly
,
after
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
a
good
one
!
"
exclaimed
Polly
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
;
"
and
it
's
a
credit
to
you
Polly
,
that
you
were
always
her
friend
when
she
was
a
little
child
.
<EOS>
You
were
her
friend
long
before
I
was
,
Polly
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
;
"
and
you
're
a
good
creature
.
<EOS>
Robin
!
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
addressed
herself
to
a
bullet
-
headed
young
man
,
who
appeared
to
be
in
but

,
and
in

,
and
who
was

.
<EOS>
Rising
,
he
disclosed
to
view
the
form
and

of
the
Grinder
.
  
<EOS>
"
Robin
,
"
said

Tox
,
"
I
have
just
observed
to
your
mother
,
as

,
that
she
is
a
good
creature
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
so
she
is
,
<EOS>
Miss.
"
quoth
the
Grinder
,
with
some
feeling
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
Robin
,
"
said
Miss
Tox
,
"
I
am

to

.
<EOS>
Now
,
Robin
,
as
I

,

,
as
my

,
with

respectability
,

I

will
never

that
you
have
,
and
have

,
a
good
mother
,
and
that
your

as

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my

I

,
Miss
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
have

,

is

as

,
Miss
,
as
a
cove
's
---
"
  
"
I
must

,
Robin
,

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
If

,
Miss
as

chap
's
---
"
  
"
Thankee
,
Robin
,
no
,
"

Tox
.
<EOS>
"
I
should

individual
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
a
indiwiddle
's
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Much

,
"

,

;
"

!
<EOS>
"
  
"
---
can

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

---
indiwiddle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

---
"

Indi
---
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
---
widdle
,
"

,
"
to

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Will

,

,
Robin
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
,
Miss
,
"
returned
the
Grinder
;
who
immediately
began
to
use
his
own
personal
grinders
in
a
most
remarkable
manner
,
as
if
he
had
been
on
very
short
allowance
for
a
considerable

.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
,
being
,
in
good
time
,
bonneted
and
shawled
,
and
Polly
too
,
Rob
hugged
his
mother
,
and
followed
his
new
mistress
away
;
so
much
to
the
hopeful

of
Polly
,
that
something
in
her
eyes
made
luminous
rings
round

gas
-
lamps
as

looked
after
him
.
<EOS>
Polly
then
put
out
her
light
,
locked
the
house
-
door
,
delivered
the
key
at
an
agent
's
hard
by
,
and
went
home
as
fast
as
she
could
go
;
rejoicing
in
the
shrill
delight
that
her
unexpected
arrival
would
occasion
there
.
<EOS>
The
great
house
,
dumb
as
to
all
that
had
been
suffered
in
it
,
and
the
changes
it
had
witnessed
,
stood
frowning
like
a
dark
mute
on
the
street
;
baulking
any
nearer
inquiries
with
the
staring
announcement
that
the
lease
of
this
desirable
Family
Mansion
was
to
be
disposed
of
.
    
Chapter
60
.
<EOS>
Chiefly
Matrimonial
 
<EOS>
THE
grand
half
-
yearly
festival
holden
by
Doctor
and
Mrs
Blimber
,
on
which
occasion
<EOS>
they
requested
the
pleasure
of
the
company
of
every
young
gentleman
pursuing
his
studies
in
that
genteel
establishment
,
at
an
early
party
,
when
the
hour
was
half
-
past
seven
o'clock
,
and
when
the
object
was
quadrilles
,
had
duly
taken
place
,
about
this
time
;
and
the
young
gentleman
,
with
no
unbecoming
demonstrations
of
levity
,
had
betaken
themselves
,
in
a
state
of
scholastic
repletion
,
to
their
own
homes
.
<EOS>
Mr
Skettles
had
repaired
abroad
,
permanently
to
grace
the
establishment
of
his
father
Sir
Barnet
Skettles
,
whose
popular
manners
had
obtained
him
a
diplomatic
appointment
,
the
honours
of
which
were
discharged
by
himself
and
Lady
Skettles
,
to
the
satisfaction
even
of
their
own
countrymen
and
countrywomen
:
which
was
considered
almost
miraculous
.
<EOS>
Mr
Tozer
,
now
a
young
man
of
lofty
stature
,
in
Wellington
boots
,
was
so
extremely
full
of
antiquity
as
to
be
nearly
on
a
par
with
a
genuine
ancient
Roman
in
his
knowledge
of
English
:
a
triumph
that
affected
his
good
parents
with
the
tenderest
emotions
,
and
caused
the
father
and
mother
of
Mr
Briggs
(
whose
learning
,
like
ill
-
arranged
luggage
,
was
so
tightly
packed
that
he
could
n't
get
at
anything
he
wanted
)
to
hide
their
diminished
heads
.
<EOS>
The
fruit
laboriously
gathered
from
the
tree
of
knowledge
by
this
latter
young
gentleman
,
in
fact
,
had
been
subjected
to
so
much
pressure
,
that
it
had
become
a
kind
of
intellectual
Norfolk
Biffin
,
and
had
nothing
of
its
original
form
or
flavour
remaining
.
<EOS>
Master
Bitherstone
now
,
on
whom
the
forcing
system
had
the
happier
and
not
uncommon
effect
of
leaving
no
impression
whatever
,
when
the
forcing
apparatus
ceased
to
work
,
was
in
a
much
more
comfortable
plight
;
and
being
then
on
shipboard
,
bound
for
Bengal
,
found
himself
forgetting
,
with
such
admirable
rapidity
,
that
it
was
doubtful
whether
his
declensions
of
noun
-
substantives
would
hold
out
to
the
end
of
the
voyage
.
  
<EOS>
When
Doctor
Blimber
,
in
pursuance
of
the
usual
course
,
would
have
said
to
the
young
gentleman
,
on
the
morning
of
the
party
,
"
Gentlemen
,
we
will
resume
our
studies
on
the
twenty
-
fifth
of
next
month
,
"
he
departed
from
the
usual
course
,
and
said
,
"
Gentlemen
,
when
our
friend
Cincinnatus
retired
to
his
farm
,
he
did
not
present
to
the
senate
any
Roman
whom
he
sought
to
nominate
as
his
successor
.
<EOS>
But
there
is
a
Roman
here
,
"
said
Doctor
Blimber
,
laying
his

on
the
shoulder
of
Mr
Feeder
,
BA
,
"
adolescens
imprimis
gravis
et
doctus
,
gentlemen
,
whom
I
,
a
retiring
Cincinnatus
,
wish
to
present
to
my
little
senate
,
as
their
future
Dictator
.
<EOS>
Gentleman
,
we
will
resume
our
studies
on
the
twenty
-
fifth
of
next
month
,
under
the
auspices
of
Mr
Feeder
,
BA
.
<EOS>
"
At
this
(
which
Doctor
Blimber
had
previously
called
upon
all
the
parents
,
and
urbanely
explained
)
,
the
young
gentlemen
cheered
;
and
Mr
Tozer
,
on
behalf
of
the
rest
,
instantly
presented
the
Doctor
with
a
silver
inkstand
,
in
a
speech
containing
very
little
of
the
mother
-
tongue
,
but
fifteen
quotations
from
the
Latin
,
and
seven
from
the
Greek
,
which
moved
the
younger
of
the
young
gentlemen
to
discontent
and
envy
:
they
remarking
,
"
Oh
,
ah!It
was
all
very
well
for
old
Tozer
,
but
they
did
n't
subscribe
money
for
old
Tozer
to
show
off
with
,
they
supposed
;
did
they
?
<EOS>
What
business
was
it
of
old
Tozer
's
more
than
anybody
else
's
?
<EOS>
It
was
n't
his
inkstand
.
<EOS>
Why
could
n't
he
leave
the
boys
'
property
alone
?
"
and
murmuring
other
expressions
of
their
dissatisfaction
,
which
seemed
to
find
a
greater
relief
in
calling
him
old
Tozer
,
than
in
any
other
available
vent
.
  
<EOS>
Not
a
word
had
been
said
to
the
young
gentlemen
,
nor
a
hint
dropped
,
of
anything
like
a
contemplated
marriage
between
Mr
Feeder
,
BA
,
and
the
fair
Cornelia
Blimber
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Blimber
,
especially
,
seemed
to
take
pains
to
look
as
if
nothing
would
surprise
him
more
;
but
it
was
perfectly
well
known

.
  
<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Toots
;
"
pray
do
not
exert
yourself
.
<EOS>
Do
remember
the
medical
man
!
<EOS>
Captain
Gills
says
---
at
least
he
do
n't
say
,
but
I
imagine
,
from
what
I
can
make
out
,
he
means
---
that
Miss
Dombey
has
brought
her
unfortunate
father
away
from
his
old
house
,
to
one
where
she
and
Walters
are
living
;
that
he
is
lying
very
ill
there
---
supposed
to
be
dying
;
and
that
she
attends
upon
him
night
and
day
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Toots
began
to
cry
quite
bitterly
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
Susan
,
"
replied
Mr
Toots
,
"
do
,
do
,
if
you
possibly
can
,
remember
the
medical
man
!
<EOS>
If
you
ca
n't
,
it
's
of
no
consequence
---
but
do
endeavour
to
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
wife
,
with
her
old
manner
suddenly
resorted
,
so
pathetically
entreated
him
to
take
her
to
her
precious
pet
,
her
little
mistress
,
her
own
darling
,
and
the
like
,
that
Mr
Toots
,
whose
sympathy
and
admiration
were
of
the
strongest
kind
,
consented
from
his
very
heart
of
hearts
;
and
they
agreed
to
depart
immediately
,
and
present
themselves
in
answer
to
the
Captain
's
letter
.
  
<EOS>
Now
some
hidden
sympathies
of
things
,
or
some
coincidences
,
had
that
day
brought
the
Captain
himself
(
toward
whom
Mr
and
Mrs
Toots
were
soon
journeying
)
into
the
flowery
train
of
wedlock
;
not
as
a
principal
,
but
as
an
accessory
.
<EOS>
It
happened
accidentally
,
and
thus
:
  
The
Captain
,
having
seen
Florence
and
her
baby
for
a
moment
,
to
his
unbounded
content
,
and
having
had
a
long
talk
with
Walter
,
turned
out
for
a
walk
;
feeling
it
necessary
to
have
some
solitary
meditation
on
the
changes
of
human
affairs
,
and
to
shake
his
glazed
hat
profoundly
over
the
fall
of
Mr
Dombey
,
for
whom
the
generosity
and
simplicity
of
his
nature
were
awakened
in
a
lively
manner
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
would
have
been
very
low
,
indeed
,
on
the
unhappy
gentleman
's
account
,
but
for
the
recollection
of
the
baby
;
which
afforded
him
such
intense
satisfaction
whenever
it
arose
,
that
he
laughed
aloud
as
he
went
along
the
street
,
and
,
indeed
,
more
than
once
,
in
a
sudden
impulse
of
joy
,
threw
up
his
glazed
hat
and
caught
it
again
;
much
to
the
amazement
of
the
spectators
.
<EOS>
The
rapid
alternations
of
light
and
shade
to
which
these
two
conflicting
subjects
of
reflection
exposed
the
Captain
,
were
so
very
trying
to
his
spirits
,
that
he
felt
a
long
walk
necessary
to
his
composure
;
and
as
there
is
a
great
deal
in
the
influence
of
harmonious
associations
,
he
chose
,
for
the
scene
of
this
walk
,
his
old
neighbourhood
,
down
among
the
mast
,
oar
,
and
block
makers
,
ship
-
biscuit
bakers
,
coal
-
whippers
,
pitch
-
kettles
,
sailors
,
canals
,
docks
,
swing
-
bridges
,
and
other
soothing
objects
.
   
<EOS>
These
peaceful
scenes
,
and
particularly
the
region
of
Lime
-
house
Hole
and
thereabouts
,
were
so
influential
in
calming
the
Captain
,
that
he
walked
on
with
restored
tranquillity
,
and
was
,
in
fact
,
regaling
himself
,
under
his
breath
,
with
the
ballad
of
Lovely
Peg
,
when
,
on
turning
a
corner
,
he
was
suddenly
transfixed
and
rendered
speechless
by
a
triumphant
procession
that
he
beheld
advancing
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
This
awful
demonstration
was
headed
by
that
determined
woman
,
Mrs
MacStinger
,
who
,
preserving
a
countenance
of
inexorable
resolution
,
and
wearing
conspicuously
attached
to
her
obdurate
bosom
<EOS>
a
stupendous
watch
and
appendages
,
which
the
Captain
recognised
at
a
glance
as
the
property
of
Bunsby
,
conducted
under
her
arm
<EOS>
no
other
than
that
sagacious
mariner
;
he
,
with
the
distraught
and
melancholy
visage
of
a
captive
borne
into
a
foreign
land
,
meekly
resigning
himself
to
her
will
.
<EOS>
Behind
them
appeared
the
young
MacStingers
,
in
a
body
,
exulting
.
<EOS>
Behind
them
,
two
ladies
of
a
terrible
and
steadfast
aspect
,
leading
between
them
a
short
gentleman
in
a
tall
hat
,
who
likewise
exulted
.
<EOS>
In
the
wake
,
appeared
Bunsby
's
boy
,
bearing
umbrellas
.
<EOS>
The
whole
were
in
good
marching
order
;
and
a
dreadful
smartness
that
pervaded
the
party
would
have
sufficiently
announced
,
if
the
intrepid

of
the
ladies
had
been
wanting
,
that
it
was
a
procession
of
sacrifice
,
and
that
the
victim
was
Bunsby
.
  
<EOS>
The
first
impulse
of
the
Captain
was
to
run
away
.
<EOS>
This
also
appeared
to
be
the
first
impulse
of
Bunsby
,
hopeless
as
its
execution
must
have
proved
.
<EOS>
But
a
cry
of
recognition
proceeding
from
the
party
,
and
Alexander
MacStinger
running
up
to
the
Captain
with
open
arms
,
the
Captain
struck
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Cap'en
Cuttle
!
"
said
Mrs
MacStinger
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
indeed
a
meeting
!
<EOS>
I
bear
no
malice
now
.
<EOS>
Cap'en
Cuttle
---
you
need
n't
fear
that
I
'm
a
going
to
cast
any
reflections
.
<EOS>
I
hope
to
go
to
the
altar
in
another
spirit
.
"
<EOS>
Here
Mrs
MacStinger
paused
,
and
drawing

up
,
and
inflating

with
a
long

,
said
,
in
allusion
to
the
victim
,
"
<EOS>
My
'
usband
,
Cap'en
Cuttle
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
abject
Bunsby
looked
neither
to

right
nor

the
left
,
nor
at
his
bride
,
nor
at
his
friend
,
but
straight
before
him
at
nothing
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
putting
out
his
hand
,
Bunsby
put
out
his
;
but
,
in
answer
to
the
Captain
's
greeting
,
spake
no
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
Cap'en
Cuttle
,
"
said
Mrs
MacStinger
,
"
if
you
would
wish
to
heal

,
and
to
see

last
of
your
friend
,
my
'
usband
,
as

,
we
should
be
'
appy
of
your
company
to
chapel
.
<EOS>
Here
is
a
lady
here
,
"
said
Mrs
MacStinger
,
turning
round
to
the
more
intrepid
of
the
two
<EOS>
,
"
my
bridesmaid
,
that
will
be
glad
of
your
protection
,
Cap'en
Cuttle
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
short
gentleman
in
the
tall
hat
,
who
it
appeared
was
the
husband
of
the
other
lady
,
and
who
evidently
exulted
at
the
reduction
of
a
fellow
-
creature
to
his
own
condition
,
gave
place
at
this
,
and
resigned
the
lady
to
Captain
Cuttle
.
<EOS>
The
lady
immediately
seized
him
,
and
,
observing
that
there
was
no
tome
to
lose
,
gave
the
word
,
in
a
strong
voice
,
to
advance
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
concern
for
his
friend
,
not
unmingled
,
at
first
,
with
some
concern
for
himself
---
for
a
shadowy
terror
that
he
might
be
married
by
violence
,
possessed
him
,
until
his
knowledge
of
the
service
came
to
his
relief
,
and
remembering
the
legal
obligation
of
saying
,
"
I
will
,
"
he
felt
himself
personally
safe
so
long
as
he
resolved
,
if
asked
any

,
distinctly
to
reply
"
I
wo
n't
"
---
threw
him
into
a
profuse

;
and
rendered
him
,
for
a

,
insensible
to
the

of
the

,
of

now
formed
a
feature
,
and
to

conversation
of
his
fair
companion
.
<EOS>
But
as
he
became
less
agitated
,
he
learnt
from
this
lady
that
she
was
the
widow
of
a
Mr
Bokum
,
who
had
held
and
employment
in
the
Custom
House
;
that
she
was
the
dearest
friend
of
Mrs
MacStinger
,
whom
she
considered
a
pattern
for
her
sex
;
that
she
had
often
heard
of
the
Captain
,
and
now
hoped
he
had
repented
of
his
past
life
;
that
she
trusted
<EOS>
Mr
Bunsby
knew
what
a
blessing
he
had
gained
,
but
that
she
feared
men
seldom
did
know
what
such
blessings
were
,
until
they
had
lost
them
;
with
more
to
the
same
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
the
Captain
could
not
but
observe
that
Mrs
Bokum
kept
her
eyes
steadily
on
the
bridegroom
,
and
that
whenever
they
came
near
a

or
other

which
appeared

,
she
was
on

to
cut

if

.
<EOS>
The
other
lady
,
too
,
as
well

her

,
the
short

with
the
tall
hat
,
were
plainly
on
guard
,
according
to
a

;
and
the

man
was
so
secured
by
Mrs
MacStinger
,
that
any
effort
at
self
-
preservation
by
flight
was
rendered
futile
.
<EOS>
This
,
indeed
,
was
apparent
to
the
mere
populace
,
who
expressed
their
perception
of
the
fact
by
jeers
and
cries
;
to
all
of
which
,
the
dread
MacStinger
was
inflexibly
indifferent
,
while
Bunsby
himself
appeared
in
a
state
of
unconsciousness
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
made
many
attempts
to
accost
the
philosopher
,
if
only
in
a
monosyllable
or
a
signal
;
but
always
failed
,
in
consequence
of
the
vigilance
of
the
guard
,
and
the
difficulty
,
at
all
times
peculiar
to
Bunsby
's
constitution
,
of
having
his
attention
aroused
by
any
outward
any

sign
whatever
.
<EOS>
Thus
they
approached
the
chapel
,
a
neat
whitewashed
edifice
,
recently
engaged
by
the
Reverend
Melchisedech
Howler
,
who
had
consented
,
on
very
urgent

,
to
give
the
world
another
two
years
of
existence
,
but
had
informed
his
followers
that
,
then
,
it
must
positively
go
.
  
<EOS>
While
the
Reverend
Melchisedech
was
offering
up
some
extemporary
orisons
,
the
Captain
found
an
opportunity
of
growling
in
the
bridegroom
's
ear
:
  
<EOS>
"
What
cheer
,
my
lad
,
what
cheer
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
To
which
Bunsby
replied
,
with
a
forgetfulness
of
the
Reverend
Melchisedech
,
which
nothing
but
his

could

:
  
"
D
---
d
bad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jack
Bunsby
,
"
whispered
the
Captain
,
"
do
you
do
this
here
,
o
'
your
own
free
will
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

answered
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
do
it
,
then
,
my
lad
?
"
<EOS>
inquired

Captain
,
not
unnaturally
.
  
<EOS>
Bunsby
,
still
looking
,
and
always
looking
with
an

,
at

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
not
sheer
off
?
"

Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
"

,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sheer
off
,
"
said

Captain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
's
the
good
?
<EOS>
"
retorted
the

.
<EOS>
"
She
'd
capter
me
agen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Try
!
"
replied
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
Cheer
up
!
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Now
's

time
.
<EOS>
Sheer

,
Jack
Bunsby
!
"
  
<EOS>
Jack
Bunsby
,
however
,
instead

by

,
said

:
  
"
It
all

that
there
chest
o
'
yourn
.
<EOS>
Why
did
I
ever
conwoy
her
into
port
that

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
"
faltered

,
"
I

you

come

;
nor
as
she
had
come
over
you
.
<EOS>
A
man
as
has
got
such
opinions
as
you
have
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Bunsby
merely
uttered
a
suppressed

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
nudging

,
"
now
's
your

!
<EOS>
Sheer
off
!
<EOS>
I
'll

.
<EOS>
The
time
's
a
flying
.
<EOS>
Bunsby
!
<EOS>
It
's
for
liberty
.
<EOS>
Will
you
once
?
"
  
<EOS>
Bunsby
was
immovable
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bunsby
!
"
whispered
the
Captain
,
"
will
you
twice
?
"
  
<EOS>
Bunsby
would
n't
twice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bunsby
!
"
urged
the
Captain
,
"
it
's
for
liberty
;
will
you
three
times
?
<EOS>
Now
or
never
!
"
  
<EOS>
Bunsby
did
n't
then
,
and
did
n't
ever
;
for
Mrs
MacStinger
immediately
afterwards
married
him
.
  
<EOS>
One
of
the
most
frightful
circumstances
of
the
ceremony
to
the
Captain
,
was
the
deadly
interest
exhibited
therein
by
Juliana
MacStinger
;
and
the
fatal
concentration
of
her
faculties
,
with
which
that
promising
child
,
already
the
image
of
her
parent
,
observed
the
whole
proceedings
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
saw
in
this
a
succession
of
man
-
traps
stretching
out
infinitely
;
a
series
of
ages
of
oppression
and
coercion
,
through
which
the
seafaring
line
was
doomed
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
more
memorable
sight
than
the
unflinching
steadiness
of
Mrs
Bokum
and
the
other
lady
,
the
exultation
of
the
short
gentleman
in
the
tall
hat
,
or
even
the
fell
inflexibility
of
Mrs
MacStinger
.
<EOS>
The
Master
MacStingers
understood
little
of
what
was
going
on
,
and
cared
less
;
being
chiefly
engaged
,
during
the
ceremony
,
in
treading
on
one
another
's
half
-
boots
;
but
the
contrast
afforded
by
those
wretched
infants
only
set
off
and
adorned
the
precocious
woman
in
Juliana
.
<EOS>
Another
year
or
two
,
the
Captain
thought
,
and
to
lodge
where
that
child
was
,
would
be
destruction
.
  
<EOS>
The
ceremony
was
concluded
by
a
general
spring
of
the
young
family
on
Mr
Bunsby
,
whom
they
hailed
by
the
endearing
name
of
father
,
and
from
whom
they
solicited
half
-
pence
.
<EOS>
These
gushes
of
affection
over
,
the

was
about
to
issue
forth
again
,
when
it
was

some

by
an
unexpected

on
the
part
of
Alexander
MacStinger
.
<EOS>
That
dear
child
,
it
seemed
,
connecting
a
chapel
with

,
when
it
was
entered
for
any
purpose
apart
from
the
ordinary

,
could

persuaded
but
that
his
mother
was
now
to

,
and
lost

for

.
<EOS>
In
the
anguish
of
this

,
he
screamed
with

,
and
turned
black
in

.
<EOS>
However

these
marks
of
a

were
to
his
mother
,
it
was
not
in

.
<EOS>
Therefore

,

,

,

;

,

seeing

in

,

<EOS>
The

being

from

,

by

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

;

<EOS>
The

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
To

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
So

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
They

<EOS>
Florence

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
61
.
<EOS>
Relenting
 
FLORENCE
had
need
of
help
.
<EOS>
Her
father
's
need
of
it
was
sore
,
and
made
the
aid
of
her
old
friend
invaluable
.
<EOS>
Death
stood
at
his
pillow
.
<EOS>
A
shade
,
already
,
of
what
he
had
been
,
shattered
in
mind
,
and
perilously
sick
in
body
,
he
laid
his
weary
head
down
on
the
bed
his
daughter
's
hands
prepared
for
him
,
and
had
never
raised
it
since
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
always
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
knew
her
,
generally
;
though
,
in
the
wandering
of
his
brain
,
he
often
confused
the
circumstances
under
which
he
spoke
to
her
.
<EOS>
Thus
he
would
address
her
,
sometimes
,
as
if
his
boy
were
newly
dead
;
and
would
tell
her
,
that
although
he
had
said
nothing
of
her
ministering
at
the
little
bedside
,
yet
he
had
seen
it
---
he
had
seen
it
;
and
then
would
hide
his
face
and
sob
,
and
put
out
his
worn
hand
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
would
ask
her
for
herself
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Florence
?
"
<EOS>
"
I
am
here
,
Papa
,
I
am
here
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
her
!
"
<EOS>
he
would
cry
"
We
have
been
parted
so
long
,
that
I
do
n't
know
her
!
"
<EOS>
and
and
then
a
staring
dread
would
be
upon
him
,
until
she
could
soothe
his
perturbation
;
and
recall
the
tears
she
tried
so
hard
,
at
other
times
,
to
dry
.
  
<EOS>
He
rambled
through
the
scenes
of
his
old

---
through
many
where
Florence
lost
him
as
she
listened
---
sometimes
for
hours
.
<EOS>
He
would
repeat
that
childish
question
,
"
<EOS>
What
is
money
?
"
and
ponder
on
it
,
and
think
about
it
,
and
reason
with
himself
,
more
or
less
connectedly
,
for
a
good
answer
;
as
if

had
never
been
proposed

until
that
moment
.
<EOS>
He
would
go
on
with
a
musing

of
the
title
of
his
old
firm
twenty
thousand
times
,
and
at
every
one
of
them
,
would
turn
his
head
upon
his
pillow
.
<EOS>
He
would
count
his
children
---
one
---
two
---
stop
,
and
go
back
,
and
begin
again
in
the
same
way
.
  
<EOS>
But
this
was
when
his
mind
was
in
its
most
distracted

.
<EOS>
In
all
the
other

of
its
illness
,
and
in

which
it
was
most
constant
,
it
always
turned
on
Florence
.
<EOS>
What
he
would
oftenest
do
was
this
<EOS>
:
he
would
recall
that
night
<EOS>
he
had
so
recently

,
the
night

she
came
down

his

,
and
would

,
and

,
and
up

.
<EOS>
Then
,

that
time
with
the
later
days
of
the
many
footsteps
,
he
would
be
amazed

their

,
and
begin

.
<EOS>
Here
,

going

;
and

be
,

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Still

Florence
.
<EOS>
Still
she
was
going
on
before
.
<EOS>
Still

restless

went
,
following
and

,
ever

,
ever

,
as
to
the

of

that
it

.
  
<EOS>
One
day
he
inquired
if
that
were
not
Susan
who
had
spoken

ago
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
said
"
Yes
,
dear
Papa
;
"
and

?
  
<EOS>
He

"
very
much
.
"
<EOS>
And
Susan
,
with

,
showed

.
  
<EOS>
It
seemed

.
<EOS>
He
begged

;
to

;

.
<EOS>
Florence
and

were
very
different

,

,

.
<EOS>
Let

!
<EOS>
He
meant
his
drawing
gentle

down

his

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It
was
natural

should
.
<EOS>
To

,

nothing

.
  
<EOS>
He
began

show

Florence

:

,

Go

,
<EOS>
my

,

,
Go

!
"
<EOS>
One

Walter

.

It

<EOS>
He
listening
,

.
  
<EOS>
Florence

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
It

,

light
to

;

.
<EOS>
She

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

,
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
She

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
Nothing
has

.
<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
put

;

father
to

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Florence

Feenix
,

.
<EOS>
Cousin
Feenix

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
could
have
wished
,
I

,
"
said
Cousin
Feenix
,
sitting
down
as
Florence
sat
,
"
to
have
had
an
earlier
opportunity
of
offering
my
congratulations
;
but
,
in
point
of
fact
,
so
many
painful
occurrences
have
happened
,
treading
,
as
a
man
may
say
,
on
one
another
's
heels
,
that
I
have
been
in
a
devil
of
a
state
myself
,
and
perfectly
unfit
for
every
description
of
society
.
<EOS>
The
only
description
of
society
I
have
kept
,
has
been
my
own
;
and
it
certainly
is
anything
but
flattering
to
a
man
's
good
opinion
of
his
own
resources
,
to
know
that
,
in
point
of
fact
,
he
has
the
capacity
of
boring
himself
to
a
perfectly
unlimited

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
divined
,
from
some
indefinable
constraint
and
anxiety
in
this
gentleman
's
manner
---
which
was
always
a
gentleman
's
,
in

---

that

to
some

was
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
mentioning

Gay

"

Feenix
,
"

I

Dombey

.
<EOS>
I

Dombey

,

.
<EOS>
I

never

.
<EOS>
But

;

do

.
<EOS>
I
know
my
friend
Dombey
to
be
a

honourable
man
;
and
it
's

to
console
my
friend
Dombey
very
much
,
to
know
,
that
this
is
the
universal

.
<EOS>
Even
Tommy
Screwzer
,
---
a

,

my
friend
Gay
is
probably

---
can
not

in
disputation

the
fact
.
"
  
<EOS>
Florence
felt
,
more

,
that

something
to

;
and

for

.
<EOS>
So

,
that
Cousin
Feenix
answered
,
as

had

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

,
"
said
Cousin
Feenix
,
"

my

Gay

my

Gay
---

.
<EOS>
I

friend
Dombey
,
will

;
but

,
that

's

.
<EOS>
As

,

---

the

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Though

,

.
<EOS>

Brown

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
"

"

<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

Yes
.
"
  
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Only

.
<EOS>
Though

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
  
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

,

and

not
but

what
the

,
that
had

.
<EOS>
She

not

;
for

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
leave
,
"
said
Cousin
Feenix
,
"
a
card
for
my
friend
Dombey
,
sincerely

that
he
will
pick

.
<EOS>
And
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
My

,

,

,

---
<EOS>
as

,

.
<EOS>
If

,
and

,

a
man
who
has
been

,

lived

in

<EOS>
,

,

in
point

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Jackson
,

---

,

my

.
<EOS>
I

,

which
might

---
in

---

"
  
<EOS>
Of

,

.
<EOS>
Then

,

.
  
<EOS>
Walter
entered

,
and
they
drove
away
.
  
<EOS>
Their
ride
was
six
or
eight

long
.
<EOS>
When

through
certain

,
lying

in
London
,
it
was

.
<EOS>
Florence
had
,
by

,
put
her

in

's
;
and
was
looking
very

,

,
into

.
  
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

's

,

,
"
Walter
,

?
<EOS>
Who
is
here
?
"
<EOS>
Walter
cheering
her
,
and

the
house
-
front
,
and
saw
that
all

as

.
<EOS>
Cousin
Feenix
had
by

,
and
was

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are

not

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
will

.
<EOS>
Do
n't

!
<EOS>
there
is
nothing
to
fear
,
dearest
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know

,
Walter
,
with

.
<EOS>
I
am
sure

that
,
but
"
  
The

,
without

,
and
Cousin
Feenix
led

of

summer

.
<EOS>
More

than

,

seemed
to
have

from
the

-

,
and
to

and

ever

.
  
<EOS>
Florence
ascended
the
dusky

,
trembling
;
and
stopped
,
with
her
conductor
,
at
the
drawing
-
room

.
<EOS>
He
opened
it
,
without
speaking
,
and
signed
an
entreaty
to
her
to
advance
into
the
inner
room
,
while
he
remained
there
.
<EOS>
Florence
,
after
hesitating
an
instant
,
compiled
.
  
<EOS>
Sitting
by
the
window
at
a
table
,
where
she
seemed
to
have
been
writing
or
drawing
,
was
a
lady
,
whose
head
,
turned
away

,
was

on

.
<EOS>
Florence
advancing
,
doubtfully
,
all
at

stood
still
,
as
if
she
had
lost
the
power
of

.
<EOS>
The
lady
turned
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
Great
Heaven
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
What
is
this
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Florence
,
shrinking
back
as
she
rose
up
and
putting
out
her
hands
to
keep
her
off
.
<EOS>
"
Mama
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
stood
looking
at
each
other
.
<EOS>
Passion
and
pride
had
worn
it
,
but
it
was
the
face
of
Edith
,
and
beautiful
and
stately
yet
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
face
of
Florence
,
and
through
all
the
terrified
avoidance
it
expressed
,
there
was
pity
in
it
,
sorrow
,
a
grateful

memory
.
<EOS>
On
each
face
,
wonder
and
fear
were
painted
vividly
;
each
so
still
and
silent
,
looking
at
the
other
over
the
black
gulf
of
the
irrevocable
past
.
  
<EOS>
Florence
was
the
first
to
change
.
<EOS>
Bursting
into
tears
,
she
said
from
her
full
heart
,
"
Oh
,
Mama
,
Mama
!
<EOS>
why
do
we
meet
like
this
?
<EOS>
Why
were
you
ever
kind
to
me
when
there
was
no
one
else
,
that
we
should
meet
like
this
?
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
stood
before
her
,
dumb
and
motionless
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
were
fixed
upon
her
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
dare
not
think
of
that
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
I
am
come
from
Papa
's
sick
bed
.
<EOS>
We
are
never
asunder
now
;
we
never
shall
be
,
any
more
.
<EOS>
If
you
would
have
me
ask
his
pardon
,
I
will
do

,
Mama
.
<EOS>
I
am
almost
sure
he
will
grant

now
,
if
I

.
<EOS>
May

to

,

,
and

!
"
  
<EOS>
She
answered
not
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
Walter
---
I
am
married
to
him
,
and
we
have
a
son
,
"
said
Florence
,
timidly
---
<EOS>
"
is
at
the
door
,
and
has
brought
me
here
.
<EOS>
I
will
tell
him
that
you
are
repentant
;
that
you
are
changed
,
"
said
Florence
,
looking

her
;
"
and
he
will
speak
to
Papa
with
me
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
Is
there
anything
but
this
that
I
can
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
Edith
,
breaking
her
silence
,
without
moving
eye
or

,
answered
slowly
:
  
"
The
stain
upon
your
name
,
upon
your
husband
's
,
on
your
child
's
.
<EOS>
Will
that
ever
be
forgiven
,
Florence
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
it
ever
be
,
Mama
?
<EOS>
It
is
!
<EOS>
Freely
,
freely
,
both
by
Walter
an
by
me
.
<EOS>
If
that
is
any
consolation
to
you
,
there
is
nothing
that
you
may
believe
more

.
<EOS>
You
do
not
---
you
do
not
,
"
faltered

,
"
speak
of
Papa
;
but
I
am
sure
you
wish
that
I
should
ask
him
for
his
forgiveness
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
answered
not
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
!
"
said
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
bring
it
you
,
if
you
will
let
me
;
and
then
,
perhaps
,
we
may
take
leave
of
each
other
,
more
like
what
we
used
to
be
to
one
another
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
,
"
said
Florence
very
gently
,
and
drawing
nearer
to
her
,
"
I
have
not
shrunk
back
from
you
,
Mama
,
because
I
fear
you
,
or
because
I
dread
to
be
disgraced
by
you
.
<EOS>
I
only
wish
to
do
my
duty
to
Papa
.
<EOS>
I
am
very
dear
to
him
,
and
he
is
very
dear
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
never
can
forget
that
your
were
very
good
to
me
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
pray
to
Heaven
,
"
cried

,
falling
on

,
"
pray
to
Heaven
,
mama
,
to

you
all
this
sin

,
and
to

if
I
can
not
help
doing
this
(
if
it
is
wrong
)
,
when
I
remember
what
you
used
to
be
!
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
,
as
if
she
fell
beneath
her
touch
,
sunk
down
on
her
knees
,
and
caught
her
round

neck
.
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
better
angel
!
<EOS>
Before
I
am
mad
again
,
before
my
stubbornness
comes
back
and
strikes
me
dumb
,
believe
me
,
upon
my
soul
I
am
innocent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mama
!
"
  
"
Guilty
of
much
!
<EOS>
Guilty
of
that
which
sets
a
waste
between
us
evermore
.
<EOS>
Guilty
of
what
must
separate
me
,
through
the
whole

of
my
life
,
from
purity
and

---
from

,
of
all

.
<EOS>
Guilty
of
a
blind

,
of
which
I
do
not
,
can

,
will

,
even

,
repent
;
but
not
guilty
with
that
dead
man
.
<EOS>
Before
God
!
"
  
<EOS>
Upon
her
knees
upon
the
ground
,
she
held
up
both
her
hands
,
and
swore
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Florence
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
purest
and
best
of
natures
,
---
whom
I
love
---
who
might
have
changed
me
long
ago
,
and
did
for
a
time
work
some
change
even
in
the
woman
that
I
am
,
---
believe
me
,
I
am
innocent
of
that
;
and
once
more
,
on
my
desolate
heart
,
let
me
lay
this
dear
head
,
for
the
last
time
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
moved
and
weeping
.
<EOS>
Had
she
been
oftener
thus
in
older
days
,
she
had
been

now
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
else

,
"
she
said
,
"
that
would
have
wrung

from
me
.
<EOS>
No

,
no

,
no

,
no

.
<EOS>
I
said
that
I
would
die
,
and
make

.
<EOS>
I
could
have
done
so
,
and
I
would
,
if
we
had
never
met
,
Florence
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
trust
,
"
said
Cousin
Feenix
,
ambling
in
at
the
door
,
and
speaking
,
half
in
the
room
,
and
half
out
of
it
,
"
that
my
lovely
and
accomplished
relative
will
excuse
my
having
,
by
a
little

,

this

.
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
that
I
was
,
at
first
,
wholly

as

the

of
my
lovely

accomplished
relative
having

,
committed

with
the
deceased
person
with

;
because
,
in
point

,
one
does
see
,
in
this
world
---
which
is

for

,
and
for

decidedly
the
most
unintelligible
thing
within
a
man
's

---
very
odd

of
that

.
<EOS>
But
as
I
mentioned
to
my
friend
Dombey
,
I
could
not

the

of
my
lovely
and
accomplished
relative
until
it
was

.
<EOS>
And
feeling
,
when
the
deceased

was
,
in
point

,
destroyed
in
a
devilish
horrible

,
that
her
position
was
a

---
and
feeling

that
our

had
been
a
little
to

in
not

more

to
her
,
and
that
we
are
a

---
and
also
that
my
aunt
,
though
a
devilish
lively
woman
,
had
perhaps
not
been
the
very
best
of
mothers
<EOS>
---
I
took
the
liberty
of
seeking
her
in
France
,
and
offering
her
such
protection
as
a
man
very
much
out

elbows
could
offer
.
<EOS>
Upon
which

,
my
lovely
and
accomplished
relative
did
me

to
express
that
she
believed
I
was
,
in
my
way
,
a
devilish
good
sort
of
fellow
;
and
that
therefore
she
put

under
my

.
<EOS>
Which
in
point

I
understood
to
be

kind

the

of
my
lovely

relative
,
as
I
am
getting
extremely

,
and
have

from
her

.
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
,
who
had

Florence
to

,
made

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

and

relative
,
"
resumed
Cousin
Feenix
,
still

about
at
the

,
"
will
excuse
me
,
if
,
for
her

,
and
my
own
,

of
my

Dombey
,
whose
lovely

daughter
we
so

,
I
complete

.
<EOS>
She
will

that
,

,

have

.
<EOS>
My

,

,

,
that

which
she

.
<EOS>
But
my
lovely

relative
being
a
devilish

,
I
knew
that
she
was
not
,
in
point

,
to

,
and

,
But

her

point

of

for
the
daughter

Dombey
<EOS>
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Therefore
,

,

,
before

,
there

,

,

,

,
I

Gay
---
handsome

,

lovely

---
and

wife
to

.
<EOS>
And
now
,
"
said
Cousin
Feenix
,

,
<EOS>
"
I
do

,

,

,

,

---
but
because

is
wrong
,

right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Cousin
Feenix
's
legs
consented
to
take
him
away
after
this
;
and
leaving

alone

,

.
   
<EOS>
Edith
remained

for
some

,
with
Florence
sitting
close
beside
her
.
<EOS>
Then
she
took
from
her
bosom
a
sealed
paper
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
debated
with
myself
a
long

,
"
she

in

,
"
whether

write
this
at

,
in
case
of
dying
suddenly
or

,
and
feeling
the

it
upon

.
<EOS>
I
have
deliberated
,
ever
since
,
when
and
how
to
destroy
it
.
<EOS>
Take
it
,
Florence
.
<EOS>
The
truth
is
written
in
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
for
Papa
?
"
asked
Florence
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
for
whom
you
will
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
given
to
you
,
and
is
obtained
by
you
.
<EOS>
He
never
could
have
had
it
otherwise
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
they
sat
silent
,
in
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mama
,
"
said
Florence
,
"
he
has
lost
his

;
he
has
been
at
the
point
of
death
;
he
may
not
recover
,
even
now
.
<EOS>
Is
there
any

that
I

say
to

from

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
tell
me
,
"
asked

,
"
that
you

to
him
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
said
Florence
,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
I
am
sorry
that
we
ever
met
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
more
?
"
said
Florence
after

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
,
if

,

I
do

I
have
done
---
not

---
for

do
again
to
-
morrow
,
I
should
do

.
<EOS>
But
if
he
is
a
changed
man
---
"
  
She
stopped
.
<EOS>
There

something
in

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
---
But
that
being
a
changed
man
,
he
knows
,
now
,
it
would
never

.
<EOS>
Tell

I
wish

never
had

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
May

,
"
said

,
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
,
"
she

,
"

that
his
daughter

.
<EOS>
He

not

,
one

,

lesson
,
Florence
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
wish

to
him
,
and
would

him

.
<EOS>
I
am
sure

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
let
me
be
able
,

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
Edith
sat
with

,

did

until
Florence
had

and

,

:
  
"
Tell

that
if
,

,
he

to
compassionate
my
past
,
I
sent

that
I

to

.
<EOS>
Tell
him
that
if
,
in
his
own
present
,
he
can

to
think
less

of
me
,
I

to
do

.
<EOS>
Tell
him
,
that
,
dead

we
are
to

,
never

this

,
he
knows
there
is
one
feeling
in
common
between

now
,
that
there
never
was
before
.
"
  
<EOS>
Her
sternness
seemed
to
yield
,
and
there
were
tears
in
her
dark

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
trust
myself
to
that
,
"
she
said
,
"
for
his
better
thoughts
of
me
,
and
mine
of
him
.
<EOS>
When
he
loves
his
Florence
most
,
he
will
hate
me
least
.
<EOS>
When
he
is
most
proud
and
happy
in
her
and
her
children
,
he
will
be
most
repentant
of
his
own
part
in
the
dark

of
our
married
life
.
<EOS>
At
that
time
,
I
will
be
repentant
too
---
let
him
know
it
then
---
and
think
that
when
I
thought
so
much
of
all

that
had
made

what
I
was
,
I
needed
to
have
allowed
more
for
the
causes
that
had
made
him
what
he
was
.
<EOS>
I
will
try
,
then
,
to
forgive
him
his
share
of
blame
.
<EOS>
Let
him
try
to
forgive
me
mine
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Mama
!
"
said
Florence
.
<EOS>
"
How
it
lightens
my
heart
,
even
in
such
a
meeting
and
parting
,
to
hear
this
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Strange
words
in
my
own
ears
,
"
said
Edith
,
"
and
foreign
to
the
sound
of
my
own
voice
!
<EOS>
But
even
if
I
had
been
the
wretched
creature
I
have
given
him
occasion
to
believe
me
,
I
think
I
could
have
said
them
still
,
hearing
that
you
and
he
were
very
dear
to
one
another
.
<EOS>
Let
him
,
when
you
are
dearest
,
ever

that
he
is
most
forbearing
in
his
thoughts
of
me
---
that
I
am
most
forbearing
in
my
thoughts
of
him
!
<EOS>
Those
are
the
last

I
send
him
!
<EOS>
Now
,
good
-
bye
,
my
life
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
clasped
her
in
her

,
and
seemed
to

all
her
woman
's

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
This
kiss
for
your
child
!
<EOS>
These

for
a

on
your

!
<EOS>
My
own
dear
Florence
,
my
sweet
girl
,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
meet
again
!
"
<EOS>
cried

.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
again
!
<EOS>
Never
again
!
<EOS>
When

in
this

,
think

you

left

in

.
<EOS>
Remember

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
And

left
her
,
seeing
her

no

,
but

by

.
  
<EOS>
Cousin

met

at

Walter

:
upon

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
"
    
Chapter
62
.
<EOS>
Final
 
A
BOTTLE
that
has
been
long
excluded
from
the
light
of
day
,
and
is
hoary
with
dust
and

,
has
been
brought
into
the
sunshine
;
and
the
golden
wine
within
it
sheds
a
lustre
on
the
table
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
the
last
bottle
of
the
old
Madeira
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
right
,
Mr
Gills
,
"
says
Mr
Dombey
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
very
rare

most

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
,
who
is
of
the
party
,
beams
with
joy
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
very

of

round

.
  
<EOS>
"
We

,

"

,
"
Ned

,
<EOS>
I

---
"

.
  
"
---

,

"

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
The

;

<EOS>
Other

grows

,
as
the
old
Madeira
did
in

;
and
dust
and

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dombey
is
a
white
-
haired
gentleman
,
whose
face
bears
heavy
marks
of
care
and
suffering
;
but
they
are
traces
of
a
storm
that
has
passed
on
for
ever
,
and
left
a
clear
evening
in
its
track
.
  
<EOS>
Ambitious
projects
trouble
him
no
more
.
<EOS>
His
only
pride
is
in
his
daughter
and
her
husband
.
<EOS>
He
has
a
silent
,
thoughtful
,
quiet
manner
,
and
is
always
with
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
Miss
Tox
is
not

of
the
family
party
,
and
is
quite
devoted
to
it
,
and
a

.
<EOS>
Her

of
her
once

is
,
and
has

ever
since
the
morning
of
her
shock
in
Princess
's

,

,
but
not

.
  
<EOS>
Nothing

from

,
but

sum
that

he

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

old
House
.
  
<EOS>
That

,
a

no

,

,
and
to
the

of
the

.
<EOS>
He

his
old
chief
sometimes
,

.
<EOS>
There

's

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
Walter

---

---
and

for

Piano
-

,

Blacksmiths
.
  
<EOS>
And
how
goes
the
Wooden
Midshipman
in
these
changed
days
?
<EOS>
Why
,
here
he
still
is
,
right
leg

,
hard

upon

,
and
more

,

;
and

,

,

shine

,
GILLS
AND
CUTTLE
.
  
<EOS>
Not

does

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

's

;

.
<EOS>
The

's

,

visage
has
expressed
the
most
contented

,
"
what
an
observant
woman
my
wife
is!What
sagacity
she
possesses
!
<EOS>
What
remarks
she
makes
!
<EOS>
It

only
last

,
when

of

---
which

,

---
that

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
"

"
he

,

-

that

with

bride
"
---
as

,
Mr
Sols
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
true
,
"

old
Instrument

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
"
Here
he
is
,
"

,
"
released

;
appointed

the
same

;
showing

;

;
beloved

"
---
which

,
Mr
Sols
?
<EOS>
My
wife
is
always

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
yes
,
yes
---
some

,

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Small

,
Mr
Toots
,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Exactly

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
"
Here

is
,
"

,
"
so

,
---
and

?
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Now

,
Captain
Gills
,

Mr
Sols
,

.

"

;
"

"

"

"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Toots
,
with

his

---
which

devote

,

to

of
his
wife
's

that
the
Captain
,

,

:
  
"
<EOS>
Sol
Gills
,
you

ould

,

?

Was

,

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Was

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
Ned
,
"

-

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
I
'll

Lovely
Peg
right

;
and

,
both

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
Buried
wine
grows
older
,
as
the
old
Madeira
did
,
in
its
time
;
and
dust
and
cobwebs
thicken
on
the
bottles
.
  
<EOS>
Autumn
days
are
shining
,
and
on
the
sea
-
beach
there
are
often
a
young
lady
,
and
a
white
-
haired
gentleman
.
<EOS>
With
them
,
or
near
them
,
are
two
children
:
boy
and
girl
.
<EOS>
And
an
old
dog
is
generally
in
their
company
.
  
<EOS>
The
white
-
haired
gentleman
walks
with
the
little
boy
,
talks
with
him
,
helps
him
in
his
play
,
attends
upon
him
,
watches
him
,
as
if
he
were
the
object
of
his
life
.
<EOS>
If
he
be
thoughtful
,
the
white
-
haired
gentleman
is
thoughtful
too
;
and
sometimes
when
the
child
is
sitting
by
his
side
,
and
looks
up
in
his
face
,
asking
him
questions
,
he
takes
the
tiny
hand
in
his
,
and
holding
it
,
forgets
to
answer
.
<EOS>
Then
the
child
says
:
  
"
<EOS>
What
,
grandpapa
!
<EOS>
Am
I
so
like
my
poor
little
uncle
again
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Paul
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
weak
,
and
you
are
very
strong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
I
am
very
strong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
he
lay
on
a
little
bed
beside
the
sea
,
and
you
can
run
about
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
so
they
range
away
again
,
busily
,
for
the
white
-
haired
gentleman
likes
best
to
see
the
child
free
and
stirring
;
and
as
they
go
about
together
,
the
story
of
the
bond
between
them
goes
about
,
and
follows
them
.
  
<EOS>
But
no
one
,
except
Florence
,
knows
the
measure
of
the
white
-
haired
gentleman
's
affection
for
the
girl
.
<EOS>
That
story
never
goes
about
.
<EOS>
The
child
herself
almost
wonders
at
a
certain
secrecy
he
keeps
in
it
.
<EOS>
He
hoards
her
in
his
heart
.
<EOS>
He
can
not
bear
to
see
a
cloud
upon
her
face
.
<EOS>
He
can
not
bear
to
see
her
sit
apart
.
<EOS>
He
fancies
that
she
feels
a
slight
,
when
there
is
none
.
<EOS>
He
steals
away
to
look
at
her
,
in
her
sleep
.
<EOS>
It
pleases
him
to
have
her
come
,
and
wake
him
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
He
is
fondest
of
her
and
most
loving
to
her
,
when
there
is
no
creature
by
.
<EOS>
The
child
says
then
,
sometimes
:
  
"
Dear
grandpapa
,
why
do
you
cry
when
you
kiss
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
only
answers
,
"
Little
Florence
!
<EOS>
Little
Florence
!
"
<EOS>
and
smooths
away
the
curls
that
shade
her
earnest
eyes
.
